title: Sheepshead Bay Handicap Split Into 2 Sections Today.
description: The Sheepshead Bay Handi cap for fillies and mares heads today's program at Aqueduct and the 14th running of the stakes again is a popular one with owners and trainers. So many (20) have been named for the 13/16mile turf event that it has been split into two di visions for the third time in its relatively short history.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Raymond M. G. Boucher, president of Wave Energy Systems, Inc., New York, was awarded a patent this week for a method of decontaminating water with a combination of ultraviolet and ultrasonic energy. In a broad sense, light and sound are used together.

title: WALTER H. ZULCH
description: LATTINGTOWN, L. I.., June 30Walter H. Zulch, a retired vice president of the interna tional banking division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Mrs. Genesta M. Strong Dead; ExState Legislator From L.I.
description: PLANDOME HEIGHTS, L. I., June 30 Mrs. Genesta M. Strong, a former State Senator and Assemblyman, died last evening at her home, 27 Chester Drive. She was 86 years old.

title: 4 Commodities Exchanges To Be Closed on Monday
description: Four commodities exchanges in this country will be closed Monday, thus giving traders and staff members a fourday holiday for Independence Day.

title: 20% SOCIAL SECURITY RISE IS VOTED BY BOTH HOUSES; NIXON APPROVAL IN DOUBT
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Congress voted a 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits tonight after days of electionyear maneuvering.

title: MISS ENGLEHORN KEEPS SHOT LEAD
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 30Shirley Englehorn clung to the lead in the United States Women's Open golf champion ship today after a lightning and thunderstorm delayed play for an hour 35 minutes and then caused it to be halted because of darkness.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Fourday weekends have become something of a rar ity ever since Congress sanc tioned placing four national holidays on the Monday clos est to hand. However, Inde pendence Day, which falls on Tuesday this time around, provides for many a four day minivacation.

title: 2 MODIGLIANIS SET AUCTION RECORDS
description: LONDON, June 30London's two leading, art auction houses realized more than $10.5million from sales this week, including a record price for a painting and a sculpture by Modigliani.

title: U.S. Court Rejects Mandatory Chapel At Service Schools
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co lumbia ruled today, 2 to 1, that compulsory chapel attendance at the United States military academies was an unconstitu tional violation of the First Amendment's guarantee of free dom of religion.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN HOG FUTURES
description: Farm products futures prices rose again yesterday in the aftermath of the announcement of imposition of Government controls on certain farm prod ucts at the wholesale and retail levels. No controls will be placed on prices received by farmers directly, however.

title: Dealings Are Hectic
description: Foreign  exchange markets here closed one of their most hectic weeks of recent years yesterday as the floating Brit ish pound continued a steady decline to close at a spot rate of $2.4450.

title: Pilic, Newcombe, Drysdale Advance in Holton Tennis
description: ST. LOUIS, June. 30 (AP) Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia won both tiebreakers and edged Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 76, 76, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Holton tennis tourna ment today. The unseeded Pilic won both tiebreakers from the fourthseeded Okker, 86.

title: Rome Ending Its NoFare Test; Commuter Bus Tickets Planned
description: ROME, June 30 This city ends tomorrow a freeride ex periment on its bus and street car network that attracted in ternational attention as an unu sual attempt to relieve traffic congestion.

title: Peace in the Hospitals?
description: The activities of a state compulsory arbitration panel have brought an expensive but precarious peace to the city's voluntary hospitals. By giving first  year wage increases of 7.5 to 9 per cent to 33,000 workers, the panel did succeed in averting an immediate showdown in the dispute it was appointed to resolve.

title: 12 NATIONS PLAN BIOLOGY INSTITUTE
description: GENEVA, June 30Represen tatives from 12 countries voted approval today of an interna tional institute whose primary task would be to develop new, highly sophisticated techniques for prolling the molecular basis of life processes.

title: Mets Down Expos, 7 to 3, on 4Run First
description: MONTREAL, June 30The New York Mets, with three scoreless innings of relief by Dan Frisella, opened a five game series tonight in Jarry Park, by beating the Expos, 73.

title: U.N. Diplomats Draw Criticism of U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30  The United States, sounding like a host with dif ficult guests, has begun to com plain openly that some diplo mats use too much taxfree li quor and tobacco, neglect to pay their bills and park their cars where they shouldn't.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: In an atmosphere of controversy, the executive com mittee of the United States Auto Club will hold a special meeting this melting in Indianapolis to decide what to do about the Schaefer 500 race, which was to have been run tomorrow.

title: Du Pont Aide in A.E.C. Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Frank E. Kruesi, an official of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., was named today to the post of director of the Atomic Energy Commission's directorate of regulatory operations. He will assume his new duties to morrow. Mr. Kruesi will suc ceed Lawrence D. Low, acting director singe April, who is retiring after 35 years of Fed eral service.

title: Trust Suit Filed Against Nissan For Alleged Pricing Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Justice Department ac cused the American subsidiary of a Japanese auto company Friday of fixing prices on the sale of Datsun automobiles and trucks in the United States.

title: JOHN H. MEARS, 87, LED INSURANCE FIRM
description: John H. Mears, former chair man of the board of Brown, Crosby & Co., an insurance brokerage concern, died Thurs day in Nassau Hospital, Min eola, L. I., after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 67 Holton Avenue, Garden City, and, in Poquott, L. I., of which community he was the Mayor for 17 years.

title: Business Briefs
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the world's largest bankthe San Franciscobased Bank of America, is thinking seriously about sponsoring a new closedend investment company, according to a senior offi cial of the company.

title: SAIGON BOLSTERS QUANGTRI DRIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, July 1  More South Vietnamese troops were lifted by helicopter into Communist occupied Quangtri Province yesterday as the drive to retake the northernmost part of the country went through its third day.

title: Hoechst Unit Lifts Prices
description: The film division of the American Hoechst Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its prices for rigid polyvinyl chloride film and sheeting by approximately 5 per cent beginning with or ders received Aug. 1.

title: ALLENDE AND FOES BREAK OFF TALKS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 The Opposition Christian Demo cratic party broke off negotia tions today with Chile's left wing Government on how a socialist economy should be established here by legal means.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 30 (AP)Ralph Therio, an 18yearold recent highschool graduate from Torrance, Calif., was selected today as a member of the United States Olympic cycling team.

title: Germany's Olympic Chief Denies Hunter Is Barred
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 30 (UPI)The president of the Olympic Organizing Com mittee said today his group had not barred an American convict from the Olympic boxing tour nament.

title: Suspect Pleads Guilty
description: RENO, Nev., June 30 (UPI)  Robb D. Heady pleaded guilty today to a Federal air piracy charge stemming from the hijacking of a United Air Lines jet from the Reno Air port earlier this month.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx County Democratic lead er, was reelected yesterday by a 56to2 vote with six absten tions, the Bronx Democratic organization said. The election took place in the organization's headquarters at 2488 Grand Concourse.

title: F.D.A. Proposes a Ban On Mercury in Cosmetics
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Citing a human health haz ard, the Food and Drug Admin istration proposed today a ban on most uses of mercury in cosmetics.

title: Panel Denies Convention Seats to 59 Daley Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Mayor Richard J. Daley and 58 other Chicago delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion lost their seats tonight as a result of a fiercely debated decision by the convention's Credentials Committee.

title: Chess World Argues Fischer's Actions
description: Bobby Fischer's erratic pos ture toward the world chess championship has touched off a wave of debate and discus sion in New York and Moscow as well as Reykjavik, Iceland, where his match with the de fending Soviet champion, Boris Spassky, is scheduled to open tomorrow.

title: Reserve Officers Fill Post
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 30 (UPI) Gen. Robert D. Upp of the United States Army Reserve was elected today president of the 70,000member Reserve Of ficers Association at the con clusion of their 50th annual convention. General Upp, a Los Angeles lawyer, is a veteran of World War II and has been a member of the Army Reserve for 35 years.

title: The Talk of Rawalpindi
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 27By midmorning the temperature has usually punched far past the 100 degree mark, the cows re fuse to budge from under the shade trees, the iceman has become everyone's friend and Mohammed Rafique has changed hands below his resting chin two or three times but has not otherwise moved. Mr. Rafique runs a small openfront jewelry shop in the gold and silver bazaar here, but in the baking sum mer months it is almost a form of unemployment. So while his helper snoozes on the floor in the back, Mr. Rafique stares out at the slowmotion parade of other people's customers ever ready to offer tea and philosophy to anyone who might care to drop in.

title: Second Michigan Suspect Held In $502,000 Hijacking of Jet
description: DETROIT, June 30Federal agents arrested today a second Detroit area man, Walter John Petlikowsky, 31 years old, and charged him with helping plot the hijacking of an American Airlines jet last week.

title: On the Edge of BedfordStuyvesant, Emotional Help for Teenagers
description: The rap session was almost over by the time Maria Her nandez got there. But it didn't make any difference  the way things had been going the 14yearold girl would have been hard pressed to make herself heard.

title: Film: Idiosyncratic 'Duck, You Sucker':Leone's New Western Is Set in Mexico
description: A thoughtful person may make a thoughtful analysis of "Duck, You Sucker," Sergio Leone's newest, most awkwardly titled Western, but I doubt that it could be even as provocative assaya thoughtful analysis of the work of Herman Wouk.All of Leone's idiosyncrasies are apparent in this tale set in Mexico during the revolution, especially his romantic attachment for macho heroes who are either greedy or disillusioned, and sometimes both. "Duck, You Sucker" is a practical guide to Leone's various affectionsfor explicit violence, for bizarre historical detail (a stagecoach that is as big and plush as a railroad car), for excruciatingly tight close-ups (which make you feel as if you're looking at the film through a venetian blind), and for cryptic narrative twists that suddenly shoot the story forward, only to be laboriously explained at some later point.The idiosyncrasies are there, all right, but they have never seemed less interesting.Leone, whose early films ("A Fistful of Dollars," "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly," among others) were condemned (unjustly, I think) for their extraordinary nihilism, is going soft. The end effect of this long, rambling film is one of awful over-stuffedness. Like a chi-chi set designer's dream of what a turn-of-the-century whorehouse parlor might have looked like, it contains too many gewgaws and too many knickknacks. In particular, there's too much plot as well as too much acting by Rod Steiger, as a sometimes Yiddish-sounding Mexican bandit, and by James Coburn, as an Irish terrorist who periodically suffers terrible bouts of flashbacks (to his troubles at home), a disease that can be fatal to this kind of movie.One thing about Leone's films does continue to fascinate me. No matter where they're made (usually around Almeria, Spain), no matter who's in them (American stars and European supporting casts), and no matter what language is on the soundtrack (English, mostly dubbed), they always have the strange look and displaced sound of an unmistakably Italian director's dream of what Hollywood movies should be like, but aren't.

title: A Family That Chose to Live Among Thousands of Frogs
description: LONG BRANCH, Tex.John Aderhold is a man who likes to take the bull by the horns, As a result, he and his family spend a good deal of their time taking bullfrogs by the legs.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The resurgence of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's Presidential campaign on the strength of a windfall of California delegates appeared today to be the Work of It neversaydie staff against the candidate's own reserva tions about his chances and fears of further division in the Democratic party.

title: Death Penalty Urged in 5 States; Some Legislators Are Uncertain
description: Legislators or officials in at least five states said yesterday that they intended to press for laws that would retain the death penalty.

title: Widespread Child Labor Persists Throughout Italy
description: ROME, June 30  In Gras sobbio, a small town near Ber gamo in northern Italy, Romeo Longhi was crushed to death recently by a winch while work ing after school for a small construction company. He was 12 years old and earned less than $5 for nearly a 40hour week.

title: Trot Bill Passes First Test
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP)The Massachusetts House gave ini tial approval today, to a bill providing 30 additional days of harness horse racing in the state. The measure would bring the total to 150 days.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: When Angela Davis was acquitted of charges of murder and conspiracy, the relief and jubilation which swept over black Americans were tempered by the realization that acquittal or not, something remains unfocused in the events which brought our sister so close to helplessness in the hands of a state which despises and fears her.

title: QUICK TAX RELIEF ON FLOODS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)The Senate voted today to allow victims of the recent Northeastern and South Dakota floods to take a tax deduction immediately on their losses.

title: HINSON CARDS A 65, LEADS GOLF BY ONE
description: CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP) Larry Hinson posted a 65 today to take the firstround lead in the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament.

title: Conferences in Icelond
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 30 Mr. Davis arrived here this morning and immediately dis appeared into Ai Series of con ferences with officials of the Icelandic Chess Federation and Fred Cramer of Milwaukee, Fischer's representative here. None of the participants was available for comment.

title: STORM KING PLANT BACKED BY COURT
description: Consolidated Edison's long delayed Storm King power plant won another approval yesterday, but conservationists who have been blocking its construction for almost 10 years said they would continue their opposition.

title: Military Hails Outcome Of Army Life Reforms
description: The volunteer army experi ment, the most extensive reform program in the service's history, ended this week on a note of optimism in the Pentagon.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congresamen
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Sometimes I wonder whether any of it is worth it, Repre sentative Otis G. Pike Demo crat of Suffolk County, told the House this week as he began what turned out to be an unsuccessful effort to cut some items pending on the floor from the $21.3billion bill for military weap ons and re search. Despite the $21.3bil lion involved, Mr. Pike went on, you look around the room and essen tially we are talking to our selves.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., June 30 (UPI)The Kentucky Court of Appeals today rejected a motion for a rehearing on the disqualification of Dancer's Image as winner of the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

title: MAJOR COMPANIES PLANNING LAYOFFS
description: Employe layoffs ranging from 140 to 2,000 workers were an nounced by several major cor porations yseterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Brown Singing Blues at Jazz City (Usually Folk City)
description: Coinciding with the opening of the Newport Jazz Festival to day, Folk City, the nightclub on West Third Street just off the Avenue of the Americas, has changed its name to Jazz City and for five weeks, through the end of July, and is concen trating on jazz instead of its usual folk and soft rock pres entations.

title: Sharon Lee Hargan Married To Lieut. Carl Mikel Kruger
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 30Miss Sharon Lee Hargan and Lieut. Carl Mikel Kruger, U.S.A., were married here this evening in the Cadet Chapel by West Point's chap lain, the Rev. James D. Ford, assisted by the Rev. Donald Theobald of Harrison, N. Y. A reception was given in the West Point Officers Club.

title: Education Group Forbids New Merger With Labor
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 After long and often heated de bate, the annual convention of the National Education Asso ciation voted today to bar further mergers such as the recent one in New York State with the American Federation of Teachers.

title: PARIS SET BACK IN BID TO BAR EXECUTIONS
description: PARIS, June 30  President Pompidou, who has in effect abolished capital punishment in France by exercising his right of pardon, is confronted with his two most difficult cases.

title: Roy E. Graves Jr. of A.B.C., Led Research Service Unit
description: TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 30 Roy E. Graves Jr., manager of special research services for the American Broadcasting Com pany television network, died last evening at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 46 years old and lived here.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRINGS, Md., June 30Gov. George C. Wallace will be moved from a hospital in this Washington suburb to a hotel site in Miami next Friday, his aides announced here today.

title: RYUN GAINS FINAL, VON BEN FAILS
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 30  Jim Ryun continued on the road to Munich tonight, but defeat lined the paths of such prominent American track and field competitors as Torn Von Ruden, Juris Luzins and Dr. Delano Meriwether.

title: A DISCLOSURE LAW ON BANKS IS UPSET
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (AP)A Federal judge barred the Government temporarily to day from requiring banks to report and disclose depositors' records under the socalled Bank Secrecy Act pending a ruling on whether the law was constitutional.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOP TALK
description: Now that it looks like prac tically everyone has a clear, seethrough, bubbleshaped umbrella to keep head and shoulders dry, wouldn't you know someone would come along and try to improve on its appearance?

title: Nixon Is Disputed on French P.O.W's
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 President Nixon inadvertently stirred a controversy last night by telling his televised news conference that, when France got out of Vietnam in 1954, 15,000 French were never ac counted for after that.

title: SelfRule for Ovambos
description: For weeks, South Africa has been expected momen tarily to announce its readiness at last to accept a United Nations observer in Namibia (SouthWest Africa), the country Pretoria continues to rule in de fiance of countless U.N. actions. This concession may yet come, but what Pretoria has announced meanwhile is something quite different.

title: Mercado Stops Fernandez In 5th at Sunnyside Garden
description: Rey Mercado, 137 pounds, of Puerto Rico stopped Chris Fernandez, 141, of the Domini can Republic at 51 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled 10round bout at Sunnyside Garden in Queens last night.

title: Strike by Pilots Halts Northwest Flights
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 30 (AP) Northwest Airlines, the na tion's seventh largest air car rier with operations from Bos ton to Hong Kong, was struck by its 1,600 pilots at 2 A.M. today after contract negotia tions that had been going on for 16 months broke down.

title: GORMAN TRIUMPHS ALONG WITH SMITH AND PATTI HOGAN
description: WIMBLEDON, June 30Still scrambling, top  seeded Stan Smith reached the quarterfinals today at Wimbledon; a reformed Patti Hogan upset fifthseeded Kerry Melville to bring eight Americans into the last 16 of the women's singles and in the match of the week the mer curial Tom Gorman of Seattle staved off a matchpoint to beat Jaime Fillol of Chile.

title: Brooklyn Hospital Sues Jersey Man For Care of Child
description: A New Jersey man is being sued by a Brooklyn hospital for $105,642 for the care of his 3yearold son, a victim of Tay Sach's disease, a rare genetic disorder.

title: Roundup: Pepitone in Action, Cubs Win
BHUTTO CONFERS WITH MRS. GANDHI
description: SIMLA, India, June 30  President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan conferred with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India for 40 minutes this evening in what Pakistani sources said were the first talks on substan tive issues that the two leaders have had since their conference began here Wednesday.

title: State Approves Plan for Shoreham Nuclear Plant
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., June 30 The State of New York gave its approval today to the nuclear power generating facility the Long Island Lighting Company proposes build here.

title: U.S. Plans New Raids to Cut All Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 United States military planners are preparing a stepped up bombing effort in an attempt to shut off what they say is the last remaining trickle of mili tary supplies moving into North Vietnam from China.

title: Panama Clears TakeOver For a U.S.Owned Utility
description: PANAMA, June 30The mili tary Government has authorized the acquisition of an American owned utility, the Compania Panamena de Fuerza y Luz, and its expropriation if satisfactory terms and conditions cannot be arranged within 60 days.

title: The Involved
description: Asserting that domestic conditions have deteriorated seriously in the last decade, a former Inspector General of the Office of Economic Opportunity warned the other day that social explosions threaten unless members of the power structure become as involved as the poor in efforts to effect improvements.

title: TV: Harpsichordist Joins Buckley on Firing Line
description: Tomorrow evening at 8, William F. Buckley Jr. puts a harpsichordist on his Firing Line. Recorded in San Fran cisco, this latest installment in the notable and quotable conservative's publictelevi sion series has Fernando Va tenti as guest. Mr. Valenti, Most music critics seem to agree, is one of the world's more accomplished masters of the harpsichord.

title: Nixon Vetoes Bill To Fund Public TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 President Nixon vetoed today a measure providing increased funds for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, arguing that the corporation was exer cising excessive control over independent educational tele vision stations.

title: My father was born thirty years too soon
description: BARBOURSVILLE, W. Va.I am a pensioned railroader. I put in 42 years in overalls on one of America's great railroad systems. Before that I worked in the coal mines, in the timber coun try and in the building trades. I earned my first wages working underground helping to gut this old earth. I bought my first overcoat and overshoes from my mine earnings in August. I had been cold all my life.

title: Congressman Assails Thailand For Keeping Press From Bases
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Representative William S. Moorhead, Democrat of Penn sylvania, sharply criticized the Thailand Government today for refusing to allow American or foreign newsmen to visit air bases used by United States Air Force and Marine Corps air units.

title: Moscow Ordering Campaign to Raise Sugar Production
description: MOSCOW, June 30The So viet Union, evidently concerned over a deteriorating sugar sup ply, today ordered a nation wide campaign to raise sugar production over the next four years.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI, June 30 (AP) George Rodericks, head of the Civil Defense in Washington, predicted today that only about 6,000 nondelegtaes would come here for the Democratic Na tional Convention and not the 50,000 to 100,000 that city officials and protest groups originally forecast.

title: Truck Line Is Censured
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)The Justice Department charged today that T.I.M.E. D.C., a truck line based in Lubbock, Tex., used reciprocal purchasing arrangements with its customers and suppliers in violation of the antitrust laws.

title: Woman In the News
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 30  A teacher who worked closely with Mrs. Catharine O'Connell Barrett while she was president of the New York State Education Asso ciation thinks that the way she ran the meeting tells a lot about her. He recalls one meeting in Albany at which the strongwilled Mrs. Barrett kept board members present until mid night  repeated ly arguing the merits of her position and giving preference to sympa thetic speakers  until she was convinced she had enough support to risk a vote on the motion she fa vored. It passed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS REQUIRE TWO RECOVERIES
description: Beset by injuries, illness, the disappearance of a player and a sudden scoring drought, the New York Cosmos tonight will attempt nevertheless to break the spell the Montreal Olympics have cast over them.

title: Pennsylvania a Disaster Area
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 30 (AP)President Nixon declared all of Pennsylvania a disaster area today because of the ex tent of flood damage through out the state.

title: Business Briefs
description: GARY, Ind., June 30 (AP) The United States Steel Corporation announced plans today for antipollution meas ures at its Gary Works, estimated by company officials and other sources to cost $80million.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First National City Bank and the Mellon National Bank Trust Companyrespectively the largest banks in New York and Pennsylvaniayesterday increased their prime, or minimum, interest rates on business 5 per cent from 5 per cent. Both banks have floating prime rates, geared directly to interest rates in the open market.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOMESTEAD AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., June 30 (AP)  A city of olivedrab tents capable of housing, feeding and equip ping at least one Army bat talion has sprouted 25 miles from the site of the Democratic and Republican national con ventions.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN HIDING. The Life of Manuel Cortes. By Ronald Fraser. 238 pages. Pantheon Books. $6.95.

title: South Korea Tries to Solve Problems of Fast Growth
description: SEOUL  Having impressed and surprised the world by years of high economic growth, South Korea is now facing days of reckoning for some of the distortions and excesses that accompanied this stillcon tinuing growth.

title: I. R. A. Removes 3 Barricades; Ulster Protestants Erect Others
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 30Three of the barri cades sealing off the Roman Catholic enclaves of Bogside and Creggan in Londonderry were removed today. The ac tion was taken by the militant Provisional wing of the out awed Irish Republican Army, which controls the enclaves.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 30One of Judge Learned Hand's arguments against a broad judicial power to interpret the Constitution was that courts would inevitably divide on such elusive ques tions. In his Holmes Lectures at Har vard in 1958 he said:

title: Mayor Signs Controversial Bill Freezing Rent for Some Elderly
description: Amid charges of unconstitu tionality, Mayor Lindsay signed a law yesterday to both con tinue and expand rentincrease exemptions for more than 100, 000 elderly people in rent controlled apartments.

title: Seoul Fears a U. S. Korean Policy Shift
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 South Korean officials asked the United States yesterday to explain why Secretary of State William P. Rogers broke with precedent on Tuesday and re ferred to North Korea, by the name it calls itselfthe. Demo cratic People's Republic of Korea.

title: Court Bars Bill to Force Papers to Run Political Ads
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP)  Pending legislation that would have forced newspapers to run all political ads has been ruled unconstitutional by the Massa chusetts Supreme Court.

title: News Analysis
description: City School Chancellor Har vey B. Scribner, greeting a visi tor the other day, asked: Are you happy? I'm only seeing happy people today.

title: Peter A. Lewis Marries Mrs. Greenfeld
description: Mrs. Elaine Kessler Green feld, a realestate broker with Pease & Ellinian here, was married yesterday noon to Peter A. Lewis, a general partner of the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres & Co. Rabbi Edward E. Klein performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: Bridge: Poiential Big Point Swing Failed to Develop in Final
description: The biggest swing of the. World Team Olympiad final last week between Italy and the United States was one that did not quite happen. Officials were considering using a computer to decide the score, or at any rate an adding machine to tally the points, but developments made it unnecessary and the swing turned out to be trivial.

title: Antiques: New York Patriot's Silver
description: With the Fourth of July coming up, New Yorkers should remember they have a counterpart of Paul Revere, Boston's patriot silversmith, in their own Myer Myers.

title: Car Production Drops
description: DETROIT, June 30 (AP)  United States car production was down 31,000 units this week, with the industry beset by model changeovers, strikes and other problems, the trade paper, Automotive News, re ported yesterday.

title: STEAM BLAST LAID TO MANY FACTORS
description: A city investigation into the rupture of a highpressure steam line in a Manhattan office building on May 3 is reported to have listed among the pos sible causes a defective piping system inaccessible to inspec tors, impurities in the steam and variations in the steam pressure.

title: MARKET STAGES A MODEST RALLY
description: The sun finally shone on the stock market yesterday as glamours, drugs and tobacco's led a modest rally.

title: Nebraska Divided on Rodgers
description: You are the coach of the No. 1 college football team in the nation. But you have a problem. Your star player has been sentenced to jail and won't go, What do you do?

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Pound Off About 6%
description: LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) The pound sterling ended its first week of floating today more than 6 per cent below its old parity with the dollar.

title: Belfast Man Fatally Shot
description: BELFAST, Saturday, July 1 (Reuters)A man died in a Protestant area of Belfast early today after being hit by shots fired from a passing car. There was no immediate Information on whether the victim was in volved in the building of Pro testant barricades.

title: Speedy Crown 85 Choice To Capture $50,000 Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 Five of the seven starters in tomorrow night's $50,000 American Trotting Champion ship have negotiated a mile in 2 minutes or faster. In fact, aside from Keystone Hilliard, who had a 2:00 clocking at Vernon Downs last season, all the other four have trotted faster.

title: Personalities: Pills Haunt Ramos
description: The muddled lightweight boxing picture is beginning to take on the overtones of a Mack Sennett comedy. Un til last Wednesday, when Mando Ramos of Los An geles beat Pedro Carrasco of Spain, in Madrid, there only were two claimants to that division's world title. Now, there may be three. Roberto Duran is the World Boxing Association's titleholder as a result of his victory over Ken Buchanan with a dis puted punch in New York last Monday. The World Box ing Council considers Ramos its, king. Or does it?

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: TRW Systems, Inc., a unit of TRW, Inc., has received a $83.6million contract from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to develop two automated highenergy astron omy observatories, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, June 30 (AP)Roberto, John W. Galbreath's 3yearold colt, was favored at 32 against a field of 14 for tomorrow's Irish Derby at The Curragh.

title: Chaban Unhurt in Car Crash
description: PARIS, June 30 (AP)Pre mier Jacques ChabanDelmas escaped uninjured today from a fourcar automobile accident in which three persons were slightly injured. The Premier's car stopped suddenly to avoid an automobile coming from a side street and was hit in the rear by the car carrying his bodyguards. Two other cars also joined in the accident.

title: Rise Shown in Inventories Of Manufacturers for May
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Manufacturers' inventories showed their Jargest increase in May since late 1970, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: 2 Dead in Motorcycle Gang Shootout in Carolina
description: DURHAM, N. C., June 30 (UPI)Six persons were shot tonight, two of them fatally, during a shootout between, rival motorcycle gangs on Inter state 85.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Senator George McGovern was assured here today by the pres ident of the International Union of Electrical Workers of an all out effort to turn President Nixon out of the White House.

title: Eastman Dillon and Blyth Agree to a Merger Plan
description: Blyth & Co. and Eastman Dillon, Union securities & Co., two of the nation's leading in vestment houses, disclosed yes terday that they plan to merge. The new firm would be called Blyth, Eastman Dillon & Co.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Senator George McGovern's strategists asserted today that they had corralled enough votes to insure that the Democratic National Convention would re instate the disputed delegates from California pledged to the South Dakotan.

title: Feminist Party Is Seeking to End Tax Freedom of Catholic Church
description: MINEOLA, L. L., June 30 The Feminist party announced today that it was filing a com plaint with the Internal Rev enue Service demanding the removal of a taxexempt status of the Roman Catholic Church and affiliated organizations, al leging that they violated I.R.S. regulations by engaging in illegal political lobbying and campaign activity in connec tion with abortion legislation.

title: Visitor Describes North Vietnamese Dike as Badly Damaged
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 30The dike at Phuly, a town about 40 miles from Hanoi, has been seriously damaged.

title: Taiwan Elections Scheduled
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 30 (UPI)Nationalist China will hold its first elections to the National Assembly in 25 years early next year, the Govern ment said today.

title: ABORTION BACKERS SEEK TO VOID LAW
description: HARTFORD, June 30The legal battle, over Connecticut's antiabortion law resumed here today with a hearing in the Fed eral District Court that is to rule on the constiutionality of the laws.

title: Strike by 5 Building Trades Unions Expected Here
description: Five major building trades unions here are expected by industry sources to strike next week following a breakdown in negotiations with various trade associations.

title: No Hazard in French Test
description: LONDON, June 30 (AP)A British Air Force team that monitored the French nuclear test in the South Pacific last weekend reported that there was no health hazard from the blast, the Foreign Office said today. France still has not offi cially confirmed the blast, which prompted worldwide protests.

title: Thieu Sees Sign From Foe
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30  President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said today that his Government had agreed to return to the Paris peace talks because there was a sign that the Communist side wants to negotiate seriously.

title: Myopia Four Gains Final, Downing Meadow Brook
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., June 30 Adam Winthrop and Mike An drew scored two goals each as the Myopia polo team of Boston scored a 54 triumph over Meadow Brook today to gain the final of the Northeastern 12goal intracircuit tournament at Bethpage State Park.

title: Met and Orchestra Reach 3Year Pact; Scale Goes to $385
description: The Metropolitan Opera and Local 802 of the American Fed eration of Musicians signed a memorandum of agreement yes terday covering the services of the Metropolitan Opera orches tra for the next three years.

title: Japan's Payments Surplus Narrowed Sharply in May
description: TOKYO, June 30 (Reuters) Japan had a surplus of only $22million in her balance of payments for May, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: POLICE ARREST TWO IN BEATINGS OF MAN
description: The police had arrested two men And were searching last night for several others in the case of 35yearold Bronx man Who has said he was beat en en four separate occasions in the last monthonce by four men impersonating policemen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MOTORS SEEKS PRICE RISE
description: DETROIT, June 30  The American Motors Corporation asked the Price Commission to day for price increases from $140 to $150 on 1973 cars, or more than 5 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ENEMY INDICATES ASSENT ON TALKS, BUT STANDS FIRM
description: PARIS, June 30Both Com munist delegations today indi cated their readiness to return to the Vietnam peace confer ence, whose resumption on July 13 was announced by President Nixon at his news conference last night.

title: Longest Day
description: Yesterday was the longest day. It had 86,401 seconds, not a mere 86,400 like other ordinary, garden variety days. The difference may not seem very great, but to guardians of the world's time that extra second was enough to justify synchronizing all the national master clocks on all the continents so that the extra second would be counted exactly at midnight Greenwich Mean Timewhich was 8 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Pentagon Cuts Meat Buying
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today, that it would re duce its beef purchases by 10 per cent for the next four months to try to push meat prices down throughout the na tion.

title: Yanks Win, 10, on White's Single in 9th
description: The New York Yankees de feated the Cleveland Indians, 10, last night on a twoout single in the ninth inning by Roy Whitewho has heard boo ing lately under the magnify ing glass of baseball.

title: Woman Wrestlers Headline. Program at Garden Tonight
description: Women wrestling for the first time in New York is the main attraction on tonight's ex hibition card at Madison Square Garden. Women had been pro hibited from appearing on a New York mat until last month when the State Athletic Com mission lifted the ban. The scheduled participants are Fab ulous Moolah and Vicki Wil liams.

title: Heavy Holiday Travel Chokes the City's Exits
description: Beckoned by stippled country glades, shimmering beaches and the promise of July sun, hun dreds of thousands of rain weary New Yorkers began the long Fourth of July weekend late yesterday with one of the city's most impressively crush ing mass exoduses.

title: Executive Changes
description: John H. Filer, 47 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Aetna Life & Casualty Company. He succeeds Olcott D. Smith, 65, who has retired.

title: Answers in Labor Disputes
description: Most energy spent on looking for alternatives to the strike is misdirected. Collective bargaining, unlike baseball, is not a national pastime designed to select the winner in a contestit is instead the best available, if imper fect, tool for solving tough problems of plant management.

title: Statute for Newsman Immunity Pushed by Congress Democrats
description: Attempts were made in both houses of Congress yesterday to press for adoption of a Fed eral immunity statute for newsmen after Thursday's decision by the Supreme Court denying journalists the right to refuse to tell grand juries about sources and information given them in confidence.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that brokers must report to customers their financial condition on a quarterly basis. The commission said the rule was aimed at protecting investors from dealing with brokers who are not financially sound.

title: Hospital Union Talks Snagged; Davis Plans a Strike Thursday
description: A new threat of a hospital strike here was raised yester day when city officials found it more difficult than expected to work out an agreement on a hospital union, jurisdictional dispute.

title: OFFERING SLATED IN AVON PRODUCTS
description: Avon Products announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Com mission covering a secondary offering of 1.081,000 shares of capital stock  a block worth more than $114million at yes terday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Selassie Ends Yugoslav Trip
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 30Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia flew home to Addis Ababa today after five days of private talks with President Tito at retreats in the Alps and on the Adriatic Sea.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Norfolk & Western Sets Big WriteOff On Erie Failure
description: The Norfolk and Western Railway announced yesterday that it would write off as ex traordinary charges to income in 1972 approximately $58.5 million as a result of the bank ruptcy of the Erie Lackawanna Railway.

title: Carol Savid Wed to Anson Fyler Jr.
description: CENTERPORT, L. I., June 30Miss Carol Ann Savid and Anson Charles Fyler Jr. were married here this after noon in an outdoor ceremony performed by Arthur B. Do brin of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island (Ethi cal Culture) at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Savid.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 27:

title: U.S. Reiterates Denial
description: WASHINGTON, June 30A Pentagon spokesman said to day in response to questions about the reported bombing of the Phuly dike that the De fens Department will stand on the statements that we have made in the past and that were made yesterday by the Presi dent.

title: Vietnam Veteran Guilty
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 30 (UPI) Richard F. McCoy Jr., a Vietnam war hero and for mer Sunday School teacher, was found guilty by a Federal court jury late yesterday of air piracy involving $500,000 in ransom.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DENVER, June 30 (AP)The Denver Organizing Com mittee, which is planning the 1976 Winter Olympics, has asked officials of the Lake Placid, N. Y., bobsled run if their facility could be used.

title: It's Newport Jazz Inundating the Town
description: The Newport Jazz Festival, newly transferred to New York, opens today for a nineday stand that will include such unlikely sites as Philharmonic Hall, the streets of Harlem and the Staten Island Ferry. It has produced logistical problems comparable to putting an Army division in the field or a travel ing circus on the rails.

title: L. G. Ross Jr. Weds Mrs. Nancy Espy
description: HUDSON, Ohio, June 30 Mrs. Nancy Parkin Espy was married here this afternoon to Llewellyn Gerard Ross Jr., who is with Procter & Gam ble in Cincinnati. The Rev. Joseph W. Fraccaro per formed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: PRICES ON AMEX REGISTER GAIN
description: After seven sessions marked by declining prices, stocks moved ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The index closed at 27.24, up 0.07, in relatively slow trading be fore the holiday weekend.

title: BIG BOARD WORKING ON S.E.C.'S REQUEST
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was making every effort to comply with the commission's request to adopt new rules on institutional membership by July 31.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Cab Fares Set for Trips to Suburbs

title: Making the Rounds of Photo Shows
description: If you're an insatiable mu seum and galleryhopper and because of the dearth of art activity during the summer, have been unable to satisfy your appetite, you would do well to make a tour of New York: photography shows. Of the several now on view, some are outstanding.

title: SLICK CHICK WINS TITLE IN JUMPOFF
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 30  Jason Parker's Slick Chick won the junior jumper cham pionship in rain and mud after a tense jumpoff against Four Seasons Farm's Cherry Bomb today at the Gaudeamus horse show.

title: I.O.S. Leadership Expects To Settle With Dissidents
description: ST. JOHN, New Brubswick, June 30The new management of I.O.S., Ltd., said today that it expected very soon to an nounce a settlement to end its complex legal dispute with a dissident faction of stockhold ers who used to be centrally involved in running the com pany.

title: QUOTAS REDUCED ON WHALE CATCH
description: LONDON, June 30The In ternational Whaling Commis sion agreed today to reductions varying from 8 to 38 per cent in the 1973 quotas for catches of finback, sei and sperm whales in the North Pacific and Antarctic Oceans.

title: WITNESSES LET GO BY JURY IN TEXAS
description: Two New Yorkers who had been subpoenaed to testify before a Fort Worth grand jury investigating the alleged smug gling of American guns to Northern Ireland for use by the Irish Republican Army returned here yesterday without having testified, but they were told they could be recalled.

title: Brown Extradition Delay
description: BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) H. Rap Brown will not be extradicted to Maryland for trial on arson and riot charges, for a long time, State At torney General Francis B. Burch said today. New York officials, who will prosecute the black militant in connec tion with a shootout with the police last October, have in formed Maryland officials that Brown will not be extradicted before facing the charges there, Mr. Burch said.

title: Rogers Arrives in Jakarta
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 30 (UPI)  William P. Rogers, Secretary of State, arrived here today to discuss with Indo nesian leaders President Nixon's visits to Peking and Moscow.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 30In women's golf, the swing no longer is the thing. Marking your ball is.

title: Must Carthage Be Destroyed?
description: WASHINGTON If there is a cardi nal principle among what we loosely call the laws of war, it is that one antagonist does not have the right to wreak Carthaginian peace upon the other. In Other words, to try to force the enemy to give in by methodically devastating his land, his crops, his people is now regarded as barbaric and deserving of punishment.

title: A.&P. Registers Deficit For First Fiscal Quarter
Comsat Opposes F.C.C. On Lifting Satellite Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation asked the Federal Communications Commission today to continue a ban on domestic communications satel lites.

title: Controls Stir Ire
description: BONN, June 30West Ger many's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller, refused today to sign a Government ordinance introducing limited foreignexchange controls that the cabinet agreed upon yes terday against his lone opposi tion.

title: PAY BOARD PLANS GUIDELINE REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, disclosed to day that the board is now ready to review for the first time its basic standard for wage increases of 5.5 per cent. But he gave no hint whether any revision would lead to a higher or lower standard.

title: SONY PROTESTS USE OF ITS TV'S ON BOMBS
description: TOKYO, June 30 (UPI) The Sony Corporation protested today that its products were being used in the Vietnam war without its knowledge.

title: Art: German Documenta
description: KASSEL, West Germany, June 30  The fifth in the series of Documenta exhibi tions, which take place in this city every four years, opened to the public today after several days of pre views for the large number of artists, critics, dealers, collectors and museum offi cials who have gathered here for what has become the the most prestigious  and will this year be the most controversial  of the big in ternational art shows.

title: Milwaukee Road Elects
description: Worthington L. Smith has been named president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad, effective July 15. He succeeds Curtiss E. Crip pen, who was elected vice chair man. Mr. Smith also was elect ed a director of the Milwaukee Road and of the Chicago Mil waukee Corporation, parent of the railroad. Mr. Crippen is scheduled to retire at the end of the year.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 30 (AP)Of the 48 yachts left in the transAtlantic race, none has reportedor been reported further west than Gerard Dijkstra of the Netherlands in the ketch. Second Life. Race officials said, however, that it was possible that British Steel and Strongbow, both of Britain, who have not reported for 24 hours, could be further across.

title: U.N. Reports Rhodesian Nickel Arrived in U.S. Despite Its Ban
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30  A Security Council committee reported today that three shipments of Rhodesian nickel had arrived in Baltimore in April and May despite United Nations embargo against trade with Rhodesia.

title: Agnew Depicts McGovern As Fraudon P.O.W. Issue
description: Vice President Agnew charged here last night that Senator George McGovern was one of the greatest frauds ever to be considered a Presidential can didate by a major American party.

title: New Jersey Bombshell
description: For years the state of New Jersey has been rife with recurring reports of extortion, bribery and kickback schemes that none of the successive Democratic admin istrations was interested enough thoroughly to probe.

title: Market Place: Lots of Glamour But Few Sales
description: Let's take a look at a few glamour situations and see if we can pick a good one.

title: Other Gas Companies Join Complaint
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company got backing yester day for its request that the Federal Power Commission re consider its approval for the importation of one billion cubic feet of Algerian liquefied natural gas over the next 25 years.

title: Pele Stars as Santos Wins
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP) Pele scored three goals as Santos of Brazil trounced the Boston Astros, 61, in an ex hibition soccer game tonight.

title: U. S. Soldiers in Vietnam an Army of Noncombatants
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30  Pfc, Larry O. Ver ocker of Streator, Ill., one of the dwindling number of American infantrymen in South Vietnam, volunteered to come here to see what it was like.

title: French Bank Opening
description: The opening has been an nounced of a main office that is also the San Francisco branch of the French Bank of California with S. Marshall Kempner as chairman. The French Bank is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Banque Nationale de Paris. Mr. Kempner, a commercial and investment banker who is chairman of the San Francisco Committee on Foreign Rela tions and of Business Friends of France, recently served as president of the Industrial Cap ital Corporation.

title: Insurance Acquisition
description: LONDON, June 30 (UPI) Control of the insurance off shoot of the I.O.S. group is being taken over by a British financier, Edward du Cann. This means his resignation as chair man of the Barclays Bank Uni corn group of mutual funds.

title: Notes on People
description: The New Jersey State Dem ocratic Committee found it self without a candidate for Congress in the 13th District, which takes in northwestern New Jersey. Its primary win ner, was forced to withdraw because he did not meet the sevenyear residency require Mont. Thursday night the committee met in, special ses sion to pick a substitute and came up with a unanimous choice, who was away on vacation with her husband and won't return until Wed nesday.

title: BOYLE AGAIN SEEKS UNION PRESIDENCY
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  W. A. Boyle will run again for president of the United Mine Workers ot, America although he was sentenced to five years in jail just three days ago; the union announced today.

title: William V. Frankel, 68, Dies; Led Warner Communications
description: William V. Frankel, board chairman and cochief execu tive officer of Warner Com munications, Inc., died yester day at Westerly, R. I.; en route to a vacation in Nantucket, Mass. He was 68 years old and lived at 110 East 57th Street.

title: U.S. Ready to Sign Pacts For $650Million in Ships
description: Government and private maritime legal experts were putting the finishing touches in Washington last night on a record batch of domestic peace time shipbuilding contracts 1.9 million deadweight tons of new shipping worth $650mil lion.

title: Another Second Makes The Longest Day Ever
description: Yesterday was probably the longest day in history. Every other day since man began recording time has had 86,400 seconds. At 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, or midnight Greenwich mean time, the world's timekeep ers added an extra second to the day.

title: Corning and State Trying to Salvage Glass Art Works
description: ALBANY, N.Y., June 30 (AP) At the Corning glass works, damaged severely in last week's flood, many priceless glass works of art are broken and buried in six inches of mud in the display room.

title: JEWISH LEADERS SCORE ALARMISTS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30 Leaders of Jewish intergroup relations agencies, representing various sections of the country, denounced today as irrespon sible and reprehensible any alarmist assertions that a massive wave of antiSemitism was likely to confront the American Jewish community.

title: Backing of Ali Fight Card Under Government Scrutiny
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 30 (UPI)The Goverment is look ing into the financial backing on Tuesday night's fight card here, which grossed an esti mated $2million from closed circuit television.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT CAREER ACADEMY
description: Wesley D. Pavalon, founder of Career Academy, Inc., Mil waukee, announced his resigna tion yesterday as president, chairman and a director of the concern, which operates voca tional training schools and gives homestudy courses.

title: 10 Juvenile Arrests In Case at Spofford Ordered by Roberts
description: District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx, who is investigating reports of dis orders at the Spofford Juvenile Center, ordered the arrest yes terday of 10 boys in connec tion with assaults on two teach ers and a counselor there.

title: Senate Confirms Moorer
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's ap pointment of Adm. Thomas H. Moorer to a second twoyear term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The action came by voice vote without dissent or debate.

title: DREA GAINS FINAL IN HENLEY SCULLS
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, June 30 (AP)Sean Drea, an Irish farmer's son, and three crack eights carried American hopes into the finals with im pressive victories at Henley Royal Regatta today.

title: NEW NAVY JET LOST IN CHESAPEAKE BAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A $16.8million Navy F14 jet fighter crashed today into Ches apeake Bay.

title: Chess Puzzle
description: Two theories have been put forward to explain Bobby Fischer's erratic behavior on the eve of the scheduled beginning tomorrow of his world championship match against Boris Spassky in Reykjavik. One view is that he is simply acting out an old chess tradition, waging psy chological warfare against Spassky, creating uncertain ties and tensions for the Soviet titleholder that he hopes will weaken Spassky's play when the battle actually be gins. The second theory is that Fischer has become un duly moneyconscious after a lifetime of relative poverty, and really may endanger the Reykjavik match and his chance for the title by insisting upon a greater financial return than he had originally agreed to accept.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The Consumers Union says its tests have shown that the Federal standard for chil dren's car seats is shockingly inadequate, offering virtually no protection in a crash at 30 miles an hour.

title: LIVINGSTONE!
description: It began as a journalistic stunt in an era when newspaper circulation wars were fought with global strategy and without gentlemanly rules; it ended as a famous story with a wellremembered line Dr. Livingstone, I presume?

title: L.I. School Budget Voted
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., July 1  A budget of $12,789,453 for the Herricks School District was passed Thursday night by a vote of 1,300 to 1,125. It would raise the school tax rate from $13,70 to $14.30 for each $100 of assessed valuation. Also approved was a $100,000 bond issue to install fire safety and fireprevention equipment.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In joining the World Hockey Association for a monetary package of more than $2.5million, Bobby Hull created headline interest never before attained by hockey at a time of year when most people relate ice to tall drinks. And in putting his $1million bonus in a bank, he has treated Interest of more than $1,000 a week. But the most significant aspect of Bobby Hull's finances is that he has created a conflict of in tefest unparalleled in sports. His longterm con tract with the Winnipeg Jets, provides for more than $1.5million. No  problem. But his $1million bonus from W.H.A. Properties, Ltd., provides intrigue. His bonus million was camouflaged as an advance against his share of royalties in deals arranged with W.H.A. Properties, Ltd., in the years to come. Such as a Bobby Hull doll. Wind it up and it counts money. But the intrigue evolves froth the source of the million was collected from the 11 other clubs in the new league. Most clubs are understood to have contributed $90,000. One chipped in $110,000, another could afford only $70,000. But no matter what the amount, each club owns a plece of Bobby Hull's magnificent muscles and curved stick.

title: Engineer Is Fiance Of Janet Lockwood
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., July 1The engagement of Miss Janet Lockwood of Scotch Plains and Stony Brook, LI., to John Moran 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moran Jr. of Seaford, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. August Lockwood of Scotch Plains.

title: U.S. and South Korea Sign Accord on $5Million Loan
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1 (UPI)  South Korea and the United States have signed an agreement for an additional $5 million in aid loans to Seoul.

title: Surgeon Weds Anna Duncan, Juniata Alumna
description: HOLLIDAYSBURG, Pa., July 1Miss Anna Bowman Dun can, daughter of Mrs. Peter Shoenberger Duncan, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Emil Von Arx 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Von Arx of Basking Ridge, N. J., and Wentworth, N. H. The Rev. Ralph T. Wolfgang performed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Ronald Gerber.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LONDON, July 1  A joint BritishFrench team of engineering consultants is un derstood to have found, after a year's feasibility studies, that the rising cost of a tun nel under the English Chan nel would make the project uneconomic, at least in its early years.

title: Giants Top Dodgers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP)Turning on the power for the second straight game, the San Francisco Giants used home runs by Dave Kingman, Willie McCovy and Dave Rader to record an 85 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: FLOOR SHOW WINS THE LAMPLIGHTER
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 1  The Mill River Stable's Floor Show proved his two previous victories were genuine when he won the $34,425 Lamplighter Handicap at Monmouth park today.

title: Reeordings
description: LET'S not romanticize the innocence of our youth. One need not be very long in the tooth to remember the dawn of high  fidelity, so  called, when a record's fidelity was measured by just how much the triangle drowned out the piano in Liszt's Eflat Concerto. We've all grown too sophisticated about re corded sound now to be en thralled by such monstrosi ties, of course. We listen for the music, and we demand the sort of unexaggerated sound, balance and perspec tive that a live performance always can provide in theory and sometimes even in prac tice.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: News of Boating
description: Who will represent the United States in Olympic sailing this year? Two of the six classes eligible  Flying Dutchman and Dragonhave held their trials, three others are under way or start today, and the Stars will hold their series next week.

title: The Nation
description: The Harlem Four have spent eight years in jail awaiting the ultimate dis position of their case. The young blacks have been tried three times for the 1964 murder of a Harlem shop keeper. In 1965: A conviction, which was overturned on appeal. In 1971: Two hung juries. Finally they were re leased on $5,000 ball each while State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Mar tinis considered whether or not to bring them to trial again.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: TAIWAN REDUCES ELECTION'S SCOPE
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 1The first regular parliamentary elec tions since the Nationalist Chi nese Government withdrew from the mainland in 1949 will involve a smaller number of seats than the Government had previously indicated.

title: Henry T. Wycis, Surgeon, Dies; Worked on Parkinson's Disease
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) Dr. Henry T. Wycis, a neuro surgeon and pioneer in the treatment of Parkinson's dis ease, died yesterday at St. Luke's and Children's Medical Center here after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.

title: HOUSING PROJECT HAILED BY ROMNEY
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 George W. Romney has praised a housing project of 84 garden apartments here as the first in the country to be sponsored by a hospital.

title: DEMOCRATS MOVE FOR CONCILIATION IN SEATING RIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Fol lowing two days of politically explosive decisions, the Demo cratic National Convention's Credentials Committee moved today toward compromise and conciliation.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ROME, June 17  Tourists flying to Palermo by way of Rome this summer are sure to arrive at Fiumicino Air port here without too much trouble, but landing at the Punta Raisi Airport at Pa lermo will be something else again.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: TWO ETCHELLS22 ARE DISMASTED
description: MAMARONECX, N. Y., July 1  Two Etchells22 Class sloops were dismasted on Long Island Sound today, one in an accident before the start of the season's 14th Yacht Racing As sociation championship regat ta, which drew the largest turn out of the campaign.

title: An Economic Boom Is On Halfway Into Election Year
description: This weekend, at the mid point of the election year of 1972, a broadbased economic boom is well under way in the United States.

title: Concorde Back From the Far East With Three Orders
description: LONDON, July 1The British prototype of Concorde super sonic airliner returned from a 45,000mile tour of the Far East today. The tour produced only three firm orders, but, ac cording to the Concorde's sponsors, the prospects for sales have been significantly en hanced.

title: Marjorie F. McNeil Married To Frederick Eagle Findlay
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 1 Miss Marjorie Fernley Mc Neil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Slack McNeil of Hick ory Farm, Plymouth Meeting, and Claneil, Eleuthera, the Bahamas, and Frederick Eagle Findlay, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Findlay Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., and Acoaxet, Mass., were married here this afternoon. The cere mony was performed in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church by the Rev. Richard T. Hawkins and the Rev. Noah Broken leg.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON In their spare mo ments last weekand there were a few, despite all the hullabaloo about the successful challenges to the Cali fornia and Chicago delegationsDem ocratic politicians were playing the game called Vice President.

title: Olympic Games Tour: $895 From New York
description: Tickets and accommoda tions still are available for a tour to the Olympic Games in Munich, West Germany. The tour, sponsored by Scho lastic Magazines, starts Aug. 21 and returns Sept. 11.

title: Retirement Towns, For Leisurely Life
description: JAMESBURG  To some people, a community for the elderly is a synonym for nursing home, a kind of gilded ghetto that isolates one group from the rest.

title: GORMAN IS OUSTED
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert are in the quarterfinals of the Wimbledon tennis tour nament on their first attempt.

title: Mitchell Quits Post, Putting Family First
description: WASHINGTON, July 1John N. Mitchell, one of the most powerful men in the capital for the last three years, resigned today as President Nixon's cam paign manager after receiving what amounted to an ultimatum from his wife that he choose either her or politics.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CALDWELL  A coffee break while shopping? Cer tainly, and if nobody offers you a cup, just help yourself. A respite from the children while shopping? Just drop them off in the store's little theater. Or a note to send? Paper, pen, envelope, stamp, even a mailbox are all in and onthe store.

title: Two schools of pools
description: Today's geometric architecture and the return to nature have given pool design two new directions. The architectural approach, shown on this page, offers the family an outdoor room with a deck that provides picnic, sunning and children's play areas plus the recessed poollooking ever so inviting on a hot July day. The romantic approach has given us naturalistic pools, op posite page, that could be mistaken for a pond in the woods. Landscaped to nestle into the site, these include rippling waterfalls with waterfilled rock hollows that resemble rain puddles. Paint colors for pool bottoms are chang ing, too. Beige undertone gives water a sea green tint while black turns the surface into enchanted reflections of woods and sky.

title: U.S. PLANS RULES ON JERSEY WASTE
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., July 1 The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has an nounced proposed stringent antipollution regulations de signed to protect the state's 120 miles of coastline.

title: Nixon Picks AllStars
description: President Nixon; in a by lined story, has selected an alltime allstar baseball team. His selections are in Section 5.

title: Strains Between Pope and Late Cardinal Reported
description: ROME, July 1  A Milan magazine, Panorama, has pub lished evidence purporting to show that the relations between Pope Paul VI and the late Eu gne Cardinal Tisserant, the dean of the College of Cardinals who died last February, were severely strained.

title: The Spirit of '76 at Your Local Supermarket
description: THE bickering over plans for the 1976 Bicentennial of America's independence is not the nation's only problem in the area of pa triotic observance. Independence Hall is facing an identity crisis as ersatz independence halls spring up in shop ping malls and museum complexes all over the place. There has been one for years in the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., built by old Henry when he reportedly tried to buy the original and Philadelphia refused to sell. There is another at Knott's Berry Farm in Buena Park, Calif., where guides dressed in the fashion of the late 1700's constantly stir up the Spirit of 1776. A replica in Kew Gardens, New York City, houses the Queens County Sav ings Bank, and another serves as a supermarket in a shopping center on U.S. 202 just outside Wilmington, Del. If the argument over how to celebrate the Bicentennial is not ended by 1976, Americans may simply drive out to their friendly supermarket or to their local bank for a few moments of silence.

title: Miss Katherine Louise Keyes Married to Glenn Nickolas Tri
description: RYE, N.Y., July 1The marriage of Miss Katherine Louise Keyes to Glenn Nick olas Tri, a doctoral candidate in political science at the University of Oregon, took place in Christ's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wendell Phillips.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Three Novels and a Novella
description: Their Family is the second in Warren Fine's series of novels about American frontier life in the 18th century. The first volume, In the Animal Kingdom, followed Gerhard Blau, Orcus Berrigan and the Indian woman Sawpootway to the edge of the Rockies in 1779. The new book is Blau's imagined account of his friends' lives 20 years later. Having parted with the Berrigans and fearful that they may no longer exist, Blau renews his feelings for them by inventing a fictive world in which they may now live. Just as his friends exist only in his imagination, Blau reveals them as living primarily in their own. Ignoring outward ad venture, he concentrates on a per ceptual drama: the way his friends respond to the wilderness on the screens of their minds. Thus, his nar rative is relatively uneventful. A trapper named Legget kidnaps the Berrigans' son in response to a hu miliating practical joke staged by Sawpootway, and most of the novel describes the elder Berrigans' search for the missing boy. After finding him, they return home only to learn that their daughter has recently eloped with a stranger. At the end, the boy too leaves, and his parents move resignedly away from their valley home.

title: Auburn Director Retires
description: AUBURN, Ala., July 1 (AP) Jeff Beard, who directed Auburn's sports program through the most dynamic growth in its history, stepped down today after more than two decades as athletic direc tor.

title: SOVIET DANCER SAID TO DESPAIR
description: Valery Panov, a leading So viet dancer who was dismissed from Leningrad's Kirov Ballet Company in April after having applied to emigrate to Israel, has become a desperate and deteriorating man, according to a Western friend who had a private conversation with him in Leningrad last month.

title: Coins
description: THE FOOD and Agricul ture Organization of the United Nations has an nounced that new mon ies for Album 2 in its httenna tional coin program are being minted by many countries or are now being designed.

title: UPSTATE FIXTURE TO IRISH SETTER
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 1 Robert Braithwaite, a judge who spent most of his day looking at 11 different kinds of terriers, picked an Irish setter best of 815 dogs at the 17th annual SusqueNango Kennel Club show today on the grounds of the Brookside ele mentary school.

title: POLITICS CHARGES CANADA'S HOLIDAY
description: OTTAWA, July 1Fireworks flared over Parliament Hill. Massed military bands, aided by guns of the 30th Field Regi ment, played the finale from Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture. And in the Opera House, Gov ernor General and Mrs. Roland Michener and many other high ranking Canadians joined in a birthday gala highlighted by a performance of Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutti.

title: Hitchcock: The Agony Is Exquisite
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK is enough to make one despair. After 50 years of directing films, he's still not perfect. He refuses to be serious, at least in any easily recognizable way that might win him the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award or the Irving Thal berg Award, or even an Oscar for di rectorial excellence. Take, for example, his new film, Frenzy, a suspense melo drama about a homicidal maniac, known as the Necktie Killer, who is terrorizing London, and the wrong man who is chased, arrested and convicted for the crimes. What does it tell us about the Human Condition, Love, the Third World, God, Structural Politics, Envi ronmental Violence, Justice, Conscience, Aspects of Underdevelopment, Discrim ination, Radical Stupor, Religious Ec stasy or Conservative Commitment? Practically nothing.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. Open Tennis Picks Blanchard For Referee Role
description: Mike Blanchard of Paradise Valley, Ariz., has been named referee of the United States Open tennis championship scheduled for the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, Aug. 30 through Sept. 10.

title: Big Beat in Hollywood Bowl Revives the 1950's
description: HOLLWOOD, Calif., July 1 Doo wah. Doo wah. Dooooo wah, doo wah.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Although the Washington, D. C., area has an abundance of motorsports enthusiasts, it has had little luck with its road racing courses. Marlboro Speedway still exists, but it has not been active since 1969. A Chesapeake Interna tional was announced with an immense publicrelations bash in 1970, but it never got any where. Summit Point had a short flurry of activity but it has been immobilized by dissension among the owners. Now a new track is being organized andwith fingers crossed it may be in operation next May. The promoters have commitments from the Sports Car Club of America for pro fessional and club racesif the track really is built and if it passes safety and other requirements.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Hijacking Suspect Seized On Flight From Seattle
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 1 (UPI)A man who airline offi cials said fitted the profile of a potential hijacker was arrested on a Hughes Air West jetliner here last night after a steward ess said he asked for $50,000 and a parachute.

title: VINCENT VAN BUREN
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 1 Vincent Van Buren, executive vice president of the Van Go In teruna Corporation, marketing consultants in New York, died yesterday at the Stamford Hos pital from injuries received in a mugging at the Stamford rail road station on May 2. He was 68 years old and lived at 155 Pine Wood Road.

title: Millions Make Pilgrimages to Birthplace of Mao
description: SHAOSHAN, China, June 26 This is the birthplace of Chairman Mao Tsetung. Viewed in that light it is almost a holy place, visited last year by 1.6 million people.

title: A New U.N. Role for Nicol
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1Dr. Davidson S. H. W. Nicol of Sierra Leone has been appointed executive director of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research. Dr. Nicol, now his government's high commissioner in London, will assume his new duties here on Sept. 1. He was Sierra Le one's chief delegate at the United Nations from 1969 to 1971.

title: Miss Valerie P. Burghardt Married
description: MAHOPAC, N. Y., July 1 Miss Valerie Pearsall Burg hardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Walter Burghardt of Mahopac, was married here this afternoon to Peter Michael Hayes of New Ro chelle. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lind Hayes of New Rochelle and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: The Good Word
description: Don't let them intimidate you, Edmund Wilson once said to me, and I thought, if you don't, sir, they certainly won't My fund of personal Wilsoniana is extremely modest, and I won't attempt to stretch it here. Claiming close friendships with the recent dead is a knavish trick, and in Wilson's case there will be a lot of it because he had, behind his hedge of crotchets, an extraordinary gift for friendship in all its degrees, from the exchange of funny post cards to the complete opening of his mind. My own degree, pitched some where between the two, was, I know for a fact, shared by many.

title: The Nation
description: With three major decisionson the death penalty, press rights, and Congressional immunitythe Supreme Court brought its session to a dramatic close last week. Above right: Senator Mike Gravel. Below: An assessment of the Court's term.

title: If You Go
description: further into the story of Stanley and Livingstone, you find that, outfitted with goods and men supplied by the Herald, Livingstone set out in the middle of August, 1872, to continue his explorations. Eight months later, while at the south end of Lake Bangweolo, he died of dysentery at the age of 60. His men carried his body, papers and instruments across Africa to Zanzibar. From there his body was borne to Eng land and placed in Westminster Abbey on April 18, 1874.

title: Miss Eliza Shelton Blanchard Is Bride of Ralph Albree Child
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 1Miss Eliza Shelton Blan chard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Ernest Blanchard, was married here this after noon to Ralph Albree Child, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Brandford Child.

title: Photography
description: FOR all intents and pur poses, the tradition of black photography be gins with Roy De Carava. DeCarava is not the first black photographer (though he was the first one to be awarded a Guggen heim); the history of black photography stretches back more than a century. Nor is he the bestknown; Gordon Parks is closer to a house hold word than DeCarava, and even James Van DerZee rediscovered recently dur ing the making of the Met's Harlem On My Mindhas received more public atten tion. DeCarava has never had a oneman show at any major museum (his largest exhibit to date, a solo retrospective which was, hardly a swan song, having been presented by the Studio Museum in Harlem several years ago). And, considering the extent and importance of the re markable body of work he has created over the last three decades, he has been vastly underpublished; only one slim volume of his im ages, The Sweet Flypaper of Life (with text by Langston Hughes), has ever been issued, and that one is almost 20 years old, though miracu lously still in print.

title: Wood Field and Stream
description: FRYEBURG, Me.  When half a mile of floating and casting on the Saco River produced only one half hearted follow from a dace, we knew that our chances of taking smallmouth bass were slim.

title: Alice Rao Will Marry
