description: SYOSSET, L. I., July 1 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rao have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Alice Veronica Rao, to David Lassiter, son of Mrs. Angelina F. Lassiter of Washington.

title: A Foreign Steel Town in the U.S.
description: GEORGETOWN, S.C.  We haven't regretted com ing here, said Wolfgang Jansen, the 32yearold presi dent of the Germanowned Georgetown Steel Corpora tion, although there are those who do regret the com pany's move.

title: American Dance Fete
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 1The American Dance Fes tival, proud bearer of a special congratulatory letter from President Nixon, opened its 25th anniversary season here last night at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium.

title: Danish Yacht Sinks In Biscay Collision; 7 in Crew Are Lost
description: BREST, France, July 1 (UPI) The Danish yacht Lesteria, with a crew ?? 11 Americans, Danes, Swedes and Dutch, sank after colliding last night with a French weatherobservation ship in the Bay of Biscay. Only four of the crew were saved, French naval authorities said today.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: Two weeks ago Martha Mitchell, the outspoken, wife of the former Nixon Attorney General, was on a speaking tour in California. Except for Vice President Agnew, she is the guest most in demand at Republican ralliesand she seemed to be enjoying the role with her usual exuberance.

title: L.I.R.R. Fails to Soothe Riders
description: Years of abuse, both real and imagined, have turned the Long Island Rail Road commuter into a very picky fellow. Railroad officials dis covered this last week when they made drastic revisions in their timetables and billed the changes as a great im provement.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 (AP) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson has withdrawn his offer to mediate the pilots' strike against North west Airlines, it was an nounced today.

title: WILLIAM A. MACOMBER
description: WATERVILLE, Me., July 1 William A. Macomber, retired director of adult education at Colby College, died in Thayer Hospital yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived in South port.

title: Economic Troubles Beset Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 1 A distinguished interna tional economist, here on a recent visit, was favorably impressed with the redistribu tion of income in favor of wage earners during the first year of Chile's leftwing Gov ernment.

title: Medicine
description: That clanging, clattering, chugging, coughing cacophony  the oppressive sound of the city. Can it be muted? Last week what was describedas the most comprehensive noise control leg islation in the country was approved by the New York City Council's Corn mittee on Environmental Protection. Final passage and Mayor Lindsay's, signature are expected next month, with the bill taking effect on Sept. 1.

title: India's Tea Pickers Earn NoBirth Bonuses
description: COONOOR, India, June 22 Like most of the 98,000 or so women who pluck tender young leaves all day on the plantations of southern In dia for the teacups of the world, Seeta is less than 5 feet tall, never went to school and is anemic, as were 85 per cent of the plan tation women covered in a recent medical survey here.

title: 2 SHOT TO DEATH AS NEW VIOLENCE FLARES IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 1New violence struck Northern Ireland today as thousands of Protestant youths, many wearing masks and grip ping wooden clubs, set up bar ricades in Belfast in a protest against British policies.

title: News of the Camera World
description: THE Grand Central YMCA, 224 East 47th Street, is offering two fivesession courses in photography this month. The first will be a basic course covering both blackand white and color (selecting a camera, taking flash and strobe pictures, composition, etc.) and it will start July 11, from 6:30 to 8 P.M. The ad vanced course, which will in clude a field trip, will start the next evening (July 12) from 6:30 to 8 P.M. Each course will cost $17.50. For information call (212) 755 2410.

title: Librarian Jobs, in Sudden Reversal, Now Hard to Find
description: CHICAGO, July 1  Peter Schend has degrees from Dart mouth College and Yale Law School, earns $19,000 a year as a researcher in African affairs at the Library of Congress, but is willing to accept $11,000 for a library job outside Washington.

title: John Sylvester 3d To Wed Miss Hess
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 1 Mrs. Max Hess has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Rice Hess, to John McFall Sylvester 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sylvester of Riverside, Conn. The prospec tive bride is also a daughter of the late Mr. Hess, former president of the Hess Broth ers department store, founded in 1897 by his father and uncle, the late Max and Charles Hess.

title: The life of the wife of a politician
description: When I read a book review, a woman said to me the other day, I want to know what the tone of the book is, and what it's about. I don't want to read an essay. I don't think that's true for every reader or for every book, but it may be for this one, which is a first book, but one whose very appearance will tend to persuade the reader that he knows what it's about when, in fact, he doesn't. So let me supply some of the information required, as often as possible in the words of the writer:

title: A vote for them was a vote for justice, truth and progress
description: Even if their relatively maverick electionyear books were to launch a paraliterary happening  which would inevitably be called the new campaign autobiography  it is not likely that Don Riegle or Bella Abzug would be venerated by prac titioners of their genre as Murray Kempton is by acolytes of the new journalism. For one thing, neither the Republican Congressman from Michigan nor the Democratic Con gresswoman from Manhattan begin to approach the tortuous literateness of the man some consider the father of the new journalism. The specter of Henry James, which ever hovers over the Atelier Kempton, would pay little more than a courtesy call on Riegle and would surely run screaming from the literary pre cincts of Abzug. And political diarieswhich both O Congress and Bella! are  date back at least as far as Samuel Pepys.

title: Art
description: THE Museum of Modern Art opened a new ex hibition last week called Symbolism, Synthetism and the Fin de Siecle, terri tory that has been explored in, so many exhibitions and exploited in so many campy guises over the last few years that anyone can be excused if the announcement of yet another reprise seems no cause for jumping up and down in jubilant anticipation. All the more pleasure, then, in discovering that Donna Stein, the museum's assistant curator of prints and illus trated books, has pulled an unexpectedly fresh and charming exhibition from the museum's bins with a few loans as a bonus.

title: Amon's Record Lap Wins Pole For French Grand Prix Today
description: CLERMONT  FERRAND, France, July 1The finish line is watched over by a World War II bunker and a herd of grazing cows unconcerned with the noise below.

title: Badarzewska To Dobrzynski
description: THERE are only two possible places where one might hear a program made up of Arthur Foote's cantata The Wreck of the Hesperus and ex cerpts from Dame Ethyl Smyth's opera The Wreckers. One is the annual Romantic Festival at Butler University in Indianapolis, the other is the New port Music Festival, which revives the same kind forgotten or ignored repertory of the Romantic era. Since Indianapolis stresses the instrumental and sym phonic literature, one would guesscorrectlythat the FooteSmyth vocal program was being given in Newport.

title: SovietU.S. Track Meet Again Goes to Richmond
description: RICHMOND, July 1 (AP) The Richmond Coliseum will be the scene of the Soviet UnionUnited States indoor track meet again in 1973, the Amateur Athletic Union has announced. The meet will be staged March 16.

title: Many Young Socialites Want a Simpler Debutante Party, or None
description: A young woman on Long Island who, in an earlier time, would have taken it for granted that she would be making a debut this winter, recently told her mother that she simply could not take Part in those crazy dance figures. Furthermore, she was not about to sit on the floor with other debutantes in a circle and sing Christmas carols while holding a candle.

title: Civil Service Reports Peak In Employment of Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The Civil Service Commission has reported that, thanks to Governmentwide training and counseling, the number of mi nority group members moving into higherpaying Federal jobs reached a record high in the 12 months ended last November.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn essence, Earl Caldwell, a black reporter for The New York Times and Senator Mike Gravel, of Pentagon Papers fame, raised the same question: Should a select few be granted a right of silence before grand juries in order to protect the free flow of information to the public?

title: Medicine
description: A couple of months ago, Paul J. Sherwin, New Jersey's Secretary of State and close friend and chief of staff to Republican Gov. William T. Cahill, chatted with friends in a Trenton restaurant about the seemingly endless series of indictments of public officials, mainly Democrats, since Republicans took over three years ago. The Cahill administration, he said, would never have such troubles, and the one thing I can promise you is that Herbert Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, will never get me.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Although the problems de scribed in your article on Welfare Island (Doubts Lin ger, but Welfare Island Ven ture Moves Ahead, June 4] are well known in planning, architectural and engineer ing circles, it is not general ly known that a more far reaching blunder has been made by the Urban Develop ment Corporation in the White Plains Battle Hill proj ect.

title: Fischer Seeks a Postponement
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 1 Bobby Fischer has asked for a twoday postponement for his chess match with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, according to Andrew Davis, Fischer's lawyer.

title: Even With Dearth of Viewers, Goldman Band Played On
description: The famous Goldman Band was the feature attraction as the 55th season of the Gug genheim Memorial Concerts got under way in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, a week ago last night. Unfortunately, there were more musicians than music lovers on hand.

title: Ailing Starr Will Play For Packers This Year
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 1 (UPI)Bart Starr, the Green Bay Papkers' quarterback, admitting he has not com pletely recovered from an arm injury that has plagued him the last three years, said today he would play again next fall.

title: In Miami Beach Politics Is Dead
description: MIAMI BEACH  Despite the fact that the Democratic National Convention will con vene next week and the Re publicans will meet a scant month later, most people in this resort below Mason and Dixon's Line couldn't care a whit.

description: A daughter was born on June 22 at Beth Israel Medi cal Center to Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Bonfeld of Riverdale, the Bronx. The child has been named Mara Leigh. Mrs. Bonfeld is the former Harriet Feinberg.

title: WALL STREET
description: A whimsical guessing game was making the rounds of Wall Street last week. The question: how slow would the trading be on the New York Stock Exchange Monday, July 3?

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 2 (AP)The South Vietnamese counteroffensive on the northern front was slowed yesterday by enemy shelling and bad weather, according to reports from the field.

description: In 15 of the 50 states this November, voters will decide on more than who will be President. Pocketbook issues must be settled.

title: U.S.A.F. IN EUROPE HAS BIG DOMAIN
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany  At dawn the F4E Phantoms of the 16th Air Force fly north from Incirlik, Turkey, to the gunnery range. The light, mov ing westward, touches bases of the 17th Air Force in West Germany and the Netherlands. Finally, in Oxfordshire, in rural England, it falls upon the sleek F111's of the Third Air Force.

description: CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)Ed Herrmann's tiebreaking single in the eighth inning sparked a four run run outburst today that gave the Chicago White Sox a 51 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Red Sox End Brewers Streak
description: BOSTON, July 1 (AP)Ben Oglivie belted two home runs and the pitcher, Marty Pattin, hit his first major league homer as the Boston Red Sox beat Milwaukee, 54, today and end ed the Brewers' longest winning streak in their history at six games.

title: Miss Ann M. Weinkauff Is Married
description: CHESTERFIELD, Mo., July 1Miss Ann Mary Weinkauff of Madison, Wis., daughter of Mrs. Oliver J. Weinkauff of Chesterfield, and the late Dr. Oliver J. Weinkauff, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Kenneth Warwick Nick erson of Peoria, Ill, The bride groom is a son of Dr. Helen Kelsall Nickerson of Prince ton, N. J., and of Dr. Walter J. Nickerson of Middlesex, N.J.

description: In Forest Hills, Kew Gar dens, Ridgewood and Linden wood Village, they've grown accustomed to a Queens face that is constantly being re newed.

title: Raceway Computers Fail, Canceling 4 Races, Bets
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 1 Dat Ol' Debbil computer, which from time to time has been harassing Howard B. Samuels and his off track betting opera tion, struck hard for the first time tonight at Roosevelt Race way. Not only did a malfunc tioning mechanical calculator prevent win, place and show wagering on all except the sec ond race, it also was re sponsible for the curtainraiser to be delayed 42 minutes and the canceling of the fifth, sev enth, eighth and ninth races.

title: Candy Ross, Nurse, Married In Darien to Robert G. Kiely

title: Deborah L. Miller Affianced
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Miller of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Leah Miller, to Norman Kram, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Leo Kram of Manhattan. A January wed ding is planned.

title: Home Improvement
description: PROBABLY the closest thing yet to the con cept of a truly port able room air condi tioner that can be carried anywhere is a new model re cently introduced by the Gen eral Electric Corporation. Weighing only 43 pounds, and equipped with a sturdy, luggagetype handle to sim plify, carrying, it is only a bit more than 10 inches deep (front to back) and draws only seven amperes, so it can be plugged into any standard household circuit.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Reginald H. Jones is gen erally considered a money man by those who follow the General Electric Com pany closely. Within the company he has been de scribed as the architect of the Honeywell deal.

description: OKINAWA  With the re version of Okinawa to Japan ese administration on May 15 went some $300million in foreign investment, the bulk of it American.

title: Home Improvement
description: ASKILLED cabinetmaker or experienced car penter can achieve a remarkably smooth finish on all kinds of wood working projects because he knows how to select and use the right kind of abrasive paper (sandpaper to most people) for each job. Home handymen or women who would like to get the same kind of results can do just as wellif they will take time to familiarize themselves with the types available, and if they will follow a few sim ple rules when choosing and using the various grades.

title: Park Plan Worries Owners of Caves in New Mexico
description: GRANTS, N. M.For the last 25 years, half their lives, David Candelaria and his wife have spent most of their waking hours turning a natu ral physical phenomenon  some volcanic ice caves  into a tourist attraction.

title: Amateurs To Dominate I.. I. Bloc At Miami
description: MINEOLA, L.I.Don Man kiewicz is the brother of one of the most powerful po litical tacticians in the United States and, in his own right, a television writer whose credits include the pilots for the widely acclaimed Marcus Welby, M.D., and Ironsides series.

title: Three Novels and a Novella
description: Inishnamonaa knobby region linked by a causeway to the west coast of Irelandis falling into eco nomic ruin, but no one in Dublin cares. To attract attention, local pa triots demolish the road and declare themselves an island, but their escapade results only in comic notori ety, an increased deficit and a shrinking supply of food and serv ices. At the start of Honor Tracy's new novel, a feckless Action Commit tee stirs hope by sponsoring a St. Patrick's Pageant Play to put Inish namona on the tourist map.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: LEO POLLAK, 89, DIES; LED ORDNANCE FIRM
description: Leo Lawrence Pollak, retired ordnance manufacturer and Navy consultant, died Thurs day in Virginia Beach, where he had gone for a vacation. He was 89 years old and lived at the Ritz Towers, 465 Park Ave nue.

title: MARK CARTER
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30  Mark Carter, a philanthropist who served as president of the City of Hope philanthropic or ganization from 1936 to 1939, died here Tuesday. He was 87 years old.

title: RANGERS SYSTEM YIELDS 3 RAIDERS
description: The New York Raiders have reached into the American Hockey League and signed three former members of the New York Rangers farm system: a defenseman, Ken Block, and two right wings, Wayne Rivers and Marc Dufour. The team now has 18 players under con tract.

title: Friday Night Fights

title: Geese Shun North to Stay In Jersey Game Refuge
description: OCEANVILLE, N. J., July 1 Instead of flying north as they are supposed to, 600 Can ada geese at the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge here sit complacently on the marsh munching grass.

title: LUDLUM IS VICTOR IN BABYLON REGATTA
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 1Bill Ludlum in Nevermore caught a sudden gust of wind just before the finish line today to edge Dennis O'Malley in Doodlebug for Raven Class honors as the Babylon Yacht Club's annual Fourth of July invitation re gatta got under way. The series resumes tomorrow and con cludes on Tuesday.

title: Television
description: SEVERAL weekends ago, Rep. Louis Stokes, Democrat of Ohio, and Mayor Richard Hatch er of Gary, Ind., were scheduled to appear on the American Broadcasting Com pany's Issues and Answers, a Sunday afternoon inter view program. On the Fri day before the program, the black politicians issued a de mand that one of the two newsmen interviewing them be black. Peggy Whedon, producer of the program, re fused, the two politicians in sisted and, finally, they were replaced on the schedule by another, white, politician.

Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, a blackandtan German shep herd, owned by Mrs. Helene Klotzman of Baltimore and handled by Kim Knoblauch of Manchester, Md., returned to New England today to score his 34th best in show at the sixth annual fixture of the Hockamock Kennel Club.

title: Railroad Picture
description: The nation's railroads got out of the passenger busi ness last year, handing over the service on May 1 to Am trak, the Governmentsponsored company created, by Con grass in 1970. The step, long sought by the roads, was costly, however.

title: Senate Passes Pension Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) A bill doubling the $5,000 an nual pension paid to widows of six Supreme Court Justices has been passed by the Senate. Action was prompted by the disclosure that the 82yearold widow of Justice Felix Frank furter was nearly impoverished. Also affected are the widows of Justices Hugo L. Black, Robert H. Jackson, Sherman Minton, Wiley B. Rutledge and Fred M. Vinson.

title: Disadvantaged Taught Clerical Skills
description: Pamela Isom, 21 years old of Brooklyn, found an alternative to the ghetto street corner society she had been used to and Sheila Andrea Dunlop, 21, who lives in upper Manhattan, found instead of the usual runarounds a solid work training experience.

title: Reds Win, Keep Lead
description: SAN DIEGO, July 1 (AP) Joe Morgan hit his 10th homer, a decisive tworun clout in the third, to give the Cincinnati Reds a 32 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight.

title: Bill Mauldin, Cartoonist, Fiance of Christine Lund
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. S., July 1 Miss Christine Lund and William H. (Bill) Mauldin, the cartoonist and author, of Chi cago and Santa Fe, N. M., plan to be married July 29 in the First Congregational Church, Wilmette, Ill.

title: Show Horse News
description: The Piping Rock horse show, one of the leading events in the country for more than half a century, has been canceled for this year. The show was sched uled for Sept. 1417. The announcement was made the other day by Mrs. Sarah Steel of Syosset, vice president of the show. We couldn't get people to support the show at the Old Field Club in Stony Brook, said Mrs. Steall. For the people who were interested in Piping Rock [in Locust Valley], Stony Brook was too far out on the Island.

title: 2 Israeli Universities Feud Bluntly and in Public
description: JERUSALEM, July 1A long simmering feud between Israel's two largest universities has come into the open in a testy exchange on financing between the Israeli president of the Tel Aviv University, Yuval Nee man, and the American chair man of the board of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, Sam Rothberg.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Is the United States falter iag in its ability to deliver new medicines to the Ameri can public?

title: President Signs Bill For Increase of 20% In OldAge Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 President Nixon signed into law today a bill on the nation al debt ceiling to which Con gress yesterday attached a 20 per cent increase in Social Se curity benefits.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon moved energetically in both private and public settings last week to deal with two persistent problemsprob lems that, if left unattended, could provide his Democratic opponent next fall with major political opportunities.

title: The Last Word
description: In 1928, when he was 32, Edmund Wil son wrote an essay for The New Republic in which he surveyed American literature and saw the need for true literary criti cism. This essay was called The Critic Who Does Not Exist and it appears in The Shores of Light (Farrar, Straus & Giroux). We reprint part of it below with the thought that the ideal Wilson describes in it was largely realized by Wilson him self as a literary critic, political and social observer, biographer, historian and me morialist. Wilson became the embodi ment of social and cultural continuity, a mediator between past and present, be tween literature and politics, scholarship and journalism. He brought new works before us; he conserved; and, above all he connected.

title: Medicine
description: Misery loves companyand many a physician and dentist must have been cheered last week by news of a Price Commission vote. That vote decided to set 2 per cent as the top price in crease allowable for fees charged by large professional organizations such as law and accounting firms. This past half year health professionals have complained that they alone of all Americans have had to live under that tight ceiling, well under the 5.5 per cent allowable for wage hikes.

title: Miss Schwartz Fiancee Of D. L. Peckmore
description: BELMAR, N. J., July 1 Mrs. Harold Bernheim Schwartz has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Judith Isabel Schwartz, to Douglas Lawrence Peck more, son of Mrs. John Peck more of Eatontown and the late Mr. Peckmore. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Nixon Picks. All Time Baseball Teams
Criminals At Large
description: Ross Thomas's THE PORK CHOPPERS (Morrow, $6.95) is primarily a muckraking novel about labor unions. It qualifies as mystery fiction because much of it deals with a gun man engaged to kill a union leader during the period he is running for reelection.

title: Stravinsky
description: In 1920, when Igor Stravinsky was not yet generally known in the Unit ed States, a young military academy cadet named Paul Horgan fell in love with his music without having heard a note of it, simply through reading articles about it by Carl Van Vechten and Paul Rosenfeld and hearing an instructor at the academy tell of the uproar occasioned in Paris by the first performance of The Rite of Spring. That this could happen, that Horgan's account of his involvement with music he had not even heard is entirely convincing and under standable, is worth pondering. It was not a matter of a young person be coming interested in a composer's work after reading critical accounts of it, but rather of the instantaneous acceptance of this composer's work, sound unheard, as the supreme ar tistic expression of our century.

title: Iceland Chess Unit Tries To Curb News Coverage
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 1 The Icelandic Chess Feder ation pressed its efforts today to prevent television stations and chess clubs around the world from staging playbyplay reconstructions of the world chess championship matches while they are under way.

title: Stephanie Sewall a Bride in Maine
description: BOOTHBAY, Me., July 1 Miss Stephanie Sewall and Douglas Arms Bacon were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Samuel Henderson of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Newcastle per formed the ceremony on the shore near the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mark Warren Sewall of Boothbay.

Canon John Morrow performed the Episcopal cer emony. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ashmun are the parents of the bridegroom. Both families reside here.

title: Phillies Reactivate Johnson
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (UPI) The Philadelphia Phillies re activated first baseman Deron Johnson today and put Chris Short on the disabled list. Johnson has been bothered by a damaged nerve in his left leg, and Short was placed in trac tion, with an ailing back.

title: the traveler's world
description: COPENHAGEN  Fellow American travelers about to set out for Europe, brace yourselves and pocketbooks. The U.S. dollar isn't what it used to be. Slimmed ?? by the Nixon devaluation and clipped by the inflation which seems to be con tinuing as merrily in Europe as in the States, the dollar's value has been trimmed further by the rising standard of living throughout Europe which not only increases the supply of consumer goods and luxury items but also the demand for them and, thus, pushes up their prices.

title: Mary Morrison Rockefeller Is Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 Miss Mary Morrison Rock efeller and Rodney Dean Runestad were married here this afternoon at St. Barna ?? Episcopal Church by the Rev. Harold Bassage.

title: Dance
description: PERHAPS my friend, the composer Nicholas ?? put it best. He described New York City Ballet's Stravinsky ?? which ended last Sunday, as like an ocean voyage. You kept on seeing the same people, there was the same intimacy, the same ?? of sharing an experi ence of some nature that is insulated from the common practices of time. During one intermission Nabokov came out of the auditorium, found me at my seat in the foyer frantically scribbling my notes in preparation for my nightly canter to the dead line for my notice, looked quizzically at me, and said: How was the soup? It was the right question.

title: A warning to technological man
description: An interesting footnote to modern history is the problem the prosecution at the Nurem berg War Crimes Trial con fronted in preparing its case. There was no difficulty gather ing evidence; the immense task was sorting through a moun tain of bureaucratic memoran da and official reports detail ing the trivial minutia of geno cide. It is precisely this aspect of contemporary life that forms the basis of Leonard C. Lewin's latest book. (His last, he con fesses, was the satire The Re port From Iron Mountain.)

description: WASHINGTON, July 1  American officials said today, that the United States and the Yemen Arab Republic were ex pected to formally resume dip lomatic relations tomorrow. Re lations were severed by Yemen at the time of the 1967 Arab Israeli war.

title: Just Another Habit?
description: THE argument in favor of heroin maintenance is presented in its purest form by Ira Glasser, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. His ideas are far out, compared with the cautious Vera proposal, but they are important because they often provide a theoretical under pinning for heroinmaintenance partisans. Taking heroin, he says, is logically and philosophically indistinguishable from smoking, drinking, overeating and a whole lot of other bad habits. Heroin, Glasser contends, is simply one of many harmful substances available to us. Indeed, the number of heroin addicts is far smaller than the number of smokers and alcoholics. There are 44.5 million adult smokers in the country, nine million alcoholics anddepending on whom you believebetween 300,000 and 560,000 addicts. If Gil Hodges dropped dead on the golf course from a heroin overdose, it would be a national scandal; from cigarettesmoking it makes no impact, says Glasser. The whole thing strikes me as com pletely irrational. Society's attempt to treat heroin differently from ciga rettes or alcohol has been a disastercreating a spiraling crime rate that is fueling a very repressive kind of politics in this country. Glasser would decriminalize heroin and make it available in pharmacies for addicts. He says he is uncertain whether it should be freely availablelike cigarettes or alcoholor under the kinds of restrictions placed on insulin for diabetics. Some of his colleagues in the Civil Liberties Union favor governmentrun maintenance clinics, but Glasser fears that clinics would have an unhealthy element of social control.

title: Billions for Defense but Not Enough for Security
description: WASHINGTON  Last February, President Nixon journeyed to China. The beginning of a reconciliation with China was long overdue, and both nations had an interest in discussing peace in Asia. But sortie weeks after President Nixon's return, Secretary of Defense Melvin Laird announced to the Congress that the escalation of the Vietnam war would cost us up to $5 billion more than anticipated.

title: Achtung! It's Alec Hitler
description: EVERYTHING'S coming up Adolf Hitler these days. Not only is Charlie Chaplin's classic The Great Dictator doing a blitzlike business at the Lincoln Art Theater, but serious and zany views of the biggest Nazi of them all are starting to sprout in movie studios around the world. Per haps the first to bloom on our local screens will be Hitler: The Last Ten Days, adapted by Ivan Moffat from H. R. TrevorRoper's The Last Days of Hitler, which was published just two years after the fall of the Third Reich.

title: Abrams in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 1 (AP)General Abrams has ar rived in Bangkok to join his family. The general is to vaca tion here for a period, before leaving for Washington, a United States military spokes man said.

title: The World
description: MELBOURNETom Christian, who shares rocky Pitcairn Island with 92 other descendants of the mutineers from H.M.S. Bounty, has learned to live with the Bomb. He recalls that when he and his fellow islanders heard the first explosions from the French nuclear tests some six years ago, some of them panicked. A few actually wanted to leave the place, he says. They packed all their possessions. Then they thought about how hard it would be to leave their families and their pets and their gardens, and they decided to wait awhile. They're still here.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1  A new link between E. Howard Hunt Jr., a former parttime White House consultant, and Bernard L. Barker, the Miami realtor arrested two weeks ago as a suspect in a raid on the Democratic National Commit tee offices here, has been dis closd by Mr. Barker's wife.

title: Namath and Barry To Play Golf on L.I. For Cancer Fund
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 1 The Suffolk County Division of the American Cancer Society hopes to get more than $75,000 from Monday's golf program at the Colonie Hills Country Club the third annual Pinter Tour nament of Stars.

title: Heaven help the working girl
description: You need a score card to tell the difference between and among the 15 single, suffering women whose reminiscences Jack Olsen has gath ered in The Girls in the Office. All of them work for The Company, a firm with a persona adding up to Procter & Gamble, I.B.M., TimeLife and MeetaMate Service.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 At least 153 California Dem ocrats will be in Miami Beach next week with their minds made up about the Democratic Presidential nominee but with no place to sit and no conven tion votes to cast, it appeared today.

title: Gardens
description: EVERY lawn operates on Parkin son's Law (the universally ac cepted maxim that says if some thing can go wrong, it will). First, there is rain, which always fallsand falls hardimmediately after grass is planted. Usually the deluge sweeps all newly planted seed to the lawn next door, or makes a mead of your flower beds. It either floods just after planting, or accompanying tornadoes stripmine the pasturage and whisk the seed off to Oz. This always happens, despite back yard shrines to St. Fiacre.

title: Joan M. FitzPatrick Is Affianced
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., July 1Mr. and Mrs. James A. Fitzpatrick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Maureen FitzPatrick, to Donald. Ken neth Wilks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Wilks Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: John Bohannon 3d Weds Miss Rosemary Ridder
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., July 1 Miss Rosemary Ridder, an alumna of Manhattanville College, was married there in the chapel this afternoon to John Neil Bohannon 3d. The bride's cousin, Msgr. Herman L. Heide, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Horowitz in Iceland
description: The regular Sunday chess column by Al Horowitz does not appear today. Mr. Horo witz is in Reykjavik, Iceland, preparing for coverage of the FischerSpassky tournament.

title: SandlerWeber Team Gains In National A.A.U. Handball
description: The topseeded team of Steve Sandler and Don Weber won its thirdround match yesterday in the National Amateur Athletic Union onewall handball tour nament at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THERE are those who can take the highly controversial plays of Fer nando Arrabalthe proof is in the success of his And They Put Handcuffs on the Flowers at the Off Broadway Mercer Arts Center  and those who can't. The latter may grace fully skip to the next item. Arrabal fans will be interested in the news that there is to be another of the Spanish play wright's works on the local boards in the fall. This None is called The Architect and the Emperor of Assyria, which, in a rather gamey production, unsettled playgoers two years ago at the Stratford Festival in Ontario.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WALL STREET endured another somewhat dis couraging and apprehensive period last week as the first half of the year closed on a dis cordant downbeat. With the approach of the July 4 holiday, investor enthusiasm was tempered by two major adverse developments.

title: Florentine finish to Genovese dish
description: For refinement in Italian food, one looks to the North. Giuseppe Beppe Bellini, the Florentine art and antiques dealer, who is renowned for the splendor of his table, drew upon the complexity of Genovese cooking and the sub tlety of the Florentine cuisine for this artful masterpiece of a recipe. It derives from a traditional Genovese dish, which is no less flamboyantly prepared in its city of origin. The result is something like a fine pat, with the flavors and textures of many ingredients combined in each slice. But the method is different. A cima is stuffed and not layered. The most luxurious sausage in the world, its casing is veal breast and its forcemeat includes more veal (from the leg), sweetbreads and calf's brain for tex ture, mushrooms, peas, pine nuts, cheese and seasonings. Other Bernal recipes appear in his bilingual Italian and English cookbook, Food a la Florentine, done in collab oration with Naomi Barry, the American food writer. It is available at Rizzoli, 712 Fifth Avenue for $11.

title: Course Innovations In Nursing Schools
description: PRINCETONDiploma schools of professional nurs ing are coming up with inno vative programs to stay alive and they are succeeding according to spokesmen for the Association of Diploma Schools of Professional Nurs ing of New Jersey.

title: Three Novels and a Novella
description: Gilbert Sorrentino's new book is full of carefully planted instructions about how it must be read. Don't expect a story: There's no plot here to worry you. Forget verisimilitude: These people aren't real. I'm mak ing them up as they go along, any section that threatens to flesh them out will be excised. You need not look for development: This is not a novel. More a collection of bits and pieces  a slap here, a dash there, a couple of anecdotes mixed with gratuitous opinions.

title: On 44th St., He Clips; In Queens, He Chips
description: I had the feeling, after I wrote about my singing neighbor, that Harold Schon berg might break diplomatic relations with me. Then, after I did that piece on the Forest Hills little theater group, I was concerned that Clive Barnes might feel threatened. Why, even after I interviewed that Metropolitan Avenue bookbinder, I worried about the insecurity feelings of still another coworker, this one a hyphenated book reviewer.

title: Marsha Cohen and Robert Feyer to Wed
description: Miss Marsha Nan Cohen and Capt. Robert Paul Feyer, U.S.A.F., both lawyers, have made plans to be married in October.

title: ValueAdded Tax
description: ROMEMany Italians are going into debt these days to buy anything from a new car to a dozen demijohns of wine, fearful that all retail prices will go up sharply next January, when the new valueadded tax finally goes into effect.

title: THURLOE SQUARE DELAWARE VICTOR
description: STANTON, Del., July 1 Gordon Grayson's Roanoke Is land and William C. Robinson Jr.'s Thurloe Square, both light ly played, shared the honors today in the two divisions of the Rosemont Stakes at Dela ware Park. The race was lim ited to 3yearolds who had not won an open stakes at a mile or more.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemente's Second Home Second Run Gives Pirates a 43 Viotdry Over Cubs in 9th
description: PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) Roberto Clemente hit his second home run of the game follow ing Milt May's pinch single in the ninth inning, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4.3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today and keeping the Pirates atop the National League East stand ing.

title: NASSAU CASHIERS CONFUSED ON TAX
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 1Con sumers in Nassau County are being charged the state sales tax 60 per cent of the time on nontaxable items, thus paying several million dollars annu ally in taxes that they should not be paying, according to a survey of supermarkets, delica tessens and drugstores by the Nassau Office of Consumer Affairs.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, was hon ored yesterday by his House colleagues as the last of the bigtime savers in celebration of his 73d birthday. Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives, stood in the House to applaud him. The fiscal conservative, known for his stern and disapproving mien, broke into smiles.

title: Holyoke, Mass., Gets Grant
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., July 1 (AP) Holyloke has received word of the final approval for a $1.16million Federal grant for the third year of its Model Cities program.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONNothing, Voltaire wrote, is more annoying than to be obscure ly hangednothing, we may add in this enlightened century, than to be obscurely massacred. In the absence of any newspaper or TV men around to record what may be going on, one might say cynically that it is decreas ingly attractive to die for a cause.

title: Family Whose LifeStyle Has Always Been New
description: NORWALK, Conn.William and Ande Manners say they have never considered their way of life at all extraordinary. But their children do.

title: S.R.O. at Drive in Flea Market
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I.  Everyone heading for the Sunrise Theater these days is not necessarily a movie buff, for hundreds of antiquers, bargain hunters and Just plain junk fanatics are doing their weekend shopping at the theater's Swap n Shop flea market.

title: Town Acts on Colonial Grant
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.A small boat cruised near shore in Huntington Harbor recent ly while a bay constable photographed private piers. Weeks later the piers owners were asked to sign leases and pay rent on their dock fa cilities.

title: Television
description: IN case you hadn't noticed, the big Rough Diamond Sweepstakes is on with a vengeance. Ever since they hit it lucky over there at CBS, com ing up with the now legendary 500carat Bunker (or Archie, famous for the way it throws off the soft, green gleam of money under the Nielsen lamp), pros pectors at the other networks have been hacking up the talent turf in hopes of unearthing their own gems.

title: Fischer Seeks Delay
description: Bobby Fischer has asked for a twoday postponement until Tuesday of his cham pionship chess match with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union. Details, Page 31.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Shortly after 8 A.M. one recent day, Miss Jerri O'Brien was sitting alone in the grand ballroom of the Wal dorf Astoria Hotel. She is the research director of ABCFM spot sales and was the first of some 900 ad vertiser, agency and radio people who would be arriv ing for this sixth annual Ra dio Workshop.

title: U.S.A.C. Aims to Reschedule Schaefer 500 Later in Year
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 1 (AP) The executive committee of the United States Auto Club mulled over the problems sur rounding the Schaefer 500 to day, then issued a statement keeping alive the possibility of a championship race at Pocono International Raceway later this summer.

title: Marriage Held For Celia Gioia
description: ROCHESTER, July 1Miss Celia Elizabeth Gioia, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony John Gioia, was married here this afternoon to Edward John Riley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Riley of Bronxville. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed in the chapel at the Cenacle Convent by the Rev. Thomas Reddington.

title: Riva Ridge Captures $109,900 Hollywood Derby by a Neck With Bicker 2d
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 1 (UPI)Riva Ridge extended his dotnination over the nation's 3yearolds to the West Coast today as the Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes winner captured the 32d running of the $109,900 Hollywood Derby by a neck at Hollywood Park.

title: Wilkins Voices Doubt on Focus of Rights Drive in Last Decade
description: In a pensive, philosophical and hopeful but not too opti mistic mood, Roy Wilkins, executive director of the na tion's largest civil rights organi zation, sat in his office last week and expressed his doubts that the civil rights movement took the most productive di rection possible 10 years ago.

title: The Nation
description: Marylin Dobrolenski wept and prayed in her cell in Pennsylvania; Lucius Jackson Jr., in Georgia, pon dered his chances for parole, and Steve Suggs, a few doors down Georgia's death row from Jackson, allowed: I may be here the rest of my life, but it's life, and no man, wants to die. The news had come to the cellblocks crystalline clear: the Supreme Court had ruled on the death penalty at last, and there would be no bloodbath, after all.

title: The World
description: PARISThe agreement took months of tough bargaining, interrupted by frequent sniping between the two par ties. At the end, each side put some water in their wine, as the French say, and the French Communist and Social ist parties agreed last week to make common cause for the first time since a Socialist Premier threw five Com munist Ministers out of his Govern ment in 1947.

title: A NEW FARM AIDE TAKES STATE POST
description: ALBANY, July 1Frank A. Walkley, who took office today as the new State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, ex pressed concern about unioni zation of farm workers in the state and possible strikes during harvest seasons.

title: When I Scream With My Horn
description: LEANDRO GATO BAR BIERI, who will be ap pearing with his quar tet at the Newport Jazz Festival in New York Wednesday afternoon, comes from Rosario, Argentina, the birthplace of Ch Guevara and a provincial capital known for its smoldering revolutionary movement. He plays the tenor saxophone with the lyrical fire typical of the poets of Latin Ameri ca, and he is a musical revolutionary in that he is one of a handful of musi cians hailing from outside the U.S. to bring rich new source material, and new dimensions, to jazz. The material includes the folk lore, rhythms, and popular music of South America; the dimensions are his concepts of Third World Music and of a musical narrative struc ture derived in part from films, especially those of the Brazilian, Glauber Roachas.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Women Golfers Above Par in Dress
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 1Along about the 15th hole in tomorrow's televised final round of the United States Women's Open here, a lot of the girls will start digging into their golf bags for lip sticks and combs.

title: Pop
description: THE corpus of Lenny Bruce is being official ly introduced as suit able material for aca demic dissection. This fall, a course on his life and work (including presumably his police record) will be one of the offerings of the De partment of Psychology at the University of Colorado in Boulder. Mr. Bruce, how ever, requires interdiscipli nary attention; and at its annual meeting in New York last December, the American Historical Association staked its claim by scheduling a special session on Lenny Bruce: AmeNeon. Room is also being made for Lenny in lectures and seminars on sociology and Constitutional law.

title: Strikes in U.S. During May Lowest in 30Year Period
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The number of strikes and the total of workers involved last month was the lowest for any May in 30 years, the Labor Department has reported.

title: ONEWORD ERROR REVERSES VERDICT
description: A conviction for destroying draft records has been reversed on an appeal here because the trial judge sent a highly prej udicial message to the jurors during their deliberations.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThere must have been times last week when Senator George McGovern, the father of Demo cratic convention reform, wanted to deny parentage, looking out over the political havoc that his new guidelines had wrought and finding the prospect something less than pleasing.

title: S. M. Schwebel, Law Professor, To Wed Miss Louise Killander
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lennart Kil lander of Adamsberg, Swe den, have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Ingrid Killander, to Stephen M. Schwebel of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Schwebel of New York.

title: jazz:
description: The Newport Jazz Festival got off to a lopsided start in New York yesterday. Opening its nineday run with two concerts, both held at 5 P.M., one at Carnegie Hall, the offier at Philharmonic Hall, the Festival program at Phil harmonic Hall attracted al most a full house while Carnegie Hall was less than halffilled. Both programs were repeated at 9 P.M.

title: ANDREWS
description: CENTERPORT, L. I., July 1 Stephen Andrews in a Star and Bill Uhl in a Lightning were the only major class unbeaten skip pers after 65 boats sailed with the Centerport Yacht Club to day in the opener of the Tri Clubs Yacht Racing Association Fourth of July holiday regatta on Huntington and Northport bays.

title: Royals Top Rangers in 11th
description: KANSAS CITY, July 1 (AP) Gail Hopkins oneout pinch single in the bottom of the 11th carried the Kansas City Royals to a 32 victory, over the Texas Rangers today.

title: PROMOTION NEAR FOR SCHOOL CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  The White House is on the verge of promoting Dr. Sidney P. Marland, the Commissioner of Education, to be Assistant Secretary of Education in the Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare, a post that has been vacant for two years.

title: China Seems to Be Planning to Improve Relations With New Japanese Leaders
description: TOKYO, July 1The Chinese leaders in Peking are giving strong evidence that they are considering an improvement in relations with Japan after a new Japanese premier takes over next week, succeeding Eisaku Sato.

title: Robert Livingston To Wed Miss Gore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chester Gore of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eloise Gore, to Robert J. Livingston. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Livingston of Wood mere, L. I.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON Almost as if the North Vietnamese offensive had never hap pened, President Nixon last week an nounced another troop withdrawal 10,000 men over the next two months, to bring the total number of American forces in Vietnam to 39,000 by Sept. 1.

title: A NEW FARM AIDE TAKES STATE POST
description: ALBANY, July 1Frank A. Walkley, who took office today as the new State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, ex pressed concern about unioni zation of farm workers in the state and possible strikes during harvest seasons.

title: Flood Victims Can File Amended Tax Forms
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  An amendment to the Fed eral debtlimit law providing aid to flood victims requires that, to qualify for quick re lief, they must file amended 1971 returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It had been a vintage year on the Col lege gridiron and the pro football draft for 1965 reflected it. Not in ages had the play forpay operatives been able to package such sparkle and effervescence for future corkpopping. Tastiest of the champagne offerings were Joe Namath, Tucker Fred erickson and Gale Sayers. Also plucked from the vines and ready to bubble in that vintage, year were Dick Butkus, Ken Willard, Mike Curtis, Fred Biletni koff, Craig Morton, Ralph Neely, Lance Rentzel, Donny Anderson and so many others. By curious coincidence, none of the top three who seemingly were des tined for matchless excellence have been able to sustain it. Much too often bad knees have turned flat the champagne sparkle of Namath, Frederickson and Say ers, the stickouts of that extraordinary draft group. And now Frederickson has reludantly, announced his retirement from the sport at the still sprightly age of 29. He's the sante Frederickson who was the first to be named in the National Football League draft, the New York Giants even picking hint ahead of Namath, Sayers and all the other superstars.

title: Time Bomb Reported as Cause Of Airliner Crash in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 (AP)A time bomb in a suitcase destroyed a Cathay Pacific Airways jetliner over South Vietnam on June 15, re liable sources said today.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Top State G.O.P. Officials Will Yield Delegate Seats
description: Governor Rockefeller and other top New York Repub licans will give up their dele gateatlarge seats at the Re publican National Convention to women, youths, Negroes and Puerto Ricans in an effort to increase the representation of these groups in the New York delegation.

title: Education
description: ATLANTIC CITY  One of the signs of change at the convention of the National Education Associa tion last week was the announce ment from the podium one day that the Gay Teachers Caucus would be meeting for lunch.

title: Humphrey Casts His Vote for Dick; Dick Allen, That Is
description: Political and showbusiness celebrities are voting, along with other baseball fans, in the annual election to deter mine starting lineups for the AllStar game, scheduled for Atlanta July 25. Voting ends July 9.

title: Governor Faces Dark Days
description: TRENTONThe last few days in New Jersey have un doubtedly represented the darkest and most agonizing period in Governor Cahill's first years in office.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONSFiftyfour times since the sixday war of June, 1967, the United Nations had voted on issues of war and peace in the Middle East. Last week it voted for the 55th timepass ing a resolution, similar to many others in the past, condemning a new re taliatory strike by Israel.

title: Art: A Sense of Place Is Theme of L. I. Show
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. The ecology rage was bound to make its way into the art world. Throughout this year, museums and galleries all over the country have mounted shows that were inspired from a variety of ecological themes.

title: Scherr Wins Soling Class In East of Rye Regatta
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 Leading at every mark of a 7.7mile Gold Cup course off Indian Harbor Yacht Club to day, Robert E. Scherr won the Soling Clash race with Auslese by 61 seconds and close to 200 yards, in the season's. 13th championship regatta for Yacht Racing. Association fleets based East of Rye on Long Island Sound.

title: U.S. OLYMPIC UNIT TO BACK CONVICTS
description: Bobby Lee Hunter and Gene White, prisoner athletes who are seeking places on the Unit ed States Olympic team, will have the complete backing of the United States Olympic Committee if they succeed in the trials.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Every Day Was Ladies' Day
description: THE pretty young woman on the screen is fend ing off a man's ad vances. As he becomes more any ardent, she knocks him to the ground and kicks him sharply and repeatedly in the groin. Cheer from a 99 per cent facade audience.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Isaac Hits 186.277 M.P.H., Gains Firecracker Pole Spot
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 1 (UPI)Bobby Isaac, who won the Firecracker 400 last year with the hood on his Dodge flapping in the breeze, took no chances today as he won the pole position for the July 4 NASCAR race.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The Doctor Lykes, the largest general cargo ship under the American flag, is heading down the Mississippi River to day on her maiden commercial voyage to Continental European ports.

title: 4 Charged With Murder In Motorcycle Club Clash
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 1 (AP) Four members of the Storm Troopers, a Durham motorcycle club, were charged with murder today in what the police said was an ambush of a Florida based motorcycle club.

title: What Agnes Left Behind
description: CORNING, N. Y.It was something that had to be seen to be believed.

title: The New Barbarians
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex.More students are attending college and more money is being spent on higher education by their parents and by society than ever before. But there is great danger that much of this investment of time and money is being squandered because many college factilties and college ad ministrations are intellectually irre sponsible and, incompetent.

title: STATE DATA SHOW 20,000 JOBS OPEN
description: Although unemployment in New York State remains high, 6.1 per cent, the State Employ ment Service currently lists thousands of jobs available in a wide variety of fields.

title: The World
description: LONDONIs a ship that rides low er in the water each day floating or sinking?

title: What's New in Theater?
description: MAN OF LA MANCHA, a revival of the musical by Dale Wasserman, got nine favorable reviews (Thomp son, Times; Watt, News; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI, Rollin, NBCTV, Sanders, ABCTV; Bookspan, WPIX) and one negative review (Tallmer, Post).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman observing, preserving, surviving
description: Maybe the spirit of the times is catching up to Eleanor Ross Taylor, and Welcome Eumenides, her sec ond book, will find readers waiting for it. Her first, Wilderness of Ladies, published in 1960, recog nized by a handful of people includ ing the late Randall Jarrell, has re mained an underground book, fierce, rich and difficult, though it seems less difficult with every passing year, just as Emily Dickinson does. In that book are two poems I've carried about with me for a decade as a kind of secret knowledge and reinforce ment: Woman as Artist and Sis ter. They, like many of Eleanor Taylor's poems, speak of the under ground life of women, the Southern white Protestant woman in particu lar, the womanwriter, the woman in the family, coping, hoarding, preserv ing, observing, keeping up appear ances, seeing through the myths and hypocrisies, nursing the sick, con spiring with sisterwomen, possessed of a will to survive and to see others survive. (The Southern black woman and the Southern white woman share a history and a knowledge that we are barely on the edge of exploring.)

title: Scientists Capture Norwalk Agent, A Flu Virus That Causes Diarrhea
description: Scientists at the National Institutes of Health have cap tured but not yet identified the Norwalk agent, a virus that causes some cases of one of man's most common ail ments.

title: What's All This Talk
description: AT 10 P.M. on March 3, Atsushi Kurahara, a 35yearold Japanese advertising execu tive, was stabbed in the heart and robbed of $40 on 103d Street between Broadway and West End Avenue. The murder, which received little notice in New York, caused a stir in Japan. Dear Mayor Lindsay, I heard that when you visited Tokyo last year you expressed a particular interest in the sub ject of Japan's public peace and order, wrote Mrs. Kurahara from Japan, asking for an explanation of the senseless killing. I think now I have a deeper insight into what you might have meant at the time.

title: Suzan Lind Married
description: HAWORTH, N. J., July 1 Miss Suzah Lind, daughter of Mrs. Edith Lind of Haworth and Frederick A. Lind of Or mond Beach, Fla., was mar ried here this afternoon to Jonathon Baron Roll, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Carl Roll of Alpine. The Rev. Dana Green performed the cere mony in the First Congre gational Church.

title: The World
description: BELFASTSgt. Malcolm Banks was a workingclass British soldier from Leeds. In his spare time in Belfast the 29yearold sergeant was building a playroom for handicapped children and writing every day to his wife, Janet, the mother of their two sons, seven years and 18 months.

title: New York
description: The payoff was set for last Monday morning. On a construction site in the Bronx, $1,000 had been assembled in crumpled, worn ten and twentydollar bills, the last installment from a builder to Buildings Department in spectors.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe most meaningful aspect of the latest international monetary flareup, according to some thoughtful people here, is the one that has been com mented on the least.

title: 200 DRIVERS TO RACE AT LIME ROCK PARK
description: A tradition that began in 1957 will bring its own kind of fireworks to the Lime Rock Park road racing circuit in Lakeville, Conn., over the week end when more than 200 sports Car Club of America drivers vie for national championship points.

title: Saigon Courts Punish 42 Newsmen in a Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1The South Vietnam ese Government announced today that 42 sentences had been meted out since June 22 against Vietnamese news papermen, including heavy fines and prison terms up to one month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your article on the mas sive Welfare Island project failed to note the travesty such a project will commit against New York history. Your article noted the pres ervation plans for certain minor historical landmarks, but failed to mention major ones whose future is uncer tain.

title: Art
description: THE art scene in Paris this summer is unusu ally rich in exhibi tions, yet remarkably arid so far as signs of new life are concerned. It is an art scene of interest primarily to the cultural tourist and the art historian. It offers very little to the critic or col lector, much less to the work ing artist, in search of lively new talent or interesting ideas. One is reminded, yet again, of the extent to which Paris continues to live off its past.

title: Gibson Wins No. 7 in Row for St. Louis in Opener
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) Donn Clendenon hit his third home run of the season in the fourth inning to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 1.0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and a sweep of their twilight night doubleheader today.

title: PERMIT IS DENIED TO CITY DAY CAMP
description: NEW ROCHELLE, July 1A federally financed, New York Cityrun day camp, scheduled to open here next Wednesday, has been denied a certificate of residency by the New Rochelle Health Department on the ground it has inadequate sani tary facilities.

title: Softball Tourney Slated
description: The Metropolitan fastpitch softball tournament will be held at Colonel Charles Young Park, 144th Street and Lenox Ave nue, on the weekends of July 1516, 2223 and 2930. Teams from all five boroughs will compete.

title: The World
description: SIMLA, IndiaThis pine  scented way station on the ancient Hindustan Tibet road, chosen by the former Brit ish rulers of India as their retreat from the torrid summers of Calcutta and New Delhi, has been the setting for a number of historic conferences affecting the subcontinent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Change Sought in DayCare Law

title: Ryan Beats A's, 53
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 1  Nolan Ryan, backed by third inning homers by Ken Berry and Leo Cardenas, struck out 16 and pitched a fivehitter as the California Angels defeated the Oakland A's, 53, tonight.

title: Peter Gordy to Marry Anne Trafford Sept. 9
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., July 1The engagement of Miss Anne Trafford to Peter Ellis Gordy has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Perry D. Trafford Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Gordy Jr. of Con way, Ark.

title: CITY SOUNDS YIELD AN OPUS BY CAGE
description: This is the way you can make your own music. All you have to do is open your ears and listen. The advice comes from John Cage in a film about him. He has composed a fourmovement piece by going to four places in New York and holding up the microphone to take in the environmental sound, and the viewer shares the experience with him.

title: Stamps
description: WHAT with our own recent rainy sea son, and summer being with us, col lectors could be interested in cooling off with thoughts of the Antarctic. Operation, Deep Freeze is on and the United States Naval Support Force Antarctica is once more offering mail from the South Pole for those inter ested collectors and non collectors alike.

title: Abrams Leaves Vietnam After Transforming War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30Gen. Creighton W. Abrams slipped quietly out of Saigon this week after his fifth year of duty in Vietnam. There were no farewell parties, no public changeofcommand cere monies. His departure was marked only by the presenta tion of a medal, under strict security, by President Nguyen Van Thieu in the Presidential Palace.

title: Keino Seeks 2 Olympic Titles
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 1 (AP)Kipchoge Keino of Ken ya will compete in the 1,500 meter run and the 3,000meter steeplechase at the Olympic Games in Munich, Germany, it was announced today.

title: George Sand Was At Home to Life, Work And Love at Nohant
description: NOHANT, France  A woman, said Virginia Woolf, who had a substantial inherited income, must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fic tion. But, she added, that leaves the great problem of the true nature of wo man and the true nature of fiction unsolved.

title: The Nation
description: The President said he had no doubts about the value of public television, and that he was committed to it in principle. But last Friday, he vetoed the bill passed by Congress to increase the funds for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: The Moscow Summit:
description: AT 4:29 A.M. on Tuesday, May 23the first morning that an American President awoke in Moscowa United States Secret Service agent was startled to see Richard Nixon, dressed casually in a maroon sports jacket, pass the agent's post on the way to a Kremlin stroll.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Traffic on the New Yorkto Washington Metroliners is up 53 per cent since a year ago, and pleased Government offi cials are looking to a further increase in the highspeed rail service.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Decisions ent Awry
description: Corporations last year de cided it was time to take the big bath.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ATLANTADemocrats here are facing a frustrating prob lem in Atlanta's Fifth Con gressional District race.

title: Caroline Lanford Married Upstate
description: CASTLETONONHUDSON N. Y., July 1Miss Caroline Aldrich Lanford, an editor in the college department of Harper & Row, publishers, was married here at noon today to William D. East man, an editor in chief at Harper & Row.

title: President Announces Pacts on Shipbuilding
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)President Nixon for mally announced today con tracts worth $660million for construction of 16 new mer chant marine ships, including three huge tankers, to be built in five American ship yards.

title: Social Announcements
description: Prigozen

title: Nursing Home Is Set For Brooklyn Hospital
description: A $17million 406bed nursing home will be con structed to adjoin the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. The 12story build ing, to be situated at Hicks Street between Atlantic Ave nue and Pacific Street, will be completed in two years.

title: SOVIET IS REVIVING ACUPUNCTURE USE
description: MOSCOW, July 1The So viet Union, evidently stung by the attention given to Chinese medicine in the United States, has taken a fresh look at acu puncture.

title: Athletic Director Is Chosen
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., July 1 (UPI)  Mel R. Sheehan has been appointed athletic director of the University of Missouri Columbia, succeeding Wilbur N. (Sparky) Stalcup. Stalcup died April 21. The 48yearold Sheehan was a football and track allAmerica at Missouri and currently is superintendent of the Normandy School district in St. Louis County.

title: Modern Art Museum Stays Open While Security Guards Strike
description: Fiftytwo security guards walked out at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday after ne gotiations over wages broke down. However, the institution remained open, with security supervisors and managerial staff members manning the beats.

title: Games
description: Most jobs are dull. The oldtime hew ers of wood and drawers of water have sent their children to college so that the graduates can be wholesale dis tributors of wood and water or ad vertising account executives for the products (The wood with added ZR3 The water doctors prefer). Natu rally enough, the, holders of all these jobs look with, admiration at the men and women who play games for their living. But it is an admiration laced with a biting envy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Thai Connection
description: WASHINGTONA major killer is loose in New York City and last year alone it claimed ever 1,000 lives. Heroin threatens our social order. The statis tics are frightening: Over 250,000 heroin addicts, and more than 50 per cent of the street crimes committed in New York City are drugrelated offenses.

title: The Doorman Who Is a She
description: For a while, according to Lynwood Glenn, the building superintendent, the tenants of the Manhattan East Apartments couldn't walk past the new doorman without doing a dou bletake.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Farmers In Suffolk Also Tired Of the Rain
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.Suffolk County farmers are the last people in the world to admit that, into their lives, too, a little rain must fall. But so far as this season is con cerned, they have had it.

title: Kekich Sets Down Indians On 5 Hits for 7th Victory
description: For the first time in nearly a year, Mike Kekich finished something that he started yes terday when he pitched the New York Yankees to a 51 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Astros Defeat Braves, 42
description: HOUSTON, July 1 (AP)Lee May cracked his 14th home run of the season and Doug Rader smacked a tworun single to night to lead the Houston As tros to a 42 victory over Atlanta in a National League baseball game.

title: How to Make and Sell a Candle
description: Once again, Shirley Glubok con vinces us that art need not be dif ficult, this time with a captivating pictorial record of our nation during its first 50 years, bursting with curios ity and optimism. If the mood of America has soured rather than mel lowed with age, if we have grown older but no wiser, this at least is how we looked at the beginning.

title: No Concorde for El Al
description: TEL AVIV, July 1 (Reuters) El Al, the Israeli airline has decided not to purchase any Concordes, it was announced today.

title: Golden Eagle Bill Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The Senate has sent to Presi dent Nixon a bill extending in definitely the $10 annual Golden Eagle passport to admit a car load of persons to national parks and other recreation areas.

title: Newcombe Defeats Pasarell And Gains Final, 63, 75
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1 (UPI) John Newcombe defeated Charlie Pasarell, 63, 75, to gain the final of the $50,000 Holton tennis tournament for contract pros tonight.

title: Power: To Use Or Not to Use
description: WASHINGTON  In re sponse to the power shortage in some regions, the electric utility industry has been re ducing promotional advertis ing and making an un paralleled effort to teach consumers to conserve power.

title: The Nude Bathing Scene
description: FRANKLY, I didn't know what to say when the editors asked me if I would go to one of the nude beaches that are becoming popular in America and write an article about my experi ences. As a girl reporter I've been in some unusual situa tions, but this was more than I had bargained for. Devout believer though I am in the new journalism, with all its personal involvement, I didn't relish skinnydipping in the Pacific with a lot of freaky Peeping Toms.

title: Mary went down and came up again
description: Mary Barnes, who could have end ed up a statistic, became instead a productive, successful artist and a folkheroine of the psychiatric left. Already well into the abyss that is the common lot of the schizophrenic, she met R. D. Laing, responded to his charisma and joined Kingsley Hall, the new therapeutic community founded by Laing on the principle that the psychiatric treatment center must be restructured so that mad ness is fully accepted.

title: Phooey on Fritz the Cat
description: HEY, yeah, the 1960's  happy times, heavy times, in tones the narrator of Fritz the Cat against a watercolor rendition of Times Square before the skinflick invasion had deci mated the Great White Way. The sight of an Astor bill board peddling The Bible, coupled with the sound track's opening monologue from a hardhat animal com plaining about his hippie daughter, suggests that this animated feature intends to look affectionately at a dec ade that already seems as adventurous and exciting as America's pioneer days.

title: Prince Weds Princess in Spain
description: MADRID, July 1Prince Alexander of Yugoslavia and Princess Marie Gloria Orleans Braganca, greatgreatgrand daughter of Emperor Peter II of Brazil, were married to night in a Serbian Orthodox ceremony in a small town outside Seville under the Andalusian moonlight.

title: Big Oil Spill Is Checked
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., July 1 (UPI)A sixmilliongallon oil spill that threatened the water supplies in a fivecounty area of southeastern Pennsylvania, including Philadelphia, has been contained by cleanup crews.

title: Susan B. Eaton And Daniel Oot Marry Upstate
description: DEWITT, N. Y., July 1 Miss Susan Bailey Eaton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Whittington Eaton of Manlius, was married this afternoon to Daniel Oot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Oot of Kirkville. The Rev. Dr. Alexander C. Carmichel, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Chrysostom Gardner, a Roman Catholic priest, per formed the ceremony in the Dewitt Community Church.

title: Mrs. Koch Is Bride Of Dr. McCracken
description: Mrs. Sally Hall Koch of Scarsdale, N.Y., widow of Walter Herbert Koch, was married here yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Robert James Mc Cracken, minister of the Riv erside Church from 1946 until his retirement in 1967.

title: Burke Hedges on Future Of Houk With the Yanks
description: Michael Burke denied yester day that the New York Yankees were for sale, but he did not completely dispel re ports that Ralph Houk might not return as manager in 1973.

title: Susan Stevic Bride of Austin Godfrey
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 1In Faith United Methodist Church here this morning Miss Susan Marie Stevic, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stevic of Marshall villa, was married to Austin Eastman Godfrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Rawson Godfrey of Lloyd Neck in Huntington, L. I. The Rev. Douglas S. Al bert performed the ceremony.

title: Bills Swamp NonWelfare Couple
description: Beulah and Ralph Wat kins did not know that a pothole lay ahead of their 1965 Oldsmobile as they were driving home through Queens Village after church and Sunday dinner at the home of friends.

title: Music
description: WHAT is the lowest form of musi cal life? No, wait. Before you start to name names, let us consider a nonhuman candi date, the American campaign song. Though political music on the whole stands even lower on the quality ladder than military music, at which so much fun has been poked, the American va riety seems to inhabit a specially pro found level of inanity. At one time, we are told, the campaign song actually in fluenced elections in this country, but it has been on a steady slide into feeble ness for at least 50 years, pushed along by radio, television and other aids to mass sophistication.

title: City Island's Own Ambulance Memorializes Dead TeenAger
description: The residents of City Island, off the northeastern corner of the Bronx, dedicated the is land's first ambulance yester day with a smalltown parade and outdoor ceremony before the 126yearold Trinity Meth odist Church.

title: The Great British Novelas if there weren't lots of them
description: For a certain type of novelist, the temptations to play at being God are immense. The whole of human history, the vastnesses of the future, the range and complexity of man, the infinite variations of the imagi nationhow rich and pliable they all are, how various and exciting! The trouble is that a novel is a finite object, created by a mortal. To be a novelist one actually needs to write a novel, which in volves a process of selection rather more limited than that available to the Creator. There are some novel ists who never quite become recon ciled to this fact.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 1 (Reuters)  President Nixon's special representative, John B. Connally will meet President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto Thursday, it was announced today. Mr. Con nally is due to arrive Wednes day for a twoday visit during a world tour.

title: Bridge
description: THE first great scandal in the his tory of card games occurred a century and a half ago when Baron de Ros, England's premier Baron, was accused of manipulating the deal while playing whist at a leading London club. The eyewitness evi dence against him was substantial, and he lost a libel suit against a newspaper in spite of bringing medi cal evidence that his arthritic fingers lacked the necessary dexterity. A wit provided an epitaph: Here lies de Ros, waiting for the last trump.

title: News of Dogs
description: Whether to have a handler is a question the exhibitor frequently faces.

title: GEORGE K. HUBBARD JR.
description: George K. Hubbard Jr., who retired last December as an executive of Maher Terminals, a stevedoring company, died on Friday at his home in Gar den City, L.I. He was 71 years old.

title: MISS BLUNT WINS AT DOYLESTOWN
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 1 Carlene Blunt, who spent more than two year on the side lines watching her opposition as a result of a back operation, rode Silver Lining to victory in the intermediate jumper knock down and out class today at the Gaudeamus horse show.

title: GHANA SPRINTER SETS A.A.U. MARK
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 1 (AP) Alice Annum, a 21yearold student from Ghana, broke Wilma Rudolph's 12yearold meet record in the 200meter dash tonight at the National Amateur Athletic Union wom en's track and field champion ships.

title: Vacationers Clog Highways in Metropolitan Area
description: Highways in the metropoli tan area, including the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway as far north as Albany, were clogged with heavy traffic yes terday as vacationers continued the Fourth of July weekend holiday.

title: Directory for Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  A service directory for the Town of Hempstead is avail able free by writing to the Office of Public Information, Hempstead Town Hall Main Street, or by calling 4895000 (Ext. 391). The directory con tains more than 80 frequent ly called numbers, including the Town Animal Shelter, the Board of Assessors and the Internal Revenue Service.

title: GandhiBhutto Talks Extended for Day
description: SIMLA, India, July 1The stalled conference between President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India was ex tended an extra day today, with subordinate officials still disa greeing on a formula to settle differences between the two sides.

title: Wottle Ties Record In 800
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 1Dave Wottle, who says I'm not a halfmiler, equaled the world record in the 800meter run to night.

title: HOSPITAL UNION ASSAILS LINDSAY
description: Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199, the Drug and Hos pital Union, yesterday declared that Mayor Lindsay was pro voking a citywide hospital strike next Thursday and that the Mayor was relinquishing responsibility in the dispute.

title: ShoppingCenter Industry Hails Court
description: When the Supreme Court upheld the right of owners of largo suburban shopping centers to bar political pam phleteers from their premises last month, it may also have given the owners the right to decide which political can didates they would allow on the premises, according to shopping center owners.

title: Growth in Southern Counties
description: At the southern end of New Jersey, two counties are reg istering brisk growth, but in contrasting ways.

title: Tigers Beat Orioles, Behind Lolich to Stretch Division Lead to 2 Games
description: DETROIT, July 1 (AP) Mickey Lolich became the first 13game winner in the major leagues and Al Kaline snapped a scoreless tie with a home run in the sixth inning, spark ing the Detroit Tigers to a 20 victory today over the Balti more Orioles.

title: Audrey Goldberg to Wed
