description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nor man Goldberg of Fresh Mead ows, Queens, of the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Audrey Dee Goldberg, to Jay Peterfreund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Peterfreund of Floral Park, L. I. Miss Gold berg was graduated this year from the State University at Albany. Her fianc is a grad uate of Syracuse University, class of '71.

title: June Rain Not a Record
description: To the surprise of some New Yorkers, last month was not the wettest June on record. With rain on all but eight of the month's 30 days, an un official monthly total of 9.16 inches was reached. The wet test June, with 9.78 inches of rain, was in 1903, the National Weather Service said. The heaviest rainfall recorded here in any month was 16.85 inches, in September, 1882.

title: WALL STREET
description: Rumor had it that Paul Kolton, president of the American Stock Exchange, was among the latest of the possibles considered for the new position as fulltime chairman of the Big Board. But apparently his name was initially rejected.

title: Irish Sweepstakes Derby Goes To Steel Pulse, 101, by Head
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, July 1(AP)Steel Pulse, a 101 shot, drew away in the final half mile today and won the Irish Sweepstakes Derby. American owned Roberto, the whiner of the English Derby, finished far back.

title: I Am Elijah Thrush
description: Even these days, the characters in James Purdy's novella (night be said to have uncommon sexual in clinations. Millicent de Frayne has lived through eight decades, six hus bands and countless lovers, but she now prefers to draw off the semen of adolescents with a siphon. This does not, however, slow her 60year pursuit of Elijah Thrush, the ancient pederast, charlatan and mime. Milli cent has just hired Albert Pegg, a black man of muddled eroticism, to write her memoir and to spy on Elijah. Although Albert doesn't much want the job, he needs money to house a golden eagle that regularly feeds an an open wound near his navel. Eventually Albert is seduced by Millicent and Elijah, but learns that the mime's heart really belongs to his mute greatgrandson, the Bird of Heaven. At the close, Albert kid naps the boy and tries to escape with Elijah on a ship called the Queen Dick. But Millicent traps the three males, marries Elijah, serves Albert's eagle among the wedding meats, and skips off to sleep with the boatswain. Sent back to shore alone, Albert appears on stage at the mime's theater and announces: I am  Elijah Thrush.

title: 8 CYCLISTS CHOSEN TO OLYMPIC TEAM
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 1 (AP) Trials for United States Olym pic cycling team ended tonight with the additions of eight cy clistsfive of them from Cali forniato round out the squad of 14, plus two alternates.

title: Car Pollution Tests Begin Wednesday
description: TRENTON  New Jersey will step up its battle against auto pollution on Wednesday. Beginning that day, a 30sec ond test of an auto's ex haust system will become part of the regular motor vehicle inspection routine, under terms of Chapter 15 of the State Air Pollution Con trol Code.

title: The Legends of George McGovern
description: THE Rise of George McGovern is sure to be recorded in political history as one of the great triumphs of propaganda and myth making.

title: 3 Anti  Women's Lib Women Run for Mayor
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThere are three candidates for Mayor of this township, the fastest growing in the state. The three seeking the $3,500a year post have widely diverse backgrounds, but they have at least one thing in common all three are women.

title: High Lead Content in Plates Reported
description: Tests conducted by the Mon roe County Health Department in Rochester have found a high lead content in a popular line of dinnerware.

title: IN THE NATION
description: It may look good in the headlines that the Supreme Court has barred the death penalty as it is now administered in the United States; nevertheless this welcome but limited step ought not to deflect attention from the rest of what the Supreme Court unfortunately did this week.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE COMMON MARKET nations agreed to defend fixed parities of members' currencies by buying more dollars, if necessary.  The I.M.F. agreed to form a Committee of 20 to negotiate reform of the world mone tary system  The pound ended a hectic week of trading at $2.44, more than 6 per cent below its old parity. The dollar also weakened.  Both Switzerland and West Germany adopted measures designed to prevent an inflow of hot money.

title: Don't Blame Delphine
description: SUDDENLY the circuit went dead. The play, so light it kept floating up instead of down, had been bobbling through space for an act and a quarter, quite merrily, virtu ally without flinching though it was rumored to have been in trouble out of town. The performersthe only two it containedhad been in cool, effer vescent control, making arabesques on the thin ice with infinite aplomb, hold ing their heads and the champagne glasses high. They looked as though they had a winner and knew it. Then everything stopped.

title: Steinkraus Is Victor At Aachen Horse Show
description: AACHEN, Germany, July 1 (UPI)Bill Steinktaus, cap tain of the United States Olympic Equestrian Team, rode Main Spring to victory today in a Class S event at the Aachen international horse show.

title: AROUND THE
description: Keep up with fruit tree spray programs. Re sow rows where radish, bean and lettuce have been harvested. Pinch back petunias and snap dragons if they are getting tall and leggy.  Use spot spray such as aerosol herbicides to de stroy broadleaved weeds  plantain or dande lion. Set lawn mower no less than one and onehalf inches or try two inches for summer cut.

title: Virginia Barry Is Wed to Roger Gross
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 1Miss Virginia Marie Barry was married here this morn ing to Roger Sullivan Gross by Msgr. John Paul Haverty in the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration. The monsignor officiated at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York in 1943 when the bride's parents, Mrs. William David Barry of Crestwood and the late Mr. Barry, were married. The bridegroom's parents are Mrs. Marion Gross of Pleasantville and Lawrence Thomas Gross of Bedford Hills, a lawyer. Mrs. Gross is managing editor of The Scarsdale Inquirer, a weekly newspaper.

title: The Nation
description: Normally, when Congress is asked by the Administration to approve an increase in the nation's debt ceiling, the reaction is one of polite disinterest. But last week, as President Nixon sought to raise the debt limit to $450 billion, Washington was treated to the spectacle of intense Congressional ex citement over the measure. In the House, the lively debate was punctu ated with shouts of Vote! Vote!

title: Laments in Wayne
description: WAYNE  Many residents of this suburb where tropical storm Agnes exacted $10 million in property damage, are up in arms over what they call 30 years of de lays in controlling the flood prone Passaic River.

title: Art
description: EATS is the title of an attractive and amusing  perhaps one had better avoid the word, tasteful  summer exhibition at the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I. The theme of EATS is food in works of the fine and decorative arts. Or ganized by Robert R. Littman, director of the gallery, the show includes some 119 items  paintings, sculptures, prints, photographs, Lalique boxes, Tuscarora Indian dolls, Beauvais tapestries and so on. There are even a few onceedible collectors items loaves of bread timeencap sulated in a cube of plastic by the contemporary French sculptor Arman, and a three breasted gingerbread woman by, an anonymous Italian baker.

title: The Nation
description: The offduty Transport plainclothes man spotted a man with a snubnosed revolver stuck in his belt. The scene: The crowded platform of the IRT sub way station at 163d Street and Hunts Point Avenue, The Bronx. The action: Patrolman John Skagen, 33, ordered the suspect to spread his hands against a wall, but the man whipped the gun from his waistband and fired two shots. Patrolman Skagen fell, mortally wounded.

title: Miss Gleskova Ties Mark
description: BUDAPEST, July 1 (AP) Eva Gleskova of Czechoslo vakia equaled the world record of 11 seconds today in the women's 100meter dash during a track and field meet between Czechoslovakia and Hungary. Her time tied the mark shared by three others, including Wyo mia Tyus of the United States and Chi Cheng of Taiwan.

title: L.I. School Budget Voted
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., July 1  A budget of $12,789,453 for the Herricks School District was passed Thursday night by a vote of 1,300 to 1,125. It would raise the school tax rate from $13,70 to $14.30 for each $100 of assessed valuation. Also approved was a $100,000 bond issue to install fire safety and fireprevention equipment.

title: Harvard Lightweight Crew and Kent Eight Capture Cups at Henley Regatta
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, July 1 (AP)An inexperi enced freshman eight from Har vard University rowed like sea soned oarsmen today and won the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal regatta.

title: Peace and Religious Festival Begins in Colorado Despite Official Opposition
description: GRANBY, Colo., July 1  After months of turmoil and at tempts to block them, young people by the thousands were quietly gathering today near Strawberry Lake in a mountain valley west of here for what they termed a religious fes tival.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Congress has sent to Presi dent Nixon a $158.38million measure to improve Coast Guard programs and author ize funds for the service.

title: ARMS RUNNING PLOT IS LAID TO 9 IN SOUTH
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 2 (AP) Federal officials have ar rested nine men Texas and Louisiana on charges of con spiring to smuggle munitions to Mexico for the overthrow of a foreign country, presum ably Cuba.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAINTCLOUD, France, July 2Rheingold, a plain looking and modestly bred colt who was barely nosed out by Roberto in the Epsom Derby, trounced the field today in winning the $246,000 Grand Prix de SaintCloud.

title: SlowPitch Softball Is Fast With Runs
description: BALDWIN, L. I., July 2 The pitch floats down from an are as high as 10feet, coming in as big as a pump kin. Jim Galloway at home plate is relaxed, muscles apparently limp, watching the ball as if he had all the time in the world. A second later the ball is gone, beyond the 290foot fence, bouncing on top of a hill where it scat ters picnickers.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MUNICH, July 2 (AP)The United States, gold medalist in 1968, was put in Group A in the draw for the Olympic basketball tournament today. Others in Group A are Japan, Cuba, Australia, Egypt, Czechoslovakia and Brazil.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, July 2 (AP)Sir Francis Chichester, Britain's gallant old seadog, was beaten in the trartsAtlantic single handed yacht race by a painkilling drug that gave him hallucinations and left him weak and exhausted.

title: Enemy Forces Shell Hue For 4 Hours, Killing 10
description: SAIGON, South, Vietnam, Monday, July 3 (Reuters) North Vietnamese troops shelled the city of Hue for four hours yesterday, killing or wounding about 50 persons, military sources said.

title: Myopia, Paced by Andrew, Beats Bethpage in Polo, 115
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 2 Mike Andrews scored nine goals as the Myopia polo team of Boston successfully defend ed its Northeastern 12goal in tracircuit championship with an 115 victory over Bethpage today at Bethpage State Park.

title: J. Frank Forster, 64, Is Dead; Was Chairman of Sperry Rand
description: J. Frank Forster, chairman and chief executive officer of the Sperry Rand Corporation, died Saturday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had been under in tensive care since being struck by a motor vehicle on May 27. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Monserrat and Robinson Vie to Head School Board
description: A behindthescenes battle has developed for the presi dency of the City Board of Ed ucation, but it now appears that Joseph Monserrat will be elected to the post when the board meets Wednesday.

title: U.S. Roadblocks Set Up to Isolate Gypsy Moth Blight
description: HADDAM, Conn. July 2 On a quiet morning in Had dam or Higganum so many caterpillars are feasting on leaves that they sound like the light pitterpatter of rain.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Only minutes after his tele vised news conference last Thursday night, President Nixon telephoned his chief of Congressional relations, Clark MacGregor.

title: Jazz:
description: Isabelle was the given name of a slave and Sojourner Truth was the name the little girl took when she seized her freedom. The story was spun in song, dance, recitation and gospel theatricality in Louis Johnson's production of Miss Truth, presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last night as part of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Jeanne Evert Wins Title
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 2 (AP) Raz Reid of Greenville, S. C., beat Charlie Owens of Tus caloosa, Ala., 63, 62, to win the men's singles crown in the Southern tennis championships today. Jeanne Evert of Fort Lauderdale Fla., 14yearold sister of Chris, defeated Becky Vest of Jackson, Miss. 61, 63, for the women's title.

title: Progress Seems Unlikely On Europe's Money Union
description: KONSTANZ, West Germany, July 2Donald R. Hodgman, economics professor at the Uni versity of Illinois, has just analyzed before an interna tional group of financial men here the prospects for a cur rency Union in Europe.

title: Roundup: McCovey Hits 14th Slam
description: In only 1,659 games, much fewer than Gil Hodges or Hank Aaron had needed to accomplish the feat, Willie McCovey yesterday hit his 14th career grandslam homer as the Giants routed the slumping Dodgers, 93, at San Francisco.

title: NORTHWEST LAYS OFF MOST NONSTRIKERS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 (AP) Northwest Airlines has laid off a very substantial major ity of its 8,500 nonstriking employes as the result of a walkout by pilots, a Northwest spokesman said today.

title: Carol Replogle Bride of D.H. Clark
description: DENVER, July 2The mar riage of Miss Carol Anne Replogle to Dudley Holbrook Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Clark of Green wich, Conn., took place here this afternoon.

title: Rainmaking Is Used As Weapon by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The United States has been secretly seeding clouds over North Vi etnam, Laos and South Viet nam to increase and control the rainfall for military purposes.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LEVANTER. By Eric Ambler. 307 pages, Atheneum. $6.95.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gunman in Bronx Wounds Six

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 2  The Senator, owned and handled by Frank Andrea of Syosset, L.I., captured the puis sance (high jump) today at the Gaudeamus Farms' horse show. The Senator and Judy Korn's Easy Rider, ridden by Terry Rudd, both knocked down the wall at 6 feet 2 inches. Miss Rudd conceded rather than go through another jumpoff.

title: Shoe Company Offered Bribe, Trackman Charges
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 2The signs of another major money scandal in track and field have appeared at the United States Olympic trials.

title: Advertising:
description: Five ad agencies are being actively considered for the Marine Corps recruiting ad vertising assignment. The contract the Corps had with J. Walter Thompson, which is one of thefive, ran out yesterday and the Pentagon said it should have its de cision in around July 20. Thompson has had the as signment for a quarter of a century.

title: JAZZ FOR THE FEW IS HEARD BY MANY
description: The Newport Jazz Festival's Connoisseur Concerts  there will be a total of fourshow case a mixture of new jazz and old, in most cases performed by players who are well known to jazz aficionados, but who still lack a wide popular fol lowing.

title: Aussie Takes Car Race
description: BRAINERD, Minn., July 2 (AP)Horst Kwech of Austra lia chalked up the first 1972 victory for Alfa. Romeo in the 2.5 Challenge Series by winning his second race in three years at Donnybrook Speedway to day. His PepsiAlfa averaged 94 miles an hour to finish 1 minute 27:3 seconds ahead of Bert Everett of Williamsville, N. Y., in a BobcorAlfa.

title: 3 U.S. Jets Lost in North
description: SAIGON, July 2 (AP)The United States command an nounced today the loss of three more United States Air Force F4 Phantom jets over North Vietnam, with all six crewmen missing.

title: Duke: His Creative ImpulseAll That JazzThrobs On
description: Duke Ellington sat cater cornered on a folded plaid blanket on the piano bench. Lemme hear it now, he said. With his left hand he cued the brass section for the biting attack he wanted on the riff theme of New York, New York.

title: Dorothy A. Rinaldi Is Married To Michael Francis McDonald
description: Miss Dorothy Anne Rinaldi was married here yesterday afternoon to Michael Francis McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. McDonald of Brooklyn. The bride's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Peter Joseph Rinaldi of Manhat tan.

title: Judges Growing Lenient In Draft Amnesty Cases
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2Two years ago, Alan Kent was drafted. Halfway through his physical examination at the Oakland induction center, he decided that he did not want to join the Army.

title: BENNIE BENSON
description: KODIAK, Alaska, July 2 (AP) Bennie Benson, designer of the Alaska flag, died today, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: SIMLA, India, Monday, July 3India and Pakistan took initial steps early this niorning toward attaining the durable peace they both profess to want, but the heart of their disputethe 25year squabble over Kashmirremains largely unresolved. The two nations agreed to withdraw their forces from along their common bor der, but not in Kashmir. Instead they agreed to freeze their armies along the ceasefire line there.

title: ARCADIUS CAPTURES 2 DRESSAGE EVENTS
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 2 Jordan Miller of Ossining, N. Y., and Mrs. Lois Stephens's Ar cadius formed an unbeatable combination today and won the two leading events in the Ox Ridge Hunt Club alldressage horse show.

title: PERCY T. COLE
description: QUEBEC, July 2Percy T. Cole, who rtired a year ago as general manager of the Canadi an Government Travel Bureau in New York City, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: By his own admission, Richard Milhous Nixon has always had a suppressed ambition to be a sports writer, and now in his 60th year he has had the thrill of seeing his byline over a piece in the sports section. Allowing the cub two or three times as much space as a staff member would get, The New York Times published his essay in full Sunday, all 2,800 clicheridden words. Frank ly, the new boy has a long way to go if he's ever going to cut it in this department.

title: Key Figure in Washington Raid Is Reported Fugitive in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 2E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency of ficial now sought by Federal agents in connection with last month's raid on the Democratic National Committee here, was reliably reported today to have fled to Europe and possibly to be in Spain.

title: JOSEPH F. SMITH OF MORMONS DIES
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 2 Joseph Fielding Smith, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saintsthe Mormon Churchdied tonight here at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Bruce R. McConkie, according to a church official. His death was apparently of natural causes. He would have been 96 years old on July 19.

title: Metreveli Next for Smith; Connors to Face Nastase
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2It doesn't seem like the same old Wimbledon. True, the contract pros are temporarily missing, but with a week gone the quarterfinal lineup pre sents for the first time three players, from Eastern Europe, and topseeded Stan Smith, who is supposed to win it, is drawn to meet them all.

title: Gray Says He Found No F.B.I. Political File
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reuter)  The acting direc tor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, L. Patrick Gray, said he had found no evidence of political dossiers in the bureau's files, although he said there might be bits and pieces of such material held by the agency.

title: What to Call the InLaws: Mom and Dador Simply Hey, You
description: Formality is still the rule in many households, but sometimes you sort of skirt the whole name thing for a while; in fact, you don't even say the names.

title: Eagle Clothes Appoints
description: Milton R. Berman has been appointed president of the re tail division of Eagle Clothes, Inc., it was announced over the weekend. The retail divi sion comprises 63 stores in 17 metropolitan areas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WADKINS, HINSON IN TIE WITH 206'S
description: CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) Lanny Wadkins shot a fourun derpar 67 today and moved into a tie with Larry Hinson for the lead after three rounds of the raindelayed $150,000 Cleveland open tournament.

title: Stock Analyst Finds Promise in Cosmetics
description: Eileen M. Gormley, a senior security analyst with Reyn olds Securities, Inc., covers a variety of industries for her firm  textiles and apparel, home furnishings, cosmetics, printing and publishing. Most of her client contact is with institutions. Before she en tered the brokerage field six years ago, Miss Gormley worked in market surveil lance and analysis for the Securities and Exchange Commission and later for the American Stock Exchange. Part of her current thinking about the stock market is that some apparel and tex tile stocks are, so depressed that they should show rela tively superior market per formance over tha next 12 months. Portions of her conversation last week with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times follow:

title: In Cape May, the Summer Stroller May Shop and Snack, Away From Traffic
description: CAPE MAY, N. J.,  One year ago this resort pity closed off a threeblock stretch of roadway and created the Washington Mall, an oleo of wellrestored Vic torian era shops and ticky tacky imitations, of old gas lights and new electrified adaptations, of merchants historically located here and of latecoming entrepreneurs.

title: MICHAEL F. MAHONY
description: Michael F. Mahony, a retired advertising executive who was a vice president, director and New York manager of Maxon, Inc, the Detroitbased agency, died yesterday in Plantation, Fla., where he had been living. His age was 73. He had also been an account executive at Arthur Kudner, Inc., and a vice president of Ruthrauff & Ryan.

title: Hospital Union Planning Strike And Rally at City Hall Thursday
description: Although both sides indicated their belief yesterday that a hospital walkout could still be averted, officers of Local 1199, the Drug and Hospital Union, went ahead with plans to strike more than 60 voluntary and municipal hospitals on Thurs day.

title: James L. Magrish, Lawyer, Civic Leader in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, July 2James L. Magrish, a civic leader and lawyer who was active in phil anthropic affairs, died here last night. He was 71 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Peron Factor
description: Seventeen years after his ouster and exile, Juan Do mingo Peron at 76 has been nominated for President Argentina by his Justicialist party, and a Federal judge has formally authorized his candidacy for elections scheduled for next March. These developments should bring Argentina's political crisis to some kind of water shed in the near future, for the country's military lead ers have said they will not allow the former dictator of run. Whether or not Peron returns from his long sojourn in Spain, he is still believed to command the allegiance of at least a third of the Argentine electorate.

title: Stock Market Open Today; Taking Holiday Tomorrow
description: Securities exchanges and banks will be open as usual today. Some commodities mar ketsbut not allwill be open today. Tomorrow practically all establishments will be closed for the Fourth of July.

title: Jazz:
description: Bigband buffs had a feast at the Newport Jazz Festi val's concerts at Philharmon ic Hall Sunday evening. If the menu left something to be desired, the lightness of the diet can be overlooked because of its sheer rarity: how often is there an oppor tunity to hear three topnotch big jazz ensembles in a single program?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editotr:

title: Personal Finance
description: Now that summer is here, parents with teenage chil dren about to go off to college have some planning to do involving taxes and other financial aspects of education.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, July 2The reconnais sance techniques developed by the United States in Vietnam are especially remarkable in their selective capacity. They can count the number of furnaces in a steel mill hit by American planes, but they do not see bombed hospitals or schools or houses.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Sup porters of Senator George Mc Govern tried to recapture their vanishing majority on the Dem ocratic convention's Credentials Committee today by replacing three New York members who had registered, ndependent vot ing records.

title: Street Fair's Wares and Music Attract Thousands in Harlem
description: The House of Molade sold, brown rice and blackeyed peas and sweet wholewheat corn bread. Amateur and profes sional musicians playedsome alone and some with dancers. And children carried red, green and black balloons at the Har lem street fair held yesterday on Seventh Avenue by the House of Kuumba.

title: U.S.Yemeni Relations Resumed After 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The Yemen Arab Republic and the United States officially announced the resumption of diplomatic relations today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Slain in Belfast as Truce Wears Thin
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July. 2Three bulletriddled bodies were found in Belfast today amid rising tension be tween Roman Catholics and Protestants.

title: State Hearing Set July 20 On Insurance Claim Ruling
description: A public hearing has been called by the State Superin tendent of Insurance, Benjamin R Schenck, on a revised draft of a regulation designed to pre vent insurance companies from engaging in unfair claims prac tices.

title: BISHOP DON D. BRIGHT
description: DALLAS, July 2  The Right Rev. Don D, Bright, African Methodist Episcopal Bishop of Philadelphia, died today, appar ently of a heart attack, during the black church's quadrennial conference here. He was 55 years old.

title: Hijacker Killed in Saigon; Tried to Divert Jet to Hanoi
description: A South Vietnamese student, apparently an antiwar dissi dent whose scholarship in the United States was canceled re cently, was shot and killed at Tansonnhut Airport in Saigon yesterday after he attempted to divert a Pan American jum bojet flight to Hanoi.

title: Henry Breyer Jr., ExHead Of Ice Cream Coneern, Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 2  Henry W. Breyer Jr., former president of the Breyer Breyer Ice Cream Company, founded by his father, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: EUROBONDS HOLD FIRM IN TURMOIL
description: BRUSSELS, July 2  The week following the floating of the pound sterling has been one of teapot tempests rather than crisis, as far as the Euro bond market is concerned.

title: FREEMAN VICTOR IN NATIONAL FOIL
description: WALTHAM, Maas., July 2 Bert Freemn captured the na tional men's senior foil cham pionship today and virtually assured himself a place on the Olympic fencing team.

title: A Word From Dr. Work Horse
description: IPSWICH, Mass.I am a socalled work horse of medicine, practicing pediatrics in a small community with out a dream of entering that 5 per cent in my specialty who will have incomes over $60,000 per year. And yet, surpris ing (or, to some, hypocritical) as it may seem, I am not only acutely aware of the, hardship that medical costs work on my patients (or, more precisely, on their often young and struggling parents), I expend considerable thought and effort to keep these costs to a minimum.

title: A LATIN DISPERSAL IN CITY REPORTED
description: A Puerto Rican exodus from Manhattan nearly double the borough's overall population rate of decline in the nineteen sixties was reported yesterday in 1970 census reports.

title: Miss Mitnick Bride of Kenneth Wallach
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 2Miss Helaine Susan Mit nick was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Arnold Wallach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wallach of Phil adelphia. Rabbi Joachim Prinz, assisted by Cantor Murray Simon, performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mitnick.

title: MARYL. CALDWELL OF COLUMBIA DIES
description: FISHKILL, N. Y., July 2Dr. Mary L. Caldwell, professor emeritus of chemistry at Co lunibia University, died at her home yesterday. She was 81 years old and had lived on Cedar Hill Road here since re tiring in 1959.

title: What Is Freedom? What Is Liberty?
description: I was born in 1879. Despite the gloomy state of the world today, it is essential for us to look beyond and ahead in order to gain perspective. One of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Four Freedoms was freedom from fear. We must bear in mind our good fortune in this country, recognize our opportunities for living the good life, accept our responsibilities for making the good life even better without first or secondclass citizens. There Must be no outcasts in the American society.

title: NIXON DISCUSSES. MITCHELL'S MOVE
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2President Nixon, on a work ing vacation at his Western White House here, telephoned today to both his justresigned campaign manager, John N. Mitchell, and Mr. Mitchell's successor, Clark MacGregor.

title: Marko Hurt as Stewart Takes French Auto Race
description: CLERMONT  FERRAND, France, July 2On the rocky road of the French Grand Prix, Jackie Stewart steered clear of trouble today, Chris Amon and Denis Hulme didn't, and Helmut Marko was injured and may lose the sight of an eye.

title: Higher Prices Loom for Australian Meat
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 2 Australian meat exporters, who earlier this year had sought bigger quotas in the United States market, are now saying the United States will get more meat from Aus tralia only if it is prepared to pay more for it.

title: DOCTORS TO STUDY A DEADLY FEVER
description: Doctors at Columbia and Yale, reacting to an unpubli cized recent outbreak of Lassa fever in Liberia that claimed the life of an American nurse among others, are planning a new study into the mysterious viral disease.

title: STEEL SHIPMENTS FACE LAG IN JULY
description: PITTSBURGH, July 2 The steel market was behaving in a predictable manner last week. Advance orders indicated ship ments would dip in July and rebound in August. Officials said this swing reflected the normal summer pattern of au tomobile production and pro curement.

title: Nixon Finds the Price Of Sirloin Has Gone Up
description: LOS ANGELES, (AP) President Nixon flew to Los Angeles from the Western White House at San Cle mente for a stag dinner to night that taught him some thing about the rising price of beef. Mr. Nixon went to Chasen's Restaurant and ordered a holo steakan extralarge New York sirloin seared in butter.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ST. LOUIS, July 2 (Reuters)John Newcombe of Aus tralia trounced Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, 63, 63, today and won $10,900 of the $50,000 purse in the Holton tennis tournament, the opener of the contract pro tour.

title: M.I.T. Alumnus, 105, Dies
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 2 (AP)Pomeroy W. Power, who was the oldest living graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the oldest pensioner of the General. Elec tric Company, died here yes terday. He was 105 years old. After graduating from M.I.T. in 1892, Mr. Power joined the Stanley Electric Company here as an electrical engineer. Stan ley Electric, was acquired by General Electric, with which Mr. Power remained until he retired in 1932. Three sons survive.

title: Mrs. Bernina Recaptures U.S. Open Golf Crown
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 2 Mrs. Susie Maxwell Berning, who won the title in 1968, be fore her 19monthold daughter was born, recaptured the Unit ed States Women's Open golf championship today.

title: Water, From Hydrant or Sea, Lures Many on Hottest Day of the Year
description: The hottest day of the year coincided yesterday with the second day of the Independ ence Day weekend, and New Yorkers and visitors sought relief at parks and beaches.

title: Chinese Manage Steel Town Despite Soviet Aid Withdrawal
description: WUHAN, China, June 23  They were our best teachers they taught us to do things with our own hands.

title: LYKESYOUNGSTOWN REDUCES FIXED DEBT
description: The LykesYoungstown Cor poration said over the week end that it had made a cash payment of $45million on out standing debt, reducing obliga tions to $60million. The com pany noted that this meant it has reduced its outstanding debt by $115million over the last 18 months.

title: LITURGY YIELDS CARAMOOR THEME
description: Kodly's gustily expansive Te Deum and Donizetti's very operatic Requiem for Bellini were the contrasting pair of choral works heard at the Cara moor Festival Saturday night. It would be difficult to imagine two more dissimilar approaches to the liturgy, but in practice these pieces played off against each other most effectively in Caramoor's congenial openair surroundings.

title: Marsha Tretin Bride Of Albert D. Abrams
description: Miss Marsha Tretin, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tretin of Monroe, N. Y., and Brooklyn, was married yes terday to Albert Daniel Abrams. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Abrams of Bally, Pa., and Philadelphia.

title: Seagren s185 Vault Sets World Mark
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 2Re affirming his status as one of track and field's supreme com petitors, Bob Seagren cleared 18 feet 5 inches on his final attempt tonight and regained sole possession of the world record in the pole vault.

title: ISRAELIS ARE URGED TO STUDY U.S. JEWRY
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2The head of a Jewish community relations group said today that he was appalled by the depth of ignorance in Israel about the character of Jewish com munity life in America.

title: Economic Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Social Security bill rushed, through Congress and signed by President Nixon last week has major, and not widely known, implications for All em ployers and for the millions of highsalaried working men and women in the country. For em ployers, the bill will mean higher costs next, year and thereafter, though perhaps not quite as much in crease in costs in later years as would have occurred under the former law.

title: Personalities: A Real Honor
description: When President Nixon named him as the best all round athlete in major league baseball history, Jackie Rob inson seemed surprised but very pleased with the real honor. The former Brook lyn Dodger second baseman and the first black athlete in the major leagues said, He's an individual making his picks and I'm honored that he thought of me in that way. It's great. Robinson, a mem ber of the Baseball Hall of Fame, was Nixon's choice as the best National League sec ond baseman for the years 1945 through 1970. The na tion's No. 1 fan called Robin son the best allround athlete because of Jackie's achieve ments in football and track at the University of Califor nia, Los Angeles.

title: Holiday Is Used Upstate To Clean Up After Flood
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., July 2Un der a hot sun that turned mud dy streets to fine dust today, residents of the Southern Tier continued cleanup operations in the wake of the worst flood in the history of the area.

title: 2 Die in Cyclist Crash
description: PRAGUE, July 2 (UPI)  Rudolf Froeling of West Ger many lost control of his Yamaha motorcycle in a race today, crashed into a crowd of spectators and was killed with an onlooker. Eight persons were injured in the mishap at Jicin, North Bohemia.

title: PAKISTAN REACHES ACCORD WITH INDIA ON MAJOR ISSUES
description: SIMLA, India, Monday, July 3India and Pakistan have agreed to withdraw all troops from their mutual borders, to freeze present troop positions in Kashmir pending further negotiations on that disputed area and to undertake a step bystep normalization of their relations.

title: Arts Abroad
description: MILAN, ItalySubscribers to expensive seats at La Scala recently snubbed Mo zart by staying away from the visiting Salzburg produc tion of The Abduction From the Seraglio.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Touch Me. No, it's not a new Xrated film. Not a new sensitivity game, either. But how about soap in a tubebecause that's what it is.

title: Tokyo And Miami Beach
description: In Tokyo this week, delegates to the convention of the LiberalDemo cratic party  the party of Japan's business establishmentwill choose a new party leader and Premier to suc ceed 71yearold Eisaku Sato. It is not for reasons of age, health or constitutional rule that Mr. Sato now steps down after seven and onehalf years at the helm, the longest term of any postwar Japanese Premier. Rather, by that quiet but decisive process of consensus that slowly forms like a pearl within the shell of the Japanese establishment, it was decided that the time had come for Mr. Sato to go, because both his foreign and domestic policies are in crisis.

title: Met Musicians, Con Brio, Praise Their New Contract
description: Metropolitan Opera orches tra members chose phrases like motto legato (very smooth) and even con amore (with love yesterday to de scribe the negotiations that settled their threeyear con tract a month before the deadline.

title: Scientists Are Critical Of Rainmaking in War
description: After years of rainmaking experimentation, scientists are still not sure they under stand the shortterm effects of cloudseeding, much less the possible longterm impact on the ecology of a region or the world.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the state Democratic chairman, said yesterday he would vote to sustain the primary results in Illinois and seat Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and 58 adherents who had been ousted in favor of a slate of challengers.

title: MISS WHITE JUMPS TO 13TH TRACK TITLE
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 2 (AP) Willy White won a 13th na tional title today, but another longtime competitor, Mrs. Olga Connally, tearfully hinted of retirement after finishing sec ond in the Amateur Athletic Union women's discus throw.

title: Irish Setter Judged Best
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., July 2 Ch. Kelly Shannon O'Deke, a 5yearold Irish setter owned by Dr. R. D. Helferty of Flint, Mich., was named best of show today in the 23d annual Del  Otse  Nango Kennel Club event in Damaschke Stadium. The show drew 822 dogs.

title: Fox Terrier Judged Best In Cape Cod Kennel Show
description: NORTH FALMOUTH, Mass., July 2Ch. Littleway, Haran wal Barrister, a 3yearold wirehaired fox terrier owned by Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N.J., and handled by Clifford Hallmark, captured the top prize today at the 24th annual dog show of the Cape Cod Kennel Club.

title: JOHN LEE DAVIDSON
description: John Lee Davidson, a vice president and executive art director of the Dancer FitzgeraldSample advertising agency, died of cancer on Saturday in the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo. He was 41 years old and lived at 40 Lansdowne Drive, Larch mont, N. Y.

title: METS LOSE, 4 TO 3, ON A WALK IN 9TH
description: MONTREAL, July 2The New York Mets, who had beat en the Expos six successive times, went down to a 43 defeat today In Jerry Park, but it was not robust hitting that elided New York's streak.

title: Religious Festival Campsite Suddenly Like a City
description: GRANBY, Colo., July 2 The campground at the religious festival high in the Rocky Mountains west of here took on an almost citylike atmos phere today, with 13,000 to 15,000 persons jammed along the paths and under the tall evergreen trees.

title: DEMOCRATIC RIFT DISMAYS WILKINS
description: DETROIT, July 2  Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared today that President Nixon was almost being handed reelection on a platter by Democratic fumblers.

title: Trade Experts Find East Europe a Perplexing Market
description: WARSAW, July 2A West ern expert on EastWest trade who had been in Warsaw 10 years ago was asked at a con ference the other day by a Polish newsman if the visitor noticed any difference in the Polish capital.

title: New York Skipper Wins
description: HANKOE, Norway, July 2 (AP)Ernest Fay of New York, sailing his boat Sundance, won the first race for the King Olav Cup for 5.5meter yachts to day.

title: Credit Markets
description: Credit analysts remained op timistic late last week, even as money rates climbed rapidly, that a major increase could be avoided in the cost of long term money. To be sure, most interest rates climbed sharply throughout June because of the ex panding economy, skepticism about the attack on inflation, heavy Treasury financing in the first. half of the new fiscal year and international currency turmoil.

title: M.T.A. Assets in 71 Rose $134Million, Audit Shows
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority showed an in crease of $134.9million in as sets in 1971, according to a report of an audit released yes terday by State Controller Ar thur Levitt.

title: PRICE OF BLACKOUT IS PUT AT $200,000
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 The nervous breakdown that shortcircuited Roosevelt Race way's computers last night, and cut betting and racing down to a minimum, was virtually cured today following hours of repairs.

title: ROBERT GARLOCK
description: Robert Garlock, a realty man and vice president in charge of management of the 65 Morton Street, 310 East 55th Street and Lipsam Corporations, died Sat urday evening at his home, 310 East 55th Street. He was 73 years old.

title: U.S. Volunteer Agency Is a Target of Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Ac tion, the conglomerate agency embracing the Peace Corps and other Federal volunteer ef forts, is under heavy attack from critics who say its under lying concept of selfless, non partisan service has been cor rupted by politics.

title: Feuding Democrats
description: Not content that the odds are against them in this election year, the Democrats seem bent, as usual, on decreasing their chances still further. The battles in the credentials committee over the California and Illinois delegations are unlikely to lose the nomination for Sen ator George McGovern, but the bitterness they are gen erating can only make the reelection of President Nixon more probable.

title: FIDDLER BOWS OUT AFTER 3,242D SHOW
description: Fiddler on the Roof, the longestrunning show in Broad way history, closed yesterday after its 3,242d performance.

title: Mr. Nixon's Theology
description: PRINCETON, N. J.  When Richard Nixon assumed the Presidency in 1969, he diagnosed the malaise of this nation as a crisis of the spirit, and he promised that his Administration would meet that crisis with an an swer of, the spirit. Since the inaugural Mr. Nixon has done his utmost to meet this pledge. He invariably at tempts to root his policies in the certainties of moral, even religious conviction. In his speeches and policy statements he regularly defends his decisions by an appeal to conscience.

title: City Apt to Remain Capital of Business
description: Ten or 20 years from now will the Manhattan central business districtthe warren of steel and stone south of 60th Street that is the work place of 2.2 million people still be the national center it is today for corporate head quarters.

title: Advertising:
description: Not only do Wall Street and retailing feel the effects of major national events, but apparently also the mail order business.

title: GoldfarbGinty Duo Gains. In U.S. OneWall Handball
description: Marcel Goldfarb and Ken Ginty, an unseeded team from the New York Athletic Club, scored another upset yesterday in gaining the semifinals of the national onewall doubles hand ball championships at Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

title: Endangered Magazines
description: A score or so of smallcirculation periodicals have banded together in a Committee, for the Diversity of the Press. Their main purpose is to fight off the threat to their very existence that is implicit in the Postal Service's staggering imposition of a 127 per cent, increase in secondclass postal rates over a fiveyear period. The name they have chosen is appropriate, for diversity of opinion is at the heart of their contribution to American society and of their claim to special consideration.

title: JAPAN INCREASING FOREIGN AID FUND
description: TOKYO, July 2Japan has budgeted a Government foreign aid program for the fiscal year 1972 (ending next March) total ing $2.13billion, up 39 per cent from the $1.53billion budgeted in 1971.

title: ALBATROSS SETS WORLD PACE MARK
description: Albatross towered above all other performers in harness rac ing's weekend as the 4yearold pacer posted the fastest mile ever on Saturday night at Sportsman's Park in Chicago.

title: ECKERD'S, INC., SEEKS ERIE TECHNOLOGICAL
description: Eckerd's, Inc., a privately owned chain of drug stores based in Erie, Pa., is making a tender offer to purchase all the 1,044,186 outstanding common shares of Erie Technological Products, Inc., at $14 a share, it was announced yesterday.

title: Jazz:
description: Some of Count Basie's for mer sidemen came out of the past yesterday to show their old boss how superbly a big jazz band can swing.

title: Graybeard in Front
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP) Light winds slowed the sev en yachts in the race from Los Angeles to Tahiti today as the leader, Graybeard out of Van couver, British Columbia, sailed to within 475 miles of Papeete on the 3,571mile run.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  Senator George McGovern in dicated today that he would work to end party factional ism in the week before the Democratic National Conven tion.

title: Yanks Defeat Indians, 61 and 52
description: In the House That Ruth Built, formally named Yankee Stadium, the big moment these days comes when a guy steps out of a car in front of the Yankee dugout. Even before he emerges to stride confidently to the mound, the crowd knows he is Albert W. (Sparky) Lyle, relief pitcher extraordi nary, and when he showed up on schedule yesterday, noisy anticipation quickly, became happy reality. He nailed, down a victory that, enabled the Yankees to sweep a double header from the Cleveland In dians, 61 and 52.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lillian Hall Wed to Bradford Rouech
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 2  In St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Lillian Milli cent Hall, daughter of Mrs. Sam W. Sharp and the late Harry James Hall, was mar ried to Bradford Rouech, son of Mr. and Mrs. Berton Rouech of Amagansett. Msgr. Anthony F. De Laura performed the ceremony.

title: Hydro Trials Put Off
description: MADISON, Ind., July 2 (AP) Drivers and crews resorted to touch football and crowd watching as qualifying runs for the $30,000 unlimited hy droplane regatta was put off to day. The Ohio River course was still not in shape as a result of recent heavy flooding.

title: Sandra Young Is Wed To David Wiesenthal
description: BUFFALO, July 2  Miss Sandra Louise Young, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Young of Grand Island, was married here this after noon to David Lawrence Wiesenthal, an assistant pro fessor of psychology at York University in Toronto, Ont. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Wiesenthal of New York and Wurtsboro Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Goldstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Zion.

title: Total Control by U.F.T.?
description: The wild demand by the United Federation of Teachers for a basic salary schedule from $12,000 to $25,000 in New York City's schools can hardly be taken seriously. This would represent an increase of about 35 per cent and 75 per cent respectively over the present starting salary of $9,400 and top base pay of $13,950. Even with out taking into consideration wage board guidelines, this demand sounds less like serious bargaining than like an effort by the union president, Albert Shanker, to impress and arouse his members.

title: MAURICE L. HEILBRUN
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 2 Maurice L. Heilbrun, who helped found Van BaalenHeil brun, Inc., New York bathrobe manufacturers, in 1921, died here yesterday He was 75 years old and had moved to Palm Beach a year ago.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm sat down, the other day with 20 male inmates awaiting sen tencing and told them about a legal advocate program to overcome some of their com plaints about court pro cedures.

title: Blast Kills 8 and Hurts 500 In Railway Station in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, July 2 (Reuters)  Seven railway cars loaded with butane gas ex ploded in the northern city of Jimenez last night, killing eight persons and injuring 500.

title: 13 Children Die Near Seoul
description: SEOUL, Korea July 2 (AP) Thirteen children perished in a fire that broke out when a child attempting to refuel a lamp mistook a contained of gasoline for kerosene, hospital authorities reported today. Seven others were hospitalized with serious burns. The blaze occurred at a farm house 35 miles east of Seoul.

title: M'GOVERN'S VIEWS ALARM BIG DONORS ON WALL STREET
description: Senator George McGovern's economic policies have aroused great controversy in Wall Street and seriously jeopardized some of the sources of cam paign funds that have tradi tionally been available in the financial community for liberal candidates.

title: Job Supply for Students Found Meager in State
description: The summer job situation for college and high school stu dents is so desperate that New York State has assigned 70 peo ple to the Summer Jobs for Youth Program to seek employ ment opportunities and it is using other Labor Department staff members to join the search for temporary work.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: President Nixon continues to lead both Senators George McGovern and Hubert H. Humphrey, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: New Zealand Hails Step
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 2 President Nixon's re moval of quota restrictions on meat imports is warmly wel comed in New Zealand as be ing in line with a policy fre quently urged on the United States to reduce agricultural protectionism.

title: Papers Show I.T.T Urged U.S. to Help Oust Allende
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation sub mitted to the White House last October an 18point plan de signed to assure that the Government of Chile's Marxist president, Salvador Allende Gossen, does not get through the crucial next six months.

title: Mrs. Berning Praised by Caddie
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 2I don't care what she pays me, Mrs. Susie Maxwell Berning's caddie said today as he trudged off the 18th green at Winged Foot Golf Club. She's the most consistent golfer I've ever worked for, male or fe male. Maybe not the longest hitter, but the most Consist ent.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Lenox Mother of Us All Lacks Nothing but Seats for the Crowd
description: LENOX, Mass., July 2With a redandwhitestriped tent, serving as opera house, the Lenox Arts Center has opened its season with Virgil Thom son's The Mother of Us All.

title: Chess Title Match Put Off Two Days On Plea by Fischer
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 2 The president of the Interna tional Chess Federation has granted Bobby Fischer a two day postponement of his world championship match with Boris Spassky, which was supposed to begin here today. But the president, Dr. Max Euwe, warned the American grand master that if he did not show up by noon Tuesday, he would forfeit the match.

title: Truman in Hospital for Tests; Condition Called Satisfactory
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 2 (UPI)Former President Harry S. Truman was hospitalized today for what doctors de scribed as a gastrointestinal problem.

title: Summer Schools Opening in the City This Week
description: School may be out for most youngsters, but by the middle of this week it will just be betinning again for several hundred thousand youthsand many adultswho want to pick up extra high school cred its or learn something about, say, tapdancing, or just to beat the boredom, and perhaps the mischief, of another sum mer in the city.

title: Overruling a Cancer
description: The death penalty is to the body politic what cancer is to the individual body, Albert Camus once wrote, with the single difference that no one has ever spoken of the necessity of cancer.

title: DROLL ROLE VICTOR IN $116,800 HANDICAP
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)Droll, Role, a 4yearold son of Tom Rolfe, came off the pace head ing into the stretch today and pulled away to a threelength victory in the $116,800 Massa chusetts Handicap before a crowd of 14,977 at Suffolk Downs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridg: 2 Teams at Olympiad Compile Remarkable Winning Streaks
description: For the 39 teams compet ing in the World Team Olympiad in Miami Beach, the qualifying stage was normally a question of zig ging to victory one moment and zagging to defeat the next. Several teams had the misfortune to zag much more often than they zigged.

title: Security Pacific National Creates BankHolding Unit
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, announced yesterday that it had completed its previously announced plan to form a onebank holding company to tak eover owner ship of the bank. Shares of the bank were exchaged on a one forone basis for those of the newly created Security Pacific Corporation.

title: FEW N.Y. LEADERS TO BE DELEGATES
description: Four years ago the roster of the New York delegation to the Democratic National Con vention read like a Who's Who in the state party.

title: Jazz:
description: Australian jazz, memories of Bessie Smith, and a so prano saxophone version of Louis Armstrong's famous trumpet solo on Struttin' With Some Barbecue were some of the tidbits offered at the Newport Jazz Festi val's second Connoisseur Concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

title: Grocers in Rome Irked by Opening Of a Red Market
description: ROMEA new Communist run supermarket on the east ern edge of Rome is becom ing a political hot potato.

title: The Fourth
description: Another Independence Day, the calendar year just past its midpoint, the solar year just past its zenith. It is summer.

title: Geophysical Warfare
description: Over the past decade a new term, geophysical war fare, has begun creeping into discussions of future types of military capability. A rough definition of the concept would be an act or acts of environmental engineering designed to change the flow of air and water in order to damage one side in a conflict and benefit the other.

title: Korea's History Is Domination and Division
description: For seven centuries, the name by which Korea has been best known to her own people is Chosen  the land of the morning calm. Along the rug gedly mountainous peninsula extending southeast from Man churia into the Sea of Japan, there are yet many scenes of beauty and mornings of peace.

title: HUE BOMBARDED BY FOE'S BIG GUNS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 4With strong Saigon forces fighting their way into Communistoccupied Quangtri Province, North Viet namese forces farther south re plied yesterday with heavy ar tillery barrages. For the first time, the city of Hue came un der fire from longrange 130 mm. guns.

title: Business Briefs
description: Favorable dividend actions rose sharply in the first half of 1972 to 1,077 from 868 a year earlier, Standard & Poor's reported yesterday.

title: GRAHAM CONQUERS DEVLIN IN PLAYOFF
description: CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) David Graham, a 26yearold tour rookie from Australia, sank a 10foot putt for a birdie on the second hole of a sud dendeath playoff today to win the $150,000 Cleveland open champlonship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ecologists Hope to Save Wild Islands Off Georgia
description: OSSABAW ISLAND, Ga. Nature resolves its problems on the United States coastline as ruthlessly as man; yet it kills with a grace beyond the craft of a bulldozer or dragline.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Loufek Cards a 69
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 3 (AP)Bob Loufek of Moline, Ill., posted a threeunderpar 69 today in the qualifying round of the International senior ama teur golf championship. William Zimmerman of Columbus, Ga., the defending champion, had a 76. Tom Draper of Troy, Mich., the United States champion, carded a 78.

title: Use of Appalachian Trail Restricted
description: Rationing has come to the Appalachian Trail in its 50th year.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 3The Demo crats open their, convention here a week from today. If they want to go on to the defeat of President Nixon, their first order of business will have to be the reversal of, the party regu lars' cynical decision to deprive George McGovern of more than half of his fairly won California delegation.

title: MetsExpos Rained Out
description: MONTREAL, July 3Rain, not the Expos, stopped the New York Mets today in their pur suit of the Eastern Division leading Pirates.

title: TRUMAN REPORTED CHEERY IN HOSPITAL
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 3 {AP)Former President Harry S. Truman was reported to be Cheerful and in satisfactory condition today at the Research Medical Center as his doctor began what was described as routine testing.

title: 10.500 Athletes in Olympics
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 3 (UPI)  A record 10,500 athletes are scheduled to com pete in the 1972 Olympic Games here, the Munich organ izing committee said today Lists of participants for the Aug. 26 through Sept. 10 games have been submitted by 123 of the 131 national Olympic groups.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) The Democratic Credentials Committee voted today to seat the 64member North Carolina delegation to the national con vention despite complaints that only 7.8 per cent of the dele gates were under the age of 30.

title: Misses Evert, Goolagong Win, Meet Tomorrow
Abe Stark of Brooklyn, Who Led City Council, Dies
description: Abe Stark, onetime City Council President and former Borough President of Brooklyn whose clothing store sign in Ebbets Field made his name familiar to a generation of base ball fans, died Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Rogers Visit Pains Opposition in Athens
description: ATHENS, July 3Leaders of the Greek political opposition expressed pain and bitter ness today over the scheduled arrival here tomorrow of Sec retary of State William P. Rogers for talks with Premier George Papadopoulos.

title: Nixon Mourns Death
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 (UPI)  President Nixon mourned today the death of Joseph Fielding Smith, presi dent of the Mormon Church.

title: 7 HURT IN SERIES OF INCIDENTS HERE
description: Seven persons were shot, knifed or clubbed and three men were arrested in a series of violent incidents following a dispute in an East Side bar yes terday.

title: Cambodia Chief Sworn In
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 3 (AP)Marshal Lon Nol swore himself in as the Cambodian Republic's first elected presi dent today and pledged to de vote all my strength and all of my soul to serve his nation.

title: China Held Ready to Aid Hanoi With Engineers
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Dip lomatic and intelligence reports have persuaded some key Ad ministration officials that China will probably send engineer ba tallions to northern parts of North Vietnam to aid in the reconstruction of bombedout railroad links to China.

title: Japan to Consider New Ways to Cut Surplus of Trade
description: TOKYO, July 3 (Reuters) The Japanese Government will start working out new meas ures for reducing the nation's trade surplus as soon as a new Cabinet is sworn in later this week, Japanese monetary offi cials said today.

title: DAY CAMP TO OPEN OVER OBJECTIONS
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3 A controversial day camp called Camporific, Inc., is sched uled to open in New Rochelle on Wednesday for a group of Brooklyn children, despite that city's refusal to grant the fed erally funded program a certif icate of residency, Joseph W. Halper, the New York City Rec reation Commissioner, said to day.

title: Bremer Moved to Hospital
description: BALTIMORE, July 3 (UPI) Arthur H. Bremer, accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama, was moved from the Baltimore County Jail today to the Clifton T. Perkins State Hospital at Jes sup for mental examination.

title: MARKET DAWDLES AT A SNAIL'S PACE
description: The stock market offered a study in slow motion yester day as volume on the New York Stock Exchange contract ed to 8.14 million sharesby far the lowest turnover of 1972.

title: Pound Drops to $2.42 Gold Rises to $65 Dealers Nervous
description: PARIS, July 3The West German Central Bank had to acquire dollars today for the first time since the June 23 dollar flood into Frankfurt fol lowing the British decision to float the pound.

title: CITY REHEARSES FOR REAL HOLIDAY
description: When is a Monday not quite a Monday? When it's not quite a holiday, either.

title: State Pleased by Results Of Welfare Work Program
description: The first year's experience, with the state's workrelief law was described yesterday as en couraging by Social Services Commissioner Abe Lavine, with one effect being a potential yearly aving in welfare grants of as much as $75million.

title: BISHOP IN BUFFALO SUSPENDS 6 PRIESTS
description: BUFFALO, July 3Six priests of the Roman Catholic diocese of Buffalo have been suspended from their duties by Bishop James A. McNulty.

title: Mrs. Kaufman Is Wed
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 3Mrs. Beulah Green burgh Kaufman of Beverly Hills, widow of Jack A. Kauf man, a manufacturer of wo men's clothing in the Los Angeles area, was married here this evening to E. Henry Sondheimer of New York, a widower and partner of Kaufmann, Alsberg & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. Rabbi Law rence Goldmark performed the ceremony at the Beverly Hills Hotel. The, couple will reside in New York, where Mr. and Mrs. John Green burgh, the bride's parents, make their home.

title: Sugar  The Question Is, Do We Need It at All?
description: For centuries it was sold only by apothecaries who measured the granules out by the ounce. Only the rich could afford it and even they couldn't splurge because the supply was so short.

title: Architect's Remains Unearthed in Florence
description: ROME, July 3The tomb of Filippo Brunelleschi, an Italian Renaissance architect and sculptor, has been dis covered beneath the floor of the Florence cathedral, it was announced today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A bed reproduced from an impression of an antiquity found on the Greek island of Santorini has again shown that in furniture, at least, it is almost impossible to im prove on the ancients. The lineforline copy is part of an exhibition of four Greek furniture manufacturers' de signs on view through Fri day at the Greek Trade Cen ter, 150 East 58th Street.

title: Art Dealer Is Found Slain In E. 65th St. Apartment
description: A 61yearold art dealer was found slain yesterday in his 26thfloor apartment at 160 East 65th Street, the police re ported.

title: No Chess Column Today
description: There is no regular chess column today. Al Horowitz is in Iceland preparing for cover ing of the world chess title match between Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union. Mr. Horowitz will remain in Iceland until the title match ends or is called off.

title: Judge Denies Motion Charging Bias in Pentagon Papers Case
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3Fed eral District Judge William Matt Byrne Jr. denied today a de fense motion in the Pentagon papers case, that would have quashed the indictment on the ground that it constituted dis criminatory prosecution.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 3The Stamford Harbor Festival marathon for powerboats will be held tomorrow starting at 2 P.M. About 75. boats capable of 80to90mile anhour speeds are expected to compete in the first closedcourse power race on Long Island Sound.

title: McNamara Order to End Rainmaking in '67 Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Two former highranking officials of the Johnson Administration said today that Robert S. McNamara, while Secretary of Defense, specifically ordered the Air Force to stop all rainmaking late in 1967, well before its first use in North Nietnam.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, July 3 (AP)Two Frenchmen appeared to be battling for the lead today in the transAtlantic single handed yacht race.

title: BUCCANEER LEADS OCEAN RACE TO SPAIN
description: Buccaneer owned by Tom Clark of Auckland, New Zealand was reported yesterday to be the leader in the transAtlantic yacht race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain. The boats had been at sea four days when they radioed their positions at noon.

title: Divers Say Caribbean Wreck Sailed to New World Long Before Columbus
description: ROATAN ISLAND, Hon duras, June 29  Michael Johnston stood on the deck of his converted World War II minesweeper, ran his fin gers through his beard and looked out across the glitter ing emerald green and blue water of Port Royal.

title: NIXON HOLIDAY TALK SET TODAY ON RADIO
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 (AP)President Nixon will address the nation by radio to morrow in a July 4 holiday speech expected to call for unity to meet the great trials the President sees ahead for the American people.

title: Jazz:
description: Seldom, if ever, has Count Basie's orchestra been cut twice in the same evening. But that has been his fate at the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., July 3 (AP)Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama left Holy Cross Hospital today for a fourhour outing to eat an early dinner at his physician's home in nearby Bethesda, Md.

title: Extent of Crowding in Jails Here Termed at New Inhuman Level
description: Leo C. Zeferetti, president of the Correction Officers Benevo lent Association charged yester day that city prisons have reached new inhuman levels of overcrowding and that they could boil over into a riot sit uation at any moment.

title: Many Jobs Are Going Begging in the FoodService Industry
description: In an era when unemploy ment is high, jobsmany of them wellpayingare going begging in the food  service industry, one of the fastest growing businesses in the country.

title: Isaac, Petty Fight Jinx
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 3 (AP)Bobby Isaac and Rich ard Petty, both fighting jinxes in the $105,834 Firecracker 400 stock car race, nonetheless are favorites for tomorrow's run at Daytona International Speed way.

title: CHARLES FEINSTEIN OF LEATHER UNION, 62
description: Charles Feinstein, general president of the International Leather Goods, Plastics and Novelty Workers Union, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: STOCK PRICES GAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was the slowest since last Novem ber, with only 2,150,750 shares changing hands. Although many stock traders apparently were taking the long fourday Fourth of July weekend, the traders left behind managed to push prices ahead, with the Amex index closing at 27.32, up 0.08.

title: Business Briefs
description: Two more companies reduced copper prices yesterday, thus following the lead taken Friday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Personalities: A New McLain?
description: Trying to forget about yesterday, when his trou bles seemed so far away, Denny McLain returns to the major leagues tonight when he will start for his new, team, the Atlanta Braves, against the Chicago Cubs. Twice voted the American League's top pitcher, he was demoted to the minors this season by the Oakland Ath letics, who traded him last week. I feel I can win again, said McLain. If you could live in yesterday that would be great but yesterday is over and I intend to live with today.  Another name to be reckoned with, Vida Blue, has two victories. He gained No. 2 on Sunday night as the A's defeated the Angels. Last year at this time he was 163. It would be nice to see the season start over so I could have some spring training, he said.

title: DR. ISIDORE S. FAUST
description: Dr. Isidore S. Faust, a physi cian in the Bronx for 55 years, died yesterday in a White Plains nursing home. He was 83 years old and lived at 263 West End Avenue.

title: Elgin Gets Refinancing
description: Elgin National Industries, Inc., said that refinancing ar rangements for a $21million shortterm debt had been con cluded with its leading banks and finance companies on a fully secured basis. The com pany said this would insure adequate working capital for Elgin's future needs.

title: JOSEPH F. SMITH OF MORMONS DIES
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 3 A noonhour funeral service in the Tabernacle on Temple Square will be held Thursday for Joseph Fielding Smith, pres ident, of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints, who died last night at the age of 95.

title: 500,000 Vegas Recalled Over Defect in Rear Axle
description: DETROIT, July 3The Gen eral Motors Corporation re called its small Vega cars again today tb correct a safety defect that could lead to a rear axle and wheel falling off.

title: For Sonsky, a Birthday, A Berth, a Better Life
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 3  Milt Sonsky celebrated his 31st birthday yesterday by winning a berth on the United States Olympic track and field team.

title: YANKEES TO START CRUCIAL ROAD TRIP
description: The future of the New York Yankees, and their key person nel, may be affected dispropor tionately by what happens on a ninegame trip through Cali fornia and Minnesota that starts in Oakland tonight.

title: DR. IRVING E. ALTMAN
description: Dr. Irving E. Altman, a vet erinarian who practiced in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 76 years old and lived at 2215 Newkirk Avenue, Brook lyn.

title: $500Million for Flood Set
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 3 (AP)An official of the Small Business Administration said today that his agency would provide some $500million for floodrelief programs and added that the biggest chunk will go to Pennsylvania.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Beach Law On Parade Control Blocked by Judge
description: MIAMI, July 3 (AP)Federal District Court Judge C. Clyde Atkins temporarily enjoined the City of Miami Beach today from enforcing a parade control law that had been attacked in court by leaders of groups plan ning demonstrations during this summer's political conventions.

title: HOT LINE PLANNED
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tues day, July 4Highlevel repre sentatives of North and South Korea held secret talks in Seoul and Pyongyang recently and agreed on principles to reunify the divided nation by peaceful means, a joint NorthSouth communiqu announced here today.

title: Six Nebraska Youths Drown
description: FALLS CITY, Neb., July 4 (AP)Five mentally retarded youths from the Omaha area and a counselor accompanying them drowned in the Missouri river at Indian Cave State Park near here yesterday. The vic time ranged in age from 17 to 22.

title: Hospitals Move in Court in Attempt To Block Strike Here on Thursday
description: The League of Voluntary Hos pitals, backing a restraint order received last month, filed a con temptofcourt showcause order against Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union yesterday in an attempt to head off a strike threatened for 6 A.M. Thurs day.

title: Miss Sarah A. Darneille Is Married
description: CAMDEN, Ark., July 3 Miss Sarah Ann Darneille, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Joseph Darneille of Camden and Houston, was married here this morning to Young Parran Dawkins 3d, son of Mr. Dawkins 2d of Golden's Bridge, N.Y., and Hilton Head, S.C., and the late Mrs. Dawkins.

title: I.T.T. Against Chile
description: If Congress needs a fresh spur for a thorough investi gation of the international political activities of giant corporations, the latest revelation about the International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation should provide it. I.T.T. not only maneuvered to try to block the inaugura tion of Chile's President Allende after his election 1970, but sought White House involvement last October in a covert campaign to bring down his Government.

title: GEORGE CAIN DIES; LED ABBOTT LABS
description: CHICAGO, July 3George R. Cain, chairman of Abbott Laboratories since 1962, died in his sleep last night at his home in Winnetka, Ill, He was 61 years old.

title: Miss Susanna Taylor Is Bride Of Joseph Cheshire Nash Upton
description: KIRBY, Mont., July 3 Miss Susanna Stillman Tay lor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jennings Taylor, was married here this afternoon to Joseph Cheshire Nash Up ton, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Graydon Upton of McLean, Va.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SAMUEL E. LEVINE
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., July 3Samuel E. Levine, judge of the Williamstown District Court since 1952, died of a heart at tack yesterday while visiting his daughter, Mrs. Pamela Sha men, in Cheshire, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 Con Ed Workmen Killed by Gas

title: Sony Marketing Subsidiary Attracts U.S. Applications
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday in Tokyo that it was establishing a subsidiary to market in Japan products made in the United States. A spokes man said Sony had received more than 1,000 applications from American companies seeking. Sony assistance in marketing their products. The applications were in response to advertisements Sony ran in selected United States news papers.

title: In Command in Vietnam Frederick Carlton Weyand
description: Man in the News

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (Reuters)New construction spending rose $1.2billion in May to a $121.8billion annual rate, in contrast to a revised $2.4billion April decline, according to preliminary Commerce Department data re leased today.

title: DR. IRVING RIBNER, EXPERT ON DRAMA
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., July 3 Dr. Irving Ribner, a Shakes pearian scholar and professor of English at the State Univer sity campus here, died yester day apparently by a heart at tack, at his home, Beach Road, Belle Terre, Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 50 years old.

title: 26 Food Outlets Here Charged With Violations of Health Code
S.B.A. May Seek More FloodLoan Funds
description: TheSmall Business Adminis tration disclosed yesterday that it might have to ask Con gress for additional funds to handle the large number of dis asterloan applications coming in from flood victims of tropi cal storm Agnes.

title: Agency Pays Track Price, Cites Good Public Relations
description: The Offtrack Betting Corpo ration, required by law to pay off at the same prices as Roose velt Raceway, yesterday figured it had lost about $7,000 because of the track's computer break down last Saturday night.

title: Indian Bus Crash Kills 27
description: NEW DELHI, July 3 (UPI) Twentyseven persons were killed and 37 others injured in a bustruck collision today near Amritsar, about 300 miles north of here, in Punjab state. The Press Trust of India, quoting informants in the state capital of Chandigarh, said that the truck was carrying a wedding party when it collided headon with the bus.

title: GandhiBhutto Pact Text
description: SIMLA, India, July 3 (AP) Following is the text of the agreement signed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of In dia and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan:

title: LARRS AND FOX WIN Y.R.A. CLASS RACES
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 3Mr. and Mrs. David Larr, by 1 minute 52 seconds and close to 200 yards with their Etchells 22, Rapscallion, and A. Shaw han Fox, by 1:37 and nearly as much distance with Fury in the Shields Class, were winners of 12.1mile Gold Cup races on Long Island Sound today.

title: Pakistani Assembly Meets On Indian Accord Monday
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, July 3 President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said here today that the National Assembly would meet in Islamabad next Monday to vote on ratification of the Indian  Pakistani agreement signed in Simla, India, last night. He spoke at the airport on arrival from his meeting with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Scholar Disputes Traditions on U. S Anthem's Origin
description: BALTIMORE, July 3A former British intelligence of ficer disputed today the tradition that Francis Scott Key saw the Star Spangled Banner wave over Fort McHenry and that someone other than Key had dis covered that the English drinking tune, To Anacreon in Heaven, would fit the words.

title: Man Drowns in East River After Rescuing His Dog
description: A 21yearold Lower East Side man jumped into the East River to rescue his dog yester day evening, and drowned after handing the dog to passersby on the seawall above.

title: Future of Oil Imports
description: Economic Analysis

title: BANNISTER LEADS DECATHLON TESTS
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 3De spite a temperature of 97 de grees, Jeff Bannister zeroed in on an 8,000point performance after opening day decathlon competition at the United States Olympic track and field trials today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation said yesterday that its postponed annual meeting had been rescheduled again, this time for Sept. 7.

title: Results Lower in Quarter At C.&O.B.&O. Railroad
description: Revenues and earnings of the Chesapeake & OhioBalti more & Ohio Railway system in the second quarter and first half this year were lower than in the yearearlier periods, the report showed yesterday.

title: Conditional Welcome in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, July 3 (AP)Bangladesh gave a con ditional welcome today to the agreement signed by India and Pakistan.

title: Roundup: Streaking Cards Take No. 7
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, baseball's hottest teeth, won their seventh straight game and 14th in their last 15 by topping the Cincinnati Reds, 42, last night at Cincinnati.

title: INTEREST RATES STEADY ON BONDS
