description: Interest rates registered only negligible changes in extremely light trading yesterday. The credit markets generally oper ated with reduced staffs, with many traders and syndicate personnel given the day off.

title: On the Dance Floor It Was 1946
description: The dancers moved about the ballroom of the Commo dore Hotel until the small hours yesterday. They shuf fled and swayed, and some times with great virtuosity people did the lindy. Mostly, however, they clumped them selves around the bandstand, or sat along the sides of the room and had reveries.

title: Converse and Eltra Sued By U.S. on Goodrich Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Justice Department to day filed a civil antitrust suit to stop the Converse Rubber Corporation from leasing, with an option to purchase, the rub bercanvas footwear operations of the B. F. Goodrich Com pany of Akron, Ohio.

title: Not a Place Upon Earth Might Be So Happy as America
description: These are the times that try men's souls. The summer soldier and the sunshine patriot will, hi this crisis, shrink from the service of his country; but he that stands it now deserves the love and thanks of man and woman. Tyranny, like hell, is not easily conquered; yet we have this con solation with usthat the harder the con flict, the more glorious the triumph. What we obtain too cheap, we esteem too lightly; It is dearness only that gives everything its value. Heaven knows how to put a proper price upon its goods; and it would be strange indeed if so celestial an article as freedom should not be highly rated. Britain, with an army to enforce her tyranny, has declared that she has a right not only to tax but to bind us in all cases whatsoever, and if being bound in that, manner is not slavery, then is there not such a thing as slayery upon earth. Even the expression is impious, for so unlimited, a power can belong only to God.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: AACHEN, West Germany, July 3 (AP)Gerd Wiltfang of West Germany rode Dorian Gray to victory today in the second, qualification round for the jumping champion ship of the Aachen international equestrian tournament. The winner was clocked in 48 seconds with no faults on a jumpoff course of 340 meters with six barriers and nine jumps.

title: Cairo Says Yemen's Renewal Of U.S. Ties Frays Arab Unity
description: CAIRO, July 3Yemen's de cision to resume diplomatic re lations with Washingtoncom bined with indications that the Sudan may soon follow suit was condemned here today as another painful example of Arab inability to take a com mon stand against common enemies.

title: HIJACKER'S LETTER TO NIXON REPORTED
description: A South Vietnamese student identified as the man who was killed sin Saigon Sunday while attempting to hijack a Pan American jet to Hanoi ap parently wrote an open letter to President Nixon on the day he boarded the plane.

title: Jazz:
description: Here is a schedule of to day's events in the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York:

title: Fox Will Film Lenny
description: Lenny, the play by Julian Barry about the late Lenny Bruce, which closed June 24 lafter 455 performances at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, will be filmed by 20th CenturyFox. Tom O'Horgan, who directed the play, and Marvin Worth, its producer, also will direct and produce the film.

title: In Blackout, Track Paid $21 Instead of $7.20 on a Winner
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 In the wake of last Saturday night's Roosevelt Raceway de bacle, caused by breakdowns in two computer systems which resulted in a fiverace card, it developed today that the win payoff of $21 on Jefferson Aiken in the second race should have been only $7.20.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 3 (UPI)The Goshen Cup, feature of the Grand Circuit openingday program, was won today by Valiant Bret. John Wilcutle drove the son of Bret Hanover to victory in the $16,212 stakes for 2yearold pacing colts.

title: Long Dress Is Still A Length Ahead
description: Barring a cataclysm, long dresses will maintain their reign during fall evenings. I went to a cocktail party in Oklahoma a month ago and all the men were in business suits and all the women in ball gowns, Oscar de la Renta remarked the other day. Even Oklahoma. Of course, ball gowns aren't the big issue. Long skirts, topped with sweaters, shirts or both are. So are long coat dresses, shirt dresses and jumpers. They're not meant for balls which, after all, occupy just a small number of evenings in the life of the most inveterate partygoer. They're the kind of thing you wear to dinner or to spend an evening with friends. In styling, they're not very different from the clothes most women wear during the day except for the skirt length, but even Mr. de la Renta concedes the extra length shows a woman has made an effort to dress.

title: Market place:Broker Explains Success: Luck
description: We asked one of our favor ite stock brokers the other day how to make money in the stock market.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Soybean futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade. Oil and meal futures prices moved up ward in sympathy with those of soybeans.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., July 3To the doctors, nurses and orderlies at Holy Cross Hospi tal, he is the model patient a scarred Southern gentleman who jokes and laughs and winks despite his pain and suf fering.

title: Business Briefs
description: Lazard Brothers & Co., a British merchant bank, announced yesterday in London the signing of a credit agreement with Societe National de Siderurgie of Algeria for ??

title: Jazz:
description: The Newport Jazz Festi val's Carnegie Hall concert last night was a peculiar mixture of quietly explora tory chamber jazz and ag gressively outgoing jazzrock.

title: Donohue Hurt as His Car Breaks Up at 160 M.P.H.
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., July 3 (UPI)Mark Donohue's Porsche came apart on the back straight away of Road Atlanta today in private practice and hurtled off the course at 160 miles an hour. But Donohue was not seriously injured.

title: Museum Sets Arts Festival; Films on List
description: The Solomon R. Guggen heim Museum will present a monthlong, summer arts fes tival of dance, film and mu sic starting July 26. The event has been made possi ble through the support of the New York State Council on the Arts.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, July 4 (Reuters)Fol lowing is the text of a joint North and South Korean communiqu made public simultaneously in Seoul and Pyongyang today, as issued in an official South Korean Government translation:

title: Baeza Victor in Features At the Big A, Monmouth
description: Braulio Baeza didn't waste any time getting favored Linda's Chief home first at Aqueduct yesterday in the $27,400 Juvenile Stakes.

description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 3 Leaders of two important Oppo sition partiesNational Awami and JamiatiIslam  welcomed the agreement today.

title: Clearance Sale of Valuable Players
description: Sports of The Times

title: Indians Praise Accord
description: NEW DELHI, July 3  The IndianPakistani agreement has been generally acclaimed by Indians.

title: U.S. COURT BACKS 2 PANEL DECISIONS ON SEATING SHIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3A Federal district judge upheld to day the Democratic Credentials Committee's actions in depriv ing Senator George McGovern of 151 of the delegates he won in California and in unseating Mayor Richard J. Daley and 58 other Chicago delegates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Candlewood Lake Spa Plan Is Opposed by Residents
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 3 A Federal plan calling for the revival of Candlewood Lake Connecticut's largest lake  as a summer spa for weekend vacationers from New York City, Hartford and New Haven is meeting angry opposition from local resi dents who say Candlewood is already overused.

title: A Showdown on Environmental Policy
description: News Analysis

title: U.S.Soviet Space Talks Due
description: HOUSTON, July 3 (AP) Soviet and United States space engineers will meet for two weeks at the Manned Space craft Center here to study a planned Joint space mission, officials announced today.

title: Finn, Tempest Trials Off
description: MARION, Mass., July 3 (AP) Dense fog forced postpone ment of the second race today in the final United States Olym pic trials for Finn and Tempest class craft on Buzzards Bay. Tomorrow's program will be moved up several hours in hopes of getting in two races.

title: Melges Takes Fourth Contest In Soling Class Olympic Trials
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP)Bud Melges of Zenda, Wis., was the winning skipper today in the fourth race of the United States Soling Class Olympic trials as the fleet raced under ideal conditions for the first time in the series.

title: Leader in N.A.A.C.P. Assails Supreme Court as a Rights Foe
description: DETROIT, July 3For the first time in recent history, the United States Supreme Court has been counted among the enemies of civil rights by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo ple.

title: Wall St. Wilts as Trading Melts
description: The summer doldrums ar rived in Wall Street yesterday, but hardly anybody was there to notice.

title: And Blacks Go South Again
description: DURHAM, N. C. A high school classmate came by the other day. He was making the rounds, saying good by before he left Durham for Atlanta to accept a Federal job down there.

title: Notes on People
description: With an exchange of quiet hellos on a dusty road in a refugee camp in South Viet nam, a search suffused with travail and romance came to an end after taking 24year old Steve Menta halfway around the world from his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. Mr. Menta, a former marine, returned last week to Vietnam to search for the young woman he knew as Leenie, 21yearold Thai Thi Thiet. Mr. Menta, who met Miss Thiet a year ago when stationed in her home town of Camlo, lost track of her after his return home when the town was overrun by Communist troops.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FREEPORT, L. I., July 2 Fishing captains at this Long Island angling retreat have had the distress flag flutter ing since the early spring. Although thete, have been sufficient flounders, fluke and bluefish about, continued foul weather has been keep ing the customers away.

title: Ilion Captures Big 6 Stake As Gaudeamus Show Ends
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 3 Ilion, the senior citizen of the division, captured the Big G I stake, closing feature of the fiveday Gaudeamus Farm's Horse Show tonight.

title: Oldest Montana House Burns
description: VIRGINIA CITY, Mont., July 3 (UPI)The oldest structure in Montana, the Madison County Courthouse, was de stroyed by fire on the weekend. The threestory brickandstone building contained records of the area and some historic pic tures of local miners dating back to 1863.

title: Intervention in Zurich Is First Since British Float of Jane 23
description: GENEVA, July 3The Swiss National Bank bought dollars today to anchor the Swiss franc to its official exchange rate against the dollar for the first time since the start of the recent monetary unrest.

title: New Specialization Policy Rankles Among Detectives
description: The robber wore a Fu Manchu mustache, his victims said, and there was a strange, sad look in his eyes as he flashed a gun and seized their watches, rings and cash.

title: SUBURBS POUNDED BY FIERCE STORE
description: Three lines of heavy thunder storms that stretched from New England across Pennsylvania rolled through several suburban and upstate counties yesterday, knocking out power lines, flood ing roads and basements and raining hailstones in several areas.

title: FANSTEEL SEEKS MERGER REVISION
description: Merger News

title: DRUG CHARGE IS LAID TO WOODSTOCK MAN
description: The state police reported yes terday that they had seized al most a half a ton of what appeared to be marijuana in Woodstock on Sunday after firemen extinguishing a blaze in a home there became suspi cious about large quantities of dry vegetable material in the kitchen.

title: Rail Group Elects President
description: M. Spalding Toon has been elected president of the Bes semer and Lake Erie Railroad Company, the Union Railroad Company, the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railway Company and the Duluth, Missabe and Iron Range Railway Company. He succeeds Fred W. Okie, who is retiring having reached the mandatory retirement age. Mr. Toon formerly was president of the Ohio Barge Line, Inc., and the Warrior & Gulf Navigation Company.

title: Video Art Turns to Abstract Imagery
description: Video is an art unto it self, with its own reality, visual language and its own conception of time and space, says Woody Vasulka, one of the increasing tribe of video artists who maintain that their medium is as much an art form as painting, sculpture and film.

title: Port Notes
description: The Port of Baltimore, one of New York's leading com petitors, has started a $23 million project to expand its containerhandling facilities.

title: Executive Changes
description: The FAG Bearings Corporation has appointed Heinz Kleinhenz as vice president, manufacturing. He succeeds Austin J. Rinella, who has resigned because of ill health.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz:
description: It was Alumni Day yester day at the Philharmonic Hall segment of the Newport Jazz Festival. Woody Herman and Stan Kenton were there with their current orchestras, joined by some of their old grads who hadmade good.

title: Books of The Times
description: A SENSE OF THE SENATE. By Seymour K. Freidin. 342 pages. Dodd, Mead. $8.95.

title: ORBAN AGAIN TAKES U.S. SABER HONORS
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 3 Alex Orban captured his fourth successive national men's saber crown and his fifth title since 1965 tonight at Bentley College.

title: The Corporate State
description: President Eisenhower was speaking of only one major segment of the political economythe sector he chris tened the militaryindustrial complexwhen he said that its total influenceeconomic, political, even spirit ualis felt in every city, every statehouse, every office of the Federal Government.  Our toil, resources, and livelihood are all involved; so is the very structure of our society.

title: ExMental Patient Charged in Slaying Of Brooklyn Woman
description: A 16yearold former state mental patient working as a porter in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 32yearold woman in the Bay Ridge Towers apart ment complex.

title: Bridge: Turkey Outperformed Potential And Finished 7th in Olympiad
description: If countries competing in the recent World Team Olym piad In Miami Beach had been ranked according to size like boxers, there is little doubt that Turkey would have won the flyweight class.

title: Javelin Mark by Lusis
description: OSLO, July 3 (AP)Janus Lusis of the Soviet Union re corded the longest javelin throw of the year tonight with heave of 297 feet, 9 inches.

title: C.A.B.. Examiner Approves Fare Rises of 1969.70
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner ruled today that the airline fare increases in effect for slightly more than a year, in 1969 and 1970, were neither unreasonable nor illegal, and need not be refunded.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: International Controls Gets Payment of $7.35Million
description: The International Controls Corporation, until recently the owner of a controlling interest in I.O.S., Ltd., said yesterday that it had received payment in cash of $7.35million from Global Financial, Ltd., a com pany owned by Norman P. Le Blanc, a former I.O.S. financial officer.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Gov ernment officials expect a war rant to be issued by Wednesday for the arrest of E. Howard Hunt Jr. as a material witness in connection with last month's raid on the Democratic Nations al Committee.

title: 11 Die on African Train
description: NORVALSPONT, South Af rica, July 3 (AP)Eleven per sons perished and 27 were in jured today in a derailment of a Port Elizabeth to Johannes burg passenger arain.

title: Big U.S. Contractor in Vietnam Ends Operations After 10 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (UPI)The big Ameri canowned construction com bine known as RMKBRJ ended its operations in Vietnam to day after 10 years in which it built $1.9billion worth of mili tary installations and public works under Government con tract.

title: When We Were a Revolutionary People
description: We had our American Revolution nearly two centuries ago, and the years have done something to it. The legends remain, and the statues and the grassy earthworks and the great body of tradition, but a good deal of the reality has been filtered out. When we look back we see Washington crossing the Delaware on, a cold winter night, or kneeling in prayer in the snow at Valley Forge; we see the Minuteman, or the lanky Virginia rifleman picturesque in fringed buckskin; but somehow it all seems to be out of a pageant, and neither Washington nor the men who followed him quite come alive for us.

title: A New Sleeping Beauty at Dutch Fete
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, July 2In Europe the Arts Festival has become a way of summer. Sometimes these events have a natural themeMozart for Salzburg or Shakespeare for Stratford onAvon. Other festivals, such as Edinburgh's, are diverse grab bags of cultural goodies. Such a festival is the Holland Festival, which this summer is celebrating its 25th year.

title: RUSSIANS EXPAND ATOM POWER UNIT
description: MOSCOW, July 3The So viet Union announced last week that a rapidly growing nuclear power station in central Russia had become the largest on the Eurasian continent and showed off the atomic complex to Pre mier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: 234th Victim of Flood Found
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., July 3 (AP)The body of the 234th victim of the Black Hills flood last month was recovered yes terday. The body of a child was found by a resident in a debrisladen tree along Rapid Creek. Nine persons are still missing and are presumed dead.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL AT A 4MONTH LOW
description: Steel production at midyear reached its Wryest level since midFebruary, according to weekly statistics released yes terday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Department Stores Here Had Higher Sales in June
description: Sales of seven of New York's largest department stores rose slightly in June from the same month last year, but excessive rain was blamed for about 10 days of erratic business.

title: Italians Say Lira Devaluation Is a Question of When, Not If
description: ROME, July 3Italian bank ers, politicians and people with savings accounts are almost fatalistically convinced that there is no longer a question of whether the lira will be de valued, but of when.

title: G.M.'s June Car Output Off
description: DETROIT, July 3 (Reuters) The General Motors Corpora tion reported today that June production of passenger cars totaled 434,236 against 458,690 a year ago. Commercial ve hicles totaled 89,888, compared with 89,377. In the year to date, passenger cars totaled 2,647,094 units against 2,737,344, while commercial vehicles totaled 556,085 against 505,411.

title: Fischer Leaves for Iceland After Briton Adds to Prize
description: A chessplaying London in vestment banker offered $125, 000 yesterday to double the world championship chess purse, and Bobby Fischer, the American challenger, agreed to fly to Iceland to meet Boris Spassky for the title.

title: U.S., Welcoming Move, Affirms Support of Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The United States tonight welcomed the news of the highlevel con tacts between North and South Korea and said that they could have a salutary impact on prospects for peace and stabil ity on the Korean peninsula.

title: Brooklyn Students Demonstrate Near City Hall for More Jobs
description: The semiholiday quiet around City Hall was shattered for a few hours yesterday as more than 150 junior and sen ior high school students from the Williamsburg area of Brooklyn staged an angry demonstration demanding more summer jobs under a federally financed program.

title: Money Crisis Is Discussed By Brandt and Pompidou
description: BONN, July 3President Georges Pompidou met here to day with Chancellor Willy Brandt in a conference domi nated by the monetary crisis.

title: Many Americans Are Raising Cattle in Costa Rica
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica There are times when Toby Orr misses Madison Valley, Mont.

title: Drive to Raise Funds for Environmental Groups Stirs Protests
description: Environmental groups are taking a second look at a new doortodoor moneyraising plan that has brought them a fresh source of funds but has run into opposition from some homeowners and government officials over its aggressive tactics.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONSometimes a nation is like its prophets who, the New Testa ment contends, are not without honor save in their own country. It is com forting to learn there are some people here who find moral value in the United Statesand rather more, in deed, than many Americans find.

title: 2 Are Named by Governor To Herkimer House Posts
description: ALBANY, July 4 (AP)Two men from Little Falls have been appointed by Governor Rockefeller as members of the board of commissioners of Herkimer House, the original home of Gen. Nicholas Herki mer, a Revolutionary War lead er.

title: Abortion Cases Creating Friction on High Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Supreme Court's decision to de lay its ruling on two abortion appeals until the next term has led to frictions within the Court and suggestions that Chief Jus tice Warren E. Burger has over stepped his authority to pick which Justices will write which majority opinions.

title: Nixon Is Encouraged
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4 (UPI)Gerald Warren, depu ty press secretary, said last night that President Nixon viewed the development as an encouraging indication of less ening of tensions in the areas which could have a favorable impact of the prospects for peace and stability on the Ko rean Peninsula.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, July 4 (UPI)Jean Yves Terlain of France, sailing the 128foot Americandesigned schooner, Vendredi 13, the largest yacht ever entered in the singlehanded transAtlantic race, surged today toward a record for a solo crossing of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Personalities: The King Loses
description: King Olav V of Norway couldn't take his cup and go home yesterday because Ernest Fay of New York skippered Stmdance to vic tory in the third and final race of the King Olav Cup competition for 5.5Meter yachts at Hankoe, Norway. Fay won by a comfortable margin over Robert H. Sy monette of the Bahamas after Australia's F. H. Tolhurst, a coleader with Fay after the first two races, damaged his rudder in the final stages and finished fifth. The King finished third. Rudolf Ugel stad of Norway won the Her man F. Whiton Memorial Cup for the Soling class.

title: Roman Proske of Circus; Leading Animal Trainer
description: MIAMI, July 4 (AP)Roman Proske, a former leading animal tamer, died of cancer yesterday at Parkway General Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Head of Max Planck Society Got Start in Texas P.O.W. Camp
description: BREMEN, West Germany, July 4The leadership of one of the world's largest and most diverse research establishments has been assumed by a dynamic figure whose scientific career began as the consequence of a depthcharge attack by two American destroyers.

title: Coleman's Skies of America in Debut
description: The Newport Jazz Festival made one kind of history this year when it moved to New York City. I suspect it will make another, and equally important, kind of history with its premiere of a major work for orchestra and jazz quartet called The Skies of America, written by Ornette Coleman.

title: Black Contractors Unite To Win Bigger Projects
description: Prior to 1969, Warren Brown, a black electrical contractor for 30 years in Buffalo, seldom obtained con struction jobs amounting to more than $10,000, and the number of blacks working on those projects at any given time was never more than three or four journeymen.

title: Market Place:
description: The smalland largein vestor is constantly poring over financial data in an ef fort to find some undiscovered investment medium in which he can make a substantial profit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,500 Are the Guests of A Funny Thing
description: About 1,500 people got to see a free performance of A Funny Thing Happened On the Way to the Forum last night, coourtesy of the man agement of the musical at Broadway's LuntFontanne Theater.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Max Bedacht, 89, CoFounder Of U.S. Communist Party, Dead
description: Max Bedacht, a founder of the Communist party in this country and a longtime member of its central executive com mittee, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamai ca, Queens. He was 89 years old and lived at 23430 131st Avenue, Rosedale, Queens.

title: San Diego to Be Paid For Convention Costs
description: SAN DIEGO, July 4 (AP) Mayor Pete Wilson says that $159,000 in Federal funds will be given to San Diego to help pay costs in preparing for the Republican National Convention that was later moved to Miami Beach, Fla.

title: A PARTY IS FORMED BY LIBERTARIANS
description: The Free Libertarian party, a new poltical party stressing op position to big government, big spending and government bureaucracy, made its debut in New York State yesterday by presenting candidates for one Congressional and two As sembly seats.

title: Jazz Fans Pack Ferry for Trip to Dixieland Via Hudson
description: A tidal wave of Dixieland jazz rolled up the Hudson River yesterday and nearly 6,000 jazz lovers were swept along with it. It carried most of them exactly where they wanted to goto shores of ecstasy or isles of euphoria.

title: $170,000 Damages Won For a Therapy Session
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP)A Superior Court ?? has awarded $170,000 to a former university coed from San Jose for injuries suffered in a 13hour therapy session with a psychologist.

title: Spassky, Refusing to Play, Asks Fischer Be Punished
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 4 The world championship chess match, moved thousands of miles, postponed and then postponed again because of the protests of Bobby Fischer, was delayed once more todaythis time because the Russian title holder refused to play.

title: Water Diversion Tunnel Is Dedicated In Colorado as Its Opponents Protest
description: LEADVILLE, Colo.,  The growing water problems of the arid Southwest states were the uninvited guests in a recent ceremony in a high mountain valley 10 miles west of here.

title: Washington Hails Korea Plan for Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The surprise agreement by South Korea and North Korea to un dertake unification talks has produced an enthusiastic initial response in the Nixon Admin istration. Some senior officials even speculated today that the latest development might bring pressure on Hanoi to negotiate an end to the Vietnam war.

title: The Korean Accord
description: This week's accord between South and North Korea is a historic development of the utmost importance for improving the political atmosphere in Asia and the world.

title: Lee Hu Rak
description: The South Korean official who secretly visited North Korea on a Kissinger  style mission in May is a chief adviser to President Park Chung Hee on national secu rity affairs and one of the most influential men in Seoul.

title: Tanaka Is Elected Premier By Party Caucus in Japan
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, July 5 Kakuei Tanaka, 54yearold Minister for International Trade and Industry, was this morning elected president of the govern ing LiberalDemocratic party at a special party caucus. Because of the party's majority position in the Parliament, he is assured of becoming Japan's next Premier.

title: L. S. Griffith Weds Mrs. Laura Fishburn
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 4 Mrs. Laura Nickell Fish burn and Lewis Scott Grif fith, both of Bronxville, were married here this afternoon in the chapel of Christ Epis copal Church by the Rev. Mark Sisk.

title: A French View of the Election
description: PARISThe idea, taken for granted a few months ago, that President Nixon would be automatically reelected in 1972, could only stem from the illusion that no basic changes had affected America during the sixties. Last fall, and even in early spring this year, it was generally admitted that all the movements born after 1960 had just faded away. American youth, one would argue, was in a state of com plete apathy, back to the fifties. Be sides, many people thought it had been obvious from the beginning that all the socalled revolutionary trends of the sixties would never find political expression. The young people, eligible to vote, were not even bothering to register, deplored some good citizens who, at the same time, were trying to prevent the students from doing so.

title: Patrolman Seized
description: A suspended policeman was taken into custody in the Gravesend Bay section of Brooklyn yesterday after being charged with possession of a large quantity of fireworks. The patrolman, Joseph Tanner, 26 years old, was apprehended in front of 2359 East Fourth Street, along with Ralph Rug gerio, who lives in the build ing, by Detective Ralph Piccolo of the 10th Detective Division.

title: FRED M'DOWELL, 68, GOSPEL SINGER, DIES
description: Mississippi Fred McDowell, an oldtime blues and gospel figure who attained fresh rec ognition during the last decade, died Monday night in Memphis. He was 68 years old and had lived for many years in Como, Miss.

title: GEORGE SCHUSTER, AUTO MOBILIST DIES
description: SPRINGVILLE, N. Y., July 4 George Schuster, who drove a 60horsepower Thomas Flyer to victory in the longest auto race from New York across America and Siberia to Paris in 1908, died today in a nurs ing home here. He was 99 years old.

title: SISTER M. RAPHAEL
description: Sister M. Raphael, a member of the Dominican Sisters of Blauvelt who was principal of the Lavelle School for the Blind in the Bronx from 1942 to 1948, died Sunday in the Mother House of the order in Blauvelt, N. Y. She was 77 years old.

title: ROGERS IS IN ATHENS; NOTES DIFFERENCES
description: ATHENS, July 4Secretary of State William P. Rogers, arriving today against a back ground of protest by the poli tical opposition, pointedly stressed the role of ancient Greece as the school of indi vidual liberty and democracy.

title: Fischer Is 52 Favorite
description: LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) Ladbroek's, the London book makers, quoted Fischer today as a 5to2 favorite to win against Spassky.

title: Three Martinis Delaware Victor
description: STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) Edward Sawyer's Three Mar tinis and Jack Van Berg's Merry Perry captured divisions of the Cochise Handicap today at Del aware Park. The races were switched from the rainsoaked turf course to the main track.

title: Padres Take 2d Game, 42, on TwoRun 9th
description: Leron Lee's ninthinning sin gle in the first game prevented Tom Seaver from pitching a no hitter, and Derrel Thomas's ninthinning single in the sec ond game prevented the Mets from sweeping the double header yesterday.

title: WILLIAM MACKEY JR., BIRD DECOY EXPERT
description: William J. Mackey Jr., an authority and writer on bird decoys, died Sunday of a heart attack while visiting friends in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived at 497 East Road, Belford, N.J.

title: Sheriff's Captain, Discharged Over 1970 Rioting in California, Is Reinstated
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4  Joel B. Honey, the Santa Bar bara County Sheriff's captain who was dismissed for alleged misconduct as commander of police forces in the 1970 Isla Vista riots, is back on duty after being reinstated by the county Civil Service Commis sion.

title: Trading in Three Companies Halted by Ontario Agency
description: TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press)The Ontario Securities Commission today halted trad ing in the securities of Seaway MultiCorp., the Security Capi tal Corporation and La Luz Mines, Ltd.

title: Image of Culture to Come
description: Slides projected on the facade of the New York Cul tural Center will publicize cultural events throughout the summer in the New York area.

title: Monday Night Fight
description: ChicagoZovek Barajas, Mexico City, knocked out Lyle Randolph. Akron, Ohio, 4 rounds, junior light weights.

title: Pastore Won't Be Delegate
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 4 (AP)Senator John O. Pastore said today that he would not be a delegate to the Democartic National Convention despite ac tion that added him and six other regular Democratic lead ers to the 22member delega tion pledged to Senator Mc Govern. The Rhode Island Dem ocrat said he was upset by the decision of the national party's Credentials Committee to add the delegates.

title: Little Rock Bishop Resigns
description: VATICAN CITY, July 4 (UPI) Pope Paul VI accepted the resignation today of the Most Rev. Albert L. Fletcher, Bishop of Little Rock, Ark., and ap pointed Msgr. Andrew L Mc Donald of Savannah, Ga., to succeed him.

title: Freddie Hubbard Generates Enthusiasm
description: Although a sign in the lobby of Carnegie Hall con firmed reports that Miles Da vis would not play at the Newport Jazz Festival con certs at 5 and 9 P.M. yester day for which he had been advertised, only 60 persons asked for a refund at the first performance.

title: HOT LINE SET UP BY THE 2 KOREAS UNDER UNITY PLAN
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 4 An hour after agreeing to end their long, bitter antagonism and start working together for peaceful reunification, North and South Korea began taking steps today to put their agree ment into action.

title: Pasolini's Film Wins Top Award at Berlin Festival
description: BERLIN, July 4Pier Paolo Pasolini's Canterbury Tales an adaptation of the Chau cer classictoday won the Golden Bear best film award at Berlin's 22d International Film Festival.

title: Little Sarah and Nancy Help Seaver to Forget That Good Pitch
description: With her frilly white underpants peeking out from her pink dress, Sarah Lynn Seaver scampered across the locker room toward her mother.

title: De Vicenzo Quits British Golf
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)Ro berto de Vicenzo of Argentina, the winner in 1967, has with drawn from the British Open golf championship that begins July 12 at Muirfield, Scotland, the organizers said today.

title: Delegate Is Approved On His 18th Birthday
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI)The Democratic Cre dentials Committee voted to seat a young Vermont dele gate who celebrated his 18th birthday today and had not been eligible to vote when he sought the post.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The fate of Senator George McGov ern's candidacy for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination may well turn on a series of procedural questions at the party's national convention next week.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Memorex Corporation and the Bank of America announced yesterday that they had agreed on the sale and purchase of $14.5million in Memorex convertible notes.

title: HUGH F. SMITH
description: Hugh F. Smith, circulation director of The New York JournalAmerican at his retire ment in 1965, died Monday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flush ing, Queens. He was 66 years old and lived at 21119A 73d Avenue, Bayside.

title: Wall Street Area Hums With Holiday Activities
description: There was bluegrass country music performed by a troupe from New Jersey and crash courses were given in the hora and in Greek folk dance in the Wall Street area yesterday as several thousand tourists joined in a daylong attempt to trans form the nation's financial cen ter into the bustling village it was 196 years ago.

title: BURNS SEES PERIL IN CURBING FUNDS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4  Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned nations today against restricting the entry of long range investment capital while controlling the Inflow of specu lative funds.

title: MRS. HERBERT GERLACH
description: OSSINING, N. Y., July 4 Mrs. Helen Carpenter Gerlach, widow of Herbert C. Gerlach, who was Westchester County Executive and chairman of the Republican County Committee, died Saturday while visiting her daughter, Mrs. John J. Frey, in Ridgefield, Conn. She was 81 years old and lived at 68 Croton Avenue.

title: SPREAD IS FEARED IN BUILDING HALT
description: The first real effects of a strike by 65,000 building trades workers is expected to be felt today when work re sumes on $2billion worth of construction projects in the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRECRACKER 400 WON BY PEARSON
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4David Pearson, continuing his brilliant comeback in stock car racing, won the Firecracker 400 today for his fourth super speedway victory of the sea son. The Firecracker, run in 96 degree heat, also represented the sixth victory in 10 races for the Wood brothers' red and gold Purolator Mercury.

title: SONGS & BANTER BY SONNY & CHER
description: Every now and then a per former, an audience and a loca tion come together in a perfect meeting of spirit and place. Sonny & Cher's opening at the Westbury (L.I.) Music Fair Monday night was a prime example: a slick, young, tele visionoriented entertainment team playing before a suburban middleclass audience in a thea ter in the round.

title: U.S. COURT DELAYS RULING ON SEATING
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia re served its decision tonight on two cases involving the polit ical composition of the Demo cratic National Convention, which opens next Monday in Miami Beach. A ruling is ex pected tomorrow.

title: Turkish Lira Is Revalued
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 4 (AP)The Turkish central bank has revalued the Turkish lira upward in relation to the pound. The bank lowered the rate of exchange from 36.47 Turkish lire for one pound to 34.28 Turkish lire.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) The American Red Cross es timated yesterday that it would cost more than $15million in Red Cross funds to provide as sistance to more than 50,000 families hit by floods in the Middle Atlantic states.

title: DOLLAR BUFFETED ANEW IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, July 4The dollar was buffeted today in Frank furt, Zurich, Paris and other money centers of Continental Europe, and central banks in tervened on a large scale to prevent their currencies from rising above fixed upper limits.

title: Promoting Inflation
description: The construction industry in this city has long been a jungle of graft. A survey by this newspaper demon strated afresh last week that every element in this multibilliondollar business, from the contractor through the municipal building inspector, is involved in an in stitutionalized system of payoffs. Not much has changed from the days of Sam Parks and the Tweed ring.

title: Quangtri Villagers Tell of Fleeing Bombing
description: PHUDUONG, South Vietnam, June 29They had lived for nearly two months under North Vietnamese occupation, but, they say, it was the constant pounding by American bombs and shells, not Communist rule, that finally drove them to desperation and to escape.

title: Truman Called WellRested After Gastrointestinal Tests
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 4 (AP)Former President Harry S. Truman was reported well rested today at Research Medi cal Center as his doctor contin ued what he described as rou tine tests for a gastrointestinal problem.

title: Business Briefs
description: Fixed exchange rates are incompatible with free capital movement and independent economic policies that result in varying rates of inflation around the world, the First National City Bank said yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: All securities and commodities exchanges and banks were closed yesterday in observance of the Independence Day holiday. Most Government offices were also shut. Canadian and overseas markets were open, however, for trading.

title: PLUMBING CONCERNS AGREE TO PAY CLAIM
description: An action charging 15 major plumbing supply companies and their trade association with violation of antitrust laws has resulted in a settlement of $91,500.

title: Flirting With Death
description: The potential magnitude of the disaster to hospital patients, as compared to the triviality of the union issue involved, makes it impossible to believe that Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union will actually carry through its threat of a citywide hospital strike tomorrow.

title: U.S. and France Will Explore Depths of MidAtlantic
description: LYONS, France, July 4  France and the United States have agreed on a threeyear plan for submarine exploration of the cavernous midAtlantic rift valleys almost a mile and a half beneath the ocean surface. It is a venture that conjures up images from Jules Verne.

title: DR. PEPPER IS SUING COKE ON TRADEMARK
description: MEMPHIS, July 4 (AP)The Dr. Pepper Company has filed suit in the United States Dis trict Court at Memphis charg ing the CocaCola Bottling Com pany with trademark infringe ment.

title: Pilot Is Killed in Crash Of Model of Old Plane
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 4 (AP)J. D. Morrison, a vet eran jet pilot flying cross country in an opencockpit plane like the one in which he learned to fly in 40 years ago, was killed today when the craft crashed near Na pier, Mo., about 40 miles north of here, the Highway Patrol said.

title: 3 Men Held on Coast in Slaying Of Girl, 4, by Shot From an Auto
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) Three young men were ar rested early today in the slay ing of a fouryearold girl. The child was playing in her front yard when she was hit by a shotgun blast fired from a passing car.

title: Waldheim Discloses Role
description: GENEVA, July 4Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations, welcoming the agreement reached by North and South Korea, disclosed to day he had played a role as intermediary in their secret talks.

title: 61 Reported Missing In Landslide in Japan
description: KOCHI, Japan, Wednesday, July 5 (Ap)Torrential rains set aff a landslide which smashed at least 10 homes and swept a locomotive and two railway coaches into a ravine in southern Japan today. The police said that 61 persons were missing.

title: SCOTT UNIT OFFERS POLL SCORING CITY
description: A Gallup poll released yester day by the Scott Commission, a body created last year by Governor Rockefeller to in vestigate the quality of the city's government, found that 60 per cent of 709 people in terviewed felt that the Lindsay administration was doing a poor job.

title: 2 Chinatown Youths Shot Near Manhattan Bridge
description: Two Chinatown teenagers were wounded, one critically, in a shooting incident last night in a small playground at Bayard and Chrystie Streets near the Manhattan Bridge. The police said the person or persons who did the shooting were appar ently waiting in ambush in the park. There were no arrests.

title: Woman Jumps to Death
description: An unidentified young woman apparently jumped to her death yesterday from the roof of the 50story Americana Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, the police said.

title: GEORGE EDGAR CLAPP
description: WATERFORD, Conn., July 4 George Edgar Clapp, retired editor of The Day, a New Lon don newspaper, died Sunday of natural causes while at the wheel of his car near his home. He was 71 years old.

title: Religious Festival Ends With a Meditation Session
description: GRANBY, Colo., July 4 Standing in line for breakfast at love kitchen, one could not mistake the form on the side of the mountain. It was snow in the shape of a white buffalo, a good omen, some said, meaning they had come to the right place at the right time and were a pleas ure in the sight of God.

title: 427 Died in Rhodesia Mine
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 4 (Agence France  Presse) The final death toll in the coal mine explosion a month ago was 427. The toll was announced here today by the Wankie Colliery Company.

title: Consumer Imports Are Going on Strong
description: Shoes and furniture from Brazil and Greece  men's clothing from Spain bathing suits from France  jewelry from Finland  everything from artificial flow ers to pocket computers and TV sets from Japan, Hong Kong and points in between.

title: Schiller Asks to Resign
description: BONN, July 4 (Reuters)  Economics and Finance Min ister Karl Schiller has asked to be relieved of his post in pro test against monetary control measures decided on by the West German Cabinet against his will, government sources said tonight.

title: Ballet Theater Opens Runin Top Form
description: The American Ballet Thea ter swung into its summer season at the New York State Theater last night with a triple bill consisting of Al vin Ailey's The River, Bir git Cullberg's Miss Julie and Harald Lander's Etudes. It offered the company at its expansive, confident and eclectic best.

title: Study Indicates McGovern Would Help in House Races
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) The chairman of the House Democratic Study Group said yesterday that a staff analysis showed that Senator George McGovern, if he were the Dem ocratic Presidential nominee, would help rather than hurt the party's chances to retain control of the House.

title: At Least 31 Are Killed as Fire Sweeps British Mental Hospital
description: SHERBORNE, England, Wednesday, July 5 (Reuters) At least 31 people were killed when a fire swept through a mental hospital in this town in southwest England early today.

title: Notes on People
description: Led by Premier Golda Meir, virtually the entire Is raeli Cabinet and military and judicial establshment ap peared at the official resi dence of the United States Ambassador in Tel Aviv for a sentimental tribute on Wal worth Barbour's 12thand probably final  Independ ence Day there.

title: Bank Study Finds Employe Savings Gaining in the U.S.
description: Employe savings plans are becoming a widespread and popular feature of American industrial life, the Bankers Trust Company said yesterday. The bank published a booklet based on a study of industrial employe savings plans which, it said, are on the whole a phe nomenon of the past 20 years, although some notable plans are much older.

title: Algeria Grants Amnesty
description: ALGIERS, July 4 (Reuters) President Houari Boumedienne today reprieved all Algerian prisoners condemned to death and changed their sentences to prison terms. The number of prisoners affected by the re prieve, which came on the eve of the 10th anniversary of Al geria's independence, was not known.

title: TASS CHANGES MIND ON U.S.SOVIET TALK
description: MOSCOW, July 4Ambassa dor Jacob D. Beam of the United States had a meeting with the Soviet Defense Minister today, and the news appeared to throw Tass, the official press agency, into confusion.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON CANCER DRUGS
description: MOSCOW, July 4  The United States and the Soviet Union, expanding their joint re search on cancer, have agreed on a program of exchanges of experimental drugs for tests in each other's laboratories.

title: Police Say Slaying Of Art Dealer Here Is Near a Solution
description: The police said yesterday that they were very close to a solution in the murder of An thony Bower, the art dealer who was found shot Monday morning in his East Side apart ment.

title: JOB PROTEST ENDS IN EAST ST. LOUIS
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, III., July 4 (AP)More than 50 black un employed men who occupied City Hall here for six days said today that they had agreed to an offer of jobs by Mayor James E. Williams and would leave the building.

title: 2d Body in 2 Weeks Found In the Connecticut River
description: WINDSOR, Conn., July 4 (UPI)for the second time in two weeks a body has been found in the Connecticut River. Both were those of murder vic tims, the police said today.

title: Lon Nol Frees Prisoners, Including Sihanouk Relative
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 4 (AP)Marshal Lon Nol to day ordered the release of a batch of prisoners including, Government sources said, a close relative by marriage of the former head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who is now in exile in Peking.

title: Gov. Ford Due at Convention
description: HOUSTON, July 4 (AP)Gov. Wendell Ford of Kentucky, re covering from vascular surgery, was given permission today to fly to Florida on Thursday to attend the Democratic National Convention.

title: Nkrumah's Mother Awaits Return of Son's Body
description: NKROFUL, Ghana, June 29 Mrs. Elizabeth Nyaniba is a small woman of somewhere over a hundred years who has lost her sight but retains a clear voice and a sharp mem ory. For weeks now she has had a growing fear that she may never again touch my son before I die.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A peaceful demonstration by dogs and their owners opposing Mayor Lindsay's call for legislation against dog litter was briefly disrupted when a rabbit happened by yesterday.

title: BIG SPRUCE WINS BY TWO LENGTHS
description: Big Spruce took to the turf with great gusto, winning the $57,900 Lexington Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by two lengths. The event, for 3year olds at 1 316 miles on the grass, attracted 11 starters and Big Spruce, carrying the Elmen dorf silks, scored by two lengths over the Greentree Sta ble's Ruritania.

title: LINDSAY ENTERS HOSPITAL DISPUTE
description: Hopes brightened yesterday for averting a strike threatened for tomorrow by 42,000 work ers in 66 voluntary and munic ipal hospitals here.

title: Saigon Intellectuals See Morale Collapse
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4A feeling is growing within South Vietnam's small educated lite that national morale has so collapsed that only a total revolution in the whole social structure offers hope of redemption.

title: Hanoi Reports Downings
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, July 5 (UPI)  North Vietnamese armed forces shot down two United States planes that raided many places inside Hanoi and Ninhbinh province at noon yes terday, the North Vietnamese press agency reported today. The downings brought the num ber of American planes shot in North Vietnam so far to 3,717, the agency said.

title: Government Confiscates 14 Saigon Newspapers
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 5Fourteen of Saigon's daily newspapers, including both Englishlan guage dailies, were confis cated by the Government last night, and the Interior Min istry announced today that they would be prosecuted for violation of the press laws.

title: Jazz: Sounds Afloat Ring Out Joyously
description: The producers of the New port. Jazz Festival got a strong hint of how to run a jazz festival yesterday when they took their audiences for a ferryboat ride on the Hud son: Pull the festival out of the concert halls and float the whole shebang on the river.

title: Nurse Leads a Fight to Change Color Blind to Color Deficient
description: CALDWELL, N. J., July 4 A school nurse who saw what a thoughtless word can do to children has begun a cam paign to eliminate the phrase color blind from the lan guage.

title: DRAFT UNITS SPAN LANGUAGE HURDLE
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 4  Remember, whenever you see the word Greetings on a let ter from your local board, you know you've been drafted, said Guillermo Muniz, wind ing up his explanation of the Selective Service system to the small group of Puerto Rican youths and their parents who gathered recently in Danbury's Young Men's Christian Associ ation building.

title: One Killed and 5 Injured In Leftist Strike in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, July 4 (UPI) One person was killed and five injured in the southeastern city of Puno after a group of strik ing leftist students and workers tried to disarm a truck full of policemen, a spokesman for the prefect of Puno said today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) The Credentials Committee completed its preconvention agenda today by disposing of a number of challenges, includ ing those involving Connecti cut and New Jersey.

title: Ezra Benson Gets Award
description: BOSTON, July 4 (AP)The New England Rally for God, Family and Country gave its Man of the Year Award tonight to Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisen hower Administration. Mr. Ben son is a member of the Council of the Twelve of the Church of Jesus Christ of Laterday Saints.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 4 (Reuters)The Soviet team competing in the Brazilian independence soccer tournament has been put on a diet after losing, 10, to Argentina last night.

title: Roundup: Dodgers Err And Alston Complains
description: This is the worst stretch I've seen like this in my ex perience, said Walter Al ston, who took over as man ager of the Dodgers in 1954. His team, which moved to Los Angeles from Brooklyn in 1958, lost its fifth game in a row, 73, last night at Mon treal for its longest losing streak of the season.

title: Nuptials on L.I. for Gayle Young
description: EAST HILLS, LI, July 4 Miss Gayle Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Young, was married here this afternoon to Carlos Escolar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hipolito Escolar of Madrid. Rabbi Ed ward Klein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, whose mar riage he had performed 23 years ago at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue of New York.

title: Sports of The Times
description: This is Grand Circuit week in Goshen, N. Y., when the trotters and pacers come back to the peaceful little seat of Orange County and find it much the same as it was when Messenger, the gray progenitor of America's light harness horse, stood at stud there 171 years ago, or when Messenger's prepotent descendant, Hambletonian 10, was foaled in 1849.

title: Swiss Erect New Dike Against Foreign Capital
description: GENEVA, July 4The Swiss Government erected new ram parts today to repel an invasion of foreign capital in a deter mined bid to prevent demand for the Swiss franc from up setting the nation's monetary balance.

title: Jerry Finkelstein: A Study In Personality and Politics
description: His eye lights upon it, and like a kid who has cracked a stuffed piggybank, he's into it. Politics, power, celebrities. A tangle of business af fairs, which means scurrying about town in his $36,000, chauffeurdriven, tan Rolls Royce. The car never works smoothly enough, stalls even. But this gives him those ex tra moments to whip out his specially made, narrow, off white cards and start jotting. His name is on top of each and beneath is the heading: FOR NOTES AND IDEAS.

title: Hearings Ended in Suit to Halt Tombigbee Project
description: ABERDEEN, Miss., July 1 Hearings have ended in an en vironmental suit seeking to halt construction of the Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway, an ex tensive United States Corps of Engineers project designed to link the highly developed Ten nessee River with the Tombig bee River in Alabama to form a navigation system to the east ern Gulf Coast.

title: PolishEast German Tourism Booming Upder OpenBorder Policy
description: ZGORZELEC, Poland, June 26  Germans are pouring across the Polish border again, but as tourists in sputtering Trabant and Wartburg cars ra ther than as soldiers in the armored vehicles of a Panzer division.

title: Vatican's Move in Poland
description: The decision of the Vatican to appoint Polish bishops for the areas of presentday Poland that once belonged to. Germany is of considerable political importance in that it represents the Pope's acceptance of Poland's Western borders. This move was only made possible by West Germany's ratification of the treaty with Warsaw in which Bonn finally recognized the OderNeisse line.

title: Nuclear Plant Watched For Heat Pollution Peril
description: SOLOMONS ISLAND, Md. It's a better design, said Dr. Joseph A. Mihursky as he stood on the rolling deck of the research vessel Aquarius and peered at the Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant on the shore, but is it good enough?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Leematt 2d at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) Calumet Farms' Eastern Fleet, guided by Angel Cordero, caught pacesetting Leematt in the upper stretch and went on to post a 1length victory to day in the $58,050 Firecracker Handicap at Liberty Bell.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: SAIGON REPORTS ITS TROOPS ENTER QUANGTRI CAPITAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 5South Viet namese paratroops and marines were reported to have moved into Quangtri city yesterday as Government forces continued their drive to retake the north ernmost province, which fell to the Communists in May.

title: U.S. Sees Nothing New
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The State Department had no im mediate comment on Mr. Tho's remarks, but a specialist on Asia said that there seemed to be nothing essentially new in the interview.

title: Connally Arrives in India; Effort to Revive Ties Seen
description: NEW DELHI, July 4John B. Connally, President Nixon's special envoy, arrived today from Dacca, reportedly to open a dialogue aimed at repairing the strained relationship be tween the United States and India.

title: HOWARD JENSEN, 58; PRODUCED TV FILMS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 4 Howard C. Jensen, a producer of historical and educational films for television, died yester day in White Plains Hospital. Mr. Jensen, who was 58 years old and lived at 43 Winston Road, had suffered a heart at tack on Friday.

title: Faked Photo Nudity Charged
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (UPI)Two members of the San Francisco Ballet filed a $2.5 million suit yesterday contend ing that a color photograph had been retouched to make them appear nude. Sara Maule and Geoffrey Thomas, the dancers, asked the court to block the display and distribution of the photograph.

title: Bannister, Bennett Finish 1, 2. in U.S. Decathlon Trial
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 4Their names are Jeff Bannister and Jeff Bennett, and if they sound unfamiliar, well, that could change in Munich this summer.

title: SMITH TRIUMPHS OVER METREVELI; CONNORS BEATEN
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 4Stan Smith and three Euro peans are in the semifinals at the Wimbledon tennis tourna ment, and the big fellow is be coming recognizable.

title: Look Urged at Labor's Economic Impact
description: We've been talking to our selves too much, said Carl H. Hageman, a vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation and a leading exponent of labor law reform.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, July 4 (Reuters)Twentyone European countries have agreed on a draft convention to establish a single organization to govern the granting and recogni tion of patents, it was announced today.

title: Advertising:
description: Some ad agencies have taken moves to formalize what to an outsider at least seems to be a wellestab lished traditionthe early slide on the eve of summer weekends.

title: TAXI LIGHT TAKES TWO HUNTER TITLES
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., July 4 Taxi Light, a 5yearold chest nut gelding, captured two championships today at the Peacefield Farm's horse show in his second appearance of the year.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Jessica, a Class A yacht, was reported 950 miles out of Bermuda at noon yesterday and leading in the trans Atlantic yacht race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain.

title: Margin Is 3 Lengths
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 Summer Guest, leading 3year old filly in the East, won the $56,500 Monmouth Oaks at 1 miles today.

title: Senator Muskie's Quandary
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Senator Ed mund S. Muskie who once expected to be the Presidential nominee of a reasonably united Democratic party now finds himself at the center of a storm which is tearing his party apart.

title: 3 Denver Policemen Hurt Trying to Dismantle Bomb
description: DENVER, July 4 (UPI)A blasting cap bomb blew up to day in the faces of three police men trying to dismantle it. The policemen, members of the de partment's bomb squad, were injured critically.

title: International Sister Cities Viewed as Allaying Fear of Isolationism
description: HORICON, Wis., Smack in front of Horicon's pub lic library is a neat red wood sign pointing eastward and stating: Our Sister City, Senonches, France, 4,494 miles.

title: Tokyo Shortage Brings Drive to Save Water
description: TOKYO, July 4 (UPI) Tokyo city offiicals distribut ed leaflets today asking res idents, department stores and restaurants to save water in the worst shortage since 1964.

title: Vietcong Assert a Serious Reply To Plan Could Have Ended War
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  Nguyen Huu Tho, president of the South Vietnamese National Liberation Front, said today that the Vietnam war could have ended if President Nixon had responded seriously to its sevenpoint peace plan aimed at creating an independent and neutral South Vietnam.

title: Number of Atlantic Brant Feared to Be Diminishing
description: TUCKAHOE, N. J., July 4 Thousands of Atlantic brant, small sea geese that have crowded the Atlantic flyway in flocks totaling 200,000 birds in recent years, are missing, and nobody is quite sure why.

title: Billingslea Oregon Aide
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 4 (UPI) Ron Billingslea, a University of Pennsylvania basketball star under Coach Dick Harter, was named today an assistant to Harter, now coach at Oregon.

title: BUZKASHI SCORES IN $83,300 RACE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP)Bill Shoemaker broke a personal stakes victory drought today when he guided Buzkashi to victory in the $83,300 Amer ican Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: BRIGGS CAPTURES POWERBOAT RACE
description: STAMFORD, July 4With nearly half the fleet of 46 ant boards knocked out of conten tion by rough water, Stamford's first Harbor Festival marathon was halted today after one hour of a scheduled twohour race.

title: Business Briefs
description: An electronic editing and display system for journalism and publishing that dispenses with the cathode ray tube has been announced by OwensIllinois, Inc.

title: Wide Gap in Acceptances Found in Welfare Centers
description: A study of seven years' ac ceptance rates of welfare family applications here shows wide and unexplained variations among the city's 43 welfare centers, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday in asking for an investigation by the State Controller.

title: Southampton's Parade Is Big and Brassy
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4Art Nagle whistled the Battle Hymn of the Repub lic as the Junior Thunderers marching band swung down Main Street in the bright morning sun.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) Britain's reserves of gold, dollars and other foreign cur rencies have dropped to $6.965billion, the lowest they have been this year, the Treasury announced today.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The latest word from In dianapolis is that the United States Auto Club and Pocono International Raceway are still negotiating a resched uling of the Schaefer 500, second segment of USAC's triple crown of 500mile races, which was to have run Sunday. Representatives of both parties held a fourhour meeting in Indy over the holiday weekend, and they are now maintaining tele phone contact.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, July 4Prompt ly at 10 A.M. a chauffeur driven RollsRoyce glides to a halt at a building in the shadow of St. Paul's Cathe dral. The car door opens and Jim Slater, a lean, dapper figure steps out quickly to move into a waiting elevator that takes him to his office round of phone callsto bankers in Hong Kong, Industrialists in South Africa, in vestors in Aus tralia and, to chess experts in London.

title: FloodSoaked Books Frozen to Ward Off Mold
description: Freeze before drying. That is the way to salvage the books damaged by the recent flood waters in the East, according to Mrs. Carolyn Horton, a lead ing book and print conservator, and that is what the Corning Glass Center in upstate New York is doing to save nearly 6,000 volumes on the history, design and craft of glass.

title: Peking to Admit Newsman
description: TOKYO, July 4 (Reuters) China has agreed to let the Yomiuri Shimbun, a masscir culation Japanese daily, station a correspondent in Peking after a break of five years, it was announced today. Yomiuri's correspondent was ousted dur ing the Cultural Revolution in 1967. There are now four Japanese correspondent in Peking and the same number of Chinese in Tokyo.

title: U.S. Golfer Senior Leader
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 4 (AP)Bob Loufek of Moline, Ill., shot a 74 for a 143 total to take the second round lead in the international senior golf championship today. Raymond Palmer, of Grosse Ile, Mich., shot 72 for 145 for second place over the 6,335yard par70 Queen's course.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Wall Street and much of the business community are in a state of confusion and alarm over Senator George McGov ern's economic proposals. If the South Dakotan wins the Demo cratic nomination for the Presi dency at Miami Beach next week, business anxiety will in tensify. Are such anxieties war ranted? Last week in an interview with one of the na tion's leading tax authorities, Joseph A. Pechman, direc tor of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, we exam ined Senator McGovern's pro posed taxcredit plan for re placing the present welfare system and redistributing in come.

title: 9 Police Hurt and Stores Looted In Predawn Harlem Disorder
description: Nine policemen were injured and 14 stores and two police cars were damaged in three hours of intermittent street dis turbances in Harlem yesterday, the police reported. Twenty three persons were arrested.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAWS ARE FOUND IN CRIMINAL LAW
description: A group of New York law yers and legal scholars has in dicted the American system of criminal law on the ground that if the main purpose of the criminal law is to reduce crime, it has failed.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Why would anyone make bread in the shape of a mushroom? Because it has mushrooms in it seems to be the answer.

title: Dangerous Orthodoxy
description: A controversy over a study of the effect of school busing on the educational progress of black children has raised serious questions about the academic response to research that clashes with accepted liberal views. David J. Armor, an associate professor of sociology at Harvard, has concluded from his analysis of busing projects in five Northern cities that the new educational experience of black youngsters transferred to predominantly white schools has failed to raise their test scores, has de pressed their selfconfidence and aspirations and has caused many of them to embrace separatism.

title: Books of The Times
description: No man is an island in himself, but many of those who would like to be go to Martha's Vineyard. It's a place where you can marinate in your own juices, lie a quarter of a mile from anybody else on a beach and let the sun fry your ontol ogy until it bursts into flames. If your own dimensions begin to frighten you, you can seek out all sorts of felicity, for like a historical and geographical depart ment store, the Vineyard has something for everyone.

title: MONETARY PARLEY FAILS TO NARROW BONNPARIS GAP
description: BONN, July 4  President Georges Pompidou of France and West German Chancellor Willy Brandt concluded today two days of talks that failed to narrow the gap between the positions of the two countries on the world monetary crisis and the character of the ex panded European Economic Community and its relations with the United States.

title: McCarthy Scores Platform
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy criticized today the proposed Democratic platform for not advocating the legaliza tion of marijuana and imme diate amnesty for draft evaders. He also said that the platform should call for a political settle ment of the Vietnam war that would include negotiation of a new Government in South Viet nam.

title: On the Need for Prophets in Our Own Time
description: Life in America is changing. School is becoming freer, community is re placing isolation, marriage is becom ing less of an enslavement, openness is taking over from superficiality, black is becoming beautiful. But the changes aren't happening fast enough, nor for enough people, and there are always those who would block them and even turn back the clock if they could.

title: LUTHERANS TIGHTEN OPERATIONAL SETUP
description: DALLAS, July 4 (AP)The Lutheran Church in America approved today a major over haul in its operational ma chinery.

title: INCREASE IS SEEN IN BLOCK TRADING
description: Financial institutions, which have increasingly dominated the trading on the New York Stock Exchange in recent years, are expected to increase their share of total volume in the balance of the present decade.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: AACHEN, West Germany, July 4 (UPI)Frank Chapot of the United States rode White Lightning to victory today in a Class S jumping event at the Aachen international horse show.

title: Oil Spill to Be Burned
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., July 4 (AP)The Environmental Pro tection Agency plans a test burn on Thursday of oilsoak ed materials gathered from the bank of the Schuylkill River.

title: AMERICAN COLONY IN CHILE DECLINES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4 The United States Ambassador, Nathaniel Davis, said today that American businessmen in Chile must feel that these are like the Conestoga wagon days when, surrounded in the desert by hostile Indians, one saw friends dropping to left and to right.

title: Bridge:
description: If you want to win, you should waste no time on guilt, recrimination or lamentation. If you reach a hopeless con tract, as South did on the diagramed deal from the re cent World Team Olmpiad, there is no point in regretting your own bidding criticizing your partner, or bemoaning the fates. Instead you should attempt to make the contract, remembering that the op ponents are human beings and do not always defend doubledummy.

title: Abdul W. Adamjee, Pakistani Magnate, Millionaire, Is Dead
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 4 Abdul Wahed Adamjee, an in dustrialist who was head of the wealthiest family in Pakistan, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Transport Workers Strike
description: SANTIAGO, July 4 (AP)  Railway employes struck today for higher pay, paralyzing train service throughout the country.

title: A's Top Yanks, 42, on Bando's Slam
description: OAKLAND, Calif. July 4 The New York Yankees' five game winning streak ended shortly after they arrived in the West tonight when the Oak land Athletics defeated Mel Stottlemyre, 42, on a grand slain homer by Sal Bando.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN 8 BRONX ATTACKS
description: Bronx detectives arrested yesterday a 21yearold man they believe committed a series of robberies and sexual as saults on eight women in the last two months in the Morris Heights and Highbridge sec tions.

title: Miles Davis Does Not Appear; Says He Never Agreed to Play
description: Miles Davis, the jazz trum peter, did not perform last night at Carnegie Hall as had been advertised by the New port Jazz Festival.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SCORES NIXON'S BUS PLAN
description: DETROIT, July 4The Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People adopted today a stinging reso lution that reiterated the asso ciation's opposition to the Nixon Administration's busing and in tegration policies.

title: William Dawson, ExEnvoy, 86; Representative to O.A.S. Dead
description: BLUE HILL, Me., July 4 Ainbassador William Dawson, whose foreign service career began as a deputy consul in St. Petersburg in 1908 and ended 40 years later after serving as United States representative on the council of the Organization of American States, died yes terday in a hospital here. He was 86 years old and had lived here since 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Named to Key Posts In Nixon Reelection Drive
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Two Californians with White House backgrounds, Frederic V. Malek and Jeb S. Magruder, were named yesterday as deputy directors of President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: San Quentin, Scheduled to Close, Takes on Air of a Ghost Town
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., July 4  Five huge tiers, inhabited only by birds that roost in the rafters are all that are left of what was once the biggest pris on cell block in the world.

title: Mayor Seeks One Agency For City's Drug Programs
description: Plans to consolidate all city drug programs under the Ad diction Services Agency, which in turn would come under the wing of the Health Services Ad ministration, were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Some officials of the A.F.L.C.I.O. are warning that the labor federation may remain neutral in a Presidential race between Senator George McGovern and President Nixon.

title: Pasolini Booed
description: BERLIN, July 4 (Reuters) Pier Paolo Pasolini was loudly booed by the Berlin Film Festival audience to night when he received the top prize for his film, Can terbury Tales.

title: 8 Killed in HeadOn Collision Of Autos Near Abilene, Tex.
description: ABILENE, Tex., July 4 (UPI) Eight persons died today in a headon collision of two cars on a barren farm road north of Abilene.

title: Woman in Queens Is Accused of Killing Her Son, 9
description: A 33yearold woman was charged with stabbing her nine yearold son to death yesterday with a fiveinch kitchen knife in a wooded section of Cun ningham Park, in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens.

title: Coast Guard Cutter Seizes Mexican Vessel Off Texas
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 4 (UPI) The Coast Guard said one of its cutters seized today a Mex ican fishing boat in United States territorial waters off the Texas coast in the same area where three Mexican shrimp boats were sighted a day before.

title: Nixon Invites World to Visit U.S. for Bicentennial
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4President Nixon issued to day what he called an un precedented invitation to the world to visit the United States four years from now as part of the festivities marking the 200th anniversary of the nation's independence.

title: HOTEL CHAIN WINS WATNEY CONTROL
description: LONDON, July 4Control of Watney Mann, Ltd., the big brewers, has been won by Grand Metropolitan Hotels, the hotel, catering and entertain ment giant.

title: Black Doctors Seeking to Improve Health Care of Urban Poor
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  Mrs. Fanie Abney was pleased as she was escorted into a doctor's office at the Shaw Comprehensive Medical Center here after having waited only eight minutes. Two days before, she said, she and her son waited four hours at a hospital to see a doctor.

title: H.R.A. AIDE NAMED ROUSING OFFICIAL
description: Howard S. Stein, an official of the Human Resources Ad ministration, has been appoint ed deputy commissioner in the Housing and Development Ad ministration's Office of Code Enforcement, which includes the controversial Emergency Repair Program.

title: Space Center Aide Named
description: HOUSTON, July 4 (UPI)  Lynwood C. Dunseith, a native of Lafayette, Ala., was named deputy director of flight opera tions at the Manned Space creft Center here today. He replaces Howard W. Tindall, who was recently promoted to director of flight operations.

title: British Aid Given Computer Concern
description: LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) Britain's sole computer com pany, International Computers, Ltd., which has aroused take over interest from a United States rival, the Burroughs Cor poration, has won Government support.

title: Winter '72: There Will Be More Fur (but Less Fun)
description: There's a fashion calm around furriers' showrooms these days. Their Seventh Avenue neighbors to the north, who deal with cloth and set the fashion pace, have stopped their shenani gans with hemlines and waistlines and have gone back to the classics.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: GREENFIELD, Ind., July 4 (AP)Two motorcyclists were hospitalized, one with critical injuries, after they tried to win $10,000 last night by jumping their cycles 200 feet over a lake.

title: JOHN E. B. MURPHY
description: John E. B. Murphy, a retired lawyer, died Sunday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 62 years old.

title: MINE BEAST TRIAL OFF IN KENTUCKY
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 4 (AP) A Federal judge has struck down 23 sets of mine safety regulations, delaying the prose cution of a coal company in connection with a 1970 explo sion that killed 38 miners.

title: Kim Yong Ju
description: The chief North Korean representative in the recent secret talks with South Korea is generally regarded as the secondranking leader in the North even though he is list ed officially as No. 6 in the Communist hierarchy.

title: Midnight Jam Session at Music Hall
description: The jam session, that most Venerable of institutions, is still at the very heart of the jazz experience. Rare though it may be in these days of musical eclecticism, it con tinues to be a kind of prov ing ground for musicians, in which they can test and measure themselves against their contemporaries.

title: Harold J. Roig Is Dead at 86; W. R. Grace Vice Chairman
description: Harold J. Roig, who retired in 1950 as vice chairman of the board of directors of W. R. Grace & Co., died yesterday at his home, 435 East 52d Street. He would have been 87 years old on Friday.

title: BRAZIL WILL RETAIN CURBS ON LIBERTIES
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4  Faced with criticism abroad and questioning at home, Pres ident Emilio G. Mdici de clared last night that Brazil would retain her curbs on civil liberties.

title: Advertising:
description: DancerFitzgeraldSample, the agency for several products from R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, has just been given several brands from its sister company, RJR Foods.

title: Ezra Pound Is Focus of New Dispute
description: BOSTON, July 4  It was 23 years ago that a major literary uproar erupted when the Bollingen Prize was awarded to Ezra Pound, the expatriate poet whose Fascist leanings and antiSemitism made his name anathema to a generation of American intellectuals.

title: Unanime, $39, Triumphs
description: CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)Una nime, owned by Allie E. Reuben of Toledo, Ohio, captured the $57,100 Stars and Stripes Han dicap by two lengths at Arling ton Park today and returned $39.

title: Soviets Revalue the Ruble
description: MOSCOW, July 4The Soviet Union has increased the official value of the ruble against the pound by just over 5 per cent. The pound was officially worth 2 rubles, 15 kopeks when Iz vestia last gave exchange rates on June 1. Now the rate is 2.03 rubles. The U.S. dollar also fell in valuefrom 82 rubles 30 kopeks per 100 to 82 rubles.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
