description: One of the nation's leading mathematical economists has charged that an implementation of Senator George McGovern's economic programat least in the form that he believes it would be most likely to pass Congresswould lead to a re cession in 1974 and an unem ployment rate of 7 per cent.

title: 51 Disaster Aid Centers Working on Floods in East
description: WAHSINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Fiftyone Federal disaster as sistance centers are operating to assist floodstricken families and businessmen in five East Coast states, the Office of Emergency Preparedness said yesterday.

title: Oceanside Girl, 15, Raped While Hitchhiking at Night
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I. July 4 (UPI) A 15yearold Oceanside girl was raped last night after she had been picked up while hitch hiking on Long Beach Road here the police reported.

title: Mock Funeral for Hijacker
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 4 (AP) Youthful protesters conduct ed a mock funeral today for a slain Vietnamese hijacker. They left quietly after the police had refused to let them place a piece of plywood strewn with hibiscus flowers in a canal as part of the funeral for Nguyen Thai Binh. He was slain in Sai gon Sunday while trying to hi jack an American jetliner.

title: Queens to Get Art and Culture Center
description: We were a cultural desert, said Donald Manes, the Queens Borough Presi dent. We had no single permanent home for cultural activities. But the desert is beginning to bloom. Today, Mr. Manes will announce that Queens finally has a showcase for the visual and performing arts, the Queens County Art and Cultural Cen ter.

title: MISS WHITE TAKES U.S. FENCING CROWN
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 4 Ruth White, a New York Uni versity senior, tonight became the first woman to capture two national fencing championships before her 21st birthday.

title: DETROIT PANEL ASKS PUPIL BUS PURCHASE
description: DETROIT, July 5 (UPI)An 11member panel appointed by Federal Judge Stephen J. Roth has asked the judge to order the state to pay $3million for the purchase of 295 school buses that could carry children between Detroit and suburban school districts.

title: Maye Cleared of Harming Homosexual
description: Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters As sociation, was acquitted yester day of charges that he had harassed a homosexual during a melee that grew out of a dem onstration by the Gay Activists Alliance in the New York Hilton last April.

title: Raids on Hanoi Reported
description: SAIGON, Thursday, July 6 (AP)The United States com mand reported yesterday that American jets struck at targets within four miles of the center of Hanoi on Tuesday.

title: Hearing Off in Bomb Threat
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., July 5 (AP)A preliminary hearing for Dennis Michael Perry, 20 years old, of Merritt Island, Fla., who is accused of threat ening to blow up the White House, has been postponed until next Monday. Magistrate Robert McGregor took the ac tion after an attorney for Mr. Perry said that his client was still undergoing psychiatric testing.

title: High School R.O.T.C. To Be Open to Girls
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The Army announced to day that the junior Reserve Officers Training Corps pro grams in high schools would be open to girls beginning with the new school year in September.

title: Sniper Shoots 2 Youths One Fatally, in Chinatown
description: A 16yearold boy died early yesterday morning after he and his companion were shot as they stood on the corner of Chrystie and Bayard Streets in Chinatown, the police reported.

title: LOUIS LIPSEY
description: Louis Lipsey, who was in charge of the Parks Depart ment's lifeguard training pro gram for 30 years, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 73 years old and lived at 145 West 96th Street.

title: Premier of Japan
description: In choosing 54yearold Kakuei Tanaka, a tough and outspoken Minister of International Trade and Industry, to succeed the 71yearold Eisaku Sato as party leader and Premier, Japan's LiberalDemocratic party has recognized the need for more energetic and independent national leadership.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (Reuters)The World Bank announced today a $76million loan to Nigeria's National Electric Power Authority for development work associated with the Kainji Dam hydroelectric system.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Clark MacGregor, President Nixon's new political campaign manager, said today that he de tected some overconfidence in the Nixon camp but that he in tended to dispel it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES S. GILLESPIE JR.
description: WESTON, Conn., July 5  James Stuart Gillespie Jr., founder and publisher of The Blue Book of Brooklyn, a so ciety listing, died of cancer Fri day at the Veterans Administra tion Hospital in West Haven. He was 56 years old and lived at 40 White Birch Road here and 122 Remsen Street in Brooklyn, N. Y.

title: The Poisoned Cup
description: The politics of the Democratic party in this precon vention period has developed into a struggle between contending forces striving to nominate or to stop Senator George McGovern.

title: Personal Finance: Plans for Thrift
description: There's a way to help beat inflation that many persons either take for granted or do not appreciate. It involves company employe savings and thrift plans.

title: At Least 3 Die in South India As Police Fire at Protesters
description: NEW DELHI, July 5The police fired on rioting crowds today in the state of Tamil Na du, where parties opposed to the ruling Dravidian party are agitating in support of a farm ers' movement against the Gov ernment.

title: The Next Nick Adams
description: ROSEVILLE, Mich.John Dos Passos ushered in the New Deal years with an essay entitled The Doughboy Thir teen Years Later. He chronicled the Bonus March, and spoke of Our Boys gone bitter and disillusioned with the nation they had served in combat; of a shabby, desperate mob besieging Washington, D. C., in demand of a bonus for the hardship they had endured while the rest of the nation was waving flags.

title: John Campbell Of Nixon Staff Weds Jane Dart
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., July 5  Miss Jane Dart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jus tin W. Dart of Los Angeles and Pebble Beach, and John Campbell, an assistant to John D. Ehrlichmann, Pres ident Nixon's assistant for domestic affairs, were mar ried here Saturday in the chapel of the Robert Louis Stevenson School, a boy's private preparatory school.

title: Hanrahan Trial Is Delayed For an Attorney's Vacation
description: CHICAGO, July 3 (UPI)  The trial of Cook County State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 codefendants was postponed for five days today so that a defense attor ney could take a vacation.

title: Self And Beyond
description: American experience has always in cluded the quest for radical novelty while retaining at the same time a quality of nostalgia for the values of its past.

title: South Korea Doubts A TopLevel Parley
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 5 Premier Kim Jong Pil said today that he saw little possibil ity of a meeting between the top government leaders of North and South Korea in the near future despite the dramatic SeoulPyongyang agreement to work for better relations.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The Pentagon today denied claims by North Vietnam that it has been moving supplies into 12 unnamed coastal points not covered by American mines, warships or planes.

title: CONNALLY SEES GAIN IN INDIA RELATIONS
description: NEW DELHI, July 5John B. Connally, President Nixon's special envoy, said today that he believed his talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and other Indian leaders had helped to mend relations be tween Washington and New Delhi.

title: Religious Excitement Fills Air At a Pentecostal Session Here
description: Singing, clapping and having what they called a shouting time, youthful members of the Church of God in Christ opened their annual meeting last night with a gospel musicale that fairly rocked the main ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Business Briefs
description: Merger activity increased in the second quarter this year, reflecting improved earnings of business in general and some higher stock prices. Disposal of subsidiaries or product lines regarded as marginal producers or misfits also helped to swell the number of such transactions.

title: Duran Wins Ring Title
description: SAN REMO, Italy, July 5 (AP)  Carlo Duran of Italy captured the European junior middleweight boxing title to night, scoring a decision over Jos Hernandez of Spain, the defending champion. Duran, 36 years old, is a former European middleweight champion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Dem ocrat of Wisconsin, said today that Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird had broken a promise to document his charge that the defense budget of Sen ator George McGovern repre sented the white flag of sur render.

title: Sound Is So Loud It Destroys the Music
description: After putting on 12 jazz concerts in 5 days that ranged from reasonably good to ex cellent, the Newport Jazz Festival hit a clinker last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Libyan Leader's Policies Meet Resistance at Home and Abroad
description: TRIPOLI, LibyaCol. Muam mar elQaddafi, Libya's strong man, is being pushed toward ever more extreme positions at home and abroad. And the force pushing him, foreign dip lomats here believe, is frustra tion.

title: 4 Piers on the West Side To Reopen for Air Cargo
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that four inactive West Side piers would be re opened next fall to relieve pressure at Kennedy Interna tional Airport by serving as the air cargo distribution cen ter for the metropolitan area.

title: Stocks on Amex Show an Increase
description: Traders were back in force yesterday, bidding up stocks on the American Stock Ex change to 27.37, up 0.05, as measured by the index. Volume zoomed to 4,616,000 shares, compared with a holiday vol ume lag of only 2,150,000 shares on Monday, the day before July 4. It will take a few more days trading to de termine if a trend for more activity has begun.

title: Deputy Kills Patrolman
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) A 25yearold highway patrol man was accidentally shot and killed last night with a bullet meant to kill an injured horse. Patrolman Dana Everett Pala dini died after being shot by Sheriff's Deputy James John son, officials said. The deputy said he had fired two shots into the horse that did not kill it and a third shot somehow glanced off and struck Patrol man Paladini.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PLYMOUTH, England, July 5 (Reuters)France's Vendredi 13 radioed today she was only 550 nautical miles from Newport, R. I. in the singlehanded transAtlantic yacht race. Her crewman, Jean Yves Terlain, reported the wind was picking up after a few days of relative calm and the sea was getting choppy. He said progress was slower than he had hoped.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (AP) Presi dent Hafez alAssad of Syria came to Moscow tonight for talks amid speculation that he would discuss with Soviet lead ers the capture of five high ranking Syrian army officers by the Israelis last month.

title: Florida Employes Urged To Curb Use of Power
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 5(AP)Florida's 73,000 state employes were urged today to sacrifice aircon ditioning comfort and help reduce power consumption during the national political conventions.

title: Chrysler Seeking 5% Rise in Prices
description: DETROIT, July 5The Chrys ler Corporation today asked the Price Commission for an aver age increase of 5 per cent, or $180, in the prices of its 1973 cars and trucks.

title: Books of The Times
description: SPRING SNOW. By Yukio Mishima. Translated from the Japanese by Michael Gallagher. 389 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Drug Unit Reports Progress
description: The Northwest region of the Office of Drug Abuse Law En forcement made more than 225 arrests for drugrelated cases and is conducting 250 investi gations, John Bartel, the Dep uty Director, said yesterday. The regional office, which has been operational since March 20, has confiscated 1.8 kilo grams of heroin and substan tial quantities of cocaine, hash ish, and marijuana, as well as a variety of weapons, he said.

title: Some Fans in U.S. Deserting Fischer
description: An American professor who developed the system of rank ing the world's chess players said yesterday that Bobby Fischer appeared to be losing fellow players' sympathy in what he called a war of nerves between Fischer and the delegation of his Soviet opponent, Boris Spassky, the world champion.

title: VIGOROUS POLICY PLEDGED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Thursday, July 6 Kakuei Tanaka, Japan's new Premier to be, promised vigor ous action yesterday to deal with Japan's domestic ills and outlined a foreign policy en compassing continued close ties with the United States, im proved relations with the So viet Union and the establish ment of diplomatic relations with China.

title: Dr. Raul Leoni, 67, President Of Venezuela, 196469, Dead
description: Dr. Raul Leoni, who sur vived imprisonment and exile to become President of Vene zuela from 1964 to 1969, died yesterday at the Cornell Medi cal Center here. He was 67 years old and had been suffer ing from a liver ailment.

title: 2.5MILLION GRANTED FOR ARTSINSCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The National Endowment for the Arts and the Office of Educa tion announced a $2.5million program today that will place professional artists in elemen tary and secondary classrooms in all 50 states.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH July 5 (AP) The Rev. Ralph David Aber nathy said tonight that if the Democratic party refused to accept 750 poor people as national convention delegates they would crash the gathering and take the seats.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALBANY, July 5  New York Republicans completed the selection today of an 88 member delegation to the Re publican National Convention that was described by Gover nor Rockefeller as broadly representational. But it still fell short of the reforms in the state's Democratic National Convention contingent.

title: Suspect in Killings Shifted
description: YUMA CITY, Calif., July 5 (AP)Juan Corona, accused of slaying 25 farm workers and burying them in orchards near here last year, was transferred today to the Vacaville State Prison to await trial in Solano County.

title: CARLETON F. SMITH
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 5 Carleton Ford Smith, a re tired executive of C. H. Stuart & Co., packaging designers of Newark, N. Y., died yesterday at the Bayhead Yacht Club. He was 76 years old and lived at 38 Kenilworth Drive.

title: Father Loses Court Appeal To Bar Surgery for Children
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 5 (Reuters)  Iowa's Supreme Court ruled today that three children should have their ton sils and adenoids removed despite their father's objection on a religious ground.

title: S.B.A. May Ask Congress Soon For Up to a Billion in Flood Aid
description: The Small Business Admin istration may soon ask Con gress for as much as $1billion in emergency loan funds for flood relief to businessmen and homeowners.

title: ROGERS STRESSES TIES WITH GREECE
description: ATHENS, July 5Secretary of State William P. Rogers made it clear today, as he ended a oneday visit to Athens, that the United States would strengthen military co operation with Greece despite criticism over suppression of democracy by the Government of Premier George Papado poulos.

title: Army Is Confident That, After Years of Crisis, Officers Are Regaining Stability, Quality and Morale
description: After four years of turbu lence and frustration, the Army is confident that the officer corps is regaining its stability, quality and morale.

title: U.S. Crackdown Credited With Curbing Heroin Flow
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Less heroin is available on the nation's streets because of the Government's crackdown on the flow of drugs, Federal officials said today.

title: U.S. F4 Loses a Rocket
description: SLEEN, the Netherlands, July 5 (AP)A United States Air Force F4 Phantom jet lost a fivefoot live rocket while on its way from the Dutch air base of Soesterberg to one at Leeu warden today, the police here reported. The rocket dropped over the province of Drenthe, and a search was under way for it.

title: Sanford Calls on Candidates To Support Party Nominee
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 5 (UPI) Terry Sanford, former North Carolina Governor, urged today all other Democratic Presiden tial candidates to join him in a pledge to support the party ticket.

title: Miss Evert Beaten, 46, 63, 64
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5Mrs. Billie Jean King won from Rosie Casals to reach her seventh Wimbledon tennis final today. Then Evonne Goola gong and Chris Evert came on the court for the longawaited meeting between the 20year old Australian who cavorted to fame by winning the title last year and the 17yearold marvel from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who had a streak of 26 victories to Forest Hills last year and 12 in her baptismal in England.

title: Abe Stark Rites Attended By 250, Including Lindsay
description: Abe Stark, former City Coun cil President and Brooklyn Borough President, was buried yesterday at Mount Carmel Cemetery in Glendale, Queens, after a short service at the Riverside, Ocean Parkway at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Philadelphia Official Asks Death Penalty in 8 Crimes
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) Acting less than a week after the Supreme Court prohibited capital punishment, as then ad ministered, District Attorney Arlen Specter asked the Penn sylvania legislature today to approve the death penalty in eight types of murder, including killings committed in kidnap pings and hijackings.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, July 5A tem porary order restraining the antiDaley delegates from being seated at the convention ex pired here today.

title: Jack Whittingham Dead; Writer for Screen and TV
description: VALETTA, Malta, July 5 (UPI)  Jack Whittingham, a screen and TV writer whose works included the popular Thunderball, died here yes terday.

title: British Data Point to Soviet Guilt in 1941 Deaths
description: LONDON, July 5 (AP)Se cret British papers made public today say that the Soviet Union was almost certainly re sponsible for the killing of about 11,000 Polish military men in the World War II massacre at Katyn Forest.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 5 (AP)President Nixon went for a swim this after noon in the Pacific Ocean and had the beach mostly to himself during his oneand ahalfhour outing.

title: 2 CITY DETECTIVES INDICTED IN GRAFT
description: Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold yesterday an nounced the indictments of two detectives who allegedly took $900 in bribes from a man found in possession of a hand gun.

title: Carmichael Upsets Riessen in Tennis; Key Point Argued
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 5 (AP)  Bob Carmichael of Australia upset thirdseeded Marty Riessen of the United States on a controversial tie breaking point, 63, 46, 76, today to proceed to the quar terfinals of the $25,000 Bretton Woods tennis tournament.

title: 2 HIJACKERS SLAIN IN JET GUN FIGHT; PASSENGER DEAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 F.B.I. agents shot and killed two armed hijackers who had held 86 persons aboard a jet airliner at San Francisco Inter national Airport today while they waited for an $800,000 ransom.

title: Dissonants Hear Another Jazz
description: The small studios and dim ly lit bars that have sus tained jazz at its most basic level have been the setting during the last five days for performances by musicians who don't like the Newport Jazz Festival or the way it has been produced.

title: OpenSpace Designs Breathing New Life Into Smothered Blocks
description: The New York of popular mythology is the everchang ing citythe one they never finish. Traditonally, those changes have been measured by looking at the skyline. Today they are measured best on the ground, at street level, where new urban pat terns are emerging that are in the process of making the city a vastly different place.

title: Conventions Costing TV $20Million
description: The three television net works are saturating their sta tion breaks with announce ments that promise more daz zling coverage of the political conventions than ever before.

title: BIG GAIN IN VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the Dem ocratic Credentials Committee had been arbitrary and un constitutional in depriving Senator George McGovern of 151 California delegates to the party's national convention. It awarded him the full 271vote delegation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 6, 1972

title: FASHION TALK
description: Adolfo is not a man given to overstatement, personally or professionally. When pressed, he is inclined to de scribe his clothes as nice to wear, an assessment long endorsed by fashionably and financially secure women.

title: Market Place:
description: No shareholder in Wrigley stock a while back will for get the day the shares dropped over 30 points.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C. Stanley Jacob, Collector Of Colonial Weaponry, 80
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 5 C. Stanley Jacob, an expert on colonial weaponry and owner of a large collection of weap ons, died yesterday in a nurs ing home in Edison. He was 80 years old and lived at 202 West Eighth Street.

title: Screen: Lenny Returns:Documentary on Life of Bruce Opens at Elgin
description: Cliff Gorman's recent "Lenny"  the play and the performance bothconveyed an infinitely stronger sense of reality, bizarre comic talent and personal doom than yesterday's new documentary film, "Lenny Bruce Without Tears."Fred and Barbara Baker have obviously gone to a lot of trouble to assemble movie footage of the real Bruce performing before club audiences. The photography is understandably shadowy. But the bald truth is that you simply can't hear much of the fuzzy soundtrack, as Bruce carbolically lances sex, religion, racial bigotry and plain old hypocrisy. There is a long, equally muffled sequence of a younger Bruce during a guest shot on a Steve Allen television show, suggesting the volcanic brilliance to come.Furthermore, the footage continually cuts from Bruce in action to a random mulligan stew of meaningless clips as the comedian's voice continues.Add to this a continual stream of tributes from people like Mort Sahl, Kenneth Tynan and Malcolm Muggeridge, especially at the end, when we see Bruce stumbling into various courts in a series of narcotics arrests. There is a skein of biographical data. The footage hits hard only near the close. That's when we see a ghostly, glassy-eyed Bruce croaking to an interviewer and doing a pathetically unfunny pantomime of drug addiction.Chances are that the 1967 movie titled "Lenny Bruce," which reportedly held to his performing, was much more effective. The man on the Elgin Theater screen yesterday seemed but a frenzied shadow, funny only when you could understand him.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 5The Miami Beach City Council, acting on a recommendation of the police, voted today to grant campsites to nondele gates for the Democratic National Convention.

title: Soviet Biologist Says Police Kept Him From Kiev Parley
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 5 (AP) Zhores Medvedev, the emi nent biologist who disappeared Sunday after being barred from an international conference here, told an American scientist today that the authorities forced him to return home.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July. 5 Mr. Connally said today that President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan had exercised a high order of statesmanship in the recent negotiations with Prime Minister Gandhi at Simla.

title: C. H. MATHEWSON, METALLURGIST, 90
description: NEW HAVEN, July 5Dr. Champion H. Mathewson, emeritus professor of metal lurgy and metallography at Yale University, died of a heart at tack yesterday at his home. He was 90 years old.

title: Three Die in Airplane Crash
description: MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) Three men died when their light plane, participating in flag raising ceremonies at a Fourth of July observance, crashed about 400 yards from a crowd of 3,000 people. The plane was preparing to drop a cargo of poppies in suburban Franklin as part of an annual ceremony sponsored by a civic club. The three victims were identified as the pilot, John K. Karsten, 41 years old, of Franklin; Mar vin Arsand, 43, and Ronald Ar sand, 49, brothers from Oak Creek.

title: Slate of Directors For the Big Board Approved by Vote
description: The membership of the New York Stock Exchange voted into office yesterday a new 20mem ber board of directors that had been proposed last month by a nominating committee. The new board replaces the old 33man board of governors.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Representative Emanuel Cel ler, who was defeated in his bid for renomination for a 26th term by Elizabeth Holtzman, has gone to court to ask for a new election on the basis of alleged voting irregularities.

title: Father Accused of Killing Son Who Pummeled Him
description: An outraged father shot and killed his 19yearold son yes terday morning, the police charged, in retaliation for a beating the son gave him after a family dispute 10 days ago.

title: PLATINUM PRICES AT RECORD LEVEL
description: Platinum futures, rising steadily for some time, reached new highs for the life of con tract yesterday and all months except the nearby October. The October option, neverthe less, rose by $9.20 an ounce. Trading was active with 1,255 lots involved.

title: Russification
description: Another Lithuanian has burned himself to death to protest Soviet occupation of his country, it is reported from Moscow. This is the latest sobering reminder of the wave of discontent that has broken out this year in the tiny Baltic country whose independence, along with that of her two neighbors, was extinguished by Stalin more than three decades ago as one of the side dividends of the SovietNazi pact. It is a measure of the desperation many Lithuanians feel that three in the last several weeks have chosen selfimmolation as a means of calling world attention to their plight.

title: Enemy Is Facing Floods, U.S. Says, Denying Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 5State Department officials said today that there was a strong likeli hood North Vietnam would be flooded later this summer, but they said North Vietnam's dike system would be responsible rather than American bombing raids.

title: Merger News
description: The title of the Plaza Hotel has been acquired by the So nesta International Hotels Cor poration, it was disclosed yes terday. The price of the pur chase could not be ascertained.

title: CONTESTING DATA IN WRITS BARRED
description: TRENTON, July 5 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that criminal de fendants may not challenge the accuracy of information con tained in police affidavits or upon which search warrants are based.

title: Fischer Apologizes to Spassky; Plans for Match Still Unsettled
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 5 Nobody in Icelandneither the contestants in the scheduled world chess championship match, nor their advisers or assistants, nor officials of the International or Icelandic Chess Federations  knew tonight when the match would begin, or whether it would be held at all.

title: Dakotan Believed to Drop Hope of Kennedy on Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Sen ator George McGovern has all but abandoned his hope of enticing Senator Edward M. Kennedy to join him on the Democratic ticket.

title: INMATES TRAINED FOR LIFE OUTSIDE
description: CHICAGO, July 5,In air conditioned rooms off a brightly painted corridor, 60 young men were ranged along the walls, each seated in a learning cu bicle with his name printed above it and his books or tape recorder in front of him.

title: RENT RISE IS DENIED A BUILDING CONCERN
description: Investigation Commissioner Robert E. Ruskin announced yesterday that a major build ingmanagement concern had been denied rent increases in 19 buildings for allegedly false ly certifying that housing vio lations had been corrected.

title: Queens Man, 36, Suspect In Sale of Drugs and Guns
description: The police announced the ar rest yesterday of a 36yearold Queens carpet layer who they said had tried to supplement his income by selling narcotics and unregistered weapons.

title: Military's Avoidance of Tax May Divert Air Travelers
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) A Pentagon order directing military air travelers to avoid airports imposing passenger taxes may divert thousands of people, particularly from Phila delphia International Airport.

title: California Assembly Passes Eased Marijuana Measure
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 5 (AP)  Californians caught smoking marijuana or simply tucking it away for their own use would face a maximum six month sentence in county jail under a bill passed today by the Assembly.

title: PRICE OF COPPER CUT BY CANADIANS
description: Price reductions for copper initiated by major United States producers spread to Canada yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tennis Match Deserving of Pomp and Ceremony
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5Under the stands, Chris Evert and Evonne Goo lagong were about to walk onto the center court today when the 17yearold Ameri can turned to the 20year old Australian aborigine.

title: 6th Bronx Inspector At DayCare Center Accused of Bribery
description: The chief elevator inspector in the Bronx office of the Buildings Department was sus pended without pay yesterday after he allegedly demanded money from a builder's fore man in exchange for speedy approval of elevator work per formed in a daycare center.

title: A Child Had Luck Many Still Need It
description: In a way, 6yearold Louise is lucky, She was born with out legs, without part of her arms and has had to live in a hospitalbut now she is about to be adopted.

title: Lindsay Refuses to Support Ticket Including Wallace
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that he would not support any Presidential ticket that in cluded Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Robert Horstield, Banker, Dies; Dry Dock's Chief Executive, 50
description: Robert Horsfield, president and chief executive officer of the Dry Dock Savings Bank died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home, 10 Dellwood Ave nue, Chatham, N. J. He was 50 years old.

title: 9 Indicted in Nassau Rackets Inquiry Into Nightclubs
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 5A Nassau County rackets grand jury indicted nine persons to day, including a reputed cap tain in the crime family of Joseph Colombo, in connection with the alleged underworld takeover of a Lake Success, L. I., restaurant and nightclub.

title: DOLLAR AND POUND GAIN IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, July 5The dollar and the pound strengthened to day in Europe, but markets re mained nervous and traders ex pressed doubt that any real recovery had set in.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, July 5 (AP)Canada added another $169.7 million to its international reserves in June, bringing the total at the end of the month to $6.22billion, the Finance Department reported today.

title: EDWIN WILSON, 80, A NEWSPAPERMAN
description: Edwin Brayton Wilson, ex ecutive editor of The Brooklyn Eagle from 1946 to 1955, when the newspaper was closed, died Tuesday in the infirmary of Heath Village, Schooley's Mountain, N.J., where he had lived for the last two years. He would have been 81 years old today.

title: ARBITERS TO DECIDE CITY PENSION ISSUE
description: District Council 37 of the A.F. of L.C.I.O State, County and Municipal Employes an nounced yesterday that it had filed a request with the Office of Collective Bargaining for ar bitration of a pension dispute affecting 120,000 members who work for the city.

title: May Installment Credit Up By a Record $1.44Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Con sumer installment credit rose by the record amount of $1.441billion in May, the Fed eral Reserve Board reported today.

title: OLYMPICS CHIEF OPPOSED TO PROS
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 5 (UPI) Cliff Buck, president of the United States Olympic Com mittee, said today during a break in the United States track and field trials that open ing up the Olympics to profes sionals would spell the end of the movement.

title: Untimely Visit
description: Despite his apparently slight impact on major foreign policy events, Secretary of State Rogers has consistently demonstrated great understanding of this country's true interests abroad. Thus it is deeply regrettable that on his present worldencircling trip Mr. Rogers let himself be routed into Greece over the Fourth of July.

title: Blair Takes Medal With 71 In Jersey Section Trials
description: WAYNE, N.J., July 5Chris Blair of Maplewood, an ama teur, shot a oneunderpar 38, 3371 today to take the medal in the northern section qualify ing round of the 52d New Jersey open golf championship over the 6,584yard, par 72 Preak ness Hills Country Club course.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 5 (UPI)The Schaefer 500 auto race, postponed last Sunday because of flooding, has been rescheduled for Saturday, July 29, at Pocono Downs, Dr. Joseph R. Mattioli, chairman of the board of Pocono, and William J. Smyth, executive director of the United States Auto Club, announced today. Already sched uled for July 30 at Pocono's 2.5mile trioval is the Penn sylvania 500 late model stock car race.

title: Advertising:
description: The Research Institute In vestors Service has taken a hard look at the mysterious world of the ad agencythe publicly held ad agencyand comments, On the whole, the larger advertising agen cies have been commendably flexible in the face of chang ing conditions and should en joy increasing profitability as the economic recovery pro gresses.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: RUTLAND, Vt., July 5 Bernie Lawrence, who oper ates a busy little automobile body shop on State Street, is convinced he's doing some thing wrong. An ardent angler, who as a 6yearold captured trout with a string and a safety pin, Lawrence is sure fish are conspiring to avoid him.

title: Notes on People
description: Dizzy Gillespie was hon ored as a musical legend in his own time by Mayor Lind say at City Hall. The 55year old jazz trumpeter, who started life as John Birks Gillespie, was there to re ceive the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award, for his superb and matchless contribution to the world of culture and music. Calling jazz America's fore most cultural export, Mr. Gillespie told the Mayor, What we need is a home for jazz in New York City; one spot we could call our own.

title: PERU WILL RESUME TIES WITH HAVANA
description: LIMA, Peru, July 5 (Reuters) Peru will resume diplomatic relations with Cuba at the end of this month, President Juan Velasco Alvarado announced today.

title: American Plan Ends Offer
description: Unfavorable market condi tions led the American Plan Corporation to withdraw its rgistration with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 450,000 shares, the diver sified insurance concern said yesterday. It said it would seek bank financing instead.

title: Strike by Crafts Slows Major Construction in City
description: Construction declined to a near  shutdown yesterday on $2billion worth of projects in the city on the first regular workday since the strike by 65,000 building trades workers started last Saturday.

title: Monserrat Elected Head Of City Education Board
description: Joseph Monserrat was elect ed president of the city Board of Education yesterday, defeat ing the incumbent, Isaiah E. Robinson, 3 to 2.

title: Saigon Forces Closing In On Heart of Quangtri City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 6South Viet namese troops continued to close in on the heart of Quang tri city yesterday, as Saigon's counteroffensive to retake the country's northernmost prov ince entered its second week, still making slow but steady gains.

title: FOSTER GAINS LEAD IN TEMPEST TRIALS
description: MARION, Mass., July 5 (AP) Glen Foster of New York and Jack Linville of Scarsdale, N.Y., scored victories today in Tempest Class races of the Olympic sailing trials.

title: S.E.C. QUESTIONED ON PROPOSED RULE
description: A key group of operations experts from the securities in dustry has raised some two dozen questions about a rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to re gulate the safekeeping of cus tomers' securities by broker age firms.

title: Jesse Jackson Calls for Summit Meeting of Black Leaders to Set Priorities
description: DETROIT, July 5The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a former aide to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Lu ther King Jr., called today for a summit conference of black leaders to formulate solutions to the problems of blacks.

title: Wallace Off Meet the Press
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama yesterday canceled his appearance on a special twohour edition of Meet the Press in which he was to ap pear with five other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination. No reason was given. The program will be car ried on television and radio Sunday by the National Broad casting Company.

title: CALVIN W. DAIL
description: Calvin W. Dail, a retired vice president of Marsh & McLen nan, insurance brokers, died yesterday at his home, 24 Mas cussue Court, New Canaan, Conn. He wa 69 years old and also had a home in Haines Falls, N. Y.

title: Advertising:
description: Either on Thursday or Fri day on the eve of what to most ad agencies was a four day weekend, seven New York shops received letters from the Buckingham Corporation inviting them to pitch for the Cutty Sark Scotch account. And would they respond within three days of the re ceipt of the letter?

title: Soviet Launches Satellite
description: MOSCOW, July 5The So viet Union today launched Cosmos 498, believed to be a military applications satellite. Its orbit of 317 by 175 miles at an angle of 71 degrees has been identified in the West as charesteristie of a series of datagathering craft launched from Plesetsk in northern Russia.

title: ACCORD REACHED; DAY CAMP OPENS
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 5A controversial day camp for 1,500 Brooklyn chil dren opened on schedule here this morning, only hours after this city agreed to avoid a law suit by waiving its zoning and sanitary codes.

title: HANOI SAYS SUPPLIES STILL GET THROUGH
description: HONG KONG, July 5 (AP) North Vietnam said today that it was getting war supplies through 12 coastal points that the United States had not been able to block.

title: Miss Evert to Turn Pro
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 5 (AP)  Jimmy Evert, father of Chris Evert, said to day his daughter would become a professional tennis player Jan. 1. She will be 18 years old in December.

title: 3 Are Indicted for Bribery In Seymour Inquiry Here
description: A lawyer, a police detective and a private investigator were charged with bribery yesterday in the first indictment resulting from a major corruption investigation headed by United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr.

title: Man in the News
description: TOKYO, July 5while he was still in his teens, Kakuei Tanaka, who was chosen to day as Japan's next Premier, thought of becoming a naval officer. He took the examina tion and came in 10th among 13,000 applicants. He never accepted the appointment. If he had, he might never have become Premier, but there is also a good chance he would never have become an admi ral. A harddriv ing, ambitious man, who formed his own construction company at the age of 25 and was a Vice Minister of Justice at 31, Mr. Tanaka has made a name for himself for flamboyance and volubility, qualities never eagerly sought in a young naval officer.

title: Is It Possible to Control Crime?
description: NEW HAVENTwo kinds of errors imperil the fight against crime: over simplifying the problem, and overcom plicating it. On the one hand, law and order candidates offer easy solu tions to crimepretrial detention, un restricted wiretapping or even totally empty get tough rhetoricwhich have a great deal of political appeal and very little real merit. On the other hand, many commentators of different persuasions treat the crime problem as If it were so complicated (or so un important) that we shouldn't even try for an answer:

title: Roundup: Homerless Y az Helps Red Sox to 6th in Row
description: He's not hitting home runs, but Yaz is back.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeport Hospital Wins Certification As Alcoholism Unit
description: FREEPORT, L. I., July 5 (UPI)Freeport Hospital today became the first treatment cen ter devoted exclusively to al coholics and their families to receive state certification, the hospital announced.

title: DR. JOHN PARKS, 64, GYNECOLOGIST, DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Dr. John Parks, vice president for medical affairs of George Wash ington University, died today at his home in Annapolis, Md., ap parently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Photographer From Going Near Mrs. Onassis
description: United States District Court Judge Irving Ben Cooper ruled yesterday that the activities of Ronald E. Galella, the self styled paparazzo photogra pher, had relentlessly in vaded the right to privacy of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and had interfered with the protective duties of the Secret Service.

title: Security National On L.I. Registers 15% Income Drop
description: Net income of the Security National Bank, Huntington, L.I., declined 15 per cent in the first half of 1972 to $6.6million, or $1.49 a share, from $7.8million, or $1.76 a share, in the cor responding period last year. The decline, the bank said, reflected security losses taken by Security in connection with its acquisition of the Royal Na tional Bank on May 5.

title: Trevino Is Full of Fight For Canada Open Today
description: FORT ERIE, Ontario, July 5  The old Lee Trevino is at full physical and jocular strength to defend his title in the Canadian open golf tourna ment, which begins tomorrow. It's his first tournament since he played in the United States Open at Pebble Beach, Calif., three weeks ago.

title: JURY COMPLETED IN PHILLIPS TRIAL
description: The 12member jury that will decide the state's murder case against Patrolman William R. Phillips was completed here yesterday, four days and nearly 100 potential veniremen after jury selection began.

title: Mets Ailing Receive An Extra Day to Heal
description: Rain forced a oneday post ponement last night of the Mets' final home game with the San Diego Padres this season, giving the Mets' ill and injured another day to recuperate. Tickets that were marked for last night's game will be good tonight.

title: Credit Markets: Pattern Is Indecisive
description: Interest rates continued to trace an indecisive pattern yesterday in light postholiday activity.

title: U.S. GRANTS BOEING LICENSE TO SELL 10 707'S TO CHINA
description: A $150million export license covering the proposed sale of 10 Boeing 707 jet airliners to China has been granted to the Boeing Company by the Nixon Administration.

title: PARAGUAY ANGERS U.S. OVER DRUGS
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 29This year for the first time in 111 years, the United States Embassy, on orders from Wash ington, scheduled no Fourth of July party for Paraguayan Government officials.

title: Sperry Rand Names Lyet As Its Chairman and Chief
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday the elec tion of J. Paul Lyet as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Open Road Industries, Inc., filed an offering of 517,189 common shares through Wert heim & Co.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UPI)The ketch Graybeard reached Tahiti today to become the first boat to finish the transPacific race but it appeared likely she might be fourth in the final correctedtime standing. The 73foot boat, skippered by L. H. Killam of the Royal Vancouver Yacht Club, entered Papeete Harbor after a crossing from Los Angeles that took 20 days zero hours 11 minutes 43 seconds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Candidates Would Abide By Bill on War Consultation
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) Senators George McGovern and Hubert H. Humphrey promised today that if they be came President they would consult with Congress at least 24 hours before sending Ameri can forces into action against another country.

title: Air Crash Bodies Recovered
description: NEENAH, Wis., July 5 (UPI) Authorities said today that the bodies, of all 13 persons killed a wek ago in the collision of two commercial airplanes had been recovered from lake Winnebago and identified.

title: U.S. Seeks to Orbit Apollo First in Trip With Russian Craft
description: HOUSTON, July 5 (UPI) United States space officials will propose that the American spacecraft be launched 16 to 40 hours ahead of the Russian vehicle in the joint United StatesSoviet rendezvous flight in 1975, the United States proj ect director said today.

title: Carswell Resignation Accepted With Regret
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 5 (UPI)President Nix on accepted today with re gret the resignation of G. Harrold Carswell, his unsuc cessful nominee for the Su preme Court, from a special advisory post on government administration.

title: Festival Was Movable And So Were Feasts Of the Producer's Wife
description: With the Newport Jazz Festival now part of the New York scene after 18 some times stormy, controversial years in Rhode Island's his toric playground of the wealthy, things are certainly different for Joyce Wein. She doesn't have to cook or en tertain as much.

title: MELCHER RETAINS U.S. EPEE CROWN
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 5 Despite being hobbled by a badly sprained left ankle, 32 yearold James Melcher of New York captured his second con secutive men's national pe crown tonight at Bentley Col lege.

title: Antisegregation Bills Enacted in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., July 5  Gov. Edwin Edwards signed today seven bills striking Louisiana's segrega tionist laws from the books.

title: Accord on Union Dispute Averts Hospital Walkout Set for Today
description: A citywide hospital strike was averted yesterday as city officials, hospital administra tors and disputing unions came to an agreement on a thorny union jurisdictional issue that had complicated hospital pay negotiations for 70 days. A total of 42,000 workers in 66 volun tary and municipal institutions had been planning to walk out today.

title: CHANGE IN VOTING ON POPES HINTED
description: ROME, July 5A few cas ualsounding words by a French layman have revived serious speculation that the Roman Catholic Church is about to enact a radical change in the ageold way of choosing the Pope.

title: 2 Concerts to Sing Folk Festival Blues
description: While New York stomps to the syncopated beat of the transplanted Newport Jazz Festival, its poor relation the Newport Folk Festivalis holding a pair of benefit con certs at Carnegie Hall tomor row night to pay off the creditors of other years.

title: Cold Balks Distance Surfer
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 5 (UPI)Larry Capune paddled 31 miles in the cold and wind today on the fifth day of his 2,260mile journey on an over sized surfboard from Boston to Miami Beach. But the 29 yearold Balboa Island, Calif., bachelor caught a cold and said he would probably stay in this town on the tip of Cape Cod for a day or two.

title: Graham Exhorts Youths To Flock to Convention
description: BLACK MOUNTAIN, N. C. July 5 (UPI)The Rev. Billy Graham called today for thou sands of young Christians to flock to both political conven tions at Miami Beach to wit ness for Christ.

title: NEW WORD SOUGHT FOR WELFARE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 A group at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has been searching for a fresh word to replace what they be lieve is a worn out and much abused term: welfare.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After more than a quarter century of service as a school ship for future merchant mariners, the old Liberty ship John W. Brown has reached the end of the line as a floating classroom.

title: South American Fish Sings Electrical Love Song to His Mate
description: When a female Sternopygus swims past an adult male of the species, she literally turns him on. For suddenly, the steady single frequency dis charge of this South American electric fish becomes a chaotic electrical love song.

title: Spain to Grant Women Legal Adulthood at 21
description: MADRID, July 5 Women won a battle of nearly a cen tury in Madrid last night with a decision by a committee of parliament to reduce the legal age of adulthood for women from 23 to 21.

title: MELGES ADVANCES IN SOLING TRIALS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (AP)Bud Melges won his sec ond straight race today in the Soling clas of the United States Olympic sailing trials and moved within a point of the series lead.

title: DR. HARRY WEISS, 89, ENTOMOLOGIST, DIES
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 5 (AP)Dr. Harry B. Weiss, an entomologist who re tired in 1956 as director of the bureau of plant industry of the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Trenton and Highland Park.

title: Jersey Begins Routine Testing Of Automobile Exhaust Systems
description: WAYNE, N. J., July 5New Jersey today became the first state to begin routine inspec tion of automobile exhaust sys tems in an effort to reduce the levels of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons in the at mosphere.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jewel Tea and Levitz Report Increased Sales for June
description: Jewel Tea Companies, Inc., Chicago, and the Levitz Furni ture Corporation, Pottstown, Pa., reported yesterday higher sales in June compared to the same 1971 month.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Sports fans have always had a low resistance to the picking of allstar teams and are quick to succumb to temp tation when given the slightest encouragement. Because sports editors print only the selections of their resident ex perts and other recognized authorities, however, unsolicited offerings from fans normally land in the wastebasket.

title: Fans, Angry Over Result, Storm Aqueduct Paddock
description: Most of the 18,913 customers at gray, rainy Aqueduct yester day thought a colt named My Guiding Light won the first race by a slight but clear mar gin over Druthers. The photo finish camera showed other wise, with the result that a large group of fans swarmed toward the paddock, obviously looking for officials on whom they could take out their bit terness.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 5 (AP)  The National Association of Basketball Coaches has voted to contribute $12,500 to the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame here to cover its mortgage for the fiscal year 1973. The decision was announced today by the Hall of Fame's executive direc tor, Lee Williams, following the coaches' recent meeting in Aspen, Colo.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Hamburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn, has appointed Joseph L. Werner chief executive officer, succeeding Joseph G. Munz, who retired as chair man of the $448million institution last week, after 50 years of service, at the bank. Mr. Werner, who became president of the bank last year, will continue with that title.

title: HARRY M. PRINCE, 83, CITY HOUSING AIDE
description: Harry M. Prince, an architect who was First Deputy Commis sioner of Tenement Housing from 1934 to 1938 and then deputy commissioner of Hous ing and Buildings until 1941, died Sunday at his home, 115 Central Park West. He was 83 years old and was still active in architectural practice.

title: Richmond to issue Stock
description: The Richmond Corporation, a diversified financial services group with assets of more than $1billion, disclosed yesterday that its stock will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange on July 17.

title: 11 FM Stations Go Off Air As Transmitter Burns Out
description: Eleven FM radio stations were off the air from 3 A.M. to almost 11 A.M. yesterday because of a breakdown in a master antenna they share on top of the Empire State Build ing. The stations were WQXR, WHOM, WBLS (formerly WLIB), WNCN, WOR, WBAI, WNYC, WPIX, WRFM, WEVD and WRVR.

title: Rangers' Dorey to Jump To W.H.A. Team Today
description: The New York Rangers, who run one of the tightest ships in the National Hockey League, have had their first deserter go over to the World Hockey Association.

title: STRIKE THREATENED AT 140 HOTELS HERE
description: Unionized workers in 140 hotels in the city have voted 16,713 to 986 to authorize a strike to back up their demands for a $125 weekly minimum wage and a $100 monthly pension. Maids now start at $91.75 a week and their pension is $60 a month.

title: Russians Disdain Fischer For Concern With Money
description: MOSCOW, July 5A Soviet newspaper editor buttonholed an American at a reception today and said:

title: DELAY FORESEEN IN MEAT COST DIP
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today following a meeting with gro cery chain executives that it would be weeks or months be fore there was a downturn in meat prices for the consumer.

title: Business Briefs
description: Employe layoffs were announced yesterday by Amer ican Airlines and the SCM Corporation.

title: Jazz: How It Developed
description: On the face of it, the pro gram for the Newport Jazz Festival's third Connoisseur Concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall seemed to be a miscellaneous jumble of talentEubie Blake, the Gato Barbieri Quintet, the Kenny Burrell Quartet and the Her bie Hancock Septet. Aside from the fact that they all play jazz, what element could possibly give unity to such a program?

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Litton Industries announced yesterday that its Rust Engi neering division was awarded a contract for $18million by the Pittsburgh and Midway Coal Mining Company of Kansas City to build a pilot plant for the production of lowash and low sulphur coal at Fort Lewis, Wash.

title: Penn State Gets Grant
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The National Cancer Institute announced today the award of a $2million contract to Penn sylvania State University for expanded cancer research, primarily on viruses.

title: News of Dogs
description: Our Cedardane Kennel is strictly an amateur one, said Mrs. Paul White of Kingsville, Md. We do no boarding and I show all our dogs.

title: Decision on Schiller Set
description: BONN, July 5  Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany said today that he would an nounce his decision on Mr. Schiller's reported resignation at a news conference Friday. It was originally planned for Thursday, but was put off to allow time for the Chancellor to have a private talk with Mr. Schiller about his letter.

title: Blind Reelect President
description: CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) Kenneth Jernigan of Des Moines, Iowa, was reelected president of the National Fed eration of the Blind today. Mr. Jernigan, 45 years old, who has been blind from birth, has served as president of the 45, 000member organization since 1968. He also is director of the Iowa Commission for the Blind.

title: Goodman Is Soloist in Park
description: Benny Goodman was not scheduled to appear in the Newport Jazz Festival, which is occupying New York's con cert halls this week, but by coincidence he turned up as soloist in the free Naumburg Symphony concert Tuesday night in Central Park. The clarinetist, abetted by perfect weather and a holiday, drew an overflow crowd, with a large ring of standees sur rounding the seating area.

title: JUNK DEALER HELD IN JERSEY SLAYING
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J., July 5 A 50yearold junk dealer was charged here today with murdering a wealthy developer to whom he owed money.

title: Personalities: Luck Fails Spinks
description: The St. Louis Cardinals' hardthrowing right  handed pitcher, Scipio Spinks, who travels with a huge stuffed toy gorilla as a good luck charm, ran out of luck Tues day when he collided with the major league's best catcher, Cincinnati's Johnny Bench, while scoring in the third inning. Spinks suffered torn ligaments in his right knee and is through for the season, according to the St. Louis team physician, Dr. Stan London. Dr. London will operate on Spinks's knee this morning at Jewish Hospi tal in St. Louis and expects Spinks to be in a leg cast for about sixweeks. The 24year old hurler scored from first on a double by Luis Melendez when Bench dropped the ball from the force of the im pact The Chicago White Sox announced that they had placed their third baseman, Bill Melton, on the 15day disabled list because of a back ailment. Melton led the American League with 33 home runs last season, but has only seven this year.

title: WALDHEIM CONFERS WITH POLISH AIDES
description: WARSAW, July 5Secretary General Waldheim of the Unit ed Nations arrived here today to begin a series of talks with Polish officials.

title: 11 PERSONS SEIZED IN HARLEM LOOTING
description: The police arrested 11 per sons in Harlem yesterday and reported that smallscale loot ing had continued in the area for the second straight night.

title: Motorists Advised On Exhaust Repairs
description: WAYNE; N. J., July 5 Motorists whose cars failed to measure up today to auto ex haust emission standards set by the state were told that a simple adjustment in many cases is all that is needed to correct the problem. They were told to look for the fol lowing probelms before agree ing to major repairs.

title: LEONARDO LIBRARY IN NEED OF FUNDS
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., July 5 (AP) A critical shortage of funds at Stevens Institute of Technology may prevent scholars from making use of its milliondollar collection of the works of Leonardo da Vinci.

title: Arrives in Bucharest
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 5Secretary Rogers arrived in Bucharest today in the first visit to Rumania by an Amer ican Secretary of State. Shortly after his arrival, he signed a consular agreement to protect travelersthe latest in a series of measures to improve rela tions since President Nixon vis ited here in 1969.

title: With Quarrys, Losing Is All in the Family
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 5 (AP)The Quarry family, whose wellknown brothers, Jerry and Mike, lost in the ring at Las Vegas, Nev., last week, was on the losing end again today.

title: Rapid City Toll Up to 235
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., July 5 (AP)Work crews uncovered today the body of the 235th victim of the June 9 flood. Coroner George Behrens said the victim, a woman, had not been identified.

title: Hal Walker, 76, Director For Movies and TV, Dead
description: TRACY, Calif., July 5 (AP) Hal Walker, a veteran motion picture and television comedy director, died Monday in Com munity Memorial Hospital here. He was 76 years old.

title: H. DOUGLAS ROBINSON
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 5 H. Douglas Robinson, who conducted his own business in realestate advertising and sales for many years, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: FATHER ON PLANE SEIZED WITH BABY
description: BUFFALO, July 5  A 23 yearold Buffalo man was ar rested this morning after he allegedly held his 18month old daughter hostage at knife point aboard an American Air lines 707 jet at Greater Buffa lo International Airport and threatened to kill her unless he was flown to a foreign coun try.

title: With Hampton, Trip to the Shrine
description: It was another trip down memory lane last night at Philharmonic Hall, when American Airlines sponsored a Tribute to Lionel Hamp ton as part of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: LEBANON AND SYRIA ASK COUNCIL SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 5Lebanon and Syria today requested a meeting of the Security Council because of Israeli defiance of a Coun cil resolution that asked for the release in the shortest possible time of one Lebanese and five Syrian army officers.

title: Two Protestant Brothers Are Found Slain in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 5Two young Protestant brothers who left home last night to visit Roman Catholic friends were found dead this morning on a lonely road out side Belfast.

title: Saving the Desert
description: The Mojave and Colorado deserts in southern Cali fornia may finally receive the protection they have long deserved. After years of rapidly increasing desecration by littering, indiscriminate road building, mineral pros pecting, speculative real estate ventures, and hordes of motorcycles and other offroad vehicles, the Federal Gov ernment now seems ready to save some of what still remains of the fragile, awesome desert landscapes.

title: THERESE CASSEL
description: Therese Cassel, who headed the language department of the Jamaica (Queens) High School from 1930 to about 1952, died yesterday at her home, 166 East 63d Street. She was 80 years old.

title: Industry Mark Likely for Month
description: DETROIT, July 4The Gen eral Motors Corporation today reported record car sales in June, 450,872 deliveries, a 7 per cent increase from 422,409 the year before. The American Mo tors Corporation reported 28,818 June sales, its best June in eight years, up 23 per cent from 23,496 deliveries the year be fore.

title: Action on Dog Litter and Graffiti Put Off for Months by Council
description: Legislation dealing with the problems of graffiti on public buildings and dog excrement in the streets will not be con sidered by the City Council until late summer or early fall, Councilman Thomas J. Cuite, Brooklyn Democrat and major ity leader, said yesterday.

title: Americans Music Fill the Program Of Kohon Quartet
description: What better time to open a concert series entitled Hear America First than on the eve ning of July 4aside from the fact that it would hardly occur to 99.99 per cent of the popu lation to spend the Fourth listening to the performance of string quartets, even if they are by Americans. Nonetheless, a mediumsized audience did at tend the Greenwich Mews Theater Tuesday night to hear the Kohon Quartet play music by Copland, Gershwin, Mennin, Helps and Schuman.

title: JOSEPH A. FITZPATRICK
description: MERRITT ISLAND, Fla., July 5Joseph A. Fitzpatrick, re tired chief engineer of the Bureau of the Budget of New York City, died on Monday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: The choice of card to lead from a given holding used to be automatic: A table had been established by authori ties of high standing, and that was that.

title: EDMUND DONOVAN
description: MIAMI, July 5 (AP)Edmund Donovan, a TV technician for the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, drowned Sunday in a hotel swimming pool here, the police reported today. He was 44 years old and lived in Malverne, L. I.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 5The Demo cratic National Committee is going into the Supreme Court to fight a lower court decision on the California challenge, but also to support the lower court's Illinois decision. This policy might appear to be what law yers describe as ridiculous on its face because If the California decision stands, the committee will be relieved of its greatest headache; but if the Illinois decision stands, the whole Democratic party may well be relieved of Chicago and Illinois in next fall's election.

title: Yanks' Kline Tops A's, 41, On Alou, Munson Homers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 5 The New York Yankees, who have not found travel very broadening this year, finally won a game in the Oakland Coliseum tonight when they de feated the Athletics, 41, on a sixhitter by Steve Kline.

title: Boggs and Ford End Visit To China, Ask Closer Ties
description: HONG KONG, July 5 (Reu ters)  The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Unit ed States House of Represen tatives arrived here today on their way home from China. They said that it was in the joint interest of China and the United States to establish closer relations.

title: A 3d Lithuanian Protest Suicide Reported by Soviet Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (AP)Dis sident sources reported today that a Lithuanian worker doused himself with gasoline last month and burned himself to death to protest Soviet occu pation, the third immolation in the Lithuanian Republic in seven weeks.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Los ANGELES, July 5The Democratic party will try to do in 19 hours this weekend what It has not been able to do in the last four yearsget out of debt.

title: XEROX TRUST SUITS ARE FILED BY LITTON
description: The Xerox Corporation con firmed yesterday that it was being sued under antitrust laws In two separate actions brought by Litton Industries, Inc.

title: Today's Jazz Schedules
description: Here is a schedule of to day's events in the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York:

title: Many Lawyers Who Provide Free Legal Counseling to the Poor Find Satisfaction in Their Work
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  After Jerome Morris obtained his Master of Law degree, he could have returned to a rewarding practice in some comfortable office, but he went to work instead for the Federal Legal Services program in a crumbling storefront here.

title: Screen:In 'Frogs,' the Animals Do In Ray Milland
description: "We," announces Jason Crockett (Ray Milland), the crochety old millionaire who lives on his own island in the middle of the Florida Everglades, "are the ugly rich.""God knows we're entitled to be ugly," says his middle-aged daughter, a woman who likes to collect butterflies. "We pay enough taxes." She thinks a minute, then asks: "Daddy, did you know they're putting strainers on our paper mills?""It's called ecology control," her father snorts, very much in the snorting manner of someone who must be taught a lesson."Frogs" is that lesson. It's nature's half-acre gone amok, apparently because of pollution and the somewhat too-free use of pesticides authorized by rich old men who live on their own islands in the middle of the Florida Everglades.One by one the Crocketts are picked off by the frenzied faunaby lizards, rattlesnakes, water moccasins, alligators, crabs, snapping turtles and tarantulas, as well as by (in at least one case) some Spanish moss. Poor old Jason is finally attacked by frogs, though what exactly they do to him is not clear. Perhaps they thump him to death."Frogs," which is not to be confused with "The Birds" for an instant, is an end-of-the-world junk movie, photographed rather prettily in Florida and acted by Milland as if he were sight-reading random passages from the dictionary.It opened yesterday at theaters throughout the metropolitan area, including the New Amsterdam, where it's double-billed with an English-dubbed Japanese film, "Godzilla vs. the Smog Monster," about a creature that lives on sludge. Godzilla, a sort of Japanese Smokey the Bear, hates pollution and saves the day, clumping around the countryside on his hind legs, looking as embarrassed and pious as an elderly clergyman at a charity masquerade ball.

title: Julie Harris Will Star in Mrs. Lincoln
description: Theater '73, the producing company of Richard Barr and Charles Woodward, has signed Julie Harris to star in The Last of Mrs. Lincoln, a new play by James Prideaux, opening here Jan. 11.

title: Pompidou Ousts Premier, Names HardLine Gaullist
description: PARIS, July 5President Pompidou accepted his Govern ment's resignation today and chose a tough, orthodox Gaullist, Pierre Messmer, as his new Premier. Mr. Messmer's main job will be to help Mr. Pompidou's party in the com ing elections.

title: Study Finds Increases in Life Expectancy at Birth
description: GENEVA, June 30  Life ex pectancies at birth, in 34 coun tries on which detailed mortal ity figures are available, have made impressive gains, ac cording to a newly completed study by the World Health Or ganizatibn here.

title: GLAMOUR ISSUES REVIVE MARKET
description: Glamour stocks, the group that repeatedly has revived a sluggish stock market over the last two years, performed the honors again yesterday. The DowJones industrial average moved ahead 4.81 to 933.47.

title: General to Aid at Trial
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., July 5 (AP)Brig. Gen. Paul Gorman, assistant commandant at Fort Benning has been transferred to Washington to assist the United States Justice Depart ment in the trial of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, an Army spokesman has confirmed. Dr. Ellsberg, charged with making the Pen tagon, papers available to the press, goes on trial in United States District Court next Monday.

title: Disbarred Boston Judge Gets Federal Disbarment
description: BOSTON, July 5 (AP)for mer Superior Court Judge Ed ward J. DeSaulnier Jr., who was disbarred by the Massa chusetts Supreme Judicial Court last January for misconduct, was today ordered disbarred from practice before the Fed eral bar as well.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Hugh F. Culverhouse of Jacksonville, Fla., filed a $5million antitrust suit in Federal Court here yesterday against the National Football League, the Los Angeles Rams and the Baltimore Colts.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: The 65foot Portuguese sloop, Jessica, owned by Georg SchederBieschin held a slim lead on the seventh day of the Race to Discovery, an ocean race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain. Jessica was eight miles in front of Phantom, Ralph B. Ryder's Class B yacht out of Miami, according to a noon report from the Westward, a diesel yacht accom panying the 47boat racing fleet.

title: Times Reporter Tells of Death Threat in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 6Fox But terfield, a reporter for The New York Times, testified today that he was threatened with death when he refused to surrender his notebook on the demand of Dr. E. Wyman Garrett, a former member of the Newark Board of Education, at a board meet ing that ended in chaos here 15 months ago.

title: The Yemeni Fissure
description: Yemen's pragmatic decision to resume diplomatic rela tions with the United States reduces the hope of Egypt for maintaining a united Arab front against Israel and its principal backer, and also the U.S.S.R. hope for speedily displacing Western influence throughout the Arab world.

title: Chess Is Game of SkillWith Some Luck
description: Unlike poker, craps, Mo nopoly, bridge or love, chess is absolutely devoid of the element of chance. Or so most people think.

title: Murphy Again Charges Court Laxity on Bribers
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy charged again yes terday that the criminal courts were lax in the handling of cases involving attempts to bribe policemen.

title: SHOWDOWN NEAR AT QUANGTRI CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 7  The South Vietnamese task force pushing north sought yesterday to clear enemy resistance for the final assault to retake Quang tri city. To the south, the North Vietnamese countered by raining their heaviest shell ing attack to date on the ner vous city of Hue.

title: GOODRICH CHEMICAL LIFTS RUBBER PRICES
description: The B. F. Goodrich Chemical Company, a division of the B. F. Goodrich Company, an nounced yesterday that it had increased prices by 0.6 cent a pound on its AmeripolMicro black masterbatch styrene butadiene rubbers, effective July 1.

title: Shultz to Meet With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, after winding up two days of meetings with repre sentatives of various segments of the food industry today, an nounced that he would fly to California to make recommen dations to President Nixon on how to drive down food prices.

title: MORTGAGE BANKER IS GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: Frank Fey, former vice presi dent of the Eastern Service Cor poration, pleaded guilty yester day to charges of fraud and conspiracy in connection with an alleged mortgagefraud scheme.

title: Brandt Accepts Resignation of Schiller
description: BONN, July 6The resigna tion of Karl Schiller as Minister of Economics and Finance, sub mitted Sunday in angry protest against West Germany's intro duction of controls over foreign exchange, was accepted today by Chancellor Willy Brandt.

title: HENRY POSTS 65, LEADS IN CANADA
description: FORT ERIE, Ont., July 6 George (Bunky) Henry of At lanta scored a 65 in the first round today to lead the Cana dian open golf championship. The 28yearold professional, a former stellar placekicker for Georgia Tech's football team and winner of the Canadian amateur golf title in 1965, as a collegian, held a onestroke edge with his sixunderpar round, a record for the rede signed Cherry Hill Golf Club course. A 66 by George Knud son in 1960 was the previous record.

title: Moscow Reaffirms Its Support Of Castro as He Ends His Visit
description: MOSCOW, June 6The So viet Government voiced expres sions of continued support for Cuba today, but gave no indica tion of any specific new aid agreement.

title: 800Employe Company Here Is Trying ThreeDay and FourDay Work Week
description: More than 800 employes of Group Health, Inc., have begun a summer experiment in the threeday and fourday work week, becoming the first union shop in the city to do so.

title: Schiller Explains Move
description: BONN, July 6, (Reuters)  Dr. Karl Schiller said in a tele vision interview tonight that he should hive resigned earlier in view of his differences with the Government.

title: AMEX RISES A BIT IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Good volume continued on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, rising to 5,784,000 shares from 4,616,000 on Wednesday. It was the heaviest trading since May 9, when 5,945,000 shares changed hands.

title: Corona Praises Mayor, Forest Hills Pickets Him
description: Mayor Lindsay had to be es corted by policemen last night through dozens of screaming pickets who denounced him for trying to build a lowincome housing project in the Forest Hills section of Queens.

title: QUILICI IS NAMED TWINS' MANAGER
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 6 (AP)Frank Quilici, 33 years old, was named manager of the Minnesota Twins today, replac ing Bill Rigney, who was dis missed by Calvin Griffith, club president.

title: New Orleans Recalled
description: New Orleans jazz, on its native turf, gains a measure of its flavor from the set tings in which it is played. The streets, the dance halls, even the sleazy bars con tribute to the character of the performances.

title: McDonnell Unit in Layoff
description: The McDonnell Douglas As tronautics Company, a division of the McDonnell Douglas. Cor poration, said it was beginning a layoff of about 750 aerospace workers at its plant in Hunting ton Beach, Calif. The company said the layoff was required because work was nearing com pletion on the Skylab orbital workshop.

title: Smith, Nastase Gain Wimbledon Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6It will be Stanley Rogers Smith against Ilie Nastase in the Witribledon tennis final Sat urday. Sixfootfourinch Stan, from Sea Pines, S.C., belabored Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia with the weight of service and smash, 36, 64, 61, 75, and mercurial Nastase of Rumania teased Manuel Orantes of Spain to defeat, 63, 64, 64.

title: G.E.NET AND SALES AT RECORD LEVEL
Bucket Brigade Cleans Up Oil Along the Schuylkill
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., July 6 One hundred youths formed a bucket brigade today to clean up a massive oil spill that stretched for 16 miles along the Schuylkill.

title: Memoirs of 200 Notables Offered in Micro Forms
description: Joe Gould lives!

title: Market Measure Passes Major Hurdle in Britain
description: LONDON, July 6 (AP)The bill taking Britain into the Common Market has cleared the last major hurdle for entry into the European Economic Com munity on Jan. 1.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Yesterday was special in New York. It didn't rain. So the secretaries who brought their lunch to Bryant Park, the lovers who came to smooch and the park's resi dent eccentrics got a treat: a parade of raincoat fashions from London Fog.

title: POUND AND DOLLAR CHURNED IN TRADING
description: LONDON, July 6 (AP)The pound sterling and the dollar were tossed around European money markets today in a flurry of unsettling gains and losses that did little to stabilize the troubled currencies.

title: Postscript to Stockholm
description: The first recommendation of the United Nations Con ference on the Human Environment to be tested in the international marketplace has now been unconscionably, though not unexpectedly, rejected.

title: DR. RALPH ROBEY, ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Dr. Ralph W. Robey, former vice president and chief econ omist of the National Associa tion of Manufacturers, died Wednesday at Doctors Hospit al. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Arkansas Slate Challenged
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 6 (AP)A suit was filed in United States District Court today charging that the 27 delegates from Arkansas to the Democratic National Conven tion had been chosen in an unconstitutional manner and asking that the court order a new state convention to select delegates. The suit, filed by a proWallace group, asks that new delegates be chosen with out regard to race, color, sex, occupation or national origin.

title: France's Latest Cabinet Includes Few New Faces
description: PARIS, July 6France's new Premier, Pierre Messmer, an nounced his Cabinet tonight. In major posts, the team is nearly a replica of the group that served the deposed Premier, Jacques ChabanDelmas.

title: Britain Raises Fund to Retain Titian Canvas
description: LONDON, July 6A na tional fundraising appeal has raised more than $4mil lion to stop the export to the United Stales of Titian's The Death of Actaeon, it was announced here tonight.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 6 (UPI)As part of their new look, the Democrats will publish their own daily con vention newspaper next week, starting with a 64page Sunday edition put together by a 30member staff, most of them volunteers.

title: GERSHWIN SCORES SUBJECT OF A SUIT
description: A court claim was filed for the Library of Congress yester day in an effort to obtain the original manuscripts of 14 songs written by George Gershwin.

title: Officers Picked for Merged Blyth Eastman
description: The merger of Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co. with Blyth & Co. will cre ate one of the nation's three largest investment houses with some $90million in cap ital, officials of the two houses indicated yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 6Sen ator George McGovern's strength among delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion is apparently holding firm despite the controversy over the California and Illinois dele gations.

title: The Food Is Classic French, The Setting Is 18th Century
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Letters to the Editor
