description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: WASILIINGTON, July 6  President Nixon is waging the air war against North Vietnam with a decentralized system of Command and control that dif fers significantly from the highly centralited system em ployed by his predecessor, Lyn don B. Johnson, during the 196568 air campaign. In the view of a number of civilian and mil itary officials with experience in Indo china, the decen tralization does not imply the unraveling of ci vilian control over the military or the loosening of the chain of military command.

title: Jersey State Police Cite Stress
description: WEST TRENTON, N. J., July 6  For the first time in the 51yearhistory of the New Jersey State Police, the troopers say they are under fire from within and with out: Citizens have brought charges ranging from har assment to brutality, and, ac cording to the troopers, there is an unprecedented crack down on alleged misbehavior within the department itself.

title: 68 Dead, 115 Missing In 600 Slides in Japan
description: TOKY0, Friday, July 7 (Reuters)The toll of dead and missing from landslides caused by torrential rains in southern Japan reached 183 today, the police said.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The Washington Star said today that the Civil Aeronautics Board had decided to reject a proposed merger of American Airlines and Western Air Lines. The re port added that the C.A.B. sent its ruling to the White House Office of Management and Budget about two weeks ago.

title: South African Bout Sought
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 6  South African boxing promoters are negotiat ing for a bout for Muhammad Ali in this country sometime this year.

title: Safety vs. Convenience
description: Signalling a new tough policy against aerial hijackers, Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., the Government's aviation security chief, last month advised the aviation industry to put greater reliance on the lawenforcement expertise of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. These agents are not triggerhappy gunslingers, he said, referring to the F.B.I. They are wellequipped and highly trained professionals fully capable of responding to hijack and extortion incidents as circumstances warrant.

title: U.S. Defends I.T.T. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Justice Department argued to day against reopening a Fed eral district court's approval of the controversial merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Com pany.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RELIEF CASE LOAD DROPS IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. L, July 6The welfare case load in Nassau County fell in the first six months of 1972, County Execu tive Ralph G. Caso said today. It was the first time in 10 years that a decline was reported.

title: REFINANCING SET BY WALSTON & CO.
description: Walston & Co., Inc., disclosed yesterday that it has arranged a $17million longterm refi nancing program, with much of the money coming from H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer mil lionaire who controls du Pont Glore Forgan, Inc.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 6  The great glass palaces of play are slowly filling up and the Army helicopters are alert overhead and the convention hall is ready. But the Demo crats are not.

title: Dizzy's Touch Animates Young Chorus
description: Dizzy Gillespie finally got a chance to do his thing his own way yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The pro grain was billed as a Sacred Concert, and featured Diz with his current group (with Big Black, a welcome addi tion, playing congas), accom panied for the second half of the performance by the New York AllCity Choir under the direction of John Motley.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOUR IN A WILD PLACE. By John Stallard. 245 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $6.95.

title: PADRES TOP METS AND M'GRAW, 70, ON WALK IN 14TH
description: Making only two hits in 14 innings, the New York Mets lost a 10 decision to the San Diego Padres last night by minimum margins with maxi mum frustration. Among other things, the winning run scored on a walk with the bases full, and the final out of the game was a spectacular tag play at home plate on what would have been the tying run.

title: HOUSING FOR POOR HELD SUBVERTED
description: DETROIT, July 6Govern ment efforts to lower the price of housing for the poor have been perverted to enrich home sellers, according to a report from the Mortgage Bankers As sociation of Michigan.

title: Cleveland Six: Crusaders
description: CLEVELAND, July 6 (UPI) Cleveland's entry in the new World Hockey Association was officially named the Crusaders today. More than 8,000 sugges tions for a team nickname were received in a fiveday contest.

title: Market Place: Municipal Bonds And Little Guys
description: In this era of high taxes, when the incometax burden on middleclass families at state and local levels is con siderable, the taxfree munic ipal bond is becoming a popular conversation piece on Main Street as it has long been in Wall Street.

title: 3 HOMEX OFFICERS OFFER TO RESIGN
description: Three of the senior officers, including the two founders, of the Stirling Homex Corpora tion, a manufacturer of modu lar housing, have offered their resignations, which have not yet been accepted by the board of directors.

title: Tanaka Names a New Cabinet But Two Refuse to Accept Posts
description: TOKYO, Friday, July 7 (Reu ters)  Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, named his Cabinet today, but immediately ran into trouble when two of his appointees refused to serve.

title: Geared to Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Government published for the first time today two measures of real corporate profits profits adjusted for inflation.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Governor Rockefeller established a Governor's Com mission on the future of horse racing in New York State.

title: CITY SAYS IT LOST $250MILLION AID BECAUSE OF STATE
description: The city has lost a minimum of $250million in Federal wel fare funds, unclaimed by the state since 1969 because of bureaucratic lethargy tanta mount to gross negligence, Mayor Lindsay's Commission on StateCity Relations charged yesterday.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Grumman Corporation received a $30.3million Navy contract for carrierbased re connaissance aircraft, it was announced yesterday.

title: Guyana, China in Pact
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July 6 (Reuters)Guyana and China have entered into a multimillion dollar contract under a trade agreement signed in Peking last November.

title: Executive Changes
description: G. A. Wagner has been elected chairman of the Shell Oil Company, succeeding Sir David Bar ran, who has resigned.

title: Lyle to the Rescue Again As Yanks Down A's, 62
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 6 The revived New York Yankees defeated the Oakland Athletics again tonight, 62, and for the 17th time this season the name on the bottom line was Albert W. (Sparky) Lyle.

title: Business Briefs
description: Advertised prices of department, specialty and general merchandise stores in May were 2.2 per cent higher on average than for the same month last year, according to the Bureau of Advertising.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Relocation Companies Accused of Harassment
description: Two of the city's largest re location and management com panies which are jointly owned, were accused by the state yes terday of conducting a con scious campaign to frighten and intimidate tenants to force them to vacate 28 Man hattan buildings proposed for demolition.

title: Kretchmer and Councilman DeMarco Trade Punches About Garbage Facility
description: A brief, violent fight broke out in the rotunda of City Hall yesterday afternoon between Michael DeMarco, 36 years old, a 5foot10, 180pound city Councilman from the Bronx, and Jerome Kretchmer, 37, the 6foot3, 180pound city Envi ronmental Protection Adminis trator.

title: Hijacker Seizes Coast Jet, Flies Off With 5 Hostages
description: SAN DIEGO, Friday, July 7 A gunman hijacked a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner with 57 persons aboard late yester day, forced it to land here, col lected $455,000 ransom and took off again with three crew members and two male pas sengers aboard as hostages.

title: FOSTER IS VICTOR IN TEMPEST TRIAL
description: MARION, Mass., July 6In the fifth race of the Finn and Tempest Class Olympic sailing trials today, the winners were determined in the first minute. Never headed after that were Norm Freeman in the single handed Finn and Glen S. Foster at the helm of the twoman Tempest.

title: U.S. Vietnam Toll Put at 14 Reporting Delays Are Cited
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (UPI)Fourteen Americans were reported killed in action last week, the highest toll in nearly two months, the United States command announced to day.

title: HONG KONG'S DOLLAR TIED TO U.S. CURRENCY
description: HONG KONG, July 6The British Crown Colony of Hong Kong, in a move described as temporary, broke its ties with sterling today, and linked its currency to the United States dollar.

title: Opposition in Seoul Says It Is Stifled, Calls Park's Tactics SelfPerpetuating
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe small, highwalled home of Kim Dae Jung up a dusty alleyway in suburban Seoul is never without a sedan parked nearby with two men inside.

title: Fishing Contest Opens at Prospect Park, and 300 Youngsters Turn Out
description: Tincan floats, keyring sinkers, treelimb poles and father's best salt  water tackle were in evidence yes terday as 300 youngsters fished the lake at Prospect Park. But the bass, perch and a certified 15pound sturgeon named Romeo  stocked by the city's De partment of Recreation  weren't biting. Kernel corn won out over worms in lur ing numerous carp and cat fish, however.

title: Jazz: Mahavishnu, A Trip Into Rock
description: John McLaughlin's Maha vishnu Orchestra split the jazz  generation gap right down the middle at Carnegie Hall last night. The eclectic jazzrock group was on a Newport Jazz program that also included the Cannonball Adderley Quintet and Oscar Peterson, solo pianist.

title: Metteer's Team Advances
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 (AP)  Richard Metteer of Anaheim, Calif., and Robert Sherman of Temple City, Calif., won their quarterfinal tennis match in the veterans doubles today against Gus Palafox and Jay Freeman of Little Rock, Ark., 64, 62.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 7, 1972

title: GLAZIERS GET PACT IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: One of 13 striking building trades unionsGlaziers Local 1087  reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the Building Trades Employers As sociation that increases pay and benefits by 21 per cent over three years.

title: Roundup: Coleman Ends Tigers' Skid on 6Hitter
description: The Detroit Tigers last night ended a fourgame losing streak that had cost them a share of first place in the American League Eastern Division with a 70 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: HIGH COURT ASKED TO STAY 2 RULINGS HELPING M'GOVERN
description: WASHINGTON, July 6Two legal appeals that could reduce Senator George McGovern's delegate strength at the Demo critic National Convention were carried to the Supreme Court today, but Chief Justice Warren E. Burger issued no decision by the time the Court's offices closed for the night.

title: Men's Matches Fail to Arouse Spectators
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6During most of the Wimbledon matches today, there was boredom. In the second set of Stan Smith's victory over Jan Kodes, spectators in the center court enclosure were yawnings. And at least on ewas sleep ing.

title: Cosmos 499 Launched
description: MOSCOW, July 6The Soviet Union launched today the un manned spacecraft Cosmos 499, believed to be a military obser vation satellite. Its orbital para meters of 176 by 130 miles at an angle of 51.8 degrees have been identified by the West as those of datacollecting satel lites launched from the central Asian center of Tyuratam.

title: Suffolk Looking Into Deals That Doubled Park's Cost
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 6A complex series of land manipulations involving more than 11,000 feet of prime oceanfront land in this resort community has more than doubled the price Suffolk County will have to pay for the 295acre county park to be created here.

title: Building Industry Here Scored by Housing Chief
description: Albert A. Walsh, the city's Housing and Development Ad ministrator, denounced mem bers of the construction indus try yesterday as spineless and morally bankrupt for failing to cooperate with investigators who are trying to combat cor ruption.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday that it had received a $5.7million, second installment from the Chilean Government in payment for expropriation of the company's copper facilities in Chile. A first payment, totaling $5.8million, was received April 3. Kennecott has an agreement with the Chilean Government providing for 31 semiannual installments for a total of $92.9million on the debt owed to it by Chile.

title: Come, Test Your Memory
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.There are mo ments in life when an era passes and you must look quickly to see its wake in the passing parade.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: ODDLOT CHARGES ARE CUT OVERALL
description: The New York Stock Ex change decided yesterday to set a charge of  of a point, or 12 cents, a share for all oddlot transactions, effective July 17.

title: CarSales Rate Soars
description: DETROIT, July 6  New car and truck sales this year are headed toward 13 million, auto industry executives said after counting record firsthalf sales.

title: I Wonder Why
description: There is, it seems to me, a common inclination among most of us in New York to dismiss conditions in East Harlem as hopeless. Black and Puerto Rican babies will be hungry, children will not be able to read, teenagers will be addicts, families will live on welfare in dilapidated apartments without heat or hot water. Yet we can build a Gimbel's on East 86th Street, we can build luxury highrises up and down our avenues, we can go into Vietnam and damn the cost. Even more strangely, to me, we can have a model integrated public school on East 96th Street and Third Avenue while only ten or twenty blocks north the children in other public schools are brutalized by violence and drugs.

title: Advertising:
description: Advertisers have once more reacted to the possibility of Government regulation by promulgating guidelinesthis time in the area of TV adver tising aimed at children un der 12 years of age.

title: Fred Wittner of Ad Agency Dies Expert on Industrial Accounts
description: Fred Wittner, president of the Fred Wittner Company, Inc., advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 15 Stew art Place, White Palins.

title: Dakota Woman Elected
description: BISMARCK, N. D., July 6 (AP) Gerridee Wheeler of Bismarck was elected today as North Dakota's new Republican Na tional Committeewoman. Mrs. Wheeler was elected on the first ballot at the state Republican convention.

title: For Weekend Chefs
description: In the menu below, the dishes marked with an aster isk is followed by a recipe.

description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: Sales of Savings Bonds declined in June but remained well ahead of redemptions for the 21st consecutive month, the Treasury Department reported yesterday. The net cash inflow totaled $149million in June against $213million in May and $136million in June, 1971.

title: Cambodia Siege Steps Up
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 6 (AP)  Enemy gunners sent more than 600 shells into the district center of Angtassom, in what the high command de scribed today as the heaviest bombardment in Cambodia in more than two years of war. Angtassom, 40 miles south of here on Route 3, is cut off and has been under heavy enemy pressure since the beginning of the week.

title: Keating Quits as Envoy in India To Support Nixon Campaign
description: NEW DELHI, July 6Ken neth B. Keating announced to day that he would resign as Ambassador to India and return to the United States to cam paign for the reelection of President Nixon.

title: Boston Navy Yard Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The Navy said today it had awarded a $5.5million contract to the Boston Naval Shipyard for extensive overhauling o a floating drydock.

title: U.N. COUNCIL IS TOLD ARABS HOLD ISRAELIS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6In a letter to the Presi dent of the Security Council, Israel said today that the pol icy of Egypt and Syria of per sistent refusal not only to release Israeli prisoners of war but also to see their own na tionals home again is not ac ceptable to civilized opinion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Social Services Department said yesterday that a breakdown in, a computer had prevented the mailing of more than 10,000 supplemental welfare checks, causing considerable confusion at seven welfare centers and three arrests for disorderly conduct.

title: WATER CRAIG DIES; ADAGENCY FOUNDER
description: Walter Craig, a retired New York advertising executive, died after a long illness Wednesday at Mountainside Hospital, in Montclair, N. J. He was 71 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Text of Fischer's Apology
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 6 (UPI)  Following is the text of Bobby Fischer's letter to Boris Spassky:

title: Weather Cuts ChainStore Gains
description: The country's largest retail chains reported higher sales in June over the same month last year, but wet and unseasonal weather in the East and Middle West held two merchandisers to their smallest monthly gains of the year.

title: Notes on People
description: A 37  year  old Foreign Service officer, James E. Baker, will become the first black American diplomat on permanent assignment to the United States Embassy in South Africa. Mr. Baker, who joined the State Department in 1960, is now assigned to the embassy in Tokyo as eco nomic and commercial of ficer, the same post he will hold in Pretoria.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON, July 6Although Senator George McGovern is still tan talizingly short of the marginal votes needed to make him certain of the Presidential nomination, political dis cussion has already turned to his selec tion of a running mate.

title: Hashish Study Finds Slight Use Causes Few Ills
description: A threeyear study of 720 regular users of hashish, the concentrated resin of the mari juana plant, has shown that persons who smoke moderate amounts, equivalent to three or four marijuana cigarettes a day, suffered few mental or physical illeffects other than a mild res piratory ailment known as hash throat.

title: French Minister in Peking
description: PEKING, July 6 (Agence France  Presse)  France's Foreign Minister, Maurice Schumann, arrived here today for an official visit during which he will discuss world and FrenchChinese problems. He was met at the airport by Chinese Foreign Minister, Chi Pengfei and other high offi cials.

title: Gay Activist Member Charges 2d Fireman With Beating Him
description: A member of the Gay Activist Alliance whose charges of ha rassment against Michael J. Maye, president of the Uni formed Firefighters Association, were dismissed on Wednesday, accused a battalion fire chief yesterday of beating him during a melee.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6 (AP)The Oklahoma Boxing Commission announced today it was withdrawing its recognition of Joe Frazier as world heavyweight champion and would recognize the winner of a planned bout between George Foreman and Oscar Bonavena in Oklahoma City this fall.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WAVERLY, Minn., July 6 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has campaigned for the Presidency for 12 years, is re luctantly resolved to fight to the finish for the Democratic nomi nation even if that fight poses the risk of widening the party rifts that plagued his own race against Richard M. Nixon four years ago.

title: Chess Play Will Start Tuesday Spassky Wins Draw for White
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 6  After months of bickering and battling, protests and post ponements, the world cham pionship chess match formally began today.

title: Has She Given Up Hope of Seeing Her Husband Alive? Oh, No!
description: There is a photograph of Mrs. Louise Stone at a Cambodian military checkpoint. She is leaning, half mockingly, on a dummy in a Cambodian Army uniform that had been propped up on a barbedwire roadblock to frighten potential attackers. There is a slight smile on her thin, drawn face. No, she said, she didn't want that picture printed. It seemed too light hearted for a woman searching for her captured husband, and the people at home, she feared, would, not understand. She is sure people did not understand her feelings at the recent dedication of a Brooklyn Museum ex hibit of war photographs taken by her husband, Dana Stone, and some of the other 18 missing journalists cap tured in Cambodia.

title: Merger News
description: The Oil Shale Corporation (Tosco) signed an agreement yesterday to purchase from the Monsanto Company its petro leum refining and marketing business operating under the Lion Oil name. The transaction involves more than $24million in cash for Lion Oil assets and related inventories.

title: Monetary Expansion Slows Markedly
description: Monetary expansion has slowed markedly in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Sys tem reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

description: COLLECTED POEMS, 19581970. By George MacBeth. 254 pages. Atheneum $7.50

title: Improvement Hinted In Forthcoming Data On Jobless in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  A top Presidential adviser dis closed tonight that the Govern ment would release tomorrow Unemployment figures for June that would be very much bet ter than the approximately 6 per cent jobless rate that has prevailed for 18 months.

title: The Talk of Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 6 The bandstand is deserted and rusting and if you stand in the hipdeep weeds the only sounds you can hear now are the raw materials of a blues number  wailing birds and moaning wind through the trees. For 17 years, Festival Field in Miantonomi Memori al Park was the site of the New port Jazz Festi val, and the week of the Fourth of July it was filled with the sounds of the great est jazz in the world.

title: Stock Exchange Extends Price Advance
description: Renewed hopes for peace in Vietnam sent stock prices sharply higher yesterday, al though the market pared its best gains in late trading.

title: LAVER CONQUERS RAHIM IN 3 SETS
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 6 (AP)Topseeded Rod Laver, the host pro, rallied in the third set today to advance to the quarterfinals of the $25,000 Bretton Woods inter national tennis tournament.

title: Rogers Assures Rumanian Chief On U. S. and Soviet Agreements
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 6  Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers was understood to have assured President Nico lae Ceausescu in a fourhour meeting here today that there would be no SovietUnited States deal at the expense of small powers.

title: Nixon Aides, Seeing Big Gains, Plan a Drive for Jewish Votes
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  President Nixon's chief politi cal strategists, convinced that he has an excellent chance of making deep inroads into the traditionally Democratic vote of the Jewish community, have developed plans for a major campaign among Jews.

title: The Flood Plains
description: In the wake of Tropical Storm Agnes the moment is right for a drastic reconsideration of flood relief. By a fortunate coincidence there is new awareness that the location of people, homes and Industries is a legitimate concern of government.

title: Man in the News
description: PARIS, July 6  Every morning for nearly 10 years a lithe, graying figure bounded into the courtyard of the French Defense Ministry on the Boulevard St.Germain at precisely 7 A.M.

title: Medicine Men Successful Where Science Falls Short
description: ROUGH ROCK, Ariz.  A young Navajo, Steven Tsosie, was troubled with strange aches in his chest and arms, sometimes all over his body. He went to the hand trem bler, an Indian diagnostician, and was told that some evil spirits had to be exorcised.

title: Sought Church Unity
description: Think of, just think of it  with St. Peter in the West and St. John in the East, one vast net could be thrown into the sea of the world and encircle with love an those 900 million Christian fish.

title: Advertising:
description: A bunch of the boys from Benton & Bowles and its client E. F. Hutton & Co. were sitting around one day try ing to figure out where to go next with the When E. F. Hutton Talks People Listen campaign.

title: Suspect Seized by F.B.I. In 2YearOld Bank Case
description: A Brooklyn man was arrest ed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday in the robbery of a Brooklyn branch of the Chemical Bank two years ago.

title: Credit Markets
description: Reports that the major Com munist powers were exerting pressure on North Vietnam to seek a settlement of the war sent bond prices broadly higher early yesterday in quickened trading activity.

title: Bulk of Technicolor Stock Sold by Company Officer
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) Harry Saltzman, chairman of Technicolor, Inc.'s executive committee, has sold the bulk of his Technicolor stock for $7.6 million to an undisclosed buyer, the company reported yester day. Before the sale, Mr. Saltz man was the company's largest stockholder.

title: N.H.L. and N.B.C Sign $7Million Pact
description: The National Hockey League, which has threatened legal ac tion against its players who jump to a rival league, yester day shocked the Columbia Broadcasting System by jump ing to the National Broadcast ing Company.

title: BIG BOARD VOTES TO EXPEL STARK
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to expel Robert W. Stark Jr., a member, and Robert W. Stark Jr., Inc., a member firm. The expulsion becomes effective at the open ing of business on July 17.

title: SHOWDOWN NEAR Al QUANGTRI CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 7  The South Vietnamese task force pushing north sought yesterday to clear enemy resistance for the final assault to retake Quang tri city. To the south, the North Vietnamese countered by raining their heaviest shell ing attack to date on the ner vous city of Hue.

title: U. S. Voices Its Concern
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reu ters)The State. Department said today the United States was concerned over Cuba's continuing military ties with the Soviet Union.

title: SILVER PRICES UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The demand for silver fu tures continuued strong yes terday and prices rose sharply in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Now that the 1972 baseball Season is over and the World Series in jeopardy, people are saying that all the trouble could have been avoided by taking a firmer hand with Charley Finley in the first place. It is all very well to say this now in October, but we didn't have the advantage of hindsight back there in July when it all started. When Finley announced during the AllStar break that he would no longer subject his Oakland Athletics to the drudgery of daily competition, there was plenty of senti ment supporting him. After all, the Athletics had the best wonandlost record in base ball, and they had achieved it with a mini mum of help from Vida Blue. Finley said they had already proved their superiority, and making them go through the charade of playing out the season against those humptydumpties in the American League West would be like demanding that a Bobby Fischer demean himself and take part in the United States zonal matches with inferior chess players.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The First Boston Corporation, as manager of an underwriting group, announced yesterday the public offering of 462,300 shares of the Chubb Corpora tion common stock at $50 a share. All shares are being sold for the accounts of certain stockholders.

title: TV: Public Access Fete
description: The Public Access Cele bration began yesterday at noon on cable television. It will continue today and Sat urday, running each day from noon to around midnight. As a retrospective of videotape programing that has ap peared or cable channels C and D during the first year of the first public access experiment in operation any where, the celebration is not entirely a celebration, even to many active participants.

title: But elements of the left now recognize that the idea is to get elected.
description: For Democrats of the left fringe, like myself, winning (via George Mc Govern) would be a profoundly un nerving experience. Suddenly we have lost our targets. Hubert Humphrey and Edmund Muskie are gone. Law rence O'Brien will shortly be leaving. Numerous politicians of the old days are retiring. Backlashes like the Cal ifornia challenge are continuing, but the McGovern movement is inexorably taking over the Democratic party.

title: Hanoi Reports U.S. Raids
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 6 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese Foreign Min istry said today that American planes attacked inhabited areas of a dozen provinces yesterday, from the southernmost part of the country almost to the Chinese border.

title: You'll have to do a lot of work on the peacethrough strength types.
description: WASHINGTON What does George McGovernif nominatedhave to say to keep the support of those Demo crats who now view themselves as antiMcGovern? This is an acute ques tion now that Senator McGovern, by his statements regarding his own pos sible defection, has legitimized the idea of Democratic voters taking their business elsewhere.

title: Personalities: Odds Favor Nicklaus, 9 to 4
description: Six United States golfers, including Tommy Aaron, withdrew from the British Open championship, sched uled to start at Muirfield, Scotland, Wednesday. These late scratches were supposed to compete with 500 other golfers today and tomorrow for the 90 spots available to nonexempt players. The others who withdrew are Jim Albus, Dean Beman, Ray Floyd, Terry Small and De Witt Weaver. Bruce Cramp ton of Australia also with drew  William Hill, one of London's leading book makers, made Jack Nicklaus a 9to4 favorite to win the British Open. Hill is also offer ing odds of 10 to 1 that Nicklaus will complete pro fessional golf's grand slam by winning the British Open and then the United States Pro fessional Golfers Association title next month. Nicklaus has won the first two tour neys in the grand slam  the Masters and United States Open.

title: Lindsay Is Denounced
description: DETROIT, July 6 (AP)Her bert Hill, national labor director of the N.A.A.C.P. accused Mayor Lindsay of New York today of perpetuating a racist pattern in the city's construction in dustry.

title: MAUDLING, 3 CITED IN BANKRUPTCY CASE
description: LONDON, July 6The Brit ish Government opened a pre liminary inquiry today into rare charges of financial corrup tion involving four public fig ures.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, July 6 (AP)The Nissan Motor Company said today it planned to install a Wankel rotaryengine production line at its Yokohama plant by the fall of 1973.

title: WITNESS RECANTS IN HARLEM 4 CASE
description: The chief prosecution witness in the Harlem Four casethe young man who identified the defendants, once his friends, as participants in the 1964 murder of a Harlem shopkeeperhas given the defense lawyers a 38 page affidavit saying that his testimony was a lie and that the boys are innocent.

title: WESTERN AIR PLANS 2TO1 STOCK SPLIT
description: Directors of Western Air Lines, Inc., proposed yesterday a 2 for 1 stock split, without change in the par value, that would be implemented only if the merger of the company into American Airlines, Inc., proposed last year, should not be consummated.

title: Mets to Play in Washington
description: The Mets will play an ex hibition game against the Bos ton Red Sox in Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Stadium on Monday, Aug. 14, formerly an open date. This game, spon sored by the Shriners, is the second scheduled for the park abandoned by the Washington Senators at the end of last sea son.

title: Stock Prices Rise On Vietnam Report
description: Stock prices advanced sharp ly yesterday as hopes for peace in Vietnam swept through Wall Street. The DowJones indus trial average, ahead by nearly 18 points at 11 A.M., wound up with a gain of 8.66 at 942.13.

title: Militants Stir Change in Acadians of New Brunswick
description: BATHURST, New Bruns wick, June 28The two main highways leading into this rocky little seaport are lined with the usual advertising billboards Danny's Motel, Cabins, Fishing Boats by the Week, The Lions Wel come You.

title: Dance: Giselle Tradition
description: Carla Fracci's performance in Giselle has become New York ballet legend. In the old days, her partner was Erik Bruhn and together they made Giselle into some thing rich and personal. With Mr. Bruhn's retirement at the beginning of the year, Ameri can Ballet Theater had to look around for a replace ment, and as a result on Wed nesday night Paolo Bortoluzzi made his debut with the com pany at the New York State Theater, dancing Albrecht to Miss Fracci's Giselle.

title: U.S. TRUST'S NET UP 9.6% IN FIRST HALF
description: The United States Trust Company of New York yester day reported net operating earnings for the first half of $3.8million, or $1.79 a share, up 9.6 per cent from the $3.4 million, or $1.63 a share earned in the like 1971 period.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: In her left band holding the racket pros like Charles Pasarell use, the Head Master.

title: Jazzmen Sound Off on State and Status of Their Art
description: How much newer can you be than Stravinsky or Duke or Bud Powell Charles Min gus, the bassist and com poser, replied last week when asked about the new direc tion of jazz in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: AliPatterson Is Set for Garden Aug. 28
description: Acting as if he had just fin ished a dual course with Amy Vanderbilt and Dale Carnegie, Muhammad Ali signed yester day for a 12round fight with Floyd Patterson at Madison Square Garden, Aug. 28.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Senator George McGovern interrupted today his prepara tions for the Democratic National Convention to pay a second courtesy call on his hospitalized Presidential rival, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Port Notes
description: Twenty years ago today the liner United States steamed into Le Havre, a broom lashed to her tower ing mast, to proclaim that she had established a new transAtlantic speed record on her maiden voyage. Yes terday Bill Kaiser, her chief engineer on that memorable voyage, now in retirement, chewed on a big cigar, spat and said disgustedly: Some anniver sary; any day now they're going to put her in moth balls, and what's even worse, they're going to give her some plastic surgery before they do. They sure know how to hurt an old lady.

title: Athenagoras I Is Dead at 86 Patriarch of Eastern Orthodox
description: ISTANBUL, July 6Athena goras I, the Ecumenical Patri arch and leader of the world's 126 million Eastern Orthodox Christians, died early today, the patriarchate announced. He was 86 years old.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The stock market displayed an extreme sensitivity to hints of progress in the Vietnam peace negotiations yesterday with an extraordinary upward surge in response to an uncon firmed rumor from London. United Press International reported prior to the market open ing in New York that China and Russia had independently advised North Vietnam to settle with the United States without much further delay.

title: BLACK NIXON AIDES REPLY TO N.A.A.C.P.
description: DETROIT, July 6  Black officials of the Nixon Adminis tration defended the Administra tion today against attacks by leaders of the National Asso ciation for the Advancement Colored People.

title: Los Angeles Times Editor Will Join Washington Star
description: David Kraslow will leave his post as chief of the Washing ton Bureau of The Los Angeles Times to join The Washington Star on July 31 as an assistant managing editor.

title: Business Briefs
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., July 6 (AP)Six officials of the United Aircraft Corporation were being sent to Peking today to take part in negotiations on the sale of 10 Boeing 707 jets to China, company officials said.

title: Electronic Data Contract
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation of Dallas an nounced yesterday that it has entered into an agreement with Walston & Co., Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, to perform data proc essing. The contract is for 10 years.

title: Bridge: Despite Rule, Bets Ara Made Sometimes Disastrous Ones
description: Laws against betting are Just as difficult to enforce in the world of bridge as they are in other areas. The Amer ican Contract Bridge League firmly prohibits betting on the results of its tournaments, and posts notices to that ef fect, but policing is impos sibleespecially if the gam bling takes place away from the scene of the tournament.

title: Court Strikes Down Fiedler Conviction
description: The 1970 conviction of Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the author and literary critic, and his wife on charges of allowing their children and others to smoke marijuana in their home in Buf falo was struck down yester day by the New York Court of Appeals.

title: Anne Homer Fryer, Violinist, Wed
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., July 6Miss Anne Homer Fryer, a granddaughter of the late Louise Homer, the con tralto, and her husband, the late Sidney Homer, the com poser, was married here this afternoon to Nigel Edward Athelstan Eddis, son of Mrs. Michel Upton Eddis of Lon don and Toronto, and the late Mr. Eddis. The Rev. Ernest Stires, an uncle of the bride by marriage, performed the Episcopal ceremony on the lawn of the home near Ticonderoga rented by Mrs. Dougas Fryer of New York, mother of the bride.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 6The Nixon Administration's new top lobbyist, William E. Timmons, denounced the record of the Democraticcontrolled Congress today as miserable, irresponsible, appalling and cynical.

title: 'Jamilya,' Lush Import
description: Yesterday a beautiful movie called "Jamilya" arrived from Russiavery obviously with love. In its simplicity, sensitivity and lyrical flow, this deeply-felt Soviet-sponsored drama and its exotic locale are refreshingly remote from the sex, strife and gore cluttering Fun City screens.The very setting, a tribal village in Kirghizia, dwarfed by towering peaks on the Soviet-Chinese border, is a fascinating novelty. So are the expressive Oriental faces of the cast, speaking their native Turkic (with good English titles).The story, by Chinghiz Aitmatov, a Turkic author, unfolds the wonder and anguish of a growing boy as he watches the furtive love of two adults he adores. These are his vivacious, lonely sister-in-law, Jamilya, whose indifferent husband is away at war, and a convalescent soldier helping the villagers feed grain to a railroad line. World War II, in a sharp pinpoint of irony, remains far, far away.But the exquisite direction of Irina Poplavskaya pulls in the human drama closely and touchingly, wisely holding to the viewpoint of the impressionable boy. And since the lad, played with earthy conviction by Nasredin Dubashev, is also a budding painter, Miss Poplavskaya and her superb photographer have a visual field day.The craggy panoramas, the foaming wheat fields and the personal drama are effectively intercut with primitive color sketches, as the general footage subtly shifts from sepia to black and white. It is a trickmost pictures would gum it upthat works beautifully. So, for that matter, do the performances of Natalya Arinbasarova and Suimenkul Chkmorov, as the lovers, and a striking musical score with folk-tune flavoring. "Jamilya" is a joy.

title: PUREX WILL SETTLE GENERAL FOODS SUIT
description: The General Foods Corpora tion and the Purex Corporation, Ltd., have agreed in principle to an outofcourt settlement of a suit filed by Purex against General Foods and the SOS Company, Inc., in the spring of 1970.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 6De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird challenged Senator George Mc Govern's proposed $30billion cut in defense spending today as a threat to America's ef forts to meet its worldwide commitments while negotiating limitations in the arms race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Storefront TV Studio Opened By Teleprompter to Aid Harlem
description: New York got its first store front public access television studio yesterday when the Tele prompter Corporation opened the facility, which it created and will operate as a commu nity service, at 60 West 125th Street in Harlem.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONNobody here wants Ire land to feature at the center of British politics, as it has had a habit of doing for more than a century. Much hope was therefore placed in the uneasy truce established in the Northand now perhaps crumbling. The dream persists that despite violations and bluster, the tragic situation will sim mer down and that sinister figure, the gunman, will move offstage.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pair Were Refugees
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (UPI)The two hijackers slain yesterday came to the United States as political refugees sponsored by the World Council of Churches.

title: Stock Phrases Ruled Out
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 The Securities and Exchange Commission will no longer accept newissue prospectuses that deal with important mat ters in unrevealing stock phrases, the agency's chair man said today.

title: Grant for Power Study
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 6 (AP)The National Science Foundation has announced a $145,000 grant to the Univer sity of Massachusetts for a longrange study of the use of ocean water to generate elec trical power with minimal pol lution.

title: Six Harvard Alumni Head U.S. EightOared Crew for Olympics
description: HANOVER, N. H., July 6 Six Harvard alumni, including two pairs of brothers, were named to the United States eightoared crew for the Olympics today, ending a long and arduous selection process. Harry Parker, the Harvard coach in charge of the Olympic team, made the announcement of the eight plus six backup oarsmen, four of whom will row in the four oaredwithcoxswain event. Two coxswains bring the total members to 16.

title: Tashkent to Simla
description: Pakistan's National Assembly will have an opportunity to help launch a new era of peace and development on the South Asian subcontinent Monday when it meets to ratify the agreement signed in Simla by President Bhutto and India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. Completion of the pact after five days of tense negotiations reflected the determination of two pragmatic political leaders to end 25 years of conflict so that both countries may henceforth devote their resources and energies to the pressing task of advancing the welfare of their people.

title: This Weekend's Prospects for Fishing and Boating
description: AREA A  Sea bass and blackfish are being taken from the bottom of wrecks, barges and artificial reefs in Barnegat Bay off Brielle, N. J. Johnny Bogan reported bluefish plentiful off Barrie gat Ridge with bunkers, and smelts as bait. Dick Myers of Barnegat reported chumming for blues off the Ridge.

title: Brandon de Wilde, 30, Is Killed In Traffic Accident in Colorado
description: LAKEWOOD, Colo. July 6 (AP)Brandon de Wilde, the former child actor, died this evening as a result of injuries suffered earlier in a traffic acci dent in this Denver suburb. He was 30 years old.

title: BEES' NAVIGATION TRACED IN STUDY
description: SEEWIESEN, West Germany Researchers here believe they have found out how bees navi gate the scentladen path that finally brings them to a food source.

title: F.B.I. Actions Defended
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation's handling of the West Coast hijacking Wednes day, which ended with the fatal shooting of the two bandits and a passenger, was defended yesterday by the airline's presi dent, the bureau and many in dustry executives.

title: Figure in Raid on Democrats Is Reported to Have Asked a Friend to Seek White House Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, July 6A friend of E. Howard Hunt Jr. said today that the former White House consultant had asked him to enlist White House aid in helping to find a lawyer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. IN COMPLAINT AGAINST CONE MILLS
description: The Federal Trade Commis sion issued yesterday a pro posed complaint charging the Cone Mills Corporation of Greensboro, N. C., with viola tions of the Flammable Fabrics Act. The commission said that certain fabrics made by the agency had failed to meet re quired fammability standards.

title: Allende's Foes Act to Remove Minister
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 6 The antiMarxist majority that controls Congress has begun ouster proceedings against Chile's Interior Minister, deep ening hostilities with the left wing Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Merger News
description: United Virgina Bankshares, Inc., of Richmond, Va., has agreed to acquire for more than $20million cash the Crompton Richmond Company, Inc., wholly owned factoring sub sidiary of the Crompton Com pany, Inc.

title: Stock Prices Rise On Vietnam Report
description: Stock prices advanced sharp ly yesterday as hopes for peace in Vietnam swept through Wall Street. The DowJones indus trial average, ahead by nearly 18 points at 11 A.M., wound up with a gain of 8.66 at 942.13.

title: 'Butterflies Are Free' Arrives
description: "Butterflies Are Free," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, is Leonard Gershe's Broadway comedy recycled as a movie with the density of Jell-o.Edward Albert, the son of Eddie Albert and Margo, makes his film debut as Don, the young blind man trying to make a life on his own in a San Francisco garret. Eileen Heckart plays his pushy, suburban mother who, when the chips are down, is selfless enough to make any matinee lady proud to identify with her, and Goldie Hawn is the desperately eccentric girl next door who falls in love with him.She quotes Dylan Thomas without knowing it, Charles Dickens when she thinks it's Mark Twain and describes sex with Don as being like the Fourth of July and Christmas combined. Don, who likes to be read to from Time, Newsweek and The Berkeley Barb, is enchanted, as obviously was yesterday's early morning audience at the Music Hall."Butterflies Are Free," the play, ranks with such other glories of the modern American theater as "A Majority of One," "The Impossible Years" and "Never Too Late." The film is not completely without intelligence, but its intelligence is in the service of the kind of sentimentality that shrivels the mind, like something left in water too long.

title: Truman XRays Delayed
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 6 (AP)Lower back Xrays were postponed until at least to morrow for former President Harry S. Truman, a hospital spokesman said today. He said they would be done when Mr. Truman has a series of gastro intestinal Xrays taken. The back Xrays were ordered after Mr. Truman reported a pain in his lower back earlier this week. The hospital says Mr. Truman, 88 years old, remains in satisfactory condition. He was admitted Sunday for a gastrointestinal problem.

title: Business Briefs
description: TORONTO, July 7 (Canadian Press)Average wages in manufacturing have been increasing faster in Canada than in the United States, and Canadian industrial workers are approaching parity, according to a study by Canadian In dustrial Relations and Personnel Development. I.R.P.D. is a publication of C.C.H. Canadian, Ltd., a national reporting authority on tax and business law.

title: Dakotan's Rivals Drawing Battle Plans to Stop Him
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7The three main rivals of Senator George McGovern arrived in this convention city today and with an assist from the Su preme Courtinvested their hopes of stopping the front runner for the Deinocratic Presidential nomination in a series of complicated parlia mentary battles affecting the California and Illinois delega tions.

title: Newport Fans Get Treat In Midnight Jam Session
description: It took more than two hours for the Newport Jazz Festival's second midnight jam session at Radio City Music Hall, held in the small hours of Friday morning, to get itself pulled together. But, shortly after 2 A.M., the enthusiastic crowd of 6,000 that filled the Music Hall heard the kind of rewarding jamsession blowing that rarely occurs anywhere, much less before an audience of 6,000.

title: Humphrey Leads Cheers
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7Sen ator Hubert H. Humphrey led the cheering in his campaign manager's hotel suite when the news of the Supreme Court's decision flashed on the televi sion screen.

title: GOVERNMENT SHIFT ADVANCES IN MANILA
description: MANILA, July 7 (UPI)The Philippine constitutional don vention approved today a change in the form of govern ment here from presidential rule to a parliamentary system.

title: Personalities: Donohue Stalled
description: Mark Donohue, winner of the Indianapolis 500 auto race on May 27, will undergo exploratory surgery on his left knee today to determine whether he suffered cartilage or ligament damage in a crash last Monday while he was putting his PorscheAudi through a test drive. As a re sult, Donohue will miss to day's CanAm race in At lanta.  George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif., will drive an other PorscheAudi at At lanta in Donohue's place. Both Follmer and Donohue drive for the Penske racing organization. The operation is expected to sideline Dono hue for three to six weeks.

title: Pros' Sale Is Approved
description: MEMPHIS, July 7 (UPI) Stockholders of the Memphis Pros, meeting in special ses sion last night, approved the sale of the American Basket ball Association club to Charles O. Finley.

title: Bar to Mark Loans Seen
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 7 (Reuters)  Informed sources said today that the Bundesbank was pressing for a temporary halt to foreign mark loans.

title: WINE:
description: Wine, like the Academie Francaise or the National Foot ball League, is one of the few remaining bastions of male supremacy.

title: Joint Economic Panel Plans Hearings on Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  The Joint Economic Com mittee will hold hearrings July 19, 20 and 21 on tax reform, its chairman, Senator William Proxmire, said today.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS DOWN FOR MONTH; PRICES RISE ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The nation's unemployment rate de clined in June after a long period of essential stability, but there was another strong rise in wholesale prices, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Atlantic Cable Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission approved today a new trans Atlantic communica tions cablethe largest of its type yet builtbetween the United States and France.

title: Miss Goolagong Falls Victim to Backhand Play
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7Mrs. Billie Jean King has won her fourth Wimbledon ti tle. In 50 norveracked minutes on the center court, the bus tling 28yearold from Long Beach, Calif., won from Evonne Goolagong of Australia, 63, 63, and avenged, her semifinal loss here a year ago to the 20yearold daughter of an abo riginal sheepshearer.

title: Mitchell Relaxes in New Office Only 50 Paces From His Old
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  For the first time in months, John N. Mitchell seemed at ease with himself and his surroundings.

title: WALLACE IN MIAMI: BACK INTO FIGHT
description: MIAMI, July 7Gov. George C. Wallace came to town today for the Democratic convention after an emotional homecoming in Alabama, where he said he would insist next week that the party's platform and nominees reflect the positions of his own Presidential campaign.

title: Phillips's Attorney Says Pimp, Not His Client, Murdered Two
description: A pimp who was looking for one of his star prostitutes was offered to the jury yesterday by F. Lee Bailey as the real killer in the double homicide with which his client, Patrol man William R. Phillips, is charged.

title: G.M. Seeks $90 Increase on 73 Cars
description: DETROIT, July 7The Gen eral Motors Corporation asked the Price Commission today to allow a $90, or 2 per cent, price increase on 1973 cars and trucks. This is half the increase sought by other car makers.

title: Allegheny Sued by Nader
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Asking $10 in damages, Ralph Nader filed suit in Federal Court today for allegedly being illegally bumped from an Allegheny Airlines flight from Washington to Hartford. The suit was filed by Aviation Con sumer Action Project, which Mr. Nader heads, and the Con necticut Citizen Action Group, which asked $100,000 in dam ages in addition to Nader's $10.

title: Plan to Put City U. Applicants In Private Colleges Is Proposed
description: An advisory council to the State Board of Regents pro posed yesterday a limited program to enable about 500 lowincome candidates for the City University to enroll in pri vate colleges here instead.

title: The Day Grand Aroma Filled Washington Sq.
description: The loveliest smell in the word drifted over Washing ton Square yesterday after noon. The sunners around the fountain looked up, their dogs sniffed the air.

title: FLORENCE GLUCK
description: Florence Gluck, who taught history for many years at Girls High School in Brooklyn until her retirement in 1958, died on Saturday. She was 78 years old. Miss Gluck was a graduate of Hunter College and earned a master's degree at Columbia University.

title: Michael W. Yacenda Dies; Fedders General Manager
description: YARDLEY, Pa., July 7Mi chael W. Yacenda, general man ager of the Fedders Corpora tion, appliance manufacturers of Trenton for the last 25 years, died today at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Phila delphia. He was 55 years old and lived in this community.

title: TENNECO WIDENS TRACTOR VENTURE
description: LONDON, July 7The David Brown Corporation, a major British engineering group, has sold its tractor manufacturing interests to Tenneco, Inc., of Houston for more than $33 million.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: After a week's delay, trading resumed in International Pro teins on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The ex change had stopped trading pending a restatement of the company's earnings.

title: SWEETAN SEIZED SELLING SECRETS
description: Karl Sweetan, a quarterback who announced his retirement from pro football, two weeks ago was seized yesterday when he attempted to sell a Los An geles Rams playbook to the New Orleans Saints. He has played for both teams.

title: Police in Brooklyn Kill Two Suspects In Separate Cases
description: Two men were shot and killed by the police yesterday in separate incidents in Brook lyn.

title: Pound Shows Gains
description: LONDON, July 7 (AP)The United States dollar continued weak in most European ex changes today but the Brit ish pound showed surprising strength after a threeweek slide.

title: Interesting Directions
description: The Newport Festival's In teresting Directions program  potentially one of the weeks most interesting  turned out to be a disap pointment. The Friday after noon program at Carnegie Hall included Weather Re port, the Roy Haynes Quin tet, Tony Williams's Lifetime and the Archie Shepp Quin tet. Ruth Brown, originally scheduled for the bill, had to cancel because of illness.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S.Soviet Research Accord Is Signed
description: MOSCOW, July 7Joint re search by United States and Soviet scientists moved a step closer to realization today as the two Governments signed an agreement outlining the first areas of cooperation in science and technology.

title: 3 ARE EXONERATED OF FRAUD ON CITY
description: Indictments charging three borrowers with fraud against the Municipal Loan Program were dismissed yesterday by Acting Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis.

title: Philippine Troops Are Reported In Battle With Moslem Raiders
description: MANILA, July 7 (UPI)More than 70 persons have been killed in the southern Philippines in the last three days by what is believed to be a band of Mos lem raiders.

title: RYUN QUALIFIES FOR 1,600 FINAL
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 7Jim Ryun survived his second test in the 1,500meter run tonight, and Tom Hill, Fred Newhouse and Randy Matson set the stage for a series of worldrecord performances.

title: I.T.T. Seizure Gains in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7 (UPI)The Senate today ap proved expropriation of the Chiliean Telephone Company, which is 70 per cent owned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Ap proval by the Chamber of Deputies is expected later this month. President Salvador Al lende Gossens proposed the ex propriation in reprisal for an alleged I.T.T. plot to prevent his inauguration in Novemeber, 1970.

title: Killebrew Clouts 527th
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 7  Frank. Quilici's debut as manager of the Minnesota Twins was a roaring success on two counts tonight19,514 customers, the biggest crowd of the season here, went through the turnstiles and Har mon Killebrew beat the New York Yankees with a tworun homer in the seventh inning.

title: ED ZIMMERMAN, 39, ACTOR ON TV SERIAL
description: Ed Zimmermann, who played the role of Dr. Joe Werner in The Guiding Light on the Co lumbia Broadcasting System television network, died of a heart attack. Thursday in the York (Maine) Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived at 15 West 55th Street.

title: Nude Ballet Poster Banned
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (UPI)  A judge has stopped all sales and display of a pos ter that shows two apparently nude and entwined ballet stars. Superior Court Judge Ira, A. Brown Jr. issued the temporary restraining order yesterday. The poster is of San Francisco Ballet dancers Sara Maule and Geoffrey Thomas.

title: Gold Down in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, July 7 (Reuters) The price of gold dropped 13.875 Hong Kong dollars to day following Hong Kong's decision to break away from sterling and tie the local cur rency to the United States dollar.

title: I.R.A. Frees Officers
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 7 (Reuters)Two British Army captains who were seized by the I.R.A. early this morning were released to night, apparently unharmed.

title: DECISION IS 6 TO 3
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The United States Supreme Court, overruling lower court action tonight, returned the controversial California and Illinois credentials cases to the Democratic National Conven tion for its decision next week.

title: Taylor Leads Good Vibes At Folk Festival Benefit
description: It's getting to the point where the only way to hear certain pop/rock/folk super stars is a benefit show. Well, I suppose that's o.k., if the cause is just and the vibes are good.

title: EXPORTING OF OIL RESUMED BY IRAQ
description: BEIRUT, July 7Export of nationalized Iraqi crude oil has been resumed after an inter ruption of more than a month.

title: Market Place:Wankel Sparks CurtissWright
description: If there is one thing better than pie in the sky, it is the promise of a new engine un der the hood of the ubiqui tous automobile.

title: 2 Hijackings in 2 Days Too Much for One Man
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7When Franz Lingnau got on that airplane at Burbank yesterday he was still a bit shaky from his experience as a passenger on the Pa cific Southwest Airlines jet liner involved in a hijacking Wednesday in which three men were fatally shot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean Leader Promises StepbyStep Approach to North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 7 President Park Chung Hee said today that the Government would pursue a stepbystep approach in solving problems with North Korea through dia logue.

title: Seaman Schepps, 91, Dies; Retired Jewelry Designer
description: Seaman Schepps, a retired jewelry designer, died yester day at his home, 118 East 60th Street. He was 91 years old.

title: 100 Arrested in Karachi
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 7 The police fired warning shots and team gas and arrested more than 100 persons after clashes with demonstrators demanding that Urdu, along with Sindhi, he made an official language of Sind Province of which Karachi is the capital.

title: Reporter Testifies on Assault At Newark Meeting Last Year
description: NEWARK, July 7Fox But terfield a reporter for The New York Times, testified today that he was gasping for air and thought he was about to pass out when he was choked, punched in the stomach and robbed of his notes and a wallet containing about $40 while he was covering a Board of Edu cation meeting here 15 months ago.

title: 3 WOMEN CARD 70'S TO LEAD IN TOURNEY
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP)  Sandra Palmer and Sandra Haynie, who live about eight blocks apart in Fort Worth, and Betsy Cullen, playing out of a Texas country club, tied for the firstround lead today in the $32,000 George Wash ington Classic.

title: Excerpts From Court Opinions on Rift
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court opinions issued tonight in the Demo cratic credentials dispute:

title: Art: Escher Prints Shown at La Boetie
description: M. C. Escher died last spring in the Netherlands. The Dutchman had been an artist for most of his 73 years, but his visionary wood cuts and lithographs received little recognition in the art world.

title: U.S. MAY SUE GROUP ON IMPEACHMENT AD
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Office of Federal Elec tions in the General Accounting Office asked the Attorney Gen eral today to sue the National Committee for Impeachment for alleged violation of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, July 7Western Eu rope is going through monetary and political turbulence that seems bound to weaken her thrust toward unity.

title: Rigney's Epilogue
description: Bill Rigney played eight seasons for the New York Giants and has been a big league manager for 17 with the Giants, California Angels and Twins. He was earning $60,000; Quilioi (pronounced Quillis see) reportedly will receive a $10,000 raise over his coaching salary of $15,000.

title: Richard C. Doane, 74, Is Dead; Led International Paper in '60s
description: WAITSFIELD, Vt., July 7  Richard C. Doane, former chair man, president and chief execu tive officer of the International Paper Company, died yesterday in the Central Vermont Medi cal Center in Berlin, He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: The Talk of Welland
description: WELLAND, OntarioIt's a shame to say it, said Dan Kehoe, shaking his head, but if it's historic, Welland will tear it down.

title: Thuy Meets With Chou
description: TOKYO, July 7 (AP)Pre mier Chou Enlai of China had a fraternal and cordial talk in Peking today with Mr. Thuy, the North Vietnamese delegate to the Paris talks, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, re ported.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Worthington Industries, Inc., filed an offering with the Se curities and Exchange Commis sion yesterday for the sale of 300,000 common shares of the company's stock. Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co., Inc., and the First Columbus Corporation are managers of the underwriting group.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, July 7 (UPI)Superior Court Judge Horace T. Cahill yesterday dissolved a dayold injunction that would have barred the sale of the Boston Celtics to New Jersey businessman Robert Schmertz. The injunction, ob tained by the Boston Celtics Basketball Club, Inc., temporarily blocked Schmertz from obtaining a lease for the Boston Garden.

title: Patriarch's Death Is Mourned by Greeks in West
description: HOUSTON, July 7The gala 50th anniversary Congress of the Greek Orthodox Archdio cese of North and South Amer ica ended in sadness this morn ing as hundreds of delegates mourned the death of their spir itual leader, Ecumenical Patri arch Athenagoras.

title: Nixon Meets Debra
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7 (UPI)President Nixon met today with Defense Minister Michel Debre of France, Who is in the Unit States for a six day visit at the invitation of Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird.

title: BUILDERS CONDEMN ATTACK BY WALSH
description: The chairman of the Mayor's Building and Construction Ad visory Council contended yes terday that an attack by the Lindsay administration's top housing official on members of the construction industry as spineless and morally bank rupt had sabotaged efforts to get the industry to combat cor ruption.

title: JOHN I. MANGE, 2D,46, OF HUMBLE OIL DEAD
description: HOUSTON, July 7John I. Mange 2d, an executive of the Humble Oil and Refining Com pany, died yesterday at Meth odist Hospital. He was 46 Years old.

title: OWNERS INCREASE POWERS OF KUHN
description: CHICAGO, July 7 (UPI) Major League baseball owners voted today to increase the commissioner's powers in dis putes and to streamline their Player Relations Committee.

title: A.W.O.L. Soldier Gives Up in Hijacking
REVISED CITY PACT PUSHED BY P.B.A.
description: After 18 months without a labor contract, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association acted yesterday to get rankandfile ratification of a 30month city contract offer slightly more attractive than one rejected by the city's policemen six weeks ago.

title: SHOP TALK
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Antiques Supermarket may not be the most unusual name in the world but the business enterprise that it stands for at 866 High Ridge Road can claim to be fairly unusual on at least a couple of other counts.

title: Vermont Editor Resigns
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 7 (AP)Walter R. Hard Jr., 57 years old the editor of Ver mont Life, announced his resig nation today. He said that he had been on the state  operated quarterly long enough. He became editor in 1950.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN GRAIN TRADING
Mellon Bank to Lift Prime Rate to 5% From 5 Monday
description: The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pittsburgh, which gears its prime business lending rate directly to inter est rates in the open market, said yesterday that this basic loan charge would be 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday, up from 5 per cent this week.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) President Nixon, preparing for his reelection campaign, has recruited William Codus, assistant chief of the State Department Protocol Office, to handle political travels of Mrs. Nixon and their two daughters.

title: Kroger Results Off in Six Months
Friendliness Marks Rogers Discussions in Budapest
description: BUDAPEST, July 7After more than two decades of tense, cool or at best distant relations between Hungary and the United States, signs of warmth appeared today in cordial onehour meeting be tween Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Janos Kadar, the Communist party chief since the suppression of the 1956 uprising.

title: Chris Evert Departs Before Final Round
description: LONDON, July 7 (UPI) Chris Evert, the 17yearold tennis star from Fort Lau derdale, Fla., who reached the Wimbledon semifinals in her first appearance here, flew home today.

title: Court Supports Forest Hills Project, 61
description: The State Court of Appeals, in a 6to1 decision, refused yesterday to halt work on the controversial lowincome hous ing project in the Forest Hills section of Queens.

title: EDUCATION BOARD UPHELD ON FUNDS
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday dismissed a suit brought by a local school board that, had challenged the Board of Education's formulas for al locating funds to the city's 31 decentralized school districts.

title: The Other Candidate
description: As the Democrats gather in Miami Beach for the open ing of their national convention next week they are naturally preoccupied with the question of whether Senator George McGovern will get the necessary votes to win the Presidential nomination. As usual, little thought is being given to the choice of a VicePresidential candidate except insofar as it might affect the conven tion's decision on the Presidency.

title: Plan Mutual Delivery
description: BERLIN, July 7 (AP)The Soviet Union and East Germany signed an additional barter trade agreement today, the offi cial East German news agency, ADN, announced.

title: Abrams to Seek Chairmanship Of State Convention Delegation
description: Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams set the stage for another struggle between regular organization Democrats and supporters of Senator George McGovern by announc ing yesterday that he would seek the chairmanship of the state's delegation to the Demo cratic National Convention at a caucus in Miami Beach to morrow.

title: Roundup: A Royal 12 Subdues Indians by 63
description: Although scores of sages have decreed that pitching is 90 per cent of a winning baseball combination, hitting does help a little.

title: Route 7 Project in Connecticut Enjoined in Environmental Suit
description: HARTFORD, July 7A Fed eral District judge issued an injunction today against further construction of a $200million superhighway running north through Fairfield County be cause, he said, it violated Fed eral environmental laws.

title: TOP AWARD TAKEN BY COCKER SPANIEL
description: DURHAM, Conn., July 17 It took Nelson Groh of Poland, Ohio, 25 minutes today to se lect a winner At the Kenilworth Kennel Club of Connecticut show, which drew 1,177 dogs to the fairgrounds. His choice was Mrs. Peggy Westphal's silverbuff, Ch. Sagamore Toc coa, from Bedford, N. Y., the topwinning cocker spaniel in America and one of the lead ing performers of all breedi on the show circuit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 7  The new prophet, seer and revelator of the world's 3,090,953 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints drives to his office at 8 A.M. daily in a Buick, wears natty but not gaudy dark blue suits and lives in a white brick New England style home on Salt Lake City's tree lined Circle Way. If those who meet Harold Bingham Lee for the first time mistake him for a businessman, the error is understandable. The newly chosen 11th President of the Mormon Church is known among his coreli gionists as something of an organizing genius. To one member of the Council of Twelve Apostles who af firmed him today as the church's leader, it is as if the Lord called him at the precise right time. We are face to face with problems of streamlining and growth, and Harold B. Lee is the right vehicle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Eases Rule Governing Communion for NonCatholics
description: ROME, July 7The Vatican today eased the conditions un der which Protestants and members of the Eastern Ortho dox faith may receive com munion from Roman Catholic priests.

title: Ghana Burial Set As Guinea Returns Body of Nkrumah
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 7 (Agence FrancePresse)The body of Kwame Nkrumah was flown back here today in a special Guinean Air Force plane.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Davidoff Quits City Hall Post

title: I'M FOR MAMA, 21, SCORES BY A NOSE
description: The finish of the main race at Aqueduct yesterday was dangerously close, although it did not appear so to most of the 23,489 customers on hand. They thought Caesar Kimmel's I'm for Mama had the clear edge over the Buckland Farm's Never Hula at the end of the sixfurlong sprint for older fil lies.

title: Chemical Antagonist to Heroin Sought in $2Million Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The White House announced today a major effort to produce an effective and safe chemical an tagonist to heroin that would help prevent young experiment ers from becoming addicis.

title: Jury Deliberations Begin in Pfingst Case
description: Jury deliberations began yes terday in Federal Court in Brooklyn in the trial of State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst, who is accused of having bought his 1968 nomina tion to the Suffolk County bench.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Federal Government will fly 120 Washingtonbased dip lomats to Miami Beach Sunday so they can observe the Demo cratic National Convention. The same number will also attend the Republican convention in August.

title: Fansteel Bars Gould Bid
description: Fansteel, Inc., said yesterday that it had decided not to rec ommend the proposed, merger offer of Gould, Inc to Fansteel shareholders because Gould had refused to improve the terms of the proposed merger. Fan steel said that no further dis cussions were expected. Subse quently, Gould also said that it contemplated no further merger discussions between the parties.

title: PRINCESS PIGNATELLI OF COAST SOCIETY, 84
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7 (UPI) Princess Conchita Sepulveda Pignatelli, longtime society col umnist and member, of one of the city's first families, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. She was 84 years old.

title: Bennett and Nady Lead Finn Class Sailing Trials
description: MARION, Mass., July 7With only 1.7 points separating Ed Bennett, today's winner, and Louis Nady in the Finn Olympic sailing trials, the stage is set for a dramatic showdown to morrow between the two Cali fornians. Unless they both suffer major mishaps, the one who finishes ahead of the other should win a trip to Kiel. Germany, with the United States Olympic team.

title: Third National Buys Stock
description: The Third National Corpora tion of Nashville said yester day it had recently bought 350,900 shares of its own out standing stock for a total cost of $14.1million. This reduces the number of shares outstand ling to 1,649,100.

title: A NEW POLL FAVORS PRESIDENT IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, July 7 If the Presidential election were held today, President Nixon would carry New Jersey easily over either Senator George McGov ern of South. Dakota or Sen ator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, according, to a poll released by a new private poll ing organization.

title: Big Bet Ring Raided In a 3County Area
description: A $110millionayear gam bling and betting syndicate operating throughout Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County was reportedly broken up last night with the arrest of 21 per sons, according to a spokes man for the Nassau County District Attorney, William Cahn.

title: Summer Upbeat
description: Two redcoated, goldsashed grand marshals, one of them holding a patchworkcolored umbrella, came sway ing across the Lincoln Center plaza the other day, step ping in a wide strut at the head of a small jazz band. Behind them in a syncopated shuffle moved a crowd of eager listeners, picking up the blaring beat.

title: E.E.C. Revives Tariffs
description: BRUSSELS, July 7 (AP)As of Monday, the European Com mon Market Commission will reintroduce 20 per cent cus toms duties on imports of beef and 16 per cent on live cattle from nonmember countries.

title: Power Off in Florida Capitol
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 7 (UPI)The Florida Capitol was plunged into darkness today by a halfhour power loss. The electricity went off while At torney General Robert L. Shevin was holding a news con ference in the subbasement's press room. He was outlining plans for reinstating capital punishment in the electric chair.

title: SOFT CONTACT LENS PRAISED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A Bausch & Lomb executive told a Senate subcommittee to day that his company's soft eye contact lens was safe and pro vided good vision for most wearers.

title: Coeducational Prison Is a Test in Rehabilitation
description: FORT WORTH, July 7 Two men and a young woman in a purple miniskirt engaged in animated conversation around a yellow table.

title: LOSONCZY, 18, WINS U.S. FENCING TITLE
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 7  Tom Losonczy, an 18yearold Columbia University sopho more, captured all 14 of his bouts today at Bentley College to win the national saber title for men under 19 years of age. It was his second title in the last three years.

title: JAN MATULKA DIES; PAINTER, TEACHER
description: Jan Matulka, who as painter and teacher (at the Art Stu dents League) championed Eu ropean modernism in the 1920's and 30s, died here on June 25, He was 81 years old and lived at 7035 Broadway, Jack son Heights, Queens.

title: Sutton Allows 3 Hits
description: The New York Mets are not having much fun in Fun City these nights.

title: Lesson in Unity Is Taught To Both Sides in Chile Vote
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7 Returns from two elections were being cited here today as evidence that neither the leftist parties of the coalition Govern ment of President Salvador Allende nor the parties of the Opposition can divide their forces and win.

title: Rumanian Envoy in Israel Said to Defect to Denmark
description: TEL AVIV, July 7Constantin Dumitrachescu, a Rumania diplomat, was reported to have defected after completing a tour of duty as first secretary in the embassy here.

title: Young People Heading For Poconos Fesitval
description: Thousands of young people left for the Pocono Interna tional Raceway in eastern Pennsylvania yesterday eve ning to attend a daylong rock music festival that is expected to thaw 100,000 fans today.

title: Rail TonMileage Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Association of American Rail roads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last Week totaled an estimated 14.5 billion tonmiles, 0.4 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 476,738, down 3.2 per cent from last year, again reflecting the effects of tropical storm Agnes. The American Trucking Associa tions, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 6.1 per cent above last year.

title: RICHEY STOPS LAVER AT BRETTON WOODS
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 7 (UPI)Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla., fought back from the brink of defeat today to upset topseeded Rod Laver of Australia, 67, 63, 75, and move into the semifinals of the $25,000 Bretton Woods tennis tournament.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Cabot Corporation advised customers yesterday in Boston that its Distrigas Corporation now expected to re ceive substantially reduced shipments of liquefied nat ural gas over the next nine months because of a delayed startup of a liquefaction plant in Algeria.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DALLAS, July 7 (AP)Duane Thomas, running back, was told today he could continue to play football for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Wrinkled Goshen Is Still a Mecca for Harness Fans
