description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7On race days here, stablehands still lead the horses down Main Street to the only sports facility in America registered as a national historic land mark.

title: Bridge: Trump Leads by the Defense Are Sometimes Good Tactics
description: If there is reason to think that the declarer has no sub stantial assets outside the trump suit, the defenders should usually lead trumps at every opportunity. A good example of the need for this defensive strategy is the dia gramed deal, reported by Richard Egan from a recent team contest at the Barclay Bridge Club, 7535 31st Ave nue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: 2 BANK CONCERNS IN MIXED RESULTS
description: Two of the nation's largest banking concerns reported yes terday sharply contrasting per formances in earnings during the first half of the year.

title: 13 Set for the Brooklyn
description: The 84th running of the Brooklyn Handicap has at tracted a field of 13, making the gross value of today's fea ture at Aqueduct $118,600. To the winner of the eventto be raced at 13/16 mileswill go $71,160.

title: Inspectors Report Increase In Cattle Hormone Residues
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI)  The rate at which Federal meat inspectors are finding ille gal residues of a cancercausing hormone in cattle livers is still increasing, the Agriculture De partment said today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: AACHEN, West Germany, July 7 (UPI)West Germany won the Prix of the Nations team show jumping event today at the Aachen international horse show with an aggregate 20 faults to Argentina's 36. Third place in the event went to the American, team with 44 faults.

title: Court of Appeals Upholds State's '70 Abortion Law
description: The Court of Appeals yester day upheld New York's liberal ized abortion law, rejecting by a 5to2 vote an argument that fetuses are legal entities with constitutional rights.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7  Richard james Murphy, the manager of the Democratic National Convention, which some have described as un manageable, put down the telephone, looked across a wellordered desk and said:

title: WILLIAM HERRIN JR.
description: William Kennedy Herrin Jr., a forniee operator of cotton plantations in Mississippi, who later was associated with the First Investors Corporation here, died Thursday in Sparkill, N.Y., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Love Will Be the Parent
description: The institution of marriage makes a parasite of woman, an absolute dependent. It incapacitates her for life's struggle, annihilates her social consciousness, paralyzes her imagination, and then imposes its gracious protection, which is in reality a snare, a travesty on human cheracter.

title: Rate of Jewish Emigration From Soviet Is Double That of '71
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Jew ish emigration from the Soviet Union in the first half of this year has already exceeded the total of about 14,000 emigrants during all of 1971, according to data compiled by the State De partment from refugee organi zations.

title: Reorganization Petitions Filed by Sheffield Watch
description: The Sheffield Watch Corpora tion said yesterday that it had field petitions for reorganiza tion under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. The Chapter XI petition is a voluntary one by a debtor who seeks to continue operating while making an arrangement for repayment to creditors.

title: Dissident Leader in Soviet Is Warned by Secret Police
description: MOSCOW, July 7 (AP)  Velery Chalidze, a physicist and founder of the unofficial Committee for Human Rights in the Soviet Union, was sum moned to secret police head quarters yesterday and warned about his activities, informants reported today.

title: Andreotti Cabinet Gains
description: ROME, July 7The new Cab inet of Premier Giulio Andreotti won a confidence vote today, 329 to 288, in the Chamber of Deputies. The Senate is sched uled to vote next week on the Andreotti Cabinet, 34th since the fall of Fascism. Endorse ment by the upper house, though by a slimmer margin, is expected.

title: Jets for Peking
description: An export permit by the Administration is not the same thing as a firm order from the Chinese People's Republic for ten Boeing 707 jets. Nevertheless, a major advance has been made by the White House decision. The principle has now been established that the Chinese are entitled to buy products of advanced American tech nology even whenas in the case of the 707'sthese products could have ancillary military significance. The implications of this principle for American exports to China of other highly specialized productsfor example, computersare selfevident.

title: Miss Ferrell Gains in 3 Events. At U.S. Olympic Final Trials
description: FREDERICK, Md., July 7  Olympian Barbara Ferrell, a 24yearold Los Angeles kinder garten teacher, took some giant steps toward her second Olym pics tonight, winning her heats in the 100meter and 200meter dashes and finishing fifth in the long jump during the qual ifying round of the United States Olympic trials for women.

title: STOCKS DECLINE AS VOLUME DROPS
description: The dove of peace flew away from Wall Street yesterday and with it went the latest rally in the stock market.

title: GRAND JURY CLEARS 2D FIRE UNION AIDE
description: David McCormack, a fire union official, Was cleared by a grand jury in Manhattan of any wrongdoing in connection with an alleged assault on a member of the Gay Activists Alliance, a spokesman for the District Attorney said yester day.

title: Jazz Schedules
description: Here is a schedule of to day's events in the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York:

title: Security Checks ordered For Busy Shuttle Flights
description: On instructions from President Nixon, the Federal Avia tion Administration issued an emergency order yesterday requiring that all passengers on shuttletype flights be given security checks as a step to curb hijacking.

title: Boeing Wins Missile Contract; Litton and Philco Also Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (Reu ters) The United States Air Force today awarded the Boeing Company a $66.5million con tract to begin development of a new strategic decoy missile for the B1 bomber.

title: SALES UP FOR GRANT, EDISON, LANE BRYANT
description: Several leading retail chains announced yesterday increased sales in June over the same month last year.

title: ELLSBERG'S TRIAL TO START MONDAY
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7. (UPI) United States District Court Judge Matt Byrne denied de fense motions today to dismiss the charges against Daniel Ells berg and ordered that his trial for theft of the Pentagon papers begin On Monday.

title: QUANGTRI DRIVE IS AT STANDSTILL AS ENEMY HOLDS
description: LAVANGHA, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 8  Wellen trenched and determined North Vietnamese troops fought a South Vietnamese advance to ward the provincial capital of Quangtri to a standstill yester day, and one Saigon element was forced to pull back after a strong enemy tank attack.

title: Pygmies, Many Owned by Planters, Are Central Africa's SecondClass Citizens
description: BAGANDOU, Central African Republic  Camille Belet, an African planter, owns 22 pyg mies. He inherited them from his father and will leave them and their children to his son with the rest of his property.

title: Harbor Greets a Portuguese Bark
description: The ghost of Prince Henry the Navigator, Portugal's fa mous 15thcentury seadog, rode into port yesterday.

title: 43Year Career
description: Mr. Doane retired as Chair man of International Paper in 1967.Under his leadership the concern's world sales had risen to a billion dollars a year.

title: WILLIAM R. KUHNS, BANKING EDITOR, 75
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., July 7 William R. Kuhns, former editor of Banking, the monthly journal of the Ameriacn Banking Asso ciation, and a former foreign correspondent, died today in Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Bombing Is Termed More Effective Now
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6Senior United States air of ficers say American pilots have inflicted more damage on North Vietnam since April than they did in a full year of President Johnson's heavy bombing cam paign.

title: Old Line, U.S. Life to Talk
description: The board of the Old Line Life Insurance Company has in structed its president, Forrest D. Guynn, to meet with repre sentatives of the U.S. Life In surance Company to discuss certain aspects of the previously announced merger proposal be fore further study by the direc tors of Old Line.

title: RESERVE ALLOWS BANK ACQUISITION
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Federal Reserve Board ap proved today the acquisition of a small upstate bank by the holdingcompany pareit of the First National City Bank, but it warned that this approval did not constitute any final judgment on the nonbanking activities of the holding com pany.

title: Business Briefs
description: DES PLAINES, Ill., July 7 (AP)The Universal Oil Products Company announced today that it would furnish the basic design for a new fluid catalytic cracking process unit for a refinery at Plock, Poland.

title: Agnew Again Criticizes Legal Services
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Vice President Agnew renewed his criticism of the Federal legal services program today with a charge that its lawyers disre gard individual poor clients but find time to engage in prac tically every cause clbre that comes along.

title: Turcotte Stays in Hospital
description: Ron Turcotte, one of the na tion's top jockeys, remained in Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights. He was taken there on Thursday after he was thrown heavily during a race. The Xrays were negative, but he was advised to rest at least an other day.

title: After a Sour Note, Harmony Reigns on Role of Blacks in Jazz
description: A few sour notes at a jazz seminar this week produced, paradoxically, harmony and perhaps an increased under standing about jazz and the people who make it.

title: Battle of Blues Heralds Festival's Move Outdoors
description: After six days in concert halls, a hotel ballroom and the enclosed deck of a ferry boat, the Newport Jazz Festival moved outdoors last night to Yankee Stadium. And, of course, it rained. Not a downpour but a drizzle to drive some of the 12,000 listeners in exposed seats back into the shelter of the stands.

title: A Not Impossible Dream
description: A projected new town to be called Soul City may have the sound of still another utopian community, but Floyd McKissick's enterprise in black capitalism is in tended as no such thing. On the contrary, it is a sane and practical as well as imaginative concept.

title: Business Briefs
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, July 7 (UPI)Volks wagen, A.G., said today that car sales to the United States have picked up following the 1971 slump.

title: PartTime Classes in Management Set
description: A new program of part time, specialized education in business and financial management will be intro duced this fall by the New York University Graduate School of Business Adminis tration.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Congressional immunity ap parently does not safeguard a United States Representa tive from being accosted by panhandlers in New York City. And when the Repre sentative tries to do some thing about it, not a great deal happens.

title: Ulster Youth 11th Victim In Killings During Truce
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 7 (Reuters)A Protestant teenager today became the 11th victim of sectarian repris al killings since the ceasefire 11 days ago.

title: Contac Defended
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Smith, Klein & French noted in a statement that the report was based on data compiled in the early nineteensixties, which demonstrated the safety and efficacy of Contac as measured by the scientific standards of that time.

title: Pennsy Will Lease 150 Locomotives And Box Cars
description: The Penn Central Transporta tion Company disclosed yester day that it was arranging to lease 150 new dieselelectric locomotives and 402 specially equipped box cars.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWPORT, R. I., ?? 7 (AP)Alain Colas of France sailed the 70foot Pen Duick IV across the finish line tonight, the first boat to complete the singlehanded Trans Atlantic race. The race began at Plymouth, England, June 17, with 56 boats entered.

title: Airline Permit Recommended
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has recommended granting a Netherlands Antilles airline, the Caribbean Air Transport Company of Curacao, a threeyear permit to operate nonscheduled cargo and mail service to Miami, New York and San Juan, Puert Rico.

title: Dance: Feld Intermezzo
description: Eliot Feld and the Ameri can Ballet Theater seem to have reached a state of ami cable truce. Ballet Theater's stormy but electrifying cho reographer, who walked out of the company three years back to form his own troupe, is back with it on a mutually guarded basis.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales last week was an estimated $784,000,000, 3 per cent above the yearearlier $758,000,000. Total retail store sales were about $8756,000,000, 7 per cent above last year's $7,165,000,000.

title: DR. CIGLIANAPIAZZA, MILAN BANKER, DEAD
description: Dr. Giorgio CiglianaPiazza, board chairman of Banca Mor gan Vonwiller, Milan, and a former director of the Interna tional Monetary Fund, died in Rome on Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 67 years old.

title: Montreal Exchange Suspends Member For 1971 Violations
description: MONTREAL, July 7 (Cana dian Press)  The governing committee of the Montreal Stock Exchange suspended to day the membership of Edgar Holland after finding that his brokerage firm had violated ex change regulations during 1971.

title: Buchwald's Father Dies
description: Joseph Buchwald, a drapery manufacturer and father of Art Buchwald, the newspaper columnist, died Thursday of a heart attack at the Forest Hills (Queens) home of a daughter, Mrs. Alice Gordon. His age was 79. Also surviving are two other daughters, Mrs. Edith Jaffe and Mrs. Doris Kahme, and seven grandchil dren.

title: VALDEZ MENA HEARD IN PIANO DEBUT HERE
description: Oscar Luis Valdez Mena, a Dominican pianist who has studied in his homeland, in Cuba and at the Juilliard School, made his New York debut Thursday night at Car negie Recital Hall.

title: ROCKEFELLER ACTS IN CREWS CONTEST
description: Governor Rockefeller's office intervened yesterday in a dis pute among Brooklyn Repub licans in an attempt to avert a major split in the county or ganization.

title: DRIVER DIES IN CRASH WITH FLOOD AID BUS
description: AUBURN, N. Y., July 7 (UPI) One woman was killed, an other was hospitalized and 29 persons suffered minor injuries today in an accident involving a School bus loaded with flood relief volunteers, the state po lice said.

title: Badillo Asks AntipovertyPlan Changes to Aid Jews
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo charged yesterday that the Jewish poor were the for gotten poor of New York, and urged Mayor Lindsay to over haul the city's antipoverty guidelines.

title: Illegal Shippers Sentenced
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., July 7 (UPI)Two Atlanta men who pleaded guilty to illegally sell ing and shipping alligator hides were sentenced yesterday to jail terms. United States Dis trict Judge Alexander A Lawr ence sentenced Q. C. Plott to six months in prison and his son, Christopher, 90 days. Both were placed on five years' pro bation.

title: Chess Champions Aides Fill Many Roles
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 7  After a week of confusion over the championship chess match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, Reykjavik is returning to Its normal activi ties.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REALTY MAN TIED TO SUFFOLK DEAL
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 7 A prominent Long Island real estate broker reportedly col lected $37,200 for helping the president of a jetset nightclub in Miami more than double his investment in land Suffolk County purchased as part of a major county park.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Hamlet Welcomes Back Restored Shahn Mural
description: ROOSEVELT, N. J., July 7 Ben Shahn's fresco is back up on the wall of the Roose velt Public School here, look ing very much as it did when Shahn painted it on the fresh plaster of the schoolhouse's community room in 1937 as his personal celebration of the arrival of European im migrants to the UnitedStates.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, july 7At about 6:20 P.M. on May 28, a television interviewer ad dressed Senator George Mc Govern with some exaspera tion. Was the South Dakotan asking the public to accept his controversial, $1,000aperson welfare reform plan without being able to state its cost?Betraying no sign of distress, Mr. McGovern replied evenly That is exactly right.

title: Fixed Yen Rate Backed
description: TOKYO, July 7 (Reuters) The new Minister of Interna tional Trade and Industry, Yaukhiro Nakasone, said today that Japan should adhere to the fixed yendollar exchange rate system and avert another revaluation of the yen.

title: GIORGIOD ANDRIA, 72, ANOPERA IMPRES ARIO
description: Giorgio D'Andria, impresario of the music world, died Wed nesday of a heart attack in Uni versity Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 333 Cen tral Park West:

title: EXGOV. DALTON OF MISSOURI DIES
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 7 (AP)Former Gov. John M. Dalton died of cancer in a Jef ferson City Hospital this after noon. He was 71 years old and had been ill for several months.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: PARISNgo Cong Duc, 36 years old, is a Roman Catholic from a prominent family in South. Vietnaties delta. The ranking Catholic prelate in Vietnam, Archbishop Binh, is a relative. Mr. Duc's father was assassinated in 1953 by the Communistled revolutionaries. He has been a Saigon newspaper editor and a member of the National Assembly.

title: A RIFT IS AVERTED AT N.A.A.C.P. TALKS
description: DETROIT, July 7 The Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People averted today a major fight with two of its longtime allies, the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith and the American Jewise Congress.

title: VIKTOR ZUYEVSKY, WARHEAD EXPERT
description: MOSCOW, July 7Viktor A. Zuyevsky, Soviet designer of nuclear warheads, died Wed nesday after a brief illness. He was 53 years Old.

title: Citizens in 60 Neighborhoods To Aid Special Street Cleanup
description: Special teams of city sanita tionmen will scrub the streets of 60 selected neighborhoods in the next four months, but the city will then rely on com munity organizations to main tain the higher level of clean liness.

title: Sears Adopting a New Plan To Figure Finance Charges
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chi cago, the nation's largest retail chain, said yesterday that it would adopt a different method in computing finance charges on its revolving credit plan in 32 states and the District of Columbia.

title: Notes on People
description: There were drinks on the lawn and borscht and lobster and shrimp salad in the Susan E. Wagner room at Gracie Mansion as Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay paid trib ute to 50 good citizens of New York City.

title: Cuban Gets Miami Post
description: MIAMI, July 7 (UPI)Man olo Reboso, a 38yearold archi tect, was appointed to the Miami City Commission yester daythe first Cuban exile to hold a commission seat.

title: Cuba and the O.A.S.
description: Peru's decision to resume diplomatic relations with Cuba points up again the need to rethink United States policy toward the Castro regime, particularly in the context of the Organization of American States. For if Washington persists in trying to maintain thee O.A.S. diplomatic and economic quarantine of Cuba, it will risk an eventual defeat comparable in the hemisphere to the humiliation it sustained with the expulsion of Nationalist China at the United Nations last year.

title: M'GOVERN REACTS WITH RESTRAINT
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Sen ator George McGovern reacted with controlled chagrin tonight to a Supreme Court ruling that will force him to win back 151 California delegates on the floor of the Democratic National Con vention.

title: Mistaken U.S. Attacks Kill 8 Allied Soldiers
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 8 (AP)  The United States command an nounced today that two American soldiers and six Vietnamese were wounded in two mistaken bombardments yesterday. Both incidents are under investigation, the com mand said.

title: HANOI SAYS NIXON PREVENTS ACCORD
description: PARIS, July 7Nguyen Thanh Le, spokesman for North Viet nam's delegation to the peace talks, said today that President Nixon still seeks a military victory and that he's not seek ing to negotiate.

title: SmallBusiness Unit Eases Rules on Flood Estimates
description: The Small Business Admin istration, which has been swamped with applications for disaster loans from victims of the recent floods, disclosed yes terday that, to eliminate some of the paper work, it would no longer require applicants in two states to submit cost estimates of repair work from local con tractors.

title: China Reported Willing to Open Talks With Tanaka on Diplomatic Relations
description: TOKYO, July 7China has reportedly communicated to Ja pan's new Premier a willingness to open talks on the establish ment of diplomatic relations be tween the two countries.

title: Executive Changes
description: George M. Miesenhelder and Richard L. Kauf man have been named vice presidentfinance and controller respectively of the Ampex Corporation.

title: Value of Cold Remedies Is Questioned
Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  An International Business Machines Corporation scien tist was granted a patent this week for a new kind of solar cell, described as far more efficient than earlier means of con verting sunlight to electricity. It is likely to be useful in satellites and space ships.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7More concerned, with the swirling wind, Billie Jean King had accepted several questionable calls with a silent stare or a shake of the head. But now, in the seventh game of the first sat in her Wimbledon's women's final today, she uncoiled in her seethrough dress and swatted a serve to Evonne Goola gong's backhand. Chalk dust rose in a puff as the ball skidded off the worn brown grass for an apparent ace.

title: Police Seize a Suspect As the Kissing Bandit
description: A 26yearold Queens man, believed to have stolen hun dreds of kisses from women riding the Flushing IRT line, has been charged with as sault and harassment.

title: Naomi Weissman, Richard Karp Wed
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., July 7The marriage of Miss Naomi Weissman to Richard Manning Karp, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Louis Karp of West Roxbury, Mass., took place here this after noon. Rabbi Michael Robin son performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs Paul Weissman of New York and CrotononHudson.

title: Business Briefs
description: An appeal by Robert L. Vesco, former chairman LO.S., Ltd., to avoid compliance with a lower court order to testify before the Securities and Exchange Commission has been dismissed by a threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, it was disclosed here yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine had hoped, once upon a time, to come to Miami Beach in glory this July, to come here having already proved his claim to the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Calvin Coolidge, the Last Great President
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind.  I suppose Hoosiers are just like other Ameri cans. We believe that what America needs is President who spends less time bumping and grinding before the bulging eyes of the media.

title: Dr. George Southworth Dead; Leader in Guidedwave Radio
description: CHATHAM, N. J., July 7 Dr. George Clark Southworth, a leader in the development of guidedwave radio, died yester day in Overlook Hospital, Sum mit. Ho was 81 years old and lived at 19 Williams Road.

title: Jazz: Kaleidoscopic Sounds, Syncopated Visions
description: Jazz can go from an exal tation of horns down to just the infectious snapping of two fingers by one man in the center of a great stage. It can be a driving, crashing, urgent soundthe cry of brass an nouncing the apocalypseor a few light piano notes, danc ing on the air like dandelion puffs.

title: Truman Undergoes Tests
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 7 (UPI)Former President Harry S. Truman, hospitalized since Sunday with a gastrointestinal ailment, underwent an exam ination of the colon today. The results were not yet available, a hospital spokesman said adding that the condition of the 88yearold patient, was satis factory.

title: 2 City Detectives Visit Witness Who Recanted in Harlem 4 Case
description: Two detectives from the Manhattan District Attorney's Office met intermittently for at least three hours yesterday in an upstate prison with the chief prosecution witness in the so called Harlem Four case.

title: Without Benefit Of Parole
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.The Su preme Court's holding that capital pun ishment as presently administered in the United States, is unconstitutional cruel and unusual punishment, may set the stage for a conservative law andorder legislative reaction of un paralleled intensity. Already there is mounting pressure to impose manda tory sentences of life without benefit of parole in all cases which would have been capital before the Supreme Court's opinion; these same pressures may lead to mandated life without parole sentences in other serious felony categories, as well.

title: NIXON ACTS TO CUT MEAT PRICE RISES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7The Nixon Administration announced today two more steps it is taking in efforts to stop the upsurge in meat prices, in particular, and food prices generally.

title: Malaysia Seeks U.S. Investment
description: We have to create 108,000 new jobs by 1975 just to keep our present unemployment rate of 7.6 per cent from going any higher.

title: Brandt Names Schmidt Finance Chief
description: BONN, July 7  Chancellor Willy Brandt named Defense Minister Helmut Schmidt today to serve as Minister of Eco nomics and Finance until the next national elections, expect ed in November.

title: Antiques: Rarities in Pressed Glass
description: Glass is the thing to look for in the bargain antique shops that dot such high ways as Routes 1 and 6 in Massachusetts. Of the late 19thcentury material that they offer most easily, the glass stands out, tending to be more attractive and inter esting than the furniture, ceramics and metal work one also finds in these shops.

title: HILL, GRAHAM TIE FOR LEAD ON 136'S

title: LETTERS
description: I was surprised to read in the article, An Economist for the World (June 18), that Dr. Milton Gilbert in vented the national account system in the nineteen forties. Whatever Dr. Gil bert's contribution to the present form of the national income and product accounts may have been, he can hardly be said to have in vented them.

title: Richey Vanquishes Ashe, 62 64, in Semifinals of Bretton Woods Tennis

title: The World
description: NEW DELHI  Two graying men, one. Indian and one Pakistani, looked at, each other, whooped in unison and embraced in the emotional man ner of Asian friends meeting after a long separation. Such happy reun ions were a common sight in hotel lobbies and the corridors of Govern ment buildings in Simla When the talks between President Zulfiker Ali Bhutto of Pakistan and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India brought to gether many senior officials, journal ists and other who had known each other as schoolmates, colleagues and friends before their two countries were carved out of British India 25 years ago.

title: Music
description: IN his Mass, Leonard Bernstein has tried to write a Mahler opera, a per sonal passion play and a morality drama for our time. A big order by no means filled. And yet to what more important task could any composer to day address himself than the one that Mahler (who never wrote an opera, of course) spent his whole career facing up to? Like Mahlerand Joyce and Eliot and most other significant 20thcentury art ists you might mention  the composer of Mass perceives that there is some thing divine in the commonplace  in popular song, folk wit and wisdom, clichs, and everyday conversation. And in religious myths. The Bernstein Mass, like few other musical works in history, sets out consciously to embrace the ordinary and to apotheosize it. That it fails to do so is not essentially the fault of the musical score itself, which is a sophisticated, sometimes quite bril liant, pastiche of a sort that no one but Bernstein is capable of producing today.

title: Fund to Foster Tourism
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (DPI) The Interior Department ap propriated $88,000 today to fos ter tourism on Indian reserva tions so as to improve job and income opportunities for Amer ican Indians. Two phases of the promotion will involve public service commercials for televi sion and research to determine what Indian facilities exist for tourists.

Va., July 8Around the turn of he cen tury, Jews from a small Lithu anian village called Popilan, fleeing Russian pogroms, came to America, and more particu larly to the Appalachian mining country, where they traveled from coal camp to coal camp, peddling notions from back packs.

description: What you fail to under stand is that I and other black Americans do not take delight or pride in seeing one of the giants of black history portrayed by a white actor . . . any white actor. On the contrary, such a portrayal is insultingly reminiscent of the ridicule we blacks suffered all too silently in the heyday of the minstrel show when your kind blackened your faces to laugh at my kind. Sorry; Mr. Quinn, but in 1972 I will not sit silently by while you, in effect, ridi cule my heroes in the same fashion.

description: Great prominence has lately been given by the Nixon Administration to the industrial destruction caused by the bombing raids now being carried on over North Vietnam. Thus, on June 12 we were told that U.S. jets have destroyed a hydroelectric plant capable of producing 75 per cent of North Vietnam's power requirements and on June 25 the U.S. command in Sai gon reported that fighterbombers have wrecked North Vietnam's only modern steel plant.

title: A cave of a house
description: Even today Mediterranean architects often return to the ancient, organic shapes of peasant buildings. The result, as in this summer cottage on the cliffs of Sardinia, can be a civilized blend of nature and artistry. The design was dictated by what most people would consider an impossible sitea cliff top slashed by a granite ravine strewn with boulders. Architect Alberto Ponsi decided to build in the ravine, using its steep granite sides as interior walls and capping it with a tentlike roof. There was no need to devise plans, says the architect. As the loose rocks were cleared from the cleft, it was already possible to identify the living areas of the house. Even windows and doorways were placed during construction. Thus, the cavernlike house with three bedrooms and two baths, practically designed itself.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 8 (AP)This, said Henry A. Kissinger, is a historic announcement.

title: From the far erotic left
description: Before La Btarde became all the rage in Paris in 1964, the late Violette Leduc had been a journey man novelist with several books to her credit and no audience to speak of. But La Btarde, an extremely graphic memoir of the au thor's love life, made her famous overnight. She was acclaimed as a new star in the tradition of great literary exhibitionists that started with Casanova. In La Btarde Violette Leduc discovered a potent mixture of bisexual poetry and crude realism which she continued to explore in succeeding works (The Woman With the Little Fox, The rse and Isabelle, Mad in Pursuit) until her position now is firmly es tablished far to the erotic left of Simone de Beauvoir in the French wing of women's liberation, an old tradition dating back to such stars as Madame de Stal and George Sand.

title: Florida Linkletter Ad Halted

The Na tional Home Life Assurance Company of St. Louis is ac cused by the State Insurance Department of violating 10 state insurance regulations, in cluding those on deceptive ad vertising and the use of an unlicensed agent.

title: Cockleburr Quarters
description: Cockleburr Quarters is a little black community with a big puppy problem. Eight of them and the mammydog are under the church, and the preacher wants them out before he has a flea problem. Dolph, from across the street, is a dog wanting boy who gets them out and then they're his problem to house, feed, clean up after, and find homes for. But he can't take them to his home because his mother says dogs are Public Enemy number one to her vegetable garden. And he can't take them food from home because there is not always enough for the two grownups, and the six growing that are already there.

title: Christopher Bennett Cerf Weds Genevieve Charbin
description: Miss Genevive Paule Char bin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Marc Charbin of Mont real and Groton Long Point, Conn., was married to Chris topher Bennett Cerf in Mont real yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Jean Guy Dubuc, a Catholic priest, who is also a reporter for the newspaper La Presse in Montreal, per formed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Cathedrale de Marie Rene du Monde, formerly the Cathedrale St. Jacques. Afterward, a cham pagne and buffet dinner re ception was given for about 100 guests at the Charbin home.

title: AROUND THE
description: Keep up with weeding, insect control and lawn mowing. ... Finish planting and replace where too much moisture rotted out vegetables and annuals. ... If you'll be away on vacation for more than two weeks, arrange to have the grass cut and the window boxes tended.

title: Rip Van Winkle Spanishstyle
description: This is the spellbinding story of a man who concealed himself inside his own house for 30 years (193969) to avoid execution by the Franco regime. The book consists of the taperecorded experience of this man, the former Mayor of Mijas, a Spanish village, and his wife and daughter. As it unfolds, modestly, factually and without pretension, one finds oneself discovering what the Spanish Civil War was really about. And one real izes all over again why it was the watershed of our age, for in that struggle the terms of social and political evolution in this century set.
