description: WASHINGTON, July 8  The Army, which sent dozens of undercover agents to the Demo cratic National Convention in Chicago in 1988, will be back in force at Miami Beach next week  but in a far less con troversial role.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: MILLERTON, N. Y., July 8An occasional freight train still rumbles through the farmland of the Upper Harlem Valley just north pf here, its melancholy Whistle a reminder of what was once a flourishing passenger and freight service.

title: A Judgment on Ezra Pound
description: BOSTONIf conformity to prevailing standards of morality were a condition for artistic recognition, Henry David Thoreau would not have fared well. The 19th Century American poet and essayist refused to vote, was jailed for not paying his taxes, railed against his gov ernment and eulogized John Brown, a man hanged for murder and treason.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: What are you doing here on a Sunday?

title: Rise in Black Children's Pride Is Found
description: A team of psychologists has found in a study that black youngsters have developed a higher self esteem and conse quently prefer people of their own color to whites.

title: Luke M. Pittoni Weds Mary Jo Rocque
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 8  Miss Mary Jo Rocque, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Rocque, was mar ried here today to Luke M. Pittoni, son of New York. State Supreme Court Justice Mario Pittoni and Mrs. Pit ton of Lynbrook, L. I.

title: That's No Prime Cut, It's Just Baloney
description: IT was Sunday afternoon of the 4th of July weekend and everybody who possibly could had fled Manhattan, piously, as if it were a duty. There was even something humiliating about the squalidly humid and hot weather. Life, instead of being a liedown on a water mattress, was like being inside one. Difficult to think or to breathe, or to hold any but vile thoughts about those who were safely outside. I thus was walking down Broadway with its glittering marquees (A Sticky Situa tion, Eroticon, etc.) when whom should I meet but Stanley, Jr., my film in dustry friend's bearded, 18yearold son who is taller and leaner than his dad, as well as a constant critic of his father's philistinism (Your wig's too long), the director of an eightminute short titled Automobiles Are Divine Yet God Makes Trees, and the author of a still unpub lished study on The Color Metaphors in The Horror Films of Freddie Francis (With Particular Attention to The Mauve). Young Stanley looked hol loweyed, haggard and deathly pale; in short, he looked to be in his equiva lent of the pink of condition.

title: English Children Stricken
description: NEWCASTLE, England, July 8 (Reuters)  More than 150 children attending an outdoor sports festival near here today were rushed to hospitals after they collapsed with abdominal pains. A local health depart ment spokesman said that the outbreak was being investi gated. It is a mystery at pres ent because, as far as we know, the children did not have a common meal, he said.

title: 300 Reservists Inoculated
description: WILLOW GROVE, Pa., July 8 (AP)About 300 Pennsyl vania Air National Guard re servists at Willow Grove Naval Air Station were inoculated against hepatitis yesterday af ter a cook was tentatively diagnosed as having the disease.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 8  They don't sell hot dogs here; they sell straw berries and cream. And the players don't take showers; they take baths.

title: FORD'S HINDSIGHT NOROTON VICTOR
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 8 Peter Ford of the Norwalk Yacht Club, sailing Hindsight, won the opening race of the annual Connecticut Governor's Cup Lightning Class regatta on Long Island Sound off Noroton Yacht Club today. Unfavorable winds prevented the sailing of two, races as planned. As a re sult, two races will be attempted tomorrow when the regatta ends.

title: Nissequogue Talks Again of Shutting Its Old School
description: NISSEQUOGUE, L. IAs usual, it was not a day strictly for the children. They were there, of course, two score or so of second and thirdgraders decorously seated on small chairs in the shady backyard of the brick andshingle schoolhouse.

title: Jazz
description: THE Newport Jazz Festi val's first foray into New York City closes today. Those fans who were not satiated (and per haps those who were) by nine days of everything from avant garde to gospel and blues might be interested in retaining a few of the good vibes generated by the event.

title: Education
description: Sam M. Lambert, the executive secretary of the National Education Association, has an idea for reliev ing the finanoial plight of the nation's schools: transfer the cost of education from the local property tax to the Federal income tax. Then he would make financial support for the Defense Department de pendent on the property taxwhich in 47 states is subject to voter approval  instead of Federal in come tax.

title: Mary J. Mason Will Be a Bride
description: PEAPACK, N. J., July 8 Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Mason Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Johanna Mason, to Francis Edgar Johnson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Far Hills and Edgartown, Mass.

title: SOLAR ENERGY STUDY IS PLANNED BY NASA
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has authorized a survey of the feasibility of using large sat ellites to convert the sun's energy into a boundless supply of electric power for relay to the earth.

title: Art
description: DADA, as we all know, was a revolt against established cul ture, a repudiation of fine art and the learned art historians who presided over its elucidation and veneration. Dadaso the myth goes wrote Finis to all those scholarly dis quisitions and abstract categories which, in the name of high culture, only serve to mask the naked realities of both art and experience. Dada affirmed what culture denied: That a gratuitous ges ture, a vulgar expression, an obscene act, even an act of violence, might be more creative in liberating man's poetic energies than the entire stock of works of art incarcerated in those cemeteries known as museums.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To ANTHONY QUINN:

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Frederic Endemann Weds Nancy Fisher
description: SOUTHOLD, L. I., July 8 Miss Nancy Gay Fisher was married here this afternoon to Frederic Buck Endemann by the Rev. Alexander Sime in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: JUDGE BARS SEATING OF RIVALS OF DALEY
description: CHICAGO, July 8 (UPI)  Circuit Court Judge Daniel A. Covelli issued an injunction to day prohibiting the challengers to Mayor Richard J. Daley from taking their seats at the Dem ocratic National Convention.

title: The Nation
description: I lied. I knew nothing about the crime at all. That statement was made last week by the man who had been the state's star witness in the three trials over the last eight years of the Harlem Four, charged with the rob berymurder of a Harlem shopkeeper in 1964. And it suddenly opened again a question that seemed to have been resolved just a week earlier: Would there be a fourth trial for the four black youths?

title: BLUE BELLE VICTOR IN SHIELDS SAILING
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 Jacques F. Bulterman's Blue Belle won the 7.5mile Shields Class race by 3 minutes 57 sec onds and 150 yards on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. It was the season's 16th championship re gatta for Yacht Racing Asso ciation fleets based east of Rye.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELFASTThere is no more suit able national symbol than the Red Hand of Ulster, recalling an avid Celtic chieftain who chopped off his hand and heaved it ashore to claim this bloody land. The only other Red Hand I know was a secret French terrorist organization that specialized in killing Algerian patriots. Ulster's Red Hand reaches out for anyone.

title: Farms Still Play Role in Bustling Bergen
description: RAMSEY Less than an hour from the George Wash ington Bridge, farms still oc cupy a small but active role in the life of sophisticated, affluent Bergen County.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Art
description: ASMALL show called Native North Ameri can Art now at the Brooklyn Museum is neither good enough nor bad enough to be extraordinary either way. A gathering of works by eight littleknown, mostly young and medium. talented Indian artists, it is, indeed, unremarkable even compared to the run of exhibitions assembled for extraesthetic reasons. Its very middlingness, however, helps recommend it as a specimen of that vexing and lately frequent phenomenon, the politically motivated art show.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: I think that it is time the freedom of the artist took priority over the ethnic bal lyhoo raised whenever a film goes into production these days. If Anthony Quinn wants to play Christophe, I say Right on! Over the years he has distinguished himself as an outstanding actor by playing individuals of a wide range of national ities and doing so with fine artistic taste.

title: BAIL SET IN MINEOLA IN GAMBLING CASES
description: Bails ranging from $500 to $2,500 was set yesterday for 17 persons arraigned in Crimin nal Court in Mineola, L. I., on gambling charges.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Newport Festival Is Here to Stay, Wein Says
description: The Newport Jazz Festival is in New York City to stay, George Wein, the festival's pro ducer, said yesterday. He said it would not return to the un certainties and tumult of its place of origin at Newport, R.I.

title: The World
description: REYKJAVIK  Onagain, offagain. For days the participants in the SpasskyFischer world championship chess match maneuvered into po sitions more complicated than the Dragon Variation of the Sicilian De fense. Nowthough no game has yet been playedit appears to be offi cially on.

title: Julie Clarke Bryant to Marry Aug. 26
description: The engagement of Miss Julie Clarke Bryant to Ste phen Langhorne Perkins has been announced by Mrs. Nan cye Clarke Sweeney of Lee Ball, Va., and C. Edgar Bryant of Washington and Culpep per, Va., parents of the bride tobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chiswell Dab ney Langhorne Perkins of Villanova, Pa. An Aug. 26 wedding is planned.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: Let's get this straight: young black kids need black heroes, not Anthony Quinn in blackface. The black actor who portrays the Haitian revolutionary will become Henry Christophe, endowed with his vigor and heroism and brilliance, and every black person can feast at this banquet. Massa in blackface ain't the same thing.

title: British Emphasis on Methadone Stirs Illicit Sales of Heroin
description: LONDON, July 8  The British Government, which for years has provided free heroin to addicts, has sharply re stricted the program in favor of methadone. The shift has stimulated the black market in heroin.

title: Chess, Anyone?In Queens, That Is
description: As Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky prepare to lock horns in Iceland this week, the whole chess world will be watching. Among the most engrossed spectators will be the 40 members of the Queens Chess Club.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES granted Boeing a $150million export license to sell 10 Boeing 707 jet airliners to China. The move could represent a massive trade breakthrough with China. ... The Justice Department sued to prevent Converse Rubber from leasing with an option to purchase to rubbercanvas footwear operations of B. F. Goodrich. ... Chrysler asked the Price Commission for a 5 per cent increase, or $180. ... New car and truck sales appeared headed for a 13million year and G.M. reported a 7 per cent rise in June sales, while A.M.C. gained 23 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: So the death penalty constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in vio lation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and I must read five opinions as to why it does and four opinions as to why it does not if I am to attempt to understand the Supreme Court's reasoning.

title: Ballot Petitions Missing
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., July 8 (UPI)Voters will not know for a while whether they will be voting to lower the drinking age in the stare from 21 to 18 next November because some body made off with the petition bearing 107,000 signatures nec essary to get the initiative on the ballot. David G. Huey, a high school student who is chairman of the sponsoring committee for uniform laws, reported the petitions missing yesterday a few hours before the deadline for petitions passed.

title: The World
description: PARISThe change in Premiers last week was advertised as a new dyna mism, a pickmeup to lead the Gaullist majority to a victorious new lease on life. But nonGaullists called it a return to port, to a more cautious and con servative Gaullism, in the face of looming storms.

title: DELAWARE RACE WON BY LIGHT HEARTED
description: STANTON, Del., July 8 (AP)  Light Hearted carried the silks of the Christiana Stables to victory in the feature race at Delaware Park today.

title: LINDSAY, IN MIAMI, TAKES QUIET ROLE
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 8 Mayor Lindsay, who had hoped to come here as a Presidential contender, arrived today as merely one of 278 New York delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: I join my voice emphat ically to those who feel it would be absolutely wrong for Tony Quinn to try to portray Henry Christophe on film, especially at this time when we black folks and other Third World people are fighting so hard to establish control over our identities. Tony is a great actor and I am happy to count him as a friend, and as an artist for whom I have the highest re gard. But more than art is at issue here. And, as a black man, fully aware that black in spite of its high visibility is still too much distorted in American film, even by wellmeaning whites, I must protest.

title: BY WHAT RIGHT?
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Kissinger Hopeful Paris Peace Talks Can Bring Progress
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 8  Henry A. Kissinger, the chief White House adviser on foreign affairs, said today that he had some reason to be lieve that North Vietnam was ready for serious negotiations looking toward an end of the war.

title: Small Business Lures Individualists
description: As the warts of many major corporations seem to grow in size, shape and dis maying visibility, students in the prestige schools of man agement have been express Ling an increasing interest in socalled small business.

title: Leasing Car Problems Away
description: DETROIT, Mich.  Mrs. Joseph D. Thrush drives to work every day in a yellow 1972 Ford Maverick. She is a secretary at the Clarence Ran dall School in the Detroit suburb of Taylor.

title: Weiskopf Posts 64 Round
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 8, (Reuters)Tom Weiskopf of Columbus, Ohio, carded a seven under par 64 today on the Muirfield course in a practice round for the British Open. He shot a 28 on the outward nine, six under. Weiskopf started out with par, birdie, birdie, birdie and an eagle.

title: North Assails Seoul Police
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)North Korea said today that the police in Seoul had been or dered to suppress the South Korean people.

title: The World
description: PARISIn the money centers and political capitals of Europe an erosion is taking place that could easily under mine the postwar structure of eco nomic cooperation, a structure that has had substantial impact on Western Europe and the United States.

title: LETTERS
description: While our Federal Govern ment achieves new heights of grandeur, it seems to care less about its original respon sibility as assigned by the Constitution and implemented by Patent Office operations.

title: Series of Clinics For Youth Planned In the Area by Nets
description: The New York Nets will hold 100 basketball clinics on Long Island and in Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan through July and August. The sessions are under the direc tion of Fritz Massmann and George Herrmann.

title: Syrian, Ending Moscow Visit, Is Given Pledges of More Aid
description: MOSCOW, July 8President Hafez alAssad of Syria ended a threeday visit to Moscow to day with Soviet pledges of more economic and military aid to his country.

title: Law
description: Much has been written since the end of the Supreme Court term 10 days ago about the dramatic con servative shift of the Court since the days of Chief Justice Earl Warren. Perhaps no single case of the recent term better illustrates that shift than the decision handed down on June 22. At issue: Property rights versus the right of free speech.

title: Decatur and Bocian Teams Gain A.A.U. Handball Final
description: The handball teams of Marty DecaturMarty Katzen and Neal BocianHowie Eisenberg will meet today for the Nation al Amateur Athletic Union onewall doubles championship.

title: Television
description: IF the Federal Government wins its antitrust case against the three televi sion networks, advertis ing agencies and big com panies, may once again be producing TV shows. But the Government's suit is really just another way of saying the obvious: TV is dull, and new producers with the same old ideas won't improve the situation. What the networks need are tieinspromotions like The Godfather Game that capitalize on successful books, movies and other newsworthy items.

title: Safety First
description: When the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board last April suggested sweeping new Federal action to prevent hijacking, Federal Aviation Administrator John H. Shaffer demurred. We don't have to make a Fort Knox or an S. A. C. [Strategic Air Command] base out of every civilian airport, he declared. I think this thing is under control. The culprits are being apprehended and brought to justice. And no one is getting hurt except the hijacker. Every day we are getting more secure.

title: Miss Yvonne Maria Strachwitz Bride on L.I. of John McQuilkin
description: HEWLETT, L.I., July 8  The marriage of Miss Yvonne Maria Strachwitz to John Atterbury McQuilkin took place this evening in Trinity Episcopal Church, here. The Rev. Donald Hood, rector, performed the ceremony as sisted by the Rev. Charles Supin, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Far Rock away, Queens. A reception was Mod at the Rockaway Hunting Club in Cedarhurst.

title: Biggers' Choice Approved
description: OMAHA, July 8 (AP)The University of Nebraska's Board of Regents approved today the appointment of Clyde W. Big gers as athletic director at the University of Nebraska at Omaha. Biggers, 47 years old, had been head football coach at Eastern Illinois University since 1965.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rushhour express bus service between the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn and Manhattan will be introduced to morrow, the Mayor's office announced yesterday. The ex pected morning travel, time to Park Row in downtown Manhattan is 45 minutes, with the buses then continuing to midtown stops, ending at Madison Avenue and 56th Street after a total trip of 75 minutes.

title: News of Dogs
description: Alaska is a long way from the Near East, where the Afghan hound is said to have roamed 5,000 years ago. But in the frozen North the ex otic hound has made great strides. So much so, that at the recent 39th show of the Alaska Kennel Club in An chorage, an Afghan was best of the 562 dogs.

title: A Science Museum In Limbo in Queens
description: Evidence of what someday may be the city's first genu ine science museumin ef fect, en expanded Hall of Science  can be seen in Flushing Meadows  Corona Park, the site of the last New York World's Fair.

title: STUDY FINDS BIAS IN NEWS OVER TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 8A survey of national television news programs accuses the three major networks of a significant degree of bias in their reporting of the Demo cratic primary campaign and the Vietnam war.

title: 2 Aides Left Drier L.I. For a School in Flood
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y. They had to fight the flood waters brought by tropical storm Agnes, but two Long Island officials who attended the conferenceschool of the New York State Supervisors and County Legislators As sociation said that they felt that the time was well spent.

title: The Ball That Never Got Started
description: Notices have gone out saying that the elephant is resting this year. This has nothing to do with the Republican party's symbol  that elephant is getting busier by the minute  but with the cancella tion of the White Elephant Ball.

title: Wallace Tells Delegates He Will Continue Drive
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 8 (Reuters)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was given a singing, cheering, footstomping reception when he made his first public ap pearance before his conven tion delegates here tonight and promised to continue fighting for the Presidential nomination.

title: High Court Sets a Record In Opinions for a Term
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)  The Supreme Court exper ienced another peak work load in the term ended last week 4,533 cases were docketed and 3,645 were cleared.

title: REFEREE TO MISS FIRST CHESS GAME
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 8 Lothan Schmid, the referee of the Boris Spassky  Bobby Fischer championship chess match, will not be able to of ficiate at the first game on Tuesday.

title: Ft. Hamilton: It's No Flag Stop
description: Nestled on 177 acres of Brooklyn shoreline in the shadow of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge is a small town whose values and neighborly ways are shel tered from the innercity con flict.

title: Inventory Actions
description: Who holds how much of what and for how long could well be the key to today's economy.

title: Two L. I. Girls Reap by Sewing
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I. A white dress made by an East Northport 13yearold won the statewide Junior Sewing Contest sponsored by the Daughters of the Ameri can Revolution. A Northport High School junior won the contest's Senior Division with a gingham dress with red, white and pink checks and oldfashioned full sleeves.

title: 3 U. S. Records Are Shattered in Windup of Women's Olympic Track Trials
description: FREDERICK, Md., July 8  Three American running rec ords were set tonight and two were threatened in the field events as the women's Olympic trials ended. An enthusiastic crowd of 6,128 witnessed the events at the Gov. Thomas Johnson High School field.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 8 (UPI)The Turkish Govern ment vetoed today the candi dacy of Archbishop Iakovos of New York as a possible succes sor to Patriarch Anthenagoras I.

title: BLACKS ARE SPLIT AT MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 8 Black politicians, leaders and delegates hoping to play a major role at the Democratic National Convention began in formal meetings today and will hold formal caucuses tomor row.

title: In Critical Condition
description: The world of medicine fascinates and instructs. Patientspinned like butterflies to their mortality, sharply aware of what is preciouscan also be teachers. Read Thomas Mann (The Magic Mountain) or Tolstoy (The Death of Ivan Ilych). Read Rachel MacKenzie's account of her own openheart procedure, Risk, or Solzhenitsyn's Cancer Ward. Better still, visit hospitals yourself and talk to strangers who are sick, in pain, dying; sit awhile with the people who know and love them. Edward M. Kennedy did something very like that when, as chairman of the Senate Health Subcommittee, he held hearings last year in Washing ton and across the country to inves tigate what is by now familiarly (if inadequately) called The Crisis in America's Health Care. He seems to have learned something important.

title: 100 ON JURY PANEL IN ELLSBERG TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8  A panel of 100 prospective jurors are scheduled to appear in Fed eral District Court here Monday as the trial of Dr. Daniel Ells berg and Anthony J. Russo, charged with stealing the Penta gon papers, gets under way. The defendants are scheduled to be tried on a 15count indict ment that could lead to 115 years in jail for Dr. Ellsberg and 35 for Mr. Russo if convicted. In five weeks of pretrial argu ments, Federal District Judge William Matt Byrne Jr. denied virtually all of a dozen defense motions to dismiss the charges or some of them.

title: This is a birthday cake?
description: When Albert Pucci was a boy, his mother always made this icebox cake for his birthday. Today, he is an artist in Brooklyn, and he makes the cake himself and shows friends how to assemble the layers of ladyfingers and anisette cream.

title: Mexican Car Race Canceled
description: MEXICO CITY, July 8 (Reu ters)  The Mexican Grand Prix, which counts toward the World Formula One champion ship and was scheduled to take place in October, has been can celed, the organizing commit tee said today. It was canceled last year after Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico died in a car crash in Nuremberg, West Germany.

title: Wrong Frenchman Wins Sail
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 8A funny thing happened yesterday at the cocktail party of the Race Committee waiting for JeanYves Terlain and his 128 foot schooner to sail in and be declared the first finisher in the singlehanded TransAtlan tic sail.

title: COSMOS 20 VICTORS OVER MIAMI RIVALS
description: MIAMI, July 8The New York Cosmos posted their first road victory of the season to night, beating the Miami Gatos, 20.

title: Swans Taking L. I. Under Wing
description: STONY BROOK, L. I. Not to the music of Tchai kovsky but, rather, to the upbeat rhythm of traffic. That, in effect, is how Long Island's swan population has been expanding along with, and sometimes alongside of, the recently completed ex pressway.

title: Social Announcements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Larry Prigmen of New York City announce the marriage of their daugh ter Nancy Ellen to Mr. David Baron Dubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Dubin of Kingston, New York, on July 8, 1972.

title: Art
description: THE Minneapolis Insti tute of Arts; which al ways saves a spot for a big show during the summer, has bagged a double header this year, a generous portion of the collection of J. Paul Getty16 examples of sculpture from ancient Greece and Rome, 38 Euro pean paintings from the 14th through the 18th centuries, a set of four Gobelins tapestries designed by Boucher, and sev eral pieces of 18thcentury French furniture.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read the article about zoos [Bronx Zoo Birds Get a Palace, June 11]. At first, I thought it was a mistake, then I realized that the Real Estate Section likes zoos and doesn't like builders.

title: Canada in China
description: PEKING  A little more than six weeks from now more than 600 Canadians will descend on Peking for what promises to be the biggest show one country has mounted in China.

title: Trackmen Ask Where All Money Goes
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 8  The handprinted sign on the bulletin board in Bean Hall begged for assistance: Help! Poverty Stricken Marathoner Will Need Way Home to Mass. (Had to pay own Way here).

title: BAIL FREES SWEETAN IN PLAYBOOK AFFAIR
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP) Karl Sweetan, 29yearold for mer professional football quar terback, and Wayne Boswell, his cousin, were released on $5,000 bond today on charges concerning an allegedly stolen Los Angeles Rams playbook.

title: Thesis, analysis, diagnosisbackground reading for the Miami conventions
description: Burton Hersh has tried, in 510 pages and 1,426 footnotes, to shatter the old molds of political biography. He may have succeeded, but at the price of obscuring his subject. What is the theme of The Education of Ed ward Kennedy? Does Hersh rehash previous works about previous Ken nedys for a purpose? Does he mean to portray the Massachusetts Sena tor as a symbol of steadiness, a mezzotint Soames Forsyte glaring from the mantelpiece of America? When Hersh narrates in crisp detail the death of Mary Jo Kopechne, what is the literary lessonthat Edward Kennedy is now to take a role in Sunrise at Chappaquiddick?

title: Fischer Furor Sparks Big Run on Chess Sets
description: Bobby Fischer may have created controversy in Iceland, but in chess stores and studios he is also creating sales. According to store buyers and studio managers, the world championship match, has generated increased demand for chess books, sets and lessons. Here is a rundown on some of the items most widely recommended by the experts:

title: the traveler's world
description: TORSHAVN, Streymoy, Faroe Is landsMillions of years ago volcanic explosion scattered 18 small islands into the deep, cold waters of the North Atlantic, well north of Scotland's Shetland Islands. Today, 40,000 Faroese inhabit these stark, lush green, rockstriated, dramatically beauti ful islands, and the avantgarde of Ameri can tourists is just beginning to find them out, trailing behind a handful of loyally returning, adventurous European tourists.

title: Patrolman, Writing a Ticket, Hit by Car in Prospect Park
description: A city patrolman was criti cally injured in Prospect Park yesterday when he was struck down by a passing automobile while he was issuing a traffic summons to another motorist.

title: Dorothy Alison Shannon Bride Of Jonathan Kingsbury Carter
description: RINDGE, N. H., July 8 The marriage of Miss Dorothy Alison Shannon to Jonathan Kingsbury Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Phelps Car ter of New Canaan, Conn., and Rangeley, Me., took place this morning in the Cathedral of the Pines. The Rev. Edwin P. Gohdin, a Methodist minister, per formed the ceremony.

title: RANGERS TOPPLE ORIOLES, 21, 31
description: BALTIMORE, July 8 (AP) Lenny Randle clubbed a three run homer in the eighth in ning to lead the Texas Rangers to a 31 victory over the Bal timore Orioles and a sweep of their doubleheader tonight.

title: Hard Rock in Poconos
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 8 A steaming hot soul group called Mother Night tore the lid off Concert 10 as rock started promptly at 1 o'clock this afternoon at the Pocono International Raceway.

title: Edward S. Cornell Jr., 80, Of American Radiator, Dies
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 8 Edward Shelton Cornell Jr., former vice president of the American Radiator and Stand ard Sanitary Corporation of New York, died Thursday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived in West port.

title: STATE WILL NAME CONSUMER CHIEF
description: Governor Rockefeller's office has announced that a suc cessor to Betty Furness as chairman of the State Con sumer Protection Board would be named in the very near future. The post has been va cant since July, 1971.

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH OVER EXPOS, 121
description: MONTREAL, July 8 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants backed Juan Marichal's first victory since June 2 with a 15 hit attack tonight that crushed the Montreal Expos, 121.

title: Bigger Budget Is Sweet Music for Arts
description: TRENTONThe New Jer sey Council on the Arts, which was established in 1967 with a budget of $125, 000, began its new fiscal year this month with a record sum of $445,000 to spend in en couraging the study, creation and presentation of artistic endeavors.

title: Soviet CivilRights Leaders Demand Bail for Dissident
description: MOSCOW, July 8 (AP)  Seven leading Soviet civilrights advocates have protested the arrest of Pyotr Yakir, an his torian, and have demanded that he be freed on bail.

title: LEITERS
description: Due to a new Federal regulation on computing in terest, New York City sav ings banks are announcing a ifew effective annual yield on savings accounts.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 8Pat McFarland, having dropped out of several, colleges, was selling pretzels and papers on Boston street corners last fall when she heard Senator George Mc Govern speak at a rally and endorse amnesty for draft resisters.

title: In Kabul, Connally Meets His Nov., '63, Dallas Doctor
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 8On Nov. 22, 1963, in the emergency room of Parkland Hospital in Dallas, Dr. James H. Duke plugged a bullet hole in the chest of John B. Connally, then Governor of Texas.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: A heterogeneous array of producers of Ice cream for the commercial market has materialized in this country since the end of World War II.

title: Just what the movement needed, an elder who isn't an adult
description: In one respect Herbert Marcuse's new book is simply a Marxist's anal ysis of the situation and prospects of the New Left in a time of not quitecomplete repression by a not yetFascist Establishment. In this respect the argument of the book can be summarized briefly: The ma jor threat to the capitalist system comes from militant students and blacks (to whom this book is ob viously addressed), rooted in the universities and ghettoes, whose task is to dispel the false and mutilated consciousness of the people so that they themselves experience their con dition ... and apprehend the ways and means of their liberation.

title: POLES EXHIBITING A POLITICAL PRIDE
description: WARSAW, July 8  A new political pride appears to be emerging in Poland, one largely evident in a shift of interest from domestic to foreign affairs.

title: The Guest Word
description: Most reviews are awfuldull, nerve less, beside the point of art, or prose, or even what an argument is Everybody knows this. Not everybody is entitled quite to say it. High quality in anything is infrequent. Nobody is obliged to like the classics. Everyone has the right not to be good at something. But reviews, unless you are devout about posterity, seem always to belong with the impre cise, the arguable, matters of opinion. Until, at a high or low period of critical discussion, you get an absolute standard setter, a piece that establishes its terms with an exemplary precision.

title: OBSERVER
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 8Here is the schedule of events for the Democratic National Convention during the com ing week:

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8A leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the guerrilla organization, was killed here today in an ex plosion in his car.

title: Mary Hickey Fiancee of Donald Weiss
description: JANESVILLE, Wis., July 8  Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hickey have announced the engagement of War daugh ter, Miss Mary Cathlin Meg han Hickey, to Donald Stew art Weiss, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alex Weiss of Roslyn, L.I. The wedding is planned for September at the chapel of the American University in Washington, where the prospective bridegroom is a trial lawyer with the Wash ington regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mary Davis Married To William D. Beebe
description: STERLING, Mass., July 8 Miss Mary Louise Davis, daughter of Mrs. George Shattuck Davis and the late Mr. Davis, was married this afternoon to William Dun ning Beebe of Annandale, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Greenleaf Beebe of Engle wood, N. J., and Cotult.

title: Music: New Brun swick Group a Hit
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A rock group, born at Rutgers University and developed at bars and fraternity dances in central Jersey, has just grabbed the brass ring on the pop music merrygo round and is enjoying its first taste of celebrity and potential fortune.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: ABOUT a month ago, before the latest international monetary crisis erupted, a leading Wall Street securities analyst issued a highly optimistic report on stock market prospects for the second half of the year. Then, one week ago, he backtracked consider ably and described himself as neutral about the outlook because of a new factorthe uncertainty after Britain floated the poundthat had entered the picture. But now, he said the other day, he is somewhat more encouraged again.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: It would be physically im possible and self defeating for someone as wellknown as you to convincingly play the part of a man whose historical truth was rooted in his blackness. Black peo ple's selfimage has changed greatly in the past 10 years; in the context of this ex panding black consciousness, your choice seems psycholog ically unhealthy.

title: STUDY FINDS BIAS IN NEWS OVER TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 8A survey of national television news programs accuses the three major networks of a significant degree of bias in their reporting of the Demo cratic primary campaign and the Vietnam war.

title: Peter Elbow Marries Miss Pelz
description: STEPHENTOWN, N. Y., July 8The marriage of Miss Caroline Campbell Pelz to Peter Henry Elbow, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. William El bow of Chilmark, Mass., took place here this afternoon.

title: Coins
description: NEXT Saturday, July 15, will be the last day for ordering the 1972dated Eisenhower proof dollars, it was an nounced by Mint Director Mary T. Brooks. Although collector interest has fallen off considerably since 1971 when the commemorative was introduced, a cutoff date was established to per mit Mint work on other col lector services.

title: ATHENAGORAS RITES TUESDAY IN ISTANBUL
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 8 (AP)Athenagoras I, the Ecu menical Patriarch, will be buried here Tuesday after funeral services, a patriarch spokesman said today.

title: Reds Top Cubs, 32, As Nolan Wins 12th
description: CINCINNATI, July 8Johnny Bench, the major leagues' lead er in runs batted in, drove home two runs with two singles and Gary Nolan, who became the National League's first 12game whiner, singled in one tally as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Chicago Cubs today, 32.

title: L.I. Man Killed and 7 Hurt In Mishap on F.D.R. Drive
description: One person was killed and seven others injured in a four car crash on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 49th Street last night, the police reported.

title: Smoke and Drums Mark Military Show
description: CROTON  ON HUDSON, N. Y., July 8There was alarming intelligence from Van Cortlandt Manor here today. Regiments of patriots and redcoats were encamped on a hillside overlooking the Hudson River. Cannon smoke shrouded the field. The air was filled with the sound of martial drums and the smells of musket powder.

title: DEADLINE IS SET ON PERON RETURN
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 8 President Alejandro A. Lanusse has given Juan D. Pern, the populist leader living in Spain, until Aug. 25 to return or lose his right to be a candidate in next year's elections.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a lifelong resident of Sunnyside Gardens (I grew up here, and when I married we purchased our own home in the neighborhood) I was pleased to see our commu nity reviewed in The Times [Sunnyside Gardens Holds Off the World, June 25.]

title: JOSEPHINE CRANE DIES IN FALMOUTH
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., July 8 Mrs. W. Murray Crane, a founder of the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and the Dalton School of New York, died of penurnonia tonight at Falmouth General Hospital. She was 98 years old and resided at her Gape Cod home in near by Woods Hole and at 820 Fifth Avenue, New York City.

title: Child to Mrs. Harkavy
description: A daughter was born June 26 to Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Harkavy of Fresh Mead ows, Queens, at Doctors Hos pital. Mrs. Harkavy, the form er Miss Roxine L. Lense, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Lense of Westbury, L.I., The child has been named Allison Leigh.

title: Native Trail, $6.20, Takes Stakes at Suffolk Downs
description: BOSTON, July 8 (AP)Afri can Queen, the 12 favorite, had trouble holding the racing strip and Native Trail sprinted to an easy victory today in the $5,920 New England Sopho more Stakes before a crowd of 10,585 at Suffolk Downs.

title: News of the Camera World
description: ASUPER 8 movie camera that features a 10to1 zoom lens and macro focusing (down to 5 inches) has been introduced by Honeywell Photographic Products, Box 1010, Littleton, Col. 80120. Called the Elmo Super 110, the camera has an f/1.8 lens that can be zoomed from 7 to 70mm (power or manual) and it of fers a choice of three speeds the normal speeds of 18 and 24 frames per second plus a true slow motion speed of 54 frames per second. The automatic exposure system (manual exposure is alsopossible) is designed to work with 50foot cartridges hav ing ASA daylight speeds of from 25 to 160, and the cam era is powered by four pen light batteries that operate the motor, the power zoom and the exposure system thus eliminating the need for a mercury cell. The Super 110 is priced at $499.50.

title: Giants Open Camp in Jersey Tuesday
description: The New Jersey phase of the history of the New York football Giants will begin on Tuesday, when both rookies and experienced players are scheduled to report for preseason training at Monmouth College in West Long Branch, N. J.

title: Movies
description: GUESS who's coming to the Met? Ingrid Bergman, that's who. But she won't have to fret about hitting those high C's, because she'll be playing the other Met the Metropolitan Museum. Miss Bergman has been signed to star in From the MixedUp Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frank weiler, based on Emily L. Konigsburg's 1968 novel about a wealthy woman who donates a mysterious, possibly Michelan gelic sculpture to the Metropolitan Museum. The adaptation has been written by Blanche Hanalis, and Fielder Cook will direct for Charles G. Mortimer Jr.'s Westfall Productions.

title: Miss Keiko Takeuchi Is Bride Of Gerald C. Harvey in Jersey
description: MOORESTOWN, N. 3., July 8  Miss Keiko Takeuchi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Toshio Takeuchi of Tokyo, and Gerald C. Harvey, son of Mrs. Peter G. Harvey of Moorestown and the late Mr. Harvey, formerly of London, were married here at noon today by the Rev. Canon Bruce A. Weatherly at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: U.M.W. Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) George J. Titler, a union coal field organizer, has resigned his post as international vice presi dent of the United Mine Workers. Mr. Titter, 77 years old, cited ill health as his rea son for stepping down from the union, in which he became a member in 1908.

title: HILL CIRCUS FIRST IN $64,600 RUE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 8 (UPI)Hill Circus, a star in England in 1971 as a 3year old, raced to her first American stakes victory today as she cap tured the seventh running of the $64,600 Beverly Hills Handi cap for fillies and mares on the turf at Hollywood Park.

title: Tokyo's U. S. Nine Opens Doors
description: LODI, Calif., July 8With one small Class A franchise in California, the Japanese have taken what some hope may be the first step toward a true World Series in base ball.

title: Jazz: Ellington Offers Own Festival at Carnegie
description: Duke Ellington held a festi val of his own yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Officially, it was part of the Newport Jazz Festival but when Mr. Ellington is in form he transcends every thing. He is, as he is fond of saying of a select few people, beyond category.

title: Theft Suspect Seized Again
description: WORCESTER, Mass., July 8 (UPDOne of four persons ar rested in connection with the $1million Worcester Art Mu seum robbery and then released on bail was arrested again yes terday as a suspect in a $10,000 bank holdup. The police said that David M. Aquafresca, 22 years old of Worcester, had been arrested shortly after four men wearing ski masks held up a branch of the Guarantee Bank and Trust Co.

title: Sara Shipley Affianced
description: MIDDLETOWN, Del., July 8Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Shipley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Wilhelmina Ship ley, to Dr. Charles Lynn Stone Jr., son of Mrs. Mary Chase Stone of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and the late Mr. Stone. Miss Shipley is a graduate of the Columbia University Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing. Her fianc was graduated from Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: World News Briefs
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 8  Troops were called out to day as violence spread through this city on the second day of demonstrations for making Urdu one of the official lan guages of Sind Province. Three demonstrators were killed by police fire in the suburb of Liaquatabad.

title: Public Defender to Get Help on Backlog
description: TRENTONWhen the na tion's oldest statewide Public Defender's Office passed its fifth birthday here last week end, its files bulged with roughly 25,000 pending cases  more than nine months' work for indigent defendants.

title: New & Novel
description: When Prof. Rodney Gorian rents an English country house for this summer, little does he know what a mare's nest he is about to share. An Orien talist and an ethical culturist, the professor intends to spend the season with his peevish mater, his three little boys, and a nubile mother's help named Stephanie. Rachel Van Bolen, his landlady, also lives on the premises and is badly snagged in a love affair with a Frenchman. (Rachel's con temptible American husband refuses her a divorce.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The recent Supreme Court ruling abolishing the death penalty will serve at least one very useful purpose in society. It will focus the attention of both proponents and opponents of capital punishment on the entire American legal system.

title: U.S. JUDGE DELAYS A POLLUTION CASE
description: HOUSTON, July 8  A Fed eral judge has held that the public interests in electric power and natural resources have balanced each other out in a complicated antipollution case. The effect of his decision was to postpone any final ac tion in tine vase for more than three months.

title: Guachero Takes Honors In Star Sailing at Sea Cliff
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 8 Alan and Bill Burtis's Gua chero was back in the Star Class winners' circle on Hemp stead Harbor today.

title: For a Princess in Exile, A Spartan Way of Life
description: SHENYANG, China (AP)  Princess Monique, the beauty queen who mar ried a prince and became the First Lady of Cambodia, is busier than ever these days working as a secretary for her exiled husband, Prince Norodom Si hanouk.

title: Bridge
description: MISFITS are a major nuisance to bridge players. To suffer a heavy penalty because your part ner turns out to be short in your long suits and long in your short suits is a common misfortune. The general rules for such situations are simple: When a misfit is evident bid with great caution; and if possi ble, let the opponents play the hand.

title: Colombia Trial Bares Life (Everyone Kills Indians) on Plains
description: VILLAVICENCIO, Colombia, July 6Out on the llanos, the vast prairies that stretch across Colombia and Venezuela from the Andes to the Orinoco, law lessness still reigns as it did in the old American West. Swashbuckling, cowboys and primitive Indians compete for life and over notions of right with the fast gun and the flashing Machete.

title: About a dogloving dog and a dog loving boy
description: When at last our canine hero con fronts his heart's desire, she tells him earnestly, That doll you have was mine when I was a child. I loved that doll and always had it with me. One day, when I'd grown up and decided I was no longer a child, I threw it away. I remember I was standing in a field thinking about life and about myself and about growing up. I became eager for the future and I felt the doll chained me to the past. So I got rid of it. But even while I was walk ing away from that field, I began to have doubts. I had been happy in my puppy days. Would I be a happy grownup?

title: COLBERT SPARKS PADRES' VICTORY
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (UPI) Nate Colbert drove in five runs, including two with a ninthinning homer, to lead the San Diego Padres to an 85 vic tory over the Philadelphia Phil lies tonight.

title: Rodolphe d'Erlanger, Banker, Weds Sarah Giles in England
description: LONDON, July 8  Miss Sarah Giles, an editor with Vogue magazine, and Rodol phe d'Erlanger, a banker with Lazard Freres & Co., the merchant bankers, were mar ried today in a combined Roman CatholicProtestant ceremony at St. Michael's Church in Withyham, Sus sex.

title: Miss Helen C. Little, Student, Bride of H. Bancel LaFarge
description: WEST HARTFORD, July 8 Miss Helen Crocker Little, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Mason Little Jr., was married here this afternoon to H. Bancel LaFarge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams LaFarge of New Canaan.

title: New & Novel
description: Mr. Edelman's novel revises my childhood impression that Disraeli resembled George Ar liss's who played him in the movies during my impression able years. (For me, Disraeli, Wellington and Rothschild would always have Arliss's long upper lip, just as, for another generation of filmgoers, Cae sar and Napoleon would enun ciate like Marlon Brando.)

title: Stamps
description: PERSONAL preference kits of the crew of Apollo 15 which landed on the moon July 30, 1971, contained, among other memorabilia for themselves and friends, 400 envelopes bearing U.S. stamps com memorating American space missionsin addition to the special cover of the U.S. Postal Service that the flight commander, David B. Scott, canceled before millions of television viewers on Aug. 2, 1971.

title: Flying Fortress in Museum
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 8 (UPI) One of the two known B17 Flying Fortress bombers has been added to the Air Force Museum at the WrightPatter son Air Force Base here. Offi cials estimated that it would take two or three years to re store the plane, called. Shoo Shoo Baby, as it was in Eng land in 1944 when ft was as signed to the 91st Bomb Group at Bassingbourne.

title: Reporters See Battered Town in North
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 8This correspondent and a group of other foreign news men were taken at dawn today to the town of Hungyen, 36 miles east of Hanoi, which was said to have been struck by American bombs yesterday.

title: MoslemChristian Strife in Philippines Brings Continual Bloodshed
description: MANILA, July 9A series of killings in southwestern Min danao this week has brought back to public attention the continuing strife between the Moslem and Christian popula tions of the southern Philip pines.

title: Thesis, analysis, diagnosisbackground reading for the Miami conventions
description: George S. McGovern is the only Ph.D. in the Senate, not to mention the Presidential race, and so the pub lication of his 1953 doctoral disser tationa chronicle of the barbarous battle over union recognition in the Colorado coal fields, building to the massacre of striking miners and the burning of their tent colony at Lud low on April 20, 1914makes the rarest sort of campaign document.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Parcel Post SpeedUp Planned in the West
description: WASHINGTON July 8 (AP)  A special train to speed up delivery of parcel post and other bulk mails in the West will begin operating July 15.

title: Direct U. S. Credit Controls?
description: The possibility of direct Federal regulation of a price most vital to the American economic system  the cost of credit  appears to have increased significantly in re cent weeks.

title: Tigers Lose to White Sox
description: CHICAGO, July 8 (AP)  Dick Allen raised his league leading homer total to 17 to day with a tworun, fifthinning wallop that helped the Chicago White Sox to a 52 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Miss Schwarga to Wed
description: WANTAGH, L. I., July 8 Miss Marilyn Jean Schwarga and John Thothas Roselli plan to be married Aug. 12. Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Schwar ga have announced the en gage of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Roselli of Allison Park, Pa. Miss Schwarga's father is general manager of the East Island News Company, a magazine distributorship in Happauge. Mr. Roselli's father is a tax accountant with the United States Steel Corpora tion.

title: Krueger Signs With 49ers
description: ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals will receive two high 1973 draft choices from the San Francisco 49ers as compensation for Rolf Krueger, a defensive endtackle, who signed with the 49ers as a free agent yesterday.

title: JEWS MAP STUDIES BY A THINKTANK
description: A series of studies dealing with various issues that affect American Jews will be under taken by the Synagogue Coun cil of America.

title: China Again Hints at Talks With Japan
description: TOKYO, July 8Peking indi cated again today that the Chi nese would quickly become im patient if the new Japanese Government of Premier Kakuei Tanaka did not take early ac tion on normalizing relations.

title: Baghdad Recognizes Dacca
description: BAGHDAD, Irag, July 8 (Reu ters)The Iraqi government has decided to recognize, Bang ladesh, the official Irag press agency reported today. Irag is the first Arab country to recog nize Bangladesh, the republic that emerged from what was East Pakistan after the India Pakistan war late last year.

title: WHAT ABOUT OPERA?
description: With reference to Ellen Holly's assertion that An thony Quinn should not play a black man's role, I wish to state that Mr. Quinn played the role of a Filipino guer rilla fighting the Japanese in the movie Back to Bataan, and I found him to be very good. I know, because I come from the Philippines.

title: Where to Go at 3 A.M.? Why the Supermarket, of Course
description: TEANECKThe Pathmark supermarket is the latenight place to be, especially on a Friday night.

title: Experimental Theater Relates to L.I. Youths
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.  It was definitely not a case of love at first sight and sound. It wasn't loathing, ei ther. The selfconscious twit ters echoing through South ampton College's Fine Arts Theater suggested instead a mild state of confusion.

title: Colleges Add Chinese Courses
description: Courses in Chinese have been added to the curriculum and Russian has been dropped, the New York City Community College in Brook lyn reports. A petition ask ing for Chinese studies was circulated at the school and signed by 1,170 students. The Faculty Council recently approved the addition of the courses.

title: KNICKS' BARNETT SIGNS FOR '7273
description: Dick Barnett, 15th among the National Basketball Asso ciation's career scorers and the fourth highest point producer in the history of the New York team, has signed to play for the Knicks in the 197273 sea son, it was announced yes terday by Red Holzman, gen eral manager and coach.

title: Out in Space, $30.20, Beats Favored Chou Croute in Molly Pitcher Handicap
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 8 Chou Croute weakened under her 124pound burden and lost by half a length to Out in Space, a long shot, in the $45, 275 Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

title: Judith Bayard Shinkle Married to Stuart Ladd
description: ST. LOUIS, July 8Miss Judith Bayard Shinltle, a greatgranddaughter of Ham ilton Fish, Secretary of State under President Grant, and a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, the last Dutch Governor of New York, was married here this afternoon to Stuart Mitchell Ladd, who is descended from Charles Pratt, founder of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

title: Vitamin Lack Causing, Anemia, ne Found Troubling Paolo Ricans
description: One of every two Puerto Rican women living in New York City suffers from de ficiency of a Vitamin called folic acid, which plays a key bio chemical role in forming red blood cells and other body cells, according to a leading medical journal.

title: Bennett and Foster Capture Olympic Finn, Tempest Berths
description: MARION, Mass., July 8 (AP) Ed Bennett of San Francisco and Glen Foster of New York sailed to secondplace finishes and United States Olympic berths today in the windup of final trials in the Finn and Tempest classes on Buzzard's Bay.

title: Stabilizing Korea
description: The surprise Fourth of July agreement in Korea to renounce the use of force and negotiate a stable accom modation between the Communist North and capitalist South promises to terminate the world's most dangerous confrontation within a partitioned country.

title: Record Flood Loss
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The American Red Cross re ported today that floods in 11 states and the District of Co lumbia caused a record loss in June, damaging 110,325 homes and directly touching the lives of more than 500,000 persons.

title: B52's Land on Okinawa; Japan Cautions on Visits
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)B52 bombers landed on Okinawa to day and the Japanese Govern ment told the United States Embassy that it would not be desirable for B52 visits there to become routine, a Japanese spokesman reported.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: It was an intellectual thrill to read Anthony Quinn's dignified and com passionate rebuke to Ellen Holly's vulgar and racistly pompous protest against his portraying Henry Chris tophe, If she's so set on pre senting an image for young black boys to emulate, there are Martin Luther King, Malcolm X. Franz Fanon, Cas sius Clay, Justice Marshall and an unjustly ignored black heavyweight, Tiger Flowers. Far greater men than the Haitian revolters who committed horrible and inhuman atrocities against the wives, daughters and in fants of the French colonists.

title: In Jersey, Horses Are Big Business
description: PISCATAWAYBy 8:30 in the morning, the trailers had bucked their way through the muddy aftermath of the tropical storm called Agnes and were parked every which way in Johnson Park, a thin band of green here between the Raritan River and River Road.

title: EXPLOITATION?
description: If you film Christophe's life without the support of the black community, you will only be exploiting us, for the vast majority of your viewers will be white. If you are truly our brother, produce the film with an entire black cast and crew. I believe this would lead to a greater ac complishment for you.

title: The Nation
description: They came by the thousands last week to Manhattan for the first sub way series of the transplanted Newport Jazz Festivalthe curious, the nos talgic, the dedicated.

title: Garden Nuptials For Elsa Nagle And a Urologist
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 8The marriage of Miss Elsa Vera Nagle to Dr. Joseph Biddle Priestley Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Priestley of Des Moines, Iowa, took place here this afternoon.

title: Iron Workers? Union Ordered To Admit Minorities for Jobs
description: A local construction union has been ordered by a Federal judge here to adopt new mem bership rules designed to end what he called a pattern and practice of discrimination against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: COUNCIL APPOINTS 4 ELECTION AIDES
description: The City Council has reap pointed three commissioners of the Board of Elections and named a fourth commissioner to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Maurice J. O'Rourke.

title: Gail Bussmeir Wed to Ophthalmologist
description: IOWA CITY, July 8Miss Gail Marie Bussmeir, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Bussmeir of Seattle, and Dr. John H. Mensher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira W. Mensher of Brooklyn, were married here this evening by Rabbi Jay Holstein at the University of Iowa Danforth Chapel.

title: M'ANDREW VICTOR
description: What had been a tautly con tested game yesterday in Shea Stadium between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Mets became a wild affair in the eighth inning.

title: Saints March Wednesday
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP) Coach J. D. Roberts begins his second full year as head coach of the New Orleans Saints Wednesday with plans to greet 34 rookies and 27 experienced players at the start of training camp. The rest of the 47 play ers from the 1971 squad were scheduled to report to the Hat tiesburg, Miss., base July 16 for physicals.

title: Collection of Rare Books On Display at the Vatican
description: ROME, July 8 (UPI)  The Vatican has put on display 150 rare and precious books some of them printed before Colum bus discovered America.

title: Views of the Review
description: Robert Alden's useful report on the United States and the United Nations in The Week in Review June 11 does not, however, draw the main and necessary conclusion with sufficient force. This is that the United States, having lost control of the United Na tions, is now essentially disinterested in it. Unless the United Nations can be manipulated to serve narrow State Department goals, the United States will go elsewhere.

title: 2 House Leaders Say Peking Fears A Pullback by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The House Democratic and Republican floor leaders, who returned yesterday from a visit to China, said today that Peking was concerned about a Soviet arms buildup and a possible American withdrawal from the Pacific and other regions.

title: Brookner Calls Post At L.I.U. Challenge
description: After almost 20 years as an admintstrator and educe tor at New York University, Dr. Lester I. Brookner says he is ready to fly by him self.

title: One Comic Who Wants to Be Funny
description: IT seems almost unfair to review Woody Allen. In this day and age anyone who can produce actual humorous humor ought to be placed in a jar in the Library of Congress, fed delicate sweetmeats and set out to stud revered, as a national resource, an endangered species, a grim reminder of the way things aren't any more. When vaudeville died in the thirties as a breeding ground for humor we should have expected this drought. When the spoken word faded out of radio at the end of the forties, when TV executives began their tawdry affair with Mr. Nielson, when Bob Hope achieved senility and found that warriors were his best audience, we should have known. The Borscht Belt now wafts a long line of initiates along a familiar road to Las Vegas, by way of the Tonight Show and mediocrity. The coffeehouse circuit, drying up, sup plies' TV talk shows with lowkeyed monologue writers urbane, pleasant, but not funny. In movies, only Elaine May and Woody Allen survive as reminders of what Hollywood humor lost when its training camps folded.

title: Insect Stings Peril the Allergic
description: A Long Island man was cut ting his grass a few Weeks ago when a yellow jacket, whose lunch was disrupted by the lawmmower, stung the man on his leg Within minutes, he collapsed and soon lapsed into a coma. He was rushed to a hospital, where his life was saved by a shot of adrenalin.

title: Swift and Snickenberger
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Ed Swift, a junior goaltender from Lake Forest, Illinois, and Walt Snick enberger, a sophomore center from Ithaca, N. Y., have been elected cocaptains of Prince ton University's 197273 hoc key team.

title: Happy Days For Cotton
description: EVANSVILLE, Miss.Ster ling W. Owen 3d, a well edu cated young farmer with a gift for laughing at himself, admitted as he surveyed his greening riches recently that if the weather stayed good, if Congress did not raise the minimum wage for farm workers or lower the subsidy to farm owners, if he could keep the bollworm at bay and if some other calamity did not occur, this would be a good year for cotton.

title: Argentina Takes Jumping At Aachen
description: AACHEN, West Germany, July 8 (UPI)Argentina won a team jumping event against the clock today, at the Aachen horse show. The victorious squad, consisting of Argentina Molinuevo on Guante Blanco, Jorge Llambi on Charly and Dr. Hugo Arrambide on Mio Mio, clocked an aggregate 183.7 seconds to the United States' 186.6.

title: Views of the Review
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Pirates Subdue Braves, 53, With 3 Unearned Runs for Blass's 10th Victory
description: ATLANTA, July 8 (AP)  Willie Stargell singled home the deciding run in the fifth inning tonight and Steve Blass re corded his 10th victory as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Atlanta Braves, 53. Three of the Pirate runs were unearned.

title: REPORT PROPOSES REVISION OF TOLLS
description: A major revision of the toll system here was proposed yes terday by the Citizens Union to ease traffic problems and raise additional revenue for both highways and mass transporta tion.

title: A.E.C. Hearings End, But There'll Be More
description: TRENTON  The Atomic Energy Commission was here for four days of hearings on plans for a nuclear power plant, and its visit figured to be the first of many.

title: Impact of Controls: Business as Usual
description: Many of the nation's larg est corporations have been almost totally unaffected by the Nixon Administration's wage and price controls pro gram, according to a survey of major companies across the country.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  How Friedmanite is the Fed?

title: For Showmobile, Township's a Stage
description: BROOKHAVEN, L.I.This sprawling township's ubiqui tous Showmobile has em barked upon its third sum mer of travels in an area embracing 220 square miles (from Cedar Beach on the North Shore to Patchogue on the South Shore).Robert E. Reid, a Councilman, and Mr. Poulos saw an op portunity to make the pro grams readily available throughout the township by acquiring a Showmobile. It was delivered in midsummer in 1970, and was used two nights a week for five weeks.

title: Georgian Church Elects
description: MOSCOW, July 8  The Council of Bishops of the Geor gian Orthodox Church has elected Metropolitan David as the new Catholicos, or head of the church, Tass the Soviet press agency, reported from Tbilisi. He succeeds the late Ephraim II, who had headed the church since 1960.

title: Yablonski Case Witness Held in Seclusion on Farm
description: PITTSBURGH, July 8A spe cial prosecutor said today that the woman who confessed and gave state's evidence in the slaying of a United Mine Work ers official was being held in seclusion on a Fayette Coun ty farm at a cost of $1,000 a month.

title: INDY 500 WINNER OUT FOR 15 WEEKS
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., July 8 Surgery performed today on Mark Donohue revealed leg in juries that will keep the race driver out of competition for approximately 15 weeks.

title: QUANGTRI DRIVE IS STILL STALLED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 9  South Viet namese troops were still stalled outside the provincial capital of Quangtri yesterday, held off by intense enemy artillery and mortar fire.

title: 200,000 Jam Rock Festival at Pocono Track
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 8 An estimated 200,000 young people jammed the Pocono In ternational Raceway today for a rainsoaked, oneday rock music festival the biggest youth gathering in the East since Woodstock three years ago.

title: Yugoslavia Gets U.S. Credits
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 (AP)The United States Gov ernment has approved a $40 million credit, to Yugoslavia for purchases of American agricul tural surpluses, it was reported today.

title: 2 Jets Lost, U.S. Says
description: SAIGON, July 8 (Reuters) Two United States Phantom jet aircraft were shot down by North. Vietnamese MIG21's northeast of Hanoi last Wednes day, the United States command reported today. The four crew men are listed as missing.

title: A high intelligence at work carelessly
description: Presumably, Joyce Carol Oates eats, sleeps, looks out the window and takes an occasional drink, but it is hard to know when, how or why. In the last few years she has published more than any other serious writer in America: two volumes of poetry, three collections of stories, five nov els and now a work of criticism, The Edge of Impossibility, nine essays on what she calls tragic forms in literature, all effortlessly well read and knowledgeable about authors ranging from Shakespeare to Ionesco. There is enough reading, writing and general hard work in this book alone to justify the last five years, over the course of which most of these pieces were published. It begins to look as though Joyce Carol Oates's own life may be lived on the edge of impossibility. And thereby, further more, may hang a tale.

title: Jersey Cuts Health Costs By Stressing Home Care
description: PRINCETON  Medicare in New Jersey costs less than the national average because emphasis is put on health care at home, according to a new report by the New Jersey Health Association about the Federal health and hospital insurance program for people at least 65 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The controversy about scattersite housing will not be solved by the simplistic conclusions reached by Martin Hochbaum in his arti cle (ScatterSite Approach Is Faulty, June 18].

title: A Collector Who Takes The Funnies Seriously
description: I've had a new neighbor in Forest Hills since February bat, until he put up a sign a couple of weeks ago, I really didn't know what to take of him.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Very often mystery writers  especially British mystery writers  give us books that defy any easy category. Strict ly speaking, they may come under crime or suspense, in that there may be horrible things building up to an un expected denouement. But the plot in these cases is a hook on which to hang a study of character or situation, and the crime itself is merely an al legory of the human condition.

title: Chinatown Leader Is Stabbed to Death in Robbery
description: Hung Moy, a 48yearold bus inessman and community lead er in Chinatown, was stabbed to death early yesterday by three youths during a robbery in a garage across the street from the Fifth Precinct police station.

title: The Nation
description: The two skyjackers were holding a Pacific Southwest Airlines 737 jet with 86 passengers and crew hostage at San Francisco International Airport last Wednesday. The two, who had entered the United States in 1968 as political refugees from Bulgaria, de manded $800,000 in ransom and a flight to Siberia. Somebody had to make a decision, said Robert Geb hardt, the agent in charge of the F.B.I.'s San Francisco bureau. We wanted to stop the hijacking, and stop it we did. The toll: Three dead.

title: U.S Helps Poor to Rent Own Homes
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 8Out of the worst slums of Kansas City, the Federal Government has taken 205 families, handed them rent money and told them to find better housing of their own choice.

title: Nesa Hassanein Plans Marriage
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 8 Miss Nesa Hassanein, a sophomore at the University of Kentucky, plans to be mar ried Aug. 19 at the West chester Country Club in Har rison to Michael McGee, a Kentucky alumnus.

title: Pincay Thrown in 9th Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 8 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. was thrown hard from Happy Be have during the ninth and final race at Hollywood Park today and taken to a hospital.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., July 7When fuel oil accidental ly began flowing into 32 milelong Lake George last May, one of the most dis tressed local citizens was Jean Flacke. Mrs. Flacke, mother of four, was certain the season's angling was about to be ruined.

description: DETROIT, July 8Lesley Yves Crosson, slumping in her straightback seat in huge Cobo Hall, raised her pink voting card at the signal by William Ming, Chicago attorney.

description: CHERRY HILL, July 8Ed win James Grace, the man who the police say killed six men and wounded six others before he turned a gun on himself dur ing a shooting spree June 21, died today at Cherry Hill Medi cal Center.

title: ZORA FOLLEY, BOXER WHO FOUGHT ALI, 41
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 8 (UPI) Zora Folley, a long time heavyweight boxing contender and the last man to fight Mu hammad All before he was stripped of his crown, died early today after striking his head on the edge of a swim ming pool at a motel. He was 41 years old and lived in Chan dler, Ariz.

title: Jesse Jackson: I Am... Audience: I Am... Jesse: Somebody Audience: Somebody
description: The service has been going on for almost two hours, Tom Todd telling of the school crisis, Ed Riddick of the welfare crisis ... songs by the Peo ple's Choir, the selfassured young black men and women, dressed in black, singing gospel music as well as it is sung anywhere in this country ... searing, wailing music by the Gentlemen of Soul band, piano, organ, guitars, saxophones ... Satur day morning meeting in the South Side, the best free show in Chicago and perhaps in America ... a true American experience ... so moving, as the choir and the band build, that chills run up one's spine.

title: The World
description: ROATAN ISLAND, HondurasIt is an intriguing idea, of course, especially for Columbusbaiters or anyone who ever wonders just what went on in the New World for the thousands of years before Europeans started arriving in the 16th Century.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (Reuters)A Chinese freighter was identified on Thursday night about two miles off the North Viet namese coast unloading cargo into barges that were ferry ing it to shore, the United States command said today.

title: The World
description: TOKYOKakuei Tanaka is a breezy, energetic, fasttalking extroverta poor farm boy with only primary and vocational school education who worked his way up from a job as a Tokyo contractor's helper to become a millionaire businessman and politi cal luminary. Last week, at the age of 54, Mr. Tanaka became the first man of the masses in modern history to become Premier of Japan.

title: CAPTURED WEAPONS SOUGHT BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, July 8 (AP) The Israeli Government has be gun a campaign to retrieve privately held illegal weapons captured from the Arabs in the sixday war of 1967.

description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 8Today's Wimbledon tennis final between Stan Smith and Ilie Nastase was postponed until tomorrow by rain.
