M., July 12 (UPI)An explosion rocked the large fireworks manufacturing plant of the Longhorn Manu facturing Company yesterday, killing five employes and starting a fire that destroyed half the building. The victims were Rosendo Martinez, 31 years old; Priscilla Fuentes, 32, and Frances Regaldo, 21, all of Dexter, N. M., and Betty Abila, 21 and Lucy Lueveno, 23, of Roswell.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Thursday, HYANNIS, Mass., Thursday, July 13Senator Kennedy said at an early morning news con ference at a Hyannis motel to day that he had told Senator McGovern that he was hon ored and humbled by the offer but for overriding personal considerations had had to de cline.

title: Search for S.I. Girl, 5, Joined by Bloodhounds
description: Aided by bloodhounds and a helicopter, the police combed mosquitoinfested swamps yesterday near the Tysens Park Apartments in the New Dorp section of Staten Island, looking for a missing 5yearold girl. But they failed to find any clues.

title: Wheat Crop Down 5 Per Cent
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Agricultu're Department estimated today the 1972 wheat crop at 1,551,000,000 bushels, down 5 per cent from last year's record harvest.

title: Pennsy Is Granted a Crew Reduction
description: A Federal judge in Philadel phia yesterday granted trust ees of the bankrupt Penn Cen tral railroad permission to re duce freight train crews from four men to three.

title: Peep Shows and Massage Parlors Are Targets in City's Intensified Drive to Clean Up Times Square
description: In its latest effort to improve the character of the Times Square area, the city has be gun to forge new legal weap ons. It says that police action has already reduced street crime and prostitution. Pornog raphy is the next target.

title: Col. Worden to Be Reassigned From Post in Astronaut Corps
description: HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI) Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Warden of the Air Force, reprimanded yesterday for permitting the sale of unauthorized stamped and concealed envelopes that he and two other astronauts took to the moon last July on the Apollo 15 mission, will be reassigned from the as tronaut corps to another posi tion with the space agency, NASA announced today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: An Olympic record in hyperbole is unfailingly set every four years at the conclusion of the track and field tryouts determining United States representatives for this most glit tering of international sports spectacles. Partly from force of habit and partly from the enthusiasm of the moment, the track nuts soar off into the wild blue yonder and exclaim, This will be America's greatest Olypmic team.

title: TEACHERS AND CITY WILL BEGIN TALKS
description: The Board of Education and the city teachers' union are ex pected to begin negotiations by early next week on a contract to replace the one expiring Sept. 8.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The General Cinema Corpo ration yesterday announced that certain shareholders were considering an offering of about 325,000 common shares and added that the company, sub ject to approval by the board of directors, was planning to participate to the extent of be tween 75,000 and 100,000 shares. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, was down 1 at 51 at the close of trading yesterday.

title: Airlines, in Flight of Fancy, Offer Under26 Travelers Rock and Organic Food
description: On Pan American's Flight 92 from New York to Am sterdam these Tuesdays, Brian Wallace, Harvard '71, plays the guitar, the stereo system sends out hardrock music and organic break fasts are served.

title: Yale Express Plan Ordered
description: The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York signed an order yesterday approving a previ ously announced plan for the reorganization of Yale Express Systems, Inc.

title: Film: Elsa's Cubs Pad In:' Living Free' Tracks Trio Raised by Humans
description: For some reason, the British sponsors of the popular "Born Free" have waited six years to dispatch a sequel. But all that really matters is that the sequel, "Living Free," is excellent screen fare for children.Remember Elsa the Lioness, the one raised like a house pet by the Adamsons, the enterprising British couple in Africa? Virginia McKenna and Bill Travers have now scooted out of the picture as the couple. A new pair of actors, Susan Hampshire and Nigel Davenport, spend the new picture fretting over Elsa's three cubs, protecting the growing trio even during hunger raids and finallyand about timecarting them off in a distant game preserve for safety.A prologue, with the two new stars, neatly recaps the first movie, introduces the baby cubs (their papa slinks off) and has Elsa (or her double), expiring as regally as Garbo in "Camille."The early scenes are best, with the three cubs tentatively on their own and edging into the wilds, treed by a fierce mother rhino, routing a python and being cold-shouldered by other animal species. The color is really lovely; the terrain looks as African as can be and there is one magnificent sweep of flapping flamingos blotting the horizon.As cubs, especially, the trio are spunky, fascinating critters to watch. For that matter, the charming Miss Hampshire (of television's "The Forsyte Saga") and Mr. Davenport are natural and winning. However, sharp-eyed youngsterswhether or not they saw "Born Free"may wonder about the childless couple's kindly obsession, the only word, with these hulking beasts.Furthermore, the action turns rather tedious toward the end before the grown animals are trucked to safety 700 miles away. "Born Free" history is repeating itself and the freshness and novelty wear thin. Still, these are enterprising, well-meaning adults, the animalsall of them  and the exotic scenery are diverting and the picture is clean as a lion's tooth, not that we've ever crawled up close for a look. "Living Free" is close enough to sensible entertainment for the children  and bright ones, too.

title: French Chefs in San Francisco: There's Always Room for Two More
description: SAN FRANCISCORen Verdon, a former White House chef, and Charles Chevillot of New York's La Petite Ferme Restaurant recently added new dimen sions to this city's roster of French restaurants.

title: Credit Markets
description: New York City raised $267.2 million yesterday in a bond sale that for the second time in two years drew an invalid bid from a group led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: TOKYO, July 12 (AP)Sixty one persons are known dead, 23 are missing and 11 have been injured in floods and landslides resulting from threeday rain storms in southwestern and central Japan, the national police agency said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Some years ago I served on Gov ernor Hughes' Commission to Evaluate the Capital Needs of New Jersey. Consequently, I have been very inter ested in Governor Cahill's socalled Master Plan for Tax Reform. I re gret to say the Governor's plan does not in my mind soundly meet the needs of New Jerse.

title: Student Corporation Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was studying the proposed set tlement in the case in which National Student Marketing Corporation is accused of vio lation of securities laws.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 New York's delegation to the Democratic National Conven tion, unlike the perennially di sheveled state party it repre sents, has proved to be a near model of unity, purpose and decorum in the deliberations so far.

title: Summer in Paris
description: WASHINGTONThe greatest test of imagination for the Nixon Administra tion at the present time will be for it to negotiate a settlement of the Viet nam war while it thinks it is winning.

title: British Panel Calls for Legislation to Protect Privacy
description: LONDON, July 12A Gov ernment committee proposed a series of measures today to safeguard individual privacy, including a law against private use of electronic and other de vices.

title: Gunman Terrorizes IRT Train On West Side, Then Disappears
description: An armed man stalked through an express train on the West Side IRT last night, and while several passengers were fleeing him in terror, another passenger was allegedly robbed of $10 by a youth who said he was carrying a pistol in a bag.

title: Braniff Traffic Up 15.3%
description: Braniff International reported yesterday that passenger traffic in June increased 15.3 per cent over the corresponding month a year earlier, exceeding any single month in the 44year history of the airline. The com pany said that it flew 441.8 mil lion revenuepassenger miles in June, up from 383 million miles in June of last year.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 12 (UPI)Omar Pabst resigned today as captain of the Chil ean Davis Cup team, which is to face the United States in the American Zone final here July 21 to 23.

title: ERHARD WEYHE, ARTBOOK DEALER
description: Erhard Weyhe, one of the last of the great art book deal ers and founder of E. Weyhe, Inc., of Lexington Avenue, died Tuesday at his summer home at Digby, Nova Scotia. He was 89 years old.

title: Consumers Urged To Shun Concerns Without Licenses
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs warned buyers yester day to shun the wide variety of unlicensed businesses operating in the city.

title: 200 East Harlem Youth Demonstrate at City Agency for More Summer Jobs
description: Two hundred East Harlem youths demonstrated at the Youth Service Agency offices yesterday, complaining that some of their share of city sum mer poverty jobs had been al located to the Bronx to pacify youth gang members there.

title: WALLACE H. MARTIN; HEADED LAW GROUP
description: KOKOMO, Ind., July 12Wal lace H. Martin, a past president of the New York Patent Law Association, died here yester day. He was 77 years old and lived in nearby Alto.

title: Heavy Fighting Reported At 3 Points Near Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 13South Viet namese marines and airborne troops clashed heavily with de fenders on three sides of the provincial capital of Quangtri yesterday the Saigon com mand said its troops had de stroyed more than 20 enemy tanks, but indications were that Government forces had lost some ground.

title: TAX REFUND AIDS MARINE MIDLAND
description: Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a big Buffalobased bank hold ing companyy, reported yester day that its net operating earn ings in the first half of the year were $21.1million, or $1.62 a share, essentially un changed from the first six months of 1971. The company's pgofits would have declined substantially except, for the fact that it was able to claim a $1.1million income tax refund this year in contrast to Feder al tax payments of $2.7million in 1971.

title: Soviet Dooms 5 in Crimea Found Guilty of Collaborating With Nazis in War
description: MOSCOW, July 12  Nearly 30 years after the German oc cupation, Soviet firing squads are still executing citizens found guilty of war crimes while collaborating with the Nazis in World War II.

title: 2 GET JAIL TERMS IN AIR PIRACY CASES
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 12 (AP)  Two men convicted earlier of attempted extortions against airlines were sentenced in Federal District Court today. Sentencing for a third man con victed of air piracy was post poned.

title: Exchange Board Still Without a Head
description: The newly restructured board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange convenes this afternoon for the first time  without a new chairman and with few indications of progress toward finding one.

title: Stottlemyre Tops Angels By 50
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 12 The New York Yankees ended their most successful trip of the season tonight by defeating the California Angels, 50, and reached two shortrange goals the .500 mark in playing per centage and their third straight series victory in the West.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Thursday, July 13The Alabama legisla tor who announced his state's votes in the Democratic con vention's Presidential nomina tion last night said early today that Gov. George C. Wallace had asked him to announce that he would not run as a third party candidate this year.

title: News of Dogs
description: In her home community of Carlisle, Mass., and through out New England, Mrs. Mar guerite Grant is known as a top breeder of Siberian hus kies. Her dogs have won fame both in sledracing and in the show ring.

title: BLACK SAFARI 300 A SOULFUL HISTORY
description: The airconditioning didn't work last night at the May fair Theater, a comfortable basement auditorium at 235 West 46th Street. But Safari 300 worked well indeed. Much of this show, a self styled musical experience of 300 years of black culture, song and dance, works bril liantly. See it.

title: On Convention Floor: The New Spirit of '72
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 At 7:40 tonight, a Wallace supporter in a gaudy outfit parades around the conven tion hall clanging people over the head with a giant bell. Two elderly delegates wear ing Jackson boaters foxtrot in the aisle.

title: Gift for Retirement Helps Arizonan to Measure Winds
description: SUN CITY, Ariz. (AP) Howard Russell measures winds as a hobby, using an anemom eter given him when he re tired.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With the announcement of United States grain sales to the U.S.S.R. and the sale of Boeing 707's to the People's Republic of China I think back on the domino theory argument of Dean Rusk and the Johnson Administration.

title: Nicklaus Shoots 70 and Trails Tupling by Two in British Open
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 12Jack Nicklaus came down the long 18th hole of the Muir field course tonight needing a par 4 to tie for the lead in the first round of this 101st Brit ish Open. Jack's drive was well placed on the left side of the fairway and his approach struck the green, hole high, and then slid over the side into a deep bunker. The shot was next to impossible. He got it out but there was no way to stop the ball in the downwind on this fast green. Nicklaus need ed two putts from 15 feet for his 5 and a oneunderpar 70.

title: PROTESTERS FIND CANDIDATE FIRM
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12Sen ator George McGovern appeared before a group of angry young demonstrators in his Presiden tial campaign headquarters here tonight to assure them that he was not shifting my positions on any of the fundamental stands that I've taken in this campaign.

title: Penn Central Hearing Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (UPI)A Federal judge has set a hearing for July 31 on a plan by the Penn Central railroad to sell 93.5 acres in the Buf falo area to a real estate de veloper. The trustees said that about 36 acres of the vacant land were in the city of Buffalo and 57 acres were in the ad joining town of Cheektowaga, N. Y.

title: DIO AND 4 OTHERS ACQUITTED OF FRAUD
description: A nineweek trial on stock fraud charges ended in Fed eral Court here yesterday with the acquittal of five defendants, including John Dioguardi, a re puted labor racketeer known as Johnny Dio.

title: Advertising:
description: Apparently old is not such a bad word these days, at least to marketers who hope to cash in on the much publicized nostalgia craze. That's why Purex is re packaging Dutch Cleanser and going back to the orig inal name Old Dutch. It is also bringing back the trademark and the slogan Chases dirt.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fish Famine
description: MONTAUK, L.I., July 12 Suddenly the piscatorial pick ings at this usually reliable angling outpost on Long Island's tip have slumped. Local captains are walking around the docks wondering whether the finny fellows are on a hunger strike.

title: Matlack Wins 9th on 4Hitter As Mets Down Giants, 4 to 0
description: With only nine healthy bodies available by the end of the game to play eight posi tions, the Mets concluded their worst homestand in a year yes terday with a 40 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: STATE SEEKS RISE IN U.S. TRANSIT AID
description: The State Department of Transportation called on Con gress yesterday to increase transportation outlays to the state by at least 37 per cent. Otherwise, it warned, New York will not even be able to meet minimal needs over the next 20 yearsneeds whose costs are estimated at $26.5 billion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The plight of the school system in New York City and the problems facing our teachers throughout the state re quire more elaboration than was presented in the July 3 editorial Total Control for the U.F.T.?

title: Business Briefs
description: The net inflow of deposits into the nation's thrift institutions apparently continued to slow during June. According to the Savings Banks Association of New York State, savings banks herewhose deposit trends often give a good clue to national flows of fundsgained $124million in deposits last month, down 14.8 per cent from the record $146million increase in June, 1971.

title: Standard International Acts
description: The Standard International Corporation has announced that it has accepted tenders of 1,355,000 of its common shares at $21 a share in an offer it initiated June 19.

title: International Paper Net Up 27% In 2d Quarter on 9% Sales Rise
Business Inventories Show Biggest Gain in Two Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Total business inventories in creased in May by the largest amount since mid1970, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Schumann, Back Home, Says Peking Aide Will Return Call
description: PARIS, July 12  Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann re ported today on his return from a visit to Peking that Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei of China accepted an invitation to Paris and would probably make the trip late this year.

title: Poor Diagnosis Brings Suit
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 12 (AP)Mrs. Dorothy Hill has filed a $125,000 malpractice suit against four doctors she says incorrectly diagnosed her condition and operated on her for gallstones when instead she was pregnant with a 15th child. The suit, filed in Sacramento County Superior Court Monday, says a son was born even though the plaintiff and her husband already had 14 chil dren between them, and neither of them wanted another child.

title: Coalition of Protest
description: In its recordbreaking allnight session on platform, the Democratic convention made a useful start toward dem onstrating the party's desire to serve as a bridge between the established elements in American society and the millions of society's outsiders. The clear effort was to show that the party can accommodate new groups and ideas while still exercising responsible restraint.

title: Use of Toxic Bombs Denied By U.S. Sources in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 (UPI)Military sources to day denied a Vietcong charge that American planes were dropping toxic or poisonous bombs in South Vietnam.

title: Amex Declines in Late Trading; Index Dips 0.16, Closes at 27.01
description: It was a slippery last hour for the American Stock Ex change trading yesterday, with the index moving down quite sharply in that space of time to 27.01, off 0.16. Perhaps one of the reasons was the trad ing of a block of 249,800 shares of House of Fabrics at 12. It closed later at 12, off 1.

title: Personalties: For Wottle First a Walk, Then a Run
description: Following thoughful con sultations with his parents and fiance, David Wottle, the outstanding middle dis tance runner, decided yes terday upon the following course of action: He will be married this weekend and he will compete in both the 800meter and 1,500meter races in the Olympic Games in Munich. The Bowling Green, Ohio, runner tied the world record of 1 minute 44.3 seconds in winning the 800 at the Olympic trials in Eugene, Ore., last week as Jim Ryun finished fourth. Then Ryun won the 1,500 trial with Wottle second. At first Wottle did not want to run anything but the 800 at the Olympics. But I came back from the Coast with my parents and fiance and they wanted my to try both. There were a lot of people out there who wanted me to run in both, too, so I will. The athlete, who wears a worn golf hat while running, did not elaborate on just who convinced him that this weekend was the right time for marriage.

title: 2 WELFARE CRITICS COOL TO NEW UNIT
description: Two frequent critics of the city's welfare administration reacted coolly yesterday to State Controller Arthur Levitt's proposal that Governor Rocke feller name a highlevel team to resolve disputes over the ex tent of ineligibility among relief recipients.

title: F.T.C. Adopts Consent Bar Against Spiegel Loan Unit
description: The Federal Trade Commis sion has tentatively adopted a consent order barring Fairfax Family Funds, Inc., a mailorder loan subsidiary of Spiegel, Inc., Chicago, from using deceptive promotional materials and vio lating the TruthinLending Act.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company has ordered four nuclear turbine generators from the Westinghouse Elec tric Corporation, the company announced yesterday Pittsburgh.

title: Job Law Aids Handicapped
description: BOSTON, July 12 (AP)A bill forbidding employers to dis criminate against the handi capped was signed today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts. The law forbids employers to refuse a job to or to dismiss a handicapped person solely because of the handicap if the applicant has the physical and mental capaci ties for the job.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: PEKING  There is a sense of anticipation in China this summeranticipation that by autumn there will be an an nouncement or an event clari fying what might be described as the third phase of the Cul ?? Revolution. Any effort to understand the direction of China's move ment today, both externally and in ternally, must be gin with the Cul tural Revolution, a vast and almost tidal phenom enon that many Chinese frankly concede they, do not entirely understand.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12Following is a summary of the major actions taken by the Democratic National Convention:

title: Lazrus Marks His 85th Birthday With $ 100,000 Gift to End Bias
description: Oscar M. Lazrus, secretary of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, took the occasion of his 85th birthday yesterday to announce that he was making a gift of $100,000 for a Center for Interreligious Affairs to combat antiSemi tism and bigotry.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Rudi Gernreich took his time about it, but he has finally joined the parade of fashion designers who have plunged into the home fur nishings field.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOSCOW, July 12 (UPI)Vladimir Kovalev, a bronze medal winner at this year's world figure skating champion ships, has been thrown, off the Soviet national team for being drunk in public, the newspaper, Sovetsky Sport, re ported today.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 Senator George McGovern's overall record in public life is basically that of a conven tional liberal.

title: Fall's Retail Outlook Appears Brighter
description: Seventh Avenue is hot and relatively quiet in the sum mer, the recent flood of out oftown buyers having waned to a trickle.

title: Market Place : Old Bear Raid In a New Skin
description: You might call it a sec ondary dip in the pool. It's certainly a new version of the old bear raid in which Wall Street professionals sold stock short in huge quantities then covered their positions at the depressed prices they had brought about them selves.

title: Dance: Surprise Debut
description: The official premiere given by American Ballet Theater at the New York State Thea ter on Tuesday night was Victor Gsovsky's Grand Pas Classique. The unofficial premiere was a new produc tion of Fokine's Les Syl phides that the company had never even mentioned.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Laird white flag reaction to Senator McGovern's alternate defense budget was predictable, but it is sur prising at the least to find adherents of the center and even liberal wing of the Democratic party also express ing deep misgivings. Large numbers of experts ranging from longtime con sultants to the Defense Department (like the present authors), former high D.O.D. officials (like Rathjens, Ravenel, Halpern, Warnike), a former Director of Defense Research and En gineering (York), a former high C.I.A. official (Scoville), a former Presidential Science Advisor (Kistiakowsky), have all publicly supported the soundness of McGovern's proposals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your excellent June 30 editorial The Key to Vietnam confirms some views I heard various officials express when I was in China in June.

title: REPORTER ABUSED, PATROLMAN SAYS
description: NEWARK, July 12  Pa trolman James Collins testified today that he had heard Dr. E. Wyman Garrett tell Fox But terfield, a reporter for The New York Times, to give me that piece of paper at a Board of Education meeting that broke up in chaos here 15 months ago.

title: Bridge: Fun City Regionals Serve As TuneUp for Nationals
description: Many New York experts who will be seeking national titlesand indirectly interna tional honorsat the Amer ican Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Denver later this month will be sharpening their partnerships at the Fun City Regionals, which begin tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: 3 Democrats Ask Ethics Study On Beach Purchase by Suffolk
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 12Three of the Democratic members of the Suffolk Coun ty Legislature said today That they would ask the County Board of Ethics to investigate the conduct of R. Thomas Strong, a fellow legislator, in connection with the county's purchase of 11,000 feet of oceanfront property at Tiana Beach here.

title: CHILDREN'S TV UNIT SET UP AT HARVARD
description: The Children's Television Workshop, producer of Sesame Street, and Harvard University have announced the establish ment of the Center for Research in Children's Television to ex plore the effects of visual media on children.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12The most important fact about the 36th quadrennial Democratic National Convention  aside from its choice of Senator George McGovern as the party's presidential nominee  is this: For all the fears and fore bodings, it did not turn into another Chicago. Mr. McGovern provided a vivid symbol of contrast, probably quite con sciously. He de scended to the lobby of his hotel to speak calmly and publicly wtih a small band of protesters. Four years ago, on a similar night, Hubert H. Humphrey watched from his hotel suite as demonstrators and troops battled in Grant Park far below him.

title: Insurer Talks Broken Off
description: The Southwestern Life Insur ance Company disclosed last night that it had broken off negotiations to merge with the Mutual Savings Life Insurance Company of Alabama for about $52million in stock. Mutual Savings is controlled by Louis J. Roussel, a New Orleans bank er. Southwestern said an audit of Mutual Savings failed to show the company would have been as profitable as originally anticipated when the transac tion was made last April.

title: Roundup: Bench's Bat Keeps Booming as Reds Win
description: Much of the talk in visit ors' dugouts is about Johnny Bench's comeback this sea son. The Cincinnati Reds' catcher, who has been at the top and near the bottom during his five major league seasons, looks again like the star of 1970 when he was named the National League's mostvaluable player. That year he drove in 148 runs, hit 45 home runs and batted .293.

title: SO. AFRICA WINS DAVIS CUP ENTRY
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 (Reuters)South Africa gained readmission to the Davis Cup tennis tournament today, and the agreement between Lamar Hunt's World Championship Tennis organization and the International Lawn Tennis Federation was ratified.

title: THIRD OF BLACKS LIVE IN POVERTY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Onethird of the nation's 23 million blacks lived below the official poverty level in 1971, marking little change from a year earlier, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Iowan Retiring as Publisher Takes a Page From Start
description: WEBSTER CITY, Iowa (AP) On his retirement as pub lisher, W. J. Carmichael took a broom and swept out the back shop of the Webster City Daily FreemanJournal.

title: Nastase Is 62, 61 Victor In $30,000 Swedish Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania, beaten last week by Stan Smith of the United States in the Wimbledon final, scored a 62, 61 firstround victory over Sweden's Jan Zabrodsky in the $30,000 Swedish international tennis championships today.

title: OYSTER BAY CREW WINS L.I. REGATTA
description: RYE, N.Y., July 12The SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club crew of Oyster Bay, L.I., captained by Mrs. W. Perry Neff, recaptured the women's Long Island Sound champion ship off American Yacht Club today as the 39th annual Syce Cup regatta ended.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had made an apparent major oil discovery off shore Nigeria in the Niger River Delta area. In a production test, the wildcat well, 90B1, flowed oil at a rate of 9,200 barrels a day from a zone located at a depth of 9,300 feet.

title: AMEX NAMES GROUP TO NOMINATE BOARD
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had appointed an eight member nominating committee to pick 20 candidates for a new board of governors under a plan of reorganization that is sched uled to become effective this fall.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: Following are excerpts from statements by Senator George McGovern on a num ber of issues:

title: INDIA, PAKISTAN LOWER BARRIERS
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 12while debate continues in the National Assembly over ratification of the Simla peace agreement, Pakistan and India have begun cooperating on a number of smaller problems, including flood control, border passage for tourists and com munications.

title: Kennedy Informs Nominee He Won't Be Running Mate
description: MIAMI BEACH, Thursday, July 13Senator Edward M. Kennedy turned down an offer this morning to run for Vice President on the ticket headed by Senator George McGovern. Mr. McGovern said through a spokesman here that he had made the offer in a telephone conversation with Mr. Kenne dy after receiving the Presi dential nomination at the Democratic National Conven tion.

title: A Study on Bangor As Gateway Airport Fought in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, July 12 (AP)  The Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce has filed a pro test with the Civil Aeronautics Board over a study on Bangor International Airport in Maine as a gateway to Europe.

title: Soviet Museum Said to Oust Aide Seeking Visa to Israel
description: LONDON, Thursday, July 13 Leonid Tarassuk, curator of the department of European and American arms and armor in the Hermitage Museum, Len ingrad, has been dismissed be cause he applied for a visa to Israel, according to a letter in The Times of London today.

title: Longshoremen in Hawaii End a TwoDay Walkout
description: HONOLULU, July 12 (AP) Longshoremen here ended a twoday walkout their union said was intended to bring con tract negotiations to a head.

title: Brewer Bankruptcy Petition
description: CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) Meister Brau, Inc., a brewing company, has filed a petition in United States District Court for voluntary reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws. The petition listed assets and liabilities at $23,510,512 as of May 31.

title: John R. Tench, Engineer And Inventor of Grating
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 12 John R. Tench, a construction and mining engineer and inven tor, died yesterday at his home, 11 Queen Lane. He was 71 years old.

title: ASTORIA IS TAKEN BY QUEEN'S MARK
DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 Senator George McGovern and black leaders who supported him have worked out an agree ment that pledges the appoint ment of blacks to the Supreme Court, 10 per cent of Federal job patronage within the states, and money for voter registra tion in black areas, in return for the leaders' backing of his candidacy for the Presidential nomination.

title: Foremost Names President
description: Thomas E. Drohan has been named president of Foremost Foods Company and executive vice president of ForemostMc Kesson, Inc., the parent com pany. He succeeds Kenneth W. Ward, who is retiring after 46 years with the company and president of the subsidiary since 1970.

title: 13 Are Killed in Crash Of a Swiss Cable Car
description: SION, Switzerland, July 12 (UPI)  An aerial cable car sped backward out of control today and smashed into the cable station it had left min utes before, the police said.

title: Dance: A Diluted Swan
description: AMBLER, Pa., July 12 With a cast led by Dame Margot Fonteyn, the Vienna State Opera Ballet presented its production of Swan Lake last night as its second and final program here at the Temple University Music Festival.

title: JERSEY NOTES RISE INPROPERTY TAXES
description: NEWARK, July 12  New Jersey's property taxes, the backbone of the state's revenue system, rose again this year, but not as sharply as in the past.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 (AP)One of the 102 Massa chusetts delegates to the Democratic National Con vention lost her job because she won a delegate seat, but she has no regrets.

title: PHILLIPS WITNESS TELLS OF THREAT
description: A nervous and sometimes tearful former prostitute testi fied yesterday that on the night before James Smith, a pimp, and Sharon Stango, a prostitute, were murdered, Patrolman Wil liam R. Phillips threatened to kill Smith if Smith failed to make a payoff.

title: Dim View of Airline Strike
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) A Federal mediator says he is becoming extremely pessi mistic over the lack of prog ress in negotiations between Northwest Airlines and the striking Air Line Pilots Asso ciation. Harry Bickfod said the discussions were stalemated. He said a major stumbling block was group life and hospi talization insurance. The pilots struck June 30.

title: SCHOOLING IS ISSUE IN ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12The capacity of the jurors in the Pentagon papers case to read and comprehend the volumi nous secret documents became an issue today as the trial judge questioned prospective jurors for the third day.

title: Ohio's Residency Statute On Welfare Ruled Invalid
description: CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) A threejudge Federal panel struck down as unconstitutional today an Ohio statute requiring a year's residency to become eligible for welfare relief.

title: 7 Indian Militants Jailed
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., July 12 (UPI)Seven members of the American Indian People a mili tant Indian rights group, were sentenced to 30 days each in the Coconino County jail yes terday after pleading guilty to reduced charges. The seven, ar rested at a Southwest Indian meeting over the Fourth of July weekend, pleaded guilty to charges of trespassing, disturb ing the peace and assault and battery. They had been charged with rioting and inciting to riot.

title: Planners Cut LowIncome Units In Battery Park City Proposal
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday reluctantly ap proved an amended develop ment plan cutting sharply the number of lowincome units in Battery Park City, the huge housing development planned for Lower Manhattan along the Hudson River.

title: Nicklaus Minds His Steps: 32 Behind Bunker on 18th
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 12On the 15th hole today in the British Open, Jack Nicklaus walked quickly through the rough, looking into the kneehigh grass where spectators were point ing. He stopped and peered at his ball.

title: G.M. PLAYS DOWN WANKEL REPORT
description: The General Motors Corpo ration sought yesterday to soft pedal the adverse reaction cre ated by published reports of its studies of the Wankel engine. The stock of the CurtissWright Corporation has fallen in one week from a new high of 59 to 36 in yesterday's trading on the Big Board. Curtiss Wright licenses the engine.

title: 30 REPORTED KILLED IN IRAQIKURD CLASH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 Thirty people were killed in fighting between the Kurds and the Iraq Army in northern Iraq earlier this month, according to informed travelers from Bagh dad.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, July 12 (AP)Three major companies of the giant Mitsubishi group have asked Peking for approval to send a mission to China. The three companies are Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsu bishi Bank. Japan's trade with China, with which Tokyo has no diplomatic relations, is conducted on a private basis.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Chicago Bears will be going to their training camp at Rensselaer, Ind., tomorrow with a new coach, Abe Gib ron, and without an old quar terback, Jack Concannon. The 29yearold Concannon, with eight pro seasons behind him, has nowhere to go except to check out an assortment of business enter prises that in clude the three North Side sub urban restaurant lounges in which he has an interest. Each is called The Some Other Place Pub Concannon and 37 others in the National Football League exercised the option clauses in their 1970 con tracts and became free agents last May 1 with the idea they then would sign to play for some other team at a higher salary.

title: Imperial Oil Sees $4Billion In Sales of Its Natural Gas
description: Imperial Oil, Ltd., an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said yesterday that its previously reported contract to sell natural gas from the MacKenzie Delta area in the Northwest Canadian Arctic to United States pipeline concerns could be worth an estimated $4billion over the 22year life of the contract.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is traditional for the Oriental to wish to save face. While we want to get out of Vietnam gracefully, we refuse to let the enemy engaged in a civil war do likewise.

title: Israelis Accept Confession of Terrorist
description: TEL AVIV, July 12 (AP) A military court agreed today to admit in evidence a confes sion by Kozo Okamoto, the sur viving member of the three man Japanese terrorist squad responsible for the Tel Aviv airport massacre on May 30.

title: Rock Fans Set for Stones to Roll In
description: Larry Turner of the Bronx will be 17 on July 27. But more important to Larry now is the fact that he has front row tickets for the July 24 Rolling Stones concert at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pakistani Dies in New Clash Over Sind Language Issue
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 12 One person was killed and three were seriously injured today when Urduspeaking people clashed with Sindhi speakers in the town of Dadu, 150 miles north of here, the Pakistani radio reported.

title: Piper Lists Storm Damage
description: The Piper Aircraft Corpora tion, controlled by the Bangor Punta Corporation, estimated yesterday that the tropical storm called Agnes had caused $23million in flood losses at its plant in Lock Haven, Pa. It said it might recover a maxi mum of $5million in insurance and tax benefits and be oper ating normally by Sept. 30.

title: Britain's Floating Pound Gains Strength in London
description: LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) Britain's floating pound gained strength on the London foreignexchange market today, picking up half a cent to close at 2.4465 against the dollar.

title: Notes on People
description: If the eyes did not deceive, the rapport of spring sum mitry was out the window and the shoepounding diplo macy of Nikita S. Khrushchev was back in fashion. There stood Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador, clutching a boulder as though ready to smash it down on the curly head of Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser. Throw it at me, dared Mr. Kissinger in a display of brinkmanship. Mrs. Dobrynin, holding a camera, prepared to record the decline and fall. But the eyes did deceive. The boulder was made of sponge rubber and packed as much menace as Godzilla.

title: Last Chance for Peace
description: The resumption of the Paris peace talks today opens what is probably the last effort by both sides to end the Vietnam war before the American elections.

title: 5 Free Concerts, Pop to Classical, Are Set for Mall
description: A new series of five free sum mer concerts will be offered at the Central Park Mall, near 72d Street, starting Monday, the city announced yesterday.

title: ULSTER PARADERS DISPLAY POWER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12  Pounding drums and gripping swords and flags, near ly 100,000 men marched through out Northern Ireland today in a vivid display of Protestant power. The day was marked by violence.

title: Mrs. Philip Timberlake, President's Aunt, Was 92
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 12 (AP)Mrs. Edith Timberlake, maternal aunt of President Nixon, died of pneumonia last night at the Riverside Commu nity Hospital. Her age was 92, and she was the wife of Philip Timberlake, a retired entomol ogist.

title: Huntington Schools Ordered to Achieve A Racial Balance
description: ALBANY, July 12The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, ordered a Hunting ton, L. I., school board today to redraw attendance zones for eight elementary schools be cause enrollment in them was racially imbalanced.

title: HARTFORD FIRE IN TIE WITH TOKYO INSURER
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has decided to go after a slice of the rapidly developing insur ance market in Japan, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Lauren D. Lyman
description: Thirtyfive years have marched past since Deac Lyman stopped chronicling the birth of aviation for The New York Times and moved into active association with its commercial and military development as an officer of United Aircraft. Both journalism and the world have changed enormously in that period, but the imprint of his passion for accuracy and thoroughness remains a lustrous element in this newspaper's heritage.

title: The Washington Daily News Ceases Publication
description: WASHINGTON. July 12The Washington Daily News, one of the capital's two afternoon newspapers, announced today that it was immediately ceas ing publication and selling its name and some other assets to its principal competitor, The Evening Star.

title: STOCKS AGAIN SLIP AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: Bursts of selling in Curtiss Wright and in airline issues jolted the stock market in late trading yesterday as prices fell again amid a pickup in the trading pace. CurtissWright plunged 9 to 36.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DUBLIN, July 12 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong of Aus tralia, who lost her Wimbledon title last Friday, played two matches today to gain the quarterfinals of the Irish open tennis tournament. Miss Goolagong, who left London last night after attending a garden party at Buckingham Palace, beat Dorothy Armstrong of Ireland, 62, 61, and Tam O'Saughnessy of Fullerton, Calif., 61, 63.

title: A STUNNING SWEEP
description: MIAMI BEACH, Thursday, July 13George Stanley Mc Govern was proclaimed the Democrats' candidate for Presi dent here early this morning to complete a stunning sweep of the party's processes and na tional convention.

title: Business Briefs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company an nounced yesterday the opening of a new international operating center in Denver to handle overseas calls.

title: Saigon May Get Improved U.S. Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Nixon Administration, con cerned that the scope and char acter of the North Vietnamese offensive have pointed up cer tain weaknesses in South Viet nam's longterm ability to de fend itself, is looking for ways to shore up its defenses.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 McGovern forces succeeded today in heading off another bruising floor fight and fur ther split in the Democratic party by agreeing to a two year delay in sweeping party reforms.

title: OBSERVER
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12The usual terrible things are already being said about the qualities that won the Demo cratic nomination for George McGov ern: that he and the agents of the new politics, whatever that is, are cool, tough, professional, hardnosed, ruthlessly efficient, brilliantly organ ized, and so on, and on, and on.

title: Merger News
description: The Loews Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had sold a block of 1 million shares of the Franklin New York Corporation  the parent com pany of the $3.3billion Frank lin National Bank  to Fasco International Holdings, A. G., which is wholly owned by Michele Sindona, an extremely wealthy, but lit tleknown, Ital ian financier. The sale price of $40 a share, or a total of $40mil lion, was $8.25 higher than Franklin's losing bid price in the over  the  counter market of $31.75 yesterday. Business as sociates of Mr. Sindona in New York said yesterday that on oc casion in the past he had rep resented financial interests of the Vatican. There was no in dication, however, that Mr. Sin dona was acting other than for himself in his purchase of shares in Franklin. The sale came at a time when the Fed eral Reserve Bank of New York had been looking into Loew's more than 20 per cent owner ship of Franklin New York.

title: Advertising:
description: There is some talk going aroundbut no proofthat certain ground rules of the Price Commission might pro vide a windfall of billings to some agencies before the year is out.

title: Man in the News
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12 George McGovern is subtler than most politicians, yet he is the least mysterious of menalmost a disappoint ment, it seemed at the begin ning, to partisans and pun dits who had come to expect profound complexity in can didates like Eugene J. Mc Carthy and Rob ert F. Kennedy and Presidents like Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nix on. An hour's conversation with the South Dakota Sen ator, yesterday or a year ago, would give a stranger much the same picture of him that close associates have.

title: Paris Court Jails Corsican As Heroin Supplier to U.S.
description: PARIS, July 12 (Reuters) A Corsican alleged to have been a major operator in the smug gling of heroin into the United States was sentenced by a Paris court today to five years in jail and fined 3,516,000 francs ($675,000).

title: C.B.S. Goes Afield For President, 37
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System Inc. yesterday an nounced the election of Arthur R. Taylor as president and a member of the company's board of directors. The 37yearold Mr. Taylor is executive vice president and chief financial of ficer of the International Paper Company.

title: Child Abuse Hearings Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) Representative Seymour Hal pern, Republican of Queens, to day urged Representative Wil bur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, to hold hearings on legislation to combat child abuse  the leading cause of death among youngsters under 5. In a letter to Mr. Mills, chair man of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Halpern said action must be taken... to prevent the continued pro liferation of child abuse and to treat the sick individuals who commit such atrocities. Mr. Halpern is sponsoring a bill to aid states that set up antiabuse programs.

title: Fischer Walks Out, Comes Back, Loses
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 12  Bobby Fischer lost the first game of his world cham pionship chess match with Boris Spassky tonight after staging a 35minute walkout.

title: Experts Expected Fischer Defeat at Adjournment
description: LOS ANGELES July 12 (AP) When Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky resumed play in the second session of their first match game for the world chess championship, it was clear to the experts that Spas sky should win.

title: McGovern Forces Shape Planks to Suit Candidate
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12In an 11hour session that ended at sunrise today, the Democra tic National Convention reject ed strong efforts to write into the party platform a series of New Left stands on such is sues as abortion, homosexual rights, tax reform and guar anteed income. The forces of Senator George McGovern were firmly in control.

title: SILVER PRICES UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: In extremely heavy trading, silver futures rose sharply yes terday on the New York Com modity Exchange.

title: AGNEW SCORES FOES OF SST DEVELOPMENT
description: Vice President Agnew ac cused leading Democratic Sena tors and The New York Times yesterday of engaging in a crusade against progress by op posing the development of the supersonic transport plane.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Charisma, a Class B yacht sailed by Jessie Phillips of Dayton, Ohio, was reported in the lead yesterday as the competitors went into the last third of the course in the 2,700mile ocean race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain.

title: Homex Asks Status Change In Bid for Reorganization
description: The Stirling Homex Corpora tion asked the Federal District Court in Rochester, N.Y., yes terday to appoint a trustee under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company had announced on Monday that it would file under the less stringent Chapter XI and thus seek to keep operating with Chapter XI protection from creditors.

title: Six Groups Share $2Million in Grants For Aid to Theater
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has made grants totaling more than $2million to six organi zations for theater activities, four of them based in New York. The grants are the largest quarterly appropria tions for theater made by the foundation since its cultural development program began in 1963.

title: Nixon to Ask $1.81Billion to Aid Flood Victims in SixState Area
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 12Homeowners and business men in a sixstate area dam aged last month by Tropical Storm Agnes would receive up to $5,000 each in an outright grant from the Federal Govern ment to make repairs to their property and replace damaged belongings, under legislation proposed today by President Nixon.

title: ' The Godson' (No Relation to 'Godfather') Opens
description: The American title, "The Godson," is not only meaningless, it is misleading, since it suggests a relationship with Mario Puzo's "The Godfather" that doesn't exist. Although the film contains very little dialogue, the dubbed English soundtrack is most disorienting. Among other things, it gives you the feeling that Paris has been occupied by body-snatchers, some of whom sound like New York cab drivers and some like bottom-rung nightclub comedians imitating Charles Boyer. But don't be put off."The Godson," which opened yesterday at the Juliet I Theater is actually "Le Samourai," Jean-Pierre Melville's immaculate 1967 French melodrama about the life and death of a hired killer, whose code of honor is no less rigid, romantic and (in our eyes) absurd than that of the Bushido of Japan.In Melville's world, Jef Costello (Alain Delon) is a beautiful misfit, an individualist who remains outside a society of complicated interdependencies, a performing artist who expresses himself entirely in terms of the grace and efficiency of his services. He makes $4,000 a contract, yet he lives in seedy solitude, in a high-ceilinged, almost barren room he shares with a caged bird. There's a shower in the kitchen and, in the closet, a couple of well-cut dark suits, a black dress topcoat, a trenchcoat and a gray fedora. Nothing else. He has a mistress of sorts (Nathalie Delon), but he apparently sees her only when he needs an alibi.The story of "The Godson" is the story of Jef's last contract. It has the form of a conventional policier, about the loner in conflict with both the law and the syndicate that hired him. The form, in fact, is so conventional, so full of the set pieces that are obligatory in this kind of film (the midnight poker game, the chase through the subway, the encounter with the beautiful woman of ambiguous loyalty) that "The Godson" comes close to being parody.The dreadful dubbing reinforces this impression, as does the stoicism of Jef under the most extraordinary circumstances, as if the expression of surprise would be a capital sin.Melville's interest, however, is the form, which is that of the American gangster film rediscovered and refined to reflect no special real world but a world of moral systems working at cross purposes, like a telephone switchboard gone haywire. At the center of "The Godson" is a man of almost loony implacability, who, when he fails, doesn't hesitate to commit his own kind of hara-kiri.In France, Melville is regarded as the patron saint of what was once called the nauvelle vague. He has made 12 films sines 1947, only one of which ("Doulos, The Finger Man"), as far as I can learn, has been commercially relased in this country. "L'Aine Des Ferchaux" was shown as "Magnet of Doom" at the first (1963) New York Film Festival but was badly received because of the anachronisms in its pretended American setting."The Godson," with Delon doing what he does best (looking impassive and slightly tarnished), is a lovely introduction to the work of a most idiosyncratic filmmaker. If you have any doubt about this, just compare "The Godson" withsayanything by Henri Verneuil ("The Burglars," "The Sicilian Clan," etc.), whose films draw on the same sources as Melville's but, in spite of a lot of jazzy claptrap, haven't a single thought among them.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12  Two members of a black sepa ratist movement were charged with gun law violations today after they had been arrested by the Federal and state au thorities at Senator George Mc Govern's hotel, the Doral.

title: SHULTZ SEES DECLINE IN RETAIL MEAT COST
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, predicted today that retail meat prices in the United States would level off next month and then decline as a result of increased imports from foreign suppliers.

title: CLAMPED
description: A man may smile and smile and be a Virginian or a Pennsylvanian or even a New Yorker. But does a Virginian smile like a Penn sylvanian or a New Yorker?

title: Two 727 Jets Hijacked; $1.1Million Is Demanded
description: A National Airlines 727 jet bound from Philadelphia to New York was diverted back to Phil adelphia International Airport last night by two hijackers de manding three parachutes and $600,000, including $20,000 in Mexican pesos.

title: U.S. Disclaimer Ordered
description: BOSTON, July 12The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ordered the Gov ernment today to file a dis claimer stating that electronic surveillance had not been used in its case against a 30yearold Harvard professor who has re fused to answer certain ques tions before a grand jury in vestigating the release and distribution of the Pentagon papers.

title: Olympic Five Off for Hawaii
description: The United States Olympic basketball team, which can't find anyone to play against on the mainland during the summer months, is leaving today for Honolulu, which is dotted with Armed Forces bases and willing competi tors.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: 4 Political Leaders Killedin Guatemala; A Boy Is Also Slain
description: GUATEMALA CITY, July 12 (Reuter)Gunmen assasinated four leaders of Guatemala's governing National Liberation Movement today and killed the sevenyearold son of one of them, police sources said here.

title: Remember the Pinafore? It Hasn't Vanished After All
description: Figuring that in every shirt andjeans wearer there lurks an oldfashioned girl with a mind for frills, Marion Moore has come up with an idea to pull them both together. It's a pinafore, with or without ruffles, that Marion Moore does in denim, dotted swiss or plaid taffeta.

title: Wall Street Flights to Downtown Philadelphia Begin
description: Downtowntodowntown air service, long a dream of busy commuters, became a reality yesterday with the inaugura tion of hourly seaplane flights between Manhattan and down town Philadelphia.

title: Democratic Choice
description: The nomination of Senator George S. McGovern for the Presidency of the United States by the Democratic National Convention is much more than a remarkable personal victory for a man of proven courage, determina tion and political skill. It marks the triumph of new forces within the Democratic party that, depending on the wisdom with which they are deployed, could either restore the party to national poweror possibly wreck it.

title: Personal Finance
description: Insurance companies have been so vigorous in weeding out thousands of unwanted policyholders and insurance agents in the last few years largely because of heavy losses on the sale of auto and homeowner coverage  that the industry is for the most part showing substantial prof its today.

title: INDIA WON'T YIELD PAKISTANI P.O.W.'S
description: NEW DELHI, July 12Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today ruled out an early return of the 93,000 Pakistani prisoners held in Indian camps for more than six months.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: BATON ROUGE, July 12 (UPI)Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana, who walked out of the Democratic National Con vention when it appeared Sen ator George McGovern was as sured of the nomination, said today he would remain aloof during the campaign and pre dicted President Nixon would carry Louisiana in November.

title: Saigon Officers' Hostility to Foreign Newsmen at Peak
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12The hostility of many Vietnamese military men to ward foreign newsmen has reached a new high.

title: Namath Gets Week Delay In Reporting to Jet Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 12 Joe Namath has received permission to report a week late to the Jets' training camp at Hofstra University.

title: U.S. CRIME UP 1% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Statistics on serious crime around the country for the first quarter of this year registered an increase of 1 per cent over the like period last year. That is the lowest percentage in crease for the quarter in 11 years.

title: Cambodia Destroys Opium Seized From an American
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 12 (UPI)  The Cambodian Government burned nearly 400 pounds of confiscated opium as United States Embassy officials looked on today to show its support of President Nixon's antinarcotics campaign.

title: RANGEL CLAIMING HARYOU CONTROL
description: A slate associated with Rep resentative Charles B. Rangel claimed a sweep in voting re sults yesterday that would give it control of the oftenwarring Haryou community corporation.

title: California Picks Insect
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 12 (UPI)A bill naming the dog face butterfly the official state insect passed the California Leg islature yesterday. The orange and black butterfly, officially called Zerene Eurydice, was first recommended as the state insect in 1929 by entomologists. It is found primarily in coastal areas from San Francisco to the Mexican border.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: Following are the measures that Senator George McGovern considers the most important he has sponsored during his years in Congress:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In 1955 President Eisenhower pro posed the Open Skies armscontrol agreement consisting of a plan to open up the entire Soviet and Ameri can landmass to mutual aerial inspec tion and thereby reduce the danger of surprise attack. The Open Skies plan was conceived at a time when the strategic bomber was the only method of nuclear delivery.

title: 32 Perish in Luzon Floods; The Toll in Japan Put at 61
description: MANILA, Thursday, July 13 President Ferdinand E. Mar cos declared a state of emer gency in Luzon today as flood waters inundated large areas. Thirtytwo people have died and the number of homeless was estimated by the Red Cross at 7,000.

title: Down From the Bottom
description: New York State, which a few years ago gave signs of leading the nation in statutory safeguards against the degradation of migratory farm laborers, now seems bent on moving in the opposite direction. That is the only conclusion to be drawn from Governor Rockefeller's appointment of Assemblyman Frank A. Walkley as State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

title: New Breed and Old
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12  On the morning after the full California dele gation was restored to George McGov ern, Assemblyman Willie L. Brown, the impressive young black who is one of its leaders, was praising the Cali fornians for their cooperation and co hesiveness in the floor fight.

title: Leonid M. Shevchenko Is Dead; Chief Adviser to Pod gorny, 59
description: MOSCOW, July 12Leonid M. Shevchenko, chief adviser to President Nikolai V. Pod gorny of the Soviet Union, died yesterday after a long ill ness. He was 59 years old.

title: Topper's Chief Confirms S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Henry B. Clarke Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Topper Corporation, con firmed yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Com mission was investigating the company.

title: ONEIDA INDIANS LOSE LAND CASE APPEAL
description: The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday upheld a lower court's rejection of two Indian tribes' claim to land in the New York counties of Madison and Oneida.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 501, Believed a Military Craft
description: MOSCOW, July 12The So viet Union today launched the unmanned spacecraft Cosmos 501, believed to be a military support craft.

title: Court of Appeals Refuses To Lower Bremer's Bond
description: RICHMOND, July 12 (UPI) The United States Court of Ap peals for the Fourth Circuit re fused today to lower the bond of Arthur H. Bremer, the ac cused assailant of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rooftop parking for 1,000 cars will be provided at the new passenger ship terminal under construction on the Hudson River between 47th and 52d Streets, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Two contracts totalling $4.3million have been awarded for construction of the roofs of Piers 88, 90 and 92 to hold the cars. The terminal is scheduled for completion in the spring of 1974.

title: U.S. Disputes French Newsman on Bombing of Dikes
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Ther Defense Department and a French correspondent in North Vietnam were in sharp dispute today over whether United States planes deliberately bombed dikes yesterday near a village 37 miles southeast of Hanoi.

title: S.E.C. Proposes New Rule For Fund Incentive Fees
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed yesterday a new rule aimed at correcting imbalances in incentivefee ar rangements between mutual funds and their advisers.

title: JOHN F. O'BRIEN, 86, REALTOR IN JERSEY
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 12John F. O'Brien, a retired realestate broker and tax as sessor, died today in a nursing home in Cedar Grove. He was 86 years old and lived at 174 South Orange Avenue.

title: White Consolidated Officer
description: CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) Roy H. Holdt, 51, was named today president and chief oper ating officer of White Consoli dated Industries, Inc., of Cleve land. Mr. Holdt, who has been with White Consolidated the past 16 years, replaces William H. Johnson, who died June 1. Mr. Holdt previously held the position of executive vice president.

title: Justice Aide Named
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 (UPI)President Nixon named today Roger C. Cramton of Ann Arbor, Mich., to be Assistant Attorney General in the office of legal counsel. Mr. Cramton, 43 years old, succeeds Ralph E. Erickson who was named recently Deputy Attorney General in the Justice Department shakeup that followed John N. Mitchell's departure and Richard G. Kleindienst's elevation to Attorney General.

title: Angry Methadone Patients Rifle A Private Clinic That Is Closing
description: A group of angry patients at one of the city's largest privately run methadone clinics ransacked its daily supply of the heroin substitute yesterday after learning that the clinic planned to close down tomorrow.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA ASurf fishing is generally thin, but fishermen near The Ridge have been pulling in blues of 12 to 15 pounds with smelts and bunker backs. Bottom fishing for sea bass of ordinary size has been good. Clams and squid have proved the best bait. Occasional fluke of varying size are in the southern end of Barnegat Bay.

title: Hanoi Delegate's Attitude Said to Please U.S. Side
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The State Department said today that it could draw no initial encouragement from what it called the pretty stiff statements made by the North Vietnamese and Vietcong at the Paris talks, which resumed this morning.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Two men arrested yesterday at Senator George McGovern's hotel here were identified today by the Secret Service as Wayne Harris Foster, 32 years old, and Jessie Dixon, 33.

title: C.&0.BAO. PAYMENT SOUGHT BY PENNSY
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company have asked the Federal District! Court in Philadelphia to permit them to withhold payment of funds the railroad owes the Chesapeake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio railroads to settle interline balances. Generally, the interline payments owed by the C. & O.B. & O., amounts to $400,000 a month more than the Penn Central owes to C. & O.B. & O.

title: Business Briefs
description: A Buffalo attorney, Frank G. Ralchle, has been appointed by a Rochester Federal court as trustee for the Stirling Homex Corporation under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act. The company filed under Chapter X yesterday.

title: Wet Spell Expected to Run Into August
description: As rain fell in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for yet another day, John Mayer, meteorologist in charge at the local office of the National Weather Service, reeled off the facts:

title: Terrorist Gives Israelis His Political Testament
description: JERUSALEM, July 13Those people we killed are now stars in the firmament. The world) revolution will continue; there will be more stars. But when, I think that their stars and our stars will one day shine in the same heaven, I am very happy.

title: Mrs. Baker Clinches Series For Great South Bay Title
description: MORICHES, L.I., July 13Mrs. Louise Rice Baker of the Westhampton Yacht Squadron I captured the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's women's championship for the second straight year today, clinching the scheduled sixrace round robin series in five events.

title: More Religious Strife Feared in Mindanao
description: PIKIT, the Philippines, July 13 (AP)Along the road east of Cotabato the view of the verdant landscape includes water buffalo, farmers wading in rice fields and many laughing children. The traveler also sees old women selling boiled corn along the roadside for a penny an ear.

title: Out in White, Nicklaus Comes Back in the Pink
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 13Under a warm sun in the clear blue sky, Jack Nicklaus pulled at his white cashmere turtleneck sweater today as he strode up Muirfield's third fairway in the British Open golf tournament.

title: Hardie and Walker Gain Semifinals at Atlanta Net
description: ATLANTA, July 13 (UPI) Unheralded George Hardie of Southern Methodist University and Ross Walker of Britain pulled off upsets today to advance to the semifinals of the National clay courts tennis championships.

title: G.M. Denies Plans For a Wankel Car
description: The General Motors Corporation yesterday denied a published report that the company planned to produce a car next year that would be powered by a rotary engine.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $771million, 17 per cent above the year earlier $657million. Total retail store sale were about $8.122billion, up 12 per cent from the year earlier $7.277billion.

title: MICHIGAN BUSING STAYED BY COURT
description: DETROIT, July 13Antibusng forces won their first legal victory today in the effort to block implementation of a massive citysuburban busing order for the Detroit metropolitan area.

title: Reds Plan Vermont Drive
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 13 (AP)The Communist party is planning a campaign in Vermont within a week to place the name of Gus Hall on the state's Presidential ballot, its campaign coordinator, Larry Moscowitz, said today.

title: Weekend Cookout: Grilled Eggplants
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Siegfried Named Coach
description: BOSTON, July 13 (UPI)Larry Siegfried, who played on five National Basketball Association championship teams with the Boston Celtics, was named head basketball coach today at North Adams State College.

title: StateCity Panel Aide Named
description: The appointment of Arthur L. Schiff, a former assistant state attorney general, as staff director of the City Commission on StateCity Relations was announced yesterday by William J. vanden Heuvel, the group's chairman. Mr. Schiff, who was the commission's research director, succeeds Dr. Jewel Bellush, who is returning to her previous post as professor of political science at Hunter College.

title: ANGELO RONZONI, 71, OF MACARONI FIRM
description: Angelo Ronzoni, vice president of the Ronzoni Macaroni Company of Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 10 Merrivale Road, Great Neck.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13A combat veteran who deserted from the Marine Corps three years ago was arrested tonight as he tried to dramatize the amnesty issue by turning himself in on the floor of the Democratic National Convention.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While salary increases under President Nixon's Economic Stabilization Program are limited to 5.5 per cent, three of the five movie theaters along East 86th Street in Manhattan have raised the price of admission from $3 to $4, an increase of 33 per cent. Not only has this been done with such a major movie as The Godfather, but with other films as well.

title: Police Still Investigating Slaying of a Business Aide
description: The police reported yesterday that they still had no suspects in the murder of a business association official found bludgeoned to death, apparently with a brick, in his West Side apartment Monday.

title: ALEXANDER J. NAPOLI
description: CHICAGO, July 13 (UPI)Judge Alexander J. Napoli of the United States District Court died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Good Art Shows Abound in Museums
description: Three basic requirements for a good summer art exhibition are that it be sufficiently lightweight to impose no strain on the observer, that it be of good enough quality to assure him that he is not wasting his time on cultural trivia, and that it take place in an airconditioned gallery. New York's museums are wellstocked with such exhibitions this summer.

title: A lot of baseball is a drag, all because of the rules. Why not cut back to two strikes, yer out, and speed the whole game up?
description: WASHINGTONThe classical encounter between the pitcher and the batter, which is of course the heart and soul of baseball, is also at the heart of the answer to the question: What's wrong with baseball? The adversary proceedings simply take too long.

title: New Far East Bank Formed
description: Barclays Bank International, Ltd., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and Nomura Securities have agreed in principle to organize a merchant bank to be based in the Far East with each concern having a onethird interest. The name of the bank and the site of its home office are still to be decided.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge can be an irritating game. One of the greatest irritations arises when an opponent makes a bid or play that by sheer unpredictable chance turns out to be a sensational success. The irritated victim on the diagramed deal was Sam Stayman of New York, inventor of the Stayman convention. He was playing in a tournament in St. Louis with Mike Ledeen, who i's also wellknown as a bidding theorist.

title: 4 Americans Were Killed In Vietnam War Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 (AP)Four Americans were killed in combat in Vietnam last week, five died from other causes and five others were missing in action, the United States command announced in its weekly casualty report. Eighteen Americans were wounded, the command added.

title: LITTON INTRODUCES MICROWAVE OVENS
description: Litton Industries, Inc., introduced here yesterday two new I home microwave ovens that are expected to be the nucleus of a drive to tap a new market whose potential is estimted at $750million by 1976.

title: West German to Visit China
description: BONN, July 13Dr. Gerhard Schrbder, the former West German Foreign Minister, left for Peking today for a twoweek official visit. It will be the first contact by a senior West German politician with the Chinese Government.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: I feel like the old firehorse who hears the clanging of the bell and doesn't know where to go.

title: MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13The Democrats came out of their convention In fairly good order, with George McGovern crying, Come home, America! In McGovern and Eagleton they have ticket that runs no farther than from Missouri to South Dakota, but at least they avoided the worst of their nightmares, and they're not deceiving themselves about the magnitude of their problems.

title: Fire Closes Mesa Verde
description: MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK, Colo. July 13 (UPI)A raging forest fire, fed by winds and dry timber, forced the closing today of Mesa Verde National Park and threatened several excavated ancient Indian ruins.

title: Vatican Opposes Absolution In Community Rites of Penance
description: ROME, July 13The Vatican today condemned a practice under which some Roman Catholic priests have been granting absolution for grave sins in community rites of penance instead of in individual confession.

title: COMMONS VOTES ENTRY TO MARKET
description: LONDON, July 13After five months of acrimonious debate, the House of Commons approved tonight legislation to take Britain into the European Economic Community.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: A Government report that the amount of acreage planted for soybeans this year is 8 per cent above that of 1971 sent soybean future prices tumbling yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: M'AFEE FETE PERMIT REFUSED BY FRESNO
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 13 (AP)  Fresno County supervisors have refused to issue a permit for the Rodger McAfee Farm Music Festival that was scheduled for Labor Day weekend.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO REACH A DREAM. By Nathan C. Heard. 212 acmes. Dial. $5.95.

title: City U. Plan Says Schools Here Should Educate Students Better
description: The Board of Higher Education was told last night that the city's elementary schools and high schools should turn out betterprepared students instead of sending on to the City University young people who need mass remedialeducation programs.

title: Market Place Shareholders And Surprises
description: RCA wrote off millions of dollars on its moneylosing computer division, Ampex swept away millions of dollars in shareholders equity on an unsuccessful foray into consumer products. Then Celanese took a writeoff, and in the wake of the debacle reluctantly dismissed many capable executives.

title: U.S. Cup Team in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 13 (UPI)The United States Davis Cup tennis team arrived today for the American Zone, final against Chile July 21A The jetliner carrying the squad arrived two hours earlier than scheduled and many Chilean officials who had planned to greet the team were not at the airport.

title: New Italian Government Wins Vote of Confidence
description: ROME, July 13Premier Gitilio Andreotti's new Government a coalition of centrist parties, won a vote of confidence in the Senate today, 163 to 155.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There must be a better way to protect the airtraveling public and to combat hijacking than the inadequate and inefficient methods presently employed by our domestic airlines. [Editorial July 7.]

title: Rain Delays Women's Golf
description: NEW SEABURY, Mass., July 13 (AP)  The first round of Angelo's Ladies Professional Golf Association fourball championship was postponed today as morning rains made the course at Oyster Harbor unplayable by noon. Play will be cut to 36 holes.

title: TANAKA MAY ATTEND U.S. TRADE TALKS
description: TOKYO, July 13Trade talks between United States and Japanese officials scheduled for July 2528 took on new importance today in the light of a statement by Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, that he would take command of the Japanese delegation during the talks and might attend personally.

title: A Shorter Hijacking
description: The companion hijacking of an American 727 was much shorter and less violent than that of the National plane but still unnerving for the 51 passengers and six crewmen aboard.

title: F.D.A. Stands By Decision On the Uses of Red Dye
description: WASHINGTON (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was sticking to its proposal of about a 30 per cent reduction in the use of red dye in foods and cosmetics.

title: PATTERSON BOXES AGOSTO TONIGHT
description: For a man who has fought only twice since 1969, Pedro Agosto of Puerto Rico and Oradell, N. J., is confident he will beat Floyd Patterson tonight in their 10round heavyweight fight at the Singer Bowl in Flushing Meadow.

title: STRAVINSKY FETE PLAYS SARATOGA
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 13  Some two weeks after its glittering Stravinsky festival ended in New York's State Theater, the New York City Ballet has brought it to the pastoral calm of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Vegetables have provided the inspiration for much of the jewelry designed by Judith Brown, a sculptor who lives and works on a hilltop in Reading, Vt.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ARMAGH, Northern IrelandEverybody involved in the emotional conflict here dislikes assertions that the argument between Protestant majority and Catholic minority is religious. Yet frequent graffiti reflect sectarian passions and one must consider the Irish question in such terms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Anyone who has carefully read the recent criticism of The New York Times by United States Attorney Whitney. North Seymour and the response of A. M. Rosenthal on behalf of The Times (June 221 has to conclude that The Times position represents an ing defensible disregard of the public interest.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
