description: The National Weather Service issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island south shore and nearby coastal area:

title: Firemen's SickCall Rate Rises to 109 in 24 Hours
description: The unusually high number of firemen reporting ill or injured increased yesterday to total of 109 as of 6 A.M., compared with 75 in the previous 24 hours.

title: Executive Changes
description: Howard J. Poduska, 52 years old, has been elected a director and, effective Sept. 1, president of the Bank of New York Company, Inc. He is now executive vice president of the statewide holding company and the Bank of New York. As president of the company, he will succeed William L. Butcher, 65, who will retire fro mthat pos tand from the post of chairman of the County Trust Company at the end of August. Mr. Butcher wii continue as a director of both organizations. At the County Trust Company, Mr. Butcher will be succeed as chairman by John A. Kley, president of the bank since 1960. Thomas J. Langan Jr., senior vice presidentloan administration since 1967, will succeed Mr. Kley as president. Herbert B. Grant, senior vice presidentcustomer service, has been named executive vice president.

title: Lynch Firm on Union
description: DUBLIN, July 13Prime Minister John Lynch said today that while the aim of a united Ireland by agreement might take many years to accomplish, this was the only basis on which the Irish Republic's Government intended to proceed.

title: Link to War Views Hinted in Ellsberg Jury Ousters
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13Attitudes toward the Vietnam war appeared to be a factor today in challenges to prospective jurors by the prosecution and defense In the Pentagon Papers case.

title: Universal Television and B.B.C. Plan Series on Europe's Rulers
description: Universal Television, a leading Hollywood producer of primetime programs for the major networks, announced yesterday that it had entered into an arrangement with the British Broadcasting Corporation to coproduce a 13episode historical drama series called Fall of Eagles.

title: June Trade Surplus Posted by Britain; Exports a Record
description: LONDON, July 13 (UPI)Britain earned a surplus of $37.5million in its visible foreign trade with the rest of the world in June, official figures showed today. Exports set a record and imports turned down.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Although the Presidential pursuit of Gov. George C. Wallace ended here last night, the leaders of his debtridden campaign declined today to announce its demise.

title: Gordone Play to Be Filmed
description: Charles Gordone's No Place to Be Somebody, the first work by a black playwright to win the Pulitzer Prize, will be filmed this year by Herbert Ross and Wagner/Damore Productions for Warner Bros. release.

title: Une de Mai May Not Go In Trot Race at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. 1., July 13Une de Mai of France may have to be scratched from Saturday night's 14th annual International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. The winner of last season's race was found this morning to be tied up with an accumulation of lactic acid in the muscles. (Lactic acid is the residue left in muscles after energy has been burned off, producing a condition of fatigue.)

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 502
description: MOSCOW, July 13The Soviet Union today launched the unmanned spacecraft Cosmos 502, believed to be a military observation satellite. Similar satellites have been identified in the West as a family of recoverable observation craft launched from the North Russian space center of Plesetsk. They generally remain in orbit 10 to 14 days.

title: Unpardonable Tax
description: In this period of continuing recession and inflation, no proposal to impose a wholly new tax can expect an enthusiastic public reception. That makes unsurprising the intense political resistance to the proposal by the New Jersey Tax Policy Committee for imposition of that state's first general income tax, even though Gov. William T. Cahill as well as former Gov. Richard Hughes and others prominent in both major parties have campaigned hard for its enactment by the State Legislature. Members of the Assembly gathering to cast their ballots on this issue next Monday appear to reflect a popular disenchantment with any new taxes. The prospects for a favorable vote are reported slim.

title: Business Briefs
description: Management of the Colorado Interstate Corporation yesterday urged stockholders to reject a tender offer OF $40 a share made by the Coastal States Crude Gathering Company, a subsidiary of the Coastal States Gas Producing Company, of Corpus Chnsti, Tex.

title: COLTS FRANCHISE TRADED FOR RAMS; PLAYERS REMAIN
description: The ownerships of the Baltimore and Los Angeles franchises of the National Football League were traded yesterday in a deal that had no precedent in major professional team sports. The players and coaches were not affected and their affiliations will remain the same but the exchange permitted Carroll Rosenbloom, the longtime owner of the Colts, to leave Baltimore and also to save $4.4million in capital gains taxes.

title: WYMAN P. FISKE, 72, TAUGHT ACCOUNTING
description: Wyman P. Fiske, a retired management consultant who had been professor of accounting at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1929 to 1944, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Rail TonMileage Off 1.7%
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States 1.7 per cent below the comparable 1971 week. Carloadings totaled 371,454 cars, 5.7 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 3.2 per cent above the 1971 level.

title: COMPANIES JOINING IN PLAN ON COAL GAS
description: The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday that it had been joined by 11 gas, coal, oil and railroad companies in financing a project for upgrading coal gas to the quality and purity of natural gas. The program, initially announced last April, calls for a new facility to be built adjacent to Westfield gasification plant in Scotland.

title: NIXON SIGNS A BILL RAISING PARK FEES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13President Nixon signed legislation today establishing somewhat increased fees for the use of national parks and recreation areas, but also providing for free or reducedrate use of these areas by the elderly.

title: Pentagon Lists 4 Area Men As Killed in Vietnam War
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in the Indochina war:

title: Training for Derailments Urged by Safety Board
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board called today for improved disaster training for local fire departments across the nation to avert potential disasters spawned by derailments of freight trains carrying explosive cargoes.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Rise in Bicycle Mishaps Prompts U. S. Standards
description: So far, bicycle manufacturers have issued no recalls, but the day may come.

title: TV: Problems of Covering Political Conventions
description: After watching an exclusive Columbia Broadcasting System interview with George Wallace during the Democratic convention the other evening, a relatively dispassionate observer commented, Well, Walter Cronkite just picked up another million votes. That remark, not entirely facetious, gets to the core of a basic problem confronted by television in the coverage of a political convention.

title: Reward Offered in Si. Case
description: A fund of about $2,500 has been offered as a reward by neighbors of the Staten Island girl who disappeared a week ago. The money will go to anyone with information leading to finding 5yearold Alice Pereira, according to Ernest Nevares and Nicholas Napolitano, of 675 Tysens Lane in New Dorp, president and vice president of the Tysens Park Tenants Association.

title: Speculators Gambling On MoneyValue Shifts
description: ROME, July 13A test of wills is under way in the money centers of Europe between the speculators who have yet to be convinced that the December currency realignment remains intact and the monetary authorities who have to do the convincing.

title: 2 Drown After Baptism
description: MAIDEN, N. July 13 (AP) Two converts to a newly organized church drowned last night while trying to swim across a 100foot lake in which they had just been baptized. The two men, Frank Hullette, 19 years old, and Franklin Herman, 38, both of nearby Newton, were among 12 members of the Bright Light Tabernacle Church who had participated in the baptism.

title: ExAide to Texan Convicted in Plot On Pay Kickbacks
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) George A. Haag, former administrative assistant to Representative James M. Collins, Republican of Texas, was found guilty today of 23 cli'arges in an $18,000 payroll kickback scheme.

title: ESCAPED PRISONER SEIZED IN JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 13 (AP)A third prisoner who escaped from the Yardville Correction Center last month was arrested early today when he returned to the New Brunswick apartment where he had been living for the last several days.

title: Dining Among Nautical Knickknacks
description: ** Griswold Inn, 49 Main Street, Essex, Conn., 2037678894.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 13 Mayor Lindsay sat quietly surveying the chaos on the Democratic National Convention floor, which has had many of the earmarks of a subway rush hour.

title: Credentials Mad Society Called Spur to Unaccredited Colleges
description: For a variety of reasons, ranging from a credentials mad society to a new recognition of untraditional approaches, unaccredited colleges are springing up all over the place, according to an official of the organization concerned with the accreditation of colleges and universities in this country said yesterday.

title: Krumpe Named to N. Y. R. A. Post
description: John H. (Jack) Krumpe was named president of the New York Racing Association yesterday, succeeding Frank M. Basil, who resigned from the post. The changes were announced by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board of the N.Y.R.A., and will become effective immediately.

title: Merger News
description: The Continental Grain Company announced yesterday $12million tender offer to purchase 500,000 shares of Allied Mills, Inc., Chicago, a manufacturer and processor of animal feed, and other agricultural products.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13 Lawrence F. O'Brien said tonight that no one could convince him to accept another term as chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: CHARLES MIANE, 69, OBSTETRICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Charles M. McLane, clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Cornell Medical College, died of a coronary attack yesterday at his home, 167 East 67th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July13 Following is a summary of the major actions taken by the Democratic National Convention:

title: Airline Talks Broken Off
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 13 (UPI) A member of the National Mediation Board said tonight that he had officially broken off talks between Northwest. Airlines and the company's 1,600 striking pilots. Harry Bickford said he was unable to resolve an impasse thati developed last Friday and would fly back to Washington tomorrow. No date for resumption of negotiations in the 14 dayold strike has been set, he said.

title: Forrestal Towed to Yard
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 13 (UPI) The Forrestal, damaged by fire earlier this week, was towed down the Elizabeth River today to the Navy shipyard for repairs. The Navy declined to estimate how long it would take to repair the attack carrier but postponed her scheduled departure Monday for the Mediterranean where she was to relieve the Kennedy. The Navy declined to say what caused the fire, which occurred in the flag officers quarters.

title: Trevino, Jacklin Share Lead With 141's
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 13Doug Sanders stormed the 18th hole three under par, heading for a twostroke lead halfway through the British Open golf, tournament, and he blew it today. He went from tee to bunker to deep rough to rough over the green to bunker again and he was finally in the hole with a triplebogey 7.

title: Fischer Stays Out, Forfeits 2d Game; Appeal Is Expected
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 13 Bobby Fischer remained in his hotel room today, refusing to show up for his scheduled game with Boris Spassky. He was declared the loser by forfeit and the score of this strange world championship chess match became 2 to 0 in favor of the Soviet titleholder.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A telegram from President Nixon complimenting the efforts of the New York City police in reducing crime here was read by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy to all members of the force in a message broadcast over police frequencies.

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices forged ahead yesterday on a broad front, extending a late Wednesday rally, but many of the gains faded as the session wore on.

title: Crenshaw, Koch Advances
description: DALLAS, July 13 (UPI)Ben Crenshaw easily captured his secondround match in the 69th TransMississippi golf tournament today, but he faces strong threat in Gary Koch.

title: Detective Commanders Will Get Wider Roles Under New Setup
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has decided to change the command structure of the detective force in a way that will put 12 key detective commanders in somewhat closer touch with individual sections of the city, high detective officers disclosed yesterday.

title: 8 More Killed in Ulster Amid Hints of Peace Talks
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, July 14Amid indications that talks to restore a ceasefire had been resumed, Northern Ireland was struck by another day of violence yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The present furor about food prices is unjustified and is based on inconplete knowledge of the facts of the costs of food production. The American housewife gets a bargain every time she shops at her supermarket.

title: Fire Sweeps Vacant Stores
description: Twenty firemen were ttreated for smoke inhalation early yesterday after battling a threealarm fire in a row of vacant stores in the Morrisania section of the Bronx. Fire officials said that the blaze, fought by 120 men, was reported at 2:13 A.M. and involved seven stores at 971 Westchester Avenue, between Kelly and Tiffany Streets. It was declared under control at 3:38.

title: PASQUALE GIVEN BY LYRIC OPERA
description: Where two or three singers are gathered together, an opera ensemble is likely to be formed. Too many young vocalists cannot find a place in the minimal number of established troupes that dot this country, so they provide their own opportunities. One that has made its first appearance this summer is the New York Lyric Opera Company, under the direction of Donald W. Johnston, and it has found a home in the Universalist Church at Central Park West and 76th Street.

title: Endurance Contest
description: The endurance champions of the depressed nineteenthirties were flagpole sitters and marathon dancers. Today it is finance ministers and central bankers who seek to prove their perseverance by showing how long they can float their national currencies. The British, latest entrants in the competition, have been floating their pound since June 23, still a long way from a record by the standard of the German mark or the American and Canadian dollars; the current champions are the Canadians, whose dollar has been afloat since the beginning of June, 1970.

title: Private Detective Indicted in Jersey On Wiretap Charge
description: TRENTON, July 13 (AP)A private detective of Roseland was indicted today on charges of violating the state's wiretapping law Lin matrimonial investigations.

title: Bank of England Account Shows Note, Deposit Gain
description: LONDON, July 13 (AP)The Bank of England account for the week ended Wednesday, in thousands of pounds:

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Friday, July 14Senator George McGovern opened his prepared acceptance speech early this morning with a goodnatured aside about the delay he experienced in appearing before the Democratic National Convention.

title: Elks Vote Overwhelmingly to Continue Exclusion of Nonwhites as Members
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 13The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, the world's largest fraternal organization, voted overwhelmingly today to continue to exclude nonwhites from membership.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your June 25 editorial Curbing Meat Prices recommends ending the exemption of meat and other raw agricultural products from price controls. Are the farmers and the stock growers of America really making excess profits or creating inflation?

title: Lima Editor and Reporter Given Suspended Sentences
description: LIMA, Peru, July 13 (AP)The director of the Lima newspaper La Prensa and one of its reporters have been sentenced to sixmonth suspended jail terms and fined on a charge of violating Peru's press statute.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On June 23 you published an editorial in which you criticized the City Civil Service Commission for requiring two applicants to lift a weight as part of an examination for the title of Audio Visual Aide Technician. The Times apparently did not understand fully the nature of the jobs involved.

title: KENNEDY EXHORTS PARTY TO VICTORY
description: MIAMI BEACH, Friday, July 14  Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, the man who shunned his party's Presidential nomination this year, electrified the Democratic National Convention this morning with praise for Senator George, McGovern and an exhortation to victory in November.

title: News Analysis
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 13 The shops across Northern Ireland are closed today, the streets are silent and the pubs are jammed. It is twoday holiday, part of the Protestants traditional Orange celebrations, but the mood is hardly festive. Ferocious anger and violence hover in the air. Perhaps not since the troubles of the nineteentwenties has Northern Ireland faced a graver crisis. The rupture of the ceasefire by the Irish Republican Army's militant Provisional wing, the erection of barricades again in Roman Catholic and Protestant neighborhoods, the talk of civil war, the armed militias on both sides, the chain of unsolved sectarian murders, the intimidation of Catholic families in mixed neighborhoodsall have shrouded Northern Ireland in darkness once again.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday adopted a previously proposed technical change in its margin rule that will end use of the sameday substitution rule on some accounts.

title: Triumph Pays on Safety Lag
description: WASHINGTON, July 13, (Reuter) British Leyland Motors agreed to pay $12,000 to settle a claim that it produced a number of Triumph. GT6 cars that did not comply with a United States safety standard, the Transportation Department announced today. It said that 19 Triumphs were sold or offered for sale without installation of shoulder harness restraints.

title: BRITAIN VETOES BIDS TO TAKE OVER GLAXO
description: LONDON, July 13  The British Government today vetoed two takeover bids for Glaxo, the parmaceutical and chemical manufacturing company.

title: CAMPAIGN TO USE PRIMARY TACTICS
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Senator George McGovern will try to win the White House in November with the same techniques he patented in the Democratic primaries: a huge registration drive among youths, reform rhetoric and national grassroots organizing.

title: PIONEER NEARING ASTEROID REGION
description: The Pioneer 10 spacecraft, bound for Jupiter, begins this weekend the most hazardous part of its flight, a sevenmonth passage through the dusty, rocky debris of the asteroid belt.

title: Tannen Finds a Horne: jet Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 13 Tuesday Morning is the name of Steve Tannen's boutique in Gainseville Fla., and that's also the day the New York Jets defensive back arrived in camp this year.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 13 (AP)An attorney for the Republic of New Africa, John Brittain Jr., said the two men had merely been distributing literature. He said they were official envoys of the group with orders to distribute 'antidepression programs at Mr. McGovern's headquarters.

title: Mrs. Bartol, Rockefeller's MotherinLaw, Dies
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., July 13  Mrs. Margaretta Harrison Fitler Bartol of Wynnewood, Pa., motherinlaw of New York's Governor Rockefeller, I died here today. Her age was 70.

title: Mrs. Sheals Wins Twice
description: CLAYVILLE, N.Y. July 13 (AP)Mrs. Allen Sheals of Allegany, who eliminated the defending champion, Dianne Wilde, in yesterday's first round; scored a double victory today to earn a semifinal spot in the 43d annual New York State women's amateur golf tournament.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13The New York delegation walked off the floor of the Democratic National Convention for 40 minutes tonight to protest the postponing of party reforms and the method of electing eight new members of the state committee to an expanded national party structure.

title: Giants Hold First Drills Minus Lakes, Grim
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 13Two regulars remained absent as the New York Giants held their first workout today, but they both spoke to club officials by telephone and the officials aren't sure if one of them quit.

title: Hawaii Dockworkers Pact Averts Threat of Walkout
description: HONOLULU, July 13 (AP)Longshoremen are scheduled to vote next week on a new labor contract that would end a year of uncertainty in Hawaiian ports.

title: Fashion Is Back in Fashion Again
description: The classics revival for next fall has been so effective it's likely to make fashion fashionable again. Sportswear casts its aura over everything, which means clothes are clean, quiet and comfortable looking. The major trends of the season all have a casual feeling. Most have been around before, of course, but not exactly in the same way.

title: 6 AT SCHOOL LACK ACCREDITEDPH.D.'S
description: One of the largest grouptherapy training schools in the city is operating with a number of faculty and advisory council members who are listed as having advanced degrees from nonaccredited and, in at least one case, nonexistent universities.

title: Vermont Senate Plan Upset
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 13 (AP)  The Vermont Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional today a new state law that would have reapportioned the State Senate.

title: Count Basie Band Rises to Occasion On St. Regis. Roof
description: There was a time when summer in New York meant, among other things, that many of the hotels with dance bands moved them upstairs to the roofthe Astor, the Pennsylvania, the Biltmore, the WaldorfAstoria, the St. Regis. But the arrival of airconditioning and the disappearance of most bigname dance bands made that kind of rooftop entertainment obsolete.

title: W.H.A. Completes Draft
description: CLEVELAND, July 13 (UPI) The general managers of the World Hockey Association's 12 teams completed a supplemental player draft today and agreed on procedural matters to put before the league's trustees. A spokesman said 120 players, 10 for each team, were chosen in the draft. Each club now has a list of 60 names, counting the 50 each team, froze from the original selection list.

title: Troops Battle I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Friday, July 14 (Reuters)Six hundred British troops moved into the beleaguered Lenadoon Avenue in western Belfast early today in an operation aimed at taking control of the area from the Irish Republican Army.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: A record $100,000 tournament has been added to the women's professional tennis circuit, Mrs. Gladys M. Heldman, director of the tour, announced yesterday.

title: Let a Single Spheroid Bloom
description: WOODS HOLE, MassSomething is wrong with our compass. Somebody seems to have exchanged its poles and painted S over its North, and N over its South pole, and we are sailing in the wrong direction.

title: Lettuce Boycott Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) A Roman Catholic agency called today for a boycott of iceberg lettuce picked by nonunion workers and said the dispute between growers and the United Farm Workers involved a fundamental issue of social justice. The endorsement of the boycott came from the Committee on Social Development of the United States Catholic Conference.

title: WALTER WENSINGER, MARINE GENERAL, 77
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Lieut. Gen. Walter W. Wensinger, U.S.M.C., retired, who served with distinction in the Pacific in World War II, died Monday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 120.2 from 119.5 last week.

title: MRS. BRADFORD LOCKE
description: PRINCETON, N. 3., July 13Mrs. Philena Fine Locke, the first woman elected to public office in this community, died yesterday after a long illness in the Princeton Hospital. She was 77 years old.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWPORT, Wales, July 13 (AP)Topseeded Clark Graebner of New York reached the semifinals of the Welsh lawn tennis championships today with a 64, 64 victory over Stephen Warboys, a 17yearold English boy.

title: Du Pont Lifts Resin Price
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it would withdraw its discount of 1 cent a pound on highdensity polyethylene blowmolding resins, effective Aug. 1. The move will bring prices of these resins to 13 cents a pound in hoppercar quantities.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: SAN DIEGO, July 13 (UPI)Representative Barry Goldwater Jr. called today for revocation of the primetimeaccess rule, which limits the number of network programs on nighttime television. He said the Communications Commission rule had forved the cancellation of more than 20 network produced TV shows between 7:30 and 8 P.M. and as a result, thousands have been put out of work in the Southern California televisionmotion picture industry.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: OTTAWA, July 13 (Canadian Press)The Canadian Government will not take the initiative in trying to persuade owners of National Hockey League teams to allow Bobby Hull play on the Canadian team that is to meet the Soviet national hockey team in the fall in an eightgame series. Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Health Minister John Munro told reporters today they did not want to risk collapse of the CanadaSoviet Union series over one player.

title: Japan Nine Tops U.S., 54
description: OKAYAMA, Japan, July 13 (UPI)Japan took a 21 lead over the United States tonight in their bestofseven college baseball world series by winning the third game, 54, in 12 Innings.

title: Mack Sennett Romance Theme of New Musical
description: Joseph Kipness and Lawrence Kasha, who cosponsored the longrun musical Applause, are planning to put on a musical called Mack and Mabel, based on the romance between the pioneer comedy movie director Mack Sennett and Mabel Normand, the silent movie comedienne, who starred in many of his short silent films.

title: Boise Cascade Weighing $200Million Writedown
description: BOISE, Idaho, July 13The Boise Cascade Corporation announced today that it is considering a special chargeall or most of which would be extraordinary totaling approximately $200million against income.

title: KISSINGER TO SET UP M'GOVERN BRIEFINGS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13  President Nixon has instructed Henry A. Kissinger, his top foreign affairs adviser, to arrange briefings on foreign policy and intelligence matters for Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, the Democnatic Presidential nominee. Presidents have made secret intelligence information available to Presidential candidates, of their own and the opposition party, ever since 1952, when President Harry S. Truman began the practice.

title: John H. O'Connell Dead at 58; Executive of Hill and Knowlton
description: John H. O'Connell, vice chairman of the board of Hill and Knowlton, Inc., international public relations firm, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J. He was 58 years old and lived at 100 Summit Avenue, Upper Montclair.

title: A Record Rainfall Snarls Road and Rail Traffic Here
description: Eclipsing a 75yearold record for the date, a threeinch rainfall drenched the metropolitan area yesterday, snarling road, rail and subway traffic, flooding basements in outlying sections and adding to the troubles of farmers and others hit hard by the tropical storm Agnes last month.

title: Exchange Selects Needham of S.E.C. As Chief Executive
description: James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was named yesterday to be the first fulltime, salaried chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Two Rabbis Plead Guilty In PhonyUniversity Plot
description: Two Orthodox rabbis pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to mailfraud charges arising from their having enrolled students in a fictitious university.

title: 2 JET HIJACKERS GIVE UP IN TEXAS; 3 HOSTAGES FREED
description: HOUSTON, July 13Two hijackers, one an Ethiopian citizen, surrendered today to a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent at a small airport south of Houston about 22 hours after they had commandeered a National Airlines jet while it was going from Philadelphia to New York.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Held
description: DETROIT, July 13Kenneth Oliver, 32yearold Detroit interior decorator, was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today and charged with the $40,000 robbery yesterday of the Manufacturers & Traders Trust Company of Buffalo.

title: Fawcett Publications Picks Vice President
description: William G. Dunn, who has been an extremely active vice presidentmarketing of the Magazine Publishers Association, will join Fawcett Publications as vice president on Aug. 1. He will be associate publisher of True, Mechanix Illustrated, Rudder arrd the 30 specialinterest magazines. George H. Allen is publisher of the magazine division.

title: Drug Hearings Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Three days of hearings will begin here Monday to explore the relationship of drugs to industry and advertising and the diversion of legitimate drugs into illicit channels. The National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse announced today that the hearings would include testimony from representatives of the drug industry, advertising, medicine and government.

title: Marathon Session Silted Long Roster of Candidates
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Senator George McGovern and his senior staff went through a marathon session of politics and pondering, apparently laced with some hardnosed disputes, before finally settling late this afternoon on Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri as his running mate on the Democratic ticket.

title: Personalities: Thomas Leaves Cowboy Camp
description: Duane Thomas, the controversial running back of the Dallas Cowboys who was fined Wednesday for reporting hours late to the team's training site at Thousand Oaks, Calif., walked out of the camp later without any explanation. A spokesman said the team presumed he was somewhere in Los Angeles. Thomas and a friend were last seen headed south in a rented car. Nobody, not even Tom Landry [the Dallas coach] knows where they are right now. Thomas has been renegotiating a threeyear contract with Tex Schramm, the club president. Thomas was supposed to have reported to camp Wednesday with other Cowboy veterans, but the player told the driver of a car sent to pick him up at Los Angeles airport that the airline had lost his luggage and that he was staying over to retrieve it. Said Landry, Duane missed rollcall for our team, and he will be fined like any other player. Later that evening Thomas finally arrived at the camp with a friend. The two talked with Landry, then left the camp.

title: Lawyer Held in Contempt in Democratic Raid Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  A 34yearold Washington lawyer was found in contempt of court today for refusing to answer a series of grand jury questions about the June 17 raid on the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Advertising:
description: It will be nice when Election Day is over, the Republicans and Democrats stop hogging the airwaves with their petty bickering and we can all concern ourselves once again with the battle between the Pink Pad and Blue Pad.

title: State Plans to Tighten Controls on Medicaid and Stress Preventive Medicine
description: A new state approach to the $1.7billionayear Medicaid program for the poor was announced yesterday in a plan to tighten controls on use and costs of the program and also to emphasize preventive medical care.

title: Combat Helicopters Carrying Tear Gas To Keep Crowds Off
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 (AP)Some American helicopters in Vietnam are carrying teargas canisters to prevent groups of panicstricken soldiers or civilian refugees from dragging them down in efforts to scramble aboard.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 13 A Federal district judge tonight jailed four members of the Vietnam Veterans against the War for refusing to assist in a Justice Department investigation of the organization.

title: GERALD T. BERGAII, AN ARCHBISHOP
description: OMAHA, July 13 (AP)The Most Rev. Gerald T. Bergan, who retired as Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Omaha in 1969 after 21 years in that capacity, died yesterday in a hospital named for him. He was 80 years old.

title: JOSEPH BINDER
description: Joseph Binder, an artist and graphic designer who created the official poster for the New York World's Fair of 1939, died June 26 in Vienna, where he was preparing an exhibition of his paintings and pastels. He was 75 years old and lived at 100 Central Park South.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Friday July 14 The only thing that seems to bother George McGovern and his bluejean machine is success. They were rattling along fine until the South Dakota Senator was nominated, and then they fumbled their hour of triumph. Their first big bobble of the convention started when they made] a sharp turn at high speed from the new politics to the old politics in the selection of the Vice Presidential nominee.

title: Books of The Times
description: INTO IT. By Edward Pomerantz. 158 pages. Dial. $5.95.

title: Screen: 2 Chillers for the Hot Weather
description: Britain's Hammer Films, which has been regularly grinding out studiously manufactured little exercises in vintage bloodlettingin color,  has done it again with "Hands of the Ripper" and "Twins of Evil," which surfaced at local houses with all the shock effects of weird fairy tales.However, credit the Hammer movie teams with providing a couple of variations on standard horror themes that should send geneticists, if not the paying customers, scurrying off to psychiatrists' couches. In "Twins of Evil," for example, comely twin sisters are turned into vampires by that scion of a long line of old Mittelcuropa's "undead," Count Karnstein, which probably is a first for the cinema.On the other hand, it is not ungallant to reveal, since it's disclosed early in the movie, that "Hands of the Ripper" has a good deal of ghoulish truck with the idea that that most storied Victorian killer, Jack the Ripper, has passed his gory predilections on to his pretty blonde daughter. And that too must set a precedent since the identity of Jack the Ripper is still an official mystery.Let's say that Mary and Madelaine Collinson, the actual identical-twin actresses of "Twins of Evil," are nobly endowed enough to keep any red-blooded boy interested in vampirism. The rest of the costumed crew, led by that veteran horror hand, Peter Cushing, as the twins' witchhunting uncle, who chases the fanged Count and his retinue, hardly give "Twins of Evil" a good name.The fog-filled London settings of "Hands of the Ripper" do not shroud the fact that Angharad Rees, as the young, schizoid heroine, is not in the hands of a fully qualified medical man. Eric Porter, as a dour, dedicated pioneer "follower of that man Freud," is decidedly anxious to cure her beyond the call of duty and the Hippocratic Oath. But Miss Rees keeps hearing those voices and stabbing people until she and the good doctor wind up dead in St. Paul's Cathedral. All things considered, Freud himself might have had a hard time with Miss Rees and company.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13High across one end of the convention hall hang some 15 giant portraits of past Democratic luminaries, Presidents and national candidates. At the other end, in a small unobtrusive annex containing portraits of Congressional leaders, there is a picture of Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Miss Muffley Wed To Thomas Hughes
description: MARSHALL, Mo., July 13 Miss Barbara Muffley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Muffley of Rochester, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Anthony Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Thomas Hughes Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y. where the bridegroom's father is serving his second term as mayor.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Nine weeks ago, at a barbecue at John B. Connally's Texas ranch, a reporter asked H. R. Haldeman, a senior White House staff member, whether President Nixon would enjoy the prospect of running against George McGovern.

title: West German Baltic Coast in Building Boom
description: TIMMENDORFER STRAND, West Germany, July 9At the entrance to a public beach near here there is a sign that says it is forbidden to build sandcastles at a distance of less than two meters from the foot of the dune with a diameter larger than 2.5 meters or a depth of more than .30 meters.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13Earlier in this convention week, when Leonard Woodcock was mentioned as a potential VicePresidential nominee, almost everyone in town was surprised. Eleanor McGovern was not. The president of the United Automobile Workers was her idea.

title: LAYOFFS PLANNED AT STATE SCHOOLS
description: ALBANY, July 13 (AP)A layoff of 155 employes at 11 state training schools is scheduled for Aug. 2 because of budget cuts imposed by the New York Legislature and declining juvenile population at the schools, spokesmen for the state said today.

title: Notes on People
description: People usually sue first and, if disappointed, carry their case to the Supreme Court. Maryann Clifford is different. Miss Clifford, who plans to enter law school this autumn, went to the United States Supreme Court first, seeking one of the summer messenger jobs customarily made available to law students.

title: Xerox Debut in SocialProblem Arena Proves Success
description: The Xerox Corporation, known for office copiers, computers, and publishing and business equipment, appears to have had a very successful first year in the fields of counseling prisoners, aiding the aged, assisting minority groups and preventing drug abuse.

title: Australia Gets 249 Runs As 3d Cricket Test Begins
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 13 (Reuters)Keith Stackpole, Australia's opening batsmen on the first day of the third cricket test against England, made 114 runs today to guide Australia to 249 for six wickets.

title: MARKET IS LOSER 4TH DAY RUNNING
description: Stock prices sank again yesterday, posting their fourth loss of the week and carrying the market below a critical support zone on the charts.

title: McGovern Begins
description: In his choice of Senator Thomas 7Eagleton of Missouri as his VicePresidential running mate as well as in his acceptance call to the nation to become again a witness for what is noble and just in human affairs, Senator George McGovern has demonstrated that he can reach out for fresh political strength without sacrifice principle.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: IRVINE, Calif., July 13 (AP)  Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, sees at least one similarity between the Democratic National Convention this week and the 1964 Republican convention that nominated him for President. The thing is defeat.

title: Reserve Moves to Stem Inflow of Money
description: The Federal Reserve System sold a massive amount of securities during the week ended Wednesday  in large part to offset a temporary, seasonal flow of funds into the money market.

title: Journalistic SqueezeOut
description: After a halfcentury of lively publication in the nation's capital, The Washington Daily News expired this week, the latest in a long list of bigcity journalistic casualties to rising costs, intensified competition from other communications media and shifting population patterns. Though always overshadowed by its prestigious rivals, The Post and The Evening Star, the tabloid Daily News sought to be engagingly informative without being either sensational or pedantic. Its demise less than a month after the passing of Boston's HeraldTraveler leaves New York as the only metropolis with more than two separately owned dailies.

title: Testimony Puts Phillips at Murder Site
description: A handyman in the building where a pimp and a prostitute were slain in 1968 testified yesterday that Patrolman William R. Phillips entered the building on the night of the murder, saying he was going up to the pimp's apartment.

title: MAJOR BANKS LIST VARIED EARNINGS
description: Major New York City banking concerns reported yesterday widely divergent earnings for the first half and the second quarter of 1972.

title: Roundup: Reds Beat Pirates Again, 20
description: Just when the Cincinnati Reds were bemoaning the fact that they couldn't shake the jinx of their home field, the Riverfront Stadium, the Pittsburgh Pirates showed up.

title: JOSEPH M'KENNA
description: CLIFTON, N. J., July 13Joseph McKenna, manager of Meyer Chevrolet in Maplewood, died Tuesday at the Passaic General Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: CLAIR FISHER DEAD; CITY LANDSCAPE AIDE
description: Clair C. Fisher, head of thel landscape review section of design of the New York City Housing Authority, died yesterday at tns home, 150 East 49th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 (UPI)The Pacific Telephone Company said today it has asked the United States Supreme Court to halt a rollback of its rates and a scheduled refund to customers.

title: Sales of New Cars For Early July Up 21 % Over 71 Rate
description: DETROIT, July 13  New car dealers today reported 168,594 sales of United States type cars in the first third of July, or an average of 24,085 in each of the seven selling days.

title: INDEX DOWN OM IN AMEX TRADING
description: Down went the American Stock Exchange index yesterday to 26.90, off 0.11, and the lowest point since Jan. 27, whenii the stock price reflector was at 26.86. Again, the reason, probably was investors lack of enthusiasm for the McGovern nomination.

title: IMPASSIONED PLEA
description: MIAMI BEACH, Friday, July 14Senator George McGovern pushed through the nomination of Thomas Francis Eagleton, a freshman Senator from Missouri, as his running mate early today and then appeared with him before a singing and screeching throng of delegates to deliver an impassioned plea for the Democratic party's Help in leading the nation in a vast enterprise of selfhealing.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The United Companies Financial Corporation yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 299,472 common shares for sale through Dominick & Dominick Inc. and Howard Weil Labouisse Freidrichs Inc. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange was down  to 20.

title: The Talk of Mitchell, S.D.
description: MITCHELL, S. D., July 13 The World's Only Corn Palace, a very distinctive fourstory Moorish structure covered with corn cobs and prairie grasses, is undergoing its annual redecoration these days. The pictures of Mother Goose nursery rhyme characters, made by nailing 10,129 pounds of colored corn cobs to the outside walls of one civic center, are being re placed by pictures on the theme, Relaxation in South Dakota.

title: CHRYSLER CUTS BID FOR RISE IN PRICES
description: DETROIT, July 13  The Chrysler Corporation reduced today its request for price increase for 1973 vehicles to $1101 from $180.

title: BOGGS GAINS LEAD IN A. A. U. DIVING
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 13 (AP)Air Force Lt. Phil Boggs and Janet Ely, an 18yearold from Ann Arbor, Mich., were the pacesetters after qualifying competition in two events at the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor diving championships today.

title: C.B.S. GAME SHOWS TO REPLACE RERUNS
description: The television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System will change its midmorning MondaythroughFriday programing in the fall, replacing reruns of former nighttime programs such as The Beverly Hillbillies with three new halfhour game shows.

title: Inviting Danger
description: Little more than a year after imposing stringent Federal rules to shield workers against industrial accidents and occupational disease, Congress is stripping that protection away from millions of employes in small businesses, the very places where costcutting pressures make skimping on safety a particularly acute hazard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The new fiftycent New York State lottery ticket is simpler and quicker to handle, yet there are certain aspects of the new system that have caused apprehension among ticket buyers.

title: Cherry Grove Stays Aloof From Gay Activists Cause
description: CHERRY GROVE, Fire Island  Homosexuals may be offering resolutions at the Democratic National Convention, demonstrating at city halls and state houses all across the country, and going into court to demand equal treatment under the law but here, on the Seacoast of Bohemia, no sound fiercer than the shrieks of the circling gulls is to be heard.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had received orders from two major utilties for nuclear and fossilfueled turbines totaling about $160million. Four 600megawatt turbines will go to the Philadelphia Electric Company. The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago contracted with Westinghouse for two 1,100megawatt nuclear and two 500megawatt fossilfueled turbine generators.

title: Missing Photographer Reappears in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 (UPI)  Michel Dumond, a French freelance photographer who has been missing in a Communistcontrolled area for more than three months, walked into a South Vietnamese Army camp northwest of Saigon today, apparently in good condition.

title: Rhodesia Frees Daughter Of Former Prime Minister
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 13  Judith Todd, 29yearold daughter of the former Rhodesian Prime Minister, Garfield Todd, was released from restriction today. She boarded a flight to London from Johannesburg, South Africa, tonight.

title: A NEW LINK FOUND IN L.I. LAND CASE
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 13  The brother of a Suffolk County legislator who had inside information that the county planned to buy 11,000 feet of oceanfront property at Tiana Beach here owned two parcels of the land himself.

title: Dikes in Hanoi Area Represent 2,000Year Effort to Tame Rivers
description: WASHINGTON, July 13For more than 2,000 years the peasants of northern Vietnam have been locked in unending battle against nature, trying to stem and control the annual high waters of the Red River with an intricate system of dikes.

title: JERSEYANS GROW WEARY OF RAINS
description: WAYNE, N. J., July 13The rains came again yesterday in what, to people living in the lowlying areas of this preaominately middleclass township, is an old familiar story.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In 1965 the Minnesota Twins won the American League pennant by seven games over the Chicago White Sox, warming the round bosom of Calvin R. Griffith with a sense of fulfillment he had not experienced since his days as bat boy for Washington's champion Senators 40 years earlier It wasn't a great team, the only one that ever won a big league baseball championship in the North Country. It wasn't as good as the Senators who won 1924 and 1925 or the team that brought Washington its last championship in 1933, but it was easily the best Calvin had had since inheriting the club from his uncle 10 years before.

title: Enemy Tanks at Quangtri Stab At Encircling South Vietnamese
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 14  The fighting around the city of Quangtri became heavier yesterday as the North Vietnamese again counterattacked with tanks against the South Vietnamese forces that partly ring the city.

title: TRW Earnings Increase by 14% on Record Sales
description: Strong performance in all of its major business categories enabled TRW, Inc., to lift secondquarter net earnings by 14 per cent on a sales gain of 13 per cent to a new record, Horace A. Shepard, chairman and chief executive of the Clevelandbased diversified industrial company, reported yesterday.

title: Hanoi, as Talks Resume, Appears to Hint at Shift
description: PARIS, July 13The North Vietnamese delegation seemed to offer a subtle change today in its negotiating position at the Paris peace talks, which resumed after a 10week hiatus.

title: Israel Spares Life of Arab Convicted of Grenade Attack
description: TEL AVIV, July 13A military court of appeals today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed three days ago on a 24yearold Arab guerrilla.

title: Fillmore, Silent a Year, Will Rock for New Owner
description: When I walked through the empty theater, I got the feeling that New York deserved to have the Fillmore live again, said Frank N. Morgenstern, the Long Island realtor and investor who has bought the grandiose old Fillmore East movie palace in the East Village that was the citadel of rock culture in New York until it closed a year ago.

title: Panel Created to Advise The O.E.O. on Resources
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Phillip V. Sanchez, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, announced today the creation of a committee to advise the office on ways to increase private resources in programs dealing with poverty.

title: Counsel for Fischer Will Fight Forfeit
description: Bobby Fischer's attorney flew last night to Iceland to try to get chess officials to lift yesterclay's forfeit against the American grandmaster. If he does not succeed, the attorney said, he will sue to force them to lift the forfeit.

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION
description: Following is the prepared text of Senator George McGovern's speech accepting the Democratic Presidential nomination:

title: ACQUITTAL DENIED IN NEWARK TRIAL
description: NEWARK, July 13Superior Court Judge Erwin S. Fulop rejected a defense motion today for the acquittal of Dr. E. Wyman Garrett and two other defendants on charges of interfering with the newsgathering activities of a New York Times reporter.

title: Sparky Lyle: A Man Nobody Knows and Nobody Scares
description: The New York Yankees will open a twoweek home stand tonight after their first winning trip of the season and their best chance to keep winning may ride on one of their newest and leastknown membersAlbert W. Lyle.

title: Dance: Dolin Variations
description: Let me confess to a prejudice. I love Anton Dolin's Variations for Four. I know most of its faults. The music by Marguerite Keogh, for example, is, if anyone can believe it, a pastiche of Minkusi And the choreography is unremittingly virtuosic. And yet

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, July 13 (UPI)The Bank of France announced today a rise in bank reserve rates affecting both current and saving accounts in order to compensate for the recent influx of foreign currencies into the country.

title: HARRIS, 3 OTHERS LEAD GOLF Al 65
description: MILWAUKEE, July 13 (AP)Four pros shared the firstround lead in the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament today with sixunderpar 65's.

title: Man in the News
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13 Thomas F. Eagleton was the first man to mark his VicePresidential selection as a surprise. I'm flabbergasted, the boyish Senator from Missouri said today. Yet he was spotted some time ago by colleagues and the press gallery as one of the brightest and most ambitious young stars of the Senate, and a variety of subtle balances in his political profile suggest a casting director's ideal for a running mate. An urban antiwar liberal from a moderately conservative state, he is also a Border state Roman Catholic chosen to run with a Prairie state Methodist. His start in political life as a prosecutor gives him some claim to the titles of crimefighter and reformer, but he is a product and friend of Missouri's muscular regular Democratic organization.

title: Holt Lifts Star Class Lead; 2 Races Remain in Trials
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 (AP)Alan Holt of Seattle increased his lead in the United States Olympic star class yachting trials today by winning the fifth race.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Activity in the soybean futures pit of the Chicago Board of Trade accelerated when it was confirmed that export sales would be high this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of course there just isn't enough gold in the world to finance the immense boom in trade, as C. L. Sulzberger points out [column June 30]. How could there be with the price of gold held down by official decree while the cost of goods and services soared into the stratosphere? The cost of mining precious metals is no exception.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 14 (Reuters)After its dismal batting display in the second cricket test, which Australia won to even the fivematch Series, England desperately sought to reassert itself today in the third test. But the English were tied down by some accurate bowling and at the close of the second day had 117 runs for four wickets in reply to Australia's first innings of 315.

title: Ontario Begins Inquiry Into Philathea College
description: The Minister of Colleges and Universities in Ontario has begun an investigation of Philathea College, an unaccredited religious college that has been granting doctoral degrees, to determine if its charter should be revoked.

title: Earnings in Quarter Gain At Westinghouse Electric
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation realized an increase of 14.4 per cent in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 7.6 per cent, lifting the halfyear net by 19.8 per cent and sales by 7.6 per cent to mark the fifth consecutive record for these periods, according to yesterday's report by D. C. Burnham, chairman.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 A twoway cable television system that was given a tryout in Manhattan last year was patented this week by Joseph H. Beck, vice president of Video Information Systerns, Inc., New York. Patent 3,676,580 covers the key instrument  a combination receiver, transmitter and tuner called a transponderand its operation in the network. A computer at the central office compiles information obtained from viewers.

title: Spots News in Brief
description: The Jets had their first contact workout at Hofstra University and their first injury yesterday while the Giants continued to watch the front door at Monmouth College with the hope that Bob Grim and Roland Lakes would walk through.

title: Fire Buffs Await the Big One
description: The 300 people who are here from all over the United States and Canada for the annual convention of the International Fire Buffs Associates, Inc., say they don't really want a big fire to break out in New York, but if there has to be one, they hope it comes now while they are here to buff it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Reporters of The Times and others, continue to insist that Hanoi's disappointments on the battlefields of South Vietnam are almost totally attributable to our escalated use of airpower. Such a view assumes that the communist military did not anticipate our aerial response when planning this offensive.

title: ABYSSINIAN GETS A NEW MINISTER
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Proctor, a professor of theology at Rutgers University, was elected yesterday to take the place of the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr. as pastor of the 164yearold Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.

title: A Brief Yet Helpful, Guide Civil Disobedieince
description: In perpetrating a revolution, there are two requirements: someone or something to revolt against and someone to actually show up and do the revolting. Dress is usually casual and both parties may be flexible about time and place but if either faction fails to attend, the whole enterprise is likely to come off badly. In the Chinese Revolution of 1650 neither party showed up and the deposit on the hall was forfeited.

title: COLBERT'S 67 TIES JOHNSON IN GOLF
description: MILWAUKEE, July 14 (AP)Jim Colbert shaved six strokes from par in his first eight holes today, finished with a 67, and gained a share of the lead with George Johnson after the sec ond round of the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament. Colbert and Johnson each had a total of 133.

title: New Bishop Elected by Methodists
description: Bishop W. Ralph Ward Jr. of Syracuse has been appointed the new Bishop of the New York Area of the United Methodist Church.

title: A Little Levittown ivaling the Taj MahalAnd She Floats
description: William J. Levitt, who 25 years ago transformed Long Island potato field into the largest experiment in instant mass housing anywhere (and built the 1,882 houses for an estimated $11.5million), has come up with something else to talk about  his yacht.

title: Eyewitness in the Phillips Trial Tells of Slaying in Brothel Here
description: The only known eyewitness to the 1968 Christmas Eve slaying of an East Side pimp and one of his prostitutes yesterday identified Patrolman William R. Phillips  a key informer and witness for the Knapp Commission  as the murderer.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (Reuters)  The State Department rebuked Miss Fonda today after reports that she had made antiwar broadcasts in Hanoi.

title: Elliott, Zett in Golf Lead
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 14 (AP) Dan Elliott of Portland, Ore and John Zett Jr. of Amarillo rex., shared the lead today at 214 in the 47th annual National Public Links golf tournament after a wind4blowtt third round. Elliott, who led by four strokes after 36 holes; shot a 76. Zett scored his second straight 72 Three golfers are at 216.

title: Central Banks Move to Bolster Dollar
description: LONDON, July 14 (AP)Banks throughout Europe today reluctantly bought $1.5billion to shore up the dollar against heavy attacks by traders.

title: Miss Todd Flies to London After Rhodesia Frees Her
description: LONDON, July 14 (UPI) The daughter of the former Prime Minister of Rhodesia, released after six months detention with her father, arrived in Britain today.

title: Nixon's Daughter Gaining After Pneumonia Attack
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla July 14 (Reuters)  President Nixon's younger daughter, Julie, who is Mrs. David Eisenhower, is recovering after an attack of viral pneumonia that she contracted a few days ago.

title: MRS. FRANK A. READY
description: Mrs. Ethel Severs Ready, widow of Frank A. Ready, former president of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria Corporation, died yesterday in Red Bank, N. J., following a fall in which she broke her hip. She was SO years old and lived at 301 East 47th Street here.

title: Fire Scars Colorado Park
description: MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK, Colo., July 14 (UPI)A forest fire that has burned out of control most of this week had scerred 2,800 acres today. Mesa Verde, which is noted for its Indian cliff dwellings, was closed to visitors yesterday as the fire continued to spread. (Park officials have brought in 600 men to fight the blaze.

title: Truman Reported Gaining
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 14 (AP)Research Medical Center reported today that former President Harry S. Truman continues in good condition. A hospital spokesman quoted Mr. Truman's personal physician, Dr. Wallace H. Graham, as saying that Mr. Truman is convalescing well.

title: Two Killed in Copter Crash
description: FORT STEWART, Ga., July 14 (UPI)  The crash of an attack helicopter today took the lives of two Army pilots training here. They were identified as C. W. 2 Edmund L. Heynoski, 23 years old, of Erie, Pa., the pilot, and C. W. 2 James A. McMullin Jr., 24, of Patuxent River, Md., a student.

title: Curtis to Replace Whitney On Board of Public TV Unit
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14The Western White House announced today that John Hay Whitney, the Communications industry executive, had resigned as a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. He will be replaced by Thomas B. Curtis, a former Republican Congress man from Missouri.

title: Town House Offered to U. N,
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14A fiveStory Sutton Place town house built more than 50 years ago for the daughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, the financier, has been offered by the owner to the United Nations as a residence for the Secretary General. The mansion, at 3 Sutton Place, has a garden and sweeping view of the East River. It is now owned by Arthur A. Houghton Jr., president of Steuben Glass.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 14On the raised platform in the British Open's interview area, Lee Trevino gulped an orange barley soft drink.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that college students must be allowed to register and vote their college towns.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14Delegates to the Democratic National Convention dispersed today to all parts of the country in the same peaceful and orderly manner that characterized a week that was almost all business and very little clay.

title: New Aid to Yemen Set, Rogers Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States had agreed to resume economic aid to Yemen.

title: Wallace 3dParty Draft Due
description: HOUSTON, July 14 (AP) Morris Womack, vice chairman of the Texas, Ameircan, karty, said today that the party would try to draft Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama as its Presidential candidate although Mr. WIlace has said he is not interested in a third party race.

title: STOCKS REGISTER WEEK'S FIRST GAIN
description: The stock market finally scored its first gain of the week yesterday, helped in part by the improved profits of several computer manufacturers and by a modest rally in the recently buffeted airlines and some glamour issues.

title: Swiss Aide Denies Terrorist Combine Has a Zurich Office
description: GENEVA, July 14A band of young Swiss, anarchists has established links with similar bands  In West Germany and Berlin, Hans Welder, the Swiss Attorney General, said today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Following are excerpts from transcripts of speeches early yesterday morning to the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, the VicePresidential nominee, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: In Japan, It's the Season for Bonus, Obon and Ochugen
description: TOKYO, July 14A reader of the Japanese press or of dispatches about this island power might conclude that from midJune to midJuly the Japanese were engrossed in the election of a new premier after the post had been held for nearly eight years by a man who had lately become increasingly unpopular.

title: Tanzania Frees 52 Held After Zanzibar Murder
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 14 (Agence FrancePresse) Fiftytwo of 97 people detained in mainland Tanzania for questioning after the assassination on April 7 of Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, the ruler of Zanzibar, have now been released, a Governmen spokesman here said.

title: Spain Slow to Act For Role in Europe
description: MADRID, July 14The European Common Market has become one of the most powerful factors for political change in Spain since Generalissimo Francisco Franco founded his regime in 1939 after victory in the civil war.

title: Thais Sentence 2 Americans On a Charge of Sacrilege
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 (Reuters)A court in central Thailand has sentenced a young American Mormon missionary and a friend to six months imprisonment each for sacrilege, official provincial sources announced today.

title: Screen: Ralph Nelson's 'Wrath of God'
description: Suppose you have the politics: violent revolution. Then you pick the time and the place: 1920's, somewhere south of Mexico. If you add the mansay, a bearish Boston priest who Is Not What He Seems (or is he?)and provide him with the machine  an improbable ancient touring caryou need only find the pride and the passion, and you will have a movie.I'm not even sure you will need film and camera. A movie will form just by the natural disposition of things. Of course it won't be a very good movie, and it will almost unavoidably resemble Ralph Nelson's "The Wrath of God," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters."The Wrath of God" has the politics, the time and place, the man and the machine. It also has some passion (Paula Pritchett in braids and Indian buckskins) and, between John Colicos and Frank Langella at opposite ends of the political spectrum, it has somewhat more neurotic pride than it knows what to do with.The man is Robert Mitchum, a priest defrocked by his own goodness, and he is joined by Ken Hutchison, who plays an Irish adventurer, and Victor Buono, who shamelessly and quite expertly plays Sidney Green-street.There is also a plot and much meaning, but to describe either would run to greater length and intricacy than roll-call at the Democratic National Convention, and both mainly serve the picturesque qualify of the elements  place, politics, man, machine, etc.rather than the other way round. But with so much junk in one pile, it would be sad indeed if there weren't a little quality at the edges.And as in all the Ralph Nelson films I have ever seen, that quality rests in the exuberance of performance and in a certain commitment to whatever dumb thing is going on at any moment. There is an active integrity in all this that, though never enough to make the movie good, is occasionally able to make this bad movie admirable.The cast is mostly excellent. Not only Mitchum and the fine Ken Hutchison (who is virtually unknown here) but also all the countless revolutionaries who die like flies, or praise the Lord, or even dance in the streets when the crazy screenplay calls for it.And I cannot finally condemn a film in which the heroine (the beauteous Indian maiden Chela), silent since she saw her parents killed long years before, suddenly regains her speech just in time to warn her lover of a perfidious assassin's bullet. Such miracles, in this day and age, bespeak a hokum beyond the reach of art.

title: WALL ST. HAILING BIGBOARD CHOICE
description: Wall Street reacted with approval yesterday to the selection of James J. Needham, commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to become the first fulltime salaried chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Proxmire Assails the Pentagon Over a Sperry Rand Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Senator William Proxmire accused the Pentagon today of allowing the Sperry Rand Corporation to reap large profits at no risk by letting it run an ammunition plant on the basis of guaranteed costplus profit.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Loss for the Public
description: A subtle trend toward erosion of the Bill of Rights is among the points of concern raised by the shift in the Supreme Court. Specifically, the decision denying reporters the right to refuse to reveal their sources of confidential information to a grand jury reflects, as Justice Stewart pointedly observed in his sharp dissent; a disturbing insensitivity to the critical role of an independent press in our society.

title: Floods Reported in Soviet
description: MOSCOW July 14 (AP)Izvestia reported tonight that a flash flood swept through Tbilisi, capital of Soviet Georgia, last month, causing severe damage and taking some lives, but it gave no figures.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STANTON, Del., July 14 (AP)Some of the victims of the bus bandits of the Baltimore Beltway will have their day at the races tomorrow. Delaware Park will name the fifth race the Belated Bettors Purse and pick up the tab for 22 guests who were among 43 passengers on a chartered bus that was hijacked, July. 3, while en route from Baltimore to the track. The passengers were robbed of $3,414.

title: Personalities: A Buyer Found for Ron Sellers
description: One slightly used wide receiver was snapped up off the trade market yesterday, but one serviceable quarterback is still available. Ron Sellers, the New England Patriots No. 1 draft choice of who missed four games last year because of an injury and lost his starting job, was traded to the Super Bowl champions, the Dallas Cowboys, for a high 1973 draft choice. However, John Mazur, the Patriot coach, who  opens his camp in western Massachusetts today, is still trying to make a deal for Mike Taliaterm, a quarterback who got no playing time behind Jim Plunkett, New England's No. 1 pick, last year: After coming to the Patriots from the Jets in 1968 for Babe Parilli, Taliaferro tied Joe Nemeth for runnerup honors in touchdown passes in the American Football League in 1969 with 19 and was: named the comeback player of the year. Two injuryplagued members of the Philadelphia Eagles announced their retirements from pro football to devote their time to separate real estate interests in south Jersey. They were Fred Hill, a receiver with the Eagles for seven years, and Joe Scarpati, a defensive back, who played seven of his eight years with Philadelphia, the other with New Orleans.

title: Theology Dean Named By Boston University
description: BOSTON, July 14Boston University announced today the appointment of the Rev. Dr. J. Robert Nelson as dean of its School of Theology.

title: Rinfret to Assist Nixon In Election Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Pierre A. Rinfret, the economist who heads RinfretBoston Associates, Inc., a consulting company, will be an economic consultant to President Nixon during his campaign for reelection, it became known today. Mr. Rinfret Mien a stmtlar role in the President's 1968 campaign.

title: Suffolk May Not Own Part of Beach It Paid For
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 14Despite the payment of $7.5million for 11,000 feet of oceanfront property at Tiana Beach, Suffolk County still does not have clear ownership of the 295 acres of parkland.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: Basil A. Paterson, elected yesterday as the vice chairman of the Democratic party, was the first black to run for statewide office in New York. He was the party's candidate for Lieutenant Governor in 1970.

title: $1 Million Down the Drain
description: ALGONA, towaEgypt can claim the wonders of the pyramids, Texas has a reiplendent Presidential library that outdoes all others. But Iowa claims the world's only milliondollar toilet.

title: Confusion Marks Caucus
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14New York delegates failed early today to select new Democratic National Committee members from the state in the confusion surrounding their walkout from the convention) floor to protest the allocation of committeemen.

title: Business Briefs
description: A survey showed yesterday that United Statesbased international corporations found earnings rosier abroad than they did at home last year.

title: CONNALLY TO WORK TO REELECT NIXON
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14John B. Connally, the Texas Democrat who was Presilent Nixon's Treasury Secretary, announced today that he would support Mr. Nixon's reelection and spend most of his time until November attemptmg to persuade Other Democrats to do likewise.

title: Afghanistan's Market for Used U. S. Clothing Shrinks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 9The old man nudged his mule, laden with grapes, through the busy bazaar. The turbanlike cloth he wore loosely around his head nodded with each slow step.

title: Jacklin Is Next and Nicklaus Trails by 6
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 14In a storybook finish that defies belief, Lee Trevino leads the British Open at 207 with a day to go. He is a stroke ahead of Tony Jacklin and six strokes ahead of Jack Nicklaus, whose improbable dream of the grand slam faded with a routine parround of 71 while the two leaders were taking the course apart.

title: JANE FONDA APPEAL REPORTED BY HANOI
description: TOKYO, July 14 (UPI) Jane Fonda, who is on a visit to Hanoi, asked United States pilots to reconsider their participation in the Vietnam war in a broadcast yesterday over the Voice of Vietnam Radio, the North Vietnamese press agency said today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ALBANY, July 14 (UPI)After six months of waiting, the city of Schenectady won tentative state approval today to Start the first offtrack betting operations outside New York City. The Offtrack Betting. Commission approved Schenectady's plan under two conditions that it submit additional data on technical arrangements, and that it not take bets during hours that Saratoga Raceway is operating.

title: Move for Harmony
description: Despite the petulant fortyminute protest walkout by the New York delegation, there ??? ??? viewing the Democratic National Convention's postponement of farreaching reforms in the party's structure and operations as a capitulation by Senator McGovern to Old Guard elements. Rather, it was a concession to true democratic procedure and an expression of decent regard for the millions of Democrats who did not happen to be in Miami Beach.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Arthur F. Leiper demonstrates in his June 24 letter, Aid, to Parochial Schools, that he knows nothing about the great organization he slanders, the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.

title: PATTERSON HALTS AGOSTO AFTER SIX
description: It was a far cry from the legions of fans that used to fill much of the old Polo Grounds or Yankee Stadium to watch Floyd Patterson fight.

title: Most New Issues Show Increases In Quiet Trading
description: Twelve new issues bowed this week in public trading on the overthecounter market and by the close yesterday most of them were being quoted at prices somewhat above their offering price.

title: Eagleton Victory Comes On the Heels of Defeat
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 14 (AP)Senator Thomas Eagleton, chosen by the Democratic National Convention yesterday as' the party's Vice  Presidential nominee, lost an electibn earlier this year in a fiveway race for alumni trustee of Amherst College. The results were announced at the college's commencement in June.

title: Curbs on Hand Luggage Asked By F. A. A. to Thwart Hijackers
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration has requested the airlines for new measures to prevent weapons from being brought aboard airplanes in carryon luggage and several airlines have taken steps to comply.

title: Foes of Rhodesia Predict New Mineral Cargoes Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14The American Committee on Africa predicted today that new shipments of Rhodesian chrome and nickel would arrive in United States ports this month in violation of Security Council embargo on trade with Rodesia.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14After one triumphant week in the Florida sun, George McGovern is again the underdog, only this time he has a whole kennel of Democrats barking fear and discontent.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP)A fiveyearold antitrust suit by 927 franchise holders against Chicken Delight has been settled for $2.5million with United States District Court approval.

title: Goldwater Expects the War To End Formally in 60 Days
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 14 (AP)  Senator Barry M. Goldwater says that he thinks the Vietnam war will end within 60 days.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14Mrs. George McGovern said today that she would like to be a very activist First Lady and I intend to be. She said she wanted to serve as the advocate in the White House for the children of America.

title: L I. Executive Is Charged In $410,000 Company Theft
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 14The president of a Long Island dental supply company was held in $100,000 bail in Suffolk County District Court today on charges of absconding with $410,000 of his company's funds.

title: A LEADER IN SIBERIA ASKS CHINESE AMITY
description: MOSCOW, July 14A high Siberian regional official has called on China to renew the goodneighborly relations that once linked his territory, Khabarovsk, with Manchuria, across the Amur River.

title: Experimental Car Built By City College Students
description: An experimental car, built by students at City College and equipped with both, an electric motor and a gasoline engine, was unveiled here yesterday.

title: Egyptian Premier Heads Home From Soviet Talks
description: MOSCOW, July 14Premier Aziz Sidky of Egypt left today after a twoday visit in which he reviewed Soviet economic and military aid and the situation in the Middle East.

title: JANET ELY, 18, WINS A.A.U. DIVING CROWN
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 14 (AP) Mike Finneran, a midyear Ohio State graduate, and 18yearold Janet Ely, a freshman at the University of Michigan, captured titles at the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor diving championships today.

title: TRACY AND HEPBURN TO BENEFIT LIBRARY
description: Nine filmsall of those that teamed Katharine Hepburn and the late Spencer Tracywill be shown at the Lincoln Center Library and the Museum for the Performing Arts, starting Sept. 13, as a benefit for the library. The screenings will be presented by Bantam Books, which is publishing the paperback edition of Garson Kanin's Tracy and Hepburn: An Intimate Memoir Aug. 4. Mr. Kanin will serve as chairman of the benefit.

title: FISCHER'S APPEAL ON FORFEIT FAILS
