description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 14 A fourman committee voted today to uphold the decision of Lothar Schmid, the referee in the world chess championship match here, that Bobby, ischer, the American challenger, had forfeited yesterday's game to Boris Spassky, the Soviet titleholder.

title: City to Look Into Ph.D. Use at GroupTherapy School
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs decided yesterday to investigate the Group Relations Ongoing Workshop (GROW) to see if the school's administrators and faculty members are making fraudulent use of Ph.D.'s from unaccredited universities.

title: EDWIN M'DONALD, BANKER, WAS 75
description: Edwin C. MCDonald, former chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada Trust Company and of Thomson Newspapers, Inc., died yesterday in Miami. He was 75 years old and lived in Miami and at the Union League Club of which he was a former president.

title: McGovern: Unknown Quantity Abroad
description: PARIS, July 14To most of the world, Senator George McGovern popped out of the Democratic convention like a jackinthebox, a disconcerting but not too important surprise.

title: NIXON IS ENDORSED BY 2 UNION LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) As George Meany summoned labor's executive council to decide whether to endorse George McGovern, two national union presidents said today that they would support President Nixon for reelection because Mr. McGovern's Democratic platform was unacceptable and repulsive.

title: Nielsen Says N.B.C. Had Most Viewers
description: Nielsen ratings indicate that the National Broadcasting Company captured the largest share of television viewers in New York and Los Angeles watching the Democratic National Convention.

title: STATE FOILS UNION ON PAY PENALTIES
description: ALBANY, July 14 (AP)A court proceeding was used by New York State today to push through scheduled payroll penalties despite a union move to have them held up until a case involving Easter weekend strikers was straightened out.

title: MRS. FRANZ PICK
description: Mrs. Margaret Pick, the wife of Dr. Franz Pick, publisher of an annual worldcurrency review, died yesterday when shei fell or jumped from a window, of her fifthfloor apartment at 419 East 57th Street. She was 77 years old.

title: Profits on the Beach
description: With the need for public beaches almost desperate, it is appalling to learn of the alleged financial juggling that skyrocketed the price to Suffolk County of oceanfront property for park purposes by 300 per cent in two years. According to charges under preparation for submission to the County Board of Ethics, Thomas Strong, a trustee of the Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation in 1967 and now a member of the County Legislature, knew a year before it was announced that the county intended to buy Tiana Beach in the Hamptons as part of a public park. His brother, John Strong, a real estate broker, then proceeded to make large fees through transactions alleged to have involved, promises of higher prices from the county for the parcels of property involved.

title: Antiques: Chess Pieces for Looking, Not Playing
description: Bobby Fischer would never be happy playing chess with the sets collectors now prize most highly, the 18thcentury examples by Wedgwood and Meissen.

title: MRS. GILBERT STEWART
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Barnard Stewart, widow of Brig. Gen. Gilbert Henry Stewart, U.S.A., died Thursday after a long illness at the Lincoln Park (N.J.) Nursing Home. She was 89 years old.

title: PATIENT IS UPHELD IN REFUSING SHOCK
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld the right of a mental patient at Bellevue Hospital to refuse electroshock treatment that had been prescribed by the hospital's physicians.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14Even George McGovern's people say frankly that he can be given no more than an outsider's chance of defeating the incumbent President. But it is important to distinguish that kind of realism from the orotund funeral orations for the Democratic party that some old political hands and commentators have been delivering here in Miami.

title: McGovern Visits Gruening
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14 (AP)  Senator George McGovern paid a hospital visit today to former Senator Ernest Gruenting fo Alaska. Mr. Gruening, 87 years old, underwent surgery a few days ago for an intestinal disorder.

title: Rights Aide Reappointed
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif, July 14 (UPI)President Nixon reappointed today Colston A. Lewis, a Richmond lawyer, as a member of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission for a term expiring July 1, 1977. Mr. Lewis, 60 years old, was first appointed to the commission Aug. 6, 1970, for the remainder of a term expiring July 1, 1972.

title: EXPORTS OF HIDES FACING U.S. CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Administration will limit exports of cattle hides in an effort to curb rising prices of shoes and other leather prodlets, Government sources said today.

title: BRITISH AND I.R.A. BATTLE FIERCELY IN BELFAST AREAS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 14British soldiers fought fierce gun battles with the Irish Republican Army here today, after occupying Roman Catholic strongholds during the night. In 24 hours of almost continuous violence, nine persons were killed, four of them British soldiers.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is a verbal sketch by a contemporary of Denis Diderot descanting in old age on a bewildering variety of topics in his usual mercurial and volatile way to young man whom he had never seen before and who had dropped by only to pay homage to a revered elder. It is a charming and vivid piece with just enough malice to add savor. Diderot laughed at it himself when he read it. I cite it to indicate that if Arthur M. Wilson had wished in his life of the 18thcentury French writer and philosopher to consider Diderot simply as an eccentric but attractive genius he could easily have fleshed out the sketch of a singular and superbly alive personality, who knew the most signifcant figures of his age and who helped shape the next one. But Mr. Wilson, a historican and biographer now retired from Dartmouth, has withstood that temptation. Diderot is important to us as editor of the illustrious Encyclopedie, the single most influential literary document of its time, and of such books as Rameau's Nephew and D'Alembert's Dream. As a result, the Wilson biography is really a branch of intellectual history. The substance of the Encyclopedie receives as much attention as Diderot's chronology, and Mr. Wilson gives more attention to the analysis of Diderot's thought than to the minutiae of his daytoday living. Not that those details are missing. But the author makes the intellectual ferment, the disputes over ideas, the challenges of friends and opponents as exciting as his subject's clandestine marriage or his long, ardent wooing of his mistress, Sophie Volland. (There surely must be another wordsomething more domesticfor a woman who retains the devotion of a man for 30 years.) Diderot's range of interest was so wide and his anticipations of modern thought so numerous that the book Diderot becomes in effect an introductory study of the Enlightenment.

title: Reward for Hijackers Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Continental Airlines added $25,000 today to the $250,000 reward offered earlier this year by five other airlines for information leading to arrest and conviction of those engaged in airplane hijacking or extortion. The five other carriers are American, Eastern, Pan Am, Trans World and United.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME WESTERN WOMAN PARTY'S CHAIRMAN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14The Democratic National Committee chose as its chairman today Mrs. Jean Westwood of Utah, a key organizer of Senator George McGovern's successful pursuit of the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Wallace Suspect is Moved
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., July 14 (UPI)Arthur H. Bremer, accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, has been transferred to Prince George's County Jail, where 20 inmates have escaped in the last two years. But before his arrival last night from a state hospital under heavy guard, workmen completed the last of new sucuriyt arrangements at the jail that cost an estimated $4,000 He is scheduled to be tried on state charges beginning July 31 in the Circuit Court in Upper Marlboro.

title: DREAM OF. KINGS FIRST BY A HEAD
description: A shadow Toll on a horse that has been afraid of shadows proved most effective once more, in the ease of Robert Dater's Dream of Kings at Agueduct yesterday. The 5yearold son' of Saidam, opposing, a small, but formidable field in the feature race on the card, went on to take the sevenfurlohg Sprint by a head.

title: PAPERS FIGHT BAN ON JOB ADS BY SEX
description: WATERBURY, July 14 (AP)Thirtyfive Connecticut newspapers have appealed a state order barring the use of separate male and female designations in helpwanted advertisements.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14President Nixon issued today a proclamation designating September as national voter registration month.

title: Dollar Plan Published
description: BRUSSELS, July 14 (Reuters) Belgium today published plan to eliminate the dollar as a reserve currency.

title: Mendoza. Upsets Graebner In Welsh Tennis, 63, 6.4
description: NEWPORT, Wales, July 14 (AP)  John Mendoza, a low ranked English tennis player, scored the biggest upset of his career today, beating topseeded Clark Graebner of New York 63, 64, in a semifinal of the Welsh lawn tennis championships.

title: Children Commemorate Amiable Child Here
description: It was a perfect day for a children's outing in Riverside Park, one that might be remembered thoughtfully in years to come. It was sunny, with a cooling breeze off the Hudson, as 25 youngsters gathered around a treeshaded, seldomnoticed gravesite 100 yards north of Grant's Tomb.

title: S.E.C. Orders Trading Halt In Illustrated. Encyclopedia
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Cominission ordered today the suspension of trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in the securities of Illustrated World Encyclopedia, a New York corporation with its principal office in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Wallace Is Flown to Center In Birmingham for Therapy
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace, his political future still in doubt, entered a rehabilitation center today for four weeks of intensive therapy aimed at making him physically independent.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Price Commission has agreed to the Interstate Commerce Commission plan calling for approval of rata increases in thetransportation industry by the I.C.C. only, George Stafford, I.C.C. chairman, said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I noted in a recent letter the remarks of one of your readers concerning the current development of shopping malls and her observation that the growth of shopping malls does occur concurrently with the growth of cultural facilities.

title: BIG BOARD TO DEFER EXPULSION OF STARK
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had agreed to defer its expulsion of Robert W. Stark Jr., as a member of the exchange, and of Robert W. Stark Jr. Inc., as a member firm, for one week until July 24.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14 (UPI) New Jersey delegates, concluding their activity at the convention today on the same divisive note that prevailed since they arrived here, chose two McGovern delegates as new national committee members.

title: U.S. Circuit Court Considering United Financial Group Appeal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP)An appeal by United Financial Group, Inc., from an order enjoining its continued operation and placing it under a receiver has been taken under consideration by the Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 The recent political campaigns, sharply increased the truancy rate of some New York Representatives on House roll calls during the first half of the year.

title: Art: Helen Torr Stands on Her Own
description: Helen Torr, who died in 1967 at the age of 81, was known more as the wife of the late American artist Arthur Dove than as a painter in her own right. She had few exhibitions during her lifetime and they usually met with a succinct criticism that underscored her esthetic dependence on her husband. It is evident in her painting that she owed not only a large debt to Dove but also a somewhat small one to Marsden Hartley and Georgia O'Keeffe. These influences might be ascribed to the fact that these artists formed part of a closeknit group in which there was a liberal exchange of artistic ideas.

title: PFINGST IS GIVEN 4 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst was sentenced yesterday to four months in jail and placed on probation for the rest of a threeyear term for his conviction of bankruptcyfraud charges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Richard Presha's statementin defense of voluntary segregation, letter June 22that. there is nothing inherently evil about wanting to be with one's own kind is implicitly, in the context of his whole letter, as racist as the racism he denounces. The separateness which he supports in denouncing Roy Wilkins broad antiracist position is not limited to voluntary association of blacks with blacks; it also involves the exclusion from such associations of whites.

title: 2 BANKS HERE RAISE PRIME RATES TO 5%
description: The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company, as expected, yesterday raised their floating prime rates on business loans to 5 per cent, effective for the week beginning Monday.

title: WESTFIELD IS AGAIN SCENE OF DISORDERS
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., July 14Violence erupted for the second successive evening here last night as black youths smashed windows in a dozen stores in this wealthy Union County suburb.

title: Thomas, 15, Wins With 76
description: JERICHO, L. I., July 14Doug Thomas, 15yearold Ramapo (N. J.) High School sophomore, toured Meadow Brook Club's 7,101yard par72 course in 76 today to win the metropolitan qualifying round of the United States Golf Association junior championship, which will be played at Dallas, Aug. 15. Glenn Goethals of Princeton, N. J., qualified with 77, as did Brian O'Leary, Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Man Released Conditionally After Mishap With Pen Gun
description: A Brooklyn man, arrested Thursday on a weapons charge when a pen gun accidentally discharged in his hand, was given a conditional release in Criminal Court yesterday after Judge Walter Gladwin reviewed the case.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CLAYVILLE, N. Y., July 14 (AP)Darcy Lepir Cheektowaga and. Catherine Morse of Rochester advanced to the championship final of the New York State Women's amateur golf tournament today at the Cedar Lake Country Club near Utica. Miss Lepir won, 4 and 3, from Mrs. Allen Sheals of Allegany. Miss Morse defeated Anne Sadowski of Mechanicville, 2 up.

title: Mysterious Oil Spill on Fire Island's Beach Is Quickly Cleaned Up
description: A mysterious oil spill lightly soiled a fivemile stretch of Fire Island's Great South Beach yesterday between the communities of Saltaire and Sailors Haven, but the Coast Guard, with the help of the Town of Islip, had the beach cleaned up by nightfall. There was no apparent damage to marine, plant or wildlife.

title: Jane Waters Married in Italy To Byrd Price Jr., Yale Law 72
description: Miss Jane Owings Waters and Byrd Leigh Price Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in Turin, Italy. The Rev. Ernesto Ayassot performed the ceremony in thp Waldensian Temple (Protestant).

title: Beauj olais: A Young and Charming Wine
description: Last Nov. 23, a Trans World Airlines jet arrived in New York from Paris with about 100 passengers and, among other things, 25 cases of Beaujolais wine. Since the air freight on a bottle of Beaujolais is probably three or four times the retail profit, there had to be some other reason for flying it from France.

title: JOHN F. KENNEDY, 58, A JOCKEY CLUB AIDE
description: John F. Kennedy, a prominent figure in racing and most recently executive secretary of the Jockey Club, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I., after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 624 Powells Lane, Westbury, L.I.

title: FOREST HILLS SITE MAY BE CUT 50%
description: Mario M. Cuomo, who was appointed by Mayor Lindsay to explore possible revisions in, the controversial plan to build scattersite, lowincome housing in Forest Hills, indicated yesterday that he would recommend a substantial compromise of up to a 50 per cent reduction in the size of the project.

title: A.E.C. SECURITY CHIEF RELIEVED IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission reported today its $36,000ayear director of security had been placed on leave without pay pending the outcome of an investigation of allegations that he borrowed more than $100,000 from other commisSion employes and has not paid it back.

title: Murder Rate Here in First Half of 1972 Set a Record
description: More homicides were committed here in the first half of 1972 than in the first half of any other year in the city's history, the Chief Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday. And the homicide rate is running 11.1 per cent higher than in 1971, when a record number of slayings were committed.

title: WILLIAM F. PYPER
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) William F. Pyper, retired chief of the Washington bureau of the Booth Newspapers, a Michigan group, died today in a Washington area hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: ExNewark School Aide Says He Saw No Threat to Reporter
description: NEWARK, July 14  Arnold M. Hess, former secretary of the Board of Education here, testified today that two defendants charged with forcibly taking the wallet and notebook of New York Times reporter Fox Butterfield were not the same men he saw reaching over the shoulder of the news man at a turbulent school board meeting here 15 months ago.

title: Union Authorizes a Strike In Dispute at Penn Central
description: CLEVELAND, July 14. (UPI) The United Transportation Union notified trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company today that it had granted strike authorization against the carrier in a dispute over crew sizes. No strike date was announced.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)Canada's Trade Minister, JeanLuc Pepin, will visit Washington later this month for trade talks with United States officials, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Calley's Father Dies at 57; Son Saw Him in Hospital
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 14 (UPI)William L. Calley Sr., whose son is under sentence for the murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians a Mylai, South Vietnam, died last night in the Veorans Hospital shortly after his son visited him.

title: Horse Infection Alert
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Agriculture Department warned horse owners in the Southwest today to be on the alert for a new invasion of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis from Mexico.

title: WILBERT CARTER, STEVENS OFFICIAL
description: WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N.C., July 14 (AP)Wilbert James Carter, retired board Chairman of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., textile manufacturers, died last night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived, in Greensboro.

title: Queens Water Rates to Rise
description: ALBANY, July 14 (AP)The Public Service Commission granted permission to the Utilities and Industries Corporation yesterday to increase water rates to customer in Queens so as to provide additional revenue needed by the utility to purchase water from New York City, the commission said. The new rates, which will affect 21,000 of the corporation's customers in the Woodhaven district of Queens, are designed to give the company about $524,000 in additional revenue each year, according to the commission.

title: McGovern, in Capital, Sees Uphill Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  Senator George McGovern arrived tonight at the same airield regularly used by President Nixon and said he had no illusions about the tough campaign ahead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To an Englishman surveying American politics there is something profoundly ironic in the policies advocated by Senator McGovern in the recent primary campaigns. To Americans they may seem novel, extraordinary, perhaps even exciting; but to anyone acquainted with the recent history of Britain or Sweden they are depressingly familiar.

title: Dance: Bruhn Sylphide
description: Erik Bruhn's staging of La Sylphide, which was restored to the American Ballet Theater repertory at the New York State Theater last night, is a most elegant and eloquent version of this old Danish ballet. It was also beautifully danced by a company that is already in its top form.

title: AsianAmerican Bishop
description: SEATTLE, July 14 (AP)The Rev. Wilbur W. Y. Choy of Berkeley, Calif., was elected today the first Asian  American bishop in the United Methodist Church in the United States. Mr. Choy, a native of Stockton, Calif., has been a minister since 1943. He has served since 1969 as a Methodist district superintendent in Berkeley.

title: GEORGE D. MORIARTY
description: George D. Moriarty, a former secretary and governor of the Real Estate Board of New York, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street. His real estate office had been at 12 East 41st Street.

title: The Screen: Cops Take Rap in 'Fuzz':Detective Shenanigans Exhibited at Victoria Raquel Welch Plays Endangered Decoy
description: "Fuzz looks more like a dress rehearsal than a finished film, a very dry run for something that is apparently meant to be a comedy-melodrama about ineptitude, especially the day-to-day ineptitude of a group of detectives attached to a Boston precinct station.When Detective Eileen McHenry (Raquel Welch) is acting as a decoy to catch a local rape artist, she almost succeeds in becoming his victim. Another stake-out comes close to failure because two detectives, played by Jack Weston and Burt Reynolds (his Zapata mustache notwithstanding), get tangled up in their disguises, which are nuns' habits.The milieu is forlongly realistic, as are the anonymous pickpockets, petty hoods, murderers and crazies who are shuttled through the station, mostly, however, for laughs. The attitude of the movie is best defined when a bungling detective shoots himself in the foot and we are asked to slap thighs with delight. There is no great amount of blood on the screen, which, I suppose, is meant to temper the spectacle of cars being blown up, of people being picked off by snipers and of Skid Row bums being set on fire by bored juvenile delinquents.Perhaps because it's aimed at people with minimum attention spans, the film contains several more plots than are strictly necessary, or than can be decently integrated by Evan Hunter, who adapted his own novel to the screen, and by Richard A. Colla, who directed the film in such short takes that even the seasons outside the precinct station don't seem to match. One minute it looks like deep winter, the next minute early fall.It's a measure of somethingthough I'm not sure of whatthat the straightest performance is given by Raquel Welch, who isn't around much of the time. When she is, she looks as irritated, but as resolutely patient as Gloria Steinem defending women's rights on a TV talk show. Jack Weston and Burt Reynolds, both of whom have been good comedians in the past, play in their roles as if performing on a Las Vegas stage to an audience of pals, including Don Rickles, who seems, unfortunately, to have presented Reynolds with his style of delivery.

title: C. Dale Fuller Is Dead at 56; Active in Foreign Policy Group
description: C. Dale Fuller, executive vice president of the Foreign Policy Association who had been aclive for more than 30 years in education on world affairs, died of cancer at his home at Mount Vernon, N. Y., on Monday. He was 56 year's old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times notes [news story July 3] that Wall Streeters are alarmed by George McGovern. Apparently they believe that his good prospects are responsible for the current market weakness. They also believe his economic proposals would, if realized, cripple the nation's economy.

title: Holt Nears Olympicterth In U.S. Star. Class Trials
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP)The series leader, Alan Holt, finished sixth in light winds today but appeared certain to win the United States Olympic Star Class yacht trials.

title: Oil Workers Find the Good Life 23 Miles Off the Louisiana Coast
description: LEMA PLATFORM, in the Gulf of Mexico, July 13 This is a subtropical island inhabited by 26 men.

title: Italy Has a Government Again, But It Has Problems
description: ROME, July 14For the first time since fall, Italy has a fully functioning Government  but the odds are it won't last long.

title: Mets Beat Padres, 3 to 2; Schneck Homers in Debut
description: SAN DIEGO, July 14Dave Schneck, the newest Met, had two reasons to celebrate after his major league debut tonight.

title: No Special Role for Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay returned yesterday from the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach, saying that most of the New York delegation had been strangers to him, that he did not even know who would run Senator George McGovern's campaign in New York State, and that no one had asked him to take any special role in it.

title: 2 Signed for Simon Comedy
description: Sam Levene and Jack Albertson have signed contracts to costar in the new Neil Simon comedy, The Sunshine Boys, which is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theater on Dec. 20. They will appear as two vaudeville partners who come out of retirement to do one last show together. Alan Arkin is staging the comedy, which is being produced by Emanuel Azenberg and Eugene V. Wolsk.

title: Panel in Pentagon Papers Case Opposes War, Questions Secrecy
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14A panel of prospective jurors that had initially appalled defense lawyers in the Pentagon papers case indicated today under questioning criticism of the Vietnam war and the Government's security classification system.

title: Democrats Feel Impact Of Women's New Power
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14Mrs. Martha Clampitt McKay of North Carolina had drink with a national polling expert Tuesday afternoon to find out how the country felt about abortion. Louis Harris, the pollster, told her that the majority of the voters in the South and MidWest were against it.

title: Woman in the News
description: MIAMI BEACH, FIa., July 14Moments after Senator George McGovern and the Democratic National Committee chose her as the new chief of the party here today, Mrs. Jean Westwood ran into the first bit of what she expects will be a mountain of problems. I'm proud to be your chairman, she told them. You're the chairwoman, someone shouted from the audience. No, she isn't, she's the chairperson, another dissenter volunteered. I'm proud to be your chairman, she reiterated and the matter was settled. As far as Mrs. Westwood was concerned, the first woman to hold the highest job in either of the national parties would answer to the traditional title.

title: Eagleton Home
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 14 (AP)  A cheering, chanting crowd of roughly 400 supporters welcomed Senator Thomas F. Eagleton to his home state tonight when the Democratic VicePresidential nominee arrived at the Municipal Airport from Miami Beach.

title: Signals Delay L.I.R.R.
description: Signal trouble on the Long Island Rail Road near Valley Stream, L. L. last night caused delays of about 35 minutes, according to a spokesman for the railroad. The spokesman, George Stone, said that the 10:52 P.M. train from Ear Rockaway to Pennsylvania Station was the first to encounter the difficulty, which necessitated turning off power. Delays then spread throughout the system.

title: Bookies Make Test Run With Auto Racers Today
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 14The big tent with the clean windows near the entrance did little business today, but its very presence at the British Grand Prix marks a new attempt to increase the popularity of mo tor racing and empty the pockets of Britons.

title: Richard Negley, Miss Thompson Marry in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 14 Miss Brooke Thompson and Richard Burleson Negley were married here this evening by the Rev. Maurice Benitez at Christ Episcopal Church. A reception for 300 guests was given at the Argyle Club here.

title: Cambodia to Elect Assembly
description: PNOMPENI1, Cambodia, July 14 (UPI)  Cambodia is to elect her first National Assembly under the republican government on Sept. 3, the Interior Ministry announced todgy.

title: CARPENTERS SING AT JERSEY CENTER
description: Pop music moved into the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N. J., Thursday night with the arrival of The Carpenters for a threeday engagement.

title: Price Cut Reported Delayed
description: Frederick Zissu, chairman and chief executive of Vornado, Inc., announced yesterday that the Price Commission had extended for an additional 10 days the suspension of an order requiring Vornado to reduce prices and refrain from price increases. The company said it hoped to work out all its differences with the Price Commission within this period.

title: I.B.M. NET INCOME UP BY 2270 IN HALF
description: The reviving health of the computer industry was attested to yesterday by the release of sharply higher earnings reports by the International Business Machines Corporation, Honeywell, Inc., and the Burroughs Corporation for the second quarter and first half of 1972.

title: Keystone Hilliard is Scratched From the International Tonight
description: WESTBURY L. I., July 14Tomorrow night's $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway is expected to wind up with only she starters. Keystone Hilliard, one of the three American representatives listed for the 14th annual 1mile event, was scratched today and. Une de Mai of France is almost certain to be withdrawn tomorrow Morning.

title: North Korea Hints It Wants Wider Issues in Talks
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 14North Korea gave a strong indication today that it wanted to turn the proposed NorthSouth Red Cross talks on reuniting separated Korean families into some sort of political talks.

title: WILLIAM K. EBEL, 73; EXAVIATION LEADER
description: BALTIMORE, July 14 (AP)William K. Ebel, former aviation industry executive in the United States and. Canada, died here Wednesday of a stroke. He was 73 years old.

title: BANK IN SAN DIEGO MAKES ACQUISITION
description: The United States National Bank in San Diegowhich is headed by C. Arnholt Smith, longtime friend and confidant of President Nixonsaid that it had acquired substantially all of the $95.5million in assets of the Beverly Hills Fidelity Bank in exchange for assumption of its liabilities, including its deposits. No other consideration was paid.

title: Meskill Proposes a Cut In Connecticut Sales Tax
description: HARTFORD, July 14With an unexpected surplus of $30million in Connecticut's treasury this year, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill proposed today that the state sales tax, at 7 per cent the highest of any state in the Union, be rolled back to 6.5 per cent, where it was two weeks ago.

title: Business Briefs
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising the selling price of chrome nickel grades of stainless steel plate by about 5 per cent, effective July 31.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: PARIS, July 14 (Reuters)Le Duc Tho of the North Vietnamese Politburo will arrive tomorrow, the Hanoi delegation at the peace talks said today. Mr. Tho has met more than 10 times with Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, and it was Mourat here that another series of similar contacts might be at hand.

title: SAMUEL HOLZMAN OF CONEY ISLAND
description: Samuel Holzman, a retired Coney Island amusement operator who in 1967 endowed the nation's first chair in endodontics at the New York University College of Dentistry, died Thursday in Coney Island Hospital, after having been struck by an automobile on a Brooklyn street. He was 80 years, old and lived at 201 Brighton First Road, Brooklyn.

title: Lynch Deplores Violence
description: DUBLIN, July 14Priffie Minister John Lynch cautioned the Irish people today against holding romantic or idealist feelings about the violent acts of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army in Ulster.

title: The Balanced Court
description: The President's goal of a politically balanced Supreme Court may have had some theoretical appeal among those who see the world entirely as a giant scale on which liberal and conservative views ought to neutralize each other. In practice, the effect of this balancing seems to be to create a sharply divided Court. Important cases involving civil rights, civil liberties and capital punishment have been decided by the narrowest of majorities. While such rulings do, of course, carry the full weight of the law, the price is high in their power of moral persuasiveness. It is higher still in respect for the integrity and detachment of the legal process.

title: Roundup: A Brother Act Behind the Plate in Detroit
description: Majorleague baseball history was made in Detroit last night when brothers worked behind the plate for the first time as Kansas City cooled off the Tigers, the American League Eastern Division leaders, 10. Detroit had won five straight games.

title: Executive Changes
description: Anthony F. Zaleski has been elected executive vice president of CooperJarrett, Inc.

title: HUMPHREY AIDE JOINS NIXON DRIVE
description: BOSTON, July 14 (AP)An aide to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in 'he Senator's unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination said today that he would work for the reelection of President Nixon.

title: Copper Range Storm Loss
description: The Copper Range Company disclosed yesterday that flood damage in the wake of tropical storm Agnes would result in an estimated aftertax loss of $570,000 at its Hussey Metals plant in Leetsdale, Pa. Full production there is expected by early August, it said.

title: U. S. Olympic Officials Unfair To Women, Mrs. Connolly Says
description: Faced with what she termed a tremendous philosophical dilemma, Mrs. Olga Connolly charged yesterday that United States Olympic Committee officials were treating women track and field athletes like sheep.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TOKYO, July 14 (AP)A 19yearold Japanese ballPlayer died today of a headinjury he received while playing in the second game of the United StatesJapan collegiate world series in Tokyo last Sunday. Akira Tomon, a member of the Japanese allstar team, was hit on the head by a ball thrown from second base to first in a doubleplay attempt. Doctors said he died of brain hemorrhage.

title: Colombia Orders 6 Ships From U.S. and Europeans
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 14 (UPI)  Colombia has ordered two destroyers to be built in the United States and four submarines in Europe, two in West Germany and two in Italy, Colombian Navy sources said today.

title: Industry is advancing on Siberia and the big lake is suffering.
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Is Siberia's farned Lake Baikal on the way to becoming another Lake Erie, a dying lake?

title: Business
description: The House Select Committee on Crime recently conducted hearings on drug abuse in the New York City schools. Although estimates of the extent of drug use varied, virtually all witnesses agreed that a drug epidemic was engulfing the New York City schools. Further, they concurred that this menace had cut across racial and economic lines, afflicting middleclass and ghetto school alike.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Slithery princess dresses. Quilted jackets. Pants with pleats and highrise waistlines.

title: Mrs. Robbins Wed to Earl C. Reno
description: CORNWALL BRIDGE, Conn., July 14 Mrs. June Mellies Robbins of Sharon was married here this afternoon to Earl Clifton Reno of Marlow, N. H. The bride is a freelance magazine writer and Mr. Reno is a retired political scientist.

title: COURT FINES GYPSUM IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP)A Federal judge today found the National Gypsum Company in criminal contempt of court for its reluctance to produce company records subpoenaed by a grand jury investigating alleged pricefixing in the gypsurn industry.

title: Merger News
description: The bank merger front was active yesterday. In New York, the First National City Corporation, whose principal subsidiary, the First National City Bank, is one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, announced an agreement to acquire the Acceptance Finance Company, a St. Louisbased smallloan company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, July 14 (AP)Auto production was up 3,000 units this week because of continuing, shutdowns and vacations, the trade paper, Automotive News, reported today.

title: Qaddafi Heard on Radio After Reports of His Jailing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, July 15 (Reuters)The Libya radio broadcast a recorded speech by Col. Muammae elQaddafi last night apparently with the aim of quashing rumors that the. Libyan leader had been jailed after an extremist coup.

title: Mrs. Pontius Wed To Dr. E. L. Becker
description: Mrs. Mary Eleanor Holden Pontius was married yesterday noon to Dr. E. Lovell Becker. Both are of New York. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Kansan Warns on Drinks
description: TOPEKA, Kan., July 14 (AP) Attorney General Vern Miller ordered the National Rail Passenger Corporation today to cease and decist immediately its activities relating to the sale, dispensing and consumption of alcoholic beverages within the state of Kansas under threat of arrest. Under Kansas law, it is illegal to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink and consumption is forbidden in public places except those licensed is private clubs.

title: Petition Drive for Wallace To Begin in State Thursday
description: The New York State Courage party, which backed Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama for President in 1968, announced yesterday that it would start a drive to get his name on the Presidential ballot in the state this year.

title: RULING MAY EASE WAGE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14A Federal District judge issued a ruling here today that could exempt some 14 million relatively lowpaid workers from wage control.

title: U.S. Plans Close Scrutiny Of Hanoi's Stand at Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) State Department officials said today that a close examination would be made of North Vietnamese statements at the resumed Paris peace talks, but the general attitude appeared negative toward any new initiatives from Hanoi.

title: Floods Forcing Pennsy to Use Last $25Million of Borrowing
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company are going to have to use the last $25million of a $100,million borrowing they made last year to meet payrolls falling due later this month and in August.

title: ICELAND ENLARGES HER FISHING AREA
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 14 (Reuters)Iceland today published regulations extending her fishing limits to 50 nautical miles from 12 miles effective Sept. 1. Publication of the regulations follows the breakdown of talks between Icelandic officials and a British delegation.

title: STOCKS MOVE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: For the first time this week the stocks on the American Stock Exchange edged upward yesterday. As measured by the Amex index the rise was 0.05 with the close at 26.95.

title: MRS. WILLIAM H. DAVIS
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 14Mrs. Grace D. Davis, widow of William Hammatt Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board under President Franklin D. Roosevelt in World War II, died today at the age of 87. She was chairman of the Women's Democratic Committee in the early nineteenforties.

title: Bobby Fischer's Tragedy
description: Bobby Fischer is certainly one of the world's greatest living chess masters, perhaps even the very best. But in the last two weeks he has written one of the least edifying chapters in chess history. His strange behavior has alienated millions of chess enthusiasts throughout the world, including many who originally favored him to win over Boris Spassky. Now the possibility seems strong that his temper tantrums will turn the present world championship match into a nonevent in which Spassky will retain his crown because of Fischer's refusal to play.

title: Saigon Reports 3Hour Battle Northeast of Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 15South Vietnamese marines trying to complete the encirclement of Communistoccupied Quangtri reportedly fought a threehour battle yesterday two to four miles northeast of the city.

title: PalmerBlalock Duo Leads
description: MASHPEE, Mass., July 14 (AP)Sandra Palmer and Janie Blalock teamed for a 64 for the openinground lead today in the $20,000 Angelo's L.P.G.A. fourball golf championship at the Country Club of New Seabury.

title: Six War Foes Indicted in a Plot To Disrupt G.O.P. Convention
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 14 Six national leaders of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War were indicted today on charges that they had conspired to disrupt the Republican National Convention next month with firebombs and shootings.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14It was like two different conventions.

title: Ethel Cutler. Freeman Is Dead; Studied and Wrote on Seminoles
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 14 Mrs. Ethel Cutler Freeman, an anthropologist who specialized in the Seminole Indians of Florida, died today at her home at Blue Mill Road. Her age was 85. She was the widow of Leon S. Freeman, a stockbroker.

title: Nixon Signs Israel Aid Bill
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 (Reuters)President Nixon today signed a bill authorizing a grant of $85million to Israel to meet the cost of resettling Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union. The money had been added by Congress to the foreign relations authorization bill providing funds for the State Department and other Government agencies involved in foreign affairs.

title: T.W.A. Negotiates $87,000 Settlement On OverBooking
description: Trans World Airlines has agreed to pay the United States Government $87,000 for failing to inform more than 500 passengers that they were entitled to free transportation after being denied passage on flights for which they held reservations.

title: Aline Saarinen, Art Critic, Dies at 58.
description: Aline B. Saarinen, chief of the National Broadcasting Company's news bureau in Paris, art critic and former associate art editor of The New York Times, died on Thursday at the DeWitt Nursing Home, 211 East 70th Street. Mrs. Saarinen, who was 58 years old, was the iwidow of Eero Saarinen, the architect. She had been suffering effects of a brain tumor for seven months.

title: Market Place: Pessimist Keeps Monetary Views
description: We talked to William H. Tehan of P. R. Herzig & Co. at lunch the other day and realized once again that he's no man to talk with on an empty stomach.

title: PAKISTANI HOUSE VOTES PEACE PACT
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 14The National Assembly approved the peace agreement with India early this morning, paving the way for a mutual withdrawal by armed forces from territory occupied along the Pakistani border since the twoweek war in Decernber:

title: 3 Killed Outside Memphis When Bus and Car Collide
description: MEMPHIS, July 14 (AP)Three persons died in the headon collision of a Greyhound bus and a car outside Memphis today. Nineteen were injured or shaken.

title: Germans Fight U.S. Army Over Forest
description: GOPPINGEN, West Germany. July 11This hotbed of rural south German conservatism, where a cry of ami go home! was rarely raised in 27 years of American military presence, is up in arms against the United States Army.

title: 3 AMERICANS HELD, PHOTOGRAPHER SAYS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP)YvesMichel Dumont, a French photographer released by the North Vietnamese yesterday after more than three months in captivity, said today that two American advisers had been captured with him and that he had seen a third captive American in Cambodia.

title: Dana Buys Its Own Stock
description: The Dana Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of 500,000 shares of its common stock from the Charles A. Dana Foundation, Inc. The price was $18.7million, or an indicated $37.40 a share. The Toledobased concern said it would hold the shares in its treasury for use in acquisitions and employebenefit plans.

title: A'S DEFEAT YANKS BY 93, THEN 10
description: The New York Yankees, who had been doing well for the past month, bumped heads with the American Leagtie's strongest, team last night and wound Up losing a doubleheader to the Oakland A's, 93 and 10.

title: Another Pakistani Town Put Under Curfew After Violence
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 14 President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's hometown, Larkana, was the scene today of the latest outbreak of the violence that has torn Sind, the main province of Pakistan, for a week.

title: Bridge: FourNothing Trump Break Proves to Be a Happy Fate
description: Declarers who curse the fates because all the outstanding trumps turn out to be in one hand should remember that a foul division can be just what is needed. A case in point is the diagramed deal, which helped Jo Morse of Silver Spring, Md., and Helen Utegaard of Bethesda, Md., win a recent regional title.

title: Soviet Floe Over North Pole
description: MOSCOW, July 14 (AP) An ice floe bearing the manned research station Severny Polyus 19 passed over the North Pole today in a first for Soviet arctic exploration, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Economic Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The United States is in an extraordinary position in the latest, international monetary flareup Its currency is the one under attack and yet there is little or nothing it can do, wants to do or needs to do.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Listening to the stories behind each hijacker during the current plethora of air piracy points to a recurrent theme of frustration: to the hijacker, the hijacking seems to represent a last, desperate effort for personal integrity in times that make this basic human feeling so hard to realize.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 15 With the help of a new Federal income tax incentive for individuals, Senator George McGovern's financial aides hope to raise from $25million to $35million for his fourmonth Democratic Presidential campaign largely through gifts of no more than $25 each from hundreds of thousands of small donors.

title: SewingMachine Pioneer in Trouble at Home?
description: The Singer Company, which has just about turned the red ink into black in its business machines division, is currently being faced with another potential drain on corporate profits at its biggest and best known operation.

title: A Friend in Need
description: What a sound of fury recently when Harper's ran a review by W. H. Auden of Chester Kallman's The Sense of Occasion! As everyone knows, Auden is Kallman's seasonal companion and operatic collaborator, and has it not been written: Thou Shalt Not Review the Books of Thy Friends? Impure! was the cry. For shame! was the hue. But why impure? Wherefore shameful? On the contrary, I think that we all owe Mr. Auden a tremendous debt of gratitude for opening up a new era of tolerance and understanding.

title: Popularity of DriveThrough Animal Parks Is Rising
description: LAGUNA HILLS, Calif.The sign says No Trespassing. Violators Will Be Eaten.

title: Angels Rally Pays Off
description: MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP) John Stephenson capped a threerun rally in the ninth inning by the California Angels today with a tworun pinchhit homer, that defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 43.

title: Astronauts:
description: It was just three years ago today that the Apollo 11 astronauts blasted off on man's first trip to the surface of the moonand hardly had they returned from that noble journey when the first rumors began. The wife of a lunar scientist at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston, so the story went, had been reported seen wearing an unusual ring with a small gray rock in a solitaire setting.

title: Miss Cornelia Clark Married To Lieut. Comdr. Michael Paine
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 15 Miss Cornelia Thayer Clark and Surgeon Lieut Comdr. Michael P. W. H. Paine, Royal Navy, son of Comdr. Geoffrey W. W. H. Paine, British Navy, retired, and Mrs. Paine of Bramdean Hampshire, England, were married here this afternoon.

title: As Cynthia Sagittarius says
description: The object flashes in on a high trajectory, catching the gleam of the spotlights as It soars with unerring accuracy toward Mick Jagger's head. He never sees it coming, and as it hits him, a trace of fear crosses his face. For the splitting of a second, time stands still; then the object, a small, harmless, lightweight ball, bounces off Mick's forehead into the dark reaches of the Chicago Amphitheater. For any other performers it would be a disturbing omen. For the Rolling Stones, well into their first American tour in 2 years, it nothing more than another anxious moment. And anxious moments have dominated a 10year career marked by riots, violence and death.nerable; everyone's always vulnerable. Look King Curtis; he got killed outside his house.

title: Religion
description: The Ecumenical Patriarch of Istanbul is the symbolic head of Eastern Orthodoxy, which stands beside Roman Catholicism and Protestantism as one of the three major branches of modern Christianity and claims allegiance of perhaps 250 million persons. In addition to his ecumenical office, the Patriarch is also the head of a particular division of Orthodoxy, the Church of Constantinople. But yet he lives in an unpretentious stucco house next to a small church in a rundown area of the former Byzantine capital.

title: Jean Dassieu Weds Karen Graham
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Miss Karen Porter Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fraissinet Graham, was married here this afternoon to Jean Dassieu at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Helene Enguehard Dassieu of Orange, France, and the late General de Brigade Jean Dassieu of the French Foreign Legion.

title: A Haven in Dublin
description: DUBLIN, July 15 (UPI)Roman Catholic mothers and children found relief today from the violence of Northern Ireland in a quiet hospital garden here.

title: U.S. Fencers Point for Medal At Munich, First Since 1960
description: Typified by the optimism of 23yearold John Norma, a youthful United States Olympic fencing team will be seeking to launch a new era in international competition at the Olympic Games in Munich.

title: How to Govern Municipalities Still a Problem
description: PATERSON  The City of Paterson is weighing an appeal from a Superior Court decision that may end the strongmayor form of local government adopted as a reform measure in 1907.

title: HOSPITAL AIDING FRESH AIR FUND
description: One of the many social agencies that refer children from their local communities for free twoweek summer vacations under the Fresh Air Fund program has decided to help in its moneyraising effort.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 15 (UPI)  Lieutenant Calley has decided not to attend the funeral of his father, who died Thursday, because, he said, he wished to avoid the publicity that would accompany him.

title: An AntiJewish Joke?
description: THE makers of Portnoy's Complaint appear to have been convinced that Jews today feel so secure in American society that nothing could possibly offend them. For, among other things, Portnoy is a truly antiSemitic film.

title: Black Sociologists Are Seeking Black Perspective on Realities
description: The vice president of the nation's largest black university said that the current ruling elite in social science, which is largely comprised of white males over 40, should be overthrown.

title: College Students Right to Vote Seen as Key to Jersey Elections
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 15A new Jersey Supreme Court decision that ruled college students could vote in their college towns could have a decisive effect on future elections here.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Westchester Kennel Club has a new site for its 55th show scheduled for Sept. 10. It is Sterling Forest, on Route 210, in Tuxedo Park, N. Y.

title: Dr. Charles K. Friedberg, 66, Heart Specialist, Dies in Crash
description: Dr. Charles K. Friedberg, a leading New York heart specialist, was killed in an automobile collision near Cobleskill, N.Y., Friday night after a consultation in Albany. He was 66 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue. His office was at 1125 Fifth Avenue.

title: B.O.A.C.Union Talks Fail
description: LONDON, July 15  Talks between union representatives for 2,500 stewards and the British Overseas Airways Corporation broke down tonight, bringing nearer a strike set for midnight tomorrow at the height of the tourist season.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Whatever his defects as a thinker and however foolish his cult may often become, Gibran certainly deserves better than the literary equivalent of a street mugging. His continuing popularity calls for a criticaland civilizedanalysis, and not the ugly sort of thing Mr. Kanfer seems to have been trained to do.

title: My rurtheste Back PersonThe African
description: My Grandma Cynthia Murray Palmer lived in Henning, Tenn. (pop. 500), about 50 miles north of Memphis. Each summer as I grew up there, we would be visited by several women relatives who were mostly around Grandma's age, such as my Great Aunt Liz Murray who taught in Oklahoma, and Great Aunt Till Merriwether from Jackson, Tenn., or their considerably younger niece, Cousin Georgia Anderson from Kansas City, Kan., and some others. Always after the supper dishes had been washed, they would go out to take seats and talk in the rocking chairs on the front porch, and would scrunch down, listening, behind Grandma's squeaky chair, with the dusk deepening into night and the lightning bugs flicking on and off above the now shadowy honeysuckles. Most often they talked about our familythe story had been passed down for generationsuntil the whistling blur of lights of the southbound Panama Limited train whooshing through Henning at 9:05 P.M. signaled our bedtime.

title: Patricia V. Eerdrnans Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Eerdmans of New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Eerdmans daughter, Miss Patricia Valerie Eerdmans, to Capt. Timothy Marlow Barker of the British Army, who lives in Colchester, England. He is a son of Lieut. Col. A. J. Barker, retired, of Beverly, and Mrs. D. J. Barker of Chislehurst, Kent, England.

title: J B. Donovan Weds Miss Goetzman
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 15  Miss Nancy Renn Goetzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Renn Goetzman, was married here this evening to John Britt Donovan, son of Mrs. Thomas M. O'Connor of Brooklyn, New York, and the late James Britt Donovan, who was president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. Mr. Donovan also was a lawyer and former president of the New York City Board of Education. The Rev. Dr. William E. Hull performed the ceremony in the Crescent Hill Baptist Church, where he was assisted by the Rev. John Kean of Brooklyn, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Looping at the London Movie Scene
description: FTER the steamy passions of Women in Love and The Music Lovers, Ken Russell's latest film, The Savage Messiah, will confound his critics because it's a nonviolent picture about unconsummated love.

title: Cocker Spaniel Named Best Of 1,386 in Vermont Show
description: WEST WOODSTOCK, Vt., July 15Mrs. Peggy Westphal's silverbuff cocker spaniel, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, from Bedford N.Y., led a field of 1,386 dogs at the Woodstock Dog Club's 13th annual show on the Woodstock Union High School grounds yesterday. It was the 22d top award for the ascob.

title: 52 Quack Captures $175,000 Gold Cup
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 15 Millard Waldheim's Quack, a strapping 3yearold, won the $175,000 Hollywood Gold Cup today, tying the United States record for 1 miles of 1:58.

title: Queens Garden Is for the Young
description: A few years ago, passersby thought that the tract of land behind the imposing Iron fence on Main Street, Flushing, was occupied by the water company. Today, with bright new signs welcoming passersby to within its gates ana with 4,000 roses heralding summer with 80,000 blooms, people are discovering the Queens Botanical Garden.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I FEEL that Stephen Farber attended the showing of SlaughterhouseFive a bit too soon after viewing The Sorrow and the Pity. He seems to feel that all war and killing must be dealt with in the same manner: bleakly, seriously, and with as much of a sense of reality as possible.

title: Man Stabs 5 in Bus Depot, Then Is Shot by a Driver
description: TACOMA, Wash., July 15 (AP)A man who attacked five persons with a knife at a bus depot here last night was listed in critical condition today after being shot by a bus driver.

title: Two Pilots Bail Out Safely As Jet Bursts Into Flames
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 15 (AP)Two Navy jet pilots from the Meridian, Miss., Naval Air Station parachuted to safety just south of Oklahoma City last night after their T2 trainer had burst into flames.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article by Martin Hochbaum ??? ScatterSite Approach Is Faulty, June 181 was interesting but quite ambiguous.

title: Margaret Ford Bride of A. M. Maramarco
description: SHORT HILLS, NJ., July 15Miss Margaret Wrenn Ford and Anthony M. Maramarco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Maramarco of Simsbury, Conn., were married here this afternoon.

title: A POVERTY GRANT SENDS 67 ABROAD
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 15  Sixtyseven teenagers are spending July and August touring Europe and Africa under a program financed chiefly by the Office of Economic Opportunity, the Federal antipoverty agency.

title: Home Hiiprovement
description: A LTHOUGH modem synthetic glues and adhesives (the terms are used almost interchangeably nowadays) are more versatile and much stronger than old fashioned organic glues, there is still no single adhesive that can be used for bonding every kind of material under all conditionsand there are still certain precautions and preparatory steps that must be followed if a firm bond is to be insured. To help home handymen and women get the best results on various mending and assembling jobs around the home, here is a list of common gluing jobs often encountered, along with some pointers on choosing and using the proper adhesive for each:

title: Hydrants and Shore Popular in 93 Heat
description: Cold, frothy waterpreferably spouting, gushing, billowing, spraying or even just sloshingwas a coveted commodity in New York yesterday as families flocked to beaches and pools, and children gathered at nozzled fire hydrants for the refreshing rites of a hot summer day.

title: Veterans Assert Testimony Was False
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 15  The Vietnam Veterans Against the War charged today that the Federal indictment of six of its members for plotting disruption of the Republican National Convention next month was based on the false testimony of an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has turned increasingly to armed force.  Security nets have been tightened. Courts have been handing down stiffer penalties.  and the number of skyjacking successes has been almost infinitesimal.

title: Leafspot Disease Spreads
description: ALBANY, July 12  The wet and cold weather of spring and early summer has precipitated a statewide outbreak of leafspot disease, according to the Department of Environmental Protection. Commissionner Henry L. Diamond said that although it was no peril to trees, it does cause unsightly spotting of leaves of hardwood trees, made by fungus. Nothing can be done to stop the problem now, he said, except collecting the leaves in the fall and compositing them to avoid new infection next year.

title: Maryland Troopers Enter Prison and Put Down Riot
description: JESSUP, Md., Sunday, July 16 Rebellious inmates seized part of the maximum security Maryland House of Corrections last night and state troopers swept through the west portion of the prison early today to quell the riot, which left at least six persons injured.

title: Reds Overwhelm Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP)Cesar Geronimo and Joe Morgan drove in three runs apiece as the streaking Cincinnati Reds unleashed a 16hit attack tonight to crush the St. Louis Cardinals 122.

title: Miss Gloria Lynn Branker Is Bride
description: Miss Gloria Lynn Branker and Raymond E. Clarke were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Anglican Episcopal Church in Christiansted, St. Croix, V. I., by the Rev. Seymour L. Clarke.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LOCUST VALLEY, LI., July 15Cathy Bostwick defeated the top favorite, Nancy Gangler, 61, 62, today for the New Jersey State girls 16andunder tennis championship. The final was switched from South Orange, N.J., to the home town of the two girls.

title: Schneck's Met Debut Like a Movie
description: SAN DIEGO, July 15 Practicing one of a baseball player's favorite pastimes, Dave Schneck went to a movie to pass some hours before he made his major league debut against San Diego last night.

title: Music
description: HANS WERNER HENZE is one of the two most significant composers in Germany since World War II, Karlheinz Stockhausen being the other. However, Henze's career has followed quite a different course from Stockhausen's. While Stockhausen has emerged as the leader of Europe's musical avantgarde, Henze writes for the traditional listener. Whether he composes tonally or uses more advanced techniques, whether he writes opera or instrumental pieces, Henze's goal is to make expressive music.

title: Nicklaus a Shot Back After 66
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 15Lee Trevino won the British Open, with 278, for the second year in a row today and he won it by a shot from Jack Nicklaus.

title: CRENSHAW AND CAIN REACH GOLF FINAL
description: DALLAS, July 15 (UPI)Ben Crenshaw, who was down three holes today after the first nine, took advantage of lapses by his opponent Gary Koch, and posted a 1up triumph that put him in the final of the TransMississippi golf tournament.

title: Ombudsmen Role Proposed For City Council Members
description: The expansion of the role of City Council members to that of ombudsmen assigned to watch over separate agencies of government was proposed yesterday by Council President Sanford D. Garelik. The goal, he said, is not to usurp the Mayor's authority, but rather to gain greater access to city department files and records so that Councilmen could deal with problems at earlier stages.

title: The World
description: Descendants of the Golden Horde that once held Russia in thrall and beat at the gates of European Christendom, the Tatars of Crimea won an important right in the Russian revolution: They were permitted to form one of the ostensibly autonomous republics of the Soviet Union. But after World War II they were accused of mass collaboration with the German occupiers of Crimea and were deported en masse to Central Asia.

title: Tear Gas Routs Fugitive
description: CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP)An armed mental patient held the police at bay with gunfire for two and a half hours after barricading himself in his exwife's house, but was routed after tear gas hurled inside the home touched off a fire. Robert Ruebush, 47 years old, who had escaped from Long View State Hospital, was treated for head cuts suffered yesterday when the police fired several canisters of tear gas through a front window at the home of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Bailey. He had fired five shots at the police, who returned about seven more.

title: Homenuik Wins at Manitoba
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba (Canadian Press) July 15  Wilf Homenuik returned to his home Glendale course and shot a fourunderpar 68 today to win the $8,500 Manitoba open golf championship.

title: Gardens
description: WBILD flowers contribute much to fields and woodlands. Because this muchness is always there, the scenes are often taken for granted. Snowy white daisies in fields  pink bouncing bet by the railroad tracks  waves of Queen Anne's lace tossing in the winds butter and eggs by the country roads  dandelion going to seed  lilies in the shaded woods. Wildlings are at home where they grow. If hikers, strollers, wayside wanderers, fishermen or campers don't take notice, they bloom just the same. Enjoy them or not. Those, who pass them by are the poorer for missing the simple beauty of this wild world.

title: Tho Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, July 15Le Duc Tho, the ranking North Vietnamese negotiator, arrived here today and expressed readiness to resume his brokehoff dialogue with Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Coins
description: GOLD rarities are among the interesting lots catalogued for the mailbid floor auction to be conducted by Schulman Coin and Mint, Inc, on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, July 25.26. The sales will take place in the Schulman Gallery at 25 West 45th Street, with each session starting at 7 o'clock.

title: Cattle Scarce as Costs Climb
description: FLEMINGTON  Harold Kitchin wasn't too busy at the window of the Flemington Agricultural Market Cooperative Association livestock market, checking off the cows, bull and calves as they were unloaded from farmers' trucks and tugged into rows of cobwebbed stalls last Monday. But then, Mr. Kitchin hasn't been really busy for many years.

title: The social contract explained and defended
description: For too long now, the main tradition of moral philosophy has been utilitarian in its broad assumptions: people ought to work for the greatest happiness of the greatest number of their fellowmen; minorities should submit to the interests of the majority. But utilitarian attitudes are incompatible with our moral judgment and with the principles on which our Constitution rests. It is, therefore, a crucial task of moral and political philosophy to make clear the inadequacy of utilitarian concepts and, more important, to provide a persuasive alternative to them. In the opinion of John Rawls, professor of philosophy at Harvard, the social contract theory of Rousseau and Kant provides the main such alternative. And it is no accident that the Founding Fathers looked to this theory, in Locke's version of it, for their main philosophical doctrines. In recent times, however, this tradition has seemed unavailable to sophisticated opinion. For modern men cannot take seriously the myth on which the theory appears to rely an actual contract agreed upon by solitary primitives determined to create the first societyand modern philosophy has been inclined to agree with Bentham's view that any appeal to natural rights is nothing more than nonsense on stilts.

title: U. S. and Poland Expand Their Joint Science Projects and Move to Make Them Permanent
description: WARSAW, July 15  The United States and Poland have agreed to establish a new framework for their rapidly expanding joint research in scientific and technological fields.

title: DETROIT BUS PLAN HEADS FOR APPEAL
description: DETROIT, July 15The confusing array of court orders plans and pleas for delay in the Detroit school busing case may be cleared up next week.

title: Inevitable Question Comes to Piccadilly: Which Direction Does Progress Lie?
description: LONDON Chez Victor is a celebrated bistro where the rich and famous as well as generations of tourists and locals have dined for 70 years, but to the men who plan to tear down and then rebuild Piccadilly Circus it is just part of an untidy, overcrowded, neonlit mess. Not surprisingly, among those who would like to demolish the planners is Chez Victor's chubby host, Gilbert France. Why do they want to kill something everyone loves, and give the tourists more buildings like what they see at home? he asks. Do they think people come here for the weather?

title: Social Announcements
description: Social Announcements

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Ben B. Lindsey first attracted nationwide attention in the years before World War I for his innovative practices as a juvenile court judge in the then frontier town of Denver procedures that have since become standard operating practice in all parts of the country. By the 1920's he had grown into a national storm center, the target of the Ku Klux Klan, fundamentalist churchmen and powerful political forces: he had advocated, in print and on the lecture platform, trial marriage, birth control, sex education in the schools, circulation of information about venereal disease and freedom of sexual conduct between consenting adults. The Good Fight tram Judge Lindsey's career from his boyhood as an orphan and school dropout through his forced retirement from the Colorado bench to the rehabilitation of his image during the New Deal era. Based on manuscript collections and the recollections of contemporaries, this first biography of a colorful Man Before His Time is briskly written, friendly but not uncritical  and long over due.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is hard to understand James Reston's F.D.R. coalition policy in its recommended application to Mr. McGovern's strategy in the coming election battle. [News analysis July 12.]

title: Smoke Bomb at Mansion
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 (UPI) An exploding smoke bomb rattled the windows of the Governor's mansion early today, but the 119yearold house was not damaged. The bomb, tossed by unknown persons, laid a cloud of smoke over the lawn of the mansion.

title: Bobby Unser Sets a Qualifying Record
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 15Bobby Unser won the pole position today for the fifth time in five races run in this season's Championship Trial of the United States Auto Club. The race for which he qualified is the Michigan 200, to be run tomorrow at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Taiwan Bans Hunting
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 15 (UPI) Taiwan has announced a threeyear ban on hunting in an effort to preserve its diminishing wildlife. Many of Taiwan's rare speciessika deer, mikado pheasant, Formosan leopard and muntjacare on the verge of extinction. Under the law, the sale of rifles, shotguns and ammunition are also suspended.

title: Charges for Drunkenness Rose to a Record in Britain
description: LONDON, July 15 (AP)There are more drunkards in Britain than before and middleaged men are hitting the bottle harder than anyone else, the Government indicated this week.

title: The Megastates Of America
description: John Gunther's Inside U.S.A. (1947) was the inspiration for this Washington freelancer's report on the 10 greatest states, home to more than half of the American people (New York, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Michigan, Florida, Texas and California). Although Neal R. Peirce describes in detail, the physical characteristics of their major cities and adjoining countryside, he is most concerned with the residents behavior: how they make their living, the churches they attend, the schools they send their children to, how they spend their leisure. Closest to Mr. Peirce's heart is state and local politics. His appraisals of these are discriminating: the legislatures of Illinois, Massachusetts and Texas are notably corrupt; Illinois's operates with relative efficiency, Texas's ranks not far from the bottom. Eyebrows will rise over Mr. Peirce's high rating of New York's Governor Rockefeller. At times the groupings and subtitles read like an A.A.A. guide, but most readers will find things to make this guided tour worth taking.

title: FOOD PLANT DRIVE TO ENLIST CONSUMER
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Health, Education and Welfare Denartment announced today that it would try to enlist consumer help to crack down on widespread unsanitary conditions found in food processing plants.

title: Kenneth Bergers Marries Miss Hill
description: CONCORD, Mass., July 15 Miss Nancy Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Hill Jr. of Stamford, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Richard Berger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Berger of New York. The Rev. Dr. Dana McLean Greeley performed the Unitarian ceremony at the First Parish in Concord.

title: FISCHER ADAMANT AGAINST CAMERAS
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 15 Lastminute attempts today to keep the stalled Boris SpasskyBobby Fischer championship chess match alive included the reported arrival of Fischer's sister, Mrs. Joan Targ; a series of meetings, a cablegram campaign and an examination of the decibel content of Exhibition Hall, the site of the match.

title: Back Taxes Are Paid With a Ton of Pennies
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 15 (AP)After months of wrailgling with the Government over back taxes, Larry Heratone finally paid off the $2,500 he owed. A truck loaded with 250,000 pennies, weighing a ton, pulled up in front of the Internal Revenue Service office here yesterday and the coins were turned over to an I.R.S. agent.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Admirable job, your piece on Gibran. Small world department: readers might like to know that the mysticallooking figure on the jacket cover of The Prophet is not Gibran himself, as many believe, but his good friend Mischa Naimi, of Beirut, Lebanon. Mischa Naimi was my parauncle, a buddy of my father's, the late 0. Arthur Stumpe, a Wall Street lawyer. Mischa was a student in this country when he suddenly found himself drafted into the U. S. Army in World War I.

title: But Does It Sell Books?
description: From The Babbitt and the Bromide by George and Ira Gershwin.

title: MOST ROLLBACKS CENTER ON RENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Cost of Living Council, in its first tabulation of wage, price and rent rollbacks resulting from consumer complaints, reported today that most reductions involved rents.

title: Television
description: N IELSEN ratings are the eternal truths of television, but they could reflect more about our society than just viewing habits. In fact, if we could see beyond the raw statistics, we might see more reflected than we ever imagined. Take, for example, the following dialogue between a couple who could easily be one of those rare Nielsen families.

title: Congressman to Stand Trial
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) Judge Philip Tome has ordered Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, to stand trial on charges that he misused his franking privileges. Judge Tome rejected yesterday in United States District Court Mr. Annunzio's motion to dismiss the case. A trial date for Aug. 9 was set.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One of the many disturbing features of the report on Ezra Pound (July 5) was the attempt of the officials of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences to suppress public knowledge of the academy's decision to deny Pound the EmersonThoreau Prize in literary achievement. Even fellows of the academyof which I am onehad difficulty in gaining full information on these events and though the academy's president, Prof. Harvey Brooks, and executive secretary, John Voss, promised fellows the transcript of the discussions to deny Pound the EmersonThoreau Prize, no such transcript has been forthcoming. What is more, the pall of secrecy the academy's officials have erected around l'affaire Ezra Pound is justified by these two officials as being in the best interest of Pound's psychological health. This argument has few peers for its disingenuousness.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: N OW that the Democratic National Convention has passed without providing any major surprise in the selection of Senator George McGovern as the Presidential candidate and the adoption of a platform, the business world and Wall Street are pondering the implications of these decisions for the domestic economy and the financial markets until the election.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14George McGovern may think, as he said in his acceptance speech, that Richard Nixon is the Democrats unwitting unifier and the fundamental issue of this campaign, but it may prove to be one of the salient facts of the 1972 election that Mr. McGovern himself is far more nearly the issue than are most challengers to incumbent Presidents.

title: Renewal Program In Inwood At Standstill
description: INWOOD, L. I.The second phase of a 17yearold urbanrenewal project is at a standstill because of an impasse between the Town of Hempstead and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: SONGS PERFORMED BY BILL WITHERS
description: Well, it took three attempts, but fans of singersongwriter Bill Withers finally got the opportunity to hear him perform here Friday night at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park.

title: World News Briefs
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 15A district court has sentenced three smugglers to death following the biggest seizure of contraband in Taiwan's history. The death penalty had never before been given to convicted smugglers.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMBy its nature, this is no ordinary army. The nation's sons and daughters all pass through it. It is important that it not be spoiled by the introduction of aims that violate the spirit in which the Israeli Army and Israel itself developed.

title: Education
description: DETROITThey were dancing in the streets in Bloomfield Hills, the vice president of an automobile manufacturer told a reporter. Normally it would take a superbonus to create that kind of joy in the Hills, the heartland of the automobile rich. But this time it was news that the first tentative pairings for the Federal Court's integration busing plan for the fall had left out Bloomfield Hills.

title: Christine Sullivan Is the Bride Of Peter McKenna in L.I. Rite
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. July 15Ixliss Christine Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McNamee Sullivan of Southampton and New York, was married here this evening to Peter McKenna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pearse McKenna of Glenageary, Dublin.

title: Family Planners of 23 Nations Voice Optimism at U.N. Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15Family planners, here from 23 countries to pool ideas, see evidence that their campaigns to halt unchecked population growth are beginning to have impact.

title: All In Favor of Plastic Bushes
description: N EWSPAPERS, magazines and television carried, in late winter months this year, information on the installation of plastic plants on a Los Angeles County boulevard.
