Most of the coverage was negative. The editors of Nursery Business in their March/April issue, took a stand for the use of plastic plants in public landscaping. They decry public condemnation of artificial landscape materials and defend the users of it They say that people have been carried away by emotional feelings baited by the dogooder ecologists. They call these travesties of trees and shrubs permanent type shrubbery and plant materials (without quotes to identify the stuff as synthetic) and state that, in a difficult site such as a freeway medial strip, its use is justified. These plant industry editors follow the line of reasoning prevalent among today's youth (e.g. if rape happening, it must be acceptable) when they say:

title: New & Novel
description: It is the night before Christmas and all through their house every member of the Coole family is doing his own thing.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Next month an ambitious, Innovative attempt to transfer idled talents from the aerospace industry to gainful, fruitful endeavor in the public sector will be phased out. Its yearlong run has been given high marks by some of the transferees.

title: Pamela Pinkham Married
description: Miss Pamela Clarke Pinkham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Pinkham of Westbury, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Gioyanni Dettori of Madrid, where the bridegroom is with the Carlo Gavassi Corporation, manufacturers of equipment for ships. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Dettori of Milan, Italy. The Rev. Paul V. Gallagher performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride's father is a vice president of Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers here.

title: Social Announcements
description: Social Announcements

title: UNION AIDE WINS STAY ON PENALTY
description: A Federal judge has ordered the executive board of the painters union here to delay the imposition of any penalty against Frank Schonfeld, the union's secretarytreasurer, who contends that he has angered the board with his campaign against corruption.

title: Cold Wave Heats Up Coffee Prices
description: RIO DE JANEIROIt may take heat to brew coffee, but there is nothing like a cold wave in southern Brazil to perk up prices for unroasted beans on world markets.

title: Isaac Takes Islip 300
description: ISLIP, L. I., July 15 (AP)Bobby Isaac won the Islip 300 auto race last night, his second straight triumph of the week on the Grand National Northern Tour. Last Tuesday the 38yearold Catawba, N. C., driver won the AlbanySaratoga 250. Driving a 1972 Dodge, Isaac took over the 83d lap and finished three laps ahead of Neil Castles of Charlotte, N. C.

title: U.S. Says B52 Raids Kill 300 of Foe Near Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 16 (AP)  United, States 1352's bombed bunkers and inflicted heavy casualties on North Vietnamese around the provincial capital of Quangtri, the United States command said yesterday. It estimated that the bombers had killed about 300 enemy soldiers in two raids.

title: Congressman to Stand Trial
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) Judge Philip Tome has ordered Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, to stand trial on charges that he misused his franking privileges. Judge Tome rejected yesterday in United States District Court. Mr. Annunzio's motion to dismiss the case. A trial date for Aug. 9 was set.

title: Law
description: LOS ANGELESDo you believe the Boston Tea Party was a justifiable act?  Do you believe that Jesus Christ was justified in throwing the money changers out of the Temple by force?  Do you believe that parents today are overly permissive in the handling of their children?

title: Olivia Spencer Bride of Bank Aide
description: MIDDLEBURY, Conn., July 15Miss Olivia Tuttle Spencer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eldridge Spencer 3d, was married here this afternoon to Donald Seymour Tuttle 3d, to whom she is distantly related. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tuttle Jr. of Middlebury and Inverness, Fla.

title: If This Be Aprille . . . It Must Be Canterbury
description: CANTERBURY, England whenne that ??? with his shoures sole the droghte of Marche bath perced to the rote, as Geoffrey Chaucer observed six centuries age, then longen folk to goon on pilgrimages.

title: Canadian Concern Restudies Mining Project in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15The Aluminium Company of Canada is reconsidering its $100  million bauxite  mining project in Brazil's Amazon Valley, it was stated today. The project is still in its beginning stage.

title: The World
description: When Fidel Castro visited Moscow in 1964, he was greeted by Premier Khrushchev with great Russian bear hugs and extolled as a revolutionary in his prime. Last weekend, Mr. Castro returned home again after a new trip to the Soviet Unionbut this time his Russian notices seemed mixed.

title: PHILADELPHIA PLANS AIRPORT TAX SHIFT
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP)  Facing formal action from other cities, officials here have proposed dropping the $2 service charge on airline passengers arriving at Philadelphia International Airport.

title: Dr. Isidor Ochs, Radiologist And ExBronx H.I.P. Aide
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., July 15Dr. Isidor Ochs, a retired radiologist and former medical director of the Central Bronx Group of the Health Insurance Plan (H.I.P.), died today of cancer. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Letters:
description: Reports of American tourists being taken in Europe prompt me to send this note on one aspect of my recent automobile tour through France. My wife stumbled and twisted her ankle on the stairway of our lovely hotel in the Dordogne at La RoqueGageac. She was in such pain the next day in Carcassonne that I asked the concierge of our hotel there to call a doctor. Within five minutes the doctor was at our door. He recommended Xrays and wrote prescriptions to be filled to alleviate the pain. The Xrays showed a simple fracture, with the bones in good alignment. The Xray specialist made clear that my wife did not need a plaster cast but recommended minimum walking and to keep her leg elevated when possible. All this, of course, in French, and with gestures.

title: North Jersey Summer Festival Under Way
description: HACKENSACK  An admissionfree performance of Verdi's Rigoletto in the concert version next Wednesday will be one of the highlights of the North Jersey Cultural Council's Summer Festival 72, which got under way last week.

title: Darwin's 2Run Homer and 5Run 6th Give Twins 71 Victory Over Red Sox.
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 15 (AP)The Minnesota Twins scored five runs in the sixth inning today and went on to beat the Boston Red Sox, 71.

title: $125,000 Trot Won By Speedy Crown
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 15With Une de Mai of France scratched by a belated order from the New York State Harness Racing Commission, the $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway was won tonight by Speedy Crownthe first American horse to win the race in eight years.

title: Sahala of Football Staff Named Coach of Baseball at Columbia
description: Dick Sakala, freshmen football coach at Columbia for the last two years, has been named coach of varsity baseball, replacing Johnny Balquist, who retired last month after 21 years in the post. Kenneth G. Germann, director of athletics at Columbia, also said Jack Gurry, a freshman football assistant and an exBoston College baseball and football star, would assist Sakala with the baseball squad.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: NEW HOPE, Pa.Sam is a 5yearold brown and white springer spaniel with an incurable case of wanderlust. One of the tours in his Baedeker is the onethirdofamile run over the new toll bridge that stretches across the Delaware into Lambertville, N. J., where he cons half a pound of hamburger out of the butchers at the A. & P. and then makes the return leg home.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15President Nixon's public approval rating is down slightly in the latest Gallup Poll, but at 56 per cent almost matches his average rating during the 41 months since he took office.

title: Ruins of Philistine Temple Are Unearthed in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, July 15 (Reuters) The remains of a Philistine temple that stood for almost, 250 years before it was burned down in the ninth century B.C. has been unearthed in an archeological excavation at Tel Kassila, in northern Tel Aviv.

title: Louise Fox Married to David B. Usechak
description: RED BANK, N. J., July 15 In the United Methodist Church of Red Bank this afternoon, Miss Louise Van Winkle Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gardner Fox of Rumson, was married to David Hunger Usechak. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Usechak of Butler County, Pa.

title: Son to the Porterfields
description: A son was born on June 21 at the LyingIn Hospital, to Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Porterfield of New York. The child has been named Kevin Stephenson.

title: Miss Pippitt Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pippitt of London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Pippitt, to Peter Withington Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hiland W. Hall of New Canaan, Conn., where the wedding is planned for spring. The future bride was graduated in May from Ashland (Ohio) College, where, her financ expects to receive his degree in December.

title: Dana Adele Brown Married To John Burns on L. I. Cliff
description: MATTITUCK, L. I., July 18 Miss Dana Adele Brown was married here this afternoon to John Spinney Burns in a field on a cliff overlooking the sound. The Rev. Charles IL Baker, an Episcopal clergyman, performed the ceremony at Four Winds, the summer residence of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Brown of Greenvale and Mattituck.

title: Chicago Witness Says Weapons Were Seized in Panther Raid
description: CHICAGO, July 15The controversial and oftendelayed trial of State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 other defendants adjourned for the weekend here yesterday after a police sergeant testified that officers had seized numerous firearms, several hundred rounds of ammunition and several dozen pills and hypodermic needles during a police raid on a Black Panther apartment.

title: Britain Sets Up New Agency For Commercial Broadcasts
description: LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) Britain's new Independent Broadcasting Authority officiallycame into being this week in advance of the establishment of, some 60 commercially sponsored radio stations based in major towns.

title: Laos Peace Talks
description: The impending resumption of peace talks in Laos adds a hopeful note to the renewed Vietnam negotiations Paris. Indeed, it was seemingly the possibility that an accord in Vietnam might finally be achieved that triggered the Laotian move.

title: The Party He Throws Is Not His Own
description: Clive David's business is parties. He describes his fees as outrageous and, at a minimum of $10,000 for a nonprofit organization and $18,000 for others, he still can't keep up with the demand for his services.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A twoweek strike by the security force at the Museum of Modern Art was settled yesterday. The security force's union ratified an agreement with the museum raising pay by $9.08to $145.20 a week for a 40hour week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It came as a disappointing surprise to a large majority of the residents near the new Intermediate School 29, at Park Avenue and 94th Street, to learn [Midtown Architecture Honored, June 18] that it had been honored by the Fifth Avenue Asociation as the best institutional building of the year.

title: WASHINGTON
description: MIAMI BEACHThe nation is now, at the same time, waging war in Vietnam, negotiating peace and fighting a Presidential election in which the tactics and objectives of the wareven the continuation of the warare central issues. And this creates the delicate and awkward problem for both President Nixon and Senator McGovern of arguing out the issues of the war without interfering with their common objective of ending the killing in Southeast Asia.

title: BRAVES TRIUMPH OVER CUBS, 4 TO 2
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (AP)Home runs by Darrell Evans and Earl Williams lifted the Atlanta Braves to a 42 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Dance: BeachBlanket Bacchanalia
description: Dennis Nahat is clearly a talented choreographer with a mind and a style of This own. His latest work, Some Times, which was given its world premiere by the American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater on Friday night, starts rather promisingly and has its moments of choreographic felicity, but it fades toward the end. There seems to be a lack of genuine choreographic energy.

title: Thailand Plans Canal Across Kra Isthmus
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 15 (Reuters)The ruling National Executive Council has approved plans for construction of a ship canal across the Kra Isthmus in southern Thailand.

title: Some Social Events in the Week Ahead
description: July 19Ed Jaffe, a professional square dance caller, will be emcee and general sparkplug for Summer Hoedown of the Junior Division of the Jewish Guild for the Blind at the Guild's auditorium, 15 West 65th Street. Arrive at 7 P.M. for fried chicken and fixings, then the orations. Don your thingcome casual, blue jeans, corduroys or calico for your kitten. Admission at door, members $8, nonmembers $10.

title: City Planning to Raise Employe Productivity
description: The Lindsay administration's nine Administrators and 87 Commissioners are meeting with Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton to mount a massive drive for measurable increased productivity from the 380,000 city employes.

title: MARVIN M. ALEDORT
description: Marvin M. Aledort, an associate editor of The New York Times Index, with which he was associated for 17 years, died of a heart attack Friday at Fire Island, L. I., while on vacation. He was 41 years old and lived at 405 East 54th Street.

title: ForMenOnly Barrier In Athletics Is Teetering
description: Mrs. Bernice Gera won a sixyear legal battle for the right to become professional baseball's first woman umpire only to quit after one game because she felt male umpires weren't cooperating with her.

title: Karen Oliver Runs P. U. C.
description: NEWARK  Mrs. Karen Oliver is 29 years old, could be described in a fashion magazine as chic and is willing to admit that she has made some mistakes.

title: Truman to Stay in Hospital
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15 (UPI)  Doctors at Research Hospital decided today to keep former President Harry S. Truman hospitalized a while longer for observation. No release date was set. A hospital spokesman said that Mr. Truman, 88 years old, appeared eager to leave and had shown a hearty appetite.

title: UNIFIED PENSIONS SOUGHT BY STATE
description: The State Pension Commission has decided to try to replace the thicket of state and city retirement plans with one that would set a uniform benefit rate statewide for public employes according to job categories.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 15Charles Larrabee, a college sophomore, enjoys his summer job traveling 398 miles a day. He works as a chair car attendant on part of the run by Amtrak's Super ChiefEl Capitan train between Chicago and Los Angeles.

title: Indians Shut Out Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 15 (UPI)Buddy Bell and Chris Chambliss delivered doubles and Frank Duffy had a triple in a sixrun second inning tonight to back the fourhit pitching of Dick Tidrow as the Cleveland Indians downed the Texas Rangers, 70.

title: 4 Die in Italian Rainstorms
description: MANFREDONIA. Italy, July 15 (AP)Three children and a man died today as violent thunderstorms on the Adriatic coast burst an earthen dike, dumping tons of water on this town. The rain caused extensive destruction all along the coast, from Bari to Manfredonia. Eleven other persons were injured and were taken to hospitals.

title: A putative poet struck suddenly to wondering
description: The most memorable speaker in Philip Levine's last volume of poems was a pig who, being led to market, contemplates himself with some admiration: It's wonderful how I jog/ on four honeddown ivory toes/my massive buttocks slipping/like oiled parts with each light step. Haughtily determined to see it through, he proceeds without evasions, superior to his captora boy who imagines he'll collapse squealing on his side

title: South Street Aint what She Used to BeYet
description: JUTTING bowsprits of the China clippers shadow South Street like the lances of charging cavalrymen. Impudent coastal packets snuggle up to the great hulls of India merchantmen. Steamships and ferry boats, pushy newcomers with a disagreeable smell, presume to challenge the oceansailers for dock space.

title: DAVID K. HECHT
description: David K. Hecht, a lawyer who once owned Camp Chipinaw, a children's summer camp at Swan Lake, N.Y., died Friday in the Beth Israel Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 54 Riverside Drive.

title: WORK ON CHARTER SLOWS IN MANILA
description: MANILA, July 15 (AP)After more than a year of noisy deliberations, the Philippines constitutional convention has completed less than half of its task of drawing up a new charter. It has a December deadline.

title: Ghulam M. Bakhshi Dies at 64; ExPrime Minister of Kashmir
description: Ghulam Mohammad Bakhshi, who as Prime Minister of Kashmir from 1953 to 1963 sought harmony among Moslems and Hindus as India and Pakistan vied for control of the state, died yesterday in Srinigar, Kashmir's capital, after suffering a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE ADMINISTRATION has worked out a tentative formula to persuade the Soviet Union to pay lendlease debts in return for credits from the U.S. Government and equal tariff treatment. The Soviet Union will exhibit wares at a Seattle Trade Fair in an effort to improve its trade imbalance with the U. S. The House of Commons approved British entry into the E.E.C.

title: Export of Hides Limited to Curb Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Nixon Administration restricted today the exporting of cattle hides in an attempt to deal with a deepening shortage of them and to ease inflationary pressures on shoes and other leather goods.

title: DIETZ SHOWS WAY IN SINGLE SCULLS
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club found the rough water of the Schuylkill River to his liking today in the 99th annual national rowing championships.

title: Anne Leslie Kelly Is the Bride Of John R. Kelly, an Engineer
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 15Miss Anne Leslie Kelly, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Lloyd Lawrence Kelly, was married here this afternoon to John Richard Kelly, son of Dr, John K. Kelly of Hartsdale, N. Y., and Mrs. Elizabeth S. Kelly of Farmington, Conn. The double ring ceremony was performed by the Rev. Kenneth Nye in the Second Congregational Church. The families are not related.

title: Would you believe $22,500?
description: It takes real ingenuity to build on a budget these days. But it can be done and architect Edmund Stevens shows how in this vacation house he built for his family in Southold, Li, for $22,500. He used salvaged lumber wherever he could, the timbers for the frame and all of the floors and decking were purchased from a demolition company. Exterior and inside sheathing is pine (knotty and easily warped, but desirable for its rustic look). Cantilevering the house five feet beyond the cement block basement/garage saved foundation costs; the displaced soil forms a grassy bank around the house. The land was costly (it overlooks a secluded stretch of the Sound) but labor was considerably less than on Long Island's more populous ocean side.

title: Urgent priorities for revival
description: This is a long overdue book. Trumbull Stickney, who died at 30 in 1904, left behind him a largely ignored book of verse and some remarkable poems in manuscript. These, with additional material, were brought out posthumously in 1905 by his friends George Cabot Lodge and William Vaughn Moody. F. O. Matthiessen included some of these in his Oxford Book of American Verse, and Conrad Aiken, some in his wonderful Modern Library anthology of 20thcentury American poetry, from which my whole generation learned so much. Edmund Wilson wrote a short but intense essay on Stickney in 1940, and there was an unpublished Princeton dissertation on him in 1947. But it was only in England, and in 1968, that there appeared a good collection of his poems, both published and from manuscript, with a bibliography and critical introduction by James Reeves and Sean Haldane.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Suzanne Haire points out in her article London Home Buyers Fear Gazumping [July 2] that the most desirable land in the heart of Londonmost of Westminster and Chelseais freehold property of the Duke of Westminster and the Earl of Cadogan.

title: Murder in Britain at Record Since End of Death Penalty
description: LONDON, July 15The number of murders committed in England and Wales during 1971 was 177, an increase of 42 over the previous year.

title: Democratic Ticket
description: With the nomination of George S. McGovern, as with the composition and character of the National Convention that chose him, the Democratic party has taken refreshing turn in American political life.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: What kind of national health insurance should the United States have? More than a half dozen schemes are before Congress, but nobody really knows what any of these plans would actually cost, or their impact upon patients, hospitals and physicians. And unhappy experience with the skyrocketing costs of Medicare and Medicaid since they became law in the mid1960's has given Congress pause.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIfas an increasing number of people here believe  the Federal Government's most serious problem is the runaway nature of its spending, what did the events last week at Miami Beach portend?

title: SLUDGE DUMPING STIRS OPPOSITION
description: NEW HAVEN, July 15Plans by the Army Corps of Engineers and a local electric power company to dump more than one million cubic yards of polluted sludge from New Haven Harbor into Long Island Sound have stirred apprehension among Connecticut legislators, environmentalists and fishermen.

title: L. L. Warner Marries Susan L. McAllister
description: NEW HAVEN, July 15 Miss Susan Lewis McAllister and Lawrence Lindstrand Warner were married here this afternoon. The Rev. C. Lawson Willard performed the Episcopal Ceremony in the Marquand Chapel of Yale University.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: A few minutes after your jumbo jet has landed at the end of a transAtlantic flight you are aboard a fast, handsome train for the nineminute trip into the city, and the ticket costs only 70 cents.

title: A gleeful dropout of Yugoslav letters
description: He once described himself as an exclochard who would like to remain hwislisle, then made international headlines from a Belgrade courtroom where he sued a publisher for not printing a novel of his that had been contracted for. (He won damages.) He can hole up in the Slovenian Alps through a long winter and spend the next three months being videotaped in Paris and for the German TV. His books are read in Afrikaans, Hebrew, Chinese (and 20 other languages), yet only occasionally in his own country, where officials wish he would go away. Such is the public image of Miodrag Bulatovic, the gleeful dropout of Yugoslav letters, whose current novel represents the third attempt to introduce him to American readers.

title: Roadie, a Miniature Pinscher, Takes Top Prize at Riverhead
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 15An 8pound miniature pinscher, Ch. BoMar's Road Runner, the smallest dog in the ring, romped out with the biggest prize at the seventh show of the Riverhead Kennel Club today. The event drew 1,168 dogs to Stotzky Memorial Park.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Stephen Farber argues that 'SlaughterhouseFive is one film that really needs more violence to convey the horror of Dresden. He concedes that the film does at least offer a lot of rubble, some raging fires, even a scattering of dead bodies, but that is apparently not enough for Farber, who goes on to deplore the omission of the fire storm, etc. This is like accusing The Garden of the FinziContinis, a similarly moving film, of taking the horror out of the Jewish persecution by not showing concentration camps.

title: Music
description: AT 65, age when most people are ready to retire, John Goldmark has taken on the presidency of the Mannes College of Music. This is neither as surprising nor as drastic a step as it might seem at first. The music administrator is following in the footsteps of his brother, Peter Goldmark, the inventor of the 33 1/3r.p.m. longplaying disk, among other things. The latter retired at 65 from a long association with the Columbia Broadcasting System in order to start his own organization. Furthermore, brother John has been a part of Mannes since 1939, and so is scarcely a newcomer to its halls.

title: Northrup Paces Tigers
description: DETROIT, July 15 (AP)Jim Northrup drove in two runs with a single and contributed to two other rallies today as the Detroit Tigers beat the Kansas City Royals, 53.

title: 3 Metal Industry Unions Settle, 12 Are on Strike
description: A metalindustry employer group has agreed on new contracts with three nonstriking unions, but 12 other unions are continuing a 16dayold strike aimed primarily at gaining more pay and benefits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Conservatives form the backbone of the Republican party, yet President Nixon continues to alienate this segment of the electorate, even though they won the election for him in 1968. He has imposed wage and price controls, which until recently had been advocated only by the most liberal Democrats. He has requested socalled welfare reform which would add twelve million more people to the welfare roils at an additional cost of $7billion. Finally, the President has compiled a Federal budget deficit of over $80 billion in his first three years in office. This certainly is nut what Republicans wanted when they elected Nixon in 1968.

title: The Pygmalion approach to nuts and vegetables
description: Look at me, said George Bernard Shaw, I have 10 times as much good health and energy as a meat eater. He was a vegetarian and lived to 94. He also wrote plays. Here are some of the maverick literary lion's recipes, as remembered by his cook, Alice Laden.

title: Andrea Miller Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph T. Miller of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea M. Miller, to Cornelius Harris Marx. He is the on of Mrs. Richard L. Blum Jr. of New York and Albert L. Marx of Palm Springs, Calif. The future bride is the assistant to the action reporter with Metromedia television news. Her fiance is a financial analyst in the office of Harold F. Linden and William T. Golden.

title: Science Gives Pupils Excuse for Wading
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.  Children clustered around a cold spring here last week, drinking noisily and discussing the morning's catch of frogs and tadpoles.

title: Complicated solutions to simple problems
description: I have for several years been an amateur collector of obscure aphorisms that divide the world into two kinds of people. Hosts and guests (Max Beerbohm). Flowers and gardeners (Mignon G. Eberhart). People who think the world can be divided into two kinds of people and people who don't (Anonymous). Whenever the world is divided up in such an arbitrary way, I have the comfort of knowing I will always find myself on the other side from L. Rust Hills. Hills is not just a fussy manas he concedes in the title of his book. He is a fanatic, clear hell to live with, a believer in order, a replacer of caps on toothpaste tubes. To read his book is to be forced to line up for or against him. I am against him. I squeeze the tube from the middle. I believe that messy is sexy. I find virtue in chaos.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 14, Black delegates, leaders and visitors to the Democratic National Convention left here today with mixed feelings of frustration, bitterness and hope.

title: Rediscovering Puvis de Chavannes
description: THE disinterment of Symbolist painting continues on its merry, necrophiliac course, and on this occasion seems to have turned up something resembling a warm body. For the principal exhibition in London this summer is the French Symbolist Painters show at the Hayward Gallery, and one of the figures prominently featured in it is Pierre Puvis de Chavannes (18241898).

title: Shorter Reviews
description: With this volume of essays, memoirs and diaries, the editors complete their trilogy of translations from the Yiddish. As in their collections of stories and poetry, the standards are singularly high, the critical discrimination uniformly judicious. Twentytwo writers living in eastern Europe and America during the last century are represented by 28 selections, most of them translated into English for the first time. In subject matter they range from literary essays (I. L. Peretz, Jacob Glatstein) to scholarly studies (Max Weinreich, C. Bezalel Sherman) to fragments of autobiographical memoir (Emanuel Ringelblum) to selections from historical works (Abraham Heschel) to cultural interpretation (Hayim Greenberg). The quality of the work is not so high as in the earlier collections, for Yiddish lacked the cultural security and intellectual sophistication the essay demands; but these examples are important because they show a now almost vanished world losing some if its insularity as it reaches out into the modern age. The editors' introduction and a glossary effectively set the background for the reader whose Yiddish is less than expert.

title: They Got the DegreeOften the Hard WayAnd Then What?
description: She is in her 40's or 50's now. She went back to school as a mature woman who had a husband and probably children, or a job, and sometimes all three. It was a time when women's liberation was scarcely a rumble, but she knew somehow she wanted more from life. And education seemed to point the way.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: Re: Hooking a Tuna Is More Fun Than Getting It Out of a Can (Travel section, June 25). The last stronghold of the male chauvinist is not the local bar or gymnasium but rather, in my opinion, the open sea. I'm sure skipper Ned Frost, who was mentioned in this article about Maine, would gladly have tolerated the color blue and pork on his boat if only he had been able to talk the three women on board into staying dockside and waving byebye to the big, brave men going off to conquer the elements. I wonder how Ned would feel if all of the crew were women and he the lone male. Would the bad luck syndrome revert to him?

title: City Is Seeking to Serve Order Limiting Firemen's Sick Leave
description: The city sought yesterday to serve a court order to restrain, rankandfile firemen from equesting an unusually high amount of time off fo sickness or injury immediately after fires, a tactic in their labor negotiations with the city.

title: Plan for Saving Pine Barrens
description: MOUNT HOLLY  With little legal power but a touch of political muscle, the new Pinelands Environmental Council will soon begin trying to protect the ecologically valuable Pine Barrens of Burlington and Ocean Counties. The effort will be one of the state's first attempts at comprehensive regional planning.

title: Elaine Learson Bride of 0. H. Dowd
description: PURCHASE, N. Y. July 15Miss Elaine Y.,July Learson, daughter of T. Vincent Learson, board chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, and Mrs. Learson of Rye, was married here this afternoon to Owen Hughes Dowd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Dowd of Rockville Centre and Bellport, L. I. The bridegroom's father is president of Natural Chemical Resources based in Wilmington, Del.

title: U.S. and Paper Mill Settle Suit Over Pollution in Maine
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Justice Department announced yesterday the settlement of a lawsuit against Marcal Paper Mills, Inc., by a consent decree in which Marcal agreed to reduce its waste discharges into the Little Androscoggin River in Maine.

title: Bridge
description: THE proposition that many people are poor because some people are rich has always been open to considerable argument. But there is no argument in a bridge context: If one player has more of something, it follows that someone, else has less.

title: Photography
description: THE Edward S. Curtis revival which began more than a year ago with a spurt of ehibits of Curtis's prints has reached its second stagethe republication in large doses of Curtis's photographs of the American Indian. In addition to Ralph Andrews's Curtis Western Indiansfor years the only available collection of the photographer's workand T. C. McLuhan's Touch the Earth, published last year, there are currently at least six books from different publishers, announced or in the works, devoted to (or at least illustrated by) this remarkable visual anthropologist.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SEA BRIGHT, N. J.Armand Giglio, who operates the well  equipped tackle shop on East Ocean Avenue, is convinced any surfcaster with only limited experiencebut with proper gearcan latch onto a striped bass.

title: Ivy Fenton Is Married
description: NEW SUFFOLK, L. I., July 15Miss Ivy Fenton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fenton of New York and New Suffolk, was married here at the summer home of her parents to Thomson N. Kuhn, son of 14rs. William Kuhn of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Mr. Kuhn. Town Judge Martin Suter of Southold performed the ceremony. The bride's father is a partner in the auditing firm of Prager & Fenton. The bridegroom's father owned Kuhn Real Estate.

title: Presbytery Gets $170,000 For Center for Retarded
description: Irene Nunemaker, a former executive with Avon Products Corporation and now an independent beauty consultant, has donated $170,000 to the Presbytery of New York to build an upstate center for handicapped and retarded children from the metropolitan area.

title: Open Tennis Tickets Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets for the United States open tennis championships go on sale at the Madison Square Garden Center box office at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: COMMUNISTS MARK 50 YEARS IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 15The Japanese Communist party marked its 50th anniversary today committed to expansion by means of nonviolent, nationalistic radicalism and cooperation where possible with other leftwing forces.

title: King Kong, where Are You
description: HEAVEN help us, saysys R Dr. Roy Bennett, if any of these rabbits get away before we know the effects of the serum.

title: A BusinessUnion Strategy
description: FORT WORTHConstrua doncompany executives and representatives of 28 buildingtrades unions here have mapped a strategy that, they hope, will protect both sides from growing competition from nonunion shops.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In seven words: Cleverness is not truth, nor bitchiness journalism.

title: The Suburbs Are Resisting Homes for Foster Care
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 15  A plan to use a private house as a group home for nine foster children from New York City has thrown a middleclass, mostly white residential neighborhood here into an uproar.

title: Happy families are not all the same
description: Francis Ianni's bookmeticulous, unpretentious, unemotional and devoid of fatbased on years of intimate social interaction, should disturb all those pseudocriminologists and lazy sociologists who have been earning good livings as authorities on organized crime, by peddling law enforcement handouts as research. It should annoy those nitpicking social thinkers who have tended to shudder when the words Mafia and Cosa Nostra swam before them. (It probably won't because they then must concede they have been professionally sloppy, at the very least.) It should force various law enforcement and investigative bodies to rethink. It probably won't because the simple citing of omerta, of tales of ritualistic bloodletting, of fear, of gangland style reprisals, can fudge all kinds of investigative shortcomings.

title: Diary of a Madman, or How to Build a Classical Theater on $5 a Day
description: I HAVE a recurrent dream. It used to be a nightmare, but now it's like an old friend; I've grown accustomed to it. There I am standing in front of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. Crossing the empty reflecting pool on the plaza, marching steadily through the glare of the afternoon sunlight, a host of pickets approaches.

title: 10% of Miami Pupils Called Habitual Users of Drugs
description: MIAMI, July 15 (UPI)  A yearlong survey of teachers, administrators and counselors indicates that about 11,000 of Dade County's 110,000 junior and senior high school students, or 10 per cent, were habitual drug users.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Georgie Anne Geyer is a journalist, young, single and a woman  attributes that were both handicaps and advantages in checking out the Arab countries and the Middle East for the Chicago Daily News since 1969. Her account of a war in Lebanon, a rebellion in Eritrea and diverse adventures from Morocco to Jordan (she failed, of course, to get into Saudi Arabia) is a flying carpet woven of lively ancedotes and piquant local color. Some of it is very revealing of the Arabs and their ways: her picture, for instance, of the Egyptian upper classes lounging over cocktails in an exclusive Cairo club in Israel she senses the anguish of a people tormented by what an endless war may force them to become. To give her book latelate news value, she has capped it with an urgent title and preface, auoting the warning of U Thant that the ArabIsraeli conflict may become the new 100 years war. Running through her reports is the theme that Zionism has engendered Palestinian nationalism, which paradoxically has failed to awaken all Arabs. An interesting, sometimes illuininating footnote to one of the world's big problems.

title: the traveler's world
description: TORSHAVN, Stremoy, Faroe IslandsOne of the rewards of a detour to this unvisited, remote group of 18 islands in the North Atlantic is the opportunity to observe the happy threeway marriage the Faroese have made of their islands' natural beauty, of their basically simple way of mostly outdoor life, and of almost all the creature comforts and conveniences of Western civilization.

title: The Great Supermarket Battle
description: Whether she realizes it or not, the American housewife is being courted by the nation's supermarkets as though she had just been discovered.

title: Lachou's Is Toasted On Its 90th Birthday
description: A half block of East 14th Street belonged for a while yesterday afternoon to lovers of German marching songs, knackwurst and bratwurst, hearty imported beerand Lchow's.

title: KICKBAR INQUIRY IS PRESSED BY U.S,
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  Federal prosecutors, who tave won the conviction of the ormer aide to Representative fames M. Collins, Republican if Texas, in an $18,000 kicktack and payrolljudggling cheme, say that the investigaion is not over.

title: GILBERT GOLDEN
description: WESTON, Conn., July 15Gilbert Golden, former advertising director for Warner Brothers, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived here.

title: Hopper: More Than a Great American Realist
description: NONE of the fanfare that attended the first public showing, last year, of the works from the Hopper Bequestthat extraordinary cache of works by the late Edward Hopper which the artist bequeathed to the Whitney Museum of American Arthas accompanied the second installment of bequest pictures now on view at the museum, 945 Madison Avenue, through Sept. 11. The present show is modest indeed, comprised of 30 or more oils and watercolors compared to the 157 paintings, drawings and prints which the Whitney displayed last fall.

title: Wanna Buy A Rhinoceros?
description: IF a couple of rats like Willard and Ben can make a killing at the box office, what's to stop a respectable Rhinoceros from following suit? Nothing at all, and that's why American Film Theater a joint venture of Columbia Pictures, the American Express Company and the Ely Landau Organization has purchased Eugene Ionesco's irreverent comedy that was a triumph of the 1961 Broadway season. And adding good news to good news, they have signed Zero

title: A 3Inch Rise of Sea Level in 8 Years Is Discerned
description: The level of the sea, after rising and falling only slightly and slowly on a very limited scale through the millennia, has suddenly risen three inches in eight years according to measurements from Maine to Virginia.

title: Aviation Emergency
description: In spite of the persisting epidemic of aerial hijacking, the Federal Aviation Administration and the nation's airlines continue to put convenience and cost before safety in half  hearted attempts to deal with what has become a national aviation emergency.

title: WASTE IS ALLEGED IN DAYCARE FUNDS
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beanie said yesterday that an dnvestigation of the city's 11 child daycare centers showed deficiences and improprieties that wasted public funds, and he urged an immediate outside audit of the program.

title: Everybody Into Nobody
description: TORONTOAt the present time the new hidden environment is the ring of satellites which began to form in 1957 with Sputnik. The effect of putting the ageold planet inside a manmade environment is to create spacecapsule earth. The planet becomes an old nose cone, a garbage dump, a resource center, an archeological museum, midden heap of trash and treasures. Typically, on Sept. 11, 1969, in the wilderness of Alaska a bevy of tycoons rallied to hold a little auction. The very ancient and decayed animal matter that was the occasion of their little rally elicited bids of almost $1 billion in total and included a bid of $73 million for one parcel of property.

title: Dona B. Van Arsdale Is Married
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Miss Dona Baker Van Arsdale, chief of press relations for the Price Commission, was married here this afternoon to Carleton Shaw Jones, deputy general counsel of the commission. The Rev. Blayney CoLmore performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System will televise portions of the Aachen, West Germany, horse show next Sunday on its, AAU International Champions television program.

title: Emily Caroline Lanier Engaged
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 15  Mr.and Mrs. Sidney Lanier of Stamford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Caroline Lanier, to Laurence Seton Ross. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. H.Justin Ross of Ringoes, N. J., and Montrose, Pa.

title: Hecht Gains Ensign Honors In Port Washington Sailing
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 15  Only 43 boats remained home today for the Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island competition under the sponsorship of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

title: Girl, 12, Gets Severe Shock Climbing Out of Home Poor
description: A 12yearold Brooklyn girl was in critical condition in Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn last night after receiving massive electrical shock while swimming in her family's backyard pool.

title: Old and New Quarterbacks Prepare for the Season
description: While the New York Jets continued to pare centers off their roster in their camp at Hofstra University in Hempstead yesterday, the Giants noted that Roland Lakes, a 6foot4inch, 265pound tackle, had missed the midnight Friday deadline for reporting to camp.

title: OBSERVER
description: It was wonderful for Sweeney returning home to the whole darned family after the rigors of Miami Beach, but the family mood was disappointingly political. They had sat through too many dawns, watching Sissy Farenthold being nominated for the VicePresidency and listening to Ohio pass.

title: Albatross Reaches $1 Million Level, Sets Pacing Mark
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 5 (AP)Albatross, the 1971 harness horse of the year, added to his laurels today at Saratoga Raceway.

title: Albert Bridge Is Standing UpWith A Little Bit of Help
description: LONDONAs all the world knows, London Bridge never got a chance to fall downit was dismantled, boxed and exported to Thamesless Arizona. But take heart, the old nursery song can still be sung, because now it's Albert Bridge that's falling down, my fair lady.

title: Rogers Sees Slight Nuances Of Change in Hanoi's Position
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that there appeared to be some slight nuances of difference from past positions in the statements made by North Vietnamese negotiators in the Paris peace talks this week.

title: Busing Order in Memphis Argued in Appeals Court
description: CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit took under advisement today appeals against an order by Federal district court for the busing of 13,789 schoolchildren in Memphis.

title: CARE CENTER GETS DAYHOSPITAL AID
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15The Burke Rehabilitation Center here has received a $294s017 Federal grant, for a day hospital, the first of its kind in the country.

title: McGovern Rejects Tactic Of an Early Trip Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Senator George McGovern has decided against any foreign travel between now and the November election.

title: Miss Heymann Fiancee Of N. Eric Pedersen.
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., July 15Miss Caryl Idrienne Heymann and N. Eric Pedersen, who were graduated in May from the University of Pennsylvania, plan to marry Aug. 26 at the Standard Club in Chicago.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ALBANY, July 15  Passenger train service between New York and Montreal will be restored soon, possibly within the next few weeks, but a major unresolved question is how to decide between two alternative routes.

title: Tripping the Quite Fantastic
description: God rest ye, Lewis Carroll. Alice, in one guise or another, is still tripping through the looking glass. Listen: When I woke up this morning, I found I'd turned into my mother. How's that for a trip, eh, Lew? Oh, nothing serious, of course. Not that kind of trip, just one of those wishfulfillment jobs.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor.

title: 18 Hurt in Prison Fights
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 15 (AP)Guards used tear gas last night to put down a series of Tights between 350 black and white inmates at the California Correctional Institution at Tehachapi, a prison spmesman said. Eighteen inmates were injured. The disturbance apparently began with an argument between one black and one white inmate over a seat in the dining room.

title: Chilean Board Is Accused Of Fraud in Union Vote Tally
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 15An electoral board controlled by Communists and Socialists declared today that Luis Figueroa, a veteran Communist politician, had retained the presidency of Chile's Central Labor Union.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: Automobile dealers in the metropolitan area will hold a public showing of 1973 model cars in November at the New York Coliseum, inaugurating what they hope will be a revival of the preWorld War II annual auto shows.

title: Son to the Greenbergs
description: A son was born last Sunday to Mr. and Mrs. Bob Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I., at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, Queens. Mrs. Greenberg is the former Miss Lynne Atkinson of Plainview, L. I. Her husband is president of Montiverdi Associates, a New York advertising agency. The child has been named Jonathan Marcus.

title: Sludge To Receive Test as Fertilizer
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS  The summer sun shone brightly and the temperature was up in the 90's as the 48 teenagers tilled the soil here last week with shovel and pickaxe.

title: 2 Scientists Resign Posts In the Astronaut Program
description: HOUSTON, July 15 (UPI)Drs. Philip K. Chapman and Anthony W. England have resigned from the astronaut corps.

title: Deuce
description: FOR the past 20 years or so the United States has been the dominating force in international dance, and the influence of American dancers and choreographers on the European scene is very considerable. Glen Tetley, who is about to produce his second work for Britain's Royal Ballet, is probably the most highly regarded choreographer of his generation in Europe, and another American, far from home but becoming increasingly famous, is John Neumeier, who is the director of the Frankfurter Ballet.

title: MET FIRST INNING BEATS PADRES, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, July 15The hitstarved Mets didn't exactly satisfy their appetites tonight, but they still edged the San Diego Padres, 21, as Gary Gentry gained his first victory since May 17.

title: NewPlay Series At Shore Hotels
description: ATLANTIC CITYA new theatrical company, the Atlantic City Playhouse, is breaking with summerstock tradition by presenting a repertory of six new plays by unknown authors in hotel ballrooms at this seaside resort.

title: Dividends on the Rise
description: Will the 4 per cent limit on dividend increases be lifted if interest rates go up this fall, as is so widely predicted in financial circles?

title: Coming Up Heads Up on a Close Play at Third Base
description: PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) Willie Stargell and Jose Pagan cracked home runs to back the sixhit pitching of Dock Ellis and Dave Giusti as the Pittsburgh Pirates sealed a 51 victory today over the Houston Astros in a nationally televised game.

title: JOSEPH J. ALLEN
description: Joseph J. Allen, a lawyer in Harlem since 1931, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Man, 21, Charged With City's First Murder of a Taxi Driver in Nearly Two Years
description: A 68year old taxi driver was shot to death on West 21st Street yesterday morning by one of three male passengersthe first slaying of a cabbie in the city in almost two years.

title: Warlord Takes Jumper Stake In Field of 23 at Four Seasons
description: READINGTON, N. J., July 15  Strathmore Farms Warlord proved to be the class of a strong field of 23 entries today and won the $1,000added jumper stake at the Four Seasons Horse Show.

title: F.D.A. Proposes Procedures To Meet Environmental Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration has described its procedures for filing the environmental impact statements required by law to support its decisions.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In one respect at least Ron Blomberg hews to the Babe Ruth tradition. As all history students know full well, everything the Babe did was done in such grandiose fashion that awed chroniclers of his extravagant excesses even coined a word to describe them. The adjective was Ruthian. It set his titanic home runs. It also could be applied to the way he scored and to all his prodigious appetites. If not a gourmet, the Babe was a ravenous eater who could wolf yards of hot dogs and slosh them down with gallons of soda pop. In his heyday the Yankee slugger was acknowledged to be the master trencherman of the league.

title: Patricia Monger Bride Of Stephen Harwood
description: LANCASTER, Ohio, July 15 Miss Patricia Monger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Monger, was married here this afternoon to Stephen Rogers Harwood of New York, son of Mrs. Stephen G. Harwood of Oak Brook, Ill., and the late Mr. Harwood. The Rev. Donald Jansen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Conference Names Jensen
description: DENVER (UPI)Nordy Jensen, editor of the NCAA News and former sports information director at Arizona State University, has been named director of information for the Western Athletic Conference. He replaces David Price, who took a similar post with the Pacific Eight Conference.

title: UNIFIED PENSIONS SOUGHT BY STATE
description: The State Pension Commission has decided to try to replace the thicket of state and city retirement plans with one that would set a uniform benefit rate statewide for public employes according to job categories.

title: Nuptials for Missy Wentworth
description: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 15Miss Melissa Wentworth, daughter of Philip Henry Wentworth of New Vernon and the late Mrs. Betty Macdonald Wentworth, was married here this afternoon to Corey Atterbury Steadman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Ree Steadman of Convent Station.

title: Learning Oriental Tongues
description: SOUTH ORANGE  The most modern techniquesincluding the use of television and computersare being employed to teach 130 students to speak Chinese and Japanese in an intensive summer program at Seton Hall University.

title: Van You Tap This?
description: I was glad to read of your new policy encouraging the exchange of ideas between the press and the F.B.I. and I thought that rather than attempt to arrange an appointment (I am sure you are very busy what with reading the files and all), I'd simply send you this letter containing some of my own thoughts on the Bureau which you have temporarily inherited.

title: Nancy Meyers Wed to William Colson Jr.
description: DEMARFST, N. J., July 15Miss Nancy Patricia Meyers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Meyers, was married here this morning to William Redmond Colson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Colson of Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Kenneth Moore performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: World News Briefs
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 15 Leaders of the Sindhi and Urduspeaking communities agreed today on a formula to resolve the language dispute that has caused widespread rioting and at least 50 deaths this week in Sind Province.

title: East Hampton Offers Works of Moses Soyer
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.One of the longstanding grievances in the New York art world is that some important shows never get to the city. One of the cases in point is the Moses Soyer circulating exhibition, which went on view at Guild Hall here yesterday.

title: Suffolk Fire District Rift Resolved
description: FARMING VILLE, L. I.After five years of bitter controversy over whether to split the HoltsvllleFarmingville Fire District into two separate ones, residents voted last week, 1,075 to 789, in favor of the division.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: DUBLINThe great majority of people in both Southern and Northern Ireland would like to see an end to violence and a peaceful solution to their common problem but the leadership they produce to cope with this ancient cancer is much too cautious.

title: Tax Plan Faces Crucial Test Tomorrow
description: TRENTON  Governor Cahill should know tomorrow whether his tax reform program is on its way to becoming the biggest victory of his administration or its bitterest defeat.

title: The World
description: LONDONFor two weeks there had been relative calm in Ulster. A ceasefire agreed to by the Irish Republican Army's militant Provisional wing had brought a halt to years of sectarian violence, explosibns and indiscriminate killings.

title: The Quadrennial Madness
description: The quadrennial madness has hit the campaign artifact industry, and manufacturers and sellers of campaign buttons and bumper stickers are scrambling to make certain that every American voter serves as a walking or driving billboard for the candidate of his choice.

title: Plaquemines Parish Revisited, With Pleasure This Time
description: NEW ORLEANS, La.  One of Mark Twain's problems was that the Mississippi River flows south. Once they missed the Ohio River turnoff, Huck Finn and Jim were on their way to the slave states. Had Twain and their raft kept them going, the last land they'd have seen before being swept into the Gulf of Mexico would have been Plaquemines Parish, the lowlying Louisiana county which forms the great river's delta.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: Along with many other Hitchcock fans I have been eagerly awaiting his latest film, Frenzy. Now that it has arrived it has been praised like no other Hitchcock film within memory. His films are usually badly received at their premieres, then given classic stature a decade later.

title: Betty Jean King Is Planning Bridal
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 15 Mr. and Mrs. Leavy Lloyd Durant have announced the engagement of Mrs. Durant's daughter, Miss Betty Jean King, to Attahjundwe Obiajulu of Rego Park, Queens. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Abd'Allah Obiajulu of Entebbe, Uganda, and the late Mr. Obiajulu.

title: Housing for 24,000 Begun in Brooklyn
description: The construction of what will be the city's largest publicly aided housing development since Coop City is under way in outer Brooklyn after six years of planning and a recent change in developers.

title: Gore SupportsMcGovern
description: CARTHAGE, Tenn., July 15 (AP)Former Senator Albert Gore expressed support yesterday for Senator George McGovern's Presidential candidacy. Mr. Gore described Mr. McGovern as one of the best men I ever served with, both from the standpoint of ability and integrity.

title: Holt Gains Olympic Berth For Star Class Yachting
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP)Alan Hoit, 33 years old manufacturer who has been sailing since boyhood, won the United States Olympic Star Class yachting trials today by finishing third in the final of seven races over an 11mile course in San Francisco Bay.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina's national soccer team lost an important match to Yugoslavia last week. To make matters worse, the game ended in an ugly brawl among the players. An Argentine in the crowd, recalling the days when the national squad beat all rivals, said, Nothing of ours works right any morefootball, telephones, social security, politics. It is all a great rot.

title: Rocks Thrown at Firemen
description: About 25 youths hurled rocks, bottles and debris at firemen working at a burning abandoned building in Brooklyn's East New York section late Friday night, the police reported. Six policemen responded to the rare fighters' call for assistance and, in 10 minutes, dispersed' the missilethrowing youths and the rest of the crowd of 100 that had gathered to watch the hlaze. No one was injured and there were no arrests, police said.

title: Asbestos Detected in Test of Drugs
description: A number of injectable drugs widely used in medicine have been found contaminated with particles of asbestos, a mineral that has been linked to the development of cancer and other diseases in man.

title: Young Women Golfers to Try Again for Day in the Sun
description: Once again the rains came to spoil the debuts of many rising young golfers last week. The Women's State Golf Committee of New Jersey, which sponsors the junior tourney had to postpone the championship scheduled for the Somerset Hills Country Club in Bernardsville, N.J., Thursday.

title: Only Towns Can Give Water Franchises
description: TRENTONThe State Supreme Court, overturning a lower court decision, has ruled that the state Board of Public Utilities Commissioners does not have the right to award water franchises.

title: The Convention
description: MIAMI BEACHIn the command trailer behind the convention hall, a single sheet of paper lay before Richard G. Stearns, the intense young McGovernite who had pursued delegate votes all across the country. On the paper, these words and numbers: Hard count, 1,451; soft count, 1,633.5.

title: Cloudy Dawn Is First in Dwyer; Ruritania 2d, HalfLength Back
description: Cloudy Dawn overcame the awkward start that has become his trademark, and went on to register a thrilling victory in the $88,875 Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: SOVIET WILL BUILD DAM TO SAVE FISH
description: MOSCOW, July 15The Soviet Government today announced plans for a gigantic dam at the northern end of the Black Sea, designed to correct an ecological chain reaction that has been destroying important fisheries.

title: art
description: THE Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, which was founded in 1805, making it America's oldest art institution, occupies not only a soft but a downright squashy spot in the heart of everybody, including this reporter, who is interested in the history of art in America. This is one reason, no doubt, why I found its current exhibition (closing July 30) a complete fascinator. But it is also an exhibition that should fascinate and enlighten anyone interested in the history of collecting and the history of taste in this country.

title: A Chinese First on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (UPI)Richard Woo, 23 years old, has become the first permanent ChineseAmerican sheriff's deputy of San Francisco County. The Chinese came to San Francisco over 100 years ago, the new deputy said. It's taken all these years before one of us became a permanent deputy sheriff. I'm proud I am the first.

title: ISRAELIS DEFEND IMMIGRANT POLICY
description: CARMIEL, Israel The official from the Ministry of Absorption, Baruch Zevulun, was on the defensive.

title: Electronic Watchdogs
description: One man at 55 Water Street in downtown Manhattan monitors 5 vaults, 70 security zones, 44 fire zones, 45 holdup and callsforassistance zones, 79 guardtour zones, 28 smokedetection zones and the automatic securities conveyor system.

title: Talk of Golf
description: Where do big name college golfers and National Amateur champions go? Into the pro ranks, as quickly as they can.

title: U.S. AID IS SOUGHT FOR CITY'S PARKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A New York City parks official has told an Interior Department forum that the future for parks in urban areas was very bleak unless the Federal Government helped provide maintenance and operating funds.

title: William Silver Marries Adrianne Wolf
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 15  Miss Adrianne Merle Wolf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob William Wolf of West Orange, was married tonight at her home here to William Silver. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Gilbert Silver of Woodmere, L. I. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony.

title: The perils and rewards of reviewing
description: The task of a professional reviewer is not to impart information or to provoke thought, but to deal in attitudes. His job is to sop up the notions and prejudices of his readership, distill them into words, and then measure them against new books as these drop off the presses. He serves his readers by putting into words what, given the likes and dislikes they already have, they will like or dislike about books and performances they have yet to read, see, or hear. He tells them what to feel, and above all what to say, about productions they may or may not read, see, or hear.

title: 246 YACHTS OPEN LARCHNONT WEEK
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 15 Larchmont Yacht Club's 74th Race Week began today as an If I had only known affair. A fleet of 246 sailboats sat in hot, muggy and listless air that forced two 20minute postponements. Then a whiff turned into a little puff that flattened to a breeze that built up to 12 knots and finally burst out to 20 knots by midafternoon.

title: Spook of The Times
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 15Striding off the seventh tee today, Jack Nicklaus turned to a friend in his gallery. Ask Barbara to stop at nine and get me a cold lemonade, he said, referring to his wife. Tell her no lime juice. It's dry enough out here without any lime juice.

title: In Salzburg, the People Look As Well Listen
description: EAVERY year, at the end of March, squads of stocky rosycheeked Austrian workmen attack three mysterious mounds of rough planks in the old city of Salzburg. Ladders are propped at precarious angles; hammers ring out; boards fly through the air. In a few hours three of the most beautiful baroque fountains in Western Europe emerge from winter hibernation: the cavorting horses of the Residenzplatz; the trainer with his plunging stallion at Sigmundsplatz, and a rather melancholy Neptune nestling in the Trevilike marble faade at Kapitelplatz. The weather is usually terrible (when it snows in the Alps, it rains in the damp Salzach valley) and Neptune looks as if he could use a blanket, bet this annual rite of spring seems to shift the ebullient Salzburg spirit into high gear.

title: News of Boating
description: The closest each year that the glamorous playboys of ocean powerboat racing get to the glamorous playboy city of New York is the Hennessy Grand Prix, which starts and ends off Point Pleasant, N J., about 65 mites away.

title: Billy Harris Takes a Tour Here and Tests Reflexes
description: Is this Fifth Avenue? Billy Harris asked, looking out the window.

title: L.I.Complex Built on Site Peter Cooper Once owned
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Long Island's newest and largest office and motel complex, the $11million Executive Plaza here, also has links to the Istand's historic past. The Holiday Inn, which occupies part of the fiveacre site on Peninsula Boulevard, Front and Clinton Streets and I'ulton Avenue, stands on property that was once the iiomesite of Peter Cooper, the inventor, philanthropist and Presidential candidate.

title: The Convention
description: MIAMI BEACHProudly or resentfully, the Democrats talked a lot about revolution here last week and the upheaval they were causing in the nation's Presidential politics. And, indeed, they had taken some sizable leaps forward on the trail of reform. But the direction of change in both major parties has long been clearand the cause of that change has been as much technological as political.

title: PROXMIRE CHARGES INFLATED F14 COST
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Senator William Proxmire said today that the cost of each new Navy F14 jet fighter would be $20.8million instead of $16.8million as the Navy says.

title: Jeanne Evert Reaches Final of U.S. Amateur Clay Tennis
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (UPI)James Delaney and Ross Walker moved into the final of the national amateurs claycourt tennis championship today. Jeanne Evert and Janice Metcalf were the women finalist.

title: Striper Dispute Is Making Waves in Montauk
description: MONTAUK, L.I.This is one of the leading sportsfishing ports on the Atlantic Coast, and it is little wonder, therefore, that it has become the focal point of a lengthy controversy: whether to classify the striped bass as a game fish, thus making it off limits to commercial fishermen.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: The enjoyable article about country auctions (Travel section, June 25) reminds me of many experiences and, in particular, of advice given to me by an auctioneer.

title: Stamps
description: C ANADA in July and August will be host to four earthscience conferences, and will release four stamps Aug. 2 to commemorate the events.

title: About Pro Football
description: The response of John Unitas to the swap of the Colt and Ram franchises was a typically cool one for the renowned Baltimore quarterback.

title: Day Work Week Getting Mixed Reception
description: DETROIT, July 15  Small companies at the rate of two a day are switching to the fourday work week, but the new schedule has yet to become major trend in American industry.

title: Miss Gonnerman Advances To Final With Miss Kanarek
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 15Topseeded Louise Gonnerman of River Edge and Mimi Kanarek of New York advanced today to the final of the New Jersey State women's tennis championship at the East Orange Tennis Club.

title: Henry White 3d Weds Miss Jaye Brinster
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 15 Miss Jaye Lacy Brinster and Henry H. Allen White 3d were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Joseph 0. Rand in the First Presbyterian Church. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Brinster of Princeton and her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. White Jr. of Wilmington, Del.

title: Joy G. Sperry Married on L.I.
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 15Miss Joy Garvin Sperry and Wyman Luther Emery, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donovan Eniery of Westport, Conn., were married here to, day at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Henry Ehlers Jr., by the Rev. Robert T. Hollett, rector of Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Donna Lee Dooley Is Planning Bridal
description: Miss Donna Lee Dooley, whose father, Arthur D. Dooley, is vice president and managing director of the Plaza, plans to be married in December to Jonathan Lee Burr.

title: Reported Smallpox Cases Up 34% in the Last Year
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (AP)Reported cases of smallpox worldwide increased 34 per cent during the last year, the United State Center for Disease Control reported yesterday.

title: Jersey Delegates Looking to Nov. 7
description: MIAMI BEACH  Christopher Jackman, a State Assemblyman from Hudson County, waved his arms in the direction of his colleagues on the New Jersey delegation to the Democratic National Convention, and said: I won't deny that these kids did a helluwa job.

title: Kathleen McKay Bride of Quentin Keith
description: HARTFORD, July 15Miss Kathleen McKay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Forbes McKay of West Hartford, was married here this evening to Quentin Barry Keith. His parents are Mrs. Jocelyn Freer Keith of Chevy Chase, Md., and Norman Clinton Keith of New York, East Hampton, L. I., and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

title: New Law for Pesticides
description: Soon after its return this week the Senate is scheduled to take up a revised pesticide control bill, one of the most importantand controversialitems on its agenda. If the legislation is to serve the interests of the environment, at home and abroad, the Senate bill will have to prevail over its feeble counterpart in the House of Representatives. And if it is to be a really major contribution, it will have to include the strengthening amendments added by Senators Nelson of Wisconsin and Hart Michigan.

title: Humanizing Executives: A Low Priority
description: It made everyone seem so human; as if we all had interests in common.

title: Arena Plan Called Blow To Builders
description: EAST RUTHERFORD Some people in New Jersey have been in a state of euphoria over since the announcement of the proposed complex that will bring bigtime sports to the Hackensack Meadowlands, but some builders believe the project has put them in limbo.

title: LAWYER FOR CALLEY TO SEEK A NEW TRIAL
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 15 (AP)The civilian lawyer for Lieut. William L. Calley said today he would seek a new trial for Calley because of the discovery of a witness to the Mylai massacre who the Army contended was missing at the time of the lieutenant's original courtmartial.

title: A Safety Panel Member Quits Over G.M. Award
description: DETROIT, July 15Walker Sandbach, the executive director of Consumers Union, said the would resign tomorrow from the National Motor Vehicle Safety Advisory Council to protest the council's award to the president of the General Motors Corporation.

title: The Belles Are Ringing With Goods Of Humor
description: Since neither of my two sons is a male chauvinist. I am forced to carry the pig banner for the entire family. And you should have seen me waving it in Forest Hills the other night when, on my way to get some cutrate cases of beer and soda on Metropolitan Avenue, I spottedyou'll never guess a Good Humor girl.

title: A.A.U. DIVING WON BY MISS POTTER
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July, 15 (AP)Cindy Potter won her second championship of the week while Rick Early won his second ever as the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor diving meet concluded today.

title: Moon Trips Help Beekeepers
description: NEW BRUNSWICKSending American astronauts to the moon has had a sideeffect here on earth, and especially in New Jersey, saving the lives of honeymakers.

title: UNION AIDE WINS STAY ON PENALTY
description: A Federal judge has ordered the executive board of the painters union here to delay the imposition of any penalty against Frank Schonfeld, the union's secretarytreasurer, who contends that he has angered the board with his campaign against corruption.

title: New & Novel
description: Among the many things I didn't know was that cockfighting was legal in the state of Florida. Charles Willeford (author of The Burnt Orange Heresy), an evident aficionado, wraps his expertise and his local knowledge in some rudimentary fiction. The result will not please the A.S.P.C.A. Nonetheless, it has pluses: in particular, rapport with the cracker constituency that keeps this anachronistic sport alive.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: For the most part I very much appreciated the article on Kahlil Gibran by Stefan Kanfer. What I didn't appreciate the tiniest little bit was one of his valid reasons for Gibran's endurance as a writer: College girls no longer have to be shoehorned into bed. But they still like to be coaxed there. What better way than with The Prophet.  How long 0 Lord?!

title: Arehitecture
description: A RCHITECTURE creates its own world  literally. A building is more than a space enclosure; it is a sealed lifesupport system. A highrise building is artdfically iigHted, ventilated, heated and cooled. Think about that. Think about it in terms of playing with the environment. Think about it in terms of the energy crisis. And polluting side effects. And the multiplication of power needed to do this for every commercial or institutional building in a city.

title: Fonty Flock, ExRacer, Dies; 4748 Stock Car Champion
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (AP) Fonty Flock, a championship stockcar racer, died today after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: Family Visits Opening of Jersey Jungle Where Lions, Camels and Buffalo Roam
description: WEST MILFORD, NJ., July 15 Somewhere between the elephant ride and the carousel, Thomas Oblitas and his wife, Martha, took their first long breath since they started their trip into the New Jersey jungle with their children this morning.

title: Congress:
description: WASHINGTONCongress, more preoccupied for the past six months with politicking than legislating, reconvenes tomorrow, apparently headed for a repeat performance of 1960 when It met after the Presidential conventions only to find itself so caught up in partisan squabbling that it could not act.

title: Fuller's Entry Runs 1 and 2 In Handicap at Arlington
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (AP)Pan, owned by Peter Fuller of Sunny Says Quick and Main Boston, finished one, two in the $28,000 Janice H. Handicap before 22,096 at Arlington Park today.

title: Books: Reforming the Parties
description: MONTCLAIR  Frederick H. Sontag spent most of his time two weeks ago commuting between his home here and the Democratic party's Credentials Committee in Washington and pronounced himself frustrated.

title: Greek Newspaper Calls for an End to Monarchy
description: ATHENS, July 15An editorial suggesting that Premier, George Papadopoulos be made the President of Greece for life was published here this week as part of what appeared to be the second antiroyalist press campaign in six months.

title: The Barracudina Is Sought As SpermWhale Substitute
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 15 (Canadian Press)A small Atlantic fish, the barracudina, is being sought by researchers at the fisheries laboratories here because they believe that its oils may provide the basis of a new industry.

title: Education
description: MOSCOW Economic conditions in the Soviet Union are forcing the Russians to realign their educational priorities, and the effects are not likely to be greeted with universal enthusiasm.

title: A Sofa Enjoyed by Families and Dogs
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Loeb got a new sofa recently and proceeded to tie it into a knot. Sometimes they tic it into two knots, one at each end.

title: The World
description: For years the struggle between the rightwing Government of Guatemala and the small bands of leftist guerrillas has been marked by assassination and murder. Hundredson both sideshave been killed; but in recent days there have been signs that a new viciousness has permeated the dispute.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Coming of Rain Overshadows Election In DroughtStricken Chilean Province
description: ILLAPEL, Chile, July 13 Ruben Cortez Araya opened the wooden gates to a thicket corral, and a herd of dappled goats trotted up a hillside where the grass was green for the first time in five years.

title: Spinoffs of a family search
description: I have told of the most dramatic successes of my search, but it has also led to other finds. In New York one morning, W. Colston Leigh, who arranges my lectures, asked if I'd fly on short notice to Simpson College in Indianola, la., to take the place of an ailing client. Barely making it, I spoke of my long searchthen the Academic Dean, Waller Wiser, told me that from things I'd said, he knew he was of the seventh generation from the Wailers of Spotsylvania County, Va., who had bought my forefather. The college since has given me the honorary Doctorate of Letters; Waller presented it. Every time that he and I get the chance to talk now, we speculate upon why we met after 200 years.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: To reduce my reaction to Stefan Kanfer's longneeded Gibran article Kalilil Gibran But is it not strange that even elephants yield  and that The Prophet is still popular? (June 25), to Gibran's seven  word limit: Bravo! bravo! bravo! bravo! bravo! bravo! bravo!

title: The World
description: In the little African village of Nkroful, 240 miles north of the Ghanaian capital of Accra, Rwame Nknnnah was born 62 years ago. Last week, the colorful former President of Ghana who had died April27 while in exile abroad, was brought back to his native village for burial.

title: Opera: Central City Presents Figaro
description: CENTRAL CITY, Colo., July 15The Central City Opera, back in operation after a year's hiatus caused by financial problems, seems to be thriving under its new artistic director, Nathaniel Merrill. Last night's performance of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, one of two productions mounted in this first season of rebirth (Verdi's Falstaff is the other) showed not only that the company's present state is artistically healthy but that the potential for growth is enormous.

title: Samuel de Champlain
description: For Europeans the 16th century was an age of excitement and wonder, with marvels more astonishing to them than the exploits of the astronauts have been for us. The explorers of the first great spaceage, the men who more than doubled the size of the world for their contemporaries, were able to bring back tangible objects that promised infinite wealth, even hopeful cures for the ailments of mankind. They also brought back living men and women from that hitherto unknown world, creatures whose souls needed saving, perhaps at the cost of their labor and liberty.

title: The World
description: About 70 per cent of the people of Pakistan speak Urdu, and Urdu is the nation's official language.
