But in the province of Sind, which includes Karachi and Hyderabad, the nations' two largest cities, half the population speaks Sindhiand 10 days ago the provincial legislature made Sindhl its official language. That angered the Urduspeaking half of the province and riots broke out. Demonstrators erected roadblocks; a government building in Karachi was set on fire.

title: Bookstore's Specialty Is Murder Most Fair
description: Mayhem and murder are afoot on West 87th Street. But for the while, most of it is safely confined at No. 271 by Murder Ink.

title: Rousseau Snaps Swim Mark
description: VITTEL, France, July 15 (UPI)Michel Rousseau of France broke his European swimming record for the 100meter freestyle event by covering the distance in 52.6 seconds. Competing in the second day of the preOlympic trials, Rousseau beat his record set a yearago, byone tenth of a second.

title: Miss Lepir's Putt on 36th Wins State Amateur Golf
description: CLAYVILLE, N. Y., July 15 (AP)Darcy Lepir sank a fivefoot putt on the 36th hole today for a 1 up victory over Catherine Morse to become the New York State women's amateur golf tournament champion.

title: Daughter for Mrs. Slovis
description: ROBINS AIR FORCE BASE, Ga., July 15A daughter was born July 2 to Capt. Norman Douglas Slovis of the Air Force Dental Corps and Mrs. Slovis at the Air Force Hospital here. Mrs. Slovis is the former Miss Carol Slobody of Cleveland. The child has been named Margo Ann.

title: Before the Words
description: At a time of loud talk and noisy demonstration of emotions, it is well to remember that the simplest, most profound truths are quietly stated and that only buds, seeds and eggs really summarize fundamental matters. Such facts are difficult to understand and accept, in part because we prefer to talk rather than listen. Maybe we should more often, particularly in such times as these, spend an hour on an open hillside or in a sunlit meadow and renew contact with basic realities. Not talking about them, but listening to them, letting them seep into us.

title: BRAZIL PRISONERS APPARENTLY FAIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15A hunger strike of some 32 Brazilians jailed for political offenses has apparently failed to achieve its objectivesto sharpen the conflict between the militaryled Government and the Roman Catholic church over human rights, and to arouse foreign public opinion.

title: Theresa O'Brien to Be Bride in Fall
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 15Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Brien have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Theresa O'Brien, to Charles E. Giuliani, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Charles Giuliani of North Merrick. The wedding will take place here Sept. 30.

title: A Collector's Choice
description: An evergrowing number of women across the country are discovering the secret of dressing in Kimberlys knits that are simply designed, yet sophisticated looking, suiting a wide range of tastes.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Over the years, newcomers have been drawn to the Jackson Heights section of northern Queens because of its attractive residential homes and apartments and its proximity to Manhattan. From midtown, it is only seven miles away, a 20minute ride on the subway.

title: Elizabeth to Visit Yugoslavia
description: LONDON, July 15 (UPI)Queen Elizabeth II will pay state visit to Yugoslavia Oct. 17 to 21. her first to an Eastern European country, Buckingham Palace announced today. The Queen's husband, Prince Philip, and her daughter, Princess Anne, will accompany her, the announcement said.

title: COLLEGE OPENINGS FOUND NUMEROUS FOR TERM IN FALL
description: Colleges and universities across the country, only two months away from the start of a new school year, still have room for at least 300,000 to 500,000 more students.

title: Christine Henriques Garfield Engaged
description: Miss Christine Henriques Garfield and Davis Wallace Young plan to be married Aug. 5 in Greenwich, Conn. The announcement of their engagement has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Douglas Sutherland Dodge of New York and Sheffield and Cuttyhunk Island, Mass., and John Newell Garfield of Chicago.

title: Letters:
description: Summer visitors who are vacationing in eastern Long Island and other areas that are infested with gypsy moth should take precautions against carrying this pest home with them. Most of the caterpillars start to pupate in July. They retire into smooth, dark brown pupa cases which usually are attached to tree trunks but in many cases to any other handy object that offers some protection, such as the underside of an automobile fender or the arm of a garden chair. The female deposits an egg mass containing from 100 to 700 or more eggs. This egg mass is an inch or more long and about a halfinch in width and looks something like a piece of chamois leather with a velvety surface. A single egg mass transported to an area hitherto free of this pest could start a fresh outbreak. The eggs are completely winter hardy and if not destroyed will hatch next spring and the larvae will begin their voracious feeding. All automobiles that have been parked in infested regions during July or August should be inspected carefully and any egg masses removed and destroyed by burning or soaking in creosote or kerosene.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, was not consulted on the selection of his party's first woman chairman, and he will not know his campaign assignment until he visits his running mate in the Black Hills of South Dakota late next week.

title: Harold Connett Dies at 77; Headed Tanners Council
description: QUOGUE, L. I., July 15Harold Connett, former president of the Surpass Leather Company, who headed the shoe and leather division of the War Production Board in World War II and was a former president of the Tanners Council of America, died yesterday in Suffolk County Hospital, Riverhead. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Bedford Runs 10,000 In Best Time of Year
description: LONDON, July 15 (AP)Dave Bedford of England recorded the fastest 10,000meter time in the world this year, running it in 27 minutes 52.8 seconds today in the British Open Athletics meet before 30,000 fans at Crystal Palace Stadium.

title: Forest Hills Workshop Guides Residents to Realities
description: When the phrase adult education is used, most people think of courses in gardening, arts and crafts, secretarial skills, dancing, bridge and photography.

title: 8 AWARDED $19,776 ON SEX BIAS CHARGE
description: The New York State Commissioner of Human Rights has ordered a bakery workers union in Buffalo to pay nearly $19,776.80 to eight women who had accused the union of sex discrimination.

description: What's New in Art

title: Jackson of A's Clouts His 17th
description: The Oakland A's, whose nicely balanced blend of effective pitching, tight defense and power hitting has enabled them to compile the best wonlost record in the major leagues, put all those qualities on display yesterday at Yankee Stadium in a'62 victory over the Yankees.

title: Austria Agrees to Pay 100% Of Catholic School Salaries
description: ROME, July 15The Vatican has announced the formal acceptance by the Austrian Government of an agreement under which it will pay 100 per cent of the salaries of teachers in Roman Catholic schools in Austria.

title: B.F.Fulton Fiance Of Martha Gerosa
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 15 Miss Martha Ann Gerosa and Barry Freeman Fulton will be married July 29. Mr. and Mrs. Alfred George Gerosa of Harrison have announced the'r daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Oliver Marcy of Franklin, N. H., and the late Col. Robert Freeman Fulton, U.S.A.F.

title: Recordings
description: HOW many Lucian will fit on the face of the arth? This is not a catechismic question belonging to some arcane theology, but a problem confronted, it would seem, almost annually by record companie3 who recognize the drawing power of certain leading ladies when coupled with everyone's bestknown coloraturasoprano display opera, Lucia di Lammermoor, but who may at the same time be leery of the public's tolerance for still another familiar trilling ascent into bel canto madness.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since mid1971 many persons have commented about the socalled baby bust. Now all the figures are in and they do not support the idea of a birth dearth. Neither do they indicate the lowest natural increase in history for the American people. Instead, all the figures considered together indicate a good many years ahead with more than four million births each year, as was true during the baby boom of the fifties and sixties.

title: CHILD CARE OFFICIAL RESIGNS H.E.W. POST
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Edward F. Zigler, director of the Offibe of Child Development and chief of the Children's Bureau, in the Department of has resigned his dual post to return to teaching and research at Yale University.

title: Music: Orchestra Filled With Concert Accordions
description: BOUND BROOK  Originally we hoped to have a fairtomiddling orchestra, said Gerald T. Glynn as he finished directing one of the regular Monday night rehearsals of the St. Mary's Accordion Concert Orchestra in the basement auditorium of St. Mary's Parish House. But today we have a crackerjack.

title: Miss. Colette Woods Betrothed To David Wilhelm Jr., Rancher
description: Mrs. Colette Ivel Woods of New York and William Johnson Woods Jr., also of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Colette Sebrell Woods to David Cudahy Wilhelm Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm of Denver.

title: Flushing Is a Pacesetter In Queens Housing Rise
description: A flurry of residential construction across a wide swath of northern Queens, but mainly in Flushing, Bayside and Douglaston, provided a net gain of 26,500 housing units in the last decade.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: For 2.9 cents a mileif you buy the right faremost of the North Atlantic ached uled airlines will package you in an envelope of pressurized air, feed you, show you a motion picture and hurl you across the ocean at 550 miles an hour in a $25million flying machine.

title: New & Novel
description: Milovan Djilas belongs to a long line of Montenegrin leadersfrom princes to revolutionaries  who have mingled politics with literature. Among the fruits of his efforts have been lengthy terms in prison, where all but one of these 13 stories were written. Taken together, they fuse into a sampling of the Balkan ambience: a mixture of ethnic pride, intransigent self  determination and mercurial tensions. Laced, as Djilas sees it, by a corollary inhumanity. This perpetual cruelty extends to beasts as well as man. It should interest those who think that violence is a recent local phenomenon.

title: West Coast Scout Takes $113,500 Haskell by Six Lengths and Returns $6.60
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15Ralph Wilson, who owns the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League, and numerous horses, was so impressed when his 4yearold colt, West Coast Scout, won the Amory L. Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park today that he said, I'm taking films of this race up to camp and I'll show them to the football team.

title: Cynthia Hayes, Duane Sadula Married on L.I.
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July 15  Miss Cynthia Anne Hayes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Gray Hayes of Manhasset, was married this afternoon to Duane Regis Sadula, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Peter Sadula, of Middlebury, Conn.

title: Motorist on an LSD Trip Chased by 25 Police Cars
description: Twentyfive police radio cars pursued a sports car, driven by a Brooklyn man who later said he was high on LSD, through 26 miles of Manhattan streets ydsterday morning in an 80mileanhour chase that ended with seven policemen and a civilian injured, seven cars wrecked And the arrest of the driver on a series of charges that included attempted murder.

title: Rosmary J. Travers Bride of R. A. Humble
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., July 15 Miss Rosemary Jeanne Travers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Travers of Fort Salonga, formerly of Lewiston Heights, N. Y., was married here at noon today to Richard A. Humble of San Francisco. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Humble of Arcadia, Calif.

title: YOUTHS LUNCHES GET LATIN FLAVOR
description: More than 22,000 children enrolled in various summer programs in Harlem and the Lower East Side have begun to receive free lunches with a Latin flavor in an effort to make the food more interesting to them while helping the economic development of the New York Puerto Rican community.

title: PENTECOSTAL UNIT GAINS FOLLOWERS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15A businessmen's group closely associated with the pentecostal movement, which gives special attention to the phenomenon of speaking in tongues, reported this week that its membership had doubled in the last two years.

title: 40,000 police agencies can be wrong
description: A little more than a year ago, the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights held four weeks of public hearings on the widespread political surveillance conducted between 1967 and 1970 by the United States Army. This February, the subcommittee's chairman, Senator Samuel J. Ervin Jr., of North Carolina, filed a brief with the Supreme Court in which he argued that the Army's activities violated the First Amendment of the Constitution because they had had a chilling effect on the rights of thousands of Americans to assemble and speak their rands. As one example of the indiscriminate surveillance, initiated by the Johnson Administration in the wake of the riots in Los Angeles, Newark and Detroit, the Senator from North Carolina noted that at least one Supreme Court Justice, numerous Senate and House members and a large number of state officials had been monitored by Army counterintelligence agents.

title: Youths Test the Influence of Ads
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  While some advertisers are undoubtedly still laughing all the way to the bank, the laugh was on them at the recent Youth Consumer Competition of Nassau County. In fact, the laughter proved the outward sign of a sobering new skepticism on the part of the young consumers.

title: MISS BLALOCK TEAM TAKES GOLF CROWN
description: MASHPEE, Mass., July 15 (AP)Janie Blalock and Sandra Palmer shot a sixunderpar 66 today for a 36hole total of 130 to win the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association fourball championship at New Seabury Golf Club.

title: SHOP TALK
description: FLEMINGTON  There may be fewer small farms, but Hunterdon County's agricultural lifestyle attracts shoppers and tourists in increasing numbers.

title: World's Communist Parties Grow by 1 %
description: WASHINGTON, July 15World Communist parties now comprise approximately 47.21 million persons, an increase of 500,000, or, 1.1 per cent, since 1970, according to an annual survey just completed by the Department of State.

title: Militancy of Antiwar Veterans Is Rising
description: With a flare for guerilla theater that has won them publicity again and again, the Vietnam Veterans Against the War have emerged as one of the most outspoken peace groups in the country.

title: AROUND THE
description: Use amino triazole, sold under various trade names to kill poison ivy. Read and follow the package label very carefully. Warm sunshine will correct many languid, bloomless plants that are just plain water soaked. Keep after weeds Feed evergreens for the last time this year Fillin harvested rows with new plantings.

title: Music
description: I CAN'T talk the way you people do around here. I can't say New York. I can't do thatit's not me. I say New Yawh. Because I'm from Newahlins; that's right, one word. Not New Orleans.Singer Merry Clayton, a delightfully energetic ball of charm under an Afro hairdo, was engaging in her favorite activity  rapping nonstop in a shift of ideas, reminiscences and opinions that cut from one idea to another with a rapidity that would do justice to a Godard movie. She has made the alwaysdifficult switch from backup singer to upfront soloist with firecracker performances that blend the rhythm and vigor of soul music with the familiar melodies of contemporary pop. Bouncing around the New York City offices of A and M Records, Miss Clayton, exhilarated by the positive response to her yearold career as a solo performer, talked about everything from singing to having babies to her appearance tomorrow night at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park.

title: Phillies Score 11 Runs in SeventhInning Surge and Turn Back Giants, 114
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies scored a season high of 11 runs in the seventh inning today and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 114.

title: Robin Lynne Schwartz Affianced
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 15  Mr. and Mrs. J. Michael Schwartz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin Lynne Schwartz, to Robert Leslie Deak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas L. Deak. Both families reside in Scarsdale.

title: POLLUTION FEARED AT LAKE IN KENYA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 15 (Reuters)Wildlife experts say pollution is threatening Lake Nakuru, the home of millions of flamingos, pelicans, storks and other birds.

title: Four Clearinghouses Aid College Search
description: There are four major nonprofit clearinghouses in the country that help students find colleges that have room for them. They usually charge the student $20 or $25 for circulating his name to the colleges.

title: Country Friend Still a Racing Factor at 10
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15 He's very difficult to live with if he loses, but when he wins, he's so elated that he momentarily forgets about the ailments that are hampering his waning career.

title: Colbert, Johnson Card 69's to Keep Milwaukee Golf Lead
description: MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP) Jim Colbert, seeking his second tour victory and first in three years, and George Johnson each carded a 69 today and continued to share the lead after three rounds of the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: 3 GET LONG TERMS IN STABLE BURNING
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 15 Three black men drew long prison sentences today for destroying a barn and 15 horses at a whiteowned riding academy stable in 1968.

title: Television
description: WNILE the Democratic Convention monopolized most lines of electronic cornmunication last week, some observers may have been movedperhaps, only perhapsto ponder the very nature of communication, electronic and otherwise. The subject has inspired professionals and amateurs to books, lectures, seminars and innumerable government and foundation grants. Communication? The consensus so far on the subject is obvious: Taint easy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  Senator Eagleton promised tonight that if he and Senator McGovern win the election the District of Columbia will have self  government within four years.

title: Pirates Hebner Injured
description: PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP)Richie Hebner,'Pittsburgh's third baseman, may be out of action for more than a week because of an ankle injury, a spokesman for the Pirates said today. Hebner suffered a pulled Achilles tendon in his left ankle during last night's game against Houston.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: In connection with your article on tourism classes in college (Travel section, May 28), 1 would like to report that Florida State University at Tallahassee awarded more bachelor's degrees (120) in this field last year than Cornell University, Michigan State or any other university conducting a fouryear program in tourism studies. These degrees were awarded in the university's School of Hotel and Restaurant Administration, and we have just recently submitted the final draft of a proposal for a new School of Tourism and Travel Administration.

title: 4 IN COLLEGE WIN RIGHT TO WELFARE
description: Four needy mothers have won the right to retain welfare benefits while they attend college as fulltime students.

title: Travel Notes: Airport Tax Faces Challenge
description: AIRLINE passengers are being eyed by an increasing number of city and state governments as a source of extra revenue, and unless a suit against the city of Philadelphia, which comes up for a hearing Tuesday, overturns a $2 tax on travelers arriving at and departing from Philadelphia International Airport, more widespread application of socalled airport head taxes can be expected.

title: ALLARD AND SCHULTZ TO PLAY OFF TODAY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 15 (AP) Bob Allard and Rick Schultz each carded a 69 today to tie at 285 after the regulation 72 holes and force a playoff in the 47th annual National public links tournament.

title: TURNPIKE TO BUILD PARK NEAR RTE. 46
description: CARLSTADTAn 85acre park completing a $1million hotel will be built along the banks of the Hackensack River near Carlstadt by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) Daniel J. Walker, Democratic candidate for governor, says he expects Mayor Daley to help produce a November victory in Illinois for Senator McGovern.

title: Water From World War II Found in Egyptian Desert
description: CAIRO, July 15 (Reuters)Pour drums containing what may be the only radiationfree water in the world have been found in Egypt's Western Desert, the newspaper Al Ahram reports.

title: Big Park Project in Canadian Rockies Rejected
description: OTTAWA, July 15The Government this week rejected $30million project that would have created a tourist town in Banff National Park in the Canadian Rockies.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, July 15The chief spokesman for the militarybacked Government said today that a plan to kidnap the late President Kennedy's son, John F. Kennedy Jr., had been foiled and that eight men had been arrested.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is astonishing that the selfproclaimed liberals who are supporting the Presidential candidacy of George McGovern have been so silent concerning his open acceptance of and allegiance to the quota system in American politics.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Those who favor Senator George McGovern's economic program should be aware of certain facts which show that his program will not soak the rich, but will assuredly soak the middle class and leave the wealthy essentially unscathed. At the heart of his program is a massive transfer of income taxation burdens to those earning more than $12,000 or thereabouts from those earning less.

title: Queens Students Hate to Yield Rats
description: A lack of funds may force the abandonment this summer of a research program under which students at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens have been conducting experiments on 300 rats.

title: Nuptials for Miss Tilghman Waechse
description: MELVILLE, L. I., July 15 Miss Tilghinan Hollyday Waesche, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Edward Waesche Jr. of Rockville Centre and the late Mr. Waesche, was married here this afternoon to Keever Berman, news director of WORFM radio in New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Berman of Seattle.

title: U.S.Japan Game Put Off
description: NAGOYA. Japan, July 15 (AP)The fourth game of the first United StatesJapan collegiate baseball series scheduled for today was postponed until tomorrow because of heavy rain. Japan leads 21 in the fourofseven series.

title: Oh, Judy! Oh, Rudy! Oh, Balderdash!
description: DUE to a severe attack of unemployment, I've been staying up most of the night for the past six weeks watching old movies on television. My doctor has forbidden me alcohol and pills; reading, for some reason, increases my anxiety so I watch old movies. Not that I enjoy them. I don't. Unlike many of my peers, I have never been overly dippy for the good old days when Hollywood helped us forget the DepressionI remember the Depression. I was out of work then, too. But the movies do finally put me to sleep.

title: 1,000 MORE FLEE ULSTER TO SOUTH; 6 DIE IN CLASHES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 15The violence continued in Northern Ireland today, with more explosions and sniper attacks and a confrontation in Londonderry between Roman Catholic women and British soldiers.

title: Television
description: 66T'S as though I'm living a David Steinberg situation. Here I am, working for CBS in a brandnew summer show. And right next door to my office the CBS guys are preparing an answer to a ui't lodged against the network by the Smothers Brothers. I was supposed to be the one, responsible for the brothers being taken off the air. And now I'll have to give evidence for the brothers, against my own bosses.

title: First Again Takes 2 Titles
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., July 15First Again, an 8yearold brown gelding owned and ridden by Eve Baskowitz of St. Louis, captured both the regular and junior working hunter championships today at the Springbrook Park horse show. The event was held at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds.

title: TOPE TRIUMPHANT IN TRANSAM RACE
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 15Warren Tope, a 25yearold systems analyst from Bloomfield Hills, Mich., won the Road America TransAm today in a Ford Mustang after George Follmer's Javelin was slowed by engine trouble. Follmer led the first 136 miles of the 200mile race around the fourmile Road America circuit. On the 33d of 50 laps Follmer pitted for gasoline and tires without losing the lead. The next time around, Follmer pitted again to complain that his engine was losing power. Tope took the lead on the next lap to stay in front until the checkered flag.

title: For Ill Youngsters, Clowns Are Just What Doctor Ordered
description: The tan tail of the white mouse wiggled in the air, but no trepidation was visible in the little girl's eyes. She swung off her chair in the hospital's Children's Ward and onto the crutches that helped move her metalbraced legs toward the creature. With a smile, she reached and petted its furry back and, when the mouse let out a cooing squeal, the little crippled girl only laughed.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Newsweek and the New York office of Time have just added the first women to their advertising sales staffs and so has American Home magazine.

title: Ability to Break Soviet Codes Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The United States is reported to have refined its electronics intelligence techniques to the point where it can break Soviet codes, listen to and understand Soviet communications and coding systems and keep track of virtually every Soviet jet plane or missilecarrying submarine around the world.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Only once a year do racing fans in this part of the country get the opportunity to see competition in the World Championship of Makes and in the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup. And then there are all those namedropping possibilitiesGrand Prix drivers like Mario Andretti, Jacky Ickx, Ronnie Peterson, Tim Schenken, Brian Redman, Reine Wise11, Peter Revson, Rolf Stommelen, Gijs van Lennep, Denis Hulme and Frangois Cevert. Add a few other international name drivers like Vic Elford, Gerard Larrousse, Derek Bell, Jackie Oliver, David Hobbs. Finally, there are the cars  Ferrari, Alfa, Porsche, Mirage, Lola, Chevron, Corvette.

title: Brooklyn Man, 59, Seized In Calling In False Report
description: A 59yearold Brooklyn man was arrested Friday evening at his home in the Crown Heights section and accused of falsely reporting that a patrolman was in grave trouble there.

title: Movies
description: CLIFF ROBERTSON has been on three airplanes already today, and he is saddlesore as he waits impatiently at Los Angeles International Airport for the 10:30 plane that will take him home to New York.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONEver since, the American air campaign over North Vietnam was resumed early in April, Hanoi had been chargingand Washington had been denyingthat the North's highly vulnerable riverdike system was being bombed. By the end of last month the controversy had swelled Into an international propaganda war, with some Hanoibased journalists and diplomats reporting that the dikes were indeed being hit by bombs.

title: Pope Goes to Summer Home
description: ROME, July 15Pope Paul VI left today for his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo in the Frascati Hills southeast of Rome, where he is expected to remain until midSeptember.

title: WILLIAM F. LEICESTER
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., July 15 William F. Leicester, a retired vice president of Borden, Inc., and a former president of the Borden Chemical Division, died yesterday in Hunterdon Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Pittstown.

title: Thompson House Adds Weaving Demonstration
description: SETAUKET, L. IThompson House, a 1700 saltboxtype residence on North Country Road, now offers visitors a demonstration of weaving. There is also a display of 18th and 19thcentury documents pertaining to weaving and an exhibition of handwoven fabrics.

title: Music
description: If I.B.M. should announce tomorrow that it had nothing, really, against computers but that in future it would concentrate on producing handlettered volumes of modern poetry, eyebrows would raise. But hardly more than they are certain to lift in contemporary music circles over some recent decisions by Paul Fromm, founder and president of the Fromm Music Foundation.

title: Education
description: Mother Goose would hardly recognize her rhyme, but officials North Miami Beach, Fla., hope that the city's schoolchildren will take the message to heart. The jingle and several others taken from the book Nursery Rhymes for the Times by Jeff Sparks are part of North Miami Beach's new educational program against litter and pollution. The rhymes with appropriate drawings will be displayed posters in the schools with the intent of fostering an ecologicalit not a poeticawareness in the students.

title: Larry Sharp, Lawyer, Weds Marcia Kline at Bard College
description: ANNANDALEONHUDSON, N. Y., July 15The chapel of Bard College was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Marcia Brayton Kline, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Reamer Kline, president of Bard College, and Mrs. Kline to Larry Dwight Sharp.

title: Antipollution Law Spreads Controversy
description: WILMINGTON, Del. Landmark legislation to preserve the Delaware coast for recreation passed its first anniversary this month with a record of effectiveness that has attracted widespread interest among officials of other states but has stirred the animosity of heavy industry.

title: PAUL J. ELLIOTT
description: DETROIT, July 15 (AP)Paul J. Elliott, a Detroit News copy editor, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while playing tennis. He was 58 years old.

title: Aussies Add to Lead Over English in Cricket
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 15 (Reuters)Australia's cricket team moved toward a massive lead today after Bob Massie and Dennis Lillee had bowled England out for 189 runs on the third day of the third test match.

title: 1,362 Storm Victims Aided
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, says that his department has provided temporary housing for 1,362 families flooded out by the tropical storm Agnes and has received 17.000 more requests for Government housing.

title: A Fourth Event Is Canceled In TransAm Racing Series
description: DENVER, July 15  The Trans  American Championship of the Sports Car Club of America, already hard hit by cancellations, lost a fourth event this week. Cancellation of the TransAm race scheduled for Sept. 2 at Edmonton (Alberta) International raceway, was announced at the S.C.C.A. headquarters here. Previous cancellations wereannounced by. Mosport Park in Ontario, Riverside in California and Summit Point in West Virginia. The TransAm races remaining are tomorrow's Road America at Elkhart Lake, Wis., and a July 30 event at Sanair International, near Montreal.

title: JOBS FOR POOR GO TO MIDDLE CLASS
description: The summer job picture here is so tight that some of the city's limited supply of jobs originally designed for the poor have been going to families with somewhat higher incomes.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Some people in Wall Street say James J. Needham, the new chairman  designate of the New York Stock Exchange, will be presiding over a dying institution.

title: Repairing motors at Freeport center for retarded.
description: FREEPORT, L. I. A short time ago Chris, a 22yearold Mongoloid who has gained a measure of dignity and success because he was given training and an opportunity to work, watched intently in his home as the plight of retraded children at a state institution was displayed on his television set.

title: RUPP, 70, TO RUN MEMPHIS IN A.B.A.
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI)Charles O. Finley said today he had signed 70yearold Adolph Rupp, longtime University of Kentucky basketball coach, as president of the American, Basketball Association's Memphis team, rechristened the Tams.

title: Meet an Average Major Leaguer: Dirty Al
description: SAN FRANCISCOIt is an artistic disaster, not much different from painting by the numbers or making plastic flamingos for the front lawn. The baseball comes leaping down the line and the third baseman simply assaults it. He almost hauls it into an alley and mugs it. The basic movement is a sudden lurch forward. Down goes the glove at the last moment to play the short hop. Up comes the ball with a wretched jerk. The throw to first is somewhat similar in style, it seems, to a twohanded push shot.

title: Emerson Fittipaldi Wins British Race
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 15  The British Grand Prix, the first motorcar race with ontrack betting, turned into a real horse race today with the runnerup claiming foul against the unofficial entrymate of the winner.

title: National Medical Information Network Is Set Up to Help Patients and Doctors
description: The first national medical information service to aid in the care of patients and to educate physicians was begun yesterday by a nonprofit private medical society with the approval of the American Medical Association. The national program is patterned after a smaller one run by Dr. Margaret Klapper at the University of Alabama Medical Center in Birmingham, which is becoming increasingly popular among Alabama physicians. Dr. Klapper said that the threeyearold program had grown to the point where Alabama physicians now place 1,000 calls a month to the statesupported school's clinical staff. Questions most often involve cardiology and cancer diagnosis and therapy.

title: ORIOLES CONQUER WHITE SOX, 6 TO 3.
description: BALTIMORE, July 15 (AP)Dave Johnson drove in three runs, two of them with his third homer of the season, to lead Mike Cuellar and the Baltimore Orioles to a 63 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Arthur Robert Taylor, the 37yearold whiz kid who was named president last Wednesday of the Columbia Broadcasting System, quit his first job in broadcasting nearly 20 years ago. His walkout occurred when he was a freshman interviewer on Brown University's radio station, and a student manager tried to limit his editorial freedom.

title: Crawford's Team Triumphs
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., July 15Mr. and Mrs. Harden Crawford of Gladstone, N. J., captured the Mrs. J. Macy Willetts Trophy, emblematic of the best turned out team in the show, today at the first annual Millbrook Hunt driving competition.

title: COMPANY ORDERED TO CUT SUBSIDIARY
description: HONOLULU, July 15 (AP)A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the country's largest operator of independent telephone systems, was in violation of antitrust laws and must divest itself of some of its holdings.

title: Rocks Thrown at Firemen
description: About 25 youths hurled rocks, bottles and debris at firemen working at a burning abandoned building in Brooklyn's East New York section late Friday night, the police reported. Six policemen responded to the fire fighters call for assistance and, in 40 minutes, dispersed the missilethrowing youths and the rest of the crowd of 100 that had gathered to watch the blaze. No one was injured and there were no arrests, police said.

title: Astrophysicist Will Head Brandeis Graduate School
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 15 (AP)  Dr. Jack S. Goldstein, an astrophysicist, was appointed yesterday as dean of Brandeis University's Graduate School of Arts and Science effective Aug. 1.

title: Lawyer With Alto Sax Is Back With First Love
description: BRIELLE  Fifteen years ago, Hugh Porter, then a 26yearold musician and law student, sold his alto saxophone, tenor saxophone and clarinet, and used the proceeds to take the New Jersey Bar examination. It was his way of demonstrating that he had decided to make money.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market declined sharply and broadly last week, maintaining the nervous, erratic pattern that has prevailed for the last two months.

title: Jerome R. Gratry Fiance Of Miss Barbara Bolton
description: MENTOR, Ohio, July 15Mr. and Mrs. Oliver P. Bolton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Bolton of New York, to Jerome R. Gratry, son of Charles P. Gratry of Geneva, Switzerland, and the Baroness Gerard de Thoisy of Paris.

title: Photography
description: A NEW model compact 35mm camera with a 38mm wideangle lens has recently been introduced by Allied Impex Corporation, 168 Glen Cove Road, Carle Place, N. Y. 11514. Called the Miranda Sensoret, this new camera measures only 4 by 2 by 2 inches and weighs only four ounces. It has a fully automatic, computerized CdS exposure system that will handle films rated at from ASA 25 to ASA 800, and features a manual override which permits the user to set the speed at 1/20th of a second, then manually adjust the aperture opening (this setting is also used for flash).

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A national Arbitron survey showed that 36 per cent of the persons watching the Democratic National Convention viewed the proceedings on the Columbia Broadcasting System, 33 per cent on the National Broadcasting Company and 31 per cent on the American Broadcasting Company, C.B.S. reported yesterday.

title: Suspect in Plane Hijacking Attempts to Commit Suicide
description: HOUSTON, July 15 (AP)A 22yearold Ethiopian student arrested Thursday in the hijacking of a National Airlines Boeing 727 attempted to commit suicide last night, the Harris County Sheriff's Office said today.

title: David Corning Iglehart Weds Frances Scarlett
description: GARRISON, Md., July 15Miss Frances Thorpe Scarlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Patterson Scarlett of Owings Mills, was married here this afternoon to David Corning Iglehart, son of Philip L. B. Iglehart of Lake Worth, Fla., and Mrs. Mary Corning Howard of Westbury, L. I. The Rev. George Sinkinson Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Thomas's Episcopal Church.

title: Wallace, in Alabama, Starts Physical Therapy Program
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15, (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace began a monthlong physical therapy program today that will prepare him to be fully independent in his wheelchair.

title: He called the loopholes truckholes
description: Perhaps Paul Douglas never should have left the University of Chicago, where he was a rather good economist and professorbut that would have been too simple. Instead, he provided the Senate with much of its integrity and backbone from 1948 to 1966. In an organization that put a premium on tradition and just getting along, he was an anomaly. That he was elected at all, and thrived on the challenge, says a greatdeal about why this country's political system will survive a few more crises. It made In the Fullness of Time (his memoirs, and his fifteenth book) worth writing and very much worth reading.

title: Rufus Millett, Student, Weds Maria N. West
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 15Miss Maria Newill West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Buell West, was married here this afternoon to Rufus Rand Millett, son of Mrs. Fredrika Rand Millett of Darien and Henry Glover Millett of New York.

title: Expos Edge Dodgers, 32
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 (AP) Boots Day singled home the tiebreaking run in the eighth inning tonight to give the Montreal Expos a 32 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: 2 EXPERTS SAY U.S. DISTORTS JOB DATA
description: Two professors of economics have accused the Federal Govemment of grossly underestimating and misrepresenting the number of unemployed, United Press International reports.

title: Cranis and Raskind Reach State 35er Tennis Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 15Paul Cranis and Dick Raskind reached the final of the New York State tennis championship for men 35 years and over today. They meet at 5 P.M. tomorrow at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: The Ice Cream Man Isn't One
description: FAIRFIELD  When the icecream man cometh, it's not always a man. More and more women are manning icecream vans according to two major vending companies, Good Humor and Pied Piper, whose driversalesmen are landmarks throughout New Jersey this time of the year.

title: Mrs. Monstead and Foshay Named U.S. Golf Captains
description: Nonplaying captains for both the men's and women's United States amateur golf teams in the world championships have been announced by the United States Golf Association.

title: Police Force on Coast Changes Its Image
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., July 15There is no detective bureau in the 35officer Menlo Park Police Department. There are no paramilitary uniforms, no military ranking and no black and white patrol cars.

title: The World
description: MANILAThe mountains of Palanan provide a thickly forested fastness along the northeast coast of Luzon. In the war of 1899 they offered sanctuary from pursuing American troops for the Philippine revolutionary, Emilio Aguinaldo. Today the mountains provide a base for a Communist guerrilla force, the New People's Army (N.P.A.).

title: Criminals At Large
description: Two of the outstanding veterans of mystery fiction are Eric Ambler and John Dickson Carr. Both started in the 1930's, and both are specialists in their fields. Ambler is the master of the spysuspense novel and the novel of location with exotic place names. Carr, a traditionalist, is the exponent of the lockedroom mystery, the hidden clue, the art of misdirection.

title: Shane's Southerly Triumphs In Hempstead Harbor Race
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 15Dale Shane's Southerly captured Ensign class honors this afternoon in the Hempstead Harbor sailing conducted by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

title: Science/Medicine
description: The announcement from Tass, the Soviet news agency, is invariably succinct. An unmanned Cosmos satellite has been launched. Its mission is unspecified. It is to continue space exploration. And the details are only the barest: the orbital track, the time taken for the first revolution of earth, the angle that it crosses the equatornothing more.

title: City's Hospitals Cut Red Tape in Getting Data for Lawsuits
description: A logjam that has held up thousands of medical records needed in lawsuitswhile also delaying payments of hospital billsis being dealt with by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Bergen Family Income Highest
description: Family incomes in the eightcounty metropolitan area of New Jersey close to New York City are highest on the average in Bergen, where 42 per cent of the families topped the $15,000mark in 1970.

title: Leafspot Disease preads
description: ALBANY, July 12  The wet and cold weather of spring and early summer has precipitated a statewide outbreak of leafspot disease, according to the Department of Environmental Protection. Commissionner Henry L. Diamond said that although it was no peril to trees, it does cause unsightly spotting of leaves of hardwood trees, made by fungus. Nothing can be done to stop the problem now, he said, except collecting the leaves in the fall and compositing them to avoid new infection next year.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: No matter what other commodity or food shortage may develop, the world is rich in textile fibers and appears destined to become richer.

title: Mrs. Cynthia Rush Lynch Married
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Mrs. Cynthia Rush Lynch, daughter of Kenneth Rush, Deputy Secretary of Defense, and Mrs. Rush, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Joseph Monahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Patrick Monahan of Southbury, Conn.

title: In France they didn't ask her
description: One of the surest ways to get a book published these days is either to be a celebrity or write about one. As Clifford Irving roved, there can be big money in it if you pick the right celebrity. What's more, the Hughes affair gave birth to two more instant celebritiesNina Van Pallandt and Irving bbnceff, both of whom promptly wrote books.

title: Miss Whitehead Wed To Cecil Hoge Jr. on L.I.
description: WADING RIVER, N. Y., July 15Miss Virginia Whitehead was married here this afternoon to. Cecil Cunningham Hoge Jr. of Wading River, son of Mr. Hoge and the late Mrs. Barbara Shewan Hoge, both of New York and Southampton, L. I.

title: The World
description: PARISWe start once again with good weather, said North Vietnam's spokesman, Nguyen Thanh Le. But this beautiful sun does not shine on any new American proposals, so there is no sunshine in the conference room.

title: Explosion Laid to Separatists Destroys a Swiss Munitions Depots
description: GENEVA, July 16An explosion destroyed an army munitions depot in the Jura region early today, and militant members of a separatist movement among the Frenchspeaking minority in Berne, a predominantly Germanspeaking Swiss canton, were blamed.

title: Children Pay Swimming Tribute to Mao;
description: PEKING, July 16 (Agence FrancePresse)The lakes in Peking's parks were crowded today as thousands of swimmers gathered to commemorate the sixth anniversary of Chairman Mao Tsetung's swim down the Yangtse River at the age of 72.

title: 35 Arrested in Disorder After Festival in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)At least 35 persons were arrested tonight and 19, including three policemen, were injured when an estimated 2,000 persons went on a rockthrowing rampage following a Spanishspeaking festival in the Roxbury section of Boston, the police said. Another report put the number of arrests as high as 50.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Henry J. Heinz concern for better nutrition, if turned to his own industry, could provide a more accurate appraisal of the problem. Attacking natural and organic foods and food faddists, as he did in a recent OpEd article, is to turn the blame away from those who are responsible in the first place.

title: HARRY G. HERMAN, SURROGATE, DEAD
description: NEWTON, Mass., July 16Former Surrogate Harry G. Herman of Westchester County died of a heart ailment Friday on visit here. He was 76 years old and lived at 90 Bryant Avenue in White Plains, N. Y.

title: A KEY GANG FIGURE SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: Thomas Eboli, also known as Tommy Ryan, a top leader of the Mafia in the New York area, was gunned down in traditional gangland fashion early yesterday on a quiet residential street in the Crown Heights district of Brooklyn.

title: Cahill Will Lobby On for Tax Reforms
description: TRENTON, July 16Gov. William T. Cahill intends to increase his lobbying pressure tomorrow on behalf of his $1.8billion taxreform program as the State Assembly returns to vote on key features of the package, but chances of passage appear slim.

title: Wiser Social Security
description: Despite the warnings of White House aides and Republican Congressional leaders that the President would veto a 20 per cent rise in Social Security benefits as inflationary, Congress passed the huge increase and Mr. Nixon rushed to sign itthereby demonstrating that political discretion is the better part of valor in an election year.

title: A.E.C. Official Foresees Some Changes in Safety Criteria for Nuclear Power Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Atomic Energy Commission's first public hearing into the safety of nuclear electricpower reactors, months behind schedule and still grinding on, is likely to produce some changes in the safety criteria but the overall result will be substantially the same, according to a key agency official.

title: Hotel Workers Seeking New Talks on a Contract
description: Fortified by a recent strike authorization, representatives of 26,000 hotel workers are to seek renewed negotiations here this week on a new contract with the 140member Hotel Association of Greater New York.

title: Suburbs Fighting State Agency's Plan to Override Local Zoning
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 16The state's Urban Development Corporation's plan to build 100unit apartment complexes in each of nine Westchester County towns has met with a rising storm of public protest from town supervisors to state legislators to ordinary homeowners.

title: Orantes Tops Nastase in Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 16 (AP)Manuel Orantes of Spain won the $30,000 Swedish international tennis championship today by upsetting Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 64, 63, 61, in the final.

title: Fire Destroys Drug Center
description: SWAN LAKE, N. Y., July 16 (UPI)Daytop Village, a threestory narcotics rehabilitation center in a former resort hotel here, was destroyed today by fire. None of the 100 residents of the onetime Pauls Hotel were injured. The 70yearold structure was once the main building in the resort complex that had been unused by vacationers for several years. Most of the residents were reportedly transferred to another treatment center in Parkville.

title: Congress Resuming Today: War Debate on the Agenda
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The betweenconventions session of Congress opens tomorrow with the Senate debating an endthewar proposal. The Senate is also expected to act on an emergency relief measure to aid victims of floods created by the tropical storm Agnes.

title: A DEPUTY MINISTER IN ISRAEL OUSTED
description: TEL AVIV, July 16The Israeli Government today dismissed a deputy minister who broke coalition discipline in a vote in parliament.

title: Books of The Times
description: When people say they have been helped by traditional psychotherapy, skeptical friends sometimes answer that the same results might have been achieved by talking to anyone with mere common sense. At first glance, Dr. Eric Berne's posthumous What Do You Say After You Say Hello? seems like a compromise between common sense and Freudian therapy.

title: French Influence Pervades Marxist Congo
description: BRAZZAVILLE, CongoThe monuments to General Charles de Gaulle and the French colonial explorer Count Savorgnan de Brazza coexist steadfastly here with an array of MarxistLeninist slogans, photos of Mao Tsetung and red flags with golden star, hammer and hoe.

title: Bridge: Griffin and Lebensold Teams Gain Fun City Regional Final
description: Teams headed by Tom Griffin and Ken Lehensold of New York contested the final of the Fun City Regional Knockout Championship at the. New York Hilton last night.

title: 21 Fire Bombs Found
description: A cardboard box containing 21 beer bottles made into molotov cocktails was found by Northeast Airlines employee at a loading ramp at Kennedy International Airport, shortly before noon yesterday. The police said the beer bottles were partly filled with an inflammable liquid, believed to be gasoline.

title: Analyst Links Inflation to Market Blues
description: William X Scheinman, 45, is a stock market professional who places much emphasis on timing strategy. He now directs institutional services for Arthur Wiesenberger & Co., Inc., brokerdealer firm that is owned by NN Corporation, financial holding company based in Milwaukee. He thinks the stock market is in a declining phase that will not end until 1973. One of the recently suggested sales by his service is the stock of Merrill Lynch. He recommended the sale of airline stocks on May 5. Last week, Gas businessexecLtiveturnedmarketanalyst was interviewed by Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Portions of their conversation follow:

title: Aviator Glasses: The Eyes Have It
description: A middleaged father, or so the story goes, strolled into the living room of his Long Island home recently wearing a pair of rakish aviator glasses with greentinted lenses.

title: N. JEROME SCHULMAN, GYNECOLOGIST, DIES
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 16 Dr. N. Jerome Schulman, director emeritus of the department of obstetrics and gynecology of the New Rochelle Hospital, died yesterday at his home, 17 Split Tree Road. He was 68 years old.

title: Niekro, Demoted, Hurls Perfect Came in Toledo
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 16 (AP)Joe Niekro, who just arrived in Toledo this morning, pitched a perfect nohit, norun game to give the Toledo Mud Hens a 20 victory over the Tidewater Tides today.

title: AutoPollution Curbs May Spur Use of South Africa's Platinum
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 16A contract to supply the Ford Motor Company with platinum for antipollution exhaust gas convertors may be only the beginning of a platinum bonanza for South Africa.

title: Man in the News
description: The election of Patriarch. Dimitrios I as the new spiritual leader of some 250 million Eastern Orthodox Christians throughout the world elevated one of the youngest of the 15 prelates who met to choose a successor to the late Athenagoras I. The 58yearold Dimitrios, who had been elevated to the rank of Metropolitan only five months ago, seemed the least likely of candi dates. Regarded as a mildly liberal theologian in a church noted for its conservatism, Dimitrios has shunned church politics in favor of pastoral duties.

title: N. C. Wyeth 3d, Edith Gluckman Marry on Coast
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 16 Miss Edith Jane Gluckman and Newell Conyers Wyeth 3d were married here last evening at Temple Emanuel by Rabbi David Robins.

title: Lammons Traded to Eagles
description: Pete Lammons, one of the last remaining links with the 1969 Jets team that won the Super Bowl, reported to camp yesterday only to learn that the New Yorkers had traded him to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Eastern Orthodox Church Chooses a New Patriarch
description: ISTANDUI, Turkey. July 16.  Metropolitan Dim itrios, a progressive who became an Archbishop only live months ngo, was elected today to succeed the late Allanagoras I as Patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church.

title: Robert Wagners Remarried
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 16 (AP) Natalie Wood and Robert Wagner were remarried aboard a yacht off the Southern California coast today, friends reported. The 33yearold actress and the 42yearold actor were divorced in 1962. Both were divorced a second time in recent years. Among those at the wedding, aboard the Rambling Rose, were Miss Wood's daughter, Natasha Gregson, 21 months old, and Mr. Wagner's daughter, Katharine, 8.

title: Chilean Communist Wins a Byelection For Federal Seat
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 16Chile's leftwing Government won its first important election victory in more than a year today in a contest for a federal deputy's seat from Coquimbo Province.

title: Bridge: Griffin and Lebensold Teams Gain Fun City Regional Final
description: Teams headed by Tom Griffin and Ken Lehensold of New York contested the final of the Fun City Regional Knockout Championship at the. New York Hilton last night.

title: Reporters Group Opposes Ban on News of Hijackings
description: The New York Reporters Association said yesterday that suppression of news coverage of airplane hijackings would sabotage the public's right to know and might possibly he used by Government officials for selfserving purposes, United Press International reported.

title: F.P.C. Head Says 3 Areas May Face Power Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, pointed today to the Southeast, the Westcentral region centering on Illinois and Iowa and New York City as possible trouble spots for power supplies this summer.

title: VAN BLOM BEATS DIETZ IN SCULLING
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 16Crews from California won four of 11 races today in the 99th annual national rowing championships. As the Schuylkill calmed down with a slight headwind, the University of California at Irvine won both the intermediate pairs and the senior parrs without coxswain.

title: Cape Kennedy Curb Hinted
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 16 (UPI)  Officials at Cape Kennedy said today that they might have to curtail operations at the visitors information center this week because tourists might interfere with normal functions at the space center. A spokesman, Gordon, Harris, said the center handled 8,000 visitors a day last week and the figure could go to 10,000 this week. He said the center might be closed in the afternoons if the visitors began to get in the way of routine activities.

title: Personalities: Nicklaus Hopeful
description: Maybe next year, said Jack Nicklaus. After narrowly missing a victory in the British Open  which would have kept him alive in his attempt to sweep a pro grandslam  he insisted it was still possible for one man to win the United States Open, the Masters, the P.G.A. and the British Open in one year. Not probable, perhaps, he said, but possible. He admitted that he had given up when Saturday's play began. But he tied the course record with a 66 that left him only one stroke behind Lee Trevino, the winner.

title: SAMUEL A. MARKSON
description: Samuel A. Markson, an Albany stockbroker and former news editor of The Albany TimesUnion, where he was a founder of the Albany local of the Newspaper Guild, died yesterday in an Albany nursing home. He was 68 years old and lived in Albany.

title: SOUTH KOREAN CHIEF SEES TRIALS IN PACT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, July 17President Park Chung Hee told his nation today that the recent accord between South and North Korea marked the beginning of new trials and challenges in a long path toward national reunification.

title: Saigon Police Holding Father of Slain Hijacker
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 16 (AP)  The father of a student who was shot to death here after he tried to hijack a jumbo jet is being held by the South Vietnamese police, who refuse to give any season for his detention.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On July 6, another bulletin was released by the National Safety Council listing the number of deaths which had occurred during the threeday holiday weekend; again the total was over 500, the result of automobile accidents.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was 20 years ago, give or take a week, when spectators in Helsinki saw Floyd Patterson leap like a springbok, throw a punch with both feet off the floor, and swat a young man from the Netherlands on the chin. They gathered the Dutchman up in a basket, and Patterson went on to the Olympic championship in the 165pound class. Sixteen years have passed since Floyd won the heavyweight championship of the world as a professional, 13 since he lost the title the first time, 12 since he regained it and since he lost it again. Wearing all his yesterdays like sackcloth, this 37yearold man of peace sat in a windowless room on Long Island the other night saying he now felt sure he would need only two more years to reach his peak as a fighter.

title: Hildegarde Gay Steimle Is a Bride
description: Miss Hildegarde Gay Steimle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas B Steimle of New York and Greensboro, Vt., was married here yesterday afternoon to Harry Frank Grabenstein, son of Mrs. Henry Carl Grabenstein of Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Grabenstein.

title: M'RAE'S AUTO WINS ROAD AMERICA RACE
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 16Graham McRae of Australia won the Road America L&M Continental 5000 championship series race today and gained a commanding lead in the points standing. He has 66 points, 12 more than Sam Posey of Sharon, Conn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Paul S. Grzybek (letter June 20) noted that greater efforts by our legislators are needed to eradicate the drunk driver. And greater efforts are needed to tighten the laws governing the licensing of drivers.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Chorus Getting Louder: Clean Up Times Square
description: To Ruby Keeler, 42d Street near Broadway is a place that used to be wonderful but no longer is. Barbara Barrie sees Times Square as a place where you don't carry money but you do carry a big umbrella, though not for rain.

title: Meat Prices in State Show Rise of 10 to 20c a Pound
description: State price analysts warned three weeks ago that still higher meat prices were likely because prices for most cuts were rising at wholesale.

title: STEEL TO ABSORB WAGE INCREASES
description: PITTSBURGH, July 16, 1972 The Aug. 1 increases in steel labor costs will not have much effect on steel prices.

title: Ghana Says It Aborted A Coap by ExLeader
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 16 (Reuters)  The Government of Ghana announced today that it had foiled a plot to restore a deposed Prime Minister, Kofi A. Bursa, to power.

title: Drug Raid in France
description: MARSEILLES, France, July 16 (APIThe police reported today that they had seized 35 pounds of heroin in a clandestine laboratory near here and had arrested four French drug traffickers. It was the third time this year that the police have found a clandestine laboratory in which morphine base is transformed into heroin, in southern France.

title: Credit Markets
description: The dollar's weakness in overseas currency market of late has produced a sharply improved condition in the market for the United States Treassury's bills and bonds. Foreign central banks, through their operations in supporting the dollar, have purchased with t heir own currencies huge numbers of dollars, many of which are then invested in this country's securities.

title: Halting French ATests
description: The mounting world concern over ecological issues aroused by the Stockholm Conference has led to increased protest, over France's current series of atmospheric nuclear tests in the Pacific, the sixth round since 1966. By releasing almost no information this year beyond the unavoidable warnings to shipping, Paris has indirectly acknowledged the political sensitivity of the issue both at home and abroad.

title: AT THE MARSHALL, ALE'S WELL AGAIN
description: Like members of the wedding, the members of the Marshall Chess Club gathered once again in their old brownstone on West 10th Street yesterday. They were anxious. Would the bridegroom show up?

title: GEORGE B. MORAN JR.
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 16 George B. Moran Jr., a former president of the Tarrytown Board of Education, died Friday in his sleep in Seattle, where he was on a business trip. He was 50 years old and a resident at 150 Harwood Avenue here.

title: Advertising:
description: The Presidential race of 1972 for the first time in memory will not involve a regular advertising agency.

title: M'GRERN FACING TROUBLESOME JOB IN UNIFYING PARTY
description: MIAMI 13 EACH, July l6 Senator George McGovern looked toward an awesome job of party reunification this weekend as the delegates who made him the Democratic Presidential nominee left Florida for It heir homes.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TRENTON, July 16 (AP)Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., won the Northern 300 stock car race at Trenton Speedway today for the first time in six attempts. His 1972 Chevrolet finished 1.4 seconds ahead of obby Isaac's 1972 Dodge in the NASCAR event. Isaac, of Catawba, N. C., led for 117 of the 200 laps around the 1mile asphalt track.

title: Search From Spain Fails To Spot Bermuda Yachts
description: BAYONA, Spain, July 16 (AP)Officials of the Bayona Yacht Club in northwest Spain said today they had not heard from any of the 46 entrants in the 2,700mile BermudatoBayona race.

title: Cycle Rally Erupts
description: ELDERSBURG, Md., July 16 (AP)At least three cyclists were injured and 15 to 20 persons arrested today after a melee broke out at a motorcycle rally on a farm here, the police said. The disorder was said to have started when about 2,500 cyclists were told by rally organizers that the annual event had been canceled because of the crowd's rowdiness.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., July 16 (AP)Bobby Lee Hunter, twice National Amateur Athletic Union flyweight boxing champion, will depart for Fort Worth tomorrow morning enter the boxing trials for the United States Olympic team.

title: Opera: Aspiring Salzburg of Rockies
description: CENTRAL, CITY. Colo., July 16Nathaniel Merrill had a problem, he recalls. When I told people here I wanted to bring in Falstaff for the opera season, somebody said, that's a beer, isnt it?  Mr. Merrill, the veteran Metropolitan Opera stage director who took over as artistic director of the Central City Opera this season had in mind the Verdi opera. Falstaff, in spite of its acknowledged masterpiece status, is still something of a connoisseur's item even in the great houses of the world.

title: 2,400 Foreign Students Meet On L.1. Alter a Year in the U.S.
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., July 16 They wore blue jeans and bell bottoms, Smile Tshirts and football jerseys, headbands and long hair and even Texasstyle cowboy hats. They were 2,400 foreign students from 64 countries who gathered here last Wednesday at Lawrence High School for a final briefing before departing for their homelands after a year's stay with families throughout the United States.

title: East Side Drive First
description: KINNELON, N. J., July 16Pat Byrne rode Dr. John Abbott's East Side Drive to victory in two of the three classes to score 10 points and win the open jumper championship today at the Smoke Rise Horse Show.

title: Eboli Is 15th Gangland Victim in a Year
description: The slaying of Thomas Eboli early yesterday in Brooklyn was at least the 15th ganglandstyle murder in New York City since Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was wounded and incapacitated in the early moments of the ItalianAmerican civil rights rally he had organized in Columbus Circle on June 28, 1971.

title: COLBERT GETS 69 TO WIN WITH 271
description: MILWAUKEE, July 16 (UPI) Jim Colbert, his putter working to perfection, broke from a tightly bunched field with a twounderpar 69 today to win the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open tournament.

title: MRS. FRANK H. PARCELLS
description: Mrs. Elise Post Hoxie Parcells, widow of Municipal Court Justice Frank Howland Parcells, died yesterday in Kings County Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived at 270 Jay Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The increasing use of express buses into Manhattan raises major problems at this time. On July 20 the Board of Estimate has scheduled hearings on the first two of a number of applications for tenyear franchises for express bus routes.

title: FOE OF BOYLE OPENS HIS U.M.W. CAMPAIGN
description: HARLAN, Ky., July 16 (UPI) Arnold Miller opened today his campaign against W. A. Boyle for the United Mine orkers presidency.

title: PUBLIC LINKS TITLE IS WON BY ALLARD
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 16 (AP)Bob Allard, a 23yearold player from Portland, Ore., shot a steady oneoverpar 71 today to win the 47th annual national public links tournament.

title: Oldies Are the New Sound As Radio Turns Nostalgic
description: CHICAGO, July 16 The airwaves over many American cities are fast filling with vintage rock n roll, the clangorous, often nonsensical sounds that ushered an earlier generation of teenagers into adulthood and their parents into seclusion.

title: Julie Eisenhower Better
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Julie Eisenhower will need several more days of bed rest at the White House before she completely recuperates from viral pneumonia, a spokesman said today. On Thursday, Mrs. Eisenhower's temperature was running between 101 and 102.She is getting better, her cough is breaking up but she will need several more days to recuperate, the White House spokesman reported.

title: Shellfish in the Chesapeake Bay Are Periled by Effects of Storm
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Scores of fishermen are out of work and the Chesapeake Bayi remains closed to commercials shellfish harvesting as a result of en abrupt ecological upset caused by the tropical storm Agnes more than three weeks ago.

title: SOVIET EXCERPTS ARTICLE ON JEWS
description: MOSCOW, July 16A widely read Soviet magazine this weekend reprinted parts of an American article on the problems faced by Soviet Jews in Israel in what appeared to be an attempt to discourage wouldhe emigrants.

title: FLOOD FREE JOHNSTOWN PENNA
description: FLOOD FREE JOHNSTOWN PENNA

title: Marine Midland Elects
description: Edgar J. Roberts, Jr., has been elected executive vice president of Marine Midland BankNew York and will head the bank's international banking department upon his return from Sydney, Australia, in September. Presently in charge of Marine Midland's far eastern region, Mr. Roberts joined the bank in 1963.

title: The Arab Portrayed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.To those Arabs who follow the American scene, Presidential elections are a time of soulsearching and even bewilderment. As election time draws nearer and campaign rhetoric approaches astounding dimensions, political hopefuls of virtually every persuasion scramble for the perennial football of antiArabism, in the form of onesided support for Israel.

title: COUNCIL IN LIBYA FORMS A CABINET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16A new Libyan Cabinet was announced today but there was no mention in it of Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the chairman of the ruling Revolutionary Command Council.

title: Huntington Wins in Polo From Bethpage Team, 75
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 16Paul Rizzo scored three goals and Fred Braunstein two as Huntington defeated Bethpage, 75, today in the Long Island Polo League opener at BethState Park.

title: Lake Constance Is Dying at a Rapid Rate
description: LANGENARGEN, West Germany  Laboratory experiments recently showed that Lake Constance, the main water reservoir for two to three million people, has aged biologically as much in the last two decades as in the previous 12,000 years.

title: 2 Wild Throws by Mets Forge 73 Padre Victory
description: SAN DIEGO, July 16The Mets, whose hitting attack makes wishywashy Charlie Brown look like a .400 hitter, might be wise to follow San Diego's batting strategy and bunt.

title: PESTHY KEEPS LEAD IN PENTATHLON TRIAL
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 16 (AP)Paul Pesthy of Binghamton, N. Y., held on to the lead in the modern pentathlon Olympic trials, placing second in the fencing event today.

title: PRISON RIOT ENDS ON MANDEL'S PLEA
description: JESSUP, Md., July 16 prison riot that broke out late last night was settled today after about 250 surrounded inmates were persuaded by Gov. Marvin Mandel to return to their cells.

title: The Patient and the Nurse
description: An acquaintance, a New York abortion counselor, telephoned me. I had just arrived home from my job as a nurse in a large Catholic hospital, where, ironically, nurses aren't allowed to teach patients methods of birth control (except rhythm), and doctors are forbidden to prescribe contraceptives or birth control pills.

title: FOX TERRIER BEST AT TWIN BROOKS
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 16 The topwinning wire fox terrier in England in 1970, Ch. Littleway Haranwal Barrister, owned by Mrs. Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N. J., took the top award today among 1,535 dogs at the Silver Anniversary show of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club on The Mall.

title: Arts Abroad
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastThe universality of man, Michel Kodjo teaches in both his work and in the classroom, can be found in nommonplace themes of village life in Africa.

title: Freedom Alert
description: The Association of American Publishers is holding an emergency meeting here today to build a united front of book publishers against an attempt by the Federal Government to investigate the Unitarian Universalist Church and to prosecute its subsidiary, Beacon Press, for publishing Senator Mike Gravel's version of the Pentagon Papers.

title: Thomas A. Campbell, 75, Dies; A Retired Anaconda Executive
description: Thomas A. Campbell, former vice president for Latin American affairs of the Anaconda Company, died here Saturday. He was 75 years old and lived at 20 Sutton Place South.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On June 13 there was an article by John D. Morris on unit pricing which expressed some wonder about consumer indifference to unit pricing. This buying guide, in my opinion, would be used more widely if it were made more accessible. The tiny print and obscure abbreviations make the edgeofshelf labels either confusing or so easy to overlook completely that most consumers are unaware of unit pricing.

title: Nixon and Japan Hail U.S. Sumo Wrestler
description: NAGOYA, Japan, July 16A strapping 365pound American from Hawaii, Jesse Kuhaulua was the victor today in the summer sumo tournament here and became the first foreigner to win Japan's ancient, ritualistic wrestling tourney.

title: State to Bring Antitrust Suit Against Mobil Oil Company
description: The Mobil Oil Company, the largest gasoline distributor in the New York Metropolitan area, will face antitrust action by the state this week for alleged price discrimination and price fixing, a spokesman for the state Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: The chief strategist of George McGovern's Presidential campaign in New York State predicted yesterday that the Senator would defeat President Nixon by a 750,000vote margin in the state in November double Hubert H. Humphrey's edge four years ago.

title: Oldak Triumphs by 6 Minutes In Soling Class at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 Half of yesterday's winners, who sailed in the brisk opener of Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week, found today's quieter air just as rewarding and added second victory to their records. But the cruising class came upon a stultifying morning and went home without a race to talk about.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ARLINGTON, Tex. July 16 (UPI)The Texas Rangers have announced that because of excessive heat here during the daylight hours, the starting time of all their Sunday twilight games has been moved back from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. during July and August.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Rev. Robert R. Parks, recently installed rector of historic Trinity Church at Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday named a fiveman management team to administer the 275yearold Episcopal parish, including its vast real estate holdings, estimated to exceed $47million.

title: Roundup: As Giusti Goes, So Go World Champions
description: When Dave Giusti is well, the Pittsburgh Pirates are better. That was evident yesterday as the Pirates won doubleheader from the Houston Astros by identical 32 scores in Pittsburgh and Giusti got his 13th save in the second game. The first game went 10 innings, and Giusti won it in relief.

title: WorkRelief Draws Mixed Reactions
description: Scrubbing graffiti off subway station walls. Snipping the ragged grass at the edge of Parks Department tennis courts. Running off Xerox copies of documents or mopping ferryboat decks or filing correspondence or running messages.

title: How New a Party?
description: MIAMI BEACH  Senator George McGovern has not merely captured a nomination. He has conquered a party.

title: GunRunning Case In U. S. Embitters I.R.A. Supporters
description: The Federal Government has embarked on an investigation of certain IrishAmericans who, it strongly implies, may have allowed their enthusiasm for the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army to carry them beyond legal fundraising and Into Illegal gunrunning.

title: Tanaka Gives a Sense of Vigor In First Days at Japan's Helm
description: TOKYO, July 16  Kakuci Tanaka, Japan's new Premier, has lived up to his reputation of being a man of action during his first 10 days in office. As a result, press and public are hailing the new image that he is giving the Government.

title: S.I. Cricketers Beaten
description: The Guyana Cultural Association defeated the Staten Island Cricket Club's B team by 10 wickets yesterday at Walker Park in Staten Island.

title: Soviet to Try Activist Jew On DraftEvasion Charges
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)The Soviet Government has denied an appeal for the dismissal of draftevasion charges against a Soviet Jew who married an American woman, and will put him on trial July 26, an American lawyer reported today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STANTON, Del., July 16 (AP)Light Hearted beat nine other 3yearold fillies today for her sixth straight triumph in winning the $56,550 Delaware Oaks at Delaware Park. Eldon Nelson rode the Christiana Stables horse to a 1:49 3/5 clocking in the 1mlle race.

title: A's Down Yankees, 52, Sweeping 4Game Set
description: The Oakland Athletics completed a sweep of the fourgame series with the New York Yankees yesterday with a 52 triumph at Yankee Stadium. The A's, playing efficiently with the result hardly in doubt, showed why they have the season's best record in the American League.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It was curious to see The Times describe a danger in the degradation of education (The New Barbarians), for this has been an object of conservative criticism for years.

title: 70 Missing Off Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 16 (Reuters)About 70 Nigerian men, women and children are feared dead after a violent storm struck their fishing fleet near the Cameroon border, official sources in Port Harcourt said today.

title: Political Dispute Perils Funds For Mississippi Health Facility
description: MOUND BAYOU, Miss., July 15  A political dispute over $5.5million is threatening the existence of a widely acclaimed Government health program for the poor in this allblack Delta town of 2,200 persons.

title: Gypsum Cargo Is an Edgewater First
description: Edgewater, N. J., for years a quiet backwater for commerce in the port, has scored an impressive shipping first  the berthing of the largest dry bulk carrier to enter the harbor carrying the largest cargo of gypsum rock.

title: NEW GARMENTS TO RESIST FLAMES
description: Preparations for offering consumers flameretardant sleepwear are well under way and the transition to garments meeting the new government standards should proceed smoothly although slowly.

title: Mrs. Ginsburg Rewed
description: Mrs. Gertrude Ginsburg of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., widow of Robert Ginsburg, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Martin Grunberg of New York, a widower who is a dentist here. State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Barshay performed the ceremony in the SherryNetherland.

title: Posters Chart Campaign Roads to the White House
description: A prostrate Abraham Lincoln, in a poster for the election campaign of 1860, is carried by his supporters into building marked Insane Asylum, with the legend underneath reading: The Republican Party Going to the Right House.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
