description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, said today that he hoped tp meet this week with George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: LSD TRIP DRIVER RELEASED ON BAIL
description: A motorist accused of leading the police on a 26mile chase through Manhattan streets early Saturday morning while under the influence of LSD has been released in $2,500 bail in Criminal Court.

title: Settlement Houses Veer From Tradition, Put Minorities in Key Posts and Take Active Role in Politics
description: To Petra Valentine, the University Settlement House, with its imposing stone and brick Victorian bulk, is the castlethe only building on the Lower East Side that will not crumble on our heads. The only place I know where my three children will be safe.

title: Test Finds I.Q.'s Can Be Lifted for Children of Retarded
description: MILWAUKEE, July 16 Can the children of intellectually retarded mothers be taught enough in their first five years to prevent them from becoming intellectually retarded, too?

title: Personal Finance
description: Women were the winners in two recent decisions by the United States Tax Court. In one case the judges reflected favorably on the 5050 help a farm wife in Indiana gave her husband, and she won a $1,870 tax deficiency battle with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: The Weekly Allowance for Children May Be a Dying Tradition
description: Allowances for children, like other Hallowed family institutions, are far less sanctified than they were a generation ago.

title: People's Party Bloc Votes Not to Support Dr. Spock
description: MIAMI, July 16 (AP)People's party delegates from eight Southern states voted today not to back Dr. Benjamin Spock as the party's Presidential candidate, and threw their support to the Democratic nominee, Senator George McGovern.

title: 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) President Nixon's top campaign organizers expressed concern in television interviews today that militant demonstrators would disrupt the Republican National Convention in August at Miami Beach and make it difficult to have our convention in peace.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: William Shannon, in his July 2 column The New Barbarians, upbraids the academic community for failing to teach what a collegeeducated person should know. For some odd reason, however, he neglects to tell us why his curricular prescriptions are desirable, nor indeed does he give us any idea of what he feels a college education is for. Mr. Shannon is apparently of the old school which believes that adults possess the wisdom of the world and young people need only plug into it to be educated. Unfortunately, that idea held sway well before Charles Eliot, Mr. Shannon's fall guy.

title: State to Investigate Ways To Limit Electricity Use
description: The state's Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would conduct an investigation far beyond anything we've ever done into how the Consolidated Edison Company will produce electricity in the coming decade and how New York City consumers will use it.

title: BOAC Strike Called Off
description: LONDON, July 16 (Reuters) Cabin crews of the British Overseas Airways Corporation tonight called off a threatened strike that would have grounded all flights effective early tomorrow. Representatives of the 2,500 stewards and stewardesses voted overwhelmingly to accept a new pay offer made earlier today by management.

title: A GANG FIGURE DIES IN JERSEY HOSPITAL
description: NEW SRUNSWICK, N. J., July 16 (AP)An alleged loan shark and convicted gambler Anthony (Nino) Interdonato, died today of gunshot wounds suffered last month.

title: Crenshaw Conquers Cain In TransMississippi Golf
description: DALLAS, July 16 (AP)Ben Crenshaw methodically wore down 36yearold John Paul Cain to win, 4 and 3, today in the 36hole TransMississippi championship round.

title: LEONARD VICTOR IN MICHIGAN 200
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 16 Joe Leonard, the defending United States Auto Club champion, won the Michigan 200 race today by a lucky break on the nexttolast lap, moving up front as the leader, Mel Kenyon, ran out of fuel.

title: MICKELSON QUITS MEDIASTUDY UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Sig Mickelson, a former president of C.B.S. News, said today he was resigning as director of the nonprofit, nonpartisan American Institute for Political Communication, He gave as his reason dissatisfaction with the methods used by the institute in releasing the results of a study charging the three television networks with a significant degree of bias in their news reporting.

title: ULSTER VIOLENCE SHOWS NO LETUP; 36 DEAD IN WEEK
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 16 Five more violent deaths in Northern Ireland today brought to 36 the number of people killed in the province since the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army ended a brief ceasefire last Sunday.

title: Accounting Group, After Long Search, Appoints Executive
description: The 85,000 member American Institute of Certified Public Accountants disclosed here yesterday that it had appointed Wallace E. Olson, 51year old executive partner of the accounting firm of Alexander Grant & Co., as the institute's new executive vice president.

title: Rules on Air Strikes in South Vietnam Allow Leeway
description: Rules on Air Strikes in South Vietnam Allow Leeway

title: MINDANAO VICTOR IN HUNTERS CLASS
description: SAGAPONECK, L. I., July 16 Mindanao, a smartstepping 5yearold gray gelding owned and ridden by Richard Hazard, won his third straight title today when he captured the green working hunter championship at the Southampton Horse Show. The event was held at the Topping Horse Farm.

title: Fischer Presses His Lead As 3d Game Is Adjourned
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 16 Bobby Fischer canceled reservations on a flight to New York and, at the last minute today, decided to play the scheduled third game of his world championship chess match with Boris Spassky. The game was adjourned after five hours in a position favorable to the American challenger.

title: Walker Wins U.S. Title
description: ATLANTA, July 16 (AP)A British player, Ross Walker, defeated Jim Delaney of Potomac, Md., 62, 76, 67, 64, today to capture the men's title in the national amateur claycourt tennis championships.

title: Agostini Wins Vienna Race
description: VIENNA, July 16 (AP) Giacomo Agostini of Italy scored his 95th victory in Grand Prix motorcycle racing by winning the 500cubic centimetere world championship event today. Agostini rode his MV Augusta over the 113 miles in 1 hour 7 minutes, beating Jack Findlay of Australia, on a Jada, by two minutes.

title: LOUIS GREENBLATT, REALTY LAWYER, 66
description: WOODMERE, L.I., July 16Louis Greenblatt, a senior partner specializing in realestate law in the New York firm of Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon & Kaplan, died yesterday of a heart attack while golfing at the Woodmere Country Club. He was 66 years old and lived at 43 Willow Road.

title: Harrod's Updates Decor To Move With the Times
description: The famed Harrod's Bank of London in Harrod's is being moved upstairs in favor of large retail cosmetics department, The Perfumery, aimed at fashionconscious women and American tourists.

title: West German Racer Killed
description: BRNO, Czechoslovakia, July 16 (Reuters)  HansJuergen Cusnig, a 22yearold West German, was killed in a crash in the Czechoslovak Motorcycle Sidecar Grand Prix today. Race officials said his B.M.W. machine went out of control on the second lap.

title: U.S. AGENCY SCANS BROKERAGE. DEAL
description: The Department of Justice is looking into the proposed merger of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis with Shearson, Hammill & Co. to determine whether a consolidation of the two big Wall Street houses would reduce competition in the securities industry.

title: Wide Organizing Drive Charted By New Chief of Textile Union
description: Sol Stetin, the energetic and enthusiastic new president of the Textile Workers Union of America, says he plans to make organizing unorganized workers in the South and elsewhere his highest priority.

title: Cranis Defeats Raskind
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., uly 16Paul Cranis fought back from a set down and 03 to beat Dick Raskind, 5.7, 64, 61, in the final of the New York State championship for men 35 years and over today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Cosmos, Montreal In 22 Stalemate; Atlanta Triumphs
description: The New York Cosmos moved closer to a North American Soccer League playoff [berth last night by tying the Montreal Olympics, 22, in Montreal, while the Atlanta Chiefs defeated the St. Louis Stars, 10, in Atlanta to complicate the Southern Division race.

title: Ballet Theater's Giselle and Sylphide Given With Fidelity to Romantic Period
description: Over the years the American Ballet Theater has acquired a special way with the Romantic ballet classics. It gives both Bournonville's La Sylphide and Perrot's Giselle with the correct understated authority of style and precision.

title: GEORGE K. FITCH
description: George K. Fitch, an industry adviser for the Agency for International Development and its predecessors, died Saturday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was 58 years old and had made his home here between overseas posts.

title: and Tax Load
description: The payroll taxes that finance Social Security are regressivethey bear down hardest on the working poor and nearpoor. Lowincome workers pay much higher proportions of their total incomes in payroll taxes than do people with larger salaries and extra returns from property. In addition, most economists believe that employers as well as employes contributions really come out of workers pay checks; together these will now climb to a total of 11 per cent of the value of the pay checks themselves.

title: RentRise Notices Confuse and Anger City Tenants in Controlled Apartments
description: Notices requiring 15 per cent increases on rentcontrolled apartments as of July 1 have caused mass confusion and anger among 400,000 New York City tenants.

title: Accord Is Reached In Footwear Suit
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)The Justice Department announced over the weekend an agreement to settle a Government antitrust suit filed earlier this month against two manufacturers of rubbercanvas footwear. The department said it had reached agreement in principle with the B, F. Goodrich Company, the Converse Rubber Corporation, and Eltra Corporation, which owns Converse, on a proposed consent decree.

title: A.E.C. Official Foresees Some Changes in Safety Criteria for Nuclear Power Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Atomic Energy Commission's first public hearing into the safety of nuclear electricpower reactors, months behind schedule and still grinding on, is likely to produce some changes in the safety criteria but the overall result will be substantially the same, according to a key agency official.

title: Robert Stevens, 65, Dies; A Financier and Investor
description: Robert Livingston Stevens, a financier and real estate investor, died Saturday at his home, 201 East 62d Street. He was 65 years old.

title: How New a Party?
description: MIAMI BEACH  Senator George McGovern has not merely captured a nomination. He has conquered a party.

title: Colon Wins by 300 Yards In Bronx 5,000Meter Run
description: Tony Colon, a Manhattan College sophomore, won the Harvey Lichtenstein Memorial senior 5,000meter run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The 20yearold Colon turned in a courserecord time of 15 minutes 11.8 seconds in beating Phil Bonfiglio of the Long Island Athletic Club by 300 yards. Bonfiglio's time was 16:02.

title: Report Shows Wide Differences Among AutoInsurance Rates
description: Automobile owners can save up to 50 per cent on their insurance in New York State by shopping around for their auto liability policy, the State InsuranceDepartment said in a preliminary report released yesterday.

title: SHOP TALK
description: What makes Gerda Clark's rooms at Abraham & Straus once again the most believable in town are the several approaches she takes to a problem that is common to almost every home.

title: Heinie Benkert, 71, Played Halfback for Giants in 20's
description: ORANGE, N.J., July 16 (AP) Henry (Heinie) Benkert, halfback in the 1920's for the New York Giants football team, died here yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Jane Marie Giegengack Is Wed To R.I. White, Fellow Teacher
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 16Miss Jane Marie Giegengack and Robert John White, members of the classics faculty at Hunter College and recipients of doctorates in classics from Yale University, were married here this afternoon in the Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle. The Rev. John V. Strong performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: SECRET VOLUMES AT ISSUE IN TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 16The United States Government is seeking to avoid diplomatic embarrassment as a result of the Pentagon papers trial, through an effort to introduce four stillclassified volumes of the topsecret study into evidence but still keep them sealed from the public.

title: B52's Bomb North of DMZ Against Reported Troop Shifts
description: SAIGON. South Victnzm, Monday. July 17 (AP)Unitcd States B52 bombers attacked North Vietnamese bases and reinforcements on both sides of the demilitarized zone yesterday and today in some of the heaviest raids of the war.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 (AP)Andres Gimeno of Spain beat Adriano Panatta of Italy, 75, 98, 64, in the final of the Swiss international tennis championship today.

title: Advertising:
description: As a direct result of the financial failure of Lennen & Newell, the American Association of Advertising Agencies will bolster its financial consultation and education service to its members and mount a public relations effort aimed at telling the media and advertisers about the industry's good credit record.

title: Miss Gonnerman Victor
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 16Topseeded Louise Gonnerman of River Edge won the New Jersey State women's singles championship today with a 61, 76 victory over Mimi Nanarelt of New York at the East Orange Tennis Club.

title: CHARLES A. O'NEIL
description: Charles J. O'Neil, a senior vice president of Duff & Phelps, Inc., a Chicago securities company, and a nationally known authority on utility ratesetting, died yesterday of cancer in Lake Forest, Ill. His age was 72.

title: Julie Eisenhower Better
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Julie Eisenhower will need several more days of bed rest at the White House before she completely recuperates from viral pneumonia, a spokesman said today. On Thursday, Mrs. Eisenhower's temperature was running between 101 and 102.She is getting better, her cough is breaking up but she will need several more days to recuperate, the White House spokesman reported.

title: Small LeftWing Party in Italy Votes Merger With Communists
description: ROME, July 16The eight andahalf yearold Italian Proletarian Socilist parly voted today to merge with the Italian Communist party.

title: MRS. STANLEY RICHTER
description: Mrs. Irene Untermyer Myers Richter, a philanthropist and daughter of the late Samuel Untermyer, a wellknown lawyer, died Saturday at her home, 1040 Fifth Avenue. She was 87 years old.

title: Heine Was Wrong: He Got No Monument
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, July 12I shall probably become one of the number of those noblest and greatest men of Germany who go to their graves with a broken heart and a torn coat. In Dilsseldorf they will then probably build me a monument.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., July 16Nancy Baroody of Lakeville, Conn., scored a double at the West Hartford Rotary Horse Show today by riding Belle Ami to the largepony hunter championship with 18 points and piloting War Dress to the junior working hunter title with 13. The show was held on the grounds of the Farmington Valley Polo Club.

title: Eboli Showed a Fiery Temper, But He Had No Feuds or Fear
description: In the last months of his life, hotheaded Thomas Eboli showed no fear of being killed despite the recent rash of gangland slayings, wellplaced informants said yesterday.

title: Fischer Turns Unorthodox Move Into an Attack
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 16 For the second time in two games, the American challenger for the world chess title has made a move that set matchwatchers on their ear.

title: Pulp and Paper Industry Is Taking a Bullish Outlook
description: After more than a year of pretty rough sledding, the pulp and paper industry is seeing brighter times ahead.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 16 (AP)A French boat, Toucan, made port today, the first in the under35foot class to finish tne transAtlantic singlehanded yacht race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In a July 8 letter headed McGovern's Stance on Israel, Dr. Ehud Sprinzak of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem writes:

title: 9 Hurt in Raid on Gang's Dance; Rival Bronx Group Is Suspected
description: Nine young people were superficially wounded early yesterday when, the police said, about 10 members of the Black Spades, a street gang, attacked a rival gang's storefront clubhouse in the Bronx and fired two shotgun blasts through the closed front door.

title: Syria, Iraq in Pipeline Pact
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July 16 (UPI)Syria has agreed to let Iraq pump crude oil through Syrian territory to Mediterranean terminals, the official Syrian press agency said today. On June 1, Iraq nationalized the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company and Syria immediately seized control of the pipelines the company used to pump oil to the sea.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Tariff Commission, reversing a recent trend, voted today in two antidumping cases that the domestic industries involved were not being injured, meaning that no special dumping duties will be imposed.

title: Market Place Ups and Downes Ina Prospectus
description: The name is Downe Communications, Inc., and its mastheads include such oldline publishing names as Ladies Home Journal, American Home and Family Weekly.

title: The Ecstasy of Orchids in the People's Republic
description: CANTON, ChinaThe Cultural Revolution is over yet not over; it has changed many things; it is now in stage which I can best describe as mature assessment.

title: Rep. Ford Has Operation
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, has had an operation to correct a knee injury he suffered as a center for the University of Michigan football team, his office said today. Mr. Ford appeared on the House floor on crutches as Congress returned from a twoweek recess.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Israel's refusal to release Lebanese and Syrian officers.

title: Ruptured Blood Vessels Caused Death of 2 Horses
description: Autopsies performed on two harness horses who dropped dead last Saturday night at Monticello (N. Y.) Raceway, indicated that each pacer died of, ruptured blood vessels, the New York State Harness Racing Commission announced yesterday.

title: EARNINGS COB AT MAJOR BANKS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, San Francisco, and the Continental Illinois Corporation respectively the parent companies of the nation's largest and ninthlargest banksreported higher earnings yesterday for the second quarter and first half of 1972.

title: England Staves Off Defeat Sy Aussies in Test Cricket
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 17 (Reuters)Brian Luckhurst helped England save the third cricket test against Australia at Trent Bridge today.

title: Guatemalans, 3 Unquiet Weeks After Assassination, Say Land Is Peaceful
description: GUATEMALA, July 16  A visitor casually reading Guatemalan newspapers in the last week noted that a 14yearold girl had been strangled, a man murdered with a machete, two farm workers blown up by a hand grenade thrown at them, and a number of other residents stabbed, kicked, robbed or kidnapped.

title: 900 Attica Inmates Stay in Their Cells To Protest a Layoff
description: ATTICA. N. Y., July 17 (AP) About 900 inmates at the $tate Correctional Facility here refused to leave their cells today, but created no disorder. According to Ernest L. Montayne, superintendent of the prison. Mr. Montayne said the prisoners were primarily protesting the layoff of a temporary nurse hired after last September's riot in which 43 persons died. The superintendent said that the inmates also claimed some of the demands they made last September had not been fulfilled.

title: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT

title: T.W.A. Seals Jet Exit Favored by Hijackers
description: In an effort to discourage hijackers, Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it had permanently sealed the rear exit doors in all 72 of its 727jet passenger planes.

title: Alcoholism, Now Viewed as a Disease, Stirs Researchers
description: In a tiny bedroom at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn a 34yearold alcoholic drinks two and a half ounces of bourbon every two hours. Through earphones he listens to a series of clicks while electrodes taped to his scalp monitor the responses of his brain to the sounds.

title: $1.5Billion in Aid to Elderly Approved by House, 351 to 3
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) A $1.5billion, threeyear program of aid for the elderly was approved today by the House and sent to the Senate.

title: Repugnant Oath
description: A Federal district judge has removed an unnecessary and to some a deeply offensiveencumbrance to foreign travel by ruling unconstitutional the oath of allegiance required for a United States passport.

title: EBOLI CHAUFFEUR BEING QUESTIONED
description: The burly chauffeur who was with Thomas Eboli when he was murdered told the police yesterday that shots from passing truck had killed the gangland chieftain as he was about to reenter his blue Cadillac after making a midnight visit in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: NADER SAYS DEFECT IN FORDS KILLED 6
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Ralph Nader's Center for Auto Safety said today it had uncovered six deaths and 29 injuries due to accidents that drivers attributed to the failure of a wheel linkage in 19651969 fullsize Fords.

title: Community Corporations To Elect Directors Today
description: Elections of hoards of directors for nine of the city's 26 community corporations will be held today, with the results expected to effect significantly the future of the antipoverty program in two Bronx areas.

title: Munson Signs With Lions As Their No. 2 Quarterback
description: DETROIT, July 17 (UPI)Bill Munson, a reserve quarter back, today ended a long holdout and signed a fouryear contract with the Detroit Lions.

title: Percentage of Families At Seven Income Levels
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The following chart, derived from Census Bureau statistics, shows the percentage of American families at different income levels. The 1966 figures, which give a fiveyear comparison, have been adjusted to constant, or 1971, dollars to offset the effects of inflation.

title: PRICES ON AMEX STAGE A RETREAT
description: The upturn late last week on the American Stock Exchange shares was shortlived; and shares resumed their decline yesterday, taking the index down to 26.80, off 0.15.

title: Sale of Home Mortgages Scheduled by Ginny May
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (Reuters)  The Government National Mortgage Association said today it would auction $240million of subsidized home mortgages, at a rate of 7 per cent, on July 27.

title: Nixon Asks Grants and Loans to Storm Victims
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17President Nixon asked Congress today to enact within a week legislation that would provide cash grants and easyterm loans for victims of Tropical Storm Agnes.

title: COMMUNIST VICTORY HAILED BY ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 17 The leftwing Government of Chile hailed today as a great political victory the election of a Communist as a provincial federal deptuy, despite a significant loss of votes to the Opposition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In response to C. L. Sulzberger's July 9 column, The Red Hand of Ulster, may I ask if his assertion that in the South, Protestants are secondclass citizens; in the North, Catholics are secondclass citizens means that the Irish Republic's Deputy Prime Minister (Childers) and Ambassador to Washington (Warnock) are secondclass citizens because they are Protestants?

title: PENALTIES ARE STIFF IN THIEU'S DECREE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (UPI)President Nguyen Van Thieu's new martiallaw decree provides jail terms for strikers, curfew violators and agitators, and allows the police to shoot to kill motorists who disregard orders to halt, the Government press agency said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a June 8 letter to the United States Consulate General in Jerusalem, Ludwig Bravmann of New York asked for confirmation or denial of statements attributed by Norman Dacey to this office. The circumstances of the consulate general's contacts with Mr. Dacey are as follows:

title: Ford Stands Behind Account
description: WASHINGTON, July 17A spokesman for Representative Ford said that the Republican leader's statement, made at joint news conference July 8, accurately reflected what was told to Mr. Ford and Representative Boggs during their talks with high Chinese leaders.

title: Drinan to Seek 2d Term
description: BOSTON, July 17 (UPI)Representative Robert F. Drinan, Massachusetts Democrat who is the only Roman Catholic priest in Congress, announced yesterday that he would seek election to a second term.

title: PRITCHARD VICTOR IN BLUEJAY CLASS
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17  There was barely enough wind for sailboat racing on Long Island Sound today, but just enough of it to give a nearrecord Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week junior fleet of 282 a full complement of races.

title: Cherokee's Time Good
description: LAHAINA, Hawaii, July 17 (AP)The 32foot sloop Cherokee of Seattle crossed the finish line today and is expected to become overall winner of the transPacific race from Victoria, British Columbia. Officials said that Cherokee had a corrected time of nine days three hours 52 minutes. This is more than 11 hours under the corrected time for Odusa, the 53foot ketch which was first to finish Saturday.

title: Mansfield Won't Ask McGovern for Advice
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)The Senate Democratic ieader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today that he had not and did not intend to consult the party's Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern, about the Senate's legislative program.

title: Notes on People
description: Male chauvinism, and possibly organized crime, were dealt another blow with the announcement that for the first time in its Gman dominated history, the Federal Bureau of Investigation had accepted two women in its special agent training program, one a former marine, the other a former nun.

title: Body Found in Teaneck Said To Be a Federal Fugitive's
description: WEST TRENTON, N. J., July 17 (UPI)The body of a young man found earlier this month stuffed in a steel barrel submerged in Bergen County's Overpeck Creek was identified here today as that of a 22yearold fugitive wanted on theft, charges.

title: PLATINUM PRICE RISES TO LIMIT
description: Platinum futures attracted some busy trading yesterday and during an active session on the New York Mercantile Exchange the January contract rose the limit of $10 an ounce. It closed at $161.50 an ounce, after being as high as $163.50 an ounce.

title: BRITISH OFFERING A TROOP PULLOUT IN BELFAST AREA
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 17  British troops and snipers exchanged gunfire today as William Whitelaw, Ulster's British administrator, applied delicate pressures on the Roman Catholic community.

title: U.S. Reports 300Man Cut In Forces in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP)  American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week to 47,200, the United States command reported today.

title: RESERVE APPROVED MONEYGROWTH LAG
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided in April to seek a slower growth in the monetary aggregates even at the cost of some rise in shortterm interest rates, it was disclosed today.

title: Chinese Disown Chou Statement As Related by Boggs and Ford
description: PEKING, July 17 (Agence FrancePresse)Reliable Chinese sources today categorically denied statements by two United States Congressional leaders that China desired continued American presence in the Far East.

title: Staub's Long Absence Painful to Mets
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17After Rusty Staub injured his right hand swinging at a pitch, Dr. Harold Brelsford, the Houston team physician, gave him a shot of cortisone and said, At the worst, he'll be out three days.

title: Youth Worker, 19, Indicted For Assault in Gang Incident
description: A 19yearold youth worker for the city's Youth Services Agency who was accused of wounding four bystanders with a rifle during a gang fight was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of assault, reckless endangerment and possession of a dangerous weapon.

title: Publisher Calls Beacon Press Case Threat to Freedom
description: Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of the Association of American Publishers, denounced yesterday as a sad, shabby affair an attempt by the Justice Department to prosecute Beacon Press for publishing Senator Mike Gravel's fourvolume version of the Pentagon papers.

title: Storm Toll Is 370 in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 17 (AP)Landslides and floods caused by heavy rains in many areas of Japan in the last two weeks have killed at least 370 persons and 67 others are missing, the National Police Agency reported today. The Construction Ministry said property damage was estimated at $472million.

title: U.S. Takes Over Pennsylvania Meat Inspections
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17The Federal Government took over all meat inspection functions in Pennsylvania today after the Department of Agriculture said state inspections had become too few and too lax to comply with the Wholesome Meat Act of 1967.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI)Alderman Vito Marzullo, an organization Democrat for 52 years, said today that he and everyone he knew would be working for President Nixon this fall despite Mayor Daley's pledge to support Senator McGovern.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Grambling and Morgan State Colleges will kickoff the college football season in Yankee Stadium on Saturday, Sept. 9 for the benefit of the New York Urban League.

title: GeorgiaPacific Gains
description: Reflecting the recovery in the forest  products business, sharp gains were reported yesterday for the quarter and half year ended June 30 by the Georgia  Pacific Corporation, Champion International and the KimberlyClark Corporation.

title: TRADING SUSPENDED IN 4 SEASONS STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered 10day suspension in the trading of the common stock of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America Inc., and the Four Seasons Equity Corporation.

title: Pope Renews Pledge Of Unity in Message To Orthodox Leader
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, July 17Pope Paul in sent a message of congratulations today to the Orthodox faith's newly elected Ecumenical Patriarch, Dimitrios I. It restated the Roman Catholic Church's pledge for unity with Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: Akron Warned on Strike
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 17 (UPI) City health officials warned today that a sixday strike by garbage collectors had become a health nuisance and would cause serious rat and fly problems if it continued. There has been no garbage pickup in this northeastern Ohio city of 293,000 since last Tuesday. Some SOO members of the State, County and Municipal Employes Union are refusing to work in a dispute with city officials over insurance coverage.

title: June Industrial Output Up, While Increase Rate Lags
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Industrial production rose further in June, but the rate of increase for the last two months has slowed from the rapid pace of earlier this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Stones in Montreal Concert Despite Bombing Incident
description: MONTREAL, July 17 (AP)The Rolling Stones began their rock concert 45 minutes late tonight, without some equipment blown up by a bomb earlier in the day and to the accompaniment of ticketless throngs milling about outside under heavy police guard.

title: Ernest Thauer, ExPresident Of F.A.O. Schwarz, 69, Dead
description: ORADELL, N. J., July 17Ernest M. Thauer, who retired last year as president of F.A.O. Schwarz, the Fifth Avenuebased toy chain, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 95 Wanamaker Avenue. He was 69 yeard old.

title: Staten Island: The City's Offshore Bucolic Niche
description: It is summertime on Staten Island, which makes it different from summertime in other places in New York. It is greener, quieter and more open on Staten Island, and for years people from other parts of the city, who think of Staten Island as being very nearly bucolic, have been spending their summers there.

title: Corona Cited for Contempt In Hearing on 25 Slayings
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., July 17 (UN)  Juan V. Corona, accused of slaying 25 itinerant, farm workers, was found guilty of contempt of court today for refusing to give the prosecutor samples of his handwriting.

title: Paratroops Nearing EnemyHeld Citadel
description: QUANGTRT, South Vietnam, July 17  This city of rubble and ashes trembled to the incessant roar of gunfire today as South Vietnamese paratroops battled their way inch by inch toward its center.

title: 75 Inmates Riot at Baltimore Prison; Back in Cells After Freeing Hostages
description: BALTIMORE, July 17About 75 inmates seized part of the Maryland State Penitentiary in downtown Baltimore today and held four hostages for five hours before releasing them and returning to their cells. It was the second outbreak of violence at a Maryland state prison in the last 48 hours.

title: DR. GISELA OSTER, 45, TAUGHT OBSTETRICS
description: Dr. Gisela Kallmann Oster, a physicist and research assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the City Univerity's Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died of cancer Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 45 years old and lived at 241 West 11th Street.

title: 200 Wind Through Chinatown In Rites for Slain Civic Leader
description: An elaborate funeral procession wound through the streets, of Chinatown during the noon, hour yesterday in tribute to a prominent businessman in the, area who was killed in a robberg July 8.

title: U.S. Beats Japan in 13th
description: TOKYO, July 17 AP)Jack Bastable of Missouri doubled home the winning run in the 13th inning today as the United States edged Japan, 32, in the fifth game of the collegiate hasehall series. Japan leads the fourofsevengame series, 32.

title: Senate Panel Bars Increase in Funds For Navy F14 Jet
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Senate Armed Services Committee refused today to increase what the Government will pay for the F14 Navy fighter, a costly plane that has run into financial and functional problems.

title: FERRYBOAT RAMS ST. GEORGE SUP
description: A Staten Island ferryboat, crowded with homebound commuters, rammed into its slip at St. George late yesterday afternoon, injuring eight passengers slightly. The boat and the slip were damaged, but service was expected to be normal this morning.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Secretary of Defense Melvin R. laird questioned today the credibility of Senator George Mc Govern's pledge to secure the quick release of American war prisoners from North Vietnam if he is elected President.

title: EllsbergCase Jury Is Expected to Have Strong War Critics
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17As the selection of the jury in the Pentagon papers trial moved into its second week today, it became virtually certain that the jury would contain some strong critics of the Vietnam war.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  First it was the Nixon Administration, scaring ideas out of the market with the Vice President's attacks on the press, and with the court cases against publication of the Pentagon Papers.

title: Stock Reporting Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 17An industry advisory committee has recommended to the Securities and Exchange Commission a twotape industrywide system for reporting trading in stocks listed on major national and regional exchanges.

title: Une de Mai to Race Speedy Crown and Fresh Yankee
description: WESTBURY, L. I. July 17 Une de Mai, the Frenchbred trotting queen whose start in last Saturday night's $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway was canceled by an 1 thhour decision by officials of the State Harness Racing Commission, will get her chance here in a closing night, $150,000 threehorse invitation race next Saturday.

title: Advertising:
description: United States companies that want to do business with China are being invited to participate in a directory that will be distributed within China and to her diplomatic and commercial missions.

title: Yugoslavia Adopting Stronger Measures to Dampen Nationalism in Her 8 Regions
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 17The Communist leadership of Yugoslavia, jolted by a recent gun battle between Croatian emigrant infiltrators and security forces in mountainous BosniaHerzegovina, is intensifying a campaign to calm nationalist passionsby persuasion if possible and by stronger methods if necessary.

title: 8Film Retrospective 01 Huston Is Planned
description: Eight feature films directed by John Huston will be shown free on a firstcomefirstserved basis next Tuesday over a 14hour period at the Columbia II Theater, Second Avenue and 64th Street.

title: Executive Changes
description: E. Clinton Towl, 67, chairman or the Grumman Corporation has been elected to the additional post of president. He succeeds Llewellyn J. Evans, who died last week.

title: Price Controls Reimposed on Small Lumber Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Nixon Administration reimposed today price and wage controls on 62,000 lumber companies that had been exempt because they were relatively small.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The announcement that Senator McGovern had pledged to black voters who supported him ten per cent of Federal job patronage within the states [news story July 13] is yet another indication of a lamentable trend set in motion by the Democratic party reform proposals: that all the institutions of public life must reflect the mathematical qualities of the population as a whole. This approach tends to judge a person by what group he belongs to rather than by what he is or has accomplished.

title: McGovern Offers to Meet Labor Chiefs
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 17Senator George McGovern, moving to unite the splintered Democratic party, offered today to meet with 150 presidents of international labor unions to talk about our common interests and discuss any differences we may have.

title: Jailing of IrishAmericans Called Civil Rights Violation
description: Criticism of the recent jailing of five IrishAmericans on charges connected with the running of guns to Northern Ireland was voiced yesterday by a spokesman for a civil rights group.

title: Plan to Raze El Is Called Ray of Sunshine for Bronx
description: Merchants and residents who have lived so long in the city of night straddled by the Third Avenue elevated line in the Bronx generally cheered yesterday the plans to demolish it and let the sunshine in for the first time in 80 years.

title: Power Failure in 65 Affected a Huge Area
description: The power failure on Nov. 9, 1965 left nearly all of New York City, parts of nine Northeastern states and two provinces of southeastern Canada in darkness. About 80,000 square miles in which perhaps 25 million people live and work were affected.

title: Sweepstakes Fraud Seen
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 17 (AP)The state has been defrauded of an undetermined amount of money through bogus claims for New Hampshire Sweepstakes prizes, Attorney General Warren Rudman said today. He estimated the loss at $3,000 to $4,000 and said he expected criminal prosecution to result.

title: Jets work out as Grant Guthrie placekicks during a drill yesterday at Hofstra University field
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., July 17Since starting his professional football career as the No. 1 draft choice of the New York Jets in 1964 and earning American Football League rookieoftheyear honors the same season, Matt Snell has had to restart his career twice.

title: STANLEY J. LEHMAN
description: Stanley J. Lehman, who served as fulltime secretary of the Newspaper Mail Deliverers Union here for 17 years before Joining The New York Post as superintendent of delivery in 1969, died Sunday at his home at 14006 13th Avenue in Whitestone, Queens. He was 57 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In 1954 and 1955, during the time Ezra Pound was confined to St. Elizabeth's, I was working on a translation into Spanish of the Pisan Cantos (published in 1956 by the National Autonomous University of Mexico; the first Spanish translation of the complete Cantos will be published this year by Joaquin Mortiz in Mexico City). Pound was my constant guide and critic.

title: Jury Looks Into Alleged Bribe Offer in Drug Case
description: A Queens grand jury questioned an insurance agent yesterday about his alleged offer of a bribe to the executive secretary of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell for information about a major narcotics investigation.

title: Stockton Beats Molina
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio. July 17 (AP)Dick Stockton of Port Washington, defeated Ivan Molina of Colombia, 57, G2, 64, at the start of the $25,000 Buckeye open tennis tournament today. Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles advanced by default.

title: Where Family Reunions Still Flourish
description: CRYSTAL LAKE, Iowa, July 17The first Sorensons arrived here early yesterday morning to stake out a prime picnic spot at the town park. They lined up 12 green picnic tables in a single row, covered them with plastic tablecloths, then turned on the coffee.

title: FLOOD FREE JOHNSTOWN. PRESS IS AND PROSPERING
description: For Details Write >>>> ??

title: Spassky Appears Weak on Opening
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 17 The two games played thus rar in the world championship chess match have disclosed Mat Boris Spassky, the champion, seems to be lacking in knowledge of the openings.

title: 73Foot Ketch Is First 100 Miles From Finish
description: Blackfin, a 73foot ketch skippered by Kenneth Demeuse of San Francisco, was reported 100 miles from the finish yesterday and leading the 2,700mile yacht race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain, according to radio reports received here by Sid Rogers, chairman of the race committee.

title: Senate Debates Democratic and G.O.P. Proposals to Increase Minimum Wage
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Senate ended a twoweek Congressional recess today by plunging into a major election year fight over increasing the minimum wage.

title: Samuel Tabas, 87, Founded Downingtown Enterprises
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17Samuel Tabas, retired industrialist and real estate developer, died today in Hahneniann Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: President Sends a Trade Delegation to Moscow
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. July 17 (AP)President Nixon sent a delegation to Moscow today with instructions to try to negotiate a comprehensive trade agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Terrorist Is Given Life Term in Israel
description: RISHON LE ZION, Israel, July 17Israel withheld the death penalty today for Kozo Okamoto, sentencing the Japanese terrorist instead to life imprisonment for his role as one of the three gunmen who fired into a crowd in the arrival hall at the Tel Aviv airport on May 30.

title: The Europe Connection
description: The President who takes office next January is certain to be confronted by the necessity for a more positive, more imaginative, more sensitive American policy for Western Europe. This cannot mean a return to the dominant role in NATO played by the United States in earlier years; but neither can it mean a walkaway from dependable defense and trade ties to Europe.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Back in the Golden Age of Sports a halfcentury so ago, the demigods strode across the stage to the accompaniment of clashing cymbals. They were lionized on the sports pages in lush verbiage and the undisputed master of purple prose was George Trevor. He was a Yale man who awed his contemporaries because his lengthy dissertations were not turned out on a typewriter but were written by hand.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corp. announced yesterday plans to register about 500,000 common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission for sale in an underwritten offering late next month or in September. The company said the offering would consist of about 350,000 shares to be sold by Tesoro and 150,000 shares to be sold by certain stockholders, none of whom is an officer or director of the company.

title: MOBIL OIL ME IN ANTITRUST SUIT
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday to halt what he charged were violations of state antitrust law by the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: Jersey Assembly Tax Bill Vote
description: TRENTON, July 17  Here is how the New Jersey Assembly voted today on the income tax bill.

title: Books of The Times
description: From Billy Budd to From Here to Eternity, the cost of bucking the system has been high. The closer a social institution resembles a military one the more conformity becomes a first principle. Men work best under the system when they move as iron filings to the pull of the magnet: under illusions of free will but following lines of force. There is no place for the maverick, for the Billy Budds, for the Prewitts in such an arrangement. It's not a matter of whether a man's ideas have merit, but whether he meshes with the machinery or becomes grit to obstruct it. An eccentric with a personal view of the joba policeman, say, with his own penal codewill stand out like a painted bird, and the system will either embrace him or destroy him, more likely the latter. James Mills, who has written about crime and justice in his previous books, The Prosecutor and Panic in Needle Park, has documented the above thesis in his new novel, Report to the Commissioner. On one level it is a superior suspense novel, on another a cool exposition of the way a paramilitary organization, in this case the New York City Police Department, eliminates anything that threatens it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Virtually the entire animal population of the childrens zoo at the Astroland amusement park at Coney Island, stolen early Sunday morning, was recovered by the police yesterday.

title: CON ED SHUTS OFF POWER TO 200,000 IN BROOKLYN AFTER FEEDER LINES FAIL
description: The Bay Ridge, Sunset Park and Gowanus sections of Brooklyn were plunged into darkness last night when the Consolidated Edison Company, shut off electrical power to avoid permanent damage to the network after feeder cables had failed.

title: Prague Puts 13 Supporters of Dubcek on Trial
description: PRAGUE, July. 17 (Reuters) Thirteen prominent supporters of Alexander Dubcek, the liberal former leader of the Czechoslovak Communist party, went on trial in Prague city courts today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Securities Industry Automation Corporation, or SIAC, formally started operations yesterday as the jointly owned subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Running ashore below the old toll bridge at Lackawaxen, Pa., hoping to find ice with which to make a recent canoe trip down the Delaware River more luxurious, I was unaware for a while that I was within walking distance of the former home of one of my boyhood heroes, the author, Zane Grey.

title: 132 on Welfare Accused In Thefts of Funds Here
description: In what is believed to be the largest move here against welfare frauds, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that his office had charged 132 welfare clients with stealing a total of $131,405 from the City Department of Social Services.

title: March to Decency
description: As a Southernerborn and brought up in the Mississippi DeltaI recall the outrages of the Ku Klux Klan, directed against Jews, Catholics and Negroes. As one who had some participation in the New Deal and the fight against McCarthyism, I remember Father Coughlin; the senior Henry Ford, whose son has so greatly atoned for the sins of his father; Gerald L. K. Smith; Joseph P. Kamp; Merwin K. Hart; Upton Close and John Rankinand then Senator Joseph McCarthy and his ugly entourage. I remember them.

title: Rams Gabriel Sidelined With a Collapsed Lung
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 17 (AP)Roman Gabriel, quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, suffered a collapsed lung today.

title: Black Films Are In, So Are Profits
description: The traditionally white motion picture industry increasingly is thinking black.

title: Accepting Ineligibles
description: The City Council has remained disgracefully aloof from the raging dispute over welfare cheating in New York Citya dispute that has kept Human Resources Administrator Jule Sugarman, Welfare Inspector General George Berlinger, State Assemblyman Andrew Stein and State Controller Arthur Levitt locked in bitter argument over acceptance rates and ineligibles on the rolls. It is past time for the Council to invoke its considerable powers of investigation and determine just whatand whois wrong about administration of the city's enormously, expensive welfare program.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The harsh opposition of George Meany to the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern is creating widespread confusion, deep cleavages and spreading dissension within organized labor.

title: Eboli's Slaying Ends a Fort Lee Era
description: FORT LEE, N. J., July 17Eboli was the Last of the Mohicans when it comes to talking about reputed Mafia leaders who have lived in Fort Lee.

title: BANKMERGER PLAN UNDER FIRE IN OHIO
description: William S. Rowe, president and chief executive officer of the $650  million Fifth Third Bank in Cincinnati, said yesterday that he would oppose the bid by the $1.2billion Union Commerce Corporation of Cleveland to take over his institution.

title: Never Hula wins the Aqueduct feature. I'm for Mama, right, was second and Candid Catherine third.
description: Eddie Belmonte failed to weighin after he guided Dutch Clover to a frontrunning1 triumph at $30.80 for $2 in the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday. To many of the 23,022 fans on hand, Belmonte's omission went unnoticed, but a few patrons were curious and vociferous, and some of them even braced Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, for an explanation.

title: Mrs. Bower's 79 Leads TriCounty Qualifiers
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 17 Mrs. Albert B. Bower of the Pelham Country Club scored 39, 4079 at Sunningdale, C. C. today to win the medal by one stroke in the 33d annual championship of the Women's TriCounty Golf Association.

title: Marcus to Leave Neiman
description: DALLAS, July 17 (UPI)Edward S. Marcus, board chairman of the NeimanMarcus Company specialtystore chain and the developer of the NeimanMarcus Christmas catalog, announced today his retirement effective this fall.

title: COMMON MARKET REACHES ACCORD ON MONETARY AIMS
description: LONDON, July 17The financial leaders of the six present and four future members of the European Common Market met here today and agreed on eight basic objectives for the reform of the world's monetary system.

title: ATOM SMASHER SETS RECORDS ON ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that its $250million atomsmasher machine at Batavia, Ill., had attained record energies far beyond what scientists originally had hoped.

title: Chou Says U.S.Soviet Pacts Won't End Arms Race
description: PEKING, July 17 (Reuters) Premier Chou Enlal said tonight that the agreements on limitation of some strategic armaments signed by the Soviet Union and the United States were by no means a step toward ending the arms race.

title: A.B.C. Shifts Major Broadcast Division Executives
description: A major restructuring of the American Broadcasting Company's broadcast division was announced yesterday by Elton H. Rule, president of A.B.C., Inc.

title: Spassky Resigns Without Resuming Play in 3d Game
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 17 Bobby Fischer today won the third game of the world championship chess match without even being there. It was his first victory in the match and the first time he had ever defeated Boris Spassky.

title: .38Caliber Bullet, Size the Police Use, Is Shown to Jury at the Phillips Trial
description: After presenting the jury with a week of witnesses who chronicled the alleged events that led to the 1968 Christmas Eve slayings of a pimp and a prostitute, the prosecution in the trial of William R. Phillips began yesterday to try to tie the remaining threads in the case together.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)Administration officials today announced a 1973 wheatcontrol program designed step up payments to farmers by about 10 per cent in an effort to cut surplus production.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Down at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Yields on United States Treasury hills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Strikes Starr in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 17 (AP)  Uruguayan labor unions began today a series of strikes that were planned to end Thursday in a general strike directed against the economic policies of President Juan M. Bordaberry. The strike Thursday will be the 10th general work stoppage called by the Communistcontrolled National Workers Convention since Mr. Bordaberry took office on March 1. The organization of about 400,000 members is demanding a 40 per cent increase in salaries.

title: Forget the Public
description: The professional labor relations establishment is back at its favorite game of pretending that collective bargaining is an arcane art impossible to practice in the full light of public knowledge. Given the enormous impact of labormanagement contracts on the cost and effectiveness of many vital services, this doctrine has little to commend itself even in private industry. It has none at all in public service, where not only the size of governmental budgets but increasingly the determination of basic public policy on education, health and public safety is reached behind the closed doors of the bargaining chamber.

title: Jersey Assembly Rejects Proposal for Income Tax
description: TRENTON, July 17  Gov. William T. Cahill's legislative drive for tax reform was defeated tonight when the Assembly overwhelmingly rejected his proposed state income tax.

title: Blackout Starts a Party in Bay Ridge
description: A threeblock residential corner of Bay Ridge came alive last night when the lights went out.

title: Kissinger Phone Call To Fischer Disclosed
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 17Fred Cramer, a spokesman for Bobby Fischer, said today that Henry L. Kissinger had telephoned the American chess star here.

title: Details Disclosed on U.S.Soviet Space LinkUp in 1975
description: HOUSTON, July 17Soviet and American space officials disclosed here today some details of the first joint space flight by men from their two countries, involving a twoday linkup of two spacecraft in earth orbit in 1975.

title: Hydroplane Withdrawn
description: MADISON, Ind., July 17 (AP) The Miss Madison unlimited hydroplane, damaged in an accident on the Detroit River several weeks ago, has been pulled off the circuit for the rest of the season, sponsors said today. The boat sank during a practice run for the Gold Cup race at Detroit.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON BROAD FRONT
description: A feeble morning rally in the stock market fizzled out in the afternoon yesterday and turned into a general retreat that carried most market indicators close to their lows for the year.

title: Wright and Letellier Tied For L. I. Golf Lead at 69
description: PLANDOME, L.I. July 17A birdie 3 on the 293yard final hole enabled Jimmy Wright to tie Ron Letellier for the firstround lead at 69 in the 54hole, Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship today.

title: Miss Goolagong Is Set To Meet Queen Today
description: HOYLAKE, England, July 17 (Reuters)  Evonne Goolagong raced through her match in the North of England tennis championships today, then flew to London for an appointment with Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace.

title: Community Board Polling Places
description: In hoard of directors elections for nine of the city's 26 community corporations today, eligible voters include all residents 18 years or older who can prove that they have lived in the area for 30 days or more. Polling places will be open from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., and are as follows:

title: She's Cool, Clever, LowKeyed and to Be Reckoned With
description: WASHINGTONWhat's a nice Cincinnati girl like Joyce Teitz doing in a fight like this? asked Stewart Udall, the former Secretary of the Interior last year when political controversy swirled around the SST.

title: A WORLD HISTORY BY 42 PROFESSORS
description: Fifty years ago H. G. Wells, the British polymath and amateur historian, was able to compress the history of the world up to 1920 into one volume of 1,171 pages weighing 3 pounds 3 ounces. The book was The Outline of History, Being a Plain History of Life and Man kind. It cost $5.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DETROIT, July 17The Ford Motor Company said today that its lowercontrol arms were not defective and called the charges by Mr. Nader absurd. It said its tests, some of which were conducted befpre observers from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, had shown that the lowercontrol arms in question had performed their intended steering and suspension functions. About four million passenger cars are involved.

title: THE DUTCH CABINET SHAKEN AS TWO QUIT
description: THE HAGUE July 17 (Reuters)  The fiveparty coalition headed by Premier Berend Biesheuvel seemed in danger of collapse tonight after the two Democratic Socialist ministers submitted their resignations to Queen Juliana, bitterly accusing their colleagues of not keeping their promise to fight inflation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The referendum to authorize an Appellate Term Court for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which is to be on the November ballot, will certainly be convenient for the lawyers concerned. Indeed, most lawyers are asked to campaign actively for this referendum. Yet its defeat should unequivocally apprise the lawyerlegislators that the voters expect something better in court reorganization and not just more of the same.

title: M'GOVERN SCORED IN RINFRET SPEECH
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, the flamhoyant economist, went down to the Wall Street area yesterday and delivered some impassioned oratory on the impact of a Presidential victory by Senator McGovern.

title: Latest Chinese Art Is Following Mao's Line
description: PEKING  A sign at the entrance to the National inc Arts Exhibition here, the he first of its kind in years, declares the exhibition's purpose: to show the faithful adherence of Chinese artists to Chairman Mao Tsetung's revolutionary line in art. And it certainly does.

title: Rumania to Get Kangaroos
description: BRISBANE, Australia, July 17 (Reuters)Two kankaroos are being flown to the Bucharest Zoo in Rumania as a gift from the Lone Pine Sanctuary here. It is the sanctuary's first gift to a Communist country.

title: Yanks Send Kline Against Twins In Effort to End Slump Tonight
description: Having lost the first four games of a 15game home stand over the weekend to the Oakland A's, the Yankees will attempt to end their downward slide tonight against the Minnesota Twins, who also will play at Yankee Stadium tomorrow night.

title: U.S. Aides Say New Libyan Cabinet Is Result of Strife in Regime
description: WASHINGTON, July 17State Department officials said today that they believed that the formation of a new Government in Libya yesterday was the result of about 10 days of severe dispute within the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, led by Col. Muammar elQaddafi.

title: ALI, PATTERSON RESET SEPT. 20
description: The 12round heavyweight fight between former champions Muhammad All and Floyd Patterson has been rescheduled from Aug. 28 to Sept 20 at Madison Square Garden, the promoters announced yesterday.

title: Nickel and Lead Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The House passed and sent to the White House today two bills authorizing disposition of 38,876 tons of nickel and 498,000 tons of lead from the national stockpile. The nickel, determined to be no longer needed in a stockpile reserve, will be transferred to the United States mint for use in the production of coins. The surplus lead is to be offered for commercial sale by the General Services Administration over a period of years.

title: Sudan Likely to Resume U.S. Diplomatic Relations
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 17Sudanese officials said today that President Gaafar alNimeiry would ask the Cabinet this week to approve the resumption of diplomatic relations with the United States.

title: In Moscow, Despite His Antics, Fischer Is the Favorite of Many
description: MOSCOW, July 17  When is Bobby Fischer going to stop thiS nonsense and get down to playing chess? a Soviet fan asked the other day in the midst of the American challenger's protests about television cameras.

title: Truman Quits Hospital After Stay of 15 Days
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 17 (AP)Harry S. Truman was released from Research Medical Center today after 15 days of examination and treatment for an inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. The hospital quoted the former President's personal physician, Dr. Wallace H. Graham, as saying that Mr. Truman was in good health for a man of 88.

title: A Soviet Oil Field Accord With Occidental Reported
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation declined to comment yesterday on reports that the company was about to sign a multibilliondollar deal with the Soviet Union that would provide technical help in the development of Russian oil and gas fields.

title: Saigon Acts Against A.P. In Report on Offensive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP) The Saigon command has temporarily suspended the military press accreditation of Richard H. Pyle, chief Associated Press correspondent here, asserting that the A.P. had violated ground rules in releasing news of South Vietnam's northern counteroffensive.

title: Athens Indicts 8 Accused Of Plot to Kidnap a Kennedy
description: ATHENS, July 17 (UPI)Eight Greeks who the Government says planned to kidnap John F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late President, and other prominent persons have been indicted for conspiracy and will he brought to trial soon, a Government spokesman said today.

title: SUNNY AND MILD WINS IN STRETCH
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 17 (AP)Sunny and Mild, claimed for $15,000 last time out, came back to win the NeptuneOcean Township allowance purse at Monmouth Park under a ride by Steve Neff today.

title: New Cabinet Meets
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, July 17 (Reud ters) Libya's new Cabinet held its first meeting here today under Premier Jallud to discuss Government policies.

title: Baldwin Among 4 Victors As Junior Sailing Starts
description: WESTHAMPTON, L. 1., July 17Steve Baldwin of the Babylon Yacht Club, the defender, came out of today's first four races in good position to retain his Great South Bay Racing Association junior championship.

title: The Vietnam Issue
description: President Nixon's onetime forecast that the Vietnam war would not be a 1972 campaign issue is unlikely to be fulfilled by the kind of slanderous attack on war criticism that was revived last week by the President's Democratic apologist, John B. Connally of Texas.

title: Scott Panel Aides Contend Harassment Delays Them
description: Officials of the state's Scott Commission who are investigating New York City's government said yesterday that their work had almost halted because Lindsay Administration harassment had reduced the interrogation of city employes from a daily average of 50 to 100 to only three a day.

title: Top Officers Quit At National General
description: The National General Corporation, in a surprise step, disclosed in Los Angeles yesterday that three of its top officers had submitted their resignations.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 (AP)The first of 217 boats went across the Mackinac Island finish line at 4:47 A.M. today in the 48th annual Port HuronMackinac Island yacht race sponsored by the Bayview Yacht Club.

title: India May Ban Executions
description: NEW DELHI, July 17 (UPI)The Indian Supreme Court today considered whether to ban the death penalty and referred the matter to a fivejudge panel. The court took the action after a lawyer asked that the death sentence be overturned against a client convicted of murder. Only persons found guilty of murder or of abetting murder are given the death sentence under Indian law.

title: Mortgage Rates Steady
description: WASHINGTON. July 17 (Reuters)  Average interest rates on conventional first mortgages remained unchanged during June from the preceding month, but declined slightly from June, 1971, the Housing and Urban Development Department reported today.

title: Mayor Keeps Hat Out Of Ring, but Waves It
description: Mayor Lindsay opened the door Mayor yesterday on his prospects for seeking a third term at City Hall.

title: Some Arithmetic on the McGovern Economic Policies
description: NEW HAVENWhat is the arithmetic of George McGovern's budgetary, tax, and welfare programs? The proposals are by no means complete and firm, but their outlines permit a trial balance. And a balance it isthe McGovern proposals add up to a balanced budget at full employment.

title: Credit Markets
description: Longterm interest rates edged higher yesterday as underwriters prepared to market this week's heavy slate of new corporate and taxexempt offerings.

title: Music: In Aspen's Tent
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 17 Someone has said that all good American tourists want to go to Paris when they die. Perhaps so, but for the American who happens to like music and skiing, there may he no happier place to go while he lives than this outrageously beautiful mountain town. With the temperature in the 80's yesterday, there actually was skiing of a barechested, pioneering sort still going on (in a snow field that survives the summer in nearby Montezuma Basin). But for less frantically sportive types there is exercise enough for the spirit in Aspen's renowned music, under the tent of the Aspen Music Festival.

title: The Ballet
description: There is something of the 19thcentury romantic style that is natural to Carla Fracci, and Sunday night it was on view again at the State Theater when she and Ted Kivitt danced the leading roles in American Ballet Theater's production of La Sylphide.

title: 2 MORE INDICTED IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., July 17 Indictments charging two officials of the United Mine Workers with murder in the shootings in 1969 of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter were returned today.

title: Israeli Parliament Supports Government on Arab Affairs
description: TEL AVIV, July 17Israel's parliament today overwhelmingly endorsed the Government's handling of Arab affairs. Most Opposition members voted with the coalition in Jerusalem to defeat a Communist noconfidence motion, 60 to 6.

title: Reform of Private Pension Systems Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17Senator Richard S. Schweiker called today for reform of the nation's private pension system, and complained that workers are losing their pension rights when their companies go bankrupt, merge with other concerns or go out of business.

title: City Plans to Raze 3d Ave. El in Bronx
description: Plans to raze the 80yearold Third Avenue El in the Bronx, beginning next summer, were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at a City Hall news conference.

title: Roth Asks Inquiry on BankStock Sale
description: Arthur T. Roth, who built the Franklin National Bank into the 18th largest bank in the nation before he was ousted as chairman two years ago, yesterday called on the New York State Superintendent of Banks to examine closely the recent purchase of 1 million shares of the bank's parent holding company by an Italian financier.

title: Personalities: Hope for Driver
description: Merle Bettenhausen, the rookie race driver who lost his right arm in an accident during Sunday's Michigan 200, was removed yesterday from the critical list at University Hospital at Ann Arbor, Mich. Bettenhausen, who was competing in his first Championship Trail race for Indianapolistype cars, also suffered thirddegree burns on the face and lacerations Fyn the pelvic area  Joe Leonard, current United States Auto Club champion, is one of the best drivers on the circuit, but making up a deficit of six or seven laps to win the Michigan 200 would have been a large drder, even for him. Joe trailed Mel Kenyon not by that many laps, as had been reported, but by six or seven seconds before winning.

title: JOHN P. M'WILLIAMS OF GOODYEAR DIES
description: CLEVELAND, July 17John P. McWilliams, former director of the Goodyear Rubber and Tire Company and the Union Carbide Corporation, died Friday at his summer home in Wianno, Mass. He was 81 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Next week the people who have responded to the direct mail pitches for financial support for Senator George McGovern will be asked to give again.

title: McCoy Sees Advance
description: Earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co, in the second quarter and first six months of this year rose sharply on record sales, the concern reported yesterday.

title: Halting I.R.A. Guns
description: Since resuming their terrorist offensive in Northern Ireland last week, the Irish Republican Army Provisionals have been firing rockets made in the United States. For some time, they have also been using semiautomatic rifles made in Japan exclusively for a California firm. Under these circumstances, the Justice Department is completely right in investigating reports of illegal gunrunning from this country to Ireland.

title: Prisoner Here a Suicide
description: An 18yearold prisoner was found hanged in his cell at the Riker's Island hospital yesterday morning, a spokesman for the Department of Correction said. The dead man, Pablo Vargas, was the seventh man in the city's jails to take his life this year. According to the spokesman, the man, a drug addict, had been admitted to the institution on May 27.

title: Hockey Aides on Trial Today
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 17 (UPI)The trial of two Vancouver Canuck hockey executives was scheduled to open tomorrow following rejection today of a defense hid for a twomonth delay. Tom Scallen and Lyman Walters are charged with the theft of $3million in the transfer of club funds to Medicor, the parent company.

title: FREDERICK PRIDE, 68, LAW PARTNER HERE
description: Frederick W. R Pride, a senior partner in the law firm of Royall, Koegel & Wells, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 293 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, N.Y., where he was also a justice of the village police court. He was 68 years old.

title: One Long Bus
description: If the proliferation of express bus service from the outer fringes of the Bronx and Queens into midtown Manhattan continues, and if the same increasingly clogged routes are designated to handle this traffic, Fifth Avenue could become the equivalent of one long bus, with a horn at one end and an exhaust pipe at the other. It's almost that bad now. On this once elegant and truckfree thoroughfareone of the fewithe behemoth buses are already as thick as taxis. A pedestrian is no match for them.

title: DOCTOR IS BACKED IN NEWSMAN CASE
description: NEWARK, July 17Mrs. Virginia Scott, president of the Parent Teachers Association, testified today that she was standing near Dr. E. Wyman Garrett at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago and that at no time did she hear him threaten either John Cervase, a board member, or Fox Butterfield, a New York Times reporter.

title: Giant Camp: HitandMiss Affair
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 17The New York Giants went through their first hardhitting scrimmage today, leaving the coaching staff pleased and three players shaken up. But more significant to the team's future remained the situation of two absentees, Roland Lakes and Bob Grim.

title: BOARD PROPOSES TEACHER CHARGES
description: The Board of Education, in a list submitted to the United Federation of Teachers virtually on the eve of the start of contract negotiations, proposed yesterday, to lengthen the school year and teachers workdays, reduce preparation periods and alter provisions on seniority, transfers, leaves and retirement.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DUBLIN, July 17 (AP)The police were called today to quell a disturbance when Muhammad Ali failed to turn up for a cashcustomersonly training session for his fight with Al (Blue) Lewis on Wednesday.

title: Sarnoff Cites Peaks
description: Sales and earnings of the RCA Corporation reached new highs for the second quarter, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday. He also noted that sales for the firsthalf were at a new high.

title: Steel Production Reverts To Level of 2 Weeks Ago
description: Steel production for the week ended July 15 reverted to the level of the July 1 week at 2,412,000 net tons, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Output for the July 8 week at 2,432,000 tons marked the first week over the previous eight weeks in which production failed to decline from preceding weeks.

title: STANLEY J. HALLE, STOCKBROKER, 81
description: Stanley J. Halle, honorary chairman of the board of Halle Stieglitz, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange concern, who was prominent for more than 50 years as a judge and breeder of dogs, died Sunday at his home in Chappaqua, N. Y. His age was 81.

title: Bridge: Four Young Players Score Victory, in Fun City Tourney
description: A team that includes some of the country's finest young players won a splendid victory Sunday night in the Fun City Regional Knockout Championship at the New York Hilton. Ken Lebensold, Steve Goldstein, George Tornay, all of New York: Louis Levy of East Orange, N.J., Mark Feldman of Cambridge, Mass., and Leslie Popper of Lynn, Mass., won the title in a field of 54 teams that included many of the world's top players.

title: Aaron Outpolls Outfield Rivals; To Start in 13th AllStar Game
description: Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves, bidding to overtake Babe Ruth as the alltime home run leader, was among four repeaters on the National League All  Star team announced yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball.

title: PENTATHLON LEAD IS TAKEN BY DRUM
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 17 (AP)Paul K. Pesthy of Binghamton, N. Y., dropped from the lead to sixth place today in the modern pentathlon Olympic trials as Air Force Capt. Loren Drum of Omaha moved into the lead.

title: DRUG SEIZURES UP FIVEFOLD IN A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs announced today that during the last fiscal year it seized illicit drugs valued at five times more than those seized in the previous year.

title: Suffolk Jury Investigates Beach Sale
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 17 The Suffolk County grand jury began its inquiry today into the county's acquisition of the 295acre Tiana Beach.

title: Defeat of IncomeTax Measure Is Blow to Aging Jersey Cities
description: TRENTON, July 17Today's defeat of a state income tax in the New Jersey Assembly means that state's aging cities will not get the financial aid many of them had been counting on.

title: Yonkers Rejoins Harness Group
description: The Harness Tracks of America welcomed yesterday the return of Yonkers Raceway and the addition of four other tracks to the organization, swelling the membership to 47.

title: DALEY TO SUPPORT MUVERN SLATE
description: CHICAGO, July 17Mayor Richard J. Daley promised today to support all Democratic candidates in the November election, but his remarks left doubts as to the extent of his backing for Senator George McGovern, the party's Presidential nominee.

title: Collision in Mexico Kills 8
description: SALINA CRUZ, Mexico, July 17 (UPI)Eight youths, ranging in age from 16 to 20, were killed yesterday when their car struck a bus in this city 500 miles southeast of Mexico City.

title: LEONARD P. FRIEDER, GENTEX PRESIDENT
description: Leonard P. Frieder, president of the Gentex Corporation, manufacturers of aeronautic materials, died Sunday in Carbondale Hospital, Carbondale, Pa. He was 77 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With reference to the June 16 ad by the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith, I am wondering if this organization has ever directed its energy to benefit any other ethnic group which is being maligned?

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Mali's Literacy Drive in Villages Is Hitched to the Plow
description: MANA, Mali, July 13Dira Doumbia, a wiry 29yearold peasant, hopes to marry in the fall and buy some new clothes. His cousin Bronlaye, 25, has bought a transistor radio, has recently taken a second wife and is saving to buy a pair of oxen.

title: North Vietnamese Are Now Requiring Everyone to Work
description: HONG KONG, July 17 (AP) North Vietnam has ordered all its citizens mobilized for the work forceto serve in any capacity or any mission assigned themand has warned that those who disobey will have to perform up to two years forced labor.

title: Roundup: Gibson Wins 1 ()thin Row, 32
description: He may be 36 years old, but Nub Gibson is still pitching as if he were 26. Or 20.

title: Heavy U.S. Support Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 18 (AP)The South Vietnamese counter offensive in Quangtri Province was reported backed yesterday by some of the heaviest United States air and naval attacks of the war.

title: SHOP TALK
