description: What with the current passion for everything Chinese, it's almost a relief to see an ethnic fashion of a somewhat genre.

title: Institutional Sales Cited
description: The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had warned its member firms that certain unnamed investment organizations might have been trading illegally on the exchange just prior to secondary distributions.

title: Median Income $10,285, But Inflation Cancels Gain
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The income of the median American family rose above $10,000 for the first time last year, but the gain was wiped out by inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Billy Talbert, director of the United States Open tennis championships, said yesterday that the contract pros had not turned in their entries for the $160,000 tournament starting Aug. 30 at Forest Hills.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times of July 3 reported that U.S. Government sources have confirmed that the U.S. has been secretly seeding clouds over North Vietnam, Laos and South Vietnam to increase and control the rainfall for military purposes. This new class of weaponry should be viewed openly with utmost seriousness by all.

title: Swedish Diplomat Slain In His Car in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 17 (Reuters)The First Secretary of the Swedish Embassy in Colombia was shot to death in his car tonight, the police said.

title: Israeli Government Silent, But Officials Are Excited
description: JERUSALEM, July 18The Israeli Government kept silent tonight on the report of the scheduled departure of Soviet military personnel from Egypt, but key officials could scarcely conceal their excitement. Government spokesmen said there would be no official comment until statements from Cairo had been studied fully.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)Bob Spitler, a Harrisburg, Pa., promoter said today a 12team major league of softball would be in operation next year with a set of rules designed to make the game zippier than baseball. Spitler, president of Major League Softball, Inc., said two sixteam divisions, including two franchises in Canada, would play a 60game season from May through July, with a fivegame series between division winners in August.

title: People Power Replaces Electric Power in Brooklyn
description: A few minutes after 11 A.M. yesterday a fan began to hum in a private home along Bay Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn. Up the street, on Eighth Avenue, a storekeeper called out: The electric is on again.

title: Roundup: Braves Halt Pirates Streak
description: Bill Virdon's pushbutton managing failed to function with its usual efficiency last night, and the Atlanta Braves downed the world champion Pirates, 42, ending Pittsburgh's fivegame winning streak.

title: Flood Routs 200 Families
description: GALLUP, N. M., July 18 (UPI) Flash floods roared through business and residential areas last night, injuring 17 persons and forcing the evacuation of 200 families. No deaths were reported, and all injuries were minor.

title: Median Family Income Here Up 60% in 60's
description: The median income of the city's two million, families increased by 60 per cent during the last decadefrom $6,091 in 1959 to $9,682 by 1970according to newly compiled figures just released by the Census Bureau.

title: Polaroid Corp
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 (AP)  The Polaroid Corporation today reported net earnings of $16,151,000 for the first half of 1972, down more than $13million from earnings for comparable period last year.

title: Bank Rejects Metter Bid
description: The directors of the Fifth Third Bank in Cincinnati, as expected, formally rejected yesterday the $80million merger bid that was announced over the weekend by the Union Commerce Corporation, a Clevelandbased bank holding company. Officials of Union. Commerce had rio comment on the rejection.

title: U.S, COURT ORDERS WAR FOES FREED
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 18 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ordered today the release of four members of Vietnam Veterans Against the War who had been jailed in Florida, and a motion for reduction of bail was filed for three other members.

title: PETERSON OPPOSED IN DELAWARE RACE
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., July 18Gov. Russell W. Peterson of Delaware faces a primary election challenge in his bid for the Republican nomination for a second term.

title: Ellsberg Defense Wins Move to Disqualify Two Potential Jurors
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18The trial judge in the Pentagon papers case granted defense motions today to disqualify two potential jurors who hold security clearances as aircraft industry officials.

title: Giants Put Work Ethic To HeadKnocking Test
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 18  With Scott Eaton. Bob Hyland and Greg Larson still hors de combat from yesterday's aches, the New York Giants went through another bruising scrimmage today and only Jack Gregory, the new defensive end, had to quit early. He suffered a slight muscle pull in his leg.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MOUNT RUSHMORE, S. D., July 18 (Reuters)  Senator George McGovern said today that he would go to Chicago in the next two weeks to confer with Mayor itichard J. Daley. The Senator told of his plans at news conference.

title: Those Chess Games With Dad: Better (at Times) Than a Fight
description: Chess, perhaps the most competitive, intellectually demanding and passionate of games, is rarely treated as casually as gin rummy in the increasing number of homes where it is played with any regularity.

title: Confusion at the Met
description: The loss of Goeran Gentele throws the Metropolitan Opera's immediate and longrange plans into confusion. The Swedish general manager, who took office officially this month, had been training for the post for nearly two years, and had mapped out at least three seasons ahead for the Met. But suddenly the horse is without a rider.

title: NEWARK THREATS DENIED BY DOCTOR
description: NEWARK, July 18Dr. E. Wyman Garrett denied today that he threatened the lives of Fox Butterfield, a reporter for The New York Times, and John Cervase, a school board member, at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago.

title: Music: Aspen's Resident Composers
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 18Audiences at the Aspen Music Festival are traditionally snooty about their listening habits. The other day, Itzhak Perlman chose to perform the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto and there was much pursing of lips. Aspen does not program much Tchaikovsky, you know. It turned out all right; Mr. Perlman stood the atfdience on its ear, in fact, by every report, and he had to go right ahead and break another taboo by playing an encorePaganini, no less.

title: CHEMICAL DEMAND RAISES EARNINGS
description: Improved demand for chemicals has helped several diversilied companies involved in this field to post record profits for the second quarter or six months, or both periods, of this year, according to reports issued yesterday.

title: Baldwin Keeps Junior Title In Great South Bay Sailing
description: WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18Steve Baldwin successfully defended his title as the junior champion of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association as the roundrobin series came to a close today.

title: Scott Will Urge Nixon For Nobel Peace Prize
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)  The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott, will nominate President Nixon for the Nobel Peace Prize, to be awarded next winter, Mr. Scott's office said today.

title: About Motor Sports
description: A New York racing fan who saw last Saturday's British Grand Prix was stunned at the introduction of parimutuel betting there, It was strange, says Miss Pat Greise, to hear them hawking odds over the publicaddress system. Im not sure I liked it. Betting on motor races is not so strange as it seems. Fortytwo years ago there was another Grand Prix with parimutuels and the promoters, fearing a riot, did not repeat the experiment.

title: MEANY SAID TO ASK NEUTRALITY ON 72
description: WASHINGTON, July 18George Meany is making strong, lastminute personal appeal to key union leaders to vote against any proposal at tomorrow's meeting of the A.F.L.C.I.O. executive council to endorse George McGovern, union officials reported today.

title: Telephone Company Draws Wrath of Many on a Proposal to Charge for Local DirectoryAssistance Calls
description: A New York Telephone Company proposal to mako customers pay for local directoryassistance calls drew the wrath of blind people, public officials, consumer activists and some phone company operators yesterday.

title: Market Place:
description: The average investor has probably only recently become aware of the municipalbond marketa sector of finance where yield levels at present rival aftertax yields available in the average stockmarket investment.

title: Stockton, Hewitt Win
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18 (AP)  Jimmy Connors, Bob Hewitt and Dick Stockton, the top favorites, made it a formful day, sweeping to victories in the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament today.

title: CAHILL ENVISIONS JERSEY AUSTERITY
description: TRENTON, July 18  Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he viewed the rejection of his tax reform program by the State Assembly as a call to maintain a frugal and austere state government that would allow no increases in state aid for the cities or for education.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: FORT WORTH, July 18 (AP)Bobby Lee Hunter traded his prison cell for a comfortable dormitory room on the Texas Christian University campus today as 80 amateur fighters underwent physical examination for the United States Olympic boxing trials opening tomorrow.

title: Sinatra Berates House Unit for Letting Felon Link Him to Mafia
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Frank Sinatra furiously denounced the House Select Committee on Crime today for permitting a convicted felon to engage in what he called character assassination by saying the singer was a front man for the Mafia.

title: 12 Dead in Philippines In 30Hour Downpour
description: MANILA, Wednesday, July 19Incessant rain for 30 hours has caused the worst flooding in decades in Manila and death and destruction in neighboring provinces.

title: RACES CANCELED IN BLUE JAY CLASS
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 The second day of the junior phase of the Larchmont Yacht Club's 74th Race Week became a long, hot, weary and wasted afternoon for the 174 Blue Jay crews in a starting fleet of 280 on Long Island Sound.

title: Suffolk Votes to Purchase More Land for Parks
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 18The Suffolk County Legislature approved the acquisition today of more than 1,000 acres of land for two new county parks, despite charges that the procedures in one instance were repeating the same mistakes of nearly three years ago when it voted to buy Tiana Beach.

title: Notes on People
description: Dressed in a purple mantle, gold stole and pallium, Dimitrios I, was enthroned in Istanbul as Ecumenical Patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church and spiritual leader of the church's 125 million members.

title: Sports of The Time
description: Some years ago, District Attorney Frank Hogan was introduced as a speaker at the annual dinner of the New York Boxing Writers Association, whereupon he rose and read the police records of many of the more prominent citizens present. Some sticklers regarded this as an unfortunate breach of etiquette on the part of an invited guest, a view shared by St. Francis of Palermo, called Blinky by intimates, whom Hogan had singled out for honorable mention. Blinky said it wasn't as if he was some kind of freeloader or something. He said he had taken two tables at $20 a plate and it was embarrassing to have his friends hear such language so soon after the dessert course. Those were the days when a wide acquaintance in the fight mob was, if not the next thing to godliness, at least more instructive than membership in the Racquet and Tennis Club. Underworld influence in boxing was regularly and properly deplored by the Better Element, but the characters who peopled the game then were a lot more fun to be around than the ribbon clerks who handle fighters today.

title: Spassky, Fischer Draw
description: Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer played to a draw in the fourth game of the world's chess championship. Details, Page 45.

title: New Exchange Chairman
description: The New York Stock Exchange has Chosen as its first fulltime, salaried chairman James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Though reportedly not the stock exchange's first choiceits top recruiters were after a chief with greater public reputation and more sophisticated inside knowledge of Wall StreetMr. Needham does bring some commendable qualifications.

title: Einar Jacobsen, President Of Lawnmower Company,66
description: RACINE, Wis., July 18Einar A. Jacobsen, president of the Jacobsen Manufacturing Company, makers of lawnmowers, tractors and snow removers and a director of Allegheny Ludlum Industries of which the company is now subsidiary, died here last night. He was 66 years old.

title: Blackfin Is First To Arrive in Spain In 2,700Mile Sail
description: BAYONA, Spain, July 18 (AP)Blackfin, a 73foot ketch sailed by Kennedh De Meuse, of Alameda, Calif., was the first of 46 craft to complete the 2,700mile voyage from Bermuda.

title: Board Defends Proposals For New School Contract
description: The president of the Board: of Education, Joseph Monserrat, yesterday defended the board's farreaching proposals for this fall's new contract with the city's teachers.

title: OFFICER PROMOTED BY PAPER COMPANY
description: The International Paper Company yesterday named Joseph P. Monge, board chairman of its Canadian subsidiary, the Canadian International Paper Company, to become chairman of its finance committee. He will also be the company's chief financial, planning and administrative officer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 1 editorial on the illegal South African rule over Namibia draws a dangerous conclusion about the possible presence of a United Nations observer in that territory.

title: Presidential Adviser
description: (A memo to the man who takes the oath as President on January 20, 1973.)

title: 18 DRUG SUSPECTS HEED IN S.I. RAIDS
description: At least 18 alleged drug wholesalers, and 50 pounds of marijuana and a large quantity of LSD tablets, were seized last night and early today in a series of police raids at several houses and apartments on Staten Island.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 18Senator George McGovern took some time off today from the time off he is taking.

title: Wilson Meets I.R.A. Men
description: LONDON, July 18  Harold Wilson, leader of the Labor party, met here today with leaders of the Irish Republican army.

title: Pianists in Park Play Smoothly But Rival Melody Lingers On
description: It's summertime, and the listenin ain't easy. On Monday evening the twopiano team of Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe opened a concert series called Summer on the Mall in Central Park. The Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Skating Rink was going on at the same time, and the voice of Merry Clayton was being amplified to such an extent that she might have been on the stage of the bandshell with the pianists.

title: Bell's Endurance Best
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., July 18 Eddie Bell, a wide receiver, led all the players today during a 12minute endurance race at the Jets morning workout at Hofstra University.

title: HEATH'S CHIEF AIDE RESIGNS OVER LINK TO BANKRUPT FIRM
description: LONDON, July 18Reginald Maudling, Home Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister, resigned today because of his past involvement with a bankrupt company.

title: Republic Steel Reports Decline In Its ThirdQuarter Earnings
description: The nation's fifth largest steel company, the Republic Steel Corporation reported declines in thirdquarter sales and earnings and lower steel shipments yesterday. However, earnings for the first half rose slightly over the 1971 period.

title: 2 MORE AIRLINES SEAL REAR EXITS
description: Two more airlines, American and Continental, announced yesterday that they were modifying their Boeing 727 jets so that the rear exit from which several hijacker  extortionists have bailed out could no longer be opened in flight.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A high Conservative party official said yesterday that if Vice President Agnew were denied renomination it would foreclose any chance in New York of a Conservative endorsement of the Republican national ticket.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SHOW NO TRENDS
description: Corporate and taxexempt borrowers dipped heavily into the capital markets yesterday, but longterm Interest rate movements remained inconclusive. There was no news outside the market to cause any major shift in sentiment, although relative calm returned to the international monetary scene. Treasury securities, which are purchased by foreigners who have accumulated ex cess dollars, ended narrowly mixed.

title: A Defeat for New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Legislature has now rejected, by overwhelming margin, a tax reform program that Governor Cahill and a host of other prominent citizens both major political parties had painstakingly fashioned over the pa'st several months. Despite the intense efforts of its advocates, this program was virtually doomed defeat. A combination of economic and political factors proved impossible to overcome.

title: Irving Book on What Happened Due
description: Grove Press will publish Clifford Irving's own account of how he tried to swindle McGrawHill, Inc., of some $850,000 with an apocryphal autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Advisories Are Issued On Stagnant Air Mass
description: As if this week's summer hot spell were not enough of problem, a stagnant mass of air  roughly nature's equivalent of an electric blanketsettled in upon the city and much of the Northeast yesterday.

title: Bridge: Westchester Association Sets Charity Game Record
description: The highest ranks of bridge administration have traditionally been dominated by men. No woman has ever held high executive office in any international federation or in the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Queens Jury Subpoenas Durk In Investigation of Bribe Offer
description: A Queens grand jury has subpoenaed Sergeant David Durk to determine the extent of police involvement in an attempt to record an alleged bribe offer to Milton Drucker, the executive secretary of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell. Sergeant Durk is to appear before the panel today.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July, 18  Two foreign affairs specialists from the United States Senate staff asked senior American military officer, during a recent briefing in Saigon, what would have happened if the South Vietnamese had not had American air support during the current North Vietnamese offensive. We would be meeting in some other place today, the officer replied.

title: Thomson Newspapers Lose Plea for Price Increases
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters)The 23 American newspapers owned by Lord Thomson of Fleet were denied price increases by the Price Commission today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 18Doris Kostrinsky of Willow Ridge eliminated Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham Country Club, the tournament medalist, on the 19th hole at Sunningdale Country Club today in the first round of the 33d annual championship of the Women's TriCounty Golf Association. Miss Kostrinsky sank a 20foot putt on the 465yard first extra hole for a birdie 4.

title: Youngstown Officer Retires
description: The retirement of Arthur J. Doyle, 64yearold chairman of the Youngstown Steel Door Company, was disclosed yesterday. Two months ago the company named Robert E. Brill as president and chief executive officer to succeed Mr. Doyle who became chairman.

title: Bronx Man, 29, Is Indicted In Transit Policeman's Death
description: A 29yearold Bronx man was indicted on seven charges yesterday, including murder, manslaughter and attempted murder, for allegedly tricking policeman into fatally wounding an offduty transit patrolman on June 28.

title: Public Eye, Devious Film By Carol Reed, Arrives
description: The Public Eye, Sir Carol Reed's film version of Peter Shaffer's oneact play (presented on Broadway in 1963 with The Private Ear), is a truly devious film. It may even be dangerous. It's a comedy that pretends to be in favor of all of life's good thingsmore or less in the order of love, horror films, sunsets, dolphins, ice cream and Franco Zeffirelli's Romeo and Julietand succeeds in making them seem more unbearably boring than need be.

title: Gentele, Head of Met, Dies With 2 Children in Crash
description: Goeran Gentele, director of the Metropolitan Opera, and two of his children were killed yesterday in an automobile crash on the Italian island of Sardinia in the Mediterranean. Mr. Gentele, 54 years old had succeeded Sir Rudolf Bing last month in one of the most important and challenging jobs in the music world.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits could create a new hardship for New York State's small property owners who are over 65.

title: Briton Seeks Views of Ulster's People
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 18William Whitelaw, the British administrator of Ulster, asked the people of Northern Ireland today to send him views about the future of the province.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Crime in Central Park Cut Sharply

title: Nixon Back in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters)President Nixon returned to Washington tonight from California, where he had spent an 18day working vacation at the Western White House in San Clemente.

title: Man in the News
description: A medical doctor who has never practiced medicine; an industrialist whose name appears more often in the arts section than on the financial pages; a softspoken, grayhaired grandfather figure whom competitors consider a promoter and a harddriving, crafty executive: these are among the many faces of Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: City Coordinator Is Urged To Curb Graft in Building
description: Representatives of the city's construction industry called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to name a construction coordinator with the power to cut through the red tape and bureaucracy that they say fosters corruption.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One cannot pretend that a correspondent from the heart of the cattle country will be credited with objectivity when he suggests caution to those who are moving to depress the high retail prices of beef. Yet one cannot but yield to the temptation to draw attention to likely unfortunate and irreversible consequences of this action.

title: COAST THRIFT UNIT REVISES MERGER PLAN
description: A leading West Coast thrift institution improved its offer yesterday in a move to take over the Citizens Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, an institution with assets of $625million.

title: SOVIET TRADE SET BY OCCIDENTAL OIL
description: LONDON, July 18Dr. Armand Haminer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced here today an unusual wideranging agreement with the Soviet Government under which Occidental will provide patents and scienciific and technological knowhow in five fields in exchange for Russan oil, natural gas, metals and other raw materials.

title: Xerox Quarter Profit Up 19% to Peak
description: The Xerox Corporation conturned its high rate of earnings and revenue increases, showing records in the three months ended June 30 as well as for the first halfyear, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Just about the most serious issue facing financial markets and governments throughout the Western world is whether a new and more severe crisis will rip apart the international monetary system and wreck the prosperity and development the nonCommunist world has enjoyed through most of the postwar period. The latest outbreak of fears for the system began with the floating of the British pound on June 23. Speculation against the pound turned into speculation against the dollar, still the lynchpin of the system.

title: BANKAMERICA PLAN VETOED BY RESERVE
description: The Federal Reserve, Board confirmed yesterday that it had denied an application by the BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the nation's largest bank, to enter the business of leasing peripheral computer equipment through a new company, the BAC Computer Corporation.

title: Eboli's Chauffeur Gives Police Useful Information on Slaying
description: After spending the night in jail, Thomas Eboli's chauffeur adopted a cordial attitude, police officials reported yesterday, and gave the Brooklyn District Attorney's office very useful information relating to the murder of the gangland chieftain in a Brooklyn street.

title: Violence Erupts in Boston For Third Night in a Row
description: BOSTON, July 18 (AP)Violence erupted tonight for the third consecutive night in the. South End as firemenpelted by missiles from a crowd brought under conrtol a blaze that forced the evacuation of 80 persons from a sixstory building housing apartments and two businesses.

title: Trautman on Lehman Board
description: Gerald H. Trautman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Greyhound Corporation and chairman of Armour & Co., a subsidiary, has been elected to the hoard of directors of the Lehman Corporation.

title: DAVID C. RANNEY
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., July 18David C. Ranney, a partner in Haskins & Sells, the international accounting firm, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield. He was 51 years old and lived at 527 Clark Street, Westfield.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 18 (AP)  The 45foot Polish ketch Polonez is the first yacht from behind the Iron Curtain Ito finish the singlehanded transAtlantic race, completing the nearly 3,000mile trip from Plymouth, England early this morning.

title: Pullman Is Licensed To Do Soviet Business
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI) Pullman, Inc., said today an agreement had been reached with the Ministry of Foreign Trade of the Soviet Union giving it formal accreditation as a company licensed to do business in the Soviet Union.

title: Flood Site Flights Planned
description: BALTIMORE, July 18 (Reuters)An aerial view of floodstricken areas of Maryland and Pennsylvania will be offered Saturday for $10 a seat on Boeing 707, Trans World Airlines announced here today. Proceeds will go to the American Red Cross.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 18 (Reuters)England gained a draw today in the third cricket test against Australia. The first two matches of the fivematch series were split.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS RALLY STRONGLY
description: A dramatic rally in glamour issues halted the stock market's retreat yesterday and led it almost all the way back into plus territory on an upsurge in trading volume.

title: Business Briefs
description: The trend toward net redemptions of mutual fund shares is apparently continuing. The Investment Company Institute, industry trade association, is expected to report todayor at the latest tomorrowthat during June, for the fifth month in a row, more fund shares were cashed in than were sold.

title: Copters and Lasers Map Grand Canyon
description: GRAND CANYON, Ariz.Across the great chasm, filled to the rim with silence a mile and 2 billion years deep, a bright new sun appeared in a flash on the southern horizon.

title: A.P. AIDES, IN CHINA, SEEK NEWS ACCORD
description: The Associated Press announced yesterday that it was holding discussions with Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, on an agreement for the exchange of news and photos.

title: Personalities: Olympic Dropout
description: Swen Nater, who fought out of obscurity as a substrtute behind Bill Walton, the allAmerican center from the University of California, Los Angeles, to be named to the Olympic basketball team, quit the squad yesterday at its training base in Honolulu. Tom McMillen, the 6foot11inch Maryland star, who had criticized the selection committee when It left him off the squad, was named as Nater's replacement.

title: PHILLIPS DEFENSE CITES BALLISTICS
description: The jury in the trial of Patrolman William R. Phillips was told yesterday that the bullets that killed James Smith and Sharon Stangothe pimp and the prostitute he is accused of murdering could not have come either of the revolvers Patrolman Phillips is known by the police to own.

title: Ballet: Transformation in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West GermanyThe most talkedabout young choreographer in Germany today is an American, John Neumeier, a Wisconsinhorn dancer and choreographer who has scarcely ever worked in the United States.

title: DENIALS REPORTED AT PRAGUE TRIAL
description: PRAGUE, July 18 (Reuters)Six liberals on trial here on charges of subversion have denied that their activities were directed against Socialism, courtroom source, said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee on Pacific Ocean territories11 A.M.

title: What Kind Of Campaign?
description: The opening statements from the two sides in the American Presidential election campaign sound more like communiques from a battlefield than reasoned statements of future policy. Accordingly, the outlook Is that the control of Pennsylvania Avenue over the next four years will be decided orrte more by the advertising techniques of Madison Avenue, and this raises one or two serious questions.

title: About Pro Football
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 18The temperature was 94 and the humidity almost as high at the Washington Redskins training camp today when Christian Adolph (Sonny) Jurgensen, a quarterback soon to be 38 years old, cocked his extraordinary passing arm. This was merely the second day for Jurgensen at his 16th training camp, the preseason torture that all pro football players must endure. Snap, crackle and pop went the Jurgensen passes straight into the hands of Charlie Taylor, Roy Jefferson and Jerry Smith. This was a highstyle performance out of the past for a man who, because of a shoulder separation, missed almost all of the last Redskin season, a glorious one that put Washington into the postseason playoffs for the first time in 26 years.

title: PHONE CABLE IS CUT IN JERSEY ACCIDENT
description: Thousands of longdistance telephone calls along the Eastern seaboard were disrupted yesterday when a piece of construction equipment severed an American Telephone and Telegraph coaxial cable near Cedar Brook, N. J.

title: BOREK, WITH 201, PLANDOME VICTOR
description: PLANDOME, L. I., July 18Gene Borek of Pine Hollow captured the 37th Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship today, with a record 54hole score of 201 over the 6,502yard, par72 Plandome Country Club course.

title: FEMINISTS SCORED BY BETTY FRIEDAN
description: Betty Friedan, whose book The Feminine Mystique, gave birth to the women's liberation movement nine years ago, warned yesterday that the movement would be irreparably damaged if it did not purge itself of female chauvinism and begin to work with men instead of against them.

title: GermanAmerican Stars Top Stuttgart in Soccer
description: The GermanAmerican League Soccer AllStars began their 50th season last night with a 20 victory over Stuttgart of West Germany before 4,000 fans at Metropolitan Oval in Maspeth, Queens.

title: CITIBANK WIDENS EARNINGS LEAD
description: The First National City Corporation, the nation's most profitable banking concern, yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for the first half and the second quarter of 1972.

title: AUGUST J. BARDO, 54, EDUCATION OFFICIAL
description: KATONAH, N.Y., July 18August J. Bardo, director since 1950 of the division of professional conduct of the New York State Education Department, died yesterday at his home here. He was 54 years old.

title: WHEAT PRICES UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Pepped up by reports of possible larger foreign purchases of American wheat, traders bid up wheat prices yesterday in an active session. The busy December delivery, for example, closed at $1.60 to $1.61 a bushel, compared with $1.57 the previous day. Soybeans also rose, reflecting some of they enthusiasm.

title: ASHE, PASARELL ADVANCE AT NET
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Six seeded players survived 90degree heat and won today in the first round of the $50,000 Washington Star tennis tournament. Ninthseeded Arthur Ashe, twice a finalist here, was forced to go to three sets.

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, 2 to 1, On Robinson Clout in 10th
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18Rusty Staub, making a surprise return to the lineup exactly one month after he injured his right hand, gave the Mets a little lift tonight, but it wasn't enough as Liis Angeles won, 21, on Frank Robinson's twoout homer off Danny Frisella in the 10th inning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In order to avoid another and much worse Vietnam in the Middle East and in order to insure a foreign policy that works in the best interests of the United States of America, I urgently recommend that the Middle East issue be left out of the coming Presidential campaign.

title: Advertising:
description: We've been waiting to shake off the shackle of the shallow analysis that we are only a fashion agency, said David Altman, secretarytreasurer of Altman, Stoller, Weiss, adding simply, and this is a breakthrough into the big leagues.

title: JAPAN TV MAKERS DISPUTE CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Japanese producers of consumer electronic products formally disputed today the allegation of their United States competitors that Government subsidies of various kinds had been a key factor in penetration of the United States market by Japanese television sets and similar products.

title: HOUSE APPROVES 3 BILLS TO STEM MAJOR DISEASES
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The House passed today by overwhelming margins two health bills that the Administration did not want and a third toward which it had been cool.

title: A 65Yearold Trouper Makes It to Broadway in the Automat
description: There is something new in Times Squarea floor show at the Automat.

title: Summary of Sadat Talk on Soviet Ties
description: CAIRO. July 18 (Reuters) Following is a summary of President Anwar elSadat's speech on the withdrawal of some Soviet advisers as issued by the Middle East News Agency, the official Egyptian press agency:

title: EUROPEAN PACT CALMS MARKETS
description: LONDON, July 18The results of a Common Market monetary conference that ended here today brought at least temporary calm to crisisplagued financial centers of Europe.

title: The Italian Idea of Fashion: Elegant but Pretty Classics
description: ROME, July 18Classic is the word for fashion in Italy today as in the rest of the civilized world, but the interpretations are a lot more exuberant. Armholes are deeper, shapes more swirly, necklines lower and evening clothes more glittery than they are any place else.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Investors who trade American Stock Exchange shares do not like their companies to file registration statements covering sale of additional shares. Yesterday, when the market closed at 26.75, down 0.05 in the index, there were several examples.

title: Con Edison Is Vulnerable To FeederCable Failure
description: Consolidated Edison engineers said yesterday that although they had replaced the damaged sections of underground cable that failed Monday night, it would take several days of examination in the shop to determine exactly what caused the failures.

title: Franco Clarifies Succession Process
description: MADRID, July 18Generalissimo Francisco Franco, acting on the 36th anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War on which he overthrow the Second Spanish Republic, promulgated two laws today to insure the continuity of his system under his successor, Prince Juan Carlos.

title: Soviet Woman Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters) Ludmila Bragina of the Soviet Union broke the world record for the women's 1,500meter run by 2.7 seconds when she was clocked in 4 minutes 6.9 seconds today during the Soviet athletic championships. The previous record of 4:09.6 was set by East Germany's Karin Burneleit in Helsinki last year.

title: Foster Child Is Returned To Her Natural Mother
description: WANTAGH, L. I., July 18  Nineyearold Adrainne Schoenowitz was returned to her natural mother this morning after a yearlong custody battle that ended yesterday when her foster parents, William and Beatrice Cahn, were denied a stay of a court decision restoring the child to her natural parents.

title: Bausch & Lomb
description: Bausch & Lomb, discloped that secondquarter consolidated sales amounted to $47,323,000, a rise of 21 per cent from $39,270,000 in the 1971 period. Net earnings of $2,494,000 for the quarter were 75 per cent above the $1,428,000 for the yearago quarter, earnings per share of common stock after preferred dividends and based on the average number of shares outstanding, assuming full conversion of debentures, were 43 cents compared to 24 cents in 1971.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: NEWARK, July 18 (UPI)The Public Service Electric & Gas Company reported an alltime record use of electricity by its 1.7 million New Jersey customers in a onehour period today, as temperatures neared 90 degrees.

title: Hospitals Appear Unprepared For Blackouts Despite Failures
description: Despite the warning of the 1965 Northeast blackout, a spot check of 22 hospitals in New York City yesterday disclosed that almost all were without adequate emergency electrical generators when the lights went out in part of Brooklyn Monday night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 1 editorial SelfRule for Ovambos is to be commended fo'r urging the United Nations to send an observer to Southwest Africa if and when an invitation for so doing is forthcoming from the South African Government.

title: Rizzo Against McGovern
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)  Philadelphia's Democratic Mayor, Frank L. Rizzo, a longtime admirer of President Nixon, said today, I will do anything and everything in my power to bring about the defeat of Senator George McGovern.

title: Mrs. Henry Morgenthau, 73 Widow of Roosevelt's Aide
description: Mrs. Marcelle Puthon Morgenthau, widow of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury under President Franklin D. Rosevelt, died on Sunday in the American Hospital in Paris. She was 73 years old and resided in New York and in Nice, France.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Demand for Power Nears Record as Blackout Ends
description: Sweltering New Yorkers increased their demands for electricity to a nearrecord level yesterday, only hours after the Consolidated Edison Company restored service to more than 200,000 Brooklyn residents who had been blacked out in the city's worst power failure since 1965.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A public offering of 700,000 shares of Tucson Gas &. Electric common at $12.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Blyth & Co. and First Boston Corporation. Proceeds of the offering will be applied to reduction of shortterm notes incurred for interim construction financing. The utility's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at 12, up .

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)Martin M. Decker, realty executive, has been granted a hearing in Federal court on a move to block disposal of his $70million empire by bankruptcy trustees.

title: Surgery on Wallace Today
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace will undergo surgery tomorrow morning to improve the drainage of an abscess in his abdomen, officials at University Hospital said today. The improved drainage is expected to promote healing and to speed Mr. Wallace's overall recovery.

title: Keep S. Africa Out, U.N. Group to Ask Davis Cup Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 (AP)The United Nations apartheid committee decided today to ask organizers of the Davis Cup International tennis competition to rescind their decision to readmit South Africa to the tournament next year.

title: CAMBODIA ASKS U.N. TO PROTECT ANGKOR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18  Cambodia has appealed to United Nations member countries to save the temples and monuments at Angkor, from threatened destruction.

title: Canada, With 6% Jobless, May Curb Immigration
description: OTTAWA, July 18  As a sparsely settled developing country, Canada historically welcomed immigrants and even solicited them. They were badly needed to boost the country's labor force.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: BOAT RACERS GET A RULES BRIEFING
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 18A couple of drivers stood on their 24foot outboard at the Kings Grant Inn marina today getting set for tomorrow's Hennessy Grand Prix ocean powerboat race.

title: A Gun at the Breakfast Table
description: BOSTONWhile I'm lingering over a cup of tea, my 6yearold hoists himself onto my lap. He shoves his red plastic water gun at my face and makes the gun noises that have been passed on from generation to generation of American children.

title: EXPOLICEMAN KILLS FAMILY AND HIMSELF
description: IRVINGTON, N.J. July 17 (UPI)A former Newark policeman fatally shot his wife j and two daughters as they slept early today and then took his own life the police said.

title: U.S. IS SUING CITIES ON HARBOR FILTH
description: A concerted effort to end the serious pollution of New York Harbor was initiated by the Federal Government yesterday in a series of lawsuits against New York City, the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission and several communities in New Jersey.

title: EXCODE ANALYST EXPLAINS HIS AIM
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 18 (AP)  A 26yearold antiwar activist credited by Ramparts Magazine as the source for an article on National Security Agency intelligencegathering said today that he had spoken out to make sure there are no more Vietnams.

title: U.S. Will Investigate Charges Of Bias in City School System
description: The Federal Government will announce today a major investigation of alleged discrimination against Puerto Rican, black and other minority  group students in the New York City school system.

title: State of Emergency Is Declared at Attica
description: ATTICA, N. Y., July 18A state of emergency for the Attica Correctional Facility was declared today by its superintendent, Ernest Montanye, after hundreds of inmates refused to leave their cells.

title: 28 Citizen Groups Cited For Tidying City Areas
description: They planted trees, vacuumed sidewalks, painted kiosks, installed ash trays at subway entrances and bus stops, and in general treated their neighborhoods as they would their homes, and yesterday they received a small token of the city's appreciation.

title: Key EgyptianSoviet Moves Since 55
description: Following is a list of major events in relations between Egypt and the Soviet Union:

title: Advertising:
description: In a proper settingan intimate but elaborate luncheon aboard the FranceCBS Publications anounced yesterday a new quarterly called Epicure and subtitled The Pleasures of Living.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: ALLEN, MITE SOX, TOP VOTEGETTER
description: Dick Allen of the Chicago White Sox was the American League's leading votegetter in the AllStar balloting by fans to gain the starting firstbase job for the annual interleague game next Tuesday night at Atlanta. Allen received 1,092,758 votes, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday.

title: Explosions Cripple Destroyer
description: SAIGON, July 18  Two heavy explosions of undetermined origin nearly sank the Seventh Fleet destroyer Warrington in the Gulf of Tonkin 20 miles off the coast and the North Vietnamese city of Donghoi yesterday, the United States command here reported today.

title: ORDERS BY SADAT
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, announced today that he had ordered the immediate withdrawal of Soviet military advisers and experts from his country and the placing of Soviet bases and equipment under the exclusive control of Egyptian forces.

title: Local Pollution Charge Is Acted On by State
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz went to court yesterday on behalf of Brooklyn and Queens residents who have complained of horrible, atrocious and intolerable odors in the air over their homes and places of business.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)B. Kuppenheimer & Co., for almost 100 years a manufacturer of men's clothing, is phasing out its operations.

title: RICHARDS GETS LEAD IN PENTATHLON TRIAL
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 (AP)  Army Capt. Charles Richards of Tacoma, Wash., swam into the lead today in the United States Olympic modern pentathlon trials, setting a United States pentathlon record in the 30,0meter swim.

title: Gray Hails Narcotics Drive
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) The acting director of the. F.B.I., L. Patrick Gray 3d, said today that the Government's crackdown on drug traffic was producing solid resultsincluding a shortage of heroin on the street market. He called the antidrug effort the most intensive drive this nation has ever directed against narcotics racketeers.

title: Sealtest President Named
description: John Steiner, president of Sealtest's Dominion Dairies, Ltd., Canada, was named yesterday president of the Kraftco Corporation's Sealtest Foods division. He succeeds John R. Edwards, who is retiring.

title: Israel Refuses to Take a Seat After Dispute in U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18Israel dramatically refused to take a seat at a meeting of the Security Council tonight after her request for discussion of a full exchange of war prisoners held in the Middle East was denied.

title: Michael J. Kingsley. Writer, Led a Division of Longines
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 18Michael J. Kingsley, a mystery writer and president of the Symphonette Purchasing Corporation of Larchmont, a division of the LonginesWittnauer Watch Company, died of heart attack yesterday at his home, 3 Pryer Place. His age was 54.

title: Bond and Vornado Executives Resign
description: Top executives of two major retail chains, each a leader in its respective field, announced their resignations yesterday.

title: Front Page 4  No Title
description: FLOOD FREE JOHNSTOWN. PENN A. IS WELL AND PROSPERING For Details write TribuneDemocial. Advt.

title: An Attempt at Symbolic Contrition for Acts Against Jewish Artists Meets Apathy in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 15  The citizens of this city have turned a deaf ear to an attempt at symbolic contrition for what Germans under Hitler did to their Jewish neighbors and to their artists. The attempt's sponsorsthe city administration and Frankfurt's leading museumare chagrined at what they consider public apathy tinged with hostility.

title: Raymond B. Fosdick Dies at 89; Headed Rockefeller Foundation,
description: Raymond B: Fosdick the League of Nation's first Under Secretary and the president of the Rockefeller Foundation for 13 years, died at his home yesterday in Newtown, Conn., at the age of 89.

title: Domestic Pressure On Sadat Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18President Anwar elSadat's de cision today to ask for withdrawal of Soviet military advisers and experts from Egypt has been attributed by informed Arab quarters here to mounting domestic pressure.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH. DRINK. DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.6 Proof Blended Seolcli Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord, Ltd., Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., July 18Pat Schwab of the Playboy Club carded a oneunderpar 71 today for a tworound total of 141 and a threestroke lead in the 52d New Jersey State open at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 18Speedy Crown gained the rail, Fresh Yankee No. 2 and Une de Mai No. 3 this morning in the drawing of post positions for Saturday night's $150,000 challenge trotting race at Roosevelt Raceway. The victor will earn $100,000. Second place is worth $30,000 and third place $20,000. The winner's share will be the largest in the sport's history. The distance will be PA miles. There will be win betting only.

title: The ChalkPlayers Dirge: A Workout Is Not a Race
description: Because of an overeager exercise boy, a rough trip and the uncertainties of horse racing, thousands of fans at Aqueduct bitterly tasted a chalk playdr's defeat yesterday.

title: Narcotics Official Named
description: ALBANY. July 18 (UPI)Dr. Harold Meiselas, a Long Island psychiatrist with 13 years experience in the drugabuse field, was named vice chairman of the Narcotics Addiction Control Commission today by Governor Rockefeller. The 44yearold physician will continue earning his $40,578ayear salary as one of five members of the policymaking commission.

title: HousetoHouse Fighting Still Raging in Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 19 (AP)South Vietnamese troops reportedly inched closer to the walled Citadel of Quangtri city yesterday as bitter housetohouse fighting continued.

title: Autocrats of Labor
description: Ever since the Teamsters Union convention a year ago it has been obvious that a strange love affair was under way between the Nixon Administration and the nation's biggest uniona union kicked out of the A.F.L.C.I.O. in 1957 because of the corruption of its dominating elements.

title: Many Russians Critical Of Heavy Aid to the Arabs
description: MOSCOW, July 18The reported Egyptian demand for the removal of Soviet military advisers may not be good news to the Kremlin but it is likely to be welcomed by the man in the street who has been traditionally critical of a heavy foreign aid burden while his own rising expectations are left wanting.

title: Stage: Four by Gilroy
description: You come away from Present Tense, four oneacters by Frank D. Gilroy, conscious of words more than anything else. Throughout last evening, down at the Sheridan Square Playhouse, you could almost hear a typewriter's clicketyclack in these tight, terse playlets, staged and performed with the same precise efficiency. With all due respect to a gifted playwright, one viewer wishes he had heard the eveninga comparatively short, 93minute one  over the radio. That's radio, not television.

title: Nixon Campaign Aide Resignsl
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Hugh W. Sloan Jr., treasurer of the finance committee of President Nixon's reelection organization, resigned today to spend more time with his family.

title: U.S. Welcomes Discussion Step
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Treasury said today we look forward to intensified discussion of the [monetary] reform issues and welcome steps to facilitate such discussions.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 18 (Reuters)An Australian dogracing official charged today that the poisoning of 22 greyhounds at Macao's race track on Sunday was the work of an offcourse betting syndicate trying to rig races. N. Smith, manager of a Sydney racing circuit, said the poisoning of the Australianowned dogs was aimed at trainers who would not agree to drug dogs.

title: Executive Changes
description: William J. Bresnan has been elected president and director of Teleprompter Corporation. Mr. Bresnan was formerly vice president and assistant to the chairman and succeeds Hubert J. Schlafly as president. Mr. Schlafly at his own request becomes executive vice president for technological development and continues as a director. Mr. Bresnan is also chairman of the National Cable Television Association.

title: The World Chess Title
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 18 After a nerveracking, wearisome fivehour session of play this evening, Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer drew the fourth game of the world's chess championship match.

title: EDGAR S. FEES EXYALE PROVOST
description: NEW HAVEN, July 18Dr. Edgar S. Furniss, who retired as provost of Yale University in 1957 after 20 years in the office, died last night at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am writing in an attempt to make public a situation that will cause many people great anguish and suffering. Recently the President signed into law a bill granting our senior citizens a 20 per cent raise in Social Security benefits. While this has been applauded by those concerned with the plight of our aged, it will have a detrimental effect on many of those it was designed to help.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CLONMEL, IrelandLike any true killer, I wish to spare the victim, writes the contemporary Irish poet, John Montague and, in a certain sense, this might be called the sentiment of today's I.R.A. (Irish Republican Army) as its two bickering factions continue their intermittent fight for a united Ireland.

title: Death Sentences Commuted
description: NASHVILLE, July 18 (AP)Governor Winfield Dunn said today that he would commute the sentences of all 21 prisoners on Tennessee's death row to 99 years in state prison, This would mean these murderers and rapists on death row would have to serve 30 years before becoming eligible for parole, he added.

title: Cairo's Hope for Recovery Of Sinai Seems Weakened
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Senior military and diplomatic analysts said today that regardless of what part of the Soviet military establishment in Egypt had been directed to leave, one effect would be to weaken, temporarily at least, Cairo's hope of fulfilling its repeated vow to drive Israeli forces out of the Sinai Peninsula.

title: EARNINGS HIGHER AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., yesterday reported higher secondquarter revenues and earnings, and it named Robert W. Haack a director. The big brokerage firm also increased its quarterly dividend slightly.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TOKYO, July 18 (AP)Japan swept a doubleheader from the United States, 53. and 30, today and won the first collegiate baseball World Series, 5 games to 2. A tworun home run by Daisuke Yamashita in the sixth inning decided the opener and in the finale, Takashi Yamaguchi allowed one hit, a single by Fred Lynn of Southern California, in gaining his third series victory.

title: 3d Jail Outbreak In 4 Days Strikes Maryland System
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md. (AP)In Maryland's third penal disturbance since Saturday, inmates at the Prince Georges County Jail took three guards hostage tonight to force a grievance meeting with county officials.

title: Yanks Kline Wins On 3 Homers, 60
description: Steve Kline, whose perfect game came apart at the seams last Friday, pitched a slightly imperfect sixhit shutout last night as the New York Yankees overpowered the Minnesota Twins, 6.0.

title: Passaic Agency Says Lack of Funds Caused Delay in Sewage Changes
description: Officials of the 69yearold Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission have argued in recent years that the cause for delays in meeting Federal antipollution schedules has been a lack of money.

title: GAP IN ARMS COST PUT AT $28BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The General Accounting Office, despite finding measurable progress in the Pentagon's armspurchasing procedures, reported today an increase of $28.7billion between the original and the current cost estimates of 77 weapon systems.

title: Gabriel Gets Operation; 3Week Recovery Seen
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 18 Roman Gabriel and the Los Angeles Rams were breathing easier today.

title: Business Briefs
description: TULSA, Okla., July 18 (AP)The Parker Drilling Company is investigating possible drilling for oil in China, Robert L. Parker, president of the Tulsabased firm, said yesterday.

title: Russians Go Home!
description: President Anwar elSadat's demand for the withdrawal of Soviet advisers from Egypt could be a momentous turning point in the Middle East. If most or all of the estimated 20,000 Soviet military personnel go home, it would substantially reduce the danger of a big power confrontation in the area and dramatically improve the possibilities for an ArabIsraeli settlement.

title: 2 STONES ARRESTED IN AIRPORT FRACAS
description: WARWICK, R. I., Wednesday, July 19 ((AP)Five members of the Rolling Stones traveling party, including Nick Jagger, the lead singer, and Keith Richard, lead guitarist, pleaded innocent last night in District Court to charges of asault on a photographer and obstructing police officers. They were released and left by automobile at about 11:30 P.M. for their scheduled concert in Boston.

title: Ali, Despite Head Cold, Fights in Dublin Tonight
description: DUBLIN, July 18After his light workout today, Muhammad Ali, in a short white satin robe, was lying on the rubbing table in his tiny dressing room at Croke Park when somebody knocked on the door.

title: Rome Police Report Uncovering Network Trafficking in Africans
description: ROME, July 18  The Roche police said today that they had uncovered what they described as a slave trade network that transported black workers from West Africa into Italy and sent them on to jobs in France.

title: Books of The Times
description: Often, for me, the mystery of a suspense novel lies more iu its appeal to its readers than in its plot. Like a doctor, book critic has a professional interest in the particular ailments or dietary imbalances that impel readers to seek easement or relief in this or that kind of literature. I'm talking, of course, of works that have

title: Carrier Engine Damaged
description: SAN DIEGO, July 18 (AP)The attack carrier Ranger sailed into routine crew training exercises on three engines today while the fourth, damaged by possible sabotage, was being repaired, the Navy said.

title: Hollow Win for Allende
description: President Allende's Popular Unity coalition has scheduled a rally in Santiago tomorrow to celebrate election of its Communist candidate to fill a vacancy in Chile's Chamber of Deputies. What the returns from Coquimbo Province actually showed, however, was a loss of 15,000 votes by Popular Unity since the municipal elections last yearhardly an emphatic expression of confidence in the Marxistdominated Government.

title: Western Union Will Offer A Direct Link to Hawaii
description: Western Union International, Inc., announced yesterday that the Federal Power Commission had authorized it to introduce direct overseas communications services to the island of Hawaii.

title: SAMUELS URGES ADDICTS PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Howard J. Samuels, president of New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation and a member of the Mayor's Narcotics Control Council, proposed today a tough, $3billion program that would put this country's half a million heroin addicts under medical care within five years.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Children. The President accepted the resignation of Edward F. Zigler as chief of the Children's Bureau, effective July 31. Mr. Zigler announced Friday that he was leaving his post.

title: Sadat's Next Step
description: No one can say for certain yet what were the reasons behind President Sadat's dramatic demand for the recall of Soviet advisers from Egypt or what the ultimate scope and effects of this action may be. But Egypt's abrupt break with her mentor fits into a pattern of extraordinary worldwide readjustments that are a natural consequence of the move toward bigpower dtente symbolized by President Nixon's visits to Peking and Moscow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a dispatch published on July 3, your correspondent said that President Bhutto was willing to agree that the ceasefire line in Kashmir should gradually become the border between India and Pakistan and wanted a secret agreement with Mrs. Gandhi to this effect.

title: Chemicals Higher
description: All of the diversified chemical companies that reported earnings yesterday showed higher results for the second quarter and first half this year, with the exception of BristolMyers whose profits for the initial six months this year declined 11.2 per cent.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 19 (UPI)The 32foot British sloop Binkie II arrived here today and assumed the lead the handicap racing of The London Observer singlehanded transAtlantic yacht race from Plymouth, England.

title: Soccer Star a Hero to German New Left
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 17  The newest hero of the West German counterculture is a tall and articulate 20yearold athlete who has captured a surprising place for the New Left in the most popular and highly paid group in the countrythe national soccer team.

title: Reputed Mafia Chief Testifies He Never Met Sinatra
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  Raymond Patriarca, reputed Mafia chief in New England, told Congressmen today that he had never had any business dealings with Frank Sinatra and never met the gentleman in my life.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: FLOOD FREE JOHNSTOWN. PENNA. IS WELL AND PROSPERING Fur Details Write TributeDemocrat. Advt.

title: Inquiry Indicates Arson in Burning Of Liner Elizabeth
description: HONG KONG, Julq 19  A marine court of inquiry returned a verdict of probable arson today after a twomonth inquiry into the spectacular blaze that reduced the Queen Elizabeth to a blackened hulk resting on her side in Hong Kong harbor.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS CURBS ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A House education subcommittee approved legislation today that would prohibit Federal courts or agencies from requiring busing to desegregate elementary schools.

title: France Won't Supply Arms
description: PARIS, July 19The French Government said firmly today that it would not attempt to step in where the Russians had stepped out in Egypt.

title: TECHNOLOGY LAG STIRS SCIENTISTS
description: The National Science Foundation, long an important source of funding for basic research far removed from the marketplace, is planning to broaden its scope by conducting experiments of its own to learn how the Government can stimulate lagging technological development in the commercial and industrial sectors of the economy.

title: STOCK SALE SOUGHT BY PENN CENTRAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UPI)Trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced today they had filed a petition with Federal court here seeking approval of a previously announced agreement to sell 95 2/3 per cent of its holding of the common stock of the Pennsylvania Company to a group of 49 banks.

title: Driver's Condition Good
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 19 (AP)Merle Bettenhausen, the race driver who lost his right arm in a crash Sunday, was reported in good condition today at the University of Michigan Hospital.

title: Insurer on London Board
description: The Combined Insurance Company of America said yesterday it had become the first American insurer to list its shares on the London Stock Exchange. Its shares are traded here over the counter.

title: Tanaka Says Revaluation Of Yen  Must Be Avoided
description: TOKYO, July 19Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, said today that another revaluation of the yen must be avoided at all costs.

title: Disney's 'Napoleon'
description: No, "Napoleon and Samantha" aren't Bonaparte and a lady love. They're two winning youngsters, a boy and a girl, with a pet lion and this is a Disney picture.As Disney features go, it's quite nice, though without much snap. The two children, red-headed Johnny Whitaker and especially Jodie Foster as his saucy chum, are appealing. So is their shaggy-maned pet, a big, indolent pussycat who perks up and swats around a mountain lion and a bear (no real rough stuff) on cue.Against the backdrop of some fetching mountain scenery, Will Geer, as a kindly grandpa, dispenses sensibility and wisdom and Michael Douglas plays a sturdy, clean-cut hippie type, for a change. Both actors are excellent. There's some commotion at the end with Douglas and the police racing to a mountain cabin to save the children. They're spunky enough, generally, to take care of themselves. All in all, prodded by Bernard McEveety's direction, the picture coasts along easily on its own genial hominess.Its prime spectacle is a three-way chase. Tearing away in front and squawking like crazy is a white rooster named Doodle-Do pursued by a mountain lion who is pursued by the hero lion, called Major.The children should enjoy this one. They did, audibly, yesterday at the Juliet 2 Theater.Disney's 'Napoleon'

title: F.P.C. Chief Sees Ottawa Shift on Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 John N. Nassikas, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission, has returned from an unannounced visit to Canada with the impression that Ottawa will reverse a 1971 position and resume licensing exports of natural gas to the United States.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DUBLIN, July 19 (UPI)The former European champion, Joe Bugner of Britain, stopped Paul Nielson of Montreal in the sixth round tonight in a preliminary to the Muhammad AliAl Lewis main event.

title: Child Labor Project Stirs Crab Industry
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  In crabmeat picking shed on the Choptank River, 40 women, mostly black, mostly elderly, sat at tables digging the meat out of blue crabs with a knife.

title: A Quieter City?
description: There is reason to hope, at last, that this clamorous, often nerveshattering city will soon have on the books the toughest antinoise code in the nation. The proposed regulations, already reported out by the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection, are expected be approved by the full Council and Mayor Lindsay. They emphatically should be.

title: GAIN CONTINUES IN WHEAT PRICES
description: GAIN CONTINUES IN WHEAT PRICES

title: Personalities: Pilot's Beau Geste
description: Don Zimmer, the manager of the San Diego Padres, took the blame yesterday for the hit by Denny Doyle, the Philadelphia Phillies second baseman, that cost Steve Arlin a nohitter Tuesday night. Doyle bounced a twoout, twostrike single in the ninth inning over the head of Dave Roberts, the rookie third baseman. Tommy Hutton followed with a single and Arlin, who now has tossed three twohitters and two onehitters this season, lost his shutout also as his team won. 51.

title: Russian, Aggressor First Time, Missed a Victory in 4th Game
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP) Boris Spassky came close to defeating Bobby Fischer in the fourth game of their world championship chess match.

title: Connecticut Legislator, 100
description: SOMERS, Conn., July 19 (AP) Louis A. Gowdy, a former; Republican state representative, died last night in a hospital. Hel was 100 years old. Mr. Gowdy served terms in the Legislature, starting in 1914 and 1932. He was a tobacco and dairy farmer most of his life, and had also been a schoolteacher.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Syrian and Lebanese request that Israel release five prisoners.

title: U.S. Officials Pleased at Sadat's Action
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Administration officials privately voiced pleasure today over the removal of at least several thousand Soviet military personnel from Egypt. But they cautioned that the overall meaning of the latest developments in the Middle East was still unclear.

title: VOLUME IS HEAVY IN OCCIDENTAL OIL
description: A public stampede to speculate in the shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has created frenzied trading in the issue in stock markets throughout the United States.

title: Vibes Better Than Ever In Crisp Hampton Show
description: The staples of a Lionel Hampton performance have remained so consistent over the years Flying Home, Mr. Hampton dripping perspiration through a vast grin onto his vibes, Hava Nagilah, even a bit of jumping on a drum if one is handythat his current performance at the Rainbow Grill comes as a pleasant surprise.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday plans for reactivating a potline at its primary aluminum reduction plant at Ravenswood, W. Va.

title: Mets Bow, 50
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19The Mets onceglorious pennant dreams plummeted sharply into near hopelessness tonight when Xrays disclosed that Rusty Staub has a fractured bone in his right hand and the team lost to Los Angeles, 50.

title: Expanding Soviet Trade
description: Back in 1952 Josef Stalin convened an international economics conference in Moscow whose chief goal was to convince American businessmen that billions of dollars in SovietAmerican trade annually was a real possibility. After Stalin, Nikita Khrushchev repeatedly sought persuade this country that such prospects were real and Worth acting upon.

title: Galitzine Provides a Little Sparkle As Rome Hunts for a Relaxed Look
description: ROME, July 19The trouble with normal fashions is they don't make very exciting viewing. Everybody is off the kooky kick, with the result that the fall couture collections are honorable but not exhilarating.

title: Eagleton Going to Hawaii
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Senator Thomas F. Eagleton announced today that he would open his first campaign swing as the Democratic VicePresidential nominee with a speech July 27 in Honolulu to the Retail Clerks International Association convention.

title: OUTSIDERS GRADE POLICE EFFICIENCY
description: In an apparent effort to reduce political influence in the city's Police Department, the International Association of Chiefs of Police has been hired to help determine which commanders should be promoted above the rank of captain.

title: Californians Bow in Rugby
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 19 (AP)The Poverty Bal rugby team defeated the touring California Grizzlies, 2719, at Gisborne today.

title: Israelis Puzzle Over the Impact of Egyptian Move
description: JERUSALEM, July 19Premier Golda Meir and her top advisers today puzzled over the departure of Soviet advisers from Egypt, uncertain whether it marked a major turnaround in the Middle Eastern conflict or only a lesser power struggle in the Egyptian leadership.

title: Dance: Lyric Unfinished Symphony
description: Diversity has been the American Ballet Theater's trademark. Tuesday night at the State Theater, the company seemed to drive this point home with insistence in its final premiere of the season, Peter Van Dyk's pas de deux, Unfinished Symphony.

title: SUSPENSE MARKS CHALLENGE RACE
description: WESTBURY, L. L, July 19As of tonight, no driver had been listed for Fresh Yankee of Canada in next Saturday night's $150,000 challenge race at Roosevelt Raceway against Une de Mai of France and Speedy Crown of the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Of all the transparent exhibitions of slanting the news, your From Saigon Mother (OpEd June 27) takes the biscuit. I admire the esprit de corps among your editors. What a pity some of the spirit cannot be channeled into backing our own soldiers engaged in a war for the selfdetermination of Southeast Asia. It is a battle in which American lives are at stake and the lives of the women and children of our present comrades in arms, defending their land against flagrant invasion.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in share ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies The report includes the following:

title: Heat Wave Proves Killer Among the Chronically III
description: The city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, said yesterday that the heat wave had begun to take its toll among the chronically ill.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 503
description: MOSCOW, July 19  The Soviet Union launched today the unmanned spacecraft Cosmos 503, believed to be a military observation satellite. The craft was placed into an orbit of 189 by 129 miles at an angle Western experts to be characteristic of a series of recoverable reconnaissance satellites.

title: M'GOVERN VOWS AID TO EUROPE DEFENSE
description: ROME, July 19  Senator George McGovern pledged in an interview published in Milan today that if elected President he would guarantee the continued defense of Western Europe.

title: Harry Weetman, Golfer, 51Led British Ryder Cup Team
description: REDHILL, England, July 19 (AP)  Harry Weetman, once known as England's best golfer and captain of the Ryder Cup itearn in 1965, died today following an automobile accident Friday. He was 51 years old.

title: Detroit Appeal
description: FLINT, Mich., July 19 (AP)Judge Stephen J. Roth of United States District Court cleared the way today for an appeal of his finding that Detroit's schools are segregated by law. He also opened avenues of appeal of his order that 52 suburban school districts be included in a desegregation plan.

title: TAYLOR TAKES RUN AT OLYMPIC TRIALS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 19 (AP)Charlies Richards of Tacoma, Wash., held his lead today in the modern pentathlon Olympic trials and Scott Taylor of Portland, Ore., jumped into second place with a superb performance in the 2mile run.

title: Sudan Hails the Move
description: KHARTOUM. The Sudan, July 19President Gaafar alNimeiry and other Sudanese officials were understood today to be elated over President Sadat's decision to send Soviet military advisers home from Egypt.

title: MIG Reported Downed
description: SAIGON, July 19 (UPI)A United States Air Force F4 Phantom jet fighterbomber chased a North Vietnamese MIG21 at low level yesterday, then shot the MIG down 15 miles from Hanoi, military spokesmen said today.

title: Human Service on the Road to Social Progress
description: More and more college graduates (and many among those who never complete college) are entering what is now engagingly called the humanservice professions. Because this coincides with the social rhetoric of recent decades, we tend to assume that large expansion in the number of health, education and welfare professionals means the improvement of the quality of life for the millions of Americans who are the clientele of these workers. The fact is, however, that the socialreform rhetoric has done more to expand the employment opportunities in the service sector of our economy than it has to solve any of the problems it has addressed.

title: Inmate Strike Ceases at Attica; State of Emergency Continues
description: ATTICA, N. Y., July 19 The three day inmate strike at the State Correctional Facility here, during which as many as threefourths of the 1,200 prisoners refused to eat or work, ended today.

title: A Town in Mekong Delta Is Battered as Vietcong Pressure Mounts
description: VINHKIM, South Vietnam, July 18Ho Van Bao hurriedly stuffed his squealing baby pigs into a big shipping basket.

title: Japan's Premier Says He Is Planning To Negotiate New Ties With Chinese
description: TOKYO. July 19  Kakuei Tanaka, Japan's vigorous new Premier, declared today that he was preparing to negotiate a new Japanese relationship with China, which he called the great diplomatic issue of this country.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Howard Johnson Company said it expected to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offer of up to 1,150,000 shares of split stock by the estate of Howard D. Johnson and certain members of the Johnson family. A twoforone split of the company's common will become effective Aug. 7 to holders of record July 10, the company reported. The registration offer is to be filed in midAugust and the offering will be made in early September.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Many have said that the Democratic convention was more representative than ever before. Is this true?

title: SAMUEL J. SOLOMON
description: Samuel J. Solomon, former executive vice president for merchandise of M. Wile & Co., a division of the Hart Schaffner & Marx clothing concern, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived on Adams Place in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Seaver and McGraw Are AllStar Pitchers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP)  Manager Danny Murtaugh of the National League AllStar team has named nine pitchers to next Tuesday's game, including Steve Blass, who pitched Murtaugh's Pittsburgh Pirates to victory in the seventh game of last year's World Series.

title: NEW POWER CUTS PLAGUE BROOKLYN WITH BROWNOUTS
description: The failure of Consolidated. Edison Company feeder and distribution cables last night reduced power voltage and blacked out buildings in scattered areas of a wide part of southern Brooklyn and in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Film: Eastwood Western
description: For perhaps its first half-hour, John Sturges's new Western, "Joe Kidd," looks surprisingly good. It seems restrained, relaxed, unfashionably out of the current mode in its commitment to people and horses rather than to sadistic monsters and machines. Nothing remarkable, but modestly decenta feeling that persists, with continually diminishing assurance, almost until the climax, when everything is thrown away in a flash of false theatrics, foolish symbolism and what I suspect is sloppy editing.That "everything" is indeed a fairly conventional story about land rights in New Mexico at the turn of the century. There is an evil land baron (Robert Duvall), a leader of the people (John Saxon), a beautiful woman of high principle (Stella Garcia) and an enigmatic loner (Clint Eastwood) who really determines the action. In a very mild way, the film supports the rights of a dispossessed Mexican minority. But no matter what the particular sympathies, politics in Westerns tends toward autocracy, and "Joe Kidd" ends with Clint Eastwood as judge, jury, and executioner in a killing that is of course supposed to change the moral nature of the world.Like so many Western heroes, Joe Kidd figures even in his own time as an anachronism  powerful through his instincts mainly, and through the ability of everybody else, whether in rage or gratitude, to recognize in him a quality that must be called virtue. The great value of Clint Eastwood in such a position is that he guards his virtue very cannily, and in the society of "Joe Kidd," where the men still manage to tip their hats to the ladies, but just barely, all the Eastwood effects and mannerisms suggest a carefully preserved authenticity.I think it is a very good performance in context.
