Ultimately, it is the only real point of interest to "Joe Kidd," and especially interesting because in recent years the Eastwood point of view has appeared mostly as ancillary to the larger vision of the director Don Siegel ("Dirty Harry," "Beguiled," etc.). What emerges here is a kind of authoritative normalcy, an actor's gift to an ordinary film that at least gives him reasonable space to breathe."Joe Kidd," which also offers the good cinematography of Bruce Surtees, and a quite notable collection of bad guys, beginning with Don Stroud, who are set up only to be put down by Clint Eastwood, opened yesterday at three Trans-Lux theaters.

title: Rangers Spur Dollar War; Give Park $200,000 Pact
description: Brad Park, who played three years ago for about $12,000, has agreed to a Ranger contract that will pay him about $200,000 a season for the next five seasons.

title: Property Given Texas City
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 19 (UPI)The Federal Government turned over three 122yearold buildings and two acres to this city today under President Nixon's legacy of parks program. Herbert G. Klein, director of communications for the White House, made the presentation to Mayor John Gatti at the downtown site of the buildings, constructed in 1850 as part of the old San Antonio arsenal.

title: Illinois Bank in Taiwan
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Compuny of Chicago today announced plans to open a fullservice branch office in Taipei, Taiwan. The Taipei branch, the first to be established there by a Chicago bank, is expected to be in operation by late 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: TV: David Steinberg Bows on C.B.S.
description: The David Steinberg Show is the latest addition to the list of summer series that have been bobbing about in a television sea of repeats. For five weeks Mr. Steinberg's show will be replacing reruns of The Carol Burnett Show on the Columbia Broadcasting System. The first instalment, with Ed McMahon and Leslie Uggams as guests, was shown last night at 8 o'clock.

title: Council Unit's Vote On Homosexual Bill Rejects It 2d Time
description: A controversial bill barring discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was voted down again yesterday by the City Council's Committee on General Welfare.

title: How People Get to Work
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Next to the automobile, the most popular way for Americans to get to work is walking, the Census Bureau reports, The bureau said yesterday that 5.7 million persons reported in 1970 that they regularly walked to work. The bureau said 59.7 million said they drove or rode in a car to their jobs, 4.2 million reported riding buses or streetcars, 1.8 million rode suhways or elevated commuter trains, 502,000 used the railroads and 296,000 took cabs.

title: Letters on Vega Recall
description: DETROIT, July 19 (AP)Chevrolet has begun sending letters to owners of 500,000 Chevrolet Vegas, asking them to take their cars to dealers for inspection and possible replacement of rearaxle shaftsat the expense of General Motors Corporation. The recall, announced July 3, involves virtually all 1971 and 1972 Vegas built prior to last May 5. Only (models with Positraction rear axles are excluded.

title: Stroot Leads in Decathlon As W. German Track Begins
description: MUNICH, July 19 (UPI)Eberhart Stroot and Horst Beyer passed the 4,000point mark in the decathlon today as the West German track and field championships opened.

title: MSGR. AUGUSTINE HICKEY
description: BOSTON, July 19 (AP)Msgr. Augustine F. Hickey, pastor of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge for nearly 40 years and former vicar general of the Boston Archdiocese, died yesterday. He was 88 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In Rachel Hays July 12 letter there was a quotation wrongly attributed to Amos and Jesus. This is a quotation from Micah, Chapter VI, Verse 8, as follows: It hath been told thee, 0 man, what is good and what the Lord doth require of thee; Only to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: An ordinance prohibiting the carrying of opened spray paint cans may help in preventing the spread of graffiti, but will this ordinance apply, too, to someone carrying a bundle of pasteon stickers? Or is a politico's printed name deemed less offensive than juvenile's handwritten name?

title: DR. EUGENE CLARK, 67, PATHOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Eugene Clark, a pathologist, cardiologist and former assistant medical examiner here, died Tuesday at his home, 201 East 79th Street. He was 67 years old and had recently retired.

title: Dr. William T. Pecora, 59, Dies; Under Secretary of the Interior
description: WASHINGTON. July 19Dr. William T. Pecora, the Under Secretary of the Interior and a geologist of worldwide reputation, died today at the George Washington University Hospital. He had undergone surgery for diverticulitisan intestinal disorderlast month. His age was 59.

title: Embarrassing Falter
description: BANGOR, Me., July 19 (UPI) A hearing on a request by the Bangor Hydroelectric Company to increase its rates was delayed for 20 minutes yesterday because of a power failure.

title: Nixon to Meet Governors
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) President Nixon will have a breakfast conference tomorrow for 13 Governors, a bipartisan group, here to testify before the Senate Finance Committee on general revenue sharing.

title: Labor Gets Set to Lose
description: WASIIINGTON, July 19  History provides no support for the political strategy which the leadership of organized labor seems determined to adopt in this Presidential campaign.

title: YANKS 7RUN 4TH HELPS ROUTTWINS
description: The New York Yankees went to heroic lengths yesterday in their summertime campaign to win back the affections of their straying public. They gave away 13,600 Tshirts to entice the next generation into the Stadium and then treated them to a 133 mauling of the Minnesota Twins.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, accused the news media today of trying to cover up the endorsement of Senator George McGovern for President by the 14member executive board of The Newspaper Guild. He also demanded that the 33,000member organization Immediately make clear its position on the matter.

title: Building Contracts Up 8%
description: New construction contracts at midyear are valued at $86billion, or 8 per cent above the total recorded a year ago, the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw Hill publications reported yesterday. Contracts for residential buildings came to $38billion, an increase of 9 per cent. Nonresidential building contracts totaled $27.65billion, up 8 per cent over the level of a year ago.

title: The Talk of Grover, Colo.
description: GROVER, ColoThe pattern seems always the same this time of year in the high plains east of the Rocky Mountains. Mornings break with a cloudless blue sky and the humidity a little high. The hot sun beats down. By midday, the moisture has begun to gather in puffy cumulus clouds over the eastern face of the Rockies. The wetness comes from the Gulf of Mexico, riding southeast winds up the front face of the mountains.

title: Senate Rejects Compromise On a Minimum Wage Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Senators on both sides of the issue voted down a compromise today on a bill to raise the minimum wage and extend its coverage to 8.4 million more workers.

title: Man of the Met
description: In the nineteen months since the announcement his surprise appointment, Goeran Gentele had impressed many people as exactly the kind of general manager needed by the Metropolitan Opera at a critical stage its existence. His zest for innovation and for modernizing the repertory, his conviction that opera had change with the times, his emphasis on the theatrical aspects of the art had fueled rising excitement and keen anticipation for the formal launching of the Gentele era at the Met this fall.

title: BUCKLEY SAYS AGNEW IS NEEDED ON TICKET
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Senator James L. Buckley, differing sharply with New York's other Senator, Jacob K. Javits, said today that dropping Vice President Agnew from the Republican ticket this fall would clearly hurt President Nixon's reelection chances.

title: Scott Panel to Reduce the Scope Of Inquiry Into City Government
description: The Scott Commission will drastically reduce the scope of its inquiry because of lack of funds, time and Lindsay administration obstacles, Stuart N. Scott, chairman of the state commission to study the city's government, said yesterday.

title: Spassky and Fischer Play With Intense Drive to Win
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 19  As they say in poker, the players came to play.

title: Water Is Cut in Many Buildings As Hydrants Are Turned On
description: Water supply in apartment houses and other buildings in several parts of the city was slowed to a trickle or shut off yesterday as a side effect of the heat wave.

title: Democratic Aide to Quit
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 19 (UPI)Stanley Greigg, deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he planned to resign. Mr. Greigg, former Sioux City Mayor and Congressman, told television station KMEG that the election of a new party chairman to succeed Lawrence F. O'Brien had put his job in doubt. He said he definitely planned to stay with O'Brien but refused to speculate in what capacity.

title: SCHWAB ROLLS UP 4STROKE MARGIN
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 19Pat Schwab of the Playboy Club carded a oneoverpar 73 for a threeround total of 214 and a fourstroke lead in the 52d New Jersey State open golf tournament today.

title: I.R.A. AND BRITISH SEEK NEW TRUCE
description: LONDON, July 19  British officials and members of the Irish Republican Army's militant Provisional wing are conducting secret talks in Belfast and London in an effort to work out a new ceasefire in Northern Ireland, knowledgeable sources said today.

title: News of Dogs
description: The need for a big guard dog led a surgeon and his wife to the royal dog of Francethe Great Pyrenees. One of the whitecoated animals, adopted as court dogs in the 17th century and first brought to America by the Marquis de Lafayette, has played an important role as protector and pet in the Connecticut household of Dr. Joseph Ventimiglia and his wife, Edith. With my husband frequently being called away at night to perform emergency surgery, we decided to buy a dog who would be good with the children and protect at the same time, said Mrs. Ventimiglia. We read descriptions of big breeds and felt the Pyr would fill our needs. That was 15 years ago and we've never regretted our decision.

title: Racial Split in Pontiac
description: PONTIAC, Mich. July 19 (AP) The parents of children bused under court order to achieve racial integration in public schools here remain split down racial lines over the program's success, according to a survey just completed.

title: Books of The Times
description: Dean Gooderham Acheson served as Secretary of State during some of the most formative years of the postwar era. Nowadays, when Presidents have a penchant for personal diplomacy and rely on special White House emissaries to carry out their most delicate foreign policy negotiations, Acheson stands out in contrast: He was his own Secretary of State. Quite simply, in Gaddis Smith's words, Dean Acheson's power was greater than any other Secretary of State in the twentieth century. In this book, Smith, a professor of history at Yale, has given us not biography of Acheson, but a study in his exercise of that power.

title: Koreans Set Aug. 5 Date for Full Red Cross Parley
description: SEOUI South Korea, July 19  Negotiators for the Red Cross organizations of North Korea and South Korea today fixed on Aug, 5 as the date when a big delegation will travel from the capital of one to the capital of the other to discuss the prospects for visits by family members between the two Koreas.

title: Airlines Still in Red
description: American Airlines, Inc., and Trans World Airlines both announced yesterday higher earnings for the quarter ended June 30 and reduced losses for the first six months of 1972.

title: Man in the News
description: Just after Anwar elSadat succeeded the late Gamal Abdel Nasser as Egypt's President nearly two years ago, he and his second wife moved into a modest home along the Nile River in Cairo, only a block from the residence of the Soviet Ambassador. Jokes abounded that a tunnel linked the two dwellings, so close was relationship between the two nations. Now the 53yearold Presi dent Sadat has ordered the Soviet Union to withdraw its military advisers and experts from Egypt.

title: Harold Miller Dead at 52; H.U.D. Rehabilitation Expert
description: Harold Miller, a rehabilitation specialist for the Department of Housing and Urban! Development, died Tuesday night in an Elmira (N.Y.) Hospital, where he had been in a coma since suffering a stroke July 9 while inspecting flooddamaged homes in the recent disaster area. He was 52 years old and lived at 1921 Bay Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: GENERAL ASSESSES SOVIET MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Gen. John D. Ryan, Air Force Chief of Staff, told a Senate committee today that United States intelligence estimates of the number of offensive nuclear missiles that the Soviet Union would have in 1977 were roughly equivalent to the number permitted under the recently concluded arms accord.

title: S. Z. WESTERFIELD JR., U.S. ENVOY IN LIBERIA
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 19 (AP)Dr. Samuel Z. Westerfield Jr., United States Ambassador to Liberia, died last evening at his home here.

title: Three Orioles Chosen
description: BOSTON, July 19 (AP)Manager Earl Weaver picked Detroit's Mickey Lolich and three of his Baltimore Orioles on the pitching staff for the American League in the AllStar game.

title: Congress Urged to Protect Newsman Rights on Sources
description: MIAMI, July 19 (AP)The InterAmerican Press Association asked today that Congress enact legislation that would allow newsmen to protect the anonymity of their sources.

title: 4 More Die in Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 19 (AP)  Bombs and gunfire claimed four more lives in Northern Ireland today.

title: Advertising: New Chief at Free
description: Stever Aubrey, a top man at J. Walter Thompson, the world's largest nency, has resigned to become chairman and chief executive of F. William Free & Co.

title: Indians Sue Railroad
description: RENO, Nev., July 19 (UPI)A Piute Indian tribe has filed a $1million suit against the Southern Pacific Railroad to recover all railroad property on their reservation. The Pyramid Lake Indians said in a Federal Court action yesterday that any tribal grants to the railroad were void because it had never paid the Indians full compensation for the desert land.

title: Seweryn Szulc, a Leader In Rio's Polish Community
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19Seweryn Szulc, a Polish emigre who was known as a sort of unofficial father to Rio De Janeiro's substantial Polish community, was buried yesterday in the Hebrew cemetery. He was 71 years old.

title: Tax Disparity Among Concerns Called as Wide as for Individuals
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Congress received today a new study of corporation taxes showing as wide a disparity in taxes paid as among individuals  with some corporations paying nearly half their profits in taxes and others apparently paying no taxes on their profits at all.

title: Chapin Is Named Acting Director by Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera still reeling from the blow of Goeran Gentele's death, has named his righthand man, Schuyler G. Chapin, as acting general manager with instructions to carry out Mr. Gentele's already firmly set plans for the coming season.

title: DRUG CHIEF TO ASK METHADONE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 19John E. Ingersoll, director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, said today that the agency would soon ask Congress for new drugcontrol laws to deal with the increased use of methadone as a substitute for heroin.

title: Dr. P. J. Linden Weds Miss Mager
description: Miss Janine Amy Mager, a publicity associate in the of Cotton Incorporated, was married here yesterday evening to Dr. Peter James Linden, a senior surgical resident at New York Hospital, where public relations department he is preparing for a specialization in plastic and reconstructive surgery.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Yelberton Abraham Tittle retired as Giant quarterback, the grateful Giants bestowed on him the rare honor of retiring his number with him. Thus was No. 14 removed from the rolls. Emotional man that he is, Y. A. was almost in tears when his uniform jersey was handed him as a permanent memento while the then vast army of Giant worshipers glowed in almost unanimous approval.

title: Saigon Says Foe Fails to Thwart Drive on Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 20 (AP) North Vietnamese infantrymen and tanks counterattacked in Quangtri yesterday but reportedly failed to halt a slow South Vietnamese paratrooper advance toward the provincial capital's walled Citadel.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ROCHESTER, July 19 (AP)Two Canadians accused of plotting to fix harness races with a laser beam pleaded innocent today in Federal Court. Sollie Viner, 45 years old, also known as Stan Winters, and Martin Goodman, 52, both of the Toronto area, were charged July 8 with foreign travel in aid of racketeering enterprises.

title: Kent State Victim's Father Loses Ohio Court Decision
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19 (UPI)The Ohio Supreme Court, overturned an appeals court decision today and said the father of a Kent State University coed killed by National Guard troops cannot sue the state for alleged negligent and wanton misconduct.

title: MARKET PRICES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Occidental Petroleum hit pay dirt in Wall Street again yesterday as a brisk market rally pushed stock prices higiier.

title: Poormouthing Aid
description: The warning by former Treasury Secretary John Connally on his world tour of seventeen developing nations that the United States can no longer afford its earlier generosity in foreign aid recalls the broken record he played to the developed countries during last year's world monetary crisis. The poverty plea is doubly unconvincing now in the light of statistics, just published by the United Nations, showing that the gap between the world's poor and rich nations is steadily widening.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Chemical Bank and Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment advisory firm, announced jointly yesterday that they were discussing the creation of a combined management service designed for large corporate pension and profitsharing funds.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A sharp decline in export orders received by the large Japanese trading companies was reported today by the United StatesJapan Trade Council here.

title: Coach Eases Up on Giants
description: MONMOUTH, N. J., July 19 Coach Alex Webster, who has been running a tough, hardworking New York Giant football camp, relented today.

title: Roundup: Aaron's 659th Matches a Ruthian Record
description: Henry Aaron tied Babe Ruth's home run record last night. No, no, not THAT record.

title: 20Acre Berlin Sector Sold by East to West
description: BERLIN, July 19  West Berlin today bought a piece of land from the East Germans at the Potsdamer Platz, in the heart of the city.

title: U.S. SHIFTS POLICY AND ACTS TO PROP VALUE OF DOLLAR
description: In a major change of policy, the United States Government intervened in the foreign exchange markets yesterday to protect the value of the dollar.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your reporters, columnists and commentators make a great point of stressing, as a serious weakness of the McGovern campaign, the fact that the entrenched Democratic city, county and state machines and the entrenched labor hierarchy are disaffected. These observations reflect, I believe, a complete misjudgment of the nature of this election.

title: 3 CZECH LIBERALS REPORTED JAILED
description: PRAGUE, July 19 (Reuters)  Unofficial court sources said today that three Czechoslovak liberals had received jail sentences of up to 28 months on subversion charges.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: FlyRodding
description: Beginner or expert, Joe Brooks's Trout Fishing (Harper & RowOutdoor Life; 302 pages, illustrated, $8.95) belongs in your library if you are a fly fisherman.

title: MRS. RICHARD A. MEDINA
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 19 Mrs. Dorothy Wood Medina, widow of Richard A. Medina, retired head of J. A. Medina Co., New York coffee importers, died yesterday In Bridgeport Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 3030 Park Avenue.

title: U.S. Chess Unit Presses Challenge on Forfeit
description: The forfeit point awarded to Boris Spassky in the second game of the world championship chess match between Spassky and Bobby Fischer is still being challenged.

title: WHOOPING COUGH FOUND IN ADULTS
description: A report of two outbreaks of whooping cough among the staff of the University of Colo rado Medical Center has focused attention on a paradoxical situation in which doctors are diagnosing cases of the childhood disease among al small but growing number of adolescents and adults.

title: Bridge: Jeff Rubens, Michael Becker Win the Von Zedtwitz Again
description: The longest competition in the New York bridge season ended Tuesday night when Jeff Rubens and Michael Becker both of New York; Bill Passell of Ardsley, N. Y., and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains won the double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy.

title: Bobick Gets Fast Knockout In Debut at Olympic Trials
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., July 19 (AP)Duane Bobick, from Bowles, Minn., knocked out Clifford Stephens with a thunderclap right hand at 61 seconds of the first round tonight in a heavyweight bout at the United States Olympic boxing trials.

title: Business Briefs
description: Ireland's position in world markets is improving. Figures released yesterday by the Irish Export Board indicated Irish exports last year rose to $1.28billion, increasing 15.2 per cent in value and 7.5 per cent in volume, to exceed the board's own minimum 1971 target by $43million. This year, exports are estimated to reach $1.46billion.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CLOSE UNCHANGED
description: Stocks struggled to rise yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but after prices jumped in the morning they turned down late in the session.

title: New Cancer Board Member
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) President Nixon named today Joseph H. Ogura of St. Louis, to the National Cancer Advisory Board. He is a professor at the Washington University School of Medicine. He will serve the remainder of the term expiring March 9. 1974, succeeding the late Wendell G. Scott.

title: Kissinger Meets Secretly With Hanoi Aides in Paris
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The White House and the North Vietnamese Government announced simultaneously today that Henry A. Kissinger had conferred secretly in Paris during the day with Hanoi negotiators.

title: STATE LOOKS INTO THERAPY CENTER
description: A former school psychologist whose previous sortie into private practice was described by the president of the Suffolk County Psychological Society as a clear violation of the ethical code is now running a therapy and teaching center offering marriage counseling, educational testing and individual and group therapy.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BAYONA, Spain, July 19 (AP)Five more yachts completed the BermudatoBayona race today, bringing to 10 the number of finishers, all but two of them from the United States. The lastest American finishers were Aura, a 49foot Class B sloop owned by Wallace J. Stenhouse of Chicago; Phantom, a 49foot Class B sloop of the Biscayne Bay Club of Miami, skippered by Ralph Ryder, and Charisma, a Class B 46foot sloop, sailed by Jessie Phillips of Dayton, Ohio.

title: DEMOCRATS LOSE KEY HOUSE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Democratic leaders suffered a stunning defeat today when the House killed their emergency program to trim unemployment through $5billion in grants for local water and sewer facilities.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. George C. Wallace underwent surgery in Birmingham to drain an abscess near one of the abdominal bullet wounds he received when he was shot at a Maryland rally in May. The Alabama Governor was said to be doing fine after the surgery, the third he has had to heal his wounds.

title: NURSING HOMES CERTIFIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Eightyeight per cent of the nation's 7,000 nursing homes that receive Medicaid funds have been granted Federal certification under a new program, the White House announced today.

title: SATULLO SWEEPS 4TH RACE IN ROW
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 19  Sandy Satullo of Cleveland won the Hennessy Grand Prix today, but that is only half the drama. He had never entered an ocean power boat race before last February, has never lost a race in four outings and today was his 50th birthday.

title: CEAUSESCU ASKS CONFIDENCE VOTE
description: BUCHAREST, July 19President Nicolae Ceausescu appealed today for a vote of confidence from the Rumaniab Communist party in the face of mounting opposition within the party's upper ranks.

title: A Panel for Judges
description: The case for the appointment, rather than the election, of judges seems to us to be persuasive. Voters stumbling through crowded ballots cannot hope to know the qualifications or lack of them of most of the candidates for judicial posts, who normally owe their nominations to entrenched party organizations. Judicial posts are part of their dispensable patronage, and too often the test applied is less genuine merit than longterm service in partisan causes.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader and one of Mayor Lindsay's severest critics, said, yesterday that he would propose a major role for the Mayor in Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 19An article published today in Nhan Dan, the official press agency of North Vietnam, praised Senator George McGovern as representing the change demanded by the American people.

title: Bus Plunge in Brazil Kills 30
description: BELEM, Brazil, July 19 (UPI) Thirty persons were killed yesterday when a bus fell off a ferry ramp into the Capim River, and an unknown number are missing, the police said today. The accident occurred at Sao Domingos, 250 miles southeast of this Amazon delta port.

title: Women's Lib
description: The women's liberation movement must have had some effect practically everywhere on this troubled globe by now with the possible exception of the Gobi Desert. But in "Stand Up and Be Counted," which turned up at local houses yesterday, the women's justifiable push for parity with males is merely good for some pithy, explicit dialogue, a few gags and giggles and fewer constructive answers. As an examination of current revolution. "Stand Up and Be Counted" erratically skips between comedy and serious causes with somewhat less than impressive impact either way.The hearts and the causes of all concerned appear to be in the right places. In essence, however, Jackie Cooper, who is making his feature directorial debut here from the script of Bernard Slade, a newcomer to movies, focuses mainly on women's lib as it affects several families in photogenic Denver, where the movie was largely shot in lovely color. The disturbing issues are still disturbing.As a fashion magazine writer sent to cover the lib scene in Denver, her home town, Jacqueline Bisset is decorative but as unbelievable in the role as her English accent. And her unresolved liaison with Gary Lockwood, as an airline pilot, is not an endorsement of the movement either. Lee Purcell, as her militantly feminist sister who arranges to become pregnant without romance or marriage, and Anne Francine, as their wise, indulgent mother, do have some incisive moments.Some natural portrayals are contributed by Steve Lawrence, in his debut as a worried ad man, and Loretta Swit, as the mother of his four children who is struggling for identity as a fashion designer. Effective too are Stella Stevens as a sexpot wife and Hector Elizondo as her husband, a roughhewn lingerie tycoon who is forced to appreciate her as something more than a sex object.However, an outspoken gab fest among the dissident distaffers and several demonstrations do more than family strife to dispel a remark in the film that lib is simply "seven women with hairy legs and a genius for getting on the Johnny Carson Show." Unfortunately, the good fight still needs fighting after everyone here has been counted.

title: FRANK CILENTO, 50, TIMES AD MANAGER
description: Frank Cilento, national automotive advertising manager of The New York Times and an assistant to the national advertising manager, died Tuesday evening in Nyack Hospital after having accidentally suffered a gunshot wound in his home at 49 Quaker Lane, Pearl River, N. Y. He was 50 years old.

title: All Stops Lewis in 11 Rounds
description: DUBLIN, July 19Weakened by a head cold and perhaps victimized by an alleged long count, Muhammad Ali didn't stop AI (Blue) Lewis until the 11th round tonight in a brawl that enthralled an estimated 20,000 spectators at Ireland's first major prize fight in nearly four decades.

title: Executive Changes
description: G. Thomas Ludwig has been named executive vice presidentproduction and engineering of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc.

title: Ghana Rulers Decree Death for Participants in Any Coup Attempt
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 19Ghana's military government has issued a subversion decree calling for the execution by firing squad of anyone convicted of attempting to overthrow the ruling council by unlawful means.

title: CONNORS, STOCKTON ADVACE IN TENNIS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors and Dick Stockton scored easy victories today to reach the semifinals of the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament.

title: Funds for Brooke Flow In
description: BOSTON, July 19 (AP)The campaign for the reelection of Senator Edward W. Brooke has drawn more than $320,000 in contributions, according to records in the office of Secretary of the Commonwealth John F. X. Davoren.

title: MADISON OFFICIAL SUSPENDED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had suspended Edward A. Merkle, chief executive officer of the Madison Fund, Inc., from association with any investment company, brokerdealer or investment adviser for 60 days. The action came after an S.E.C. finding that he had violated Federal securities laws as head of the New Yorkbased investment concern.

title: SendOff Is Careful
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19Travelers from Cairo reported here today that Soviet advisers in Egypt have been arriving in Alexandria since Monday, preparing to embark for home. The advisers have arrived in buses and military trucks under strict security provided by the Egyptian forces, according to the travelers, who said that the Egyptians have been careful to treat the departing Russians well.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: PHYSICIAN PLEADS GUILTY IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, July 19Dr. E. Wyman Garrett pleaded guilty in Essex County Superior Court today to a reduced charge of interfering with a New York Times reporter at a turbulent Board of Education meeting here 15 months ago.

title: Housing Starts Continue at a High Level
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Housing starts continued at high level in June and the nation's factories have begun to operate at a slightly higher proportion of their capacity, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Decline for Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  Mutualfund redemptions exceeded sales again in June for the fifth consecutive month, but not redemptions were at their lowest level since February, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Westinghouse Expecting A $5Billion Sales Mark
description: Sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation this year will be around the $5billion mark  a significant milestone in our climb from the $2billion plateau where we were perched for so many years, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, told a special meeting of security analysts and the press yesterday.

title: Acupuncture Clinic Here Closes Down
description: An acupuncture clinic that opened here one week ago closed down yesterday after the State Department of Education, which regulates the practice of medicine, issued an opinion that the nonphysicians who were administering the needle therapy at the clinic were practicing meditine.

title: Needham's Chief Quits
description: The Needham Packing Company announced last night the resignation, effective immediately, of Jerry P. Kozney as president and chief executive officer. The posts were given to James R. McDonald, already chairman. The company earlier reported a drop in earnings.

title: Gentele's Wife and Daughter Are Recovering From Injuries in Crash
description: ROME, July 19Arrangements were being made today to return to Sweden the bodies of Goeran Gentele, director of the Metropolitan Opera, and two of his daughters. They were killed yesterday in an automobile crash on the island of Sardinia.

title: Cooper Calls for an Unconditional U.S. Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Senator John Sherman Cooper, la leader of antiwar Republicans in the Senate, proposed today the unconditional withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina within four months.

title: Thomas P. Coleman. 54, AP Broadcast Executive
description: FREEPORT, L. I., July 19 (AP) Thomas P. Coleman, a former broadcast executive for The Associated Press, died today. He was 54 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Attentive readers of The Times will note some serious recent developments concerning the fate of dissenting intellectuals in the Soviet Union. On June 21, Pyotr I. Yakir, an outspoken advocate of civil rights, was arrested. On July 7, Valery Chalidze, founder of the Human Rights Committee with A. D. Sakharov, was ordered by the K.G.B. to cease his activities. Such orders are usually a prelude to arrest. The cancellation last week of Mstislav Rostropovich's concert tour in Salzburg, Austria, signifies a renewed attack on this spokesman for cultural and intellectual freedom.

title: W. B. HAMILTON, DUKE HISTORIAN
description: DURHAM, N. C. July 19Dr. William B. Hamilton, historian and author who taught at Duke University for 36 years, died of a heart attack Monday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: Irving Wallace's 'The Man':Political Movie Stars James Earl Jones
description: "The Man," which opened yesterday at the Cinema I Theater, is the triumphantly short (93-minute) film version of Irving Wallace's almost endless (actually, 768-page) novel about the first black President of the United States.Douglass Dilman (James Earl Jones), who is the president pro tempore of the Senate because the Vice President has suffered a stroke, becomes President after the incumbent and the Speaker of the House are killed while attending a summit conference in Germany. How? When a ceiling in their 600-year-old Frankfurt palace falls on their heads.At one time or another most of us have seen ceilings fallin kitchens, in living rooms, in bathroomsusually because of faulty plumbing. It's no fun and always a mess, with the plaster dust and all. But this one was obviously a whopper, being high and probably marble.It's an indication of the difficulty I had in relating to "The Man" that for the rest of the movie, which only exploits ceilings as melodramatic conveniences, I kept wondering what really happened. Hadn't anyonethe C.I.A. or somebodychecked out the palace? Had the Russians been fiddling around? Did a loo leak? I simply couldn't buy the casual explanation: "Well, you know those old palaces, Jim."About halfway through "The Man," one comes to realize that, in its own unwitting way, the film is much more interested in contemplating incompetence than in presenting any ideas about politics, race relations, international diplomacy, personal ambition, courage, or what-have-you.On its surface, "The Man" is the story of how President Dilman, a former university professor and an inconsequential Senator, rightfully claims his office by being more shrewd than the members of his Cabinet and by being man enough to admit his mistakes. (The novel, although written in 1963, seems more truly to be a souvenir of the Eisenhower years.)What is most memorable about the film, however, is not the story, which doesn't make too much sense, but the supremely dopey dialogue, as when Dilman's daughter berates him for not being militant enough: "You must have conned me with your soft voice and your metaphors!" And especially the incompetence.When the news of the fatal accident arrives from Germany, no one in the Cabinet seems to know who's in the line of succession. At the end of the movie, President Dilman, having proved his all-American mettle in a nasty confrontation with local blacks, prepares to go onto the convention floor to fight for nomination by his own party (never, of course, identified), as if that were the custom.If "The Man" were a better movie, it might possibly be offensive. It isn't. It's silly and innocent, and when the band strikes up "Hail to the Chief," it invites an idiotic tear.Rod Serling, who wrote the story and screenplay, has reworked and recut the original novel as if he were a tailor remodeling an old-fashioned suit to conform with current fashions, and Joseph Sargent, whose direction of "The Forbin Project" I admired, has made sure that it's all in focus.In addition to Mr. Jones, who persists in being an interesting actor no matter what, the cast includes a couple of members of Otto Preminger's stock company, Burgess Meredith and Lew Ayres, and some others too nondescript to mention.

title: Most of Rhode Island Deprived Of Electrical Power After Storm
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 19 Electrical power was shut down in Providence, its suburbs and most of Rhode Island for more than an hour tonight after a severe rainstorm struck southern New England. Parts of southeastern Massachusetts also were blacked out.

title: RIGGINS IS HOPING FOR 2D BIG YEAR
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 19  That John Riggins has been having trouble getting into his New York Jets helmet is not because his head is swollen over last season's accomplishments.

title: Holmes Man Linked to 2 Bank Burglaries
description: Two teams of burglars hired a Holmes Protection Company maintenance man to disconnect the alarm systems at two banks here, enabling them to get away with $315,000 in cash and jewelry, the Federal Government charged yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Senator George McGovern's appearance July 12 before dissident elements in the lobby of the Doral Hotel was indeed a remarkable event. After having prevailed upon local police not to break up this peaceful group who sincerely felt disillusioned by the wording of a statement on Vietnam, Senator McGovern risked further embarrassment and confusion by agreeing to submit to such questioning.

title: Mrs. Binh to Visit Cuba
description: MIAMI. July 19 (AP)Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh will head a Vietcong delegation to Cuba this weekend to attend a rally, commemorating the start of the Castro revolution, the Havana radio said today.

title: Police, Seeking Crime Figures Named By His Chauffeur, Film Eboli Cortege
description: The police were hunting yeserday for gangland figures named by the chauffeur of Thomas Eboli, the Mafia leader who was slain on Sunday.

title: McGovern Goes for a Ride on His 50th Birthday
description: CUSTER, S.D., July 19Senator George McGovern celebrated his 50th birthday today by riding horseback through the Ponderosa pines at his Black Hills vacation retreat.

title: Guatemalans Report a Culture Gap': Too Much Mexico, Too Little Marimba
description: GUATEMALA, July 16When Guatemalans go to farewell parties, they sing Las Golondrinas. It is a Mexican song.

title: Her Dishes Are Haute Cuisine  And Healthful, Too
description: Pearl Gordon has learned to combine the joy of French cooking, the subtleties of Chinese cuisines and the regimen of natural foods she followed as a youngster to prepare meals for her family and at the same time satisfy her own need for a low cholesterol diet.

title: Personal Finance
description: Airline hijackings are so common now that someone has finally decided that there may just be a fairly substantial market forof all thingshijack insurance.

title: MARKET STILL AIMING FOR SUMMIT PARLEY
description: BRUSSELS, July 19 (UPI)The 10 nations of the enlarged; European Common Market announced agreement today to continue preparations for the controversial meeting of heads of government in October.

title: Senate Panel Shelves License Plan That Benefits Nuclear Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Senate Interior Committee shelved indefinitely today a Nixon Administrationbacked bill to authorize the temporary licensing of nuclear power plants.

title: Phone Official Admits Proposal Conceals 11.3Million Rate Rise
description: A New York Telephone official admitted yesterday that the company's application for the right to make customers pay for local directoryassistance calls concealed a rate increase of about $11.3million.

title: Prof. Edward B. Wisely, 68, Taught English at Brooklyn
description: Dr. Edward B. Wisely, who retired in 1968 as an assistant professor at Brooklyn College after 30 years in its English department, died Sunday in a Philipsburg (N.J.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and had homes here and in Asbury, N.J.

title: Consumer Buying
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 19 (AP)Consumer inclinations to buy slowed down in the AprilJune quarter and 56 per cent of those interviewed do not expect Government inflation control attempts to be successful, the University of Michigan Survey Research Center reported today.

title: Russians Leaving Egypt After Careful SendOff
description: CAIRO, July 19 (Reuters)Many of the military advisers and technical experts sent by the Soviet Union to Egypt since the Arab defeat in the 19G7 war with Israel were on their way home today, ordered out by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Fed Names Two Officers
description: The board of directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has named E. Gerald Corrigan and Michael J. Hamburger officers with the title of senior economist in the research and statistics area of the bank. Mr. Corrigan was also appointed an assistant secretary.

title: On British TV, Advice on Contraception
description: LONDON  A young girl and boy appear on the viewing screen. Arm in arm they walk together In the spring sunlight; at first glance the dewy scene looks like a cigarette commercial, but then comes the voiceover.

title: A Gainsborough Sets Mark For English Art in London
description: LONDON, July 19A record auction price for an English painting was paid today at Sotheby's for a painting by Thomas Gainsborough.

title: Democrat on the Outside
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, my party's national convention sustained the core of my ideas and liberal values. This year, like the diesenters of Chicago, I feel that I have been shut out and that my views were substantially underrepresented.

title: Sudan Plans to Resume Relations With the U.S.
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 19 (Agence FrancePresse)The Sudan decided today to resume diplomatic relations with the United States, broken off after the sixday ArabIsraeli war of 1967, it was announced here.

title: Market Plaace:
description: Talk to most brokeragehouse customers and you'll find they resent paying commission when they lose money in the stock market.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State unemployment insurance benefits beyond the basic 26week period will be curtailed and possibly eliminated within the next two weeks, the Labor Department said yesterday in Albany.

title: Murphy Cards 69 to Lead By Stroke in State Golf
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 19 (AP)Charles Murphy Jr. of Albany had two birdies on the way to a 69 and a onestroke lead as the New York State men's amateur golf tournament began at the Dutchess Golf and Country Club today.

title: RHODESIA IS TARGET OF OLYMPIC PROTEST
description: BONN. July 19 (Reuters)Britain has formally objected to the West German Government over Rhodesian athletes taking part in the Munich Olympic games, a British Embassy spokesman said here tonight.

title: Dr. Louis L. Perkel Dies; Jersey Gastroenterologist
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J., July 19Dr. Louis L. Perkel, a past president of the New Jersey Gastroenterological Society, died Sunday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, He was 73 years old and lived at 2220 Radburn Road.

title: Merger New
description: Tidewater Marine Service, Inc., New Orleans, and the Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle for merger that would involve an estimated $50million. The proposed exchange, subject to final auditing of figures and shareholder approval, calls for an exchange of 0.35 shares (an estimated total of 1,826,156) of Tidewater for each of the 5,252,600 outstand ing shares of Exchange Oil.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: The Virgin Islands Government gave a testimonial luncheon here yesterday for Jackie Robinson, the man who broke baseball's color barrier 27 years ago, and a number of his old Brooklyn Dodgger teammates were on hand. Among the guests were Joe Black, Ralph Branca, Sandy Amoros and Clyde Sukeforth, a former Dodger scout.

title: Goodyear Names New President And Reports Record Earnings
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday the naming of a new president and heralded the event by reporting record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1972.

title: Doomed Hotel Is Still Home for 40 Elderly
description: The Nevada Hotel is still standing, but most of its tenants are gone now and most of its windows are covered with tin.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ ?? MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The McGovern candidacy may or may not be successful in November but, win or lose, the Democrats will meet in convention again and the McGovern reforms will endure. The confrontations that ocurred four years ago on the streets of Chicago and their nonviolent equivalents that occurred on the convention floor this year will not occur again.

title: Eastman Sales Gain
description: The Eastman Kodak Company realized a 34 per cent rise in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 17 per cent and increases of 32 and 15 per cent, respectively, for the half, all setting new records, the midvear report disclosed yesterday.

title: Knapp Appearance Held Key to Phillips Indictment
description: The jury in the trial of Patrolman William R. Phillips was told yesterday that the defendant's appearance at the Knapp Commission's hearings on police corruption was instrumental in his indictment in two 1968 murders.

title: J. C. Penney Opens Store At Roosevelt Field Center
description: The J. C. Penney Company yesterday opened its second fullline store on Long Island in the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center, joining Macy's, Gimbels and Alexander's in the Garden City center.

title: Rhode Island Primary Rule Overturned by U.S. Court,
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I, July 19A longstanding Rhode Island law that required persons voting in the primary of one political party to wait 26 months before voting in the primary of another party was declared unconstitutional today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Recent Census Bureau statistics for the greater New York metropolitan area and for the nation agree on one cardinal pointthe median income of black families continues to lag far behind that of white families. The New YorkNew Jersey figures showed black families slipping even farther behind in recent years, despite rising incomes.

title: Linda's Chief Takes Tremont Dash for 5th Straight
description: Linda's Chief, a real running machine in the words of his trainer, Al Scotti, registered his fifth straight victory in an undefeated career by taking the $27,575 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Federal Aid for Ohio
description: WASHINGTON. July 19 (Reuters)President Nixon today declared Ohio a major disaster area as a result of the flooding caused by Tropical Storm Agnes, making the state eligible for special Federal relief funds.

title: VIETNAM VETERAN GIVES UP IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 19 (UPI) William Patterson, declaring that he had committed no crime except expressing his revulsion at the war in Vietnam, surrendered to United States marshals today and was charged with conspiring to disrupt next month's Republican National Convention.

title: Airliner Lands Safely After the Pilot Is Slain
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 19The copilot of a Colombian airliner with 52 passengers aboard, wounded by a passenger who had shot the captain to death, made a smooth landing at Cartagena, Colombia, last night as other passengers used paper napkins to keep blood from blinding him.

title: 5 Pianists at Finale of Hear America First Series
description: 11 Hear America First, the perky little concert series that materialized recently at the Greenwich Mews Theater to brighten a few July evenings, offered its third and final event on Tuesday and retired for the summer. According to Joseph Fennimore, the man in charge of this presentation of American chamber music, the series will be revived in the fall on a longerrunning basis if present plans become realities. Its reappearance would be welcome.

title: 39% OF FIRE CALLS PROVE FALSE HERE
description: Every five minutes on an average, five New York fire trucks race from their firehouses with screaming sirens on an unnecessary trip because someone turned in a false alarm.

title: Richard Reagan, 74, Dies; Herald Tribune Reporter
description: EL PASO, July 19Richard Reagan, chief shipnews reporter for The New York Herald Tribune from 1928 to 1947 and a founding member of the New York chapter of the American Newspaper Guild, died last Thursday at the Army's William Beaumont General Hospital of Fort Bliss. He was 74 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a somewhat modest chess enthusiast, I would like to make a few contributory remarks concerning the FischerSpassky chess match.

title: AL SPOHRER
description: PLYMOUTH, N. H., July 19 (AP)Al Spohrer, catcher for the Boston Braves from 1929 to 1932, died Monday in Spears Memorial Hospital. His age was 74.

title: Moscow Says Troops Quit Egypt by Mutual Consent
description: MOSCOW, July 19The Soviet Government told its citizens today for the first time that Russian military personnel were being removed from Egypt, but contended that the action was being taken by joint agreement.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Chiefs Vote Neutral Stand on Election
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. voted today to refrain from endorsing either President Nixon or Senator George McGovern for the Presidency. This was the first time that the merged labor federation, which was formed on Dec. 5, 1955, did not support officially the Democrats nominee. The council, by a vote of 27 to 3, decided to adopt a position of neutrality but reiterated that individual member unions had a right to support any candidate of their choice.

title: A Woman Steeple Jack Is Keeping on Top of Things
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 19Mary Ann Quinn was back in town and, for her, it was just another day on the job.

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices inched ahead early yesterday on the hope that Presidential adviser Henry Kissinger's secret journey to Paris would result in some break in deadlocked peace talks on Vietnam.

title: BIRCH ERS PUSHING BOOK IN LIBRARIES
description: BELMONT, Mass., July 18The ultraconservative John Birch Society, unsuccessful in prolonged past efforts to impeach Earl Warren as Chief Justice of the United States and to get the U.S. out of the U.N. and the U.N. out of the U.S., has begun a project that is producing results.

title: E. F. HUTTON PROFIT UP 12% IN QUARTER
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., a major brokerage house, reported yesterday that its secondquarter earnings rose 12 per cent. The concern said it earned $2,395,000 in the period, up from $2,107,000 a year earlier.

title: FEMINISTS REBUT FRIEDAN CHARGE
description: Betty Friedan's charge that the women's liberation movement is being torn apart by deep ideological differences over whether to fight men or ask them to join the cause has brought reactions of exasperation, indignation and simple snickering from within the movement.

title: Jet Overturns on Landing
description: KEENE, N. H., July 20 (UPI) A Blue Angels jet, part of the Navy's precision flying team, overturned yesterday while landing at DillantHopkins airport. The two pilots received only minor injuries.

title: Bridge: Intercity Championship Opens Summer Nationals in Denver
description: DENVER, July 20Hundreds of players arrived here today for the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships in time to watch the annual intercity championship match. A strong Boston team that has held the title for two years led the Denver team by 63 international match points after 20 deals of a 60deal match.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is discouraging to one white to read about the tests given to black children and the results obtained by Mrs. Ward and Dr. Braun [news story July 9]. Do we really want selfesteem which is nurtured on the rejection of others because of their color? Isn't that what we've suffered from right along? Why the rejoicing because the black children pick a white puppet as the one which looks bad? What benefit ensues when a black child is encouraged to think a white child looks bad?

title: Rockefeller and 11 Other Governors Appeal to Senate Panel for Quick Approval of RevenueSharing
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Governor Rockefeller and 11 of his fellow Governors appealed today to the Senate Finance Committee to approve quickly a Housepassed revenuesharing bill without major changes.

title: U.N. AIDE WELCOME, SOUTH AFRICA SAYS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20  Secretary General Waldheim said in a report submitted today that South Africa was willing to accept a special United Nations representative to work toward selfdetermination and independence for, the disputed territory of SouthWeit Africa.

title: O'BRIEN GETS POST IN MOVERN DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Senator George McGovern named Lawrence F. O'Brien today as chairman of his Democratic Presidential campaign and, assigned him the task of making peace with labor and the party's old guard.

title: Cox Sets Acquisition
description: The Cox Broadcasting Corporation announced yesterday an agreement, subject to the signing of a mutually acceptable contract and to approval of the Federal Communications Commission, to acquire from the Earle C. Anthony Trust operating assets of AM radio station KFI in Los Angeles for $151.1million. On Wednesday the American Television and Communications Corporation announced an agreement in principle to merge with Cox Cable Communications, Inc., 56.3 per cent owned by Atlantabased Cox Broadcasting.

title: Peterson Arrives in Moscow For U.S.Soviet Trade Parley
description: MOSCOW, July 20  The United States Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson, arrived here today for the first meeting of a new Joint SovietAmerican Commercial Commission opening tomorrow.

title: State Welfare Aide Cites Abuses at City Office
description: George F. Berlinger, the State Welfare Inspector General, said yesterday that 28 per cent of 125 cases studied at the Veteran Assistance Social Services Center here were ineligible to receive public assistance, according to an investigation he recently examined.

title: Spassky Obviously Rattled
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 20 As far as this chess columnist can remember, no world champion has ever made such terrible blunder as Spassky made on his 27th move in the fifth game of the match with Bobby Fischer today. But even without his fatal mistake, the Soviet champion was not at his best today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HOYLAKE, England, July 20 (UPI)  South Africa's Brenda Kirk thrashed secondseeded Virginia Wade Britain today in the North of England tennis quarterfinals, 86, 64.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Nguyen Thai Binh, shot five times on a Pan American 747 at Saigon [news story July 3], died a hero.

title: SHOW TO REPRISE WEILL'S MUSICALS
description: Berlin to Broadway With Kurt Weill, a mlange of the German composer's enduring musical stage success, will be presented at the Theater de Lys beginning Oct. 1 by Hank Kaufman, an agent turned producer who has lived in Rome for the last 18 years.

title: Short Interest Off For the Big Board
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a technical ingredient in the stockmarket outlook, dropped 201,791 shares in the month ended last Friday, the Big Board reported yesterday.

title: British Example
description: Reginald Maudling was one of the intelligent young British ConservativesEdward Heath and the late lain Macleod were otherswho worked overtime under R. A. Butler to give their party a muchneeded facelifting after its unexpected defeat in 1945. He then performed ably in a succession of Tory Governments and had served Mr. Heath as Home Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister since the surprise Conservative election victory of 1970.

title: A Quintuple Show at Cultural Center
description: Beginning on the fifth floor and working down, the New York Cultural Center at Columbus Circle is now offering a quintuple summer show suggesting four questions that you might feel like asking yourself and offering a halfanswer to a question that may never have occurred to you, which is: What's going on in Chicago?

title: Mrs. Smoke Paces Trials For Olympic Canoe Team
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 20 (AP)  Mrs. Marcia Smoke of Niles, Mich., trying for her third Olympic appearance, won her heat today in the women's kayak singles and led 51 entrants to the final rounds of qualifying for the United States canoeing team.

title: Evidence on Jersey Aide Traced to Memo in April
description: TRENTON, July 20Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said today that a memorandum and a complaint by a former top official of the State Transportation Department touched off the Federal investigation last April that led to the indictment of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two other men on conspiracy and extortion charges.

title: The Right to Bear Wanted Children
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.The antiabortion movement in this country has begun to masquerade as a right to life movement, but it seems to be concerned more with the lives of fetuses than with the lives of people. I too am for the right to life, and a much better life than most people have the chance to live, but I think our job is to work for that better life, and not to force unintentionally fertilized eggs to become unwanted children.

title: Farmers Group Neutral
description: RICHMOND, Wash., July 20 (AP)Orin Staley, president of the National Farmers Organization, said in an interview yesterday that his group doesn't care which party is in the White Housewe won't make any endorsements. Mr. Staley said Agriculture Secretary Earl Butz had related well with farmers, but when you look in depth, he has not raised any support prices for farm produce.

title: 19 Arrested in Philadelphia As Rolling Stones Perform
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 20, (UPI)Bomb threats, 17 narcotics arrests and two weapons arrests in the crowd of 17,000 failed to halt the Rolling Stone's concert tonight.

title: A Congress Group Hears A.E.C. Head In Security Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy held a secret hearing today to investigate charges that the director of the Atomic Energy Commission's Division on Security had borrowed more than $150,000 from commission employes.

title: SILVER FUTURES LOSE EARLY GAINS
description: Silver prices made a bright showing in early morning futures trading yesterday gaining 3 cents an ounce in some contracts. Later in the day there came some tarnishing news about heavy stocks of silver in Commodity Exchange authorized depositaries. Enough sellers entered to push prices below the previous day's level.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gosh all hemlock  please advise Sam Brightman (OpEd, July 12) that it was the SellsFloto Circus not the WellsPlato Circus that apparently came to Columbia, Mo., in the twenties.

title: Brewers Protest A's Use Of a Player They Traded
description: MILWAUKEE, July 20 (AP) Frank Lane, director of baseball operations for the Milwaukee Brewers, filed a protest today with the American League over the Oakland A's use of the infielder, Marty Martinez, last night.

title: Deluge of Occidental Orders Is Continuing
description: Orders for shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation continued to deluge the New York Stock Exchange and the rest of the nation's securities markets yesterday in an unprecedented surge of public speculation.

title: Carbide Profits Rise
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer, realized 33 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 5 per cent, while halfyear earnings were up 25 per cent and sales by 3 per cent, the midyear report disclosed yesterday.

title: Spassky Resigns After Blunder; Match Is Even Through 5 Games
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, july 20 Bobby Fischer, swooping down on a blunder by Boris Spassky, forced, the champion's resignation today in the fifth game of their world championship chessmatch.

title: David Lichine, Choreographer And Ballet Star, Is Dead at 62
description: David Lichine, the dancer and choreographer, died June 26 in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA LAGS IN EARNINGS
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation reported yesterday a marked slowdown in the rate of growth in its earnings. The company, the parent organization of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, said that its net operating earnings in the first half of the year amounted to $17.2million, or 1.39 a share, up 3.7 per cent from the $16.6million, or 1.35, earned last year.

title: DRUG FIRMS HALT CHILDREN'S TV ADS
description: Three major drug companies have agreed to end vitamin advertising on children's television programs in response to public pressure spurred by Action for Children's Television, the fouryearold Boston organization that is opposed to all TV advertising aimed at children.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The most Interesting tourists in the world this summer are the travelers to Moscow. Every few days now there is a report of some American, German, Japanese or British mission to the Soviet capital to talk about exchanging Western technology for Soviet gas and oil.

title: American Airlines in Loews Hotel Pact
description: American Airlines, Inc., has arranged a lease agreement with the Loews Corporation under which the airline will become one of Manhattan's major hotel operators, it was learned last night.

title: About Pro Football
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 20There are 17 free agents in the National Football League still available to the highest bidder but George Allen, the maestro of the Washington Redskins who operates with an unlimited budget, says he is not especially interested. We're talking to some, Allen admitted here today at the Redskins steamy training camp. We might pick up one. He ex pressed no specific interest in one of the best  John Williams, the former Baltimore guard.

title: Space Launching Delayed
description: LOMPOC, Calif., July 20 (UPI) The launching of a spacecraft designed to gather information on the earth's ecology has been postponed because of engine trouble, the national space agency said today. The Environmental and Earth Resources Satellite is now scheduled for launching Saturday afternoon.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: CHICAGO, July 20  The regular Democrats who were denied seats at the party's Miami Beach convention sought contempt citations today against the 59 Democrats who replaced the delegation led by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., July 20  Around Carbondale and Murphysboro the corn is as high as, well, say a Shetland pony's eye, but here, only 18 miles up the pike, it isn't a great deal taller than the soybeans, because up to a few days ago it seemed that every time rain hit the southern tip of the state it stopped somewhere below Dowell, the village down Highway 51 where Minnesota Fats, the great pool hustler, was born and christened Rudolph Wanderone. The drought was broken last weekend, though. The browning pastures regained some of their green freshness and Bill Hayes permitted himself to hope that his rolling, wooded parklands would be at their best for the 50th annual Du Quoin State Fair. For the last 15 years, Du Quoin has been the site of (and the fair has lent its trappings to) a horse race without counterpart on earth  the $100,000plus Hambletonian Stake. This is the world's premier harness race and it enjoys a distinction as the only major horse race anywhere that survives without betting. Not even Howard Samuels, pit boss in New York's OffTrack betting bucket, handles, action on this corded frolic. It draws little or no attention from television. Yet on Aug. 30 the population of Du Quoin will swell from 7,000 to perhaps 30,000 and half this number will spend the whole perishing afternoonprobably in temperatures ranging up from 90 degreeswatching a race that could require four onemile heats to establish a winner.

title: American Export May Fail To Pay Interest on Aug. 1
description: American Export Industries, Inc. may be unable to meet a $1,575,000 interest payment due Aug. 1 on a $60million debenture issue, Ellis B. Gardner Jr., president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Dover, Del. He said that the company had had several conversations with the trustee of the debentures but we have no indication as to what course of action they might take if we do fail to meet the interest payment.

title: Ferenc Kormendi, Author, Dies; Wrote Novels About Hungary
description: BETHESDA, Md., July 20Ferenc Kormendi, a Hungarian author whose novels were translated into 19 languages, died at his home here today of an occlusion of the arteries. He was 72 years old.

title: DUTCH CABINET QUITS OVER BUDGET CRISIS
description: THE HAGUE, July 20 (Reuters)The Dutch Cabinet resigned today. An official communique said that Premier Barend W. Biesheuvel and his cabinet had resigned because the coalition Government made up principally of the Catholic and Labor parties had broken down as a result of the resignation of two Labor party ministers, Willem Drees, the Transport Minister, and W. M. de Brun, the Minister for Scientific Research.

title: BIG BOARD ENJOINED ON STARK EXPULSION
description: A federal judge yesterday granted a stockbroker a preliminary injunction against the New York Stock Exchange, which has called for the broker's expulsion from membership because of the way he recapitalized his firm.

title: Railways and Union Settle 35Year. Fireman Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The nation's railroads and the United Transportation Union announced jointly today an agreement that will eventually eliminate the job of fireman on diesel freight, locomotives.

title: Puerto Rico Low on Water
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 20 (UPI) Puerto Ricans were asked today to use as little water as possible after sabotage reportedly reduced the flow during a strike of water agency employes that continued in defiance of a court order. The alleged sabotage against water mains and pumping stations seriously cut the supply to parts of San Juan and several other cities, a spokesman for the Governmentoperated agency said.

title: Ulster Protestant Slain As His Shop Is Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 20  A newsdealer was spot dead here today after gunmen had planted a bomb in his shop on Springfield Road. His wife was shot in the back and seriously woundeta as she knelt beside the dying man.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Lately, there has been considerable public criticism of welfare payments made to drug addicts who are not receiving treatment in recognized narcotics rehabilitation programs.

title: Navy Writer Calls Nuclear Sub, Not Carrier, Main Sea Weapon
description: The aircraft carrier's role as the Navy's primary weapon and the traditionalism of the Present naval building program are challenged in this month's Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute, the most prestigious of American service publications.

title: CENSUS ASSAYS BLACK FAMILIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The percentage of black families headed only by women has reached nearly 32, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Sunday Is Soul Day at Lincoln Center
description: Soul, the phenomenon that has been described as the ability to transform pain into beauty, is coming to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts for two weeks beginning Sunday.

title: Rabbit Inspection Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) A Senatepassed bill for mandatory inspection or rabbits slaughtered for human food was approved by the House Agriculture Committee today. By 19 to 0, the committee voted to include rabbits under provisions of the poultry inspection program.

title: Mets Defeat Dodgers, 21, On Mays's Double in Fifth
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20 While Rusty Staub entered Roosevelt Hospital in New York, where he will undergo surgery tomorrow for the fractured bone in his right hand, the Mets carried on without him here tonight and edged the Dodgers, 21.

title: A SELECTIVE HALT IN CONTROLS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Committee for Economic Development recommended today that the government chart guidelines and procedures for selective termination of wageprice controls.

title: 4 Employes Hurt in Melee At The Amsterdam News
description: Four employes of The New York Amsterdam News were injured yesterday, afternoon during a chairthrowing melee in which a band of nearly 40 teenagers ransacked the newspaper's Harlem office.

title: Demand for Texas Oil Up
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 20  Mounting summer demand for Texas oil simply cannot be met by Texas wells, the Texas Railroad Commission reported today.

title: WEAKENED MARKET FORESEEN THIS YEAR
description: Forecast of a lower stock market and higher consumer savings were made yesterday by Albert Sindlinger and Eliot Janeway at an interview between sessions of the July seminar sponsored by the latter in the New York Athletic Club.

title: Personalities: A Fraud Of AllStar Proportions
description: The AllStar game's selection of pitchers is a fraud, the Pirates top reliever, Dave Giusti, charged yesterday. His former manager, Danny Murtaugh, selected the National League's nine pitchers (the starting lineup, except for the pitcher, was selected by fans). Murtaugh picked two relieversthe Mets Tug McGraw and the Reds Clay Carroll. Giusti has 14 saves, a 1.91 earnedrun average and a 44 wonlost mark. McGraw has as many saves, but a 2.05 E.R.A. and a 34 mark. Carroll is 42, with 21 saves and a 1.69 average. Earl Weaver, the American League manager, picked the American League hurlers and didn't select one reliever. That means that Sparky Lyle of the Yanks, one of the best relief pitchers in baseball, will not be on the squad. Another top player not on the team is Richie Scheinblum, the American League's leading hitter, who is a rookie and was left off the computercard ballot.

title: Screen: Doing 'Our Latin Thing' as Documentary:Leon Gast Production Opens at Cine 2 Film Is Based on Fania Concert at Cheetah
description: The musical-event moviefrom Woodstock to Altamont to Big Sur and beyondhas become such a commonplace in the last few years that it is unusual and refreshing to see a film about a pop concert that makes no serious claims to be sociology or world history. Leon Gast's "Our Latin Thing" has much smaller ambitions and it would generally be fair to say that the film is not so much a documentary as an elaborate, rather free form, production.Almost everybody who receives a credit in "Our Latin Thing" is a musician or a disc jockey, and almost all the musicians work for Fania Recordswho seem responsible for the movie and the record and the tape cassettes and the souvenior booklet and the "Our Latin Thing" T-shirts that have been appearing around town. Fania sponsored the concertlast August, at Cheetahwhere the principal footage was shot, and what they have now is a fairly? presentable showcase for their stars. These include a lot of people, like Ray Barrotto, the conga player, and Larry Harlow, the pianist, and Johnny Pacheco on the flute, who sound good to me. Some of the songs are very long, up to 16 minutes, and the lyrics, which are not translated, are likely to leave you bewildered if you don't know Spanish."Our Latin Thing" does, alas, bill itself as "revealing the Latin life in N.Y.C." And to this end it intermittently goes into the community to film domino games, shaved-ice vending, cockfighting and blocks where the city sanitation sweepers seem never to have visited. Some of this material is interesting, much is gratuitous, and all of it seems dedicated to solving the problem of how to alleviate the tedium involved in photographing a musical performance.I don't think that Leon Cast's solutions are very successful  but I don't think that any other director's solutions have been either  and "Our Latin Thing" at least avoids the camera and lab tricks so often used to make a group of people playing, or listening or informally dancing to music seem visually important. It is surely valuable to get musicianswhether the Juilliard Quartet, the Rolling Stones or the Fania Records All-Stars  down on film. But it is a specialized value, more limited than a live concert or a great recording. And it is not altogether comfortable in a medium the strengths of which lie elsewhere."Our Latin Thing" opened Wednesday at the Cine 2 Theater.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThere is no doubt that the withdrawal of Soviet military forces from Egypt is the most important regional development since Moscow sent SAM missiles and crews to that country. How many of the approximately 20,000 Russians there will go is unknown but, both psychologically and factually, the East Mediterranean power balance must change.

title: Miss DeCozen Gains Final
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y. July 20Charlotte DeCozen, Westchester Country Club and Mrs. Alexander F. Munro, Innis Arden, won semifinals in the Women's TriCounty Golf Association championship today at the Sunningdale C. C. Miss DeCozen defeated Mrs. Charles Crawford, Apawamis, 4 and 3, and Mrs. Munro beat Mrs. Blancke Noyes, Wee Burn, 1 up.

title: DOWNTURN HITS STOCK MARKET
description: A dispirited stock market resumed its losing ways yesterday as a familiar set of worries  politics, the economy, mutual fund redemptions, inflation and the market's own technical structureheld sway once again.

title: SINGER, 75, MAKES HIS DEBUT IN CITY
description: At the age of 75, Sam Chatmon, a singer and guitarist, made his New York debut Wednesday evening at the Folklore Center, Avenue of the Americas at Third Street. Mr. Chatmon, a thin, wiry man with a lined face and twinkling eyes, has been performing since World War I and, with several of his brothers, was a member of the Mississippi Sheiks, a group that was popular in the late nineteentwenties and early thirties.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 119.5 from 120.2 last week.

title: Black Bug Hunted on Coast
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. July 20 (UPI)A special task force was set up yesterday by the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors to hunt the western grape leaf skeletonizer. The tiny black bug was spotted for the first time in the region's vineyards last month.

title: Theater: Revivals Enlivening London
description: LONDON, July 20Revivals seem to be very much the order of the day in the London theaterwhich is partly as it should be. It is always sensible for a theater to take stock of where it is, both in the classic repertory and, more dangerously but often just as rewardingly, in the repertory of the fairly recent past.

title: ROBERT AMORY DIES; A TEXTILE LEADER
description: Robert Amory, who retired in 1965 as vice president for sales of Springs Mills, Inc., textile manufacturers, died yesterday in Manchester, Mass. He was 86 years old and lived at the Somerset Club in Boston.

title: U.S. Attempted to Ignite Vietnam Forests in'6667
description: MISSOULA, Mont., July 16Wellinformed civilian and military sources have disclosed that in an effort to clear away enemycontrolled forests, the United States made a number of concerted attempts to set huge fire storms in Vietnam during 1966 and 1967. The project was ultimately abandoned, they said, because the moist tropical rain forest would not burn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The position stated by Xuan Thuy, the chief North Vietnamese delegate, at the July 13 session of the Paris peace talks, that the United States could end its intervention in the internal affairs of Vietnam without dealing with the question of power in Saigon, strongly suggests that the prospect of an agreement among China, the Soviet Union and the United States to discontinue supplying any military equipment to any Vietnamese forces might be the key element necessary for the success of the current negotiations, and the return of our prisoners of war.

title: 2 Workouts for Giants
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 20After giving the Giants yesterday afternoon off, Coach Alex Webster went back to his twoaday workout plan. Given three downs to score, one squad, led by Randy Johnson at quarterback did. Charlie Evans went over on a 15yard draw play.

title: STATE RESTS CASE AGAINST PHILLIPS
description: Detective John Justy, whom the defense accuses of malevolently assembling the murder case against Patrolman William R. Phillips, withstood two hours of crossexamination yesterday rejecting, among other things, the defense contention that he once conspired with Mr. Phillips to take a bribe.

title: YANKEES, ANGELS ARE RAINED OUT
