description: A light but persistent rain forced the Yankess to postpone their scheduled game against the California Angels last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: FORD ASKS $92 RISE IN 1973 AUTO PRICES
description: DETROIT, July 20The Ford Motor Company asked the Price Commission today for an average price increase of $92, or 2.2 per cent, on the retail price of its 1973 cars and trucks.

title: Occi Victor in Junior Golf
description: RYE, N. Y., July 20Michael T. Occi of Cranford (N. J.) High School, who plays out of Galloping Hills, defeated William Britton of Silver Lake G.C., Staten Island, 3 and 2, at the Apawamis Club today to win the 55th annual Metropolitan Golf Association junior cham pionship.

title: MONEY EXPANSION IS ACCELERATED
description: Monetary expansion accelerated during the last two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. It appeared doubtful, however, that the quickening represented any change in the central bank's policy of moderate monetary expansion.

title: TAX REPORT DENIED BY CONTINENTAL OIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Continental Oil Company denied today a report by Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, that the con cern paid no Federal corporate taxes in 1971.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re Anthony Lewis July 2 column, Back to the Stone AgeTwentyseven years ago this country bombed two smaller nationsGermany and Japanback a good ways for the same reason we are now bombing North Vietnam: They attacked their neighbors with armed force.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 20 (AP)The Atomic Energy Commission announced that it set off a low yield underground nuclear explosion today at the Nevada test site about 65 miles northwest of here. The blast, described as in the 20kiloton range, was the fourth announced test here this year. The test produced no measurable release of radioactivity, a spokesman for the commission said.

title: Books of The Times
description: Perhaps every unmarried woman is a bit of a sociologist, majoring in men. If she works with them, listens to their troubles and sleeps with them too, this ought to entitle her to some sort of Ph.D. God knows her life will need all the philosophy, all the doctoring, she can give it. No man is a hero to his valet, someone said: This is equally true of his secretary. And imagine how much less a hero he is when he sleeps with her too, gets staggering drunk with her and cries on her to boot.

title: Coast Ban on Mail Deliveries In Smog Alerts Rescinded
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 20 (AP)The western region postal director, Fred HUleen, rescinded yesterday a dayold policy to halt deliveries during smog alerts.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) President Nixon took a Potomac cruise tonight aboard the Navy yacht Sequoia. A White House spokesman said that he was accompanied only by H. R. Haldeman, chief of the White House staff, and Secret Service agents.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Slow trading of 3.1 million shares marked another day of declining prices on the American Stock Exchange. The index closed at 26.68, off 0.07. In the overthecounter market the NASDAQ index ended at 134.27, off 0.57.

title: President Planning To Resign Oct. 31 At Federated Chain
description: J. Paul Sticht will resign as president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., effective Oct. 31 to become a consultant to the large retail company and solve as an active parttimer in various personal and business endeavors.

title: Yea!
description: ASPEN, Colo.Amid July 4th weekend distractions, President Nixon's veto of the Public Broadcasting Act failed to arouse the public curiosity it deserved. On the surface, the differences seemed minor. Mr. Nixon had recommended oneyear extension of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting with $45 million for fiscal 73; Congress voted two years with $65 million for 73 and $90 million for 74.

title: Men in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Labor leaders were surprised when they went to dinner ac the home of William H. Dempsey. Instead of the expected retinue of servants, they found Mr. Dempsey and his wife preparing and serving dinner themselves. Most of these management types have servants, one labor man said, but Bill is as comfortable as an old shoe. This relaxed attitude is characteristic of Mr. Dempsey's lowkey approach, associates say, and is one of the traits responsible for helping to work out a historic agreement announced today with labor leaders on the manning of Diesel trains.

title: CORDERO IS FIRST ON 4 AT AQUEDUCT
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the leading jockey at the meeting, picked up a fair bundle of getaway money on yesterday'S Aqueduct program to ease him through a suspension that will keep him out of action from tomorrow through July 31.

title: London Denies Protesting Rhodesian Role in Olympics
description: LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) The British Foreign Office said today that it had not protested or made formal objections to West Germany about Rhodesian participation in the Munich Olympic Games next month.

title: Broker Cites Blunders on Beach Deal
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 20The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors and the County Attorney's office approved all plans to acquire 11,000 feet of oceanfront property at Tiana Beach and made official offers to the owners nearly two years before any appraisal of the property was officially made, it was learned last night.

title: Delight and Sympathy Mingled Among Marshall Club Observers
description: There was incredulity at the Marshall Chess Club here yesterday when Boris Spassky resigned to Bobby Fischer.

title: Level of Personal Income Unchanged During June
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Personal income, held back by the floods in the eastern part of the country, showed no increase in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THREE TIE AT 290 IN N.J. OPEN GOLF
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 20  Dennis Walters and Art Silvestrone each carded a par72 today and drew even with faltering Pat Schwab at 290 after four rounds of play in the 52d New Jersey State open golf, tournament. The tie created a threeway playoff for the title tomorrow at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club.

title: Two Battle to the Death After Surviving Crash
description: BELEM, Brazil, July 20, (Reuters)  Two weary survivors of a bus crash that killed 13 persons managed to reach the bank of the river into which the vehicle had plunged. Then, the police said today, as 25 other survivors watched in horror, the two men drew knives and fought to the death.

title: Willis Reed Arrested After an Auto Incident
description: Willis Reed, the New York Knicks basketball star, was arrested last night in an automobile incident involving an offduty patrolman. Mr. Reed was charged with reckless endangerment, menacing, harassment and inipersonating a police officer.

title: Pro Sports Heads Seek To Halt Cable TV Influx
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The commissioners of major professional sports presented a united front today against proposed regulations that would allow cable television to pick up many events without the promoter's permis, sion, but one of their club owners, who Is also a cable television operator, took the opposite view.

title: Uniformly Safe Levels of Radiation Questioned
description: Two biostatisticians have pinpointed a group of children who appear to be highly susceptible to the leukemiainducing effects of socalled low, safe levels of radiation.

title: French Restaurant. In a jersey Setting
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Sports News in Brief
description: GREENSBORO, N. C.,. July 20 (AP)  The Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association announced today that a former Cougar, Doug Moe, would serve as assistant coach and director of player personnel next season. The 34yearold Moe, a former. University of North Carolina star, retired as an active player because of knee surgery he underwent last April after playing last season with the Virginia Squires of the A.B.A.

title: Company Town Hopeful Without the Company
description: SALTVILLE, Va.When I first came here, Saltville was a utopia. If it could have gone on for an eternity, that would have been beautiful. Robert G. McCoy was recalling Saltville, perhaps with a touch of irony, as the ultimate company town, just a few years ago, when the giant Olin Corporation owned the houses and the stores and hospital and helped the lives of several thousand residents.

title: Banff's Protector
description: Canada is to be congratulated on the good judgment of its Minister of Northern Development, Jean Chretien, who also supervises that country's 28 national parks. Confronted by a plan to impose a whole new tourist town on Banff National Park, the Minister rejected the proposal for the obvious damage it would do to one of Canada's bestknown scenic attractions.

title: SUPER BRUCE 13 IN YOUR RADIO! GET HIM IN YOUR MORNING! BRUCE BRADLEY. 610 A.M. WHN/1050.Advt
description: SUPER BRUCE 13 IN YOUR RADIO! GET HIM IN YOUR MORNING! BRUCE BRADLEY. 610 A.M. WHN/1050.Advt

title: Books of The Times
description: Right at the outset, Louise Varese in her memoir of the composer Edgard Varese, who was her husband, warns off the musicians and the musically knowledgeable. Her book, she says, is a personal memoir, neither exhaustive nor technical. Her disclaimer may have been designed for those who believe they can better understand the music by getting close to the man. If so, her remark was fair warning. For Varese's music, more than most, can never be reduced to words. Verbal description of music is at best a frustrating attempt to describe one art in terms of another.

title: Secretary Sees Action as Limited to Those With Egypt's Units
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Egyptian order ousting Soviet military personnel appeared to be limited at present to advisers serving with Egyptian military units.

title: Priorities for Power
description: The decision of the state Public Service Commission to investigate New York City's electric power needs in the next decadeand the way the Consolidated Edison Company plans to meet themis good news. It would be far better news if the investigating body had a tradition of greater independence with respect to the utilities it is charged with regulating; or if its study panel for the purpose were broadened to include representatives of the public and its environmental agencies.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A Federal grand jury in Spokane, Washington, has indicted three men in connection with an allegedly fraudulent sale of stock reported to have netted them $1million. The company, Spokane National Mines, Inc., is now in reorganization.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President held a breakfast meeting with 12 Governors on revenue sharing. Heard a report from the Occidental Oil Company chairman, Armand Hammer, on the details of his concern's trade deal with the Soviet Union. Announced that 12 Federal properties in nine states and Puerto Rico had been turned over to state and local government for park and recreation use.

title: Credit Markets
description: Underwriters of taxexempt securities pushed interest rates down another notch yesterday but demand from investors for several new issues was nonetheless brisk.

title: A New GangStyle Killing Uncovered
description: Dozens of Mafiosi have been in hiding since the shooting of Thomas Eboli, high officials reported yesterday as a new apparent gangland slaying came to light.

title: Mrs. Fortnow Wed to S. L. Bartels
description: Mrs. Linda Lauretz Fortnow and Stanley Leonard Bartels, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon by Surrogate Samuel S. DiFalco in his chambers.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 1.8%
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads totaled 14.1 billion tonmiles last week, 1.8 per cent above the corresponding 1971 week. Carloadings totaled 473.524, down 2.3 per cent from last year.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS PREDICTED IN U.S.
description: PARIS, July 20The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development had some good words to say today about the future economic performance of the United States. What it saw was a lower rate of inflation and unemployment and significant improvement in the balance of payments.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: BrowningFerris Industries Inc. yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a 900,000share secondary offering through E. F. Hutton & Co. The shares are being issued by the company in connection with recent acquisitions. The company's stock closed at 28, down 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Death Toll Put at 142 on Luzon As Floods Wreck More Dikes
description: MANILA, July 20  Floodwaters continued to rise in the six middle provinces of Luzon Island and President Ferdinand E. Marcos went on the air to reassure the 1.8million victims that all resources for relief were being mobilized.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial (July 13) correctly states that the resumption of the Paris peace talks offers the last chance to end the Vietnam war before the American elections.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A Treasury official said today that banking leads all other industries in hiring of minorities, with a rise in black employment of 147 per cent between 1966 and 1970.

title: Tremblay jumps to WHOA.;
description: QUEBEC, July 20 (Canadian Press)J. C. Tremblay, an allstar defenseman in three of his 12 National. Hockey League seasons with the Montreal Canadiens, signed the a multiyear contract with Les Nordiques, the Quebec City team in the New World Hockey Association tonight. No terms were disclosed.

title: Fire Damages Texas Building Used in Kennedy Shooting
description: DALLAS, July 20 (UPI)Arsonists broke into the Texas School Book Depository building today, spread gasoline across five floors and set fire to the 68yearold structure where Lee Harvey Oswald waited to assassinate President Kennedy.

title: LEWIS THOMPSON, 57, WROTE MYSTERIES
description: Lewis Thompson, a mysterysitory writer, died yesterday at his home, 211 East 60th Street. He was 57 years old.

title: DOLLAR IS FIRMER IN TRADE ABROAD
description: PARIS, July 20The dollar continued to strengthen in Western Europe's financial centers today as European bankers and monetary authorities enthusiastically welcomed the decision of the Federal Reserve Board to intervene in the markets in dcfense of the dollar's exchange rate.

title: Pattison Upsets Gonzales
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 20 (AP)Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia turned in a 26, 63, 6.4 upset victory over Pancho Gonzales today in the Buckeye open tennis championships.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mayor Lindsay, who plans to stay at his City Hall desk during most of the Presidential campaign, criticized the Democratic ticket yesterday for failing to pay sufficient attention to the problems of the cities.

title: Executive Charges
description: Warner Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that Steven J. Ross has been elected chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Ross who will continue as president, succeeds the late William V. Frankel. The company also announced that Ted Ashley, chairman of Warner Bros., Inc., a subsidiary, has been elected chairman of the executive committee. Richard Sheiiherd has been made an executive vice president for production at Warner Bros.

title: Vorster Pledges Cooperation
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 20Prime Minister John Vorster said today that his Government was prepared to cooperate with a special United Nations representative over the future of SouthWest Africa.

title: Smith Opposes Pinto in Davis Cup Opener Today
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. July 20 (AP)Stan Smith of the United States and Jaime Pinto of Chile were picked today to oppose each other in the opening match of the American Zone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition beginning tomorrow.

title: VIETNAM SESSIONS CONTINUE IN PARIS; PORTER OPTIMISTIC
description: PARIS, July 20The formal Vietnamese peace talks continued today,. but they only marked time in the wake of renewed private contacts between Hanoi's Le Duc Tho and Henry A. Kissinger in Paris yesterday.

title: Rand McNally Publishes Political Atlas by Markel
description: A political atlas combining maps and essays on world affairs, communications and population has been published by Rand McNally in conjunction with The New York Times. The softcover book of 156 pages sells for $4.95.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TEL AVIV, July 20 (AP)The word hasn't reached Munich yet, but already Israel's Olympic team is embroiled in a religious squabble over the closing ceremony of the 1972 Games.

title: O.E.O. Rejects Jersey YouthTour Bill
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 20 Pending further investigation, the Office of Economic Opportunity announced tonight that it would withhold payment of $60,000 in Federal antipoverty funds to a private agency that arranged to send 67 local high school students on a tour of Europe and Africa during July and August.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I would like to answer the letter of Dr. Edwin Kerr in The Times of July 14, headed Furor Over High Prices.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The executive board of the Washington chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, a professional journalists society, has criticized endorsement by the Newspaper Guild of Senator George McGovem's Presidential campaign. In a statement signed by its president, Samuel F. Yette, the Sigma Delta Chi chapter said:

title: The Corner Closes Sunday
description: The Corner, a program of three oneact plays by Ed Bullins, Clay Goss and Oyamo, will end its run at The Other Stage oft Sunday night after 87 performances. Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare Festival presented the plays.

title: U. S. Car Study Disputes Nader On Corvair Safety Charge in 65
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A twoyear Government study released today concludes that, contrary to charges that catapulted Ralph Nader on the way to prominence, 1960.63 Chevrolet Corvair models were at least as safe as comparable models of other cars sold in the same period.

title: Formulas for Survival
description: Fifteen years ago when the bigpower arms race was beginning to take a new upward leap as a result of this country's alarmed response to the Soviet sputnik, a note of sober caution was sounded in a New York Times Magazine article entitled: Christmas Thoughts A World Gone Mad.  Deploring the obsession with armaments, its author, Raymond B. Fosdick, counseled that peace on earth and good will toward men are no mere slogans; they are formulas for survival.

title: Tax Evaders Smoked Out All 60,000
description: About 60,000 New Yorkers are finding out that the wages of tax evasion aretaxes.

title: Market Place: The New Breed Taken to Task
description: The Little Guy has always been the scapegoat in Wall Street. Cynical financial men have always looked down their noses at him and made comments like, It must be time to get out of the stock marketthe Little Guy is coming in.

title: 3 Tie for Lead With 65's In $27.000 French Golf
description: LA NIVELLE, France, July 20 (UPI)Peter Oosterhuis and Noel Hunt of Britain and Jose Arruti of Spain share a onestroke lead today after the first round of the $27,000 French open golf championship over two Basque Coast courses.

title: Heat, Humidity Expected To Go On Despite Showers
description: New Yorkers endured yet another day of furnacelike heat and sticky, humid air yesterday, and the National Weather Service predicted at least two more days of the same.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, July 20 (Reuters)Canada had a trade surplus in June of $207million, unchanged from the balance in the corresponding month last year, Statistics Canada said today.

title: SENATE APPROVES MINIMUMPAYRISE TO $2.20 BY 1974
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Senate voted today to increase the Federal minimum wage for most nonagricultural worker's to $2.20 an hour over the next two years, a much larger rise than had been sought by President Nixon or approved by the House. The vote was 65 to 27.

title: Swan Lake Given By Ballet Theater; Kivitt Is Siegfried
description: Swan Lake has usually been considered a ballerina's ballet. Her doublefaceted role as OdetteOdile is a dramatic and technical challenge. Siegfried, in contrast, usually gets the choreographic short end.

title: Con Ed Center Stays Unruffled in Crisis
description: Everyone speaks softly in the circular, welllighted room on West End Avenue. The still air oscillates only to the beeps, buzzes and squawks of the wilderness of meters lining the walls and the steady clacking of the highspeed computer.

title: Diaries Show Stravinsky Kept Score on Expenses
description: During his prolific life as a composer of modern music, Igor Stravinsky kept terse but minute records of his activitiesand occasionally of random reflectionsin dozens of redcovered diaries that have just come to light.

title: Lower East Side Board Hires Principal Ousted in Brooklyn
description: Luis Fuentes, a PuertoRican activist and former public school principal in Brooklyn, has been appointed superintendent of District One, on the Lower East Side, in a surprise move by the Community School Board and despite the objections of some principals in the district.

title: Tobacco Area Weak
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc. achieved record sales and earnings in the three and six months ended with June for the eighth successive year, according to yesterday's semiannual report.

title: Goyette to Coach Islanders
description: Six weeks before their first training camp the New York Islanders yesterday finally picked their coachPhil Goyette, one of hockey's most respected players.

title: Ziegler Comment Cited
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Gerald Warren, deputy press secretary at the White House, said tonight that the Administration had no immediate comment on Dr. Blake's charge that United States planes were deliberately bombing North Vietnamese dikes.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Front Page 4  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskles. Imported by Palmer & Lord. Ltd., Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: CERRUDO, ON A 65, LEADS BY STROKE IN GOLF AT AKRON
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 20On a day when scores were low and the temperature and humidity Egh, Ron Cerrudo, a 29yearold California professional, carded a 65 to take the firstround lead in the $150,000 American Golf Classic.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AGood catches of bluefish, some up to 17 pounds, are being made by boats trolling and chumming off Barnegat Ridge and a run of mediumsized weakfish has begun about a mile off the beach in the Barnegat area. The weakfish are being picked up by jigging. Fluke fishing is improving and good fish are being caught by boats working north of Barnegat Inlet. South of Barnegat at Surf City, the surf fishing is so poor it is beyond description, according to Johnny Falkiewicz, proprietor of Johnny's Tackle Shop. Some blues and weakfish are being caught from boats in Great Bay. North of Barnegat at Point Pleasant, charter boats are bringing in bluefish from Barnegat Ridge.

title: EL TIEMPO GOES INTO BANKRUPTCY
description: El Tiempo, the nation's secondlargest Spanishlanguage daily newspaper, was declared, bankrupt and ordered closed by a Federal judge yesterday after nine profitless years of publication here.

title: Maryland Guards Protest
description: BALTIMORE, July 20 (UPI)About half of the guards at the Maryland Penitentiary walked off their jobs briefly today, demanding stricter controls over the prisoners. It was the third walkout by guards in four days after an inmate Tebellion Monday that caused $500,000 in damage. In the latest incident, about 65 of the 130 guards on duty stayed on their jobs and searched the prison for weapons and contraband. After two hours, the other guards were persuaded to join in the search.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: Senator George McGovern is threatened with massive defections by traditionally in Democratic labor unions in New York, labor and political sources reported yesterday.

title: GEORGE BELL, 59 PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: MONTREAL, July 20 (AP)George Maxwell Bell, one of Canada's leading newspaper publishers and an internationally known horseman, died last night after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Egypt Appears to Seek to Limit the Impact of Russians Ouster
description: CAIRO, July 20The Egyptian leadership made several moves today apparently intended to limit the emotional and political impact of President Anwar elSadat's decision to oust Soviet military advisers from Egypt.

title: and in Rome, Valentino Regards Pants as Pas
description: ROME, July 20Fashion designers aren't the only people yearning for the good old days. Storekeepers also fondly recall the time when women traveled with steamer trunks filled with clothes instead of with back packs, when ladies wore white gloves and hats, and blue jeans were for farmers and laborers.

title: MINORITY CABINET RESIGNS IN FINLAND
description: H0ELSINKI, Finland, July 20 (Reuters)Finland's minority Government resigned here last night four days before the nation was due to sign a freetrade agreement with the European Common Market.

title: G & S Gondoliers Is Kept Bouncing With Much Style
description: There have been years of drought, but New York seldom goes for long without a Gilbert and Sullivan repertory company. The current defender of the faith is the Light Opera of Manhattan, which was founded three years ago by William MountBurke and is operating at the small Jan Hus Playhouse on East 74th Street. It gives performances Wednesday through Saturday evenings, with matinees on Saturday and Sunday.

title: M'DONALD DECIDNS TO DO THE DRIVING
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 20Duncan MacDonald, the owner of Fresh Yankee, named himself today to drive the 9yearold mare in Saturday night's $150,000 challenge trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: DR. RALPH ANDRE KLING
description: Dr. Ralph Andre Kling, an internist with offices at 485 Park Avenue, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Le Rouret, near Cannes, France. He was 71 years old and lived at 30 Sutton Plade.

title: ALEXANDER UPSETS LAVER, 25, 62, 75
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Rod Laver, the world's best unseeded player, and three of the topseeded stars were eliminated today in the third round of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

title: Beirut Sources Assert Move Was Forced by Sadat's Officers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20The Egyptian military command played a major role in the removal of the Soviet military advisers from Egypt, according to a variety of sources here.

title: Mayor Issues Urgent Plea For Power Conservation
description: Goaded by another day of oppressive heat, New Yorkers sapped Consolidated Edisdn's troubled electrical system yesterday and tapped hydrants so often that officials pleaded for restraint and expressed fear of tragedy.

title: Notes on People
description: Clifford Irving, the writer who is preparing to go to prison for his fradulent autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire, said his upcoming book about the hoax would not be a hoax. I have been told in no uncertain terms by the U.S. Attorney's office, Mr. Irving said at a news conference in New York, that if anything in the book contradicts my sworn statements or testimony before the grand jury, I will face a perjury charge and that carries up to five years in prison. No sane man would take that risk. Mr. Irving's 2year sentence will start in a few weeks. And, oh yes, Mr. Irving said the new bookto be published in Septemberwould disclose the name of a person involved in the hoax who had not been publicly connected with it.

title: Nay!
description: We have a very strong tradition in this country, observed Clay T. Whitehead, director of the Office of. Telecommunications Policy, that the press and Government stay at arm's length, that they be kept apart.

title: Americans Visiting Polish Relatives Find Some Surprising Similarities in LifeStyles
description: BIELSKOBIALA, Poland, July 11  A young woman dental student living in this southern Polish industrial city stopped an American relative's account of life in the States few days ago with an expression of stunned disbelief:

title: U.S. War Toll Last Week Is Given as 8, a Rise of 4
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (AP)  The United States command today listed eight Americans as killed in action in Indochina last week, four more than the previous week.

title: Justice Darwin W. Telesiord, Of State Supreme Court, Dies
description: Justice Darwin W. Telesford of the State Supreme Court, First Judicial District, who retired Dec. 31, died Wednesday at his home, 409 Edgecombe Avenue. He was 71 years old.

title: Prague Sentences 3 Former Communist Party Aides to Up to 2 Years in Prison
description: PRAGUE, July 20 (AP)Three former Communist party officers, including a key supporter of Alexander Dubcek, received sentences of up to twoandahalf years in prison today for antiGovernment activities.

title: DIETZ ADVANCES IN TWOBOAT HEAT
description: LAKE WARAMAUG, Conn., July 20  The national single sculls champion, Jim Dietz of the New York A.C., had little trouble qualifying today for tomorrow's semifinals in Olympic rowing trials on Lake Waramaug. Only Tom Rafferty of the Schuylkill B.C. made it to the starting line with him in the fourth heat.

title: In New. York's Heat, the Minis Are Still Very Much in Style
description: Who killed the miniskirt? Certainly not the fashion hierarchy, which did its utmost to drop hemlines a couple of years ago.

title: Accords on Arms Control Approved by Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today the agreements on strategic arms control recently concluded by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: SAIGON'S TROOPS OPEN NEW DRIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 21The South Vietnamese armed forces, already pushing to recapture lost territory in northern Quangtri Province, have begun a second counteroffensive to retake Communistheld areas  this time in Binhdinh Province on the central coast.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, July 20The feeling is growing among veteran architects of the EuropeAmerica partnership that neglect is endangering the whole system, which has kept the two continents at peace among themselves since World War II.

title: Cars, Movies Backless Dresses Help New Yorkers Fight Heat
description: A man's home may be his castle, but not these days unless it is airconditioned.

title: IL VAGABONDO IS NOW OPEN
description: 351 E. 62nd st.(Advt)

title: 3 VIETNAM VETERANS ARE FREED ON BOND
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 20 (UPO)Three members of Vietnam Veterans Against the War posted bonds totaling $75,000 today and walked away after week in jail, calling the Federal conspiracy charges against them garbage.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Suffolk Guidance and Counseling Center, Inc., Smithtown, LI., therapy, marriagecounseling and teaching center that the local professional psychologists society claims has been a source of complaints from clients, now being looked into by the State Attorney General.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 Clark MacGregor, the manager of President Nixon's reelection campaign, said today that he had asked Mr. Nixon to delay any serious campaigning until three weeks before the election.

title: TREASURY NOTES RESERVE'S MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Treasury confirmed today the decision of the Federal Reserve System to intervene in the foreign exchange markets and said the new technique Would be used upon occasion  when it is desirable to help deal with speculative forces.

title: ROWE YACHT, ANN, WINS THIRD RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 The senior onedesign class sailors returned to the 74th Race Week at Larchmont Yacht Club today after a hiatus of three days.

title: Scott Panel Wins Court Ruling On City Employes Testimony
description: The state commission investigating the city government won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to question city employes even when two commissioners were not present.

title: City Starts BurglaryPrevention Program
description: Nine years after a wealthy Los Angeles suburb instituted a burglaryprevention program in which identifying numbers are etched onto belongings and registered with the police, and after similar programs spread to 41 states and 400 cities around the country, New York City announced yesterday that it was starting one also, in eight of its 70 precincts.

title: Men in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Al H. Chesser became the first elected president of the United Transportation Union on Jan. 1. That was the same date on which William H. Dempsey took over the National Railway Labor Conference, which is the management group. After their first meeting, Mr. Chesser came back and told his associates, We put a lot of hay in the barn. Less than seven months later  and after a few smaller steps toward cooperationrailroad workers and management have made a significant move toward reducing the kind of featherbedding that has plagued the country's rail lines for decades.

title: DEMENT OUTPOINTS HUNTER IN TRIALS
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., July 20 (AP)Tim Dement of Bossier City, La., his flicking left jab consistently on target, all but sidetracked Bobby Lee Hunter's quest of a gold medal tonight in the United States Olympic boxing trials. Dement recorded a decisive flyweight victory over Hunter.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP)  Willie Mays of the New York Mets was among 11 players named by Manager Danny Murtaugh today to complete the 28man National League AllStar squad for next Tuesday's game at Atlanta.

title: PHONE COMPANY DENIED INCREASE
description: The chairman of the State Public Service Commission said yesterday that his agency would not at this time allow a request by the New York Telephone Company to charge for directoryassistance calls.

title: Evans to Coach Gulls
description: SAN DIEGO, July 20 (UPI)An experienced defenseman, Jack Evans, 44 years old, was appointed coach of the Western Hockey League's San Diego Gulls today.

title: Channel Swim Mark Claimed by Miss Cox
description: DOVER, England, July 20 (UPI) Lynne Cox, 15 years old, of Los Alamitos, Calif., today claimed a record for swimming the English Channel from Dover to France.

title: For Bobby Fischer, The Nabokov Defense
description: Vladimir Nabokov, one of whose novels is about a Russian chess genius, said yesterday that Bobby Fischer was quite right in objecting to the use of television cameras at the world championship match in Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)Russian grain production this year probably will drop to not much over 171 million tons, about 10 per cent short of Soviet goals, an Agriculture Department report forecast today.

title: SEYMOUR WARNS THOSE WHO BRIBE
description: In a hardhitting attack on the business community here, United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. warned yesterday that his office was adopting a new policy of prosecuting the businessmen who pay bribes as well as the government officials and labor racketeeri who receive them.

title: Advertising: Thompson Holds a Pep Rally
description: The gang from the New York office of J. Walter Thompson trooped over to the grand ballroom of the Commodore yesterday for a pep rally that included the announcement that E. Wyatte Hicks is the new managing director of the office.

title: FLOOD FRER JOHNSTOWN. PENNA. IS WELL AND PROSPERING
description: For Details Wrtle TribuneDemocrat. Advt.

title: GENERAL PHONE RAISES PROFITS
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries achieved new highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales, net income and share earnings for both the second quarter and first half, Leslie H. Warner, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: ATLANTA, July 20Gov. George C. Wallace, recuperating in Birmingham, Ala., from bullet wounds and further surgery, will not attend the nominating convention of the American Independent party next month, a spokesman for his campaign said today.

title: Blake Charges Deliberate U.S. Bombing of Dikes
description: GENEVA, July 20The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Secretary General of the World Council of Churches, has written President Nixon that he believes that United States planes are deliberately bombing dikes in North Vietnam.

title: Maynard Is Given Jets Permission To Show Up Last
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 20  Don Maynard, not Joe Namath, will be the last of the New York Jets regulars to report to camp. Namath, the quarterback, is due here by 11 P.M. Sunday night. Maynard is not expected until sometime next week.

title: Judge Bars Prospective Juror Who Read the Pentagon Papers
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20On the ninth day of jury selection in the Pentagon papers case, the trial judge questioned the 40th prospective juror today and found the first one to say he had read any material from the controversial papers.

title: Manhattan Landing Clears Last Major Governmental Hurdles
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday removed the last major government hurdle in the way of Manhattan Landing, the proposed $1.2billion develcipment along the East River and Lower Bay and downtown Manhattan.

title: Bus Safety Code Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Representative Les Aspire Democrat of Wisconsin, milk today for Senate passage of bill that would require the Government to set comprelensive safety standards for construkion of school buses. Ht pressed for enactment in testimony before a Senate Commerce Committee hearing or school bus safety legislation.

title: William J. Wardall Dies at 87; Trustee of McKesson & Robbins
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., July 20  William J. Wardall, a former corporation executive and director, who was sole trustee in the reorganization of McKesson & Robbins Inc., died yesterday at Huntington Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived here.

title: Monetary Responsibility
description: The Administration's dramatic move in joining Europe to defend the dollar and other current exchange rates in world markets was described most pungently by the New York banker who said it demonstrated that the United States was back in the human race. The Connally era of adversary relationships with the country's major allies and trading partners has been ended by this one symbolic stroke, which signifies a return the kind of international monetary cooperation that to existed before the former Treasury Secretary took office.

title: NIXON WON'T PUSH ANTISTRIKE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The White House said today that it was dropping plans to press ahead this year with emergency legislation to combat transportation strikes but denied that the decision represented a deal with organized labor.

title: BUSING IN DETROIT HELD UP BY COURT
description: DETROIT, July 20  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit blocked at least temporarily today moves to start school busing in the fall between Detroit and its suburbs.

title: Line Halts Honolulu Flights
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 20 (AP) Northwest Airlines announced today that it was dropping weekend round trips between Chicago and Honolulu for the duration of the strike by 1,600 members of the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: But Sales Show Gain
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday declines in net income for the second quarter and first half Jespite higher sales and operating revenues in both periods.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Syrian and Lebanese request that Israel release five prisoners.

title: Running Fire Hydrants Cause Muddy Water and Lower Pressure
description: All over the city, apparently in record numbers, children have been trying to beat the heat the last few days by opening fire hydrants. In so doing they have played havoc with the water system.

title: Roundup: Garr of Braves Pulls Grambling Reverse
description: Not every athlete who attends Grambling College in Louisiana goes on to fame and fortune in professional football  although it frequently seems that way.

title: China Opens Pavilion at Montreal Fair
description: MONTREAL, July 20China made her first appearance at an international exposition in North America today by opening a pavilion here featuring her cultural heritage.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: President Nixon's bid for reelection has the endorsement of organizations representing some 155,000 policemen across the nation, a national police official said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: These three whodunits ought to please a broad spectrum of aficionados: those who like tight and intricate plotting (The Baron Goes Fast), those who enjoy seeing a murder mystery unfold in the confines of a venerable English mansion (Tied Up in Tinsel) and those who enjoy the tingling sensation of menace as it is revealed in the confrontations of warring components in a small American town (Shock Wave).

title: Petition Bids Meany Quit
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)The executive board of Local P616 of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America voted today to circulate a petition among its members calling for the resignation of George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., for his decision to keep labor neutral in the Presidential election.

title: Sally Benson, Author, 71, Dies; Wrote Meet Me in St. Louis
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif., July 21 (AP)  Sally Benson, author of Meet Me in St. Louis as well as other books and screenplays, died Wednesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital. She was 71 years old.

title: Meta eat Giants, 3 to I on May's 650th Home Run
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21celebrated his return to San Francisco with two resounding whacks today. First, he walked into a pillar at the airport early this morning and then tonight he hit the 650th homer of his career.

title: 151DayOld Strike Ended
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 21 (UPI) Members of the Newspaper Guild voted 76 to 22 today to approve a wage contract offered by publishers of The Canton Repository, ending a 151dayold strike.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: THURMONT, Md., July 21 (AP)President Nixon flew by helicopter from hot and smoggy Washington today to his mountaintop Maryland retreat at Camp David with former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally.

title: Roundup: Gibson Garners 11 th Straight
description: It's a cliche, but the fact is that Bob Gibson, like wine, gets better with age.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF BACKS CONTROLS ON GUNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) L. Patrick Gray, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, favors the licensing and registration of all firearms and the banning of the socalled Saturday night specials.

title: ScheringPlough
description: Record sales and earnings were attained by ScheringPlough Corporation in the second quarter and first half this year, Witt Conzen, president and chief executive of the drugs, toiletries and cosmetics company reported yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Senator Thomas P. Eagleton said today he would emphasize law and order and urban problems as the Democratic VicePresidential candidate this fall, but vowed he would not outAgnew Agnew no matter how rough the campaign gets.

title: 7 CHARGED HERE AS TOP GAMBLERS
description: Seven men described by law enforcement officials as among the city's top known gamblers were indicted here yesterday on charges that they operated a $20millionayear gambling ring.

title: DIRECTORY COMPILED OF MINORITY SERVICE
description: A listing of 172 minority suppliers of goods and services in metropolitan New York has been compiled by the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, a national, nonprofit organization devoted to developing minoritybusiness.

title: Widow Sues Con Ed On Ending of Service
description: The Consolidated Edison Company is being sued by a 77yearold Brooklyn widow who protests that the termination of her electric service without prior notice of a hearing violates her civil rights.

title: Police Lack Clues In the Investigation Of Eboli's Murder
description: Chief of Detectives Louis Cottell said yesterday that the investigation into the murder of Thomas Eboli, the Mafia chieftain, was getting nowhere.

title: St. Louis Mayor Loses Appeal on Life Libel Suit
description: ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has upheld a lower court decision dismissing a $12million libel suit against Life magazine by Mayor A. J. Cervantes of St. Louis.

title: PAROCHIAL AID LAW SET BACK IN STATE
description: A state law designed to provide about $4million a year for the maintenance and repair of parochial schools was declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a panel of three Federal judges.

title: KENNETH S. HOWARD
description: DOVER, N. J., July 21 (AP)Kenneth S. Howard, a charter member of the Marshall Chess Club of New York and a former leditor of the American Chess Players Bulletin died yesterday at All Souls Hospital in Morristown. He was 90 years old.

title: Shriners Install Chief
description: DALLAS; July 21 (UPI) About 100,000 Shriners completed their 100th meeting of th imperial council today by installing a new imperial potentate. Henry B. Struby of Evansville, Ind., was installed as imperial potentate of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of North America, at a special ceremony.

title: Party Conference In Rumania Votes For Broad Reforms
description: BUCHAREST, July 21 The Rumanian Communist party approved a broad reform program tonight, providing major economic improvements at home and some radical initiatives in foreign policy.

title: Petrouchka Given By Ballet Theater, And It Still Charms
description: Petrouchka is a wonderful ballet, and the American Ballet Theater offers a wonderful production of this early Fokine work for Diaghilev's Ballet Russe. It was, in effect, the ballet that set the seal on the international reputation of its composer, the young Igor Stravinsky.

title: From Mud Hole to Playground, Thanks to 16 Schoolchildren
description: TENAFLY, N. J.Dear kind, lovable, contributing parents  we are building a playground for the school (level four that is) and we were short on dough for supplies.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas will stay on as Republican national chairman after the party's convention in Miami Beach next month, President Nixon told his Cabinet today.

title: WACHOVIA CORP. SHOWS NET GAIN
description: The Wachovia Corporation, a diversified bank and financial service concern with $3billion In assets reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in the first half of 1972 were $15.5million, or $1.06 a share, up 7.1 per cent from the $14.5million or 99 cents a share earned in the same period last year.

title: Meskill Calls on President To Keep Agnew on Ticket
description: HARTFORD, July 21Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today he had urged President Nixon in a letter to keep Vice President Agnew on the Republican ticket as his running mate this fall.

title: Cost Increase Here Lowest in 5 Years
description: Consumer prices in the metropolitan area rose only slightly last month, with a sharp decline in clothing costs offsetting major increases in food and housing costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

title: Judge Orders the Abolition Of Death Rows in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (UPI)  United States District Judge Robert Peckham has ruled that death rows in California prisons must be abolished.

title: Four Steps to Wise Divorce
description: In the current crusade for women's equality the abed for changes in the marital lawshas not hadthe attention it deserves and requires.

title: British Dock Strike Grows
description: LONDON, July 21 (Reuters)  Britain's docks moved toward total paralysis tonight as thousands of workers marched off their jobs to protest an order jailing five of their leaders today for alleged illegal picketing.

title: Huge Traffic Jams On Way to Quangtri Easy Target of Foe
description: MYCHANH, South Vietnam, July 21A kind of random killing has begun all along Route 1 south of Quangtri, in which there seems to be no safe place for anyone, especially the cursing drivers of trucks, tanks and ambulances jammed up for miles.

title: INDIANS TO MEET ON SAYING LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Representatives of 19 Indian tribes in the West will meet in Denver for two days beginning tomorrow to devise a strategy against seizures of their land and water that they fear will force them into urban slums.

title: BreastStroke Mark Set
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 21 (UPI)Walter Kusch Was clocked in 1 minute 6.42 seconds today for a national 100meter breaststroke record at the West German swimming championships. His own previous standard was 1:07.1.

title: Yanks Make Clean Sweep: 60. and 30
description: Since Fritz Peterson and Mel Stottlemyre set down the California Angels without a run for 18 straight, innings last night the Yankees had an easy time winning a twilightnight doubleheader 60 and 30. But they enjoyed showing off their newly found muscles anyway.

title: ROSS DENIES A ROLE IN TIEMPO CLOSING
description: Stanley Ross, who helped found the Spanishlanguage newspaper El Tiempo in 1963 and served as its editor in chief until ousted in a 1969 proxy fight, charged yesterday that the paper's demise on Thursday was the sole responsibility of management over the last three years.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Trade. The White House announced that United States Ambassador for Trade William B. Eberle would resume trade talks in Japan next week. The talks are a continuation of earlier discussions held last May in Tokyo to exchange views on trade and related matters.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE GAINS
description: Soybeans made a strong showing yesterday, pushed ahead by continued enthusiastic reports about increased export demand. Earlier in the week traders reacted favorably to the news that the United States and Japan had signed a trade agreement.

title: FRENCH DRUG MOVE IS HAILED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 21President Nixon has sent congratulations to President Georges Pompidou on the seizure of three heroin laboratories in southern France since last Saturday, Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: TORONTO, July 21Canada's Department of National Defense will buy 33 new longrange patrol aircraft to cost about $750million. Tenders have been invited from the Boeing Company, Tacoma, Wash., the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Burbank, Calif., and McDonnell Douglas, all in the United States, and the Hawker Siddeley group Britaki.

title: PAUL L. TROAST, 78, OF JERSEY TURNPIKE
description: CLIFTON, N. J., July 21Paul L. Troast, a New Jersey builder who was the first chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, died yesterday at his home, 324 Dwas Lane, after an illness of three months. He was 78 years old.

title: 100 Envelopes Sold
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The 100 postal covers from the moon advertised by Herman Sieger, a West German dealer, reportedly were snapped up at the $1,500 asking price.

title: Sports of The Times
description: While negotiations for FrazierAli II have stalled to where the rematch is unlikely to develop until next year, an offer of $8million for Jack Kent Cooke's contract the promoter has been made by a mysterious group London sportsmen.

title: Auto Output Is Cut By a ChangeOver To the 73 Models
description: DETROIT, July 21 (AP)Continuing model change  overs dropped domestic auto production 17,000 units this week, the trade newspaper Automotive News said today.

title: Dr. Irwin B. Gould, 47, Dies; Was Psychotherapist Here
description: Dr. Irwin B. Gould, a psychotherapist, psychologist and psychoanalyst, died of a brain tumor at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center on Thursday. He was 47 years old and lived at the El Dorado, Central, Park West and 91st Street.

title: Russians Puzzled
description: MOSCOW, July 21You're asking about the blunder? the young Russian chess enthusiast said. I think the biggest blunder Spassky ever made was to sit down opposite Fischer to play chess.

title: The Vantage Point
description: What makes my hackles rise is to hear a woman described as a man's mistress. I get the same prickling of the skin, sense of suffocation and adrenal overstimulation as from instant insults such as kike, spic, nigger, and dago. They are all so meanspirited and contemptuous, aimed at the supposedly weak by the selfassured mighty.

title: DIETZ, VAN BLOM ROWING VICTORS
description: KENT, Conn., July 21 (AP)  Jim Dietz and John Van Blom recorded victories in singlesculls competition today on Lake Waramaug to advance to the final of the United States Olympic rowing trials.

title: DON'T MISS THE AQUAQUEEN AD ON
description: DON'T MISS THE AQUAQUEEN AD ON page 18. You'll never have to vacuum your swimming pool amtin.Advt.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, July 21Boston became the first threetime winner of the annual intercity championship by defeating Denver here last night.

title: Mort Kaye Weds Miss Shackleton
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 21  Miis Leslie Ashton Shackleton, an advertising associate with The Palm Beach Daily News, was married here this afternoon to Mort Kaye, a professional photographer and president of Mort Kaye Studios here. Rabbi Robert Frazin performed the ceremony at the Breakers Hotel.

title: In Striving for Poise, Spassky Tries Tennis
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 21Boris Spassky the world chess champion, was playing tennis today, apparently trying to regain his poise after last night's resounding defeat in the fifth match game against the challenger, Bobby Fischer of the United States. The score is now even at 2 to 2.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: This is in partial reply to Ralph S. DeClark's letter (July 10) on extending the subways. The George Washington Bridge was designed to have railroad tracks incorporated within its structure, and the IND subway was originally built with a spur from the 168th Street station directed toward the bridge; that was back in the 1930's. The rapid transit system could have been used In connection with a Fort Lee (N.J.) bus terminal. This plan and so many others never came about because of the intractable position of each local public agency.

title: 57 Slayings Here in Week Set Record the Police Link to Heat
description: Fiftyseven homicidesa recordwere committed here in the sevenday period that ended at midnight Thursday, the office of the Chief Medical Examiner reported yesterday.

title: Art: Museums for a Day in the Country
description: Museums in the country take better to the summer than their city cousins, While art activities in Manhattan tend to taper off at this season, rural and suburban musums stage their most significant exhibitions. So delightfully pastoral are the museums surroundings that they provide a welcome refuge from the New York hurlyburly. Here, on what might be called the Offoff art scene are some museums well worth the time and the travel to visit.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Let's just say you couldn't reach me for comment, one New York Democratic Representative said this week when reached for comment on how actively he would be supporting the McGovernEagleton ticket in the fall campaign. His reaction indicated that not all of the 23 Democratic Representatives from New York still seeking reelection had decided whether to tie their own campaigns closely to the party's national ticket. There was no indication that any of the incumbent New York Democrats would openly repudiate the candidacy of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, as some liberal Republicans in the state did when Senator Barry M. Goldwater was their party's Presidential candidate in 1964.

title: In Anchorage, the Ultrahigh Prices Are a Shock to Newcomers
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 21 Mrs. Neta Morris of Dixon, Ill., a new arrival here, stood, outside a supermarket and admitted that the food prices left her flabbergasted.

title: PATRICK MEADE DIES; WRITER ON HUNTING
description: WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 21 (AP)Patrick A. Meade, a writer on hunting, died Wednesday in Day Kimball hospital, Putnam. He was 77 years old.

title: Six Arrested in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 21 (UPI)The Suffolk County District Attorney's office announced today that it had broken up a $1millionayear bookmaking and policy ring operating out of an Italian bakery in East Babylon with the arrest of four men and two women.

title: Professional Athletes Exempted By Council From Curbs on Pay
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Cost of Living Council announced today that professional athletes were exempt from Pay Board regulations under the Administration's economic stabilization program.

title: Hicks Still Prime Man In the Jets Secondary
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 21 Two years ago, after W. K. Hicks had come from Houston to New York for a fifthround draft choice, there was seven years of professional football starting experience in the Jet defensive backfieldand Hicks had six ot them.

title: Senate Backs Restoral Of the Canaveral Name
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)The Senate passed today without debate and without objection a measure to restore the name of Cape Canaveral to the area on the Florida East Coast designated as Cape Kennedy by President Johnson.

title: RAIL POWER LOSS STALLS THOUSANDS
description: Thousands of Penn Central commuters were stranded in sweltering trains and thousands of others were delayed during the evening rush hour yesterday when a lightning storm knocked out all power on the New Haven Division between Mount Vernon and New Haven.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN O'BRIEN CRITICIZES CONNALLY TACTICS Asserts He Uses Blackmail to Woo Some Democrats Into President's Camp
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Lawrence F. O'Brien. Senator George McGovern's new campaign chairman, accused John B. Connally today of using strongarm tactics to persuade Democratic leaders to join President Nixon's reelection drive.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: An estimated 200 Newspaper Guild members employed at The New York Daily News have signed a petition demanding that the International Newspaper Guild rescind its endorsement of Senator George McGovern for president.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Freud's Disaster With Cocaine
description: SAN FRANCISCO Those in the medical profession or the youth culture who do not seriously consider the hidden consequences of drug use may profitably ponder the unfortunate error of that astute observer of human experience, Sigmund Freud. The story of Freud's fascination with cocaine is not unknown but its retelling at this time may be useful.

title: Soviet Venus 8 to Land Today; 8Satellite Cosmos Is Orbited
description: MOSCOW, July 21Soviet) scientists prepared today for a soft landing of their latest Venus spacecraft tomorrow in the hope that it will supply the first chemical data on the surface of the distant planet.

title: Italians Break Relay Mark
description: BARLETTA, Italy, July 21 (UPI)The Italian 800meter relay team, anchored by Pietro Mennea, clipped twotenths of a second from the world record tonight. The team of Franco Ossola, Pasqualino Abeti, Luigi Benedetti and Mennea, who is coholder of the European 100and 200meter track records, clocked 1:21.5 minutes over the distance. The previous mark was 1:21.7, set by Texas A. ana M. in 1970.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALBANY, July 21Mayor Lindsay, in a strong plea for party unity, told Democrats here today that they could not afford petty bickering or ideological spite if they wanted to elect Senator George McGovern President and win control of the State Legislature.

title: C.I.A. AIDES ASSAIL ASIA DRUG CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Central Intelligence Agency has begun a public battle against accusations that it knew of but failed to stem the heroin traffic of United States allies in Southeast Asia.

title: Exchange Fines Brokers Over Student's Escapade
description: The stockmarket escapade seven months ago of Abraham H. Treff, a Philadelphia college student, continued yesterday to produce repercussions in Wall Street.

title: MELNYK, YANCEY AND FLOYD SHARE AKRON GOLF LEAD
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 21Steve Melnyk, a rookie on the pro tour with a limited budget and a bit of tendonitis in his right arm, shared the 36hole lead in the $150,000 American Golf Classic today with Bert Yancey and Ray Floyd. The trio was tied at 137.

title: Suffolk Ethics Unit Begins Inquiry Into Beach Deal
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 21The Suffolk County Board of Ethics began an investigation today, at a closeddoor session, of transactions leading to the acquisition of Tiana Beach as a county park.

title: Daniel J. O'Meara Dead; Ad Agency Merchandiser
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., July 21Daniel J. O'Meara, who retired in 1962 as vice president in charge of merchandising at Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell & Bayles, Inc., New Yorkbased advertising agency, died July 7 at the North Broward Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Senate Backs U.S. Housing Built and Run by Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Senate passed 60 to 11, today a bill to let public utility holding companies bund, own and operate federally assisted low and moderate income housing projects.

title: Courts Act on Air Pollution Over the Ohio River Valley
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UPI) A mass of polluted air hovered over the Ohio River Valley today and officials obtained court orders to force some industries to halt air emissions in an attempt to ease the crisis.

title: Notes on People
description: Three, goldpainted, horsedrawn, stateowned landaus drew up in front of Buckingham Palace, and out stepped Sung Shihkuang, the first Communist Chinese Ambassador to Britain and therefore the first to present himself and his credentials to Queen Elizabeth II. In what was hardly an exercise in secret diplomacy, the Ambassador and nine of his assistants were seen by hundreds of camerawielding tourists as they entered the palace dressed in simple darkblue Maoist tunic suits. The Ambassador's conversation with the Queen was private.

title: Honz Wins 400 at Munich
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 21 (UPI)Karl Honz won the 400meter run today in the national record time of 44.7 seconds at the West German track and field championships. Honz bettered the previous mark of 44.9 seconds, set by Carl Kaufmann 12 years ago. Annegret Kroniger, 19, won the women's 200meter dash in 23.10 to equal the national record.

title: TEAMSTERS ALERTED TO ANTISTRIKE SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that the Nixon Administration had told the teamsters union that it would drop its effort to gain passage this year of a bill unpopular with transportation unions before the teamsters endorsed President Nixon for reelection.

title: Rumania, Soviet Tied
description: MOSCOW, July 21 (AP)Rumania and the Soviet Union split the opening singles matches today in the European Zone A Davis Cup tennis final at the Georgian capital, Tbilisi.

title: Mead Corporation
description: Corrugated shipping containers volume, which is regarded as a leading economic indicator, is the strongest in years, the Mead Corporation stated yeserday in reporting results for the second quarter and first half this year.

title: New Orleans Dances At Benefit for Its Zoo
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 21This hardly seems the time of year to give a charity dinnerdance, especially in a city known for its heat and humidity. But a group of innovative New Orleanians did last night and raised over $35,000 for the Audubon Park Zoo.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's large power transformer division at Muncie, Ind., announced yesterday that it would extend the warranty on all new orders for shell form transformers to 10 years. This was said to line years longer than the industry standard.

title: Insurance Agents Back Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Insurance Workers International Union announced today its members had approved a new contract with John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company providing $26 a week in increased pay and fringe benefits over three years to 6,000 agents.

title: CITY ACTS TO CITE FIRE OFFICER UNIT
description: State Supreme Court Justice Margaret Mary J. Mangan considered yesterday a request by the city to cite the Uniformed Fire Officers Association for contempt of court.

title: ERIC ROSS HEARD IN RARE CONCERT
description: Although Eric Kloss has been recording for six years, since he was 17, and has shown on those recordings that he is one of the most thoroughly accomplished of today's young jazz saxophonists, he is very rarely heard in New York. This week, thanks to a promotional gambit by his recording company, Cobblestone, whereby Folk City has been turned into Jazz City for five weeks to put Cobblestone's jazz artists on display, Mr. Kloss is making one of his rare local appearances and, in the process, demonstrating that there has been nothing misleading about his recordings.

title: Airports Here Are Shut HalfHoar Daring Storm
description: The electrical storm that knocked out service on the Penn Central also forced airports in the metropolitan area to close down for halfan hour last evening.

title: Warr, Vroom, It's Music a la Moog
description: The Moog Synthesizer can make you hear the aroma of coffee or fill your ears with the purple of a sunset.

title: Superfecta Pays $29,618
description: CANADAIGUA, N. Y., July 21 (UPI)The superfecta at Finger Lakes race track yesterday was just thatsuperfor Mrs. Joan Mastroianni of Auburn, N. Y., who was the only winner in the ninth race with the superfecta numbers of 9,5,7,6. It paid $29,618. To win the superfecta it is necessary to select the first four horses to cross the finish line in exact order.

title: Convicted Hijacker Appeals. Saying Search Was lllegal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 21 (AP)Richard Floyd McCoy Jr. has appealed his conviction in the hijacking of an airliner for $500,000 ransom.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)Manager Earl Weaver named Bert Campaneris of the Oakland A's today to replace injured Luis Aparicio of the Boston Red Sox as the American League's starting shortstop in the AllStar game next Tuesday at Atlanta. The 38yearold Aparicio was voted the starting honor in balloting by fans, but he has been sidelined with a broken finger suffered a month ago.

title: Del Monte Buys Own Stock
description: The Del Monte Corporation reported yesterday the purchase of a block of 272,000 shares of its own stock. Alfred E. Eames, Jr., chairman, said the purchase had been made through Sutro & Co. and the price was slightly below the curent market price. He added that the shares wont dbe used for general corporate purposes, including future evpansion and diversification.

title: Moriarty Held in Jersey
description: J'ERSEY CITY, July 21Joseph Moriarty was among 23 persons arrested in a series of gambling raids conducted throughout Hudson County tonight.

title: Peak Sales and Profits Shown By Schlitz and ScheringPlough
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company rolled up record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended with June, with profit gains of 35 and 30 per cent, respectively, for the periods, it was reported yesterday.

title: Black Man Fatally Beaten; 5 White Youths Are Sought
description: A 47yearold black man was beaten to death with a baseball bat by five white youths late yesterday afternoon on Bleecker Street near Mott Street in the East Village, according to the police. The youths reportedly turned on the man when he interfered in an argument they were having among themselves.

title: Reed to Plead Not Guilty In Incident With Police
description: Willis Reed, the captain of the Knicks, will plead not guilty Aug. 3 to charges of reckless endangerment, menacing, harassment, impersonating an officer and a traffic violation. Those charges were lodged against him after a nearaccident Thursday with a car driven by an offduty, patrolman, Joseph Guarino.

title: WINE TALK
description: Would you prefer a DC10 with Paul Masson Cabernet Sauvignon, or a Boeing 747 with Inglenook Chenin Blanc? The choice is yours these days, because wine has become very big with the airlines.

title: Administration, Press
description: During its three and a half years in office, the Nixon Administration has evinced undisguised hostility toward working reporters and has attempted by threats and by legal and economic reprisals to intimidate television networks, influential metropolitan newspapers, and magazines.

title: Jane Fonda's 'F.T.A.' Show Now a Film
description: By now most people must know something about the political vaudeville troupe formed by Jane Fonda, Donald Sutherland and others to offer soldiers an alternate entertainment to say, Bob Hope, or whatever shows are provided by the U.S.O. The troupe called itself F.T.A., which stands for Free Theater Associates, or for other things such as, Free the Army.Last year, against considerable official opposition, it toured United States military bases in the Pacific. Francine Parker's "F.T.A.," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Victoria theaters, is a documentary about aspects of that tour.The film divides its attention pretty evenly between the performers and their audience, and a lot of time is given to interviews with dissident, or merely disillusioned, servicemen. Some hate the war in Vietnam. Some just voice dismay at certain truths about the military like "They don't want you to be an individual") that have been perpetually rediscovered by raw recruits at least since the Battle of Thermopylae.So much time is given to the audience, whose insights, though real, are neither original nor profound, that the actual performance comes across in scattered bits and pieces.A lot of the show must have been very funny, with a kind of humor genuinely in touch with the desperation borne of simply being in the service. (Army doctor prescribing to obviously pregnant wife of enlisted man: "Go home and take two A.P.C. tablets and come back when your swelling goes down.")But as presented in the movie, most of the show doesn't seem very funny, except inadvertentlyas when Donald Sutherland seriously recites the prose of Dalton Trumbo with a straight-from-the-shoulder solemnity that happens to be perfectly in keeping with his phony-preacher characterization in Jules Feiffer's "Little Murders."Occasionally the F.T.A. troupe becomes involved with the local population, so that we may hear the Just Grievances Against American Imperialism of the people of Okinawa or Japan or wherever Miss Fonda and her colleagues happen to be listening. I found most of this a predictable bore, but it did allow for the film's only really striking sequence: an anti-American guerrilla theater pageant in the Philippines that momentarily turns revolutionary passion into a romantic gesture of extraordinary beauty.Otherwise there are a few good things. There is the lovely ballad singing of Rita Martinson (most of the singing, by Len Chandler, isn't so lovely), some hints at lively routines, an occasional glimpse of deep happiness in eyes of Miss Fonda or of Holly Near. But the spirit of F.T.A. must lie elsewhere, in other times and special places. For all its agility and pressing close-ups, the film doesn't capture that spiritor even adequately show the kind of experience that might have let it grow.

title: Advance for Namibia
description: South Africa's Government says it is willing to accept a personal representative of the United Nations Secretary General to assist in achieving selfdetermination and independence for the people of Namibia (SouthWest Africa). This considerable advance derives from Dr. Kurt Waldheim's visit to Namibia and South Africa last spring, and he rightly proposes, with Security Council sanction, to accept Pretoria's offer.

title: Senate, Bowing to Nixon, Cuts Funds for Public TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)  Bowing to President Nixon's veto, the Senate passed today a cutdown authorization for the public broadcasting system.

title: Lindsay's Campaign Role
description: I served for a decade in Washington, in the executive branch and in the Congress. I made speeches; I wrote laws, said Mayor Lindsay in announcing his candidacy for his newly adopted Democratic party's Presidential nomination several months ago in Florida. He then drew a contrast between himself and the triumvirate of Senators who were his principal rivals. But any single week as Mayor of New Yorkconfronting crime, disease and stunted livesconfronting the same reality I have seen in dozens of towns and cities and suburbshas taught me more about America than all my years in Washington.

title: RASA CONCERNED OVER MOON STATUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21An official of the space agency deplored today the commercial exploitation of a memorial sculpture placed on the moon last summer by the crew of Apollo 15. Copies of the small castaluminum figure have been placed on sale at $750 apiece.

title: V. A. Vans Cruise in Texas to Aid Disadvantaged
description: NEW BRAUNFELS, TexA shbeless 21yearold MexicanAmerican meekly approached the Veterans Administration vans that were parked in the shade of a mulberry tree behind the civic center and asked if he could file a disability claim for severe burns he suffered a year ago in Vietnam.

title: Friedrich Flick Is Dead at 89; Industrialist Who Aided Hitler
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, July 21 (AP)Friedrich Flick, a farmer's son who became one of Hitler's biggest industrial backers and was reputed to be postwar Germany's richest man, died yesterday at his home on Lake Constance, Switzerland. He was 89 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PRICHARD, Ala.On a street corner here recently, Jay Cooper, an aggressive young black man who went North, became a lawyer and is back home running for Mayor, asked a friend about support.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Gov. Tom McCall of Oregon, formerly an outspoken critic of Vice President Agnew, said today that he would not join any effort to drop Mr. Agnew next month as running mate for President Nixon. Governor McCall said in an interview that Mr. Agnew was pretty satisfactory to me.

title: U.S. ADMITS MOVE TO BURN FORESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)  Jerry W. Friedheim, the Pentagon spokesman, denied today that American attempts to destroy enemy cover in South Vietnam through forest fires had ever been secret or that the measures had been intended to produce devastating fire storms of the kind that ravaged aerial targets in Germany and Japan in World War II.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Tributes to John Paul Vann, who died recently in a helicopter crash near Kontum, have recognized his role as principal architect of the pacification program, his complete personal commitment to the U.S. undertaking in Vietnam and his outstanding qualities of personal courage and blunt, critical honesty. But they have not recognized the paradox that necessarily resulted when these qualities combined in one man.

title: Publisher On Federal Board
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., July 21 (AP)The White House announced today the appointment of Fred Conn, publisher of The San Angelo StandardTimes, to the Water Pollution Control. Advisory Board in the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Conn, whose term will expire June 30, 1975, succeeds a retiring member, Wallace Harvey. Also named to the board were Jack A. Beaver of Redlands, Calif., and Dr. Mitchell D. Zadronzny of Chicago.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 21A team of Moscow inventors was granted a United States patent this week for the TU144, the Soviet supersonic aircraft that was exhibited at the International Air Show in Le Bourget, France, in 1971. The inventors are Aleksei A. Tupolev, the chief designer, and seven associates. Earlier applications were filed for Soviet patents, and other American patents are pending on specific features.

title: The Voice of a Lieutenant
description: WEST POINT, N. Y.For many years, American citizens, have placed their trust in institutions such as the United States Military Academy at West Point to prepare young men to serve as competent and conscientious leaders of our armed forces.

title: ECONOMIC NEWS SPURS STOCK GAIN
description: Surprisingly bright gains in the nation's economy parted the gloom clouds over Wall Street yesterday and sent the stock market into a booming rally.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 21 (UPI)The 107,000member International Woodworkers of America announced today its endorsement of Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, for President.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is easy to appreciate the needs dogs satisfy and the pleasure they give their owners. Still, the mess they make in the streets is a very real nuisance and some means should be found to deal with it. The suggestion that owners clean up after their dogs is being resisted with some energy. It is a demeaning task.

title: U.S. Uncertain on Numbers
description: WASHINGTON, July 21State Department officials said today that the United States intelligence community remained uncertain how many Soviet military personnel would be withdrawn from Egypt as the result of President Sadat's orders. Estimates ranged from as low as 4,000 advisers to virtually all of the 18,000 to 20,000 advisers, pilots, missile technicians and others believed to be in Egypt.

title: Aruba Is Crippled by a Strike; Power and Water Supply Cut
description: The Dutchadministered island of Aruba is in the throes of a crippling strike by government workers that began on Tuesday, according to returning tourists and a spokesman here.
