The tiny tourist attraction in the Caribbean has been left with no electricity, little transportation, sporadic telephone service and a dwindling supply of water.

title: G.N.P. RATE IS 8.9%
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Government reported today a big rise in the nation's output of goods and services and a notable drop In the rate of inflation in the second quarter of this year.

title: SAIGON'S TROOPS RECAPTURE TOWN ON CENTRAL COAST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 22  South Vietnamese troops reportedly recaptured a district capital on the central coast yesterday without a fightalmost as they had lost it to Communist forces nearly three months ago.

title: Antiques: Looking at Baltimore Federal Furniture
description: Take a good look at the exhibition of Baltimore Federal furniture in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum, and you will understand why Americana enthusiasts prefer it so emphatically to English work of about the same period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Some governmental agenciesFederal, state and city (why discriminate?) operate by means of a curious logic of their own. Sometimes the results are harmless or amusing, but more often they are destructive.

title: OLIVE REEVESSMITH MUSICAL ACTRESS, 77
description: Olive ReevesSmith, a veteran actress last seen on Broadway as Mrs. EynsfordHill in My Fair Lady, died Thursday in the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street. She was 77 years old and formerly lived at the Edison Hotel.

title: Business Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 21 (Reuters)The Argentine Government today effectively devalued the peso by what observers estimated to be 3.54 per cent by modifying foreignexchange regulations.

title: Hyland, Larson Drill
description: MONMOUTH, N. J., July 21Two of the three Giants injured in last Monday's scrimmage returned to work today as a team held a controlled workout prior to tomorrow's intrasquad game.

title: Lynch Deplores Salrogery
description: DUBLIN, July 21 (Reuters)  The Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, John Lynch, tonight described the bombings in Belfast as savagery and called for an end to what he called these vile events.

title: Bronx Sewage Plant Contracts Signed
description: Contracts totaling $61million calling for the upgrading and expansion of the Hunts Point Water Pollution Control Plant in the Bronx were signed yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Gets a Sculpture Garden for All Seasons
description: A permanent sculpture garden in Brooklyn's Borough Hall Plaza opened yesterday at noon, when Parks Administrator August Heckscher unveiled weatheredtimbered works by the New York artist John Cross.

title: Penn Central Strike Is Averted By a Formula on Train Crews
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Labor Department announced today an agreement averting a threatened strike on the Penn Central railroad.

title: SILVESTRONE, ON 65, TAKES JERSEY GOLF
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., July 21Art Silvestrone of Pike Brook carded a sevenunderpar 33, 3265 today and won a threeway playoff for the 52d New Jersey State open golf championship at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club.

title: 2d Prisoner Who Escaped From Jersey Jail Is Caught
description: LINWOOD, N.J., July 21, (AP) The second of two men who escaped from the Atlantic County Jail Tuesday was caught today as he attempted to cool off in a private swimming pool.

title: Retailers Inventory Losses Trimmed
description: Retail inventory losses the merchant's bane and also believed to be symtomatic of a deeplyrooted social problemare down slightly so far in 1972, along with shoplifting and internal theft, a nationally known lossprevention expert reported yesterday.

title: Gisbert Upsets Kodes
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Ally 19 (AP)  Spain took a 10 lead over Czechoslovakia but darkness halted the second match with Spain in the Davis Cup European Zone. B tennis, final.

title: MINORITY BANKS SEEN OVER GOAL
description: ATLANTA, July 21Charls E. Walker, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, predicted here today that total deposits in minority banks would top $1billion by the end of this year.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TOKYO, July 21 (AP)Mayumi Aoki, 19 years old, of Japan set a world record of 1 minute 3.9 seconds in the women's 100meter butterfly swimming event today, breaking the previous mark by twotenths of a second. Alice Jones of the United States had established the listed mark of 1:04.1 at Los Angeles on Aug. 20, 1970.

title: Prime Rates Unchanged
description: The First National City Bank, the Irving Trust Company and the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday that their floating prime interest rates on business loans would remain unchanged at 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday.

title: 3 Youths Seeking a Fix Slain on West Side Roof
description: Three of the 57 persons slain here in a single week were West Side youths who walked the dark streets early Tuesday morning in search of a heroin fix.

title: Prague Imprisons 4 Dubcek Supporters
description: PRAGUE, July 21 (Reuters)Four prominent supporters of the former Communist party leader, Alexander Dubcek, were sentenced to terms ranging up to six years in jail today on charges of subversion.

title: Campbell Defends N.H. L. Ban of Hull from Canada Team for Soviet Series
description: Hockey's long, hot summer, in which players are becoming capitalists overnight, stars are jumping leagues, and a league jumped television networks, is in the midst of its most heated debates:

title: CHARITY CARE RULES IN HOSPITALS EASED
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Federal Government issued its first regulations today specifying the levels of charity care that more than 6,300 federally financed hospitals and health institutions must provide.

title: A Corruption Fighter Retires Undeterred After 31 Years on Force
description: Sydney C. Cooper, who during the last 31 years earned a reputation as one of the straightest, toughest policemen in New York City, retired from the department yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 21 (AP)  Approximately 8,000 Jefferson County residents are getting a mailed apology for a mistake that left the March of Dimes horrified, a printer in Pennsylvania mortified and the Republicans embarrassed.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, July 21 (UPI)Two more banks today raised their base rate to 7 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: S. David Leibowitt (letter July 5) criticized as discouraging philanthropy Senate bill 3378, which denies taxdeduction status to charitable gifts outside the U.S. He also took a sponsor, Senator McGovern, to task.

title: Think About It: Meditation Is Good for You
description: The desire for meditationconcentration with a spiritual objectiveis an innate tendency of the human mind and has been in evidence for the past thousand years. Patanjali, the most renowned authority on Yoga in India, divides meditation into three parts. Dharana; concentration in the preliminary stage. Dhyana; stabilized concentration for a certain length of time. And Samadhi; complete absorption in one thought or object to the exclusion of every other thought and even sense impression.

title: Paris Tightens Its Control Over Radio and TV News
description: PARIS, July 21The Government has won another round in the struggle for tight political control of France's stateowned television, it dismissed Pierre Desgraupes, whose name has stood for objective, critical, sometimes nonconformist reporting, from his job as director or newscasts of the network's major channel.

title: Price Changes
description: The price of a cup of coffee appears to be on the way up.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorials have consistently alleged that President Nixon is deliberately creating an artificial political issue in school busing. I suggest that The Times should do a little pioneer research with the citizens of Detroit, Charlotte, Richmond, Miami, Montclair, N. J., or any other town where busing has been instituted by decrees of addled educational officials, backed by liberal judges, most of whom have their own children in private schools.

title: Weekly Store Sales Gain
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week totaled an estimated $783million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $713million. Total retailstore sales were about $8,452billion, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $3,730billion.

title: Bahamas Phone Rate Cut
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a new reduced rate schedule for telephone calls to the Bahamas. The new rates would become effective on Nov. 26 because of economies to be realized when a new underseas cable from Palm Beach, Fla., to Nassau is expected to go into operation. Under the new schedule, a threeminute stationtostation call from New York to the Bahamas, which now costs $6, would be reduced to $3.90.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN DULL TRADING
description: In a dull trading session involving only 2,897,000 shares investors managed to bid up prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The Amex index closed at 26.75, up 0.10.

title: $1,500 Collected for Reward
description: The sum of $1,500 has been collected by a tenants group as a reward for information leading to the finding of a missing Staten Island girl. The money was collected by the Tysens Park Tenants Association in New Dorp, where 5yearold Alice Pereira disappeared 15 days ago.

title: FRANCOIS DESNOYER
description: PERPIGNAN, France, July 21 (AP)  Francois Desnoyer, French painter who drew his inspiration from the seafront, Idled last night at the Perpignan Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BIARRITZ, France, July 21 (AP)Douglas MacClelland and Peter Oosterhuis of Britain tied for the secondround lead today in the French open golf championship with 132 totals.

title: Starr Retires, 15 Years With Packers
description: Bart Starr, the 38yearold quarterback of the Green Bay Packers, who wanted to go on and play for one more season, announced his retirement yesterday, because of recurring pain in his passing arm and shoulder.

title: ROWE TRIUMPHS IN SAILING AGAIN
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 Stuart B. Rowe Jr. of Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club won his fourth consecutive race today in his neighbor's backyard at Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week. But Rowe's perfect record in the International OneDesign Class, with only one day remaining, may discourage some skippers from returning and thus hurt his chances of winning the trophy as the outstanding skipper.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., July 21 (AP)George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, returned to South Dakota today to map his coming campaign against President Nixon for the White House.

title: SOME COUNSELORS SAID TO ABUSE LAW
description: The State Attorney General's office said yesterday that the, operators of unlicensed mentalhealth counseling services here were exploiting loopholes in the laws governing the use of professional titles to give the impression that their practices were approved and regulated by the state.

title: Sadat's Ouster of Russians Called Cool and Deliberate
description: CAIRO, July 21President Anwar elSadat's decision to end Egypt's reliance onSoviet military assistance was a coolly arrived at, deliberate move that was several weeks in the making, informed Egyptian sources and foreign diplomats said today.

title: Sommer Entry Suburban Choice
description: The Suburban Handicap, holdover from the days when the horses were in action at Sheepshead Bay and Empire City, will have its 80th running today at Aqueduct and, with an overnight field of nine, will be worth a gross of $113,800. To the winner of this 1%mile test will go a purse of $68,280.

title: Man In the News
description: PARIS, July 21The Catalans of France have a reputation for being eccentric, and Arthur Conte, who has been named to run the country's most powerful medium, the stateowned radiotelevision network, is no exception. Mr. Conte was a Social ist who hated Marx, a humanist who believed in France's colonial mission in North Africa, and a par tisan politician who switched parties three times.

title: SMITH GIVES U.S. 10 TENNIS LEAD
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 21 (UPI) Stan Smith defeated Jaime Pinto, in straight  sets today to give the United States a 10 lead over Chile in the American Zone final of Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: and the Guild
description: Because of the Nixon Administration's record, it could be argued that the Fourth Estate has the responsibility to oppose Mr. Nixon's reelection. The repeated disparagement, intimidation and coercion of the press are not only a broad public issue but also a specific concern of reporters and editors.

title: Irwin L. Moore, ExHead Of New England Electric
description: WABAN, Mass., July 21Irwin L. Moore, retired board chairman of the New England Electric System, died today at the age of 76.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DOVER, England, July 21 (AP)Fifteenyearold Dick Crowell of Westport, Conn., gave up his attempt to swim the English Channel today after covering 5 miles of the 21mile stretch.

title: Communications Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today revenues of $25,618,000 for the second quarter of 1972, and $50,858,000 for the first six morns, compared with $22,229,000 for the AprilJune period of 1971 and $44,163,000 for the first half of 1971.

title: A Cool Air Mass From Canada Ends City's Power Crisis
description: A weekend respite from crisis and heat beckoned wilted New Yorkers yesterday after Consolidated Edison met another day of high electrical demand without major power failures and the National Weather Service forecast drop of 8 to 10 degrees in the temperature.

title: Challenge Race Tonight Caps Westbury Meeting
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 21The second of Roosevelt Raceway's three harnessracing meetings this year will end tomorrow night with a program Marked by the $150,000 challenge trot among Une de Mai, Speedy Crown and Fresh Yankee.

title: Screen: Japanese Life:'Late Spring' by Ozu Opens at New Yorker
description: With the New Yorker Theater's opening yesterday of "Late Spring," five films by the great Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu (1903-1963) have received commercial release herethe most recent being "Tokyo Story," which played the New Yorker in March and April. After neglecting Ozu for years, we now seem about to embalm his reputation with flattery, with the kind of fulsome praise that makes him sound like this year's Ermanno Olmi, a man to discover, devour, and then forget.The difficulty with Ozu is not in appreciating his films, nor which are always beautifully lucid, nor even in attaching the right film to the right title, though it's somewhat confusing remembering whether "End of Summer" is actually "Early Autumn" or whether "Late Spring" is just another name for "Early Summer." The difficulty is in describing an Ozu work in a way that doesn't diminish it, that doesn't reduce it to an inventory of his austere techniques, and that accurately reflects the unsentimental humanism of his discipline.Perhaps the only proper Ozu review would be one from which all adverbs and adjectives had been excisedthey being the prose equivalents to the kind of subjectivism that he so rigorously avoids in his films. Don't ever go to Ozu and expect to participate in someone's nightmare or to share a flashback to a remembered time. We're lucky occasionally to share a view from the window of a moving train, which, in the context of Ozu, is practically an early Cinerama roller-coaster ride."Late Spring" was made in 1949, only four years after the end of the war, when General MacArthur was still very much in residence in Tokyo. Yet the only reminders we have of the period are the passing views of a road sign in English and a "Drink Coca-Cola" ad. Ozu's concern is middle-class family life seen through relationships that certainly are not removed from great social changes but, rather, not immediately connected to them. Or, more to the point, the great social changes in Ozu are the changes in the family that is his cosmos.In "Late Spring," Ozu's family is an irreducible two, consisting of an aging professor (Chisu Ryu), a wid-owner, and his daughter (Setsuka Hara), a lovely woman in her late 20's who probably would have married some years before if life with her father hadn't been so serene. They are joined from time to time by the professor's practical, bossy sister who believes that everybody, including the professor, should be married.The film is the story of the professor's campaign not to marry his daughter off but to steer her in the direction of a life of her own, which in Ozu's world necessarily means a husband and her own family. The father's ploy: to make her think he wants to marry again.The idea strikes her with horror and disgustfor reasons that Ozu manages to define without tying the girl up in Oedipal knots. In "Late Spring," the collapse of the old civilization and the advent of a new is the girl's acceptance of a suitor (whom we never see), at first grudgingly, then with resigned good humor and finally with something on the order of anticipation, though hardly ecstasy.Ozu's characters don't seek ecstasy, not because they are afraid of it but because they are brave enough to accept compromise, to admit change and to understand, as the daughter does, when the father says: "Marry him. I'm sure you'll be happyit's not difficult." Ozu is often called the most Japanese of all Japan's directors, and I suspect that typical of what we find exotic about him is hisodd to our way of thinkingassociation of happiness with difficulty.Chisu Ryu, the grandfather in "Tokyo Story," and Setsuko Hara, who played the widowed daughter-in-law in that film, are immensely affecting  gentle, loving, amused, thinking and feeling beings.I would imagine that acting in an Ozu film might not have been too rewarding for the performers. The director depended as much on camera angle, setting, time of day and time of year as on acting. Yet Ozu's recognition of the wall of skin separating the mind of the character from the viewer is an integral part of his philosophy. It amounts to a profound respect for their privacy, for the mystery of their emotions. Because of thisnot in spite of thishis films, of which "Late Spring" is one of the finest, are so moving.

title: Kaiser Industries
description: The Kaiser Industries Corporation had a secondquarter net profit of $6,674,000, or 23 cents a share, including an extraordinary gain of $578,000, or 2 cents, from the sale of CATV operations, it was reported yesterday.

title: Data Processors Sue And U.S. for End to Curbs
description: The Association of Data Processing Service Organizetions, Inc., has filed a petition in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York seeking to compel the Attofney General of the United States and the International Business Machines Corporation to terminate courtordered restrictions on the release of information to the public concerning, the ongoing antitrust litigation against I.B.M.

title: U.N. Council Asks Israel to Release Six Arab Officers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21The Security Council, with the United States abstaining, approved a resolution today calling on Israel to return a Lebanese captain and five highranking Syrian general staff officers taken prisoner in a border raid on June 21.

title: 76 Are Killed and .103 Hurt in Spanish Rail Crash
description: LEBRIJA, Spain, July 21 (Reuters)Seventysix persons died and 103 were injured when a holiday express and a local passenger train crashed headon near this town in southern Spain today.

title: Casey Sees Unified Ticker Operative in About a Year
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21A national stockmarket tape incorporating trades on all regional securities exchanges as well as on the New York boards will be operative in about one year, William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today.

title: Grace & Co. Will Remain in City and Move to Midtown
description: After 106 years in the Wall Street area, W. R. Grace & Co., which is known to many of its associates as the old lady of Hanover Square, will move to midtown.

title: Merger News
description: The Singer Corporation announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement in principle to sell the Vapor Corporation, a subsidiary, to a new and as yet unnamed corporation to be formed and owned by Bear, Stearns & Company, the First Chicago Investment Corporation and other investors. Singer would be paid $36.5million in cash, subject to closing adjustments and approval of the Singer board of directors.

title: Fedicare? Fastaid? H.E.W. Officialdom Stands on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has decided that fedicare, arnericare, or amerishare just won't do as replacements for the word welfare.

title: $2Million Crash Suit Filed
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP)The family of one of 13 persons killed in an airplane collision over Lake Winnebago in Wisconsin on June 29 sued in Circuit Court today for $2million damages. The suit was brought by Jean Cutler, 35 years old, of Fremont, Nev., the widow of Joseph Cutler, 41; their daughter, Sally, 14, and son, Timothy, 17. Mr. Cutler was aboard an Air Wisconsin plane that collided with a North Central Airlines plane.

title: Goodby to Featherbed
description: A settlement has finally been negotiated in the interminable dispute over the elimination of locomotive firemen with no fires to tend. The nation can be happy at removal of the recurrent threat of nationwide rail strikes over union insistence on perpetuating useless jobs, but there is little else to justify the extravagant jubilation over the pact expressed by Secretary of Labor Hodgson.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME COURT NOMINEES
description: Three Democratic judicial conventions nominated 13 men yesterday, including the Bronx County District Attorney, Burton Roberts, to run in November for the State Supreme Court.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, July 21 (AP)A United States electronic computer industry mission said it has found that the reported technology gap between Japanese and American computer makers has been sharply reduced.

title: $13Million Order for Goss
description: The Goss division of MGD Graphic Systems received yesterday a $13million order for printing preses from the Oregonian Publishing Company of Oregon. Installation of the equipment, which includes offset presses and auxiliary units, is scheduled to begin in September, 1973, in a nev, downtown office for The Oregon Journal and The Oregonian. MGD is a subsidiary of the North American Rockwell Corporation.

title: SIDNEY SHAPIRO, PARKS ENGINEER
description: Sidney M. Shapiro, who retired last April as chief engineer and general manager of the Long Island State Park Commission, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Babylon, L.I.

title: Satellite Delayed Again
description: LOMPOC, Calif., July 21 (UPI)A second postponement was announced today in the launching of a space satellite designed to give the first comprehensive information about the earth's resources and its surface environment. The launching of the Earth Resources Technology Satellite was put off at least until Sunday because of technical difficulties.

title: Brazil to Resume Exports
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 21Brazil returned to the world coffee market today, raising the minimum export price by 10 cents per pound for coffee shipped in August and September.

title: H. Rap Brown Ch'arges U.S. Violated Court Agreement
description: H. Rap Brown charged yesterday that Federal agents illegally spirited him out of New York two months ago, in violation of a Federal court agreement, and flew him to Louisiana to face sentencing for violation of the Federal Gun Control Act.

title: Personalities: Staub Has Cast, West a Raise, Best a Rest
description: Rusty Staub, the Mets home run and runsbattedin leader despite having played in only one of his team's last 28 games, underwent surgery yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. The onehour operation for the removal of the hook in the hamate bone of his right wrist was performed by Dr. Richard Eaton, assisted by Dr. Peter LaMotte, the Met's team physician, who said, Everything went well.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The red tide, a sea condition caused by the growth of rustcolored microorganisms, has, returned to the waters off New York and New Jersey, but so far officials have not closed any swimming areas. John Mahoney, research biologist at the Sandy Hook Marine Laboratory, said yesterday that the current infestation had not resulted in reports of sore throats, stinging eyes and ear infections that accompanied the last major red tide, in 1968.

title: MENTAL STATUTE UPHELD BY COURT
description: Reversing a State Supreme Court decision, the Appellate Division yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a provision of the state's Mental Health Law that directs the transfer of a dangerously mentally ill patient from a state civil hospital to Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The dog litter question in New York City brings to mind an order that appeared in the Heidelberg Post (U.S. Army, Europe) Circular No. 210(Instructions to Occupants of Dependent Quarters). It went like this:

title: Gardner Bids McGovern Press For Major Reform of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 21John W. Gardner, chairman of Common Cause, charged today that Senator George McGovern had not been wholly forthright on the issue of Congressional reform.

title: Emergency Status Is Lifted At Attica After Three Days
description: ATTICA, N. Y., July 21 (AP)  Superintendent Ernest R. Montanye said today that he was lifting the temporary state of emergency insituted Tuesday at the Attica state prison following a protest by inmates.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Jose Fernandez of the Dominican Republic won the North American junior lightweight championship by beating Jose Luis Lopez of Mexico on a unanimous 12round decision at the Singer Bowl last night. It was a wild fight with Fernandez applying the pressure during the, entire bout.

title: 2 Convicts Killed in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 21  Two prisoners were killed today in the central jail at Hyderabad, about 100 miles north of here, when the police opened fire on prisoners attempting a jail break. Other prisoners were reported to have been injured.

title: NIXON AIDE URGES TOUGHER TAX LAW
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Administration's top tax policy expert suggested today that Congress rewrite and toughen the section that was put into the tax law in 1969 in an attempt to force all wealthy persons to pay some reasonable amount of Federal income tax.

title: F.C.C. Says Loss Of Children's Ads Could Cost Millions
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The elimination of commercials from television programing for children could cost the major networks millions of dollars they could not replace, according to a study released today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: BELFAST BOMBINGS KILL AT LEAST 13 AND WOUND 130
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, July 22Belfast was struck yesterday by a coordinated bombing attack in which at least 13 people were killed and 130 were wounded.

title: Galloping Gourmet to Sail Awhile Instead
description: TORONTO, July 21 (Canadian Press)Graham Kerr, television's Galloping Gourmet, has decided to perform from now on for an audience of onehis wife, Treena.

title: Egypt's Envoy to Moscow Hails TV on Soviet Ties
description: MOSCOW, July 21  The Egyptian Ambassador went on Soviet television today with a speech that hailed relations between the two countries as a shining example and ignored the current withdrawal of Soviet military advisers from Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although put off for months, it is pleasing to note that action on dog litter and graffiti is finally being considered by the City Council.

title: Toronto Investment Executive Will Manage Arctic Gas Study
description: TORONTO, July 21William P. Wilder, an executive in Canada's investment industry, has resigned as president of Wood Gundy, Ltd., to become chief executive officer of the management committee of GasArcticNorthwestStudy Group.

title: About Pro Football
description: READING, Pa., July 21The Philadelphia Eagles last season won twice as many gamessixas they had in 1970; jumped over the Giants and St. Louis into third place in the National Conference Eastern Division, and established as head coach 36yearold Eddie Khayat, only four years out of the player ranks. This year a winning season can be anticipated for the Eagles, ac cording to Khayat, a former high school English teacher with considerable depth and perception. That would be something because the Philadelphia club has had only one victorious campaign out of the last 10.

title: DEMENT IS VICTOR IN TRIALS AGAIN
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., July 21 (UPI)Duane Bobick pummeled flabby Leroy Jones to win his 58th straight heavyweight fight and Tim Dement, conqueror of Bobby Lee Hunter, captured a squeaky decision over Gregory Lewis tonight, to move into the finals of the United States Olympic boxing trials.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation, announced yesterday the election of E. Clinton Towl as chairman and chief executive officer. William M. Zarkowsky was made vice chairman and Joseph E. Gavin succeeds him as president. John C. Bierwirth was elected a director of the subsidiary's board. Mr. Towl, chairman of the Grumman Corporation, recently replaced the late L. J. Evans as president the parent company. Mr. Evans also held the chairman's post prior to his death on July 9. Mr. Gavin has been a senior vice president of the subsidiary and Mr. Bierwirth is vice president of finance of the parent corporation.

title: TRADE TALKS OPENED BY U.S.SOVIET GROUP
description: MOSCOW, July 21  The newly established United StatesSoviet Commercial Commission began a series of meetings today in as effort to achieve the first overall trade agreement between the two countries since World War II.

title: Connors Gains Buckeye. Mall
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21 (AP)  Jiminy Connors advanced to the final of the Buckeye open tennis tournament for the second straight year today, beating Dick Stockton in a semifinal match played in 92degree heat.

title: Ruffleis Upsets Richey
description: MAHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Ray Ruffels of Australia upset Cliff Richey, 67, 64, 61, in a 2hour match toiday to highlight the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis championships.

title: U.S. MAY REPAY OVERSEAS DEBTS
description: PARIS, July 21The United States may have to pay some old debts as it reactivates reciprocal borrowing facilities with other countries to get the money that may be needed for propping up the dollar in the exchange markets, Paris sources said today.

title: Threat Case Due Dismissal
description: HARTFORD, July 21 (AP)Randolph Roeder, Assistant United States Attorney, said today he would ask for dismissal of a charge of threatening the life of the President against Michael James Brody, heir to an oleomargarine fortune. Mr. Brody, 24 years old, who is the grandson of J. F. Jelke, an oleomargarine magnate, has been under psychiat ric care since December, according to his lawyer.

title: Market Place:
description: There must be hundreds of companies that have tried to zero in on the profit potentials in leisure time, but few have been successful. There are, of course, the Coleman Company, Inc.; Winnebago; the Shakespeare Company and Arctic Enterprises, to name a few of the viable independents.

title: Bombing the Dikes
description: Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Secretary General of the World Council of Churches, has posed an issue of supreme urgency and moral import to the President and people of the United States with his letter to President Nixon charging that United States planes are deliberately bombing dikes in North Vietnam and appealing to President Nixon to order an immediate halt to these actions.

title: At U. N., Blitz Doesn't Always Mean War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21The United Nations plays an important role on the international chessboard, and international chessboards play an important role at the United Nations.

title: JURY COMPLETED IN EMBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 With the defense using an elaborate jury selection system designed by a psychiatrist, a jury of eight women and four men was selected and sworn in today in the Pentagon papers case.

title: Bethlehem Plant Upstate To Increase Operations
description: The Bethlehem Steel Company said yesterday it planned a major stepup in operations at Its Lackawanna, N.Y., plant on Aug. 1 The mill had employed about 18,000 a year ago but had been cut back to between 8,000 workers in recent months. A union official was quoted as saying that as many as 2,000 idle employes might be rehired.

title: Art
description: CHICAGO Imagist Art, which opened Friday at the New York Cultural Center, represents a longdelayed assault by barbarians from lands west of the Hudson on the citadel of decadent estheticism called Manhattan. But there's nothing to worry about. Not only are the attacking forces much reduced in numbers; the barbarians look pretty decadent themselves.

title: Mrs. Jacqueline DeVoe Remarries
description: Mrs. Jacqueline DeVoe was married here yesterday afternoon to Roy Series Durstine Jr., president of Durstine Ltd., an advertising agency here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William A. McQuoid in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: How Boys In Blue Can Stay Out of Red
description: Most bigcity folks have probably heard of the Kelly Girls. It supplies temporary office workers. Fewer know about Flight 485. It gets jobs for offduty airline stewardesses.

title: World News Briefs
description: Using workers flown in from the nearby island of Curacao the Government of strikebound Aruba restored electric power to the small islandstate early yesterday, according to a Government representative in New York. Ken Bomar, the representative, said that the strike by about 500 Government workers in Aruba was within hours of final settlemnt.

title: TANAGRA TAKES MARGATE EVENT
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 22 Two ladylike stretch battles provided excitement for 21,254 fans at Monmouth Park today and victories in the split Margate for Tanagra and Kittiwake.

title: Parks Are an Issue in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 22 Two incidentsthis summer involving groups of New York City teenagers in Westchester County parks have prompted renewed calls to restrict or Completely ban the use of the parks by nonWestchester, residents.

title: Depression cutup, authentic blacks, modern gothic
description: A thriller by Joan Aiken is like an ice cream cone. Both must be consumed at a single sitting and both leave a cold but pleasurable feeling in the pit of the stomach.

title: Kibbutz Losing Popularity Among Immigrants to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 22 (AP)The kibbutz, the communal way of life on which the Jewish state was founded, is losing popularity among new immigrants.

title: Bubba Losing $300 a Day
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 22 (AP)Bubba Smith, in a dispute with the Baltimore Colts over a demand for more money, will be fined $300 a day as a holdout, the National Football League club announced today.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In this bright, gossipy volume, Kansas  born Kathleen Trautman, wife of a U.S.I.A. information officer, tells all about life in Afghanistan with the American Foreign Service. Americans are pampered beyond belief, she writes, and proceeds to document the statement with descriptions of the backbiting and fragmentation of officialdom. Obviously Mrs. Trautman had herself been insulated: how else could she have been so fearful of a ride in an Afghan taxi or so nervous on the winding road to the Khyber Pass that many American visitors drive happily? On the whole she displays more compassion for the Afghans than for her compatriots in the American colony. If this all sounds like cocktail party chatter, well, cocktail parties can be fun. And who knows better than the Foreign Service that you can pick up a lot of information at cocktail parties?

title: The Pilgrims Keep Coming to Times Square, the Tarnished Mecca
description: T HE lettering over the door says simply Information Center, and there are a lot of people who think that means just what says, so they walk in to ask all sorts of questionshow many pounds are there in a metric ton, where can you buy goats in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Having read of all the air piracy, was somewhat apprehensive on a recent trip to Paris via Air France. After our gate was called each passenger passed through a magnetic detector and our hand baggage was searched. We were then sent to wait in an area that was separated from a public area only by rope. Anyone could have passed weapon or explosive to an alreadysearched passenger. I flew from Paris to London, and to my astonishment this same procedure of going through careful search and then being returned to a public area was followed. On my return flight from Paris to New York, no magnetic detector was in evidence and our hand luggage was not searched.

title: The World
description: The cry came from members of the Holy Synod of the Eastern Orthodox church gathered in special conclave in Istanbul last Sunday. It was the traditional sign that the Orthodox church had chosen a new leader. The Patriarch elected to succeed Athenagoras I, who died July 7 at the age of 86, was Metropolitan Dimitrios, 58yearold Archbishop of Imbros and Tenedos. Of three candidates for the leadership of the Eastern Orthodox church's 250 million faithful, he had received 12 of 15 possible votes from the Synod, which functions in the same way as Rome's College of Cardinals in electing a new leader.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THERE are, it seems to me, reasons as yet unexplored in print for the impending Cavett crisis. Despite his fine intentions, the scope of his interests and even his undeniable appeal, in my opinion Dick Cavett is his own worst enemy.

title: Child Agency in Bay State
description: BOSTON, July 22 (AP)Legislation creating a state office for children to oversee children's welfare programs in Massachusetts was signed into law this week by Gov. Francis W. Sargent. The office, operating under the Secretary of Human Services, will concentrate on development of daycare services.

title: Europe vs. the Dollar
description: LONDON  Ten countries of Western Europe, the members of the soontobe enlarged Common Market, are talking about what is to become of the dollar, in a new monetary system. It may sound a little presumptuous for them to discuss such a subject without the presence of the United States.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I should like to comment on the precautions against hijacking taken as departed from various airports during a recent trip to Venice.

title: Timetable Is Revised By L.I.R.R. After Month
description: An extra latenight train on weekdays to Port Jefferson is one of several changes that are being made tomorrow in the Long Island Rail Road's monthold revised timetable.

title: KIERNAN'S YACHT STAMFORD VICTOR
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 17The 20th annual predicted log contest conducted by the Stamford Yacht Club for the Mortimer L. Doolittle Trophy was won by Henry J. Kiernan of New York Athletic Club Yacht Club today in his 48foot cruiser Virginia K with an error of 0.8608 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Two news reports in your July 10 issue explain why the United States is coming to be regarded as a selfish nation, indifferent to the plight of the rest of humanity.

title: Education Figure Erred
description: Because of a transcription error, it was inaccurately reported in the Bergen County census story last Sunday that in Garfield less than 1 per cent had finished high school. The report should have stated that fewer than one in three adults over 25 years old had finished high school.

title: Meany Backs Olympic Fund
description: George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O. has accepted the post of honorary chairman for the National Labor Division of the United States Olympic Fund. Meany met with fund officials in Washington recently and agreed to head the recently organized division.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Dear Mr. Monroe, read the headline over Lester Markel's letter, would you abolish traffic lights? The question means, of course, would I abolish all regulation of broadcasting. And the answer, Mr. Markel, is no, of course not.

title: New Prayer Book Issued for Conservative Judaism
description: A revised high  holy  days prayer book for Conservative Judaism has just been published here designed to give Jewish liturgy, or public worship, a modern dimension.

title: VENUS 8 LANDS AND RADIUS DATA
description: MOSCOW, July 22The Soviet Union announced today that its latest unmanned Venus, spacecraft had made a soft landing on the planet's surface and had radioed back data on the chemical composition of Venusian rocks.

title: AROUND THE
description: Now that the sun has decided to shine around for a bit, the flowers are coming out. Their debut has been retarded by the rain, and some of the best display plans have come to naught. But Us wonders what a few sunny days can do and with patience, the planter's rewards will follow.

title: Letters
description: James Markham's polemic against heroin maintenance contains so many distortions that it almost takes another article to answer it. After paying lip service to estimates of crime committed in order to maintain habits that cost $50 to $100 per day of perhaps several hundred thousand addicts in our country, he proceeds to dismiss these figures as conjecture. They are, since absolutely accurate figures in this area will never be available, but this is an old debater's trick to take our minds away from a substantial reality. Mr. Markham attempts to document the notion that the crime rate is not measurably increased by addiction by using an old quotation of Dr. Lawrence Kolb and some dubious statistics to the effect that addiction is secondary to criminal behavior in some cases. These are not the views of anyone who has either experience or eyes in his head to see how the need to raise large sums of money daily by perhaps 100,000 addicts in New York City has turned our city into a place of violence and fear in the past decade. No city can withstand an army of 100,000 turned against it daily to plunder desperately for $50 or $100.

title: Agnew Made His Mark As a Critic of the Critics
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The man that President Nixon designated again to be his running mate on the Republican ticket is a defender of the established order and a critic of the critics.

title: The World
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandShoppers were preparing for the weekend. Office girls were returning to work. Children were strolling with their mothers. The time was 2:09 P.M. last Friday.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: This is a very happy book. There's little text, but all of it is Calder; his words about his circus. In 1929 he was invited to perform at a party given by Mine Bernstein. He was seen there by a certain young writer. About this, Calder says, I was never aware that the great Wolfethat is, Thomas Wolfe, the writerwas present at my performance. He did not have the good sense to present himself and I only heard from him much latersome nasty words on my performance, included in a longwinded book. (That longwinded book was You Can't Go Home Again.)

title: The Postman Rings Thrice
description: IF the postman can ring twice, he can always ring three times. At least, that seems to be the theory of the masterminds at MGM. In 1946, they turned out a steamy version of James M. Cain's The Postman Always Rings Twice that starred Lana Turner, as a restless waitress married to a wealthy old man, and John Garfield, as a brooding bum who becomes Lana's lover. And four years before that, Luchino Visconti had already made an Italian version called Obsession.

title: James G. Hanes, 86, Former Top Officer Of Textile Company
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 22James Gordon Hanes, who guided the Hanes Hosiery Mills Co, into one of the world's largest producers of seamless stretch nylon hosiery, died here this morning while on vacation. He was 86 years old.

title: SURVIVOR RECALLS RAID ON PANTHERS
description: CHICAGO, July 22A survivor of the 1969 raid on a Black Panther apartment here insisted yesterday that no shots were fired at the State's Attorney's special police squad when it broke into the apartment and killed two Panther leaders Fred Hampton and Mark Clark.

title: Boston Court Trims Docket
description: BOSTON, July 22 (AP)Only emergency civil cases will be heard by the United States District Court here for three weeks this fall while the court tries to catch up on a critical backlog of criminal cases.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: DETROIT, July 22Some American travelers returning from Europe say that there is a bus gap.

title: DIVERS FIND SHIP SCUTTLED IN 1779
description: CASTINE, Mc., July 22The remains of the American brigantine Defense, a Revolutionary War vessel that was scuttled by her crew to avoid capture by the British, have been found in the murky waters of Penobscot Bay, officials of Maine Maritime Academy say.

title: Hong Kong Blast Kills 3
description: HONG KONG, July 22 (AP)Three men were killed and nine injured in an explosion on the 3.396ton Somaliaregistered ship Pei Kiang in Hong Kong harbor today. The nationalities of the dead were not immediately known. Most of the injured were Chinese crew members.

title: Thomas Flynn Young jr. to Wed Miss Cynthia Campbell Ratsey
description: RYE, N. Y., July 22Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ernest Ratsey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Campbell Ratsey, to Thomas Flynn Young Jr., son of Mr. Young of Islip and Mrs. Wilton H. Marvin of Hampton Bays. A Sept. wedding is planned.

title: Miss Judith A. Weller
description: Miss Judith Anne Weller and Danforth White Starr plan to marry Sept. 16.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWSecretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson arrived in Moscow last week with an American trade delegation and announced that he would be guided by what he said was an old Russian proverb: New life, new laws. There is a new situation in SovietAmerican relations, he implied, and the consequences for trade between the two countries could be profound. His Soviet hosts beamed.

title: LETTERS
description: I am enraged by the attitude of Sheldon G. Gilgore in his article Controls Stifle New Drugs (July 2). To leave medical and pharmaceutical decisions entirely to the professionals is to place an inordinate amount of power into the hands of people who have brought us Thalidomide, for example. Our healthcare crisis is one of delivering what we have to all people, not more to the same few.

title: Pamela Cross Is Bride
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 22Miss Pamela Jeanne Cross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Cross, was married here this afternoon to Benjamin Franklin Bowles 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bowles 2d, in the Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Dickson, pastor emeritus, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Edward Clydesdale, cousin of the bride.

title: Control of Coffee Insect Reported by Guatemala,
description: GUATEMALA, July 16 Earlier this year, coffee growers near Lake Atitln, west of here, discovered their coffee beans were being infested by something they had not encountered before.

title: DIETZ WINS FINAL IN OLYMPIC TRIAL
description: KENT, Conn., July 22Jim Dietz, 6foot6inch, 190pound national champion, won the final of the Olympic singles rowing trials today on Lake Waramaug.

title: Sarah Robins Jesup to Wed Oct.
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 22Miss Sarah Robins Jesup, a senior at the University of Pennsylvania, plans to be married Oct. 7 to Francis Jamison Rue 3d, a Pennsylvania graduate with the class of 72.

title: Seven Ways Not to Make a Best Seller
description: To many outsiders, the publishing of books seems as chancy as horse racing. Insiders know better. As astute veteran observers of the trade have remarked, there are seven simple rules that, if conscientiously applied, are almost certain to induce a best seller. As a public service, we share them with readers of the Book Review.

title: Britain Says Jobless Total Rose 80,000 in a Month
description: LONDON, July 22 (AP)Unemployment jumped more than 80,000 in Britain this month, the Department of Employment announced this week, dealing another blow to the economic policies of the Conservative Government. The number of jobless rose to 915,531 on July 10 compared with 833,473 on June 12, the department said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Bronx Borough President threatens to use his Board of Estimate membership to prevent a muchneeded development at the lower tip of Manhattan. Such internecine quarrels, triggered by the personal ambitions of our politicans, are made possible by the chaotic cornplexity of our governmental structure.

title: World News Briefs
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 22 The trial of 41 leftwing revolutionaries accused of conspiring to wage war against the state and to overthrow Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike's Government in April, 1971. began today.

title: Dark Horse
description: Dark Horse recalls those old Jimmy Stewart and Gary Cooper movies, where Mr. Smith or Mr. Deeds outsmart the corrupt hotshots of the System. The lifestyle here is different (the author has projected his plot four years ahead, into the climax of election year 1976), but the platitudes are familiar.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A trew Gallup Poll, released today, raises a sharp challenge to the expectation of strategists for Senator George McGovern that he can win a critical eightmillionvote margin over President Nixon among firsttime voters by conducting a massive youthregistration campaign.

title: 188 Yachts Leave Chicago In Sail to Mackinac Island
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)A fleet of 188 yachts set sail under favorable winds today in the 65th annual ChicagotoMackinac Island race.

title: Saratoga Nine Wins Title
description: BEACON, N. Y., July 22 (AP) Bruce Brochette stole second and then made it home on a teammate's grounder and an error to give the Saratoga AllStars a 21 triumph today over the Beacon AllStars for the New York State Babe Ruth championship.

title: Hempstead Sailing Off
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 22Lack of wind forced the cancellation of today's Hempstead Harbor sailing sponsored by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club. Races are scheduled tomorrow.

title: David Duncan Protests
description: To THE EDITOR: Do War Pictures Change Anything? (Gene Thornton, June 25) The answer is obvious; not for the man who is assigned to review them. For the rest of us who had the opportunity to view David Douglas Duncan's artful photographs, we were deeply moved by his ability to capture the emotions and situations of war which cannot be articulated. Thornton projected his own ideas into these pictures. At no time did we feel that Mt. Duncan was asking us to win or lose the war.

title: Notes: Indian Tourism
description: A N independent nonprofit corporation has been formed by Indian tribal interests to assist Indians and native Alaskans in promoting and marketing their tourist attractions. The corporation, which will have its headquarters in Denver, will solicit memberships from Indian tribes interested in the program's benefits and from companies and individuals in the travel and outdoor recreation industries.

title: Lost Crops and Quiet Resorts Recall Agnes's Wrath
description: HARTFORD, July 22  The farmers, resort keepers and others most beset by the tropical storm Agnes are beginning to perceive relief at the end of a very wet tunnel.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALBANY, July 22Democratic State Chairman Joseph F. Crangle announced here today that 53 of the 57 county leaders outside New York City had declared their enthusiastic support for the Presidential ticket of Senator George McGovern and Senator Thomas Eagleton.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22Max Palevsky, one of Senator George McGovern's earliest and largest financial supporters, has left the campaign.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Is the bloom off the electronic rose? Has television peaked? Leveled out? Sagged?

title: Allergist to Wed Cynthia Chisholm
description: LAUREL, Miss., July 22Miss Cynthia Wisner Chisholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Field Chisholm, plans to be married Sept. 9 to Dr. Nathan Emile SaintAmand. The ceremony is planned to take place in the chapel of St. James's Episcopal Church in New York. The bridegroom, an allergist, is on the attending staff of Roosevelt and Lenox Hill Hospital in New York.

title: Susan Chapman Affianced
description: NORWICH, Conn., July 22 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rowe have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rowe's daughter, Miss Susan Chapman, to Jeffrey Paul Slimmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mac Slimmer of Wantagh.

title: Claudia Neuhauser To Be Bride Nov. 4
description: MERRICK, L. I., July 22Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Neuhauser have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claudia Beth Neuhauser, to Robert M. Scherzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Scherzer of Wantagh. The wedding is planned for Nov. 4.

title: Christine Shapleigh Is Married
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 22 Miss Christine Shapleigh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren McKinney Shapleigh of St. Louis, was married here this afternoon to Paul Albert Schmid 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmid of South Westport, Mass.

title: Expos Stop Padres, 31
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22 (AP)Hector Torres broke a tie with a leadoff home run in the sixth inning tonight to give the Montreal Expos a 31 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One of our contemporary nightmares is the atom bomb in a suitcase. We have all read about it: this little package that can wreak more destruction than the bomb that hit Hiroshima.

title: Dubassoff Takes American Derby
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)The entry of Dubassoff and King's Bishop, invading from New York and trained by Tom Kelly, finished one, two today in the 62d running of the $117,800 American Derby at Arlington Park.

title: Big Disposal Plant Set for Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.What is believed to be the nation's first major solidwaste disposal plant, one capable of handling up to 2,000 tons of garbage a day, reducing it to less than 3 per cent of its original volume and recycling glass, ferrous and nonferrous metals so that they can be resold, will be constructed within the Town of Hempstead, Supervisor Alfonse M. D'Arnato has announced.

title: You Get Used To a Place
description: There are many approaches to asylum fiction  introspective, surrealist, muckraking, confessional. In this novel about a mental institution, Vera Randal (author of The Inner Room) adopts a Grand Hotel format, thumbnailing a handful of the walking wounded at Glenville State Hospital. What draws her disparate cases together is their common fear of leaving the institution, even to be transferred to another. Thus Brush, an apparently outgoing hustler, tries to escape but wants to be intercepted. (Brush wouldn't know what to do on the outside anymore. Brush been away too long.) And Dugan, a deeplywithdrawn spinster, rejects all suggestions of going home. Outside, she devoted her life to caring for her invalid mother; inside, she is content to act as an inmateattendant to one or another human vegetable.

title: Warn of Cosmos Scores Lone Goal As Tornado Bows
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 22 The New York Cosmos scored a firsthalf goal and withstood a secondhalf rally by the Dallas Tornado to defeat the defending champions, 10, at Hofstra Field tonight.

title: Family Income:
description: WASHINGTONThe good news: In 1971, the Census Bureau reported last week, median family income reached $10,285a $418 jump over 1970. It sounded like the ultimate symbolic certification of America as the affluent society. It meant that for the first time, half the nation's families make more than $10,000.

title: The Economy:
description: The economy is booming isn't it? Well, then, why the hangover of concern and uncertainty encountered among the nation's businessmen?

title: CIRCUS
description: The Circus World Museum, on the site of the first winter quarters of the Ringling Brothers in Baraboo, Wis., has a display of memorabilia that can be adequately described only in the unfettered phrases of a circus publicity man. In a restored elephant barn and ring barn are a Fabulous display of circus posters from around the world, and a Fantastic collection of 25,000 miniature circus figures. A modern building houses the World's Most Magnificent Array of circus wagons, more than 100 of the Most Resplendent old vehicles that ever rolled down a main street.

title: 9 Missing as Fire Breaks Out At Cod Mine in West Virginia
description: BLACKSVILLE, W. Va., July 22Nine miners were unaccounted for after a fire broke out late tonight in the Blacksvile No. 1 mine of the Consolidation Coal Company.

title: Divers Help Seek Darien Boy
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 22 Scuba divers joined policemen Dand volunteers from three arien fire departments in seeking Robert Schmidt, a 7yearold son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Schmidt of Pratt Island, Noroton. The boy, missing since 11:30 A.M. Friday, was reported to be an excellent swimmer.

title: LETTERS
description: Mr. Gilgore's article omitted reference to a major cause for the institution of these controls, the tendency of the pharmaceutical manufacturers to create markets by encouraging use of their products even when not the product of choice or even sometimes when not indicated. The stringent regulation Mr. Gilgore decries arose as a result of the excesses of the pharmaceutical manufacturers who put financial return above ethics.

title: Lioness Severs Boy's Army
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 22 (UPI)The forearm of a 3yearold boy was bitten off by a lioness today when he wandered too near the animal's cage at the home of a pet shop owner. Mathew Ramsbottom, who had gone to see the lioness with his mother, was reported in satisfactory condition, his left arm severed just above the elbow.

title: SURVIVOR RECALLS RAID ON PANTHERS
description: CHICAGO, July 22A survi vor of the 1969 raid on a Black Panther apartment here insisted yesterday that no shots were fired at the State's Attorney's special police squad when it broke into the apartment and killed two Panther leaders, Fred Hampton and. Mark Clark.

title: Miss Harriet Milliken Is Bride In Bay State of George Starr 3d
description: DUXBURY, Mass., July 22 Miss Harriet Paige Milliken and George Ross Starr 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Starr Jr. of Doxbury were married here this afternoon. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Oothout Milliken Jr. of New York and Duxbury.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The most important turning point in Italy's recent history began on the night of July 2425, 1943, when leading members of the fascist Grand Council, including Ciano, Mussolini's soninlaw, obliged 11 Duce to return supreme command of the armed forces and all political power to Victor Emmanuel III. This book by an American journalist narrates what occurred in the next 45 days, during the government of Marshal Pietro Badoglio, whom both the Allies and Hitler, with reason, distrusted. It is a story of cowardice and treachery that ended with the armistice and flight from the capital of Badoglio and the royal family. There is available a vast library on the period, and Mr. Davis has used it all, illuminating and enlivening history with the recollections of the many eyewitnesses he interviewed. The result is a vivid, human, often exciting story that makes clear the lasting damage done to the Italian people by the hollow and sabrerattling dictatorship of Benito Mussolini.

title: William Getty, Lawyer, Weds Sarah Flower
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., July 22 Miss Sarah Eleanor Flower and William Patton Getty of Pittsburgh were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Jack Maxwell in the Shields Presbyterian Church. A reception was given at the Allegheny Country. Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: From my moment of awareness of his rambling rumblings ( Media  Galaxy  Vanishing Point ) I have held Marshall McLuhan in everincreasing, tunginchic disdain. His writings strike me as mere tours de farce.

title: Hoffman Wins A.A.U. Run
description: CHARLESTON, III., July 22 (UPI)Tom Hoffman of Fort Atkinson, Wis., representing the University of Chicago Track Club, outlasted a field of 134 other runners today to take the Amateur Athletic Union 20kilometer crosscountry run. Hoffman was timed in 1hour 5 minutes 4 seconds. He finished eighth in the marathon events at the recent Olympics trials at Eugene, Ore.

title: Halting Nuclear Spread
description: By 1976 about onefourth of the countries in the world will have large nuclear reactors in operation for the production of electric power and thus a significant potential for making atomic weapons. Apart from today's five nuclear weapons nations  the United States, Russia, Britain, France and China some 27 other countries will be producing plutonium as a byproduct of electric power generation, enough of it to make at least 900 Hiroshima bombs a year.

title: The best book on the dope decade
description: We were somewhere around Barstow on the edge of the desert when the drugs began to take hold. The hold deepens for two days, and the language keeps pace for 200 pages, in what is by far the best book yet written on the decade of dope gone by.

title: Nation's Oldest Fund Group Is Strong
description: BOSTONThe way some people tell it, mutual funds are in trouble.

title: Mrs. Cheek Wed to Reginald Roome Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 22Mrs. Cabell B. Cheek of Darien was married here today to Reginald Roome Jr.

title: Yank Sluggers of Past Swing for Fences on Their Day
description: The 29 championship pennants won between 1921 and 1964 were strung around the top tier at Yankee Stadium yesterday, flapping easily in the warm winds. In the Yankee clubhouse John Mize sipped an orange drink and recalled the days when you walked out onto this field and knew you always had time; if you didn't win today, why, you'd win tomorrow.

title: Williams Joins Red Sox
description: BOSTON, July 22 (AP)The Boston Red Sox announced today the acquisition of Stan Williams, 35yearold righthanded pitcher, from their Louisville farm team. Williams has pitched in the majors with the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Yankees, Cleveland, Minnesota and St. Louis.

title: Hewitt Beaten, 60, 75
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 221 (AP)Unseeded Andy Pattison moved into the final of the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament today with his second straight upset, a 60, 75 verdict over secondseeded Bob Hewitt of South Africa.

title: The Gttest Word
description: Two weeks ago Renata Adler spoke The Guest Word against my June 18 review of Lillian Hellman's plays. Critical understanding can only be enhanced by arguing about interpretations and judgments. But I find Miss Adler's specific points unedifying (of that, more later), and she chose to preface them with an irrelevant personal attack.

title: ANTIMONOPOLY BILL ANNOUNCED BY HART
description: WASHINGTON, July, 22 (AP) Senator Philip k Mart; Democrat of Michigan; Announeed today that he wouldintroduce legislation Monday aimed at breaking up monopolies that he said cost American consumers $55billion to $60 billion a year.

title: Mideast 1: The Exodus, Updated, With a Soviet Cast
description: CAIROThe speech before the Central Committee of the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political organization, started predictably enough. President Anwar elSadat reviewed the nation's history since the revolution of 1952, spoke of the conflict with Israel, of the help received from the Soviet Union. Then, a twist: an admission that the Egyptian and Soviet Governments had not always seen eye to eye, particularly on the types of arms the Egyptians wanted and the Russians would not give.

title: Insurance Agents Up In Arms
description: MILFORD, Conn.It was almost 10 A.M. and as Barney Burns climbed into his 1972 Cadillac he couldn't help smiling.

title: Learning How to Plan
description: HAMILTON, N.Y.Tucked away amid the cornfields, farmhouses and gently rolling acres of Madison County is a modern think tank where businessmen come to learn how to plan.

title: Larchmont Race Week Ends, With Fox Taking Trophy as Leading Skipper
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 Larchmont Race Week No. 74 ended today in the customary fusillade of minicannonfire, a loud round of applause for a tireless race committee headed by Donald B. King and an award to A. Shawhan Fox of New York as the outstanding skipper.

title: Beame Bids Board of Education Tighten Policies on Attendance
description: Charging that the city's school system had a generally lackadaisical attitude toward trunants, City Controller Abraham D. Hearne urged the Board of Education yesterday to reaffirm its commitment to compulsory education by demanding attendance and by developing the tools necessary to increase attendance.

title: The Nation
description: Five months ago, at a closeddoor meeting with some of labor's ranking political strategists, George Meany laid down the A.F.L.C.I.O. party line for the 1972 Presidential election. We're against Nixon, he said. We're ready to back anybody, including George McGovern.

title: California Capitol Is Ruled Unsafe for School Tours
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 22 (AP)California's historic domed state capitol has been placed off limits for official school tours for fear an earthquake might shake it down upon the children's heads.

title: Nader Report Scores U.S. Unit On Mental Health Center Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)A report by a Ralph Nader group charged today that the Federally financed community mental health center system designed to replace state hospitals had been vastly oversold and quickly perverted into a new bureaucracy largely unresponsive to local needs.

title: WALDHEIM VOICES WORRY ON DIKES
description: MOSCOW, July 22Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations ended a week's visit to the Soviet Union today after having expressed concern over allegations that the United States was bombing dikes in North Vietnam.

title: Books:
description: There is a small group of participants in the financial markets to whom, money is not a means to a goal, such as those who invest in bonds and stocks, but to whom money is a commodity to be purchased or sold.

title: Libya Threatens Its Youth: Somber Dress or the Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 (UPI)  Libya's youths have been told to trim their hair and wear more sober clothes. If they do not, they could end up undergoing several weeks of armystyle training.

title: On the Road to Anloc, a Break at Last
description: ON ROUTE THIRTEEN, in South Vietnam, July 21South Vietnamese troops, after being stalled for three and a half months on Route 13 north of Saigon, are making what appears to be their first significant progress toward breaking through and opening up this crucial road to the rubberplantation town of Anloc, which still has to get all its supplies and troop reinforcements by air.

title: Are Gimbels Troubles All Wrapped Up?
description: Yes, Virginia, there is a Mr. Gimbel of Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

title: Divers Help Seek Darien Soy
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 22 Scuba divers joined policemen and volunteers from three Darien fire departments in seeking Robert Schmidt, a 7yearold son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Schmidt of Pratt Island, Noroton. The boy, missing since 11:30 A.M. Friday, was reported to be an excellent swimmer.

title: The Bunshaft style
description: Bunshaft's first building in New York remains his most famous: Lever House. Completed in 1952, it was among the city's first skyscrapers in the modern glassandsteel idiom. In the early stages of the building boom, its style was often copied; one builder of cheap commercial buildings used to offer his clients the Lever look at half the price. As a result, Lever was soon flanked by fat, ungraceful boxes of similar bluegreen glass. This destructive form of flattery notwithstanding, Lever remained virtually unchallenged as the city's finest postwar skyscraper for six years, until Mies van der Rohe's and Philip Johnson's Seagram Building came along to compete for the title. Even now, with the list of distinguished office towers expanded to include C.B.S., 140 Broadway, Union Carbide and a handful of others, Lever House still has champions in people who believe that its proportions (Lever is one of the few towers in town with a horizontal element as strong as its vertical element) and its smallish size (Lever contains only a third of the footage it could, given the size of the site) make it the best skyscraper in town. Bunshaft himself is not among the most zealous of its champions: he admits to thinking that Seagram is the best.

title: Horse Show News
description: West Germany, which has been installed as the overwhelming favorite to win the team gold medal in the Olympic Games this year, has named four riders to its equestrian team.

title: Bulgarian High Court Jails ExMerchant Navy Chief
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22 (Reuters)  Bulgaria's Supreme Court has jailed the official who ran the merchant navy for 20 years, it was reported from Sofia today.

title: Social
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gary W. Alexander (Lila Gems) joyfully announce the birth of Elyse Lynn and Barry Steven on July 13, 1972.

title: Mrs. Agnew Is Happy As Guessing Game Ends
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)Mrs. Spiro Agnew is happy that the guessing is over.

title: Churchill's Account of His Early Wars Is Ridiculed in a Contemporary's Notes
description: LONDON July 22  Winston Churchill's descriptions of some of the incidents in his dashing military career in the Boer War and on the North West Frontier in India (and now in Pakistan) have been characterized by an officer who served with him as pure lies and journalistic exaggeration.

title: Gerulaitis Gains Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. (UPI) Ferdi Taygan of Framingham, Mass., won the 16andunder title at the national junior claycourt tennis championships today with a 61, 16, 63 victory over Howard Schoenfield of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: U.S. Olympians Battle Dallas Tornado Today
description: The members of the United States Olympic soccer team will take a kick at the many critics who underrated them when the team meets the Dallas Tornado in Dallas today in one of the concluding workouts before leaving for Munich in their quest for gold medals.

title: 980,000 GERMANS MISSING IN WAR
description: BONN, West Germany, July 22 (UPI)  When Adolf Hitler sent his forces into Poland in 1939, First Lieut. Bernhard Rempe's cavalry regiment was one of the first units sent to the front.

title: P.S.C. Planning to Inspect Con Ed's Steam Facilities
description: ALBANY, July 22 (AP)The Public Service Commission said today that it wanted to take a look at Consolidated Edison Company's steam service and facilities to see if they were adequate, economical and safe.

title: Social
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bert Epstein of Woodmere, Long Island announce the engagement of their daughter, Penny Sue, to Mr. Jeffrey Gatsik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gatsik of Teaneck, New Jersey, A 1973 wedding is planned.

title: Depression cutup, authentic blacks, modern gothic
description: I love to read about young hellions, about Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer, the Katzenjammer Kids and Ham Drumm. You never heard of Ham Drumm? He is the hero of This Mysterious River, and a divil of a boy, as my motherinlaw would say. He steals, gets drunk on moonshine, sells carp as black bass, kills birds to make a buck, and even stages his own drowning. Poor Ham can do no right. No matter what his intentions, no matter how he tried, he kept jumping from the back of one sin right onto the back of another. All his troubles started when he borrowed $10 from the church collection to buy a bike his family could not afford. Ham, of course, had to return the money and expiate his sin, or suffer hell's fire not to mention the fury of his father, a quick man with a switch. The 12yearold twists and turns with devilish ingenuity before winning his way back to a state of grace.

title: Donations Pass Million In Flood Relief Telethon
description: BALTIMORE, July 22 (UPI) More than a million dollars was raised in the first hours of a telethon tonight to help pay for Red Cross relief to flood victims of Tropical Storm Agnes.

title: U. S. Coach Says It Pays To Practice in East Bloc
description: For the last eight months, Sovietbloc countries have been supporting their athletes while they trained with their teams for the Summer Olympic Games.

title: BRITISH, IN A SHIFT, SEARCH FOR I.R.A. IN CATHOLIC AREAS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. July 22British troops moved in force into Roman Catholic neighborhoods today as gun battles, bombings and killings continued to grip Northern Ireland.

title: Art
description: ONCE the focus of a small, rather cultish, mostly nonartworld audience, the late Dutch printmaker, M. C. Escher, has in recent years become the focus of a vast rather cultish, mostly nonartworld audience. A new show of his woodcuts and lithographs at La Boetie, Inc., is but one manifestation of the current Escher vogue, which is being fueled this summer by a major exhibition at the National Gallery in Washington and the arrival of a book, presenting the artist's oeuvre nearly entire, from Abrams. Meanwhile, Escher has been discovered by the psychedelic young, and reproductions have lately appeared on posters, Tshirts and rock LP jackets.

title: Means and Ends
description: Opponents of the late General de Gaulle used to say that they accepted his goals but disliked his methods. In international affairs, however, methods cannot separated from goals: chauvinistic methods are chauvinistic policy, and protestations of worthy purpose are either hypocritical or selfdelusive.

title: Late Sprint Pays Off
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (UPI)Bold Liz sprinted with a rush in the stretch to capture the 33d running of the $140,500 Hollywood Juvenile Championship for 2yearolds today and becalm the first filly to win the race since 1947.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SKHIRAT, MoroccoAfrica is short of many things as a result of a history as dark as the skins of many of its peoples but there is no dearth of new ideas, original if not always practical. There has been a ferment of experimentation since colonialism waned.

title: A funny thing happened on the way to the coronation
description: MIAMI BEACH: The word had just gone forth the McGovern trailer outside the Convention Hall. Frank Mankiewicz, McGovern's top political strategist, was in the back room with Rick Steams, the young Rhodes Scholar who was overseeing eight staff members at telephones, who in turn were touch, directly and indirectly, with about 250 McGovern whips on the floor.

title: Letters
description: There were a few points that weren't made clear in James Markham's article on heroin maintenance (What's All This Talk About Heroin Maintenance? July 2).

title: Mary Elizabeth Howe, Teacher, Is the Fiancee of Jeremy Cripps
description: CINCINNATI, July 22Miss Mary Elizabeth Howe and Jeremy Cripps, a grandnephew of the late Sir Stafford Cripps, former Cancellor of the Exechequer, will be married Aug. 26 in Cincinnati.

title: Even Vacationers Take Benefit Route
description: SAGAPONACK, L. I. Mr. and Mrs. Fred Marquardt and Mr. and Mrs. Milton Leidner would seem to have little in common. The Marquardts and their four young children come from Bohemia, L. I., and, utilizing a truckcamper, spent a recent weekend at a Suffolk County park in East Hampton. The Leidners, from Philadelphia's Main Line, spent the same weekend with friends at their oceanfront estate in Southampton.

title: Breathing Spell for Dollar
description: WASHINGTON  Last week was momentous in the rapidly evolving story of world money. But one salient fact of recent times endures: Events in the private markets and decisions by Governments leave no sure guide as to what is to come next.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Harry R. Silver to Wed Jessica Dunsay
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman. Dunsay of Floral Park, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jessica Ann Dunsay of New York, to Harry R. Silver, also of New York. He is a son of Mrs. William Furr of Philadelphia and Jerome Silver of Hawthorne, Calif.

title: DAVID WELD, 61, AIDE OF INVESTMENT FIRM
description: ST JAMES, L. I., July 22David Weld, a partner in the investment firm of White, Weld & Co., until its incorporation last February, when he became a director, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived at Boney Lane.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times reports (July 14) that President Nixon has instructed Kissinger to arrange briefings for George McGovern on foreign policy and intelligence matters, in accordance with the practice begun in 1952 by President Truman. Perhaps it is time to end this tradition, at least in the special circumstances of the current campaign.

title: The Rapes of Bangladesh
description: DACCA: Bangladesh is a green and pleasant land. It is flat, with a dozen rivers snaking their way through it to the sea, watering the fields of jute, making them as emerald as the fields of Ireland, or putting the rice fields under calm pools which throw back a tranquil sky. Among this beauty move a tranquil, soft people, living in villages raised on mounds above the waters. They are poor, but not so very poor, like so many others in the world who are living on an abundant soil. They speak Bengali, a lilting, tripping language, accompanied by delicate gestures. They are smallboned, shy and kindly to a fault. They love their families, they love the land into which they were born. They love peace.

title: Where Are the Joys of Yesteryear?
