description: One of Wall Street's most timehonored theories is that the small investor  the little guy who deals in small batches of stockis always wrong in his investment decisions, that he buys at the top and sells at the bottom.

title: Bell Is Often Out of Sight, But Is Never Out of Mind
description: When you're the smallest New York Jet, it's no small problem making yourself visible behind those huge football players. That's the way it has been for Ed Bell, the 5 foot 10  inch, 160  pound wide receiver who joined the Jets two years ago out of Idaho State.

title: Baker Homer Sinks Cards
description: ATLANTA, July 22 (AP)Dusty Baker greeted Tony Cloninger, a reliever, with a home run leading off the 10th inning, powering the Atlanta Braves to an 87 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: Music: New York Neophonic Debut
description: HACKENSACKThe name of the orchestra is the New York Neophonic, but New Jersey is going to hear it before anyone in New York. This 23piece orchestra, patterned on the Los Angeles Neophonic, which Stan Kenton founded in 1965, will make its first appearance anywhere Wednesday evening at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium as part of the North Jersey Cultural Council's Summer Fun 72 Festival.

title: Papers on The War
description: (Melville) was born for Purgatory Some souls are purgatorial by destiny.

title: Squeals of Delight for An Aging Crooner
description: WASHINGTONFrank Sinatra played to a packed house last week, belting out an angry tune that left a Capitol Hill committee as limp as the bobbysoxers he used to wow.

title: CLINICS WILL FIGHT SICKLE CELL ANEMIA
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The Government has announced the opening of a network of hospitalbased research centers and education clinics to combat sickle cell anemia, the deadly blood disease that primarily afflicts blacks.

title: Support for Sadat
description: CAIRO, July 22 (UPI)The Egyptian parliament was addressed by President Sadat at an emergency session today and then declared full support for his nationalistic decisions, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Twins Down Brewers, 95
description: MILWAUKEE, July 22 (AP)Charlie Manuel's tworun single capped a threerun eighth inning that carried the Minnesota Twins to a 95 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today.

title: Lori Ann Litt Affianced
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 22 Mr. and Mrs. Donald DLitt of Scarsdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lori Ann Litt, to Joseph S. Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Roth of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for Aug. 5 at the Delmonico's Hotel in New York. Miss Litt's father is vice president of the Techmation Corporation in Long Island City, Queens. Her fianc's father is a Baltimore real estate broker.

title: M'GOVERN SEEKING NIXON THEBES
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 22Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, called today for a series of nationally televised debates this fall between himself and President Nixon.

title: The End Of the Dream
description: This posthumous novel of Philip Wylie's comprises a kind of Pollution Papers, documenting the whimpering end of the world. Looking backward from the year 2023and dimly forwardit reports on escalating catastrophies leading up to the abyss. Lethal inversions, volcanic aberrations, exploding rivers (from industrial waste), exploding people (from combustible flatulence), isotopes on the Spuyten Duyvil, sea leeches in the Gulf Stream, plagues of insects, failure of the earth's crust, epidemics of blue haze, green slime, black blight Mr. Wylie's pessimism is given carte blanche.

title: Movies
description: IWENT not long ago to Peter Bogdanovich's The Last Picture Show under the mistaken impression I would find a nostalgic reminder of what it was like, really like, to go to the movies in a small town a generation ago. Instead, I found that the last movie at the Royal picture palace was a metaphor for the passing of the old order or something like that.

title: OLD HOUSES SOLD BY SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22Fortyone Victorian buildings were put on sale this week by the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency, mostly for $500 each.

title: HOUSING OPPOSED IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 22The political potential of the growing opposition to the Urban. Development Corporation was convincingly demonstrated this week when 2,000 people, including 50 elected officials and candidates, gathered at Fox Lane High School in Bedford for a rally against the state agency's plans to build 100 low and moderateincome apartment units in each of nine Westchester towns.

title: Recordings
description: ODDLY enough, a big, complex work like Mahler's Symphony No. 8 is well represented on disks. What has come to be called the Symphony of a Thousand, because it requires so many performers, has been recorded by Leonard Bernstein with the London Symphony, Bernard Haitink with the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, Dimitri Mitropoulos with the Vienna Festival Orchestra and Maurice Abravanel with the Utah Symphony. There is another version in the set of Mahler symphonies made by Rafael Kubelik and the Bavarian Radio Symphony, and this will be available independently in September (two disks, Deutsche Grarnmophon 2707 062). Finally, there is a new recording on the London label from Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony (two disks, OSA 1295).

title: The World
description: Little is left in Czechoslovakia of the Prague Spring of 1968, when the regime of Premier Alexander Dubcek permitted a flowering of individual and political liberties unknown in any other Communist country. Now politically unreliable writers find it difficult to publish abroad. The famous Theater Behind the Gate is closed. Scholars, writers, journalists, composers and other artists are questioned about their political views. Negative attitudes can mean loss of jobs or worse.

title: John Jay's 1763 War With Columbia
description: John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States, as a matter of principle, accepted prolonged suspension as a Columbia student rather than inform against a fellowstudent with whose actions he did not sympathize.

title: Drug Discoveries Sometimes Backfire
description: The discovery of powerful drugs has been a prime factor in the successes of the modern era of medicine by helping doctors treat so many diseases so much better.

title: Plans to Spur Health Care
description: NEWARK  When Mary Reed discovered that she had to have open heart surgery last month, she was asked if family and friends could donate the necessary blood for the mitralvalve repair operation. Unfortunately, 53yearold Mrs. Reed has rare blood  type B. Rh negative.

title: Sudanese President Tells Of a New Plot Against Him
description: CAIRO, July 22 (Reuters) President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan announced in Khartoum today that a plot to overthrow the regime had been uncovered.

title: The Nation
description: ATTICAA state of emergency, the wire copy said. In the plane, in the rented car, the words echoed in a reporter's mind. A state of emergency at the Attica Correctional Facility just 10 months since the revolt that had been broken at a cost of 43 lives.

title: About Motor Sports
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. July 22  There's an old saying in racing: Speed costs money. How fast do you want to go?

title: David Duncan Protests
description: TO THE EDITOR: I do not know who Gene Thornton is; for all I know he may be the world's foremost photo critic (or whatever ene calls whatever he does). But one thing I do know, at least on the evidence of his column (concerning two photo exhibitions on the Vietnam war), he is the world's foremost practitioner of the non sequitur. What sense does it make to ask (rhetorically, perhaps?) that if war pictures do not change anything, if things just go rolling on the same old way In spite of them what do they do? Did Tolstoy's War and Peace change anything? What did it do?

title: MARQUEZ ABOARD
description: Hitchcock, the lesser potential in the Sigmund Sommer entry, won the $113,300 Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MATAWAN TOWNSHIPThere is a whole slew of stores here that sell closeouts, ovcrcuttings, cancellations and secondsand look good doing it. The Marketplace, An Unusual Concept, is an unlikely shopping center of seven (next month 13) onestory, shingled, sloperoof stores on nine nicely wooded and landscaped acres two miles north of Matawan on Route 34.

title: Why Is Bella Bored?
description: THE critics say this movie, The Candidate, gives the real inside stuff about how to run a campaign. And besides, it has everythingsatire, cinema verite, a hero who's supposed to be KennedyTunneyLindsay but looks like Robert Redford (that's even better), sex on the run, the old politics versus the new, the mastermind political technicians making with the TV spots and the trumpedup crowds and the ghetto walking tours, and most of all, the sellouts, because that's what politics is supposed to be, and we have to warn the young people, don't we?

title: Stamps
description: IT appears that there were an additional 232 covers carried to the moon aboard Apollo 15 last year by Astronauts Col. David B. Scott, Col. James B. Irwin and Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden. These are in addition to the 400 reported in this column July 9. This fact came to light with the announcement July 11 that the three had received reprimands from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the smuggling of the 400 covers, of which 100 eventually found their way to Herman W. Sieger, a West German stamp dealer who sold 99 covers for about $1,500 each, and retained one for himself.

title: Carol Herman Betrothed
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., July 22 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Herman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mist Carol Anne Herman, to Martin Philip Averbuch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Averbuch of Baldwin.

title: Books:
description: Two young writers and management experts offer some refreshing insights on business and many sensible suggestions.

title: Park Visitors Are a Dangerous Breed
description: SO many persons are injured while vacationing in Yosemite National Park that the park has to maintain a complete hospital and three fulltime doctors. But of the four most dangerous, and sometimes deadly, items within the 1,182squaremile park, only onethe sceneryis indigenous. The other three are automobiles, cameras and human stupidity.

title: MaryLouise McRoberts Plans Sept. 9 Marriage
description: MUTTONTOWN, L. I., July 22The engagement of Miss MaryLouise McRoberts to John Ashhurst Richards Jr. of Oyster Bay, son of Mr. Richards of Long Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Agnus N. MacDonald of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin C. McRoberts of Muttontown.

title: POLICE TRACE BODY FOUND BY AIRPORT
description: The police have identified the body of a 220pound man found beaten and stabbed near Kennedy International Airport Thursday morning as that of a 63yearold Massachusetts lawyer, and they are no longer considering the homicide a gangland slaying.

title: More Beef Found Faulty
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Four more beef livers have been found by Federal inspectors to contain illegal traces of DES, a cancercausing growth and commonly used by livestock producers the Agriculture Department has announced. The new findings Thursday raised to 58 the number of positive samples detected among 2,550 cattle and sheep checked for the hormone this year.

title: U.S. 1,2 in Irish Oaks
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, July 22 (UPI)  Americanowned horses finished first and second today in the Irish Oaks fillies classic, which carried its richest purse, $62,500.

title: Education
description: Only a few years ago there was a general panic about getting into college  there were too many applicants for the seats available. Today, the situation has been reversed: Two months before the new academic year, it is estimated that there may be as many as half a million vacancies in a total of 8 million seats.

title: Richards Captures His 3d Pentathlon For Olympic Berth
description: SAN ANTONIO. Tex., July 22 (AP)  Charles Richards of Tacoma, Wash., captured a third consecutive national pentathlon championship today, assuring him of a post on the United States Olympic team.

title: Plea of Detroit Paper To Oust Agnew Halted
description: DETROIT, July 22 (AP)The Detroit News called for replacement of Vice President Agnew on the Republican ticket in an editorial for Sunday editions, but the press run was halted with the announcement that Mr. Agnew was being retained by President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The Army War College piece stated that in the Carlisle Indians vs. West Point game in 1912 Jim Thorpe scored all of his team's 27 points. The fact is that Thorpe (although he played whale of a game at fullback that afternoon) did not cross the Army goal line. He did not make any of the Indians touchdowns but he did make three conversions for a total of three points. There is an account of the game, which the Indians won by 27 to 6, in The Greatest Sports Stories From The New York Times.

title: Deirdre McCrystal to Marry in Greece
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., July 22 Miss Deirdre McCrystal and Thomas Duncan Silverman, graduates of Monmouth (Ill.) College, plan to be married Aug. 12 in Corfu, Greece.

title: Child to Mrs. Richmond
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Richmond of Rockville Centre, L.I., June 28 in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Richmond is the former Miss Marjorie A. Miller of West Hempstead, L.I. The child, the couple's third, is named Nancy Leigh.

title: The Midwest Is a Nice Place to Live, But Would You Want to Visit There?
description: C HICAGOThere is a widely held theory on both coasts of America that between the Hudson River and the Rockies there is a huge glacial scour called the Middle West, as flat as your hand and inhabited by men who spend most of their time at Rotary meetings, women who spend most of their time baking and children who play all day with Penrod and Sam.

title: Students In Sea Cliff Are Getting Into the Act
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I.Many Long Island teenagers are already sporting vigorous tans gleaned from lazy hours of beach and sun. But not the Summer Workshop Theater students from North Shore High School here in Sea Cliff. They are still pale. They have had little time for the sea.

title: Mackay Trophy Given To Two Air Force Men
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)The Air Force has awarded its Mackay trophy to a crew that set a highspeed endurance record in the Lockheed SR71 reconnaissance airplane more than a year ago.

title: Music
description: AGRAY and sultry Monday noontime in Brooklyn Heights, I on my way somewhere Important. I never got there, for as I turned a corner into Montague Street, I heard the crisp chatter of a snare drum and the shimmering cry of an electric guitar. Rock n roll in Brooklyn Heights? I ran to the sound. There in a square outside the Borough Hall subway station were five kids doing something that sounded like an old Howlin Wolf number.

title: LAWYERS DRAWN TO PHILLIPS TRIAL
description: There are court buffs, offduty policemen, prosecutors wives and rejects from the jury pool. But mostly, crammed into the hot and humid 13th floor courtroom where Patrolman William R. Phillips is on trial in the SmithStango murders, there are lawyers.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Before the final round of the United States Open golf tournament last month. Lee Trevino was on the Pebble Beach putting green.

title: Music
description: CAN we even imagine what their music might have been like Schoenberg had grown up not knowing the works of Wagner and if Stravinsky had known nothing of RimskyKorsakov? Except possibly for Ives, it is hard to find such innocence and insularity in our century. And yet that is what happened with Mozart. He knew the music of Bach's sons intimately, but not that of the father almighty, who stood for everything Mozart's own idols found repellent in the Baroque: the overelaboration, the complexity, the dry and seemingly pointless counterpoint. They felt smothered and wanted to break clean with all that. And they did, taking Mozart with them.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Unique is a dangerous word because its careless use often ignores the exclusivity that is an integral part of the definition. Yet it still seems safe to attribute the quality of uniqueness to the University of San Francisco football team of 1951. Eleven members of that squad went on to careers in the National Football League. So did the coach, Joe Kuharich. So did the press agent, a fellow who advanced farther than any of them, Pete Rozelle, the lord high commissioner. But this projection into the realm of the unusual can be extended even beyond these dizzy extremes. Two teammates on that University of San Francisco squad, Gino Marchetti and Ollie Matson, will be inducted on Saturday into the Pro Football Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio. Unique? It sure had to be a strain on the laws of probabilities.

title: THE AFFLUENT ASK HELP OF OPERATOR
description: The State Public Service Commission concluded last week the first series of hearings on a plan of the New York Telephone Company to cut the use and therefore the cost of directory assistance by charging users for it rather than all the subscribersnonusers and users alike.

title: LETTERS
description: Spiro Agnew can breathe easier. The Time has lost its liberal bias. This is evident by the barrage of three items against Senator McGovern in the issue of July. 16Edwin L. Dale Jr.'s McGovernWhat's Ahead? and the two letters under the headline McGovernomics.

title: Reds, Led by Morgan's 4 Hits, Subdue Pirates for Fifth Straight Time, 63
description: PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP)  Ted Uhlaender's pinchhit bunt single on a squeeze play highlighted a tworun rally in the eighth inning that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 63 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: Wind, rain and chemical erosion work continuously to reduce the earth to a smooth oblate spheroid. Their success would eliminate all dry land and the creatures, including man, that dwell there. But an opposite process is also at workone that constantly thrusts new land masses into view. This process drives plates of the earth's crust together so that they undercut and override one another, creating islands and mountain ranges, increasing the land area of continents and raising such great Inland regions as the Colorado Plateau.

title: Cairo Aide Lays Sadat Move To Basic Nonalignment Policy
description: CAIRO, July 22The Egyptian Government's official spokesman today placed President Anwar elSadat's orders for the withdrawal of Soviet military personnel squarely in the context of political nonalignment between East and West.

title: The weapons are words, the heroes are writers;Uncensored Russia
description: Protest and Dissent in the Soviet Union. The Unofficial Moscow Journal. A Chronicle of Current Events. Edited, Translated and With a Commentary by Peter Reddaway. With a Foreword by Julius Telesin. Illustrated. 499 pp. New Yorh: American Heritage Press. $10.

title: Art Notes
description: THE seedy, 80yearold building at 10 Bleecker Street is not what you'd call a prime showcase for art. Fire has oared the ceiling beams of its huge tirstrtoor interior and the floor itself has a sumptuous carpet of splinters. Nor does the Bowery neighborhood have the  well, decorum of Upper Madison. On a sizzling day last week, kids turned a fire hose through a secondstory window, creating a small Niagara from floor to floor.

title: Photography Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE review of my photographic exhibition, One Generation of Peace and War, currently on display at the Whitney Museum, contains several basic errors and a distortion so extreme of my attitude toward war photography that I should like to correct the recordwhile I'm still around to do it myself.

title: Poverty Areas Reduce Incomes in Passaic County
description: Slightly more than onequarter of the 121,000 families in Passaic County had a total income exceeding $15,000 in 1970, according to newly released figures from the Census Bureau.

title: JOHN J. VERDON
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 22 John J. Verdon, a New York lawyer, died yesterday in Valley Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 248 Claremont Avenue, here. His office was at 120 Broadway, New York.

title: The Face Is Familiar (Darn It)
description: WHAT can you say about a profession in which success leads to oblivion, victory eventually turns to defeat, and celebrity fades into anonymity? For the actor performing them, television commercials offer precisely this, a unique opportunity to disprove everything espoused by Horatio Alger Jr.

title: A DayCare Directory For Nassau Is Issued
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.A new publication, A Directory ot DayCare Services in Nassau County, is available to parents of children needing such aid. Prepared by the Day Care Council of Nassau County, the directory lists the available care centers, nurseries, and parttime programs. It also lists hours of operation, meal and other fees, and eligibility requirements.

title: Center for Rehabilitation Dedicated on Staten Island
description: A rehabilitation center with the first sheltered workshop to employ disabled adults on Staten Island was formally dedicated in Port Richmond yesterday under the auspices of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City.

title: He's Among the Last of the BigTime Horseplayers
description: PARIS, July 22  PierreDesire Allaire is one of the last of the bigtime horseplayers. And big time he really is. Allaire, coowner of the great trotting mare, tine de Mai, bet a staggering $8million on the horses last year.

title: Mideast 2: The Power Balance, Upset, With The Future In Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  Henry A. Kissinger once called the expulsion of Soviet military personnel from Egypt a paramount American goal. President Nixon early this year said Soviet inroads in Egypt had serious implications for the stability of the balance of power in the area and in the world. Yet when the news of President Sadat's order to his Russian military advisers to go home broke last week, officials here were stunned, as though unwilling to believe that the Egyptian leader was actually doing what American policy could only envisage as a distant objective.

title: 3Horse Trot Won By Speedy Crown
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 22A week ago, the physical fitness of Une de Mai of France raised enough questions to prompt officials to order the mare scratched from the $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Racewty.

title: Madeleine Vanderpool Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Madeleine McAlpin Vanderpool of Harpursville, N. Y., and Wynant D. Vanderpool Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Vanderpool, to Kenneth Speiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno Speiser of Syosset, L. I.

title: Home Improvement
description: N0 matter how spacious the closets in a home or apartment may seem when a family first moves in, sooner or later complaints inevitably arise about a lack of adequate closet and storage space. Yet in many instances there really is no lack of space. It's just that the existing closets really are not being used to their fullest extent  in some cases because part of each closet is too hard to reach, and in others because of improper utilization of the space that is availaislo.

title: LAWYER IS DISMISSED IN RAID ON OFFICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) President Nixon's campaign organization has dismissed a Lawyer who refused to answer questions by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in connection with a breakin at Democratic National Headquarters.

title: Miss Matthews Wed
description: MERCHANTVILLE, N. J., July 22  Miss Bernadette Eileen Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Matthews of Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon to Samuel Sloan Duryee 3d, son of Mr. Duryee Jr. of Haddonfield, N. 3., and Mrs. Mills Duryee of Boston. The Rev. Timothy W. Held of Sunbury, Pa., performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Dorothy Morss And Instructor To Be Married
description: BEVERLY FARMS, Mass., July 22Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Morss of Beverly Farms have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Hovey Morss of New York, to Peter Randolph Decker, also of New York. He is the son of Frank Decker of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Decker. The couple will be married Sept. 16 in Squam Lake, N.J.

title: Plays and stories by a Soviet Chekhov
description: Edited by Ellendea Proffer. Translated by Carl R. Proffer and Ellendea Proffer. 418 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $10.

title: White Whale Is Born Here But Soon Dies
description: A white whale was born yesterday afternoon at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island but survived only ten minutes after swimming around in a large tank as hundreds of visitors watched.

title: U.S. BLACKS TOUR AFRICA SLAVE FORT
description: ABANDZE. Ghana, July 15The Rev. William A. Jones Jr., a Brooklyn Baptist minister, was the first of a group of black American clergymen to climb the winding, stone steps to Fort Cormantin, built in 1641 hold slaves for shipment to the Americas.

title: John Livingston Finds Return to Rowing Puts Rewarding Beat in His Life
description: It would have been convenient for John Cleve Livingston to forgo the pressures of another Olympic experience.

title: CHORAL WORK LED BY ROBERT SHAW
description: Robert Shaw, an infrequent visitor to New York nowadays, appeared at Riverside Church on Friday night to conduct a performance of Bach's St. Matthew Passion presented by the Westminster Choir College. Mr. Shaw, who is now music director of the Atlanta Symphony, had led a twoweek workshop on the Passion at Westminster in Princeton, and this performance was the concluding event of that project.

title: Webster Pleased at Giants Progress
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 22  A 71play, onehour full scrimmage completed the preliminary phase of preseason training for the New York Giants today, and Coach Alex Webster expressed satisfaction with the way the work had progressed.

title: 3 FROM CITY HELP SET BRIDGE PACE
description: DENVER, July 22  Two teams, including one with three New York experts, led a field of 60 teamsthe survivors of an original entry of 168into the final session of the, master mixed team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals here tonight.

title: the traveler's world
description: TORSHAVN, Stremoy, Faroe Islands In two preceding columns we reported on the exciting adventure of our first visit to these 18 Volcanic islands, lying far away in the north Atlantic, noting the great unusual natural beauty of the islands, the friendly welcome the Faroese uniformly extend to visitors from abroad, and our great delight in discovering this undervisited, unspoiled, untouristic and almost unknown part of the world. But before we inspire a mass tourist movement to the Fames, it must be reemphasized that this is not mass tourist country yet, nor is it likely to be for a long time, if ever.

title: The Nation
description: The assumption that women have any moral or spiritual superiority as a class or that men share some insensitivity as a class  this is male chauvinism in reverse; it is female sexism. Those words came list week from the woman who has been called the mother of women's liberationBetty Friedan.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The trend of events in the election is now clearly running with President Nixon. On the surface, the U.S. economy is turning up, the war in Vietnam is winding down, the Paris peace talks sound a little more hopeful, Cairo is expelling some of the Soviet fliers and missile technicians and Moscow is buying American farm surpluses and negotiating even more significant trade deals with Secretary of Commerce Peterson and U. S. industrialists.

title: Rosemarie Lee Is Bride
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., July 22Miss Rosemarie Mergerete Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester B. Lee, was married here this afternoon to Hans Werner Vogel, son of Mrs. Judith Schutz von Tscharner of Innsbruck, Austria. The Rev. Paul Brndjar performed the Lutheran ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: 5 New Conditions For Boating Safety Take Effect Aug. 7
description: Starting Aug. 7, Coast Guard boarding officers throughout the United States will be empowered to send pleasure boats back to port or the nearest safe mooring if one of eight unsafe conditions exists on the boarded boat.

title: Albatross, 4th in Delaware. Loses 10Race Streak, Too
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 23 (UPI)Albatross, a $2,500,000 syndicated pacer was defeated last night at Brandywine Raceway as Nansemond won the Adios Harry invitation pace in the track record time of 1:56 15.

title: We Might Call This The Politics of Fantasy
description: WASHINGTONAt one minute after 11, on the morning of July 18, walked into a large hearing room in the Cannon Office Building in Washington to testify before a group called the Select Committee on Crime. The halls were packed with visitors; the rows behind me were sold out. And every member of the Congressional committee was present, an event which I'm told does not happen too often.

title: Avi Sheloush, an Israeli, Marries Abbie Zion at Ceremony in Haifa
description: Miss Abbie Zion, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Joel Y. Zion, spiritual leader of Temple Israel in Lawrence, L. I., and of Mrs. Zion, was married last evening in Haifa, Israel, to Avi Sheloush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shalom Sheloush of Haifa. The ceremony was performed in Ulamay ha Carmel by her father and Rabbi Raphael Behrdo.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CHILMARK, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., July 23Miss Ruby Martyn of Spring Street in Vineyard Haven was 90 years old on Friday, The Vineyard Gazette reports, 'and birthday greetings came to her not only from President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon but from Carl Yastrzemski, left fielder for the Boston Red Sox. The Yastrzemski autograph, which came to her on his photograph, was the most exciting part of the day, she said, for I'm a Red Sox fan from way back.' By expressing her preference thus candidly, Miss Martyn may have put herself away as an effete snob in Spiro Agnew's book, but it seems here that a fan who has been viewing the scene for 90 years is entitled to set her own standards.

title: FitzGibbon Triumphs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 23Herb FitzGibbon of New York, the topseeded player, defeated Pete Fishbach of Great Neck, 76, 62, today to win the Nassau claycourt invitation tennis tournament, a new event on the Eastern circuit, at the Shore Tennis Club. FitzGibbon ranks fourth in the East and Fishbach sixth.

title: Fianchettoed? In Zugzwang? Relax, Grasping Chess Is as Easy as NN4!?
description: Because chess has been played so long, a tangle of terminology has grown up around it.

title: Oil Industry Opens Drive for Sea Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, July 23With the Nixon Administration preparing to resume the sale of offshore oil drilling leases, the oil industry has begun publicrelations campaign to ease public fears that offshore exploration and production may be environmentally harmful.

title: Services on Toll Roads Often 10% More
description: On many toll roads and other limitedaccess highways across the nation, motorists must pay as much as 10 per cent more for gasoline and at least 10 per cent more for food and other refreshments than they would pay for comparable services nearby.

title: Something Is Going On
description: WASHINGTONIt is fashionable these days to characterize the United States as an ailing giant, as a society which has lost faith in itself, a state whose governmental structure is failing, a world power which cannot be relied upon. One can easily gather material to support such a presentation; nothing could be easier.

title: U.S. EIGHT TAKES FINAL BY LENGTH
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 23 (AP)  The United States Olympic eight beat favored West Germany by a length today to win the West German rowing championships in a test of the Olympic Games course.

title: M'COVERN TO SEEK JOHNSON SUPPORT DESPITE WAR VIEW
description: CUSTER. S. D., July 23 Senator George McGovern made today what appeared to be a peace overture to former President Lyndon B. Johnson, the man whose Vietnam policies he has criticized long and severely.

title: Talk of the South
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 21In one little corner of the land, at least, the national politics of 1972 seem remarkably uncomplicated. From Atlanta to Chattanooga to Birmingham, the whites with a stake in the outcome are fleeing from George McGovern and the blacks are flocking to him as if he were the last hope of the decade. You can hear various reasons expressed, but the unavoidable impression is that racial reasons and sentiments form the basis of all others.

title: In Norway, Sweaters Are Among the Sights
description: BERGEN. NorwayTo Norwegians, they're koftes. To Englishspeaking tourists, they're Norwegian sweaters, and they hang by the thousands in shops throughout Norway, sending out a silent siren song to tourists searching for The Representative Souvenir.

title: Advertising:
description: Berger Stone & Partners, which has been doing really competitive automobile advertising in behalf of 10 Chevrolet dealer organizations, has just been named to a very special kind of auto account  a jeeptype fourwheel drive vehicle from Rumania.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LA NIVELLE, France, July 23 (UPI)Barry Jaeckel Los Angeles beat Clive Clark of Britain in a suddendeath playoff for the French open golf championship today for his first tournament victory since turning pro nine months ago.

title: Giants Subdue Mets and Seaver, 5 to 2
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23Thanks to the AllStar Game break, the Mets have the next three days off. But their run and hit totals on those days won't be much lower than they've been on any other day this month.

title: Small Business
description: If you look at the relatively high prices on items at the Globe Food Market at 64th Street and First Avenue$1.79 a pound for fancy mushrooms compared with 90 cents for the more ordinary variety at the A. & P. a block away and 36 cents for a quart of milk compared with the A. & P.'s 32 centsyou might conclude that the Globe is a gold mine.

title: Western Bancorporation Criticized for Operations
description: A leading dealer in bank securities charged over the weekend that there has been a serious loss of confidence among investors in the senior management of the Western Bancorporation, a giant, $13.7billion bank holding company whose operations sprawl over 11 Western states.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Yesterday's announcement from the White House that Vice President Agnew would remain on the Republican ticket did more than merely end speculation on the identity of Mr. Nixon's running mate next fall. It gave some new insights into the assumptions on which Mr. Nixon intends to base his campaign; and it also, in an indirect way, sheds some badly needed light on the plans of one man who might have been the President's partner on the ticket had Mr. Nixon decided to get rid of Mr. Agnew John B. Connally, a Democrat and former Secretary of the Treasury.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: ANCHORAGE, July 23Vice President Agnew, sounding conciliatory to the news media and, rejuvenated by his selection to be President Nixon's running mate again, won two of three early morning tennis sets before moving into a twoday fundraisingtour among Alaska Republicans.

title: Personalities: Count Hunter Out
description: Bobby Lee Hunter declined yesterday to join the Olympic boxing team that left Fort Worth for Bear Mountain, N. Y., and a final week of trials. Hunter is the fighter convicted of manslaughter who suddenly discovered he had fans. They pressed for a temporary prison release so he could box. But Hunter lost a flyweight bout last Thursday night to a 17yearold high school student named Tim Dement. Yet, late Saturday, the boxing committee asked Hunter if he would go to Bear Mountain as Dement's challenger. The committee can select a challenger in each division. If the challenger wins, he goes to the Olympic Games. I'm not going to fight any more, Hunter explained. I might as well go back to prison. Go back and serve my time. He has 12 years remaining on an 18year sentence.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered creation of an alcoholism program for permanent city employes afflicted with the disease. The program will be managed by the bureau of alcoholism of the city's Health Services Administration. The health agency will establish a unit to provide, medical examinations, psychiatric and psychological evaluations.

title: Bowles Wins Sunfish Sail
description: SHINNECOCK, L. I., July 23 Bob Bowles of Garden City, L. I., the world Sunfish Class champion, today won the Shinnecock Yacht Club's invitation regatta for the class, outpointing Bill Pagels of Sayville, L. I. Bob Fischer, Doug Crocker and Peter Young, three other Long Island skippers, finished behind the two leaders in that order.

title: CITY CALLED LAX ON BOILER SAFETY
description: Negligence and inefficiency by the city's Buildings Department have permitted dangerous conditions to develop in elevators and boilers in various parts of the city, State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday.

title: MISS WHITWORTH VICTOR AT RALEIGH
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 23 (AP)  Kathy Whitworth, leading., career moneywinner in women's pro golf, successfully defended her laurels today in the $20,000 Raleigh classic, winning by two strokes from Marilynn Smith.

title: L.I. CAMPAIGN BACKS RESTRICTED BEACHES
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., July 23Hempstead Town's Presiding Supervisor, Franois Purcell, anticipating a suit by the American Civil Liberties Union to open residential beaches to the public, made appearances on two town beaches today to promote support for keeping the beaches restricted.

title: Physician Weds Nancy Riseman
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 23Miss Nancy Royce Riseman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Riseman of Poughkeepsie, was married here at noon today to Dr. Gary I. Wadler. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wadler of Brooklyn.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: NEWARK, July 23 (AP)Maurice M. Veneri, the president of the 120,000member state Industrial Union Council, has criticized the national A.F.L.C.I.O. executive council and its president, George Meany, for not endorsing the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern.

title: Community Health Centers Are Defended by Official
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Responding to a report by Ralph Nader, a health association official said today that community health centers were beginning to have significant impact on the communities they serve.

title: Karoly Csatorday of Hungary; Deputy Foreign Minister, Dies
description: BUDAPEST, July 23 (AP)Deputy Foreign Minister Karoly Csatorday, chairman of the United Nations Security Council for a month in 1969, died today of injuries suffered when his glider plane crashed during competition Thursday. He was 46 years old.

title: Egyptians Mark Holiday With a New Pride
description: CAIRO, July 23In a mood of relaxed rejoicing, Cairo celebrated today the 20th anniversary of the nationalist revolution in which damal Abdel Nasser and his fellow officers overthrew, the monarchy.

title: Reds Hurler Reports Offer for aFat Pitch
description: PITTSBURGH, July 23The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Pittsburgh police today were looking into a bribe offer repbrtedly made yesterday to the Cincinnati pitcher, Wayne Simpson, asking him to throw a fat pitch to Bob Robertson of the Pirates in the sixth inning of last night's game.

title: Bob Stewart, Athletic Head Of St. Louis U., Dies at 56
description: CARMEL, N. Y., July 23 (AP) Bob Stewart, a former athletic director at St. Louis University and an executive with the St. Louis Cardinals, died here Friday night of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Coastal States to Purchase 47% of Colorado Interstate
description: The Coastal States Gas Producing Company announced over the weekend that it would purchase an estimated 2.04 million shares of common stock of the Colorado Interstate Corporation.

title: Western Concerns In Iranian Oil Talks
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 (UPI)  Major oil companies from Britain, the Netherlands, France and the United States began negotiations today with Iran's national oil company in an effort to extend standing export arrangements with the West, oil sources said.

title: Chief of Park Police Dies
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 23Edward R. Gleason Jr. of Congers, chief of the Palisades Interstate Park Police for the last three years, died after suffering a heart attack at Lake Welch Beach this afternoon while on an inspection tour of the park's recreation centers, which had the laargest crowds of the year. Mr. Gleason was 51 years old and had been a member of the Park Police Department for more than 25 years.

title: DONALD :MACKENZIE
description: JERSEY CITY, July 23Donald Mackenzie, who directed Pearl White through The Perils of Pauline, died Friday at his home here. He was 92 years old.

title: Mailing of Some Receipts For Property Tax to Halt
description: Starting this fall, the city will no longer mail real estate tax receipts automatically to taxpayers who pay by check, according to Richard Lewisohn, the city's Finance Adminstrator.

title: PICKUP EXPECTED IN STEEL BUSINESS
description: PITTSBURGH, July 23The steel market appears to be recovering from the summer slowdown.

title: Power Fails in Greece
description: ATHENS, July 23 (AP)A nationwide power failure paralyzed Greece today, trapping hundreds in elevators and causing heavy traffic jams in Athens and other major cities. Power was knocked out when lightning struck a generator. It was restored in two hours in many sections but parts of Athens were without electricity for two more hours.

title: GERARD WALRAVENS
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 23 (Agence FrancePresse)Gerard Walravens, the Belgian ambassador to the Ivory Coast, died this morning at his home here, the Foreign Ministry announced today. Mr. Walravens was also accredited to other West African countries, including Upper Volta.

title: Fire Forces Plane Down
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., July 23 (AP)  The pilot of a small plane towing an advertising banner escaped serious injury today when he was forced to land his burning craft in a marsh, the state police said. Francis J. Flood, 49 years old, a former detective with the Philadelphia police, suffered burns of the legs and left hand in the fire and required hospital treatment, the police said.

title: EDWARD R. GLESON JR.
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 23Edward R. Gleson Jr., chief of the Palisades Interstate Park Police for the last six years, died of a heart attack at Lake Welch Beach this afternoon while on an inspection tour of park recreation centers. He was 51 years old and had been a member of the park police department for more than 25 years.

title: Threadbare Sheepskin
description: Careful review of the qualifications of those graduates of Philathea College who are holding teaching or public service positions is clearly in order. Whether the obscure Canadian Bible college is an outright diploma mill remains to be determined; but, as indicated by recent disclosures in The Times, the institution is obviously no position to train psychotherapists, classical scholars or educational administrators.

title: 30 in Congress Urge U.N. to Act in Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Thirty members of Congress urged the United Nations today to take steps in the Security Council to punish countries that offer refuge to airline hijackers.

title: Montana Town Embattled
description: WHITEHALL, Mont., July 23 (UPI)A brawl broke out in bar here early today, then moved into the street where 200 persons battled. The fight ended when two persons were shot, apparently by sheriff's deputies trying to handcuff a prisoner. Four other persons were arrested.

title: BUILDERS PRAISE RAIL LABOR PACT
description: New York and New Jersey building contractors, engaged in wage and productivity disputes with their striking unions, believe that the labormanagement agreement ending the 35yearold dispute over featherbedding firemen on the nation's railroads has implications for their own industry.

title: Michalak Conducts Orchestral Works At a Site by Hudson
description: The eighth Summer of Music season is again this year in picturesque residence on the grounds of Lyndhurst, the historic estate overlooking the Hudson, just south of Tarrytown. The programs by the Orchestral Society of Westchester are usually well attended, as they should be considering the caliber of the guest artists, the beauty of the surroundings and the decidedly popular prices ($2 general admission, $3 for a seat inside the concert tent); more than 2,000 were there Saturday night to hear Aaron Rosand play SaintSatins and Thomas Michalak conduct Beethoven and Borodin.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Tickets may be obtained at the public desk, main lobby United Nations Headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: Leslie J. Hain Married to Mel Lederman
description: JAMESBURG, N. J., July 23Miss Leslie Jean Hain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Malcolm Hain of East Brunswick, was married here this afternoon to Mel Lederman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lederman of Great Neck, L. I.

title: MOZART FESTIVAL TO STRESS DETAIL
description: Unlike the recent Newport jazz extravaganza, which seemed to thrive on lively improvisation, the Mostly Mozart Festival that opens tonight at Philharmonic Hall will be concentrating on measured detail.

title: Case Histories in Levitt's Audit
description: The Levitt audit is full of grim case studies of deaths and injuries from uninspected boilers and elevators.

title: CONSUMERS SHOW MORE OPTIMISM
description: Preelection rhetoric is having some dampening effect on consumer confidence, the Conference Board reported over the weekend. However, there has been a rise in optimism about the state of the economy, with a sharp drop in the number of people considering current business as bad.

title: New Corruption Unit Chief Picked for Seymour's Office
description: Richard BenVeniste has been named to succeed Edward M. Shaw as chief of the corruption unit in the office of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.

title: EARNINGS GAIN 6.9% AT INGERSOLLRAND
description: The IngersollRand Company reported over the weekend secondquarter net income of $18,413,000, equal to $1.09 a share, up 6.9 per cent from the $17,384,000, or $1.02 a share, a year ago.

title: Men in the News
description: Fifteen hundred sweltering worshipers, most of them fending off 90degree heat with hand fans, gave a rousing welcome yesterday to the new pastor of Harlem's famed Abyssinian Baptist Church.

title: Gerulaitis Takes Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 23 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis of New York breezed to a 61, 61 victory over Billy Martin of Palos Verde, Calif., to win the national junior claycourt tennis championship today. Gerulaitis will be 18 on Wednesday. Martin is 15.

title: Personal Finance
description: The question of when a person who trades in the stock market actually becomes an owner of the shares he or she is buying can be very important for tax and other reasons. Two recent cases decided in the United States Tax Court and in the Supreme Court of New York State underscore the significance.

title: Experts Accuse Surgeons Of Improper Amputations
description: American surgeons are amputating too many legs improperly, according to a national commission of experts in diseases of the blood vessels and circulatory system.

title: LADY CONYERS'S DOG BEST IN YORK FIELD
description: WELLESVILLE, Pa., July 23 Ch. MiLe's Mischief Gold Pot triumphed at the third annual York Kennel Club show today. The Pomeranian, owned by Lady Conyers of Bermuda, defeated 1,577 rivals. It marked his sixth bestinshow award and his 16th group victory.

title: Merckx Wins Cycling a 4th Time
description: PARIS, July 23With a look of triumphant boredom and a gesture of good will, Eddy Merckx won his recordtying fourth straight Tour de France today.

title: NENEKHALI C. CAMARA
description: DAKAR, Senegal, July 23 (Agence FrancePress)  Nenekhali Condetto Camara, the scientific research minister of Guinea, died yesterday in Conakry, the Guinean Voice of the Revolution radio station reported today.

title: Quietly, Joe Namath Arrives in Jet Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, July 23 Joe Namath arrived quietly at 4:40 P.M. today at the New York Jets training camp.

title: CATHOLIC COLLEGES SEEN IN FISCAL PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The nation's Roman Catholic colleges and universities face serious financial difficulties and, unless a remedy is found, will not be able to play a dynamic role on the American educational scene, a new study said today.

title: COMPANY PROFITS UP 16% IN QUARTER
description: Sizable corporate profits were piled up in the second quarter, swelling the halfyear earnings increase well within the rates forecast six months ago by optimistic economists. Price and wage controls, apparently, had little impact on the upward thrust.

title: Bridg'e: Two New York Couples Take Title in Mixed Team Play
description: DENVER, July 23  Two New York married couples captured the master mixed team championship here last night and New Yo4 experts dominated the final standings in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. The winners were Mike and Gail Moss, winning the title for the second time in four years, and Bill and Marietta Passell of Ardsley, N. Y., all adherents of the Precision System.

title: Tenfold Rise Is Reported In Strikes in Government
description: A study showed yesterday that there were 10 times as many strikes by Government workers in 1970 as there were 10 years ago, The Associated Press reported.

title: Should Newsmen Keep Secrets?
description: WASHINGTONMore than a century ago, The New York Times published charges that Congressmen were taking bribes. A Times reporter named James Simonton was asked to reveal the sources of his article before Congressional committee. He refused.

title: Mitchell Wins in Judo
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 23 (AP)  Dewey Mitchell of St. Petersburg, Fla., scored an upset victory over Temoc Johns tonOno of New York City to win the open class division in the National junior judo championships today.

title: VENUS CRAFT DATA STUDIED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, July 23Is the surface of the planet Venus cast in eternal gloom as a dense cloud cover keeps out virtually all sunlight? Is the Venusian ground made up of molten lead and tin in an environment with temperatures around 900 degrees Fahrenheit?

title: I.R.A. MEN HUNTED IN BELFAST AREAS
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, July 23  The British Army, pursuing its toughest tactics in months, mused into five Roman Catholic strongholds today in a hunt for members of the terrorist Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: DR. C. A. D'ALONZO, DU PONT AIDE, DIES
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 23 (AP)Dr. C. Anthony D'Alonzo, medical director for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., died at his home here. He was. 59 years old.

title: Kyoto Is Swamped by Tourists
description: KYOTO, Japan, July 8 This ancient seat of Japanese government and culture is beginning to feel the special truth of Wordsworth's line: The world is too much with us.

title: Hope Dims for 9 Missing in Mine Fire
description: BLACKSVILLE, W. Va., July 23 (UPI)  Fourteen rescue teams, battling smoke and fumes from an underground coalmine fire, raced against time today to reach nine men trapped more than a mile from the surface. A foreman gave them a 5050 chance of survival.

title: Heat Equals 72 Record; Relief Is Due Tomorrow
description: New York City endured its third consecutive day of over90degree temperatures yesterday, a sweltering Sunday whose 94degree high equaled the hottest day of the year, and today is likely to be much the same. But the National Weather Service predicts normal temperatures in the mid80's for tomorrow.

title: Qaddafi Said to Offer Sadat Merger of Libya and Egypt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 (AP)The Libyan leader, Col.: Muammar elQaddafi, disclosed today that his ruling Revolutionary Command Council has offered to merge Libya with Egypt into one state, the Middle East News Agency reported from Tripoli, Libya.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of June 28, Middle East Myopia, constitutes a marked departure from the constructive attitude which you have in the past adopted on the questions of Jews, Israel and Palestinians. It is astonishing to read that the root of the problem [are the] deadly Palestinian guerrilla attacks against Israel from Lebanese soil. No decent man can deny that violence must not be condoned. But there is another violence which is indeed the root of the problem and that is the continued Israeli myopia for Palestinian existence. The taking of life of innocent Lebanese is an exercise of organic punishment which is primitive and barbaric for it punishes the innocent for the misdeeds of others. It proclaims the rule of guilt by association, which is so repulsive to justice anywhere.

title: Report of Jet Hijacking Called Misunderstanding
description: BOSTON, July 23 (AP)A Lufthansa Airlines plane landing here after a flight from Frankfurt was diverted to a secluded area of Logan International Airport for 30 minutes today because of an apparently false report that a hijacker was aboard.

title: Haizlip, Festival's Soul, Hopes for Broad Appeal
description: What Ellis B. Haizlip wanted as a young black man was more room in a sometimes too constricted world, artificially narrowed by custom and prejudice. Yesterday Mr. Haizlip obtained considerably more room for a black expression of the black experience when he took over Lincoln Center for a 12day Soul at the Center festival.

title: Fischer Crushes Spassky, Takes Lead in Title Match
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 23 Bobby Fischer, unleashing crushing attack that enveloped Boris Spassky in a mating net, tonight won the sixth game of the world championship chess match and took the lead for the first time.

title: JUMPER SWEEP BY COPPER KHAN
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 23 Glen View Stable's Copper Khan made a clean sweep of the open jumper division by winning the final class today at the closing session of the three day Lake Placid horse show.

title: Roche Ends Victory Drought
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Tony Roche, within 1 point of defeat in the second set, fought back to beat Marty Riessen, 3.6, 76, 64, to win The Washington Star international tennis tournament today.

title: DIXIE 600 TAKEN BY BOB ALLISON
description: HAMPTON, Ga., July 23 (AP) Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., took the lead 140 miles from the finish, following an illtimed pit stop by the favored David Pearson, and raced to an easy victory in the Dixie 500 stock car race today.

title: U.S SAYS PLANES DAMAGE 2 DEPOTS IN RAIDS ON HANOI
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 24  United States fighter bombers have attacked two large supply complexes in Hanoi, an American military spokesman said last night.

title: STREAKING GIBSON IS COOL TO CLASSIC
description: ATLANTA, July 23 (AP)The opposing managers will name their starting pitchers tomorrow for Tuesday night's 43d baseball AllStar game, but the hottest hurler at the moment, Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals, doesn't want the assignment.

title: Ring Qualifiers Picked
description: FORT WORTH, July 23 (AP) The United States Olympic Boxing Committee today announced the team for the Olympic trial finals beginning Aug. 5 at Bear Mountain, N. Y., to determine this country's entries in the Gaines.

title: ALFRED COOKMAN
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., July 23Alfred Cookman, who retired in 1953 as director of the biology department of Jonathan Dayton High School in Springfield, died Friday at the Toms River Convalescent Center. He was 80 years old and lived at 707 North Broad Street.

title: Haack, in Big Board Farewell, Voices No Regrets
description: Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, took a deep breath, stepped to the rostrum in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria last Tuesday night and told an audience of 1,400 persons from the financial community:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Confident that the most successful grassroots appeal for small contributions in American politics will see them through what is likely to be the costliest Presidential year, fund raisers for Senator George McGovern are shrugging off the threat of defections by some of the Democratic party's largest donors.

title: Black Theater Unit Combines Ritual, Dance, Song
description: Soul at the Center's program at Philharmonic Hall last night merited far better attendance than the halffull auditorium which greeted it.

title: 92 Freed in Philadelphia After Being Held at Concert
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) All 92 persons taken into custody by the police during last week's concerts here by the Rolling Stones have been released because searchandseizure methods used did not meet constitutional standards, District Attorney Arlen Specter said today.

title: U.S. Advisers Refuse To Speak to Newsmen
description: HAILANG, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP)United States advisers said today that they had been ordered not to talk to newsmen about action in South Vietnam's northern offensive.

title: Cambodian Action Reported
description: SAIGON, Monday, July 24 (Reuters)  South Vietnamese Rangers led by armored cars fought their way into the southern half of Kompong Trabek town in southeast Cambodia last night, military sources said.

title: An Asian Anachronism
description: Before his election as President, Richard M. Nixon described the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, which recently held its annual meeting in Australia, as a somewhat anachronistic relic. That negative assessment would appear to have been strengthened, if anything, by developments during the Nixon Presidency so farthe avowed attempt to extricate the United States from South Vietnam, the Nixon doctrine calling for a lower American profile abroad and selfreliance on the part allies, and above all, the President's overtures and visit to China, the original target of the late Secretary of State Dulles 1954 defensive alliance in Asia.

title: NIXON WILL MEET TANAKA ON AUG.31
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Nixon will meet with Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, in Hawaii on Aug. 31 and Sept. 1 for talks expected to concentrate on China and trade.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 23 (AP)Juan Gisbert and Manuel Orantes scored a doubles victory today to give Spain a 21 lead over Czechoslovakia in the European Zone B Davis Cup final.

title: Angry British Workers Testing New Labor Law
description: LONDON. July 23  In the sunshine outside of Pentonville Prison in North London this atternoon, Eric Rcchnitz, truck driser, and Jim Carpenter, a dockworker, were talking about Britain's latest industrial dispute, which has closed most of London's docks, disrupted publication of national newspapers and raked the possibility of a national strike that could paralyze the country.

title: A Ceausescu Cult Emerges in Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, July 22Expressions of support for President Nicolae Ceausescu are plentiful in Rumania, ranging from carefully planned demonstrations to warm and obviously sincere responses on factory or market visits.

title: U.S. DUO CLINCHES DAVIS CUP SERIES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 (AP)The United States won the American Zone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition today with a hardfought doubles victory over Chile.

title: Scarlett Tennis Victor
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 23 Bill Scarlett of Short Hills successfully defended his New Jersey State 35yearsandover tennis title today by beating Jack Schofield of Paramus, 64, 62, in the final.

title: Sassy and Windigo Setting a Record Pace in Mackinac Yacht Race
description: MACKINACISLAND, Mich., July 23 (UPI)Sassy, owned by E. Russell Schmidt of Grosse Pointe, and Windigo of Grand Rapids set a record pace today in the ChicagotoMackinac Island yacht race.

title: Jobs for Railway Suppliers Decline 25 Per Cent in Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Employment among companies that supply the nation's railroads is 25 per cent below the level a year ago, the Railway Progress Institute reported today.

title: Connecticut College Fete Stages Three Dances by Murray Louis
description: Man alone, by choice or by circumstance, is the hero of Murray Louis's eccentric and slightly disjointed pinball universe and he struggles through with varying degrees of success. At Connecticut College's American Dance Festival on Saturday his company presented three probings into this ricochet world, Chimera, Continuum, and Hoopla.

title: Perfectly Played Opening
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 22 In the sixth game of the world championship chess match, the opening was played to perfection by Bobby Fischer.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: IMOLA, Italy, July 23 (UPI)John Surtees of England, driving a Surtees, outlasted a field of rivals with mechanical troubles today to win the Imola Formula Two Grand Prix, but a Frenchman, Bob Wollek, gained the most ground the scoring race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: George Meany's reluctance to support George McGovern's candidacy against a Republican Administration points up the dilemma in which workers find themselves these days.

title: 2,000 War Objectors Freed From CivilianDuty Obligation
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Selective Service System, following several adverse court rulings, has ordered that more than 2,000 conscientious objectors be released from any obligation to perform alternative service.

title: An Increasingly Motorized Yugoslavia Has New Headache:
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23Yugoslavia's drivers, who already endure one of the highest highway accident and death rates in Europe, are worrying about an added hazard this summerTurks hastening homeward from jobs in West Germany or other countries, usually in secondhand cars of uncertain condition, frequently with forged driving licenses and generally reluctant to spend money along the way for a night's lodging.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The widespread and wellreported Israeli enthusiasm for the reelection of President Nixon is both simplistic and shortsighted.

title: Parties in Connecticut Are Told To ReHold Nominating Parleys
description: HARTFORD, July 23  With new Congressional district lines imposed on Connecticut by Federal court, the Republicans and Democrats of the state have been ordered to hold their Congressional nominating conventions over again, on Aug. 5.

title: MALDWIN FERTIG, LEGISLATOR, DIES
description: M. Maldwin Fertig, a lawyer, legislator and public official who played a key role in the unification of the city's subway system, died yesterday at his home, 150 West End Avenue. He was 85 years old.

title: Ghanaians Asked to Grow Own Corn and Raise Rabbits for Food
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 22 Stressing a theme of selfreliance, the sixmonthold military Government of Ghana is gambling that a spirited national program called Operation Feed Yourself will galvanize the nation, win popular support for the soldiers and also help to rescue a failing economy.

title: London's Night Cleaning Women Arise
description: LONDONMaggie, a blueeyed mother of five children, doesn't have a bed. In between her two jobsone as a guide at school crossings and the other as a night cleaner at the large ShellMex Building in south Londonshe catches odd hours of sleep on her living room sofa. Last year she took a week off, her first vacation since 1943.

title: Mrs. William Dalton, Aided Hospital, Honored by Pope
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., July 23 Mrs. Marie O'Reilly Dalton, widow of William A. Dalton, who had been an assistant vice president of the New York Telephone Company and president of the New York Athletic Club, died last night at the Jersey Shore Medical Center. She was 81 years old and lived in Avon.

title: $2Million Is Pledged To Aid Flood Victims
description: $2Million Is Pledged To Aid Flood Victims

title: Along Quangtri Street Without Joy, Quiet Reigns Among Ruined Villages
description: ALONG ROUTE 555, South Vietnam, July 23The war has moved inland from coastal Route 555the road that was known to the French as the Street Without Joybut it has left an aura of desolation unmatched anywhere in Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since I have long been a kneejerk defender of the accuracy, objectivity and general saintliness or The Times, I am disappointed as well as annoyed at being crudely misquoted in your story on Philathea College in the July 13 issue.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 23 (UPI)Two more boats reached port early today in the singlehanded transAtlantic race, which began June 17 at Plymouth, England.

title: 26 YACHTS START INOVERNIGHTRACE
description: RYE, N. Y., July 23The American Yacht Club cruise, extended this year, in its 41st running, to seven days, began shortly before noon on a whitecapped sea today.

title: Yancey Beats Ulozas On First Extra Hole
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 23Bert Yancey, who says he is practicing more and playing better golf, rolled in a putt for par and beat Tom Ulozas today at the first extra hole in a playoff of the $150,000 American Golf Classic.

title: Congress Under Pressure
description: Congress has resumed its work in this fiveweek period between the Democratic and Republican conventions, but the outlook for passing effective legislation is bleak.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BOSTON, July 23 (AP)Reggie Smith of the Boston Red Sox was added to the American League outfield today after Amos Otis of the Kansas Royals was injured when he crashed into the fence in a game against Baltimore.

title: Bostwick's 5 Goals Lead Aiken to Polo Victory, 82
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., July 23G. H. (Pete) Bostwick scored five goals and led Aiken to an 82 triumph over Westbury today in a Long Island Polo League match at Bethpage State Park.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The nomination of Senator George McGovern for President has to rank as one of the saddest moments in American politics. It is both a severe indictment of democracy and a ready confirmation of the fact that our party is truly bankrupt.

title: Credit Markets
description: Pressures appear to be building that would force bond rates, after months of relative stability, into higher ground. Few analysts expect an immediate, sharp rise in longterm interest levels, but a number of developments can be cited leading toward the conclusion that rates will be mov ing up some time during the third quarter.

title: Hanoi Reports Many Dead
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 23American air raids over Hanoi reached a peak this weekend and, according to an official communique, left many dead and wounded throughout the city.

title: New Centers Urged For Child Offenses Now Before Court
description: Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri of Manhattan urged yesterday that neighborhood family service centers be established to enforce special children's rules now in the jurisdiction of the Family Court.

title: New Warner Bros. President
description: Warner Bros., Inc., a subsidiary of Warner Communications, Inc., has elected Frank Wells as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Wells, who had been vice president of West Coast business affairs for the last three years, will report to Ted Ashley, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: WOLFRAM MIX
description: VRSAC, Yugoslavia, July 23 (Reuters)  Wolfram Mix, a Canadian glider pilot, died early today after being injured Friday when his glider slammed under a truck during the World Gliding Championship here. He was 46 years old.

title: To Many, Hudson Cruise Is THE One
description: I called up all my friends, said Dee Strickland, and told them I was taking a cruise to Poughkeepsie. On Saturday, Mrs. Strickland, who lives at 303 West 154th Street, did just that, along with 2,431 other persons, and unlike passengers on cruises to the Caribbean or around the world, it was difficult to find a complainer among them.

title: Report to U.S. Sees No Hope of Halting Asian Drug Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A Cabinetlevel report has concluded that, contrary to the Nixon Administration's public optimism, there is no prospect of stemming the smuggling of narcotics by air and sea in Southeast Asia under any cpnditions that can realistically be projected.

title: A Pleasing Tone Marks Piano Recital by Lynbok
description: The biography of David Lynbok reads like that of many young men who give debut piano recitals in New York. Now 25, he has been a piano student since he was six, has played clarinet and bassoon in a high school band, served as an accompanist for choral groups and soloists, earned college and university degrees (in this case Madison, in Virginia, and the University of Illinois) and gave a number of recitals in various places.

title: OLYMPIC TEAM, TORNADO TIE, 11
description: The United States Olympic soccer team utilized 17 players last night and fought the Dallas Tornado of the North American Soccer League to 11 tie in Dallas before a crowd of 4,176.

title: VILLAGERS LOSE APPEAL IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, July 23 The Israeli Government, after heated public controversy, decided today to bar the return of two communities of Israeli Arabs to their former homes on the Lebanese border.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: That Senator McGovern does not yet have the endorsement of big labor leadership may be for himand the Democratic partya blessing in disguise. As he emerged from the Miami convention owing no debt to old line political bosses, so, Senator McGovern owes no debt to old guard labor bosses.

title: Ohira to Attend Talks
description: TOKYO, Monday, July 24Chief Cabinet Secretary Susumu. Nikaido announced this morning that Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira would accompany Premier Tanaka to the twoday meeting with President Nixon and other American officials.

title: A.C.L.U. CRITICIZES MAYDAY ARRESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The American Civil Liberties Union, in a detailed report, has concluded that the response by Federal and local authorities to last year's May Day antiwar protests here amounted to a profound blow to civil liberties and a suspension of certain provisions of the Constitution.

title: West German Duo Wins
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 23 (Reuters)The 24hour Francorphamps Endurance Race was won today by Hans Stuck and Jochen Mass, West German drivers, in a Ford Capri.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 23 (AP)Twelve thousand spectators rose to their feet in enthusiastic support of the touring California Grizzles when they played and won their last Rugby game in New Zealand today.13.6.

title: Thieu's Daughter Engaged
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP)President and Mrs. Nguyen Van Thieu have announced the engagement of their 18yearold daughter, Nguyen Thi Tuan Anh, to a son of the directorgeneral of the national airline, Air Vietnam. The hushandltihe is Nguyen Tan Trieu, whose older brother way married earlier this year Io a daughter Of Premier Tran Thien khiem. No wedding date was announced.

title: Harriet Beth Rubens Is Bride of Physician
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 23Miss Harriet Beth Rubens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Rubens of Stratford, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Edward Robert Alexson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Alexson of Queens Village, Queens, New York.

title: CITY LAG IS CITED IN CURBING CRIME
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he was disappointed at the failure of efforts by his department and other lawenforcement agencies to curb organized crime, the narcotics traffic and police corruption.

title: Bonnie Stier Is Wed
description: JERICHO, L. I., July 23Miss Bonnie Stier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Stier of Massapequa, was married here this afternoon to Clifford Zaner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Zaner of Bethpage. Rabbi Kenneth Poplacl; performed the ceremony at the Fountainebleau.

title: Troops Seize Guns
description: DELFAST. Northern Ireland, 23 (AP)  British troops seized an armery of guns and explosives early today in raids on Catholic areas the raids yielded more than 700 pounds, of gelignite and other explosives, enough to devastate a dozen streets.

title: Advertising:
description: Times Square is in danger of losing its title of the Great White Way and the city government knows it.

title: Stevie Wonder to Open Stones Concert at Garden
description: SNight finally has arrived. After all the waiting, all the anticipation, and all the colorful reports from cities that span the continent, the Stones will open the final concerts of their 1972 tour tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Angels Hit 2 Homers to Top Yanks, 63
description: Yankee bats, which had blasted California pitching for one homers in four previous games, fell silent yesterday at the Stadium.

title: Peking's Team Cancels 2Week Australia Tour
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 23 The Chinese table tennis team's twoweek tour of Australia was Canceled today after its officials protested that the presence of a women's basketball team in Sydney from Taiwan at the same time was a political plot.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (AP)Ilie Nastase defeated Teimuraz Kakulia, 62, 62, 6.3, to give Rumania a 32 triumph over the Soviet Union in the European Zone A Davis Cup final at Tbilisi in Georgia.

title: Housing Reform Bill Lags As Nation's Crisis Grows
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 While a succession of Congressional investigations have disclosed a deepening crisis in the nation's subsidized and public housing programs, legislation intended to begin reform has foundered in the House of Representatives.

title: Frank Howard Shorr Marries Miss Brotman
description: HEWLETT, L. I. July 23Miss Sandra Dale Brotman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Brotman of Brooklyn, was married here this evening to Frank Howard Shorr, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Shorr of Rockville Centre. Rabbi Morris M. Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center.

title: Hulme Wins Glen CanAm With Revson a Close 2d
description: WATKINS GLEN, N Y., July 23Denis Hulme overcame the exhausting effects of today's 85degree heat and, leading from wire to wire, won the Glen CanAm for his second victory of the season.

title: Curtain Rises on Shubert Alley West
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23The opening of the new Shubert Theater here last night gives the 72yearold Shubert organization, largest theatrical empire in the world, its first theater in California.

title: The Man Who Gets Ahead: Being Married Really Helps
description: DETROIT  Being married almost triples a man's chances for success on the job.

title: Arab Aide's Talk With Nixon Called Factor in Sadat Decision
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23Informed diplomatic sources here say that a meeting in Washington last month between President Nixon and the Saudi Arabian Defense Minister, Prince Sultan ibn Abdel Aziz, had a significant bearing on President Anwar elSadat's decision to order Soviet military advisers to leave Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What strikes me as most incongruous in Talib elShibib's July 17 OpEd article, The Arab Portrayed, is not, of course, an Arab plea for fair treatment in the process of our Presidential elections, which may have been the reason you saw it fit to print. True, the proCommunist political alignment, the break in diplomatic relations and confiscatory policies in economic interests on the part of most of the Arab states, and especially of Iraq, visavis the United States, give Iraq's Ambassador to the U.N. little ground to arouse sympathy.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WITH SUPER MUTE IN YOUR MORN. ING. YOU'LL HAVE A BETTER DAYI. Bruce Bradley, 610 AM. WHN /1050Advt.

title: Best Smile Is Best
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 23Best Smile, owned and ridden by Mrs. Sara Steall of Syosset, L.I., won two classes and finished second in a third to score 13 points and capture the green working hunter championship today at the Old Westbury horse show.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Haile Selassie Is 80
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 23 (Reuters)An 80gun salute at dawn today signaled the start of Emperor Haile Selassie's 80thbirthday celebrations in Addis Ababa.

title: Indian Says Poles Agree To Keep Peace Unit Going
description: NEW DELHI, July 23 (AP)The External Affairs Minister, Swaran Singh, said today that India and Poland had agreed to keep the 18yearold international peacekeeping commission in Indochina in operation, to be ready for use when fighting in the region ends.

title: HERMAN A. HASKINS
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., July 23 (AP)Herman A. Haskins, who gained fame as a painter late in life with Christmas card drawings for the United Nations Children's Fund, died Monday. He was 83 years old.

title: An EarthExploring Satellite Is Orbited
description: A new era of earth exploration began yesterday with the successful lofting of an unmanned earthorbiting satellite that will continuously scan the surface of the earth, radioing back many kinds of information on global environment and natural resources.

title: Easy Hydroplane Victory Registered by Bill Muncey
description: PASCO, Wash, July 23 (AP)  Bill Muncey steered Atlas Van Lines to an easy victory today in the hydroplane final heat of the Atomic Cup race.

title: Roundup: Clemente Is Back
description: After two weeks on the sidelines with a virus infection, Roberto Clemente returned to action for the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday and saved them from a continuing state of embarrassment at the hands of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: RALPH C. CRAIG
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 23  Ralph C. Craig, who won gold medals in the 100meter and 200meter dashes in the Stockholm Olympics in 1912, died Friday at his summer home on Lake George. He also lived in Alexandria, Va. He was a retired industrial engineer and was 83 years old.

title: Mr. Agnew Again
