description: When Richard M. Nixon picked Spiro T. Agnew as his VicePresidential running mate four years ago, it seemed incredible that a man would be chosen to stand next in line for the Presidency who had experience neither national government nor in foreign affairs.

title: Peterson of Delaware
description: Environmentalists throughout the nation will regret that Governor Russell W. Peterson of Delaware failed clinch his party's nomination at last week's Republican state convention. Anything that diminishes the chance this courageous Governor to succeed himself  he will now have to go through a popular primary as well as an election campaign is a threat to his great achievement of a coastline guaranteed against further incursions heavy industry.

title: 42d St. Library Shows Olmsted Letters and Maps
description: The art is not gardening, nor is it architecture. It is the sylvan art, fine art in distinction from agriculture, or sylvan useful art,

title: Books of The Times
description: Late in life Sigmund Freud wrote that his achievement was less the result of intellect than of character. Today the word character has an oldfashioned ring to it. And in America we have been told again and againby beamish Freudian revisionists and existentialists, by Herbert Marcuse and Norman 0. Brown, by primalscreaming California optimists, by feminists who lack the insight of Juliet Mitchellthat Freud is old hat, that orthodox psychoanalysis is hopelessly Victorian. To talk about character is a downer. Yet Freud's description of his character was hardly dull, cold, pallid or uptight: I am actually not at all a man of science, he wrote at 43 after the publication of The Interpretation of Dreams, not an observer, not an experimenter, not a thinker. I am by temperament nothing but a conquistador, an adventurer with all the inquisitiveness, daring and tenacity characteristic of such a man.

title: Our Money for Theirs
description: Less than two weeks ago, speculators were pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into Europe, mostly into West Germany, in anticipation of a dollar devaluation. As the flood of dollars rose, the Governor of the German Central Bank, Karl Kiasen, wa, asked how much longer the Germans could go on taking dollars. Sounding more like a riverboat gambler than a respectable German banker. Dr. Kiasen replied, The sky's the limitit's our paper for theirs.

title: Bodies of Three Women Found on Alaska Peak
description: MOUNT McKINLEY NATIONAL PARK, Alaska, July 23 (UPI)Rangers at Mount McKinley National Park said today that the bodies of three Japanese women mountain climbers have been found at the 15,000foot level of the 20,320foot mountain. The climbers had been missing since June 29.

title: Quake Off British Columbia
description: BOULDER, Colo., July 23 (AP)An earthquake registering 6.4 on the Richter scale occurred in the Vancouver Island region of British Columbia off Canada's Pacific Coast today, the National Earthquake Information Center reported. The quake was about 350 miles northwest of Seattle. There were no immediate reports of damage, a spokesman for the center said.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: Life magazine urges President Nixon this week to drop Vice President Agnew as his running mate.

title: CONNORS SWEEPS BUCKEYE FINALS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 23, (UPI)  Jimmy Connors defeated Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia in the final of the $25,000 Buckeye tennis tournament today, 75, 63, 75. The 119yearold Illinois lefthander won $5,000 in prize money.

title: WAGNERIAN FUROR STIRS IN BAYREUTH
description: BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 12  An East German stage directors conception of Wagner's opera Tannhauser struck much of the firstnight audience at this year's Bayreuth festival last night as a Communist attack on Nazism. It aroused a furor in the usually reveren festival theater and angry attacks on the director at a public discussion today.

title: Jersey Suburbs Are 35% Foreign
description: More than onethird of the 4.6 million people living in the eight metropolitan area counties of New Jersey close to New York City are of foreign stock, according to a newly released study by the United States Census Bureau.

title: Tully Hall Rocks as 2 Choirs Open the Festival
description: Soul at the Center got off to a rocking start yesterday afternoon with a gospel service that had members of the audience at Alice Tully Hall hugging one another and capering in the aisles.

title: Riverhead's 1931 Traffic Circle Stumps Experts and Motorists
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 23Replacing the flagpole with a traffic signal is not going to solve the kind of problem we have there, Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein said last week.

title: U.S.StateVender Pact Saves FreeLunch Program in City
description: A dispute that had threatened to shut down a summer freelunch program for 500,000 city children was resolved by Federal and state officials yesterday on terms acceptable to a group of food companies that had said they would discontinue their services.

title: Israeli Cabinet Discusses Sadat Move on Russians
description: JERUSALEM, July 23 The Israeli Cabinet discussed in detail today President Anwar elSadat's moves to reduce the Soviet military presence in Egypt. No decisions were reached, nor were there any Israeli responses.

title: Mrs. Smoke Leads Group
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 23 (UPI)Mrs. Marcia Smoke of Niles; Mich, unbeaten national kayak singles racing champion the last 10 years, led a group of paddlers named to the United States Olympic training camp today.

title: Drug for Alcoholics Is Found Promising
description: A drug commonly used to control irregular heartbeats has shown initial promise in blocking the psychological and behavioral effects of drinking alcohol, a leading researcher in, alcoholism has found.

title: Even Bobby Fischer Would Have His Hands Full
description: The Bronx's St. James Park, Jerome Avenue at 192d Street entrance. Men bent intently over chessboards. Men of all ages, but most closer to life's twilight than its dawn. In battle with one another, the chessboard their battlefield.

title: 40 ADDICTS PROTEST CHARLEST ON BLUE
description: About 40 young heroin addicts now undergoing rehabilitation picketed the DeMille Theater, Seventh Avenue and 47th Street, yesterday in protest against what they felt was the light treatment of addiction in the film Come Back Charleston Blue, in its premiere engagement at the DeMille.

title: EGYPTIAN ASSERTS MOSCOW CAUTION CAUSED OUSTERS
description: CAIRO, July 24President Anwar elSadat today blamedthe Soviet Union's excessive caution as an ally for his decision to demand the departure of Soviet military personnel.

title: Late on Housing
description: Desperately late, the House Banking and Currency Committee is at last getting down to business on the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1972, one the most comprehensive and important pieces of housing legislation of the past three decades. Members of the committee started reading and marking up this bulky bill, line by line, only yesterday.

title: Adopted Children Who Wonder, What Was Mother Like?
description: Three years ago, Florence Ladden Fisher was in an automobile accident. Her last thought before the crash, I'm going to die and I don't know who am.

title: Swede Tells of Bombing
description: STOCKHOLM, July 24 (UPI)  A Swedish journalist said today that he saw United States planes bomb civilian targets in North Vietnam Saturday.

title: Jackson Finds Laird Testimony On Arms Accords Reassuring
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, today softened his criticism of the accords on strategic arms as the result of assurances he received from Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

title: JOHNSON IS BACK IN TEXAS HOSPITAL
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 24 (AP)Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who suffered a second heart attack in April, was hospitalized here tonight after suffering chest pains and nause.

title: Patent Suit Settled
description: WEST POINT, Ga., July24 (AP) Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., has settled a suit brought by West Point Pepperell for patent infringement. Fieldcrest has agreed to pay royalties on the production of fabric used in flocking operation as well as the method application of the flocking on a laminate of polyurethane foam.

title: Negro General Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Army nominated Brig. Gen. James F. Hamlet today for major general. He would become the second Negro in Army history to achieve twostar rank.

title: State Inquiry Hears Testimony On Correction Officer's Arrest
description: The State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime presented evidence yesterday that the politically wellconnected father of a correction officer arrested on a major drug charge went to see the assistant Brooklyn district attorney handling the case.

title: Nixon Is Told of Progress on Narcotics
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)President Nixon received a progress report today on the Government's crackdown on narcotics violation but told officials heading the drive that he wanted the number of arrests for drug violations doubled in the next year.

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP)The trial of Martin M. Decker, an industrialist charged with using the telephone to defraud the defunct City Bank of Philadelphia, was postponed today until Aug. 1 by United States District Judge James H. Gorbey.

title: Antitrust Officials Of E.E.C. Accuse 22 Sugar Refiners
description: PARIS, July 24The European Economic Community accused 22 sugarrefining companies today of flouting the interest of the consumer by restraining competition and keeping prices artificially high.

title: Westchester Golfers Triumph
description: GLEN COVE, N. Y., July 24Westchester retained the Stoddard Cup by turning back Long Island and New Jersey today in the annual Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional matches at Nassau Country Club. The defending champion collected 25 points to 24 for Long Island and 22 for New Jersey.

title: $230,000 IS PAID FOR SON OF RIBOT
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 24 (AP)The Cromwell Bloodstock Agency, bidding for an unnamed buyer, paid $230,000 tonight for a bay son of Ribot at the Keeneland summer sale of thoroughbred yearlings.

title: Lehigh Valley's Trustees File Plan for Rail Merger
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) A plan to merge three financially pressed railroad lines was made public today by trustees of the Lehigh Valley Railroad in a general plan for reorganization filed at the Federal District Court here.

title: Spassky's Hold on World Chess Title Seems Slipping at the Quarter Mark
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 24 At the quartermark of the world championship chess match, Bobby Fischer seems to be well on his way to taking the title away from the Soviet Union, which has held it since Mikhail Botvinnik won the crown in 1948.

title: FOREIGNAID BILL KILLED IN SENATE AFTER PASSAGE OF ENDWAR AMENDMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Senate, in a series of seesaw actions, adopted today an amendment requiring the withdrawal of American troops from Viettiam in exchange for release of prisoners of war, but then reversed itself by killing the overall bill.

title: DAVID KEANE JR., 56, OF TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: David C. Keane Jr., chief administrator of the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority, a subsidiary of the City Transit Authority, died of a heart attack Sunday, at his home, 144 Beach 142d Street, Neponsit, Queens. His age was 56.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 24 (UPI)Kahali owned by Frank W. Zurn of Erie, Pa., was declared the winner in section I, division I of the ChicagoMackinac yacht race today, finishing with an elapsed time of 35.8571 hours. Sassy, owned by E. Russell Schmidt of Grosse Pointe, which had crossed the finish line first, was ruled second on a corrected time of 36.1604.

title: Better Days at Standing Rock
description: WASHINGTONAfter each one of Buffalo Bill's Wild West shows, Sitting Bull would give the money he had made to the ragged troupe of hungry children who always followed him. The famous Sioux chief never understood the white man's savage neglect of his own poor. The human indignity of begging was incomprehensible to him. In fact, he once told Annie Oakley during a road show tour, The white man knows how to make everything, but he does not know how to distribute it.

title: Hendrick L. Busch Dead; Maritime Arbitrator, 62
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 24Hendrick Ludwig Busch of Adams Lane, vice president of the Society of Maritime Arbitrators, died yesterday in Kent Memorial Hospital, Warwick, R.I., of injuries received July 10 in an automobile accident. He was 62 years old.

title: NASA Scientist Honored
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded Dr. George R. Carruthers the NASA Exceptional Scientific Achievement medal today for his leadership in development of man's first moonbased space observatory.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DETROIT, July 24 (UPI)Eighty per cent of the pro football fans who answered questions in a survey by the weekly Football News favor changing the rules and allowing the optional 2point conversion. The 2point conversion exists in college ball and was considered a recent meeting of the National Football League owners, but did not gain the 20 votes required for passage.

title: M'GOVERN IS FIRM ON BOMBING HALT
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 24 Senator George McGovern said today that as President he would not resume the bombing of North Vietnam even if there were difficulties in obtaining the release of prisoners of war after all United States forces had been withdrawn from Indochina.

title: PAULINE WILLIAMSON
description: Pauline Brooks Williamson, cofounder of the American Association for Gifted Children and chief of the school health bureau of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company from 1925 to 1947, died Saturday at her home, 15 Gramercy Park. She was 85 years old.

title: Tamquan Reported Taken
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, July 25Tamquan, a district capital in South Vietnam's central coast province of Binhdinh, has been recaptured by Saigon troops after two months of Communist occupation, an army spokesman reported yesterday.

title: U.S. KILLINGS LAID TO UGANDAN TROOPS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 24 (Reuters)Two Americans who disappeared in southwest Uganda a year ago were slain by Ugandan troops, according to the report of a judicial inquiry published today.

title: 3 BIG ITALIAN UNIONS TAKE STEP ON UNITY
description: ROME, July 24The three major Italian trade unions today ratified a laborfederation pact that many Italians hope is a step toward unification of the labor movement here.

title: Earnings Climb 18%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the three months ended June 30 were the highest for any quarter in its history. The report also showed that profits in the first half exceeded $100million and sales surpassed $1billion, both for the first time.

title: Treasury Bills Yields Climb at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Richard Nixon's Agnew move, a sort of king's pawn opening to his campaign, apparently gives the President a needed opportunity to bring king's rookJohn Connallyinto play as well. If he develops that line of attack properly, Mr. Nixon himself may have little more to do this autumn than call Bobby Fischer in the locker room at the moment Spassky falls.

title: U.S. Sweeps Chile, 5.0
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 (UPI)The United States won the two remaining singles matches against Chile today for a 5.0 sweep of the American zone Davis Cup final.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, July 24  Two California experts led the field of 168 pairs into the second semifinal session of the life master pairs championship in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here tonight. Thanks to a magnificent 433 session score, John Fox of Los Angeles and Carl Cronemiller of San Jose, Calif., totaled 464 match points.

title: JAMES F. FALLON
description: UNION CITY, N.J., July 24 (AP)James F. Fallon, a retired newspaperman and instructor of journalism, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND COUNTER UP
description: Dawdling stock prices ended yesterday on the American Stock Exchange with the index up 0.16 to 26.94. It was the sharpest rise since May 12, when the index also made 0.16point gain.

title: Life Revises Editorial On Dropping of Agnew
description: Life magazine, which published in its current issue an editorial urging President Nixon to drop VicePresident Agnew as his running mate in November, has revised its comments in the light of the President's announcement Saturday that he would retain Mr. Agnew.

title: N. & W. Reports Loss
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company reported yesterday a loss of $22,406,000 for the second quarter of 1972, including special charges totaling $44,266,000 to provide for a decline in the company's investments in Dereco, Inc., subsidiary that includes the Erie Lackawanna Railway. The Erie Lackawanna entered bankruptcy proceedings on June 26.

title: Calls to C.O.P. Unit Linked To Raid on the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, July 24At least 15 calls to President Nixon's campaign organization were placed from telephones in the home and office of a man said to have led the breakin at the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISES
description: Rains in the plains states and talk of better export business combined to propel wheat prices upward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1967 and 1969, the magazine Outdoor Life ran five true stories that were excerpted from manuscripts sent to the editor by a woman in her middle 60's named Olive Fredrickson, The manuscripts described, in phonetic spelling, her life in the northern part of western Canada during the first six decades of this century, and the stories evoked such an astonishing response from readers in every part of the United States and Canada that Ben East, the magazine's senior field editor, decided to shape Mrs. Fredrickson's manuscripts into a book, The Silence of the North.

title: SAMUEL ROSENBERG
description: PITTSBURGH, July 24 Samuel Rosenberg, an artist and professor at Carnegie Mellon University, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital. He would have been 76 years old Friday.

title: Jane Fonda Accuses Nixon
description: PARIS, July 24 (AP)Jane Fonda, who arrived here yesterday from a trip to Hanoi, said that President Nixon was a traitor. The American actress declared that a traitor was not someone who opposed the Vietnam war but rather someone who is committing the most heinous crimes I think have ever been committed.

title: Advertising:
description: The cause of volunteer work for community projects is going to receive tremendous support during the coming professional football season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: House Narrowly Votes Payment For Losses in Cyclamate Ban
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The House of Representatives narrowly approved today a bill to authorize Federal compensation to food growers, manufacturers, packers and distributors who claim to have lost money as a result of the Government's 1969 ban on the use of cyclamates as an artificial sweetner.

title: Excerpts From President Sadat's Speech in Cairo Criticizing Policies of the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. July 24Following are excerpts, in unofficial translation from the Arabic, from a speech in Cairo today by the Egyptian President, Anwar elSadat, as monitored here by the Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am a naturalized American citizen, a professional man of moderate means, a liberal and a registered Democrat with a perfect record of party loyalty. I respect Senator McGoverns intelligence, his honesty and his ambition.

title: Israel Intensifying Settlement of Seized Territories
description: JERUSALEM, July 24The Government of Israel is quietly intensifying the establishment of new settlements in the lands captured from the Arab countries in the 1967 war.

title: Personalities: Wilt Seeks Raise
description: Wilt Chamberlain thinks he is underpaid. The 7foot1inch center, who was a vital cog for the Los Angeles Lakers as they won their first National Basketball Association championship last season, has made it known through Seymour Goldberg, his lawyer, that the reported $200,000 a year he is receiving from a contract, which has two more years to run, Is not enough. Wilt deserves a raise because of his great year, said Goldberg in Los Angeles. He hasn't had a raise since he joined the Lakers in 1968 and we certainly think he's entitled to one. His popularity has never been greater. Wilt would rather play basketball, but he doesn't have to do it for a living, especially if he's in an unhappy atmosphere. Goldberg said that Chamberlain, who will be 36 years old on Aug. 21, was prepared to try business enterprises, movies or television if he could not get satisfaction from the Lakers. The lawyer also said that the Lakers signing of Jerry West to a twoyear pact for a reported $500,000 last week had nothing to do with Wilt's bid for more money. It has been the policy of the Lakers not to renegotiate contracts, was the only comment by Pete Newell, the Los Angeles general manager.

title: Dikes Hit, Waldheim Says; Rogers Quickly Denies It
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24  Secretary General Waldheim and Secretary of State William P. Rogers clashed today over charges that the United States bombing had intentionally damaged dikes in North Vietnam.

title: Gibson and Palmer to Start AllStar Game
description: ATLANTA, July 24Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals and Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles were named the starting pitchers today for baseball's 43d AllStar Game, which will be played in the home of the Atlanta Braves here tomorrow night before a sellout crowd of 52,744 fans and a national television audience.

title: Ulster's Bloody Friday
description: Earlier this month, British Minister William Whitelaw risked violent reaction from militant Ulster Protestants and abuse from his own Conservative party by meeting secretly with leaders of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals. In discarding his previous pledge never to negotiate with gunmen, Mr. Whitelaw thus indicated that the Provos could help shape Northern Ireland's future if only they would halt the terrorism.

title: Yacht in Tow in Atlantic
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 24 (Reuters)A Coast Guard cutter took in tow today a catamaran in the transAtlantic solo yacht race after the skipper, Murray Sayle, an Australian, reported the yacht had been dismasted. The yacht was picked up 800 miles southeast of Halifax, N. S., on her way from Plymouth, England, to Newport.

title: KNAPP WITNESS HERE ENTERS GUILTY PLEA
description: A suspended patrolman pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to commit perjury at the time he was a witness at a closeddoor session of the Knapp Commission investigation into allegations of corruption in the Police Department.

title: CHRYSLER PROFIT DOUBLES TO $1,33
description: DETROIT, July 24  The Chrysler Corporation today reported that its Junequarter profit had more than doubled to $68.4million, or $1.33 a share, from $31.4million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Three States Ask High Court Review Of Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The Supreme Court was asked by three states today to reconsider its historic decision of last month that sentences of death as now Imposed under some state laws violate the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.

title: IRT Car Derails in Bronx
description: The, rear wheels of the second car of an eightcar southbound Pelham Bay local of the IRT derailed as it pulled into the Hunts Point station at Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx yesterday at 4:13 P.M. There were no reports of injuries. Local trains were rerouted to the express tracks while emergency crews removed the disabled train.

title: CHINESE WILL BUY TWO CONCORDES
description: PARIS, July 24  Chinese representatives have signed a preliminary purchase agreement to buy two Concorde supersonic aircraft, it was announced today.

title: 1.3 Million Vietnam Veterans Reported Aided in Job Hunt
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, said today that the Administration had found jobs or job training for at least 1.3 million Vietnamera veterans during the 12 months ending June 30.

title: America the Good
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  In his speaking tour on behalf of the League of Nations in the fall of 1919, Woodrow Wilson told an audience: Sometimes people call me an idealist. Well, that is the way I know I am an American. America is the only idealistic nation in the world.

title: Soul Festival:
description: Dance came into its own at Soul at the Center last night at Alice Tully Hall with Diana Ramos and George Faison, black choreographers who have something to say and who say it very well.

title: City's Loss of Subway Riders In 1971 Is Set at 61 Million
description: The city's subways lost 61 million riders in 1971 while auto traffic in the city's core was on the increase, according to a regional planning report released yesterday.

title: June Record Is Registered For DurableGoods Orders
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 New orders for durable goods soared in June to a record of $34.99billion, the Commerce Department reported today. A surge of defense orders was partly responsible for the advance.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STOCKHOLM, July 24 (AP)Team Canada, the players from the National Hockey League who will meet the Soviet Union in a homeandhome eightgame exhibition series next month, also will play two games in Stockholm, officials said today. The squad will train here for its games against the Soviet Union in late September and will play a Swedish national team Sept. 16 and 17.

title: WILLIAM ABRAMOWITZ
description: BOSTON, July 24William Lewis Abramowitz, a plastics company executive who was vice president of the chemical division of the Borden Company in New York from 1955 to 1957, died yesterday at the age of 57.

title: William Edward, $9.40, Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) William S. Farish's William Edward, a stablemate of the Preakness winner, Bee Bee Bee, won the $9,500 mileand70yards feature race today at Liberty Bell race track.

title: Health Department Cites Food Outlets For Violating Code.
description: The Health Department has (cited 21 more restaurants and foodprecessing establishments for serious violations of the city Health Code.

title: Wall Street Panel Fights S.E.C. Proposal
description: A highlevel Wall Street operations committee has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that a proposed rule for the safekeeping and control of customer securities would be so onerous that it might jeopardize the public interest.

title: JERSEY STANDARD LISTS DROP IN NET
description: The net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) fell in the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: Stock Prices Soar In Year's Best Gain
description: Stock prices soared yesterday in their best showing of 1972 in response to the latest Government reports of a rapidly expanding economy.

title: Stones Performance Is Lacking in Muscle
description: Opening nights in New York, whether for the Rolling Stones or the Broadway theater, are fraught with the pains of nervous anxiety. When the Stones made it to the stage at Madison Square Garden last night for the closing concerts in their twomonth American tour, there was at least the suspicion that the stomach butterflies were fluttering.

title: DeJesus to Oppose Wilburn In Garden Bout on Friday
description: Two hardhitting lightweights, Esteban DeJesus of Puerto Rico, and Chuck Wilburn of Cleveland, will meet in the featured 10round fight at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

title: Jolly Fox Triumphs
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 24 (AP)B. J. Brown's Jolly Fox took the lead on the backstretch and triumphed by 61/2 lengths today in the $8,500 Ocean Township Purse at Monmouth Park.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert J. A. Irwin Jr. has been elected a director and, effective Aug. 1, senior vice president of Niagara Share Corporation. Mr. Irwin was formerly executive vice president of DreyfusMarine Midland, Inc.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rikers Inmate Died of Overdose A drug overdose administered in the prison killed an inmate found dead on Rikers Island on Saturday, the Chief Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday. Aides to Dr. Milton Helpern, the Medical Examiner, said that the prisoner, 29yearold John Smith, was the second inmate in city jails to die of an illegal drug dosage this year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 24 Vice President Agnew outlined today the Republican campaign position on the environment as choosing progress as a nation instead of an end to growth and an end to technological progress.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Broadbased but nonscientific polls taken in preparation for drafting the Republican national platform in Miami Beach next month indicate that crime, drugs, inflation, welfare and Federal spending are among the most urgent issues facing Americans.

title: Aerospace Experts And Urban Leaders Resuming Dialogue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24More than 1,000 aerospace technologists and urban leaders convened here today to resume a dialogue that so far has produced more promises than mutual assistance.

title: News Analysis
description: Two main philosophies about corruption have emerged in the last three weeks as city officials and construction industry executives have sat down together to grope for antidotes to the poisonous graft that pervades the building business in New York.

title: 500 Safety Violations
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., July 24 (AP)The Consolidated Coal Company's Blacksville No. 1 mine amassed nearly 500 citations for Federal safety violations in its four years of operation, statistics of the Bureau of Mines show.

title: E. EARL HAWKES, UTAH PUBLISHER
description: SEATTLE, July 24 (UPI)Elden Earl Hawkes, a former executive with the Hearst newspapers and publisher of The Deseret News of Salt Lake City since 1964, died today after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: McGregorDoniger Elects
description: The board of directors of McGregorDoniger, Inc., has elected Richard H. Goldman as chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds William N. Doniger, who died June 3. Mr. Goldman has been president of the company since Jan. 1, 1970, and will continue in that post.

title: Olin Unit Is Raising Prices Of LightGauge Cellophane
description: The film division of the Olin Corporation said yesterday that is would increase prices for most domestic lightgauge cellophane by an average of 2 per cent. Prices in the company's larger line of heavygauge polymercoated films will remain unchanged.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart Festival Opens
description: Whether the astonishing work in E flat (K.271) is the greatest of the early Mozart piano concertos or the earliest of the great Mozart piano concertos is the kind of hairsplitting we may safely leave to the virtuosos of lobby discussion. But its indubitable greatness and earlyness certainly qualified the piece for inclusion on the opening program of the Mostly Mozart Festival last night at Philharmonic Hall.

title: Young Silversmiths Show Their Wares
description: A rather unlikely subject, silversmithing, is attracting more students every year in art schools and universities across the countrythree institutions in New York State give Masters of Fine Arts degrees in itbut the question in an outsider's mind is likely to be: Why are so many young persons interested in majoring in it? And, after taking it, what can they do with it?

title: Advertising:
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has found reasonable cause to believe that McCannErickson violated the law by maintaining a discriminatory hiring policy for minority groups.

title: MURPHY ASSAILED BY P.B.A. LEADERS
description: The retiring president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and his successor both accused Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday, of lowering department morale and urged Mayor Lindsay to replace him.

title: CITY IS ACCUSED IN HEART DEATHS
description: Coney Island Hospital officials charged yesterday that heart patients were dying needlessly because the hospital had not been permitted to hire nurses to staff a newly completed addition to the coronary care unit.

title: Sharp Premium Cuts Are Urged In Assigned Risk Plans in State
description: Extraordinary growth and lower loss ratios justify sharp premium cuts for the more than 700,000 New York motorists required to buy automobile liability coverage through the assigned risk plan, a State Insurance Department actuary testified yesterday.

title: Cleanup Is Begun on Oil Spill Off Maine
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., July 24Workmen and residents of islands in Casco Bay are cleaning up island beaches and Portland Harbor of an estimated total of 40,000 gallons of industrial fuel oil that has spilled into the ocean from an oil tanker.

title: Cards Sign Simmons
description: ATLANTA, July 24 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals signed Ted Simmons to a twoyear contract today reportedly worth $35,000 per season.

title: Baseball Players Agree With Owners on Talks
description: ATLANTA, July 24  Player representatives of the 24 majorleague baseball teams took a novel but not necessarily promising step todaythey agreed with their owners on something.

title: MORE WATER NOW
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ BUSINESS MAGAZINE ADVT.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent publicity about Amtrak led me to reserve tickets from Rye to Baltimore in my first break from air travel in many years. A preliminary trip to the Rye station and police department revealed that there is no provision for other than daytime commuter parking.

title: MORE BLACKOUTS IN TWO BOROUGHS; 400,000 AFFECTED
description: A succession of cable failures at a Consolidated Edison substation cut off power yesterday to more than 400,000 people in Brooklyn and Queens and left them without airconditioning or food refrigeration and, in some cases, without water.

title: Hot Search for Cool Slumber Empties Homes
description: The lingering oppressive heat has driven people all over the city out of their homes to spend nights in search of breezes and sleep in parks, on beaches, fire escapes and stoops.

title: U.S. Says Report of Talk With Arab Is Speculative
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The White Ilouse today discounted as clearly speculative and without substance a published report from Lebanon crediting a meeting between President Nixon and the Saudi Arabian Defense Minister last month with having had a significant bearing on President Anwar elSadat's ouster of Soviet military advisers from Egypt.

title: GEORGIAPACIFIC IN A TRUST PACT
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission that would create a new corporate organization in settlement of an antitrust action by the F.T.C.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With the advent of New York's first protracted hightemperature period of 1972 and its concommitant strain on power resources, it was hardly surprising that the occasion coincided with your frontpage account of a State Public Service Commission announcement. An investigation far beyond anything we've ever done is to be undertaken into the production and use of electricity, according to spokesman for that body.

title: SCHENECTADY OTB GETS STEADY PLAY
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 24With about 300 patrons and a host of political figures on hand, the first offtrack betting office outside New York City opened today.

title: Integrated City Rising on an Old Plantation
description: MANSON, N. C., July 24On a green hill near this tiny town, an ancient antebellum mansion sits as both a monument to the past and a sign of the times.

title: Wood Field and. Stream: Catfish King
description: LAC DESERT, QuebecA fierce competitiveness lurks inside the restaurateur, Peter Kriendler, of New York City's 21 Club.

title: White Plains Fire Snarls Penn Central Rush Hour
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 24A flash fire destroyed the Penn Centrai.'s new highlevel station platforms here this afternoon, disrupting service through the evening rush hour.

title: There's Racing at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, July 24  As Yonkers Raceway reopened tonight for its secondhalf, 72card season, the start of the first event was three minutes late. No one seemed to mind, because for more than eight hours picketing security guards had threatened to cancel the first program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This letter is in response to the recent editorials and letters regarding the recent flood disaster in the eastern United States. The germane point of all of these articles has been the suggestion to move the river valley communities to higher land in the mountains.

title: WHERE NTEDED
description: Cloud Seeding WEATHER ENGINEERINC CORPORATION OF CANADA LIMITEDAdvt.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 24 Mayor Lindsay of New York said tonight that he would serve as an adviser on urban affairs to the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, if the Senator wants me.

title: WHITELAW MOVES TO ISOLATE I.R.A.
description: LONDON, July 24William Whitelaw, Northern Ireland's administrator, today urged supporters of the Irish Republican Army in the United States and other nations to reject the organization.

title: Nixon's Economic Aide Warns Against Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTO July 24 President Nixon's chief economic adviser told Congress today that it was a delusion to believe that the steep rise in Government spending could be covered by increasing taxes on a few people who are presumably not paying their fair share.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Market Place:
description: It is a matter of growing concern in the mutual fund industry that, every month for the last several months and from time to time before that, more mutual fund shares are turned in than are purchased. But, as in all rundowns of industry results, the general figure masks considerable variations within.

title: Sesame Street Creators Plan New Series on Health
description: The creators of Sesame Street announced yesterday that they were planning to develop a series on health.

title: Screen: Parades Set in a Stockade
description: Of course it is unfair to judge a movie by its ad campaign. But the remarkable collection of testimonials that has been printed for Robert Siegel's Parades prompts me to point out that here is a film that devastated, people like Leo Lerman, Pat Paterson and Shirley MacLeine, and that knocked out Jack Newfield, Lloyd Price and also Daphne Davis of Women's Wear Daily.

title: Howard Johnson Will Filed
description: BOSTON, July 24 (UPI)Howard D. Johnson, who built an ice cream parlor into a nationwide chain of restaurants, left $1.65million to his family, according to his will filed today in Suffolk Probate Court.

title: Planes Will Try Again To Seed Hurricanes
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)The Government said today that it would try again to seed hurricanes this year in an effort to establish whether their destructive: force can be diminished.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Two supporters of Senator George McGovern are preparing to offer personal assurances to the Israeli Government that the Democratic Presidential nominee would be a stanch ally in the White House.

title: Prime Rate Raised to 5% By Franklin National Bank
description: The Franklin National Bank, the 20th largest bank in the country, has increased its prime lending rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent. Franktints action, which was not announced, was effective July 17.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON RELIEF DISPARITY
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein urged the City Council yesterday to investigate what he alleged to be a wide disparity in the rate of welfare applicants placed on the rolls in the city's 43 welfare centers.

title: Iced Items Go Down Drain As Freezers Fail
description: It's a wipeout, Mrs. Giselle Szanto said yesterday as she looked around at the empty freezers in her Carvel store at Queens Boulevard and 82d Street.

title: LAYER, PILIC ROUT FIRSTROUND FOES
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 24 (UPI)Rod Laver, miffed over not being seeded, quickly defeated Tom Leonard 60, 63 today in the opening round of the $50,000 First National Tennis Classic.

title: Jagger and Stones Whip 20,000 Into Frenzy at Garden
description: The Rolling Stones, considered by many the most exciting rock n roll band in the world, whipped 20,000 fans into a frenzy last night at the first of four soldout concerts in Madison Square Garden.

title: Israelis Say Egyptians Fired 2 Missiles at Jets Over Sinai
description: JERUSALEM, July 24Four surfacetoair missiles were fired at Israeli Air Force planes flying over the Sinai Peninsula today from a battery on the Egyptianheld western bank of the Suez Canal, the Israeli military spokesman announced. The last such attack occurred in September, 1971.

title: Vesco Says I.C.C. Made $5.3Million On I.O.S. Holding
description: The International Controls Corporation, whose major claim to fame has been its stake in I.O.S., Ltd. since soldtold shareholders here yesterday that it had done well on its 18month I.O.S. investment. But few shareholders seemed in the mood to hear it.

title: Business Briefs
description: HARTFORD, July 24 (AP)The United Aircraft Corporation has filed a $136million counterclaim against the Boeing Company in response to a $94million Boeing claim first disclosed in 1971. The claims revolve around an early version of the JT90 engine developed and produced by United Aircraft's Pratt & Whitney division for the Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Periodically an article appears in some publication similar to the editorial Watch Your Language in the July 10 Times deploring the deterioration of English as a means of communication. Actually, such locutions as far out, where I'm at and so on are additions, making expression sharper. Can anyone think of synonyms for such expressions?

title: S.E.C. Charges Coast Writer Profited From Touting of Stock
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud suit today against a financial columnist for The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer, charging him with buying stock, then touting it in his column and finally selling it after the price went up.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Briefings. The White House announced that a tentative appointment had been set up for Senator George McGovem, the Democratic Presidential nominee, to receive an intelligence briefing from Henry A. Kissinger, the President's security affairs adviser. Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, will also be given a briefing when he chooses.

title: Egyptian Belligerence
description: President Sadat and Egyptian missile crews have already undermined hope that last week's announcement of the expulsion of Soviet advisers from Egypt might mark a turn toward rationality and peace in the Middle East.

title: Grace M. Showalter Dies; A Philanthropist in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 24 (AP) Grace M. Showalter, philanthropist and honorary director of the Indiana University Faundation, died yesterday.

title: Kubelik Steps Up Commitment to Met
description: Rafael Kubelik, the Czechoslovakborn conductor, agreed yesterday to strengthen his immediate involvement with the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera, which was to have been the first under the direction of the late Goeran Gentele.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 24 (UPI)Roman Gabriel, the quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, was back on the practice field today, just one week after having suffered a collapsed lung. The 31yearold star did some running and throwing as Coach Tommy Prothro watched intently from the sidelines.

title: The Paris Showings: Off and Running
description: PARIS, July 24 Finally, evening dresses to make you want to go out at night. They're Marc Bohan's designs for Christian Dior and they helped get the couture showings here off to a good start.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker was sidelined today on the final day of the Hollywood Park summer racing meeting because of a back strain. The jockey hopes to return to competition Wednesday the opening of a 42day season at Del Mar.

title: Soul Festival:
description: Bobby Womack, The Soul Communicator, has a hoarse but penetrating voice and an explosive, declamatory style of delivery that ought to cut through steel walls. Steel walls, maybe. But he was engulfed in echoing rumble when he tried to push his voice through a foggy amplifying system last night at Alice Tully Hall, where he shared a Soul at the Center program with the George Faison Universal Dance Experience and Diana Ramos.

title: Namath Won't Play Without Contract
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24 After asking for, and getting, a oneweek delay in reporting to training camp, Joe Namath showed up eight hours before the 11 P.M. deadline yesterday. But the New York Jet's quarterback is still not completely in the fold.

title: Credit Markets
description: Prices of taxexempt bonds edged higher in moderately active trading yesterday, but longterm interest rates in the corporate and Treasury sectors showed practically no change at all.

title: Sheehan Gets Contract With Raiders of W.H.A.
description: The New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association yesterday signed Bobby Sheehan, a 22yearold center from Weymouth, Mass., to a multiyear contract, bringing to 24 the number of players under contract to the Raiders.

title: Concordes for China
description: Chinese representatives have signed a preliminary purchase agreement to buy two Concorde supersonic airliners. The price of the BritishFrench planes and an initial supply of spare parts was estimated at $50million apiece at 1977 delivery prices. Details on Page 41.

title: Old New England Lives Again as Town Gives Annual Play
description: SWANZEY, N.H., July 24People in Swanzey say that the Lord watches over The Old Homestead. On nights when the drama of rural Yankee life in the late 19th century is revived in the outdoor Potash Bowl here well, it just hardly ever rains.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP)Dismissing as a prank the reported attempt to bribe one of his players, the Cincinnati Reds manager, Sparky Anderson, said today: This whole thing shows there's nothing cleaner than baseball.

title: Bhutan Crown Prince Is Enthroned as King
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 24 (AP)  The sacred scarves that symbolize the throne of Bhutan passed today to a teenager who was brought to his Himalayan homeland in the late nineteensixties to learn how to be king.

title: No Deal
description: In February 1970, after months of deliberation on various alternatives, President Nixon submitted a special message to Congress setting forth his recommendations for new legislation to deal with strikes in the transportation industry.

title: A RISE IN DRUG USE ALARMS YUGOSLAVS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24 (Reuters)  The rising number of drug addicts in Yugoslavia is causing increasing concern among the police and health authorities of this socialist state.

title: Sgt. Durk, Out for Pizza, Shoots A Mugger and Seizes Another
description: Sgt. David Durk, a key witness in the Knapp Commission investigation of corruption in the Police Department, foiled and captured two alleged muggers on a street on Manhattan's West Side last night with the aid of his service revolver and a pizza.

title: PROFIT REPORTS FACE NEW CHECK
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The Price Commission, citing what it called inconsistent and unorthodox profitmargin reporting by big corporations, has tightened the reporting rules to require companion statements by a certified public accountant.

title: 6 Big Companies in japan Guilty of Air Pollution
description: TOKYO, July 24  A district court in central Japan found six large industrial companies guilty of air pollution today and ordered them to pay $286,350 in daniages to 12 plaintiffs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again the New York area commuters are victims of the old railroad game. Despite U.S. Government 5.5 per cent guidelines, we have 01, pay a 23 per cent increase in commuting fares. Along with that change in fares this month, we have been greeted with a new schedule. Although the operas tors of the trains would have us believe that the schedule changes are mere shuffling of trains, it turns out that fewer trains are running and the elimination of the express trains makes commuting and daily railroad travel less convenient than ever.

title: REV. DR. JOHN MOSES SR.
description: The Rev. Dr. John W. Moses Sr., presiding elder of the BrooklynWestchester district of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, died Sunday in the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived at 425 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Buddy Bradley, Director And Choreographer, Dead
description: Buddy Bradley, play and dance director and choreographer, who popularized black tap and jazz dancing in the American and English theater, died July 17 in Beth Israel Hospital.

title: MRS. BERNARD ERNST
description: Mrs. Roberta Christine Claus Ernst, widow of Bernard M. L. Ernst, lawyer and amateur magician who succeeded his friend Harry Houdini as president of the Society of American Magicians, died yesterday at her home, 1192 Park Avenue. She was a founding member of the United Parents Association.

title: Dolphin Slaughter
description: The Senate is expected to begin consideration today a marine mammal protection bill which falls far short what is required if dolphins and other ocean mammals are to receive the timely help they urgently need. As reported from the Senate Commerce Committee, the bill is weaker than the already unsatisfactory bill passed by the House.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: From Dave Brinkley to the nextdoor neighbor, people are saying that Nixon will be hard to beat. It seems to me that only a miracle could cause his reelection.

title: Man in the News
description: Robert Martin McKiernan signaled his ascension yesterday to the presidency of the 25,000member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association with a virulent denunciation of Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On a Vietnam Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)The following is the 50to45 rollcall vote by which the Senate tonight adopted an amendment providing for the withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina within four months if American war prisoners are released:

title: Two More Subversion Trials Begin in Czechoslovakia
description: PRAGUE, July 24 (Reuters) Two more subversion trials opened in Czechoslovakia today, one of them carrying the possibility of 10year prison terms for the defendants.

title: SHIFT IN STRATEGY BY PEKING IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Senior American analysts believe China is rapidly building an arsenal of tactical nuclear weapons and special aircraft designed to deter a major Soidet military thrust across the long border, or to throw lup a nuclear defense if deterrence should fail.

title: Notes on People
description: Friends of Mrs. Marit Gentele, whose husband, Goeran Gentele, director of the Metropolitan Opera, was killed in an automobile accident last week in Sardinia, said she was planning to return to New York by the opening of the new opera season in September.

title: SPAIN CAPTURES CUP TENNIS BY 32
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 24 (UPI)Juan Gisbert beat Frantisek Pala of Czechoslovakia, 63, 63, 46, 60, to clinch the European Zone B final of the Davis Cup today and advance Spain to the next round against the United States.

title: Princeton Alumnus, 100 Dies
description: HARTFORD, July 24John N. Dodd of Newtown, chief electrical engineer of the Port of New York Authority from 1922 to 1938, died here yesterday at the age of 100. Mr. Dodd, the oldest living graduate of Princeton, class of 93, held a master's degree in mathematics.

title: Net and Sales Rise By GENE SMITH
description: The Anaconda Company reported yesterday dramatic gains in secondquarter and firsthalf net income after inclusion of certain extraordinary items. However, John B. M. Place, president and chief executive officer, was quick to point out that all divisions were profitable in the first half and contributed to the earnings gains. Sales and revenue in both periods were higher than the yearago levels.

title: Soviet Poet Who Left for U.S. Appeals for the Right to Return Later
description: MOSCOW, July 24  Iosif Brodsky, the Russian poet who left for the United States last month, has appealed to Leonid, I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, for the right to return eventually to the Soviet Union.

title: Stones Boom 16,000 Watts of Sound
description: As if Con Edison did not have enough trouble with the heat wave, the utility is going to have to deliver a staggering amount of current this week to keep the Rolling Stones rolling.

title: An Akron Lawyer Pleads Guilty To 26 Counts in Security Sales
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 24 (UPI) D. Donald Lowers, a lawyer whose multimilliondollar investment scheme collapsed in bankruptcy leaving him $11million in debt, pleaded guilty today to 26 counts of selling unregistered securities.

title: COURT BIDS ARMY REINSTATE CADET
description: A demeritprone cadet has won a court order preventing his expulsion from the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: South Vietnamese Force Reported Attacking the Citadel of Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 25 (AP)  South Vietnamese paratroops tried to storm the Citadel of Quangtri city yesterday but ran into withering enemy fire, according to reports from the scene, and at nightfall the outcome of the battle was said to be still in doubt.

title: Commissioner John Grace, 70, Of the Salvation Army Is Dead
description: Lieut. Commissioner John Grace, who retired in 1970 after serving for nine years as National Chief Secretary of the Salvation Army, died Sunday in Philadelphia. He was 70 years old.

title: FRANK D. SULLIVAN
description: Frank D. Sullivan, who retired in 1968 as assistant vice president and manager of the Chemical Bank branch at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street, died on Sunday. He was 69 years old and lived at 37 Maple Avenue, HastingsonHudson, N.Y.

title: D.C. Appeals Judge Named
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) President Nixon named Gerald D. Reilly today as chief judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals for a fouryear term. Judge Reilly, 66 years old, a native of Boston, has been serving as an associated judge of the court since October, 1970.

title: Stock Prices Rocket In Biggest 1972 Gain
description: The stock market responded to highly favorable economic news yesterday by rocketing to its biggest gain of 1972.

title: Executive Is Moving to Gillette
description: Edward Gelsthorpe, president and chief executive officer of HuntWesson Foods, Inc., a subsidiary of Norton Simon, Inc., will leave his job to become vice chairmanmarketing for the Gillette Company on Sept. 1.

title: 31 IN JAIL REFUSE TO MOVE TO COURT
description: Charging that the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn had no concern for their human rights, 25 of 55 prisoners scheduled to appear in Supreme Court yesterday refused to leave their cells in the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: GEORGE B. CORWIN
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 24George Brownson Corwin of 16 Ludlow Manor, retired program service secretary of the National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association, died Saturday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: 'Marjoe,' Documentary About Evangelist, Arrives
description: "I'm in town to give the devil two black eyes!" the sweetfaced, curly-haired little boy announced in a voice that would shatter a beer stein at 100 paces. It's an old 16-mm. promotional clip for Marjoe Gortner at the age of 6.Marjoe (a contraction of Mary and Joseph), the son of professional evangelists, began preaching at 3, received "the infilling of the holy spirit" at 4, performed marriage ceremonies at 4, first retired from the pulpit at 14, and now, at 28, is retiring again, but with a difference.In "Marjoe," which opened yesterday at the Cinema II, he's spilling his beans. "I'm a hype, but I'm not a bad hype," says the adult Marjoe, who had been considering one way or another of getting out of the "Jesus business" until Howard Smith, The Village Voice columnist, and Sarah Kernochan came along and offered to make a movie about him."Marjoe," filmed last year on location in California, New York, Michigan and Texas, is less a documentary about Marjoe's final weeks on the pentecostal church-and-tent circuit than a feature-length screen test for Marjoe, who apparently hopes for a career in show biz, either as an actor or as a rock star like Mick Jagger, whose dress and mannerisms he so carefully imitates."Marjoe" belongs to that genre of new cinema journalism that has produced at least two fine films, Albert and David Maysles's "Salesman," and Robert Kaylor's "Derby," and a lot of others ("King Murray," "A Married Couple") that fail to elevate the unsolicited confession to the level of something approximating art. No matter how you slice it, it still comes out as self-exploitation of a sort that strikes me as being exceedingly sleazy.Mr. Smith and Miss Kernochan have made a film that stands somewhere between these two poles It's Americana, all right (and so is lynching), but it's often funny and moving in quite surprising ways.It's to the filmmakers' credit that scenes of fervid revival meetings, which follow Marjoe's rather cool explanations of how he operates to excite the crowds and milk them of funds, are less exploitative of the believersof all ages, types and colorsthan of Marjoe himself who, for all his performing dynamism, seems more truly desperate and lost. Imagine wanting to be a rock star!Marjoe talks at length about his career, about how his mother used to hold his head under a faucet if he forgot his lines, about his always being aware that he wasn't "a miracle child," about his lack of belief and wish to make a clean break."Movie or no movie," he says at one point, "I'd have to get out." He slips in and out of self-ridicule, laying his hands on the head of his dog and crying out: "Kill a commie for Jesus!" Yet he is never a particularly appealing hustler, not because he'swellsmall-time, but because we are aware that the movie is, after all, another hustle.We are also aware that none of the other evangelists who appear in the movie, including Marjoe's father (who, with amazement, describes his son as "a preaching machine") have the faintest idea what the movie they're appearing in is up to. They might have objected. At the height of one service, a middle-aged woman collapses in religious ecstasy. The hand of Jesus has been laid upon her and the cameras keep turning for the benefit of Marjoe's career.It's very difficult to separate a movie like this from its subjectperhaps impossible which is why my feelings about it must be as mixed as they are about Marjoe.Where does Marjoe go from here? According to one source, he lives in New York, has an agent, a manager and a lawyer, and hangs out at Max's Kansas City and Elaine's.

title: RIFT HERE CALLED PERIL TO M'GOVERN
description: The rift between Senator George McGovern and Democratic party leaders in this state is so serious that it is unlikely that the Presidential nominee will be able to win more than token support from many of the leaders.

title: Noroton Y. C. Sets Pace In Junior Sailing Series
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 The Noroton, Conn., Yacht Club crew, captained by John Hammel, held a 14point lead today after four races in the qualifying series of the 49th annual junior sailing championship on Long Island Sound off Belle Haven Club.

title: Heath and Unions Firm As British Strikes Spread
description: LONDON, July 24  Industrial chaos spread across Britain today as thousands of workers walked off their jobs in support of five imprisoned dockers.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI)The Peoples Gas, Light and Coke Company announced today that it would build $50million plant near here to convert petroleum liquids into substitute natural gas. The company, a unit of the Peoples Gas Company, said the plant would produce about 150 million cubic feet of gas a day from 1.39 million gallons of liquid hydrocarbons to be supplied by the American Oil Company and the Union Oil Company.

title: MICHAEL HOPKINS
description: Michael Hopkins, an employe of the editorial information service of The New York Times since 1939, died Saturday in the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Flood Victims Will Get 2,500 Homes From U.S.
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP)The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that it would provide 2,500 industrially built homes for Pennsylvania flood victims.

title: Increases Are Predicted for Jewelry Prices
description: Retail price rises are likely this fall and winter for gold, diamond and other finegem jewelry.

title: Power Failure Shuts Aqueduct
description: An electric power failure in Queens forced the cancellation of the thoroughbred racing card at Aqueduct yesterday, disappointing about 22,000 fans, the expected attendance for a hot Monday in July, plus thousands more who normally wager at the city's 82 offtrack betting shops.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee on Pacific Ocean territories11 A.M.

title: Protestants Vow Action
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 24The militant Protestant Ulster Defense Association today pledged itself to take action against strongholds of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Small Operators Entering The French Drug Scene
description: PARIS, July 24A dramatic spurt in French arrests of heroin manufacturers and dealers has produced a new picture of this side of the American drug trade. It doesn't quite fit the film version of The French Connection.

title: Merger News
description: A proposed affiliation of three New England utilities into a single entity was approved yesterday, subject to certain conditions, by a Securities and Exchange Commission examiner.

title: William H. Hill, 95, Dead; Upstate Republican Leader
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., July 24 (AP)William H. (Billy) Hill, an upstate Republican leader for half a century, died this morning at a convalescent home. He was 95 years old.

title: Buffalounion Pacts Approved
description: BUFFALO, Tuly 24 (AP)Contractors today approved a new labor agreement with five of the eight unions that have been on strike here for seven weeks. The settlement, whose terms were not disclosed was with 9,300 carpenters, bricklayers, ironworkers, laborers and teamsters.

title: Swan Lake Cast Changes
description: Eleanor D'Antuono and Ted Kivitt will appear in American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake at the New York State Theater tonight. They will be replacing Natalia Makarova and Ivan Nagy, due to an injury to Mr. Nagy.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A proposed public offering of 1.5 million common shares of Canteen Corporation, a move related to the divestiture by I.T.T. in connection with its Hartford Fire Insurance Company acquisition, has been postponed because of the poor condition of the newissue market, managers of the underwriting group announced yesterday. The managers are Lazard Freres & Co., Kuhn Loeb & Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.

title: Yacht Race Prizes T Witchcraft And Fair American
description: FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 24Herbert L. Jamison Jr.'s and Rudolph J. Schaefer 3d's Fair American, sailed by Jamison, won the Commodore John B. Shethar Bowl today. The 84foot sloop placed first in Division I, on corrected time, on the 81mile distance race which opened the American Yacht Club's 41st annual cruise.

title: Giants Feel Heat, Call Time Out
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 24  Anywhere you go around the Monmouth College campus here, where the Giants are training, you can find some fan or journalist cornering some member of the Giants and saying:

title: Hijacker Convicted In California Case; Gets Life Sentence
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) Ricardo ChavezOrtiz, an unemployed father of eight who hijacked a jetliner last April and then held a gun on newsmen as he poured out his troubles in a radio broadcast, was convicted of air piracy today and sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: BEACH LIMITATION VOIDED IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a Jersey shore municipality could not charge nonresidents higher fees than residents for the use of a municipal beach.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ATLANTA, July 24The appropriate procedure, course, would be for Henry Aaron to hit a gamewinning home run for the National League in tomorrow's AllStar Game spectacular in the Atlanta Stadium. That was Babe Ruth's style and Henry already is crowding in on the Babe in inexorable approach to one Ruthian record of majestic proportions, the career mark of 714 homers.

title: DR. MILTONSINGER, 61, PEDIATRICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Milton Singer, a pediatrician who developed techniques for treating children suffering from cerebral palsy, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 61 years and lived at 14 East 90th Street. His office was at 69 East 76th Street.

title: BLAST ENDS HUNT FOR 9 COAL MINERS
description: BLACKSVILLE, W. Va., July 24An explosion today in the Consolidation Coal Company's Blacksville No. 1 mine ended any hope of finding alive nine miners trapped In the mine since Saturday.

title: Dollar Gains and Pound Drops On ForeignExchange Markets
description: The dollar was strong in world foreignexchange markets yesterday, as traders continued to assess the Federal Reserve System's decision last week to intervene in the markets in support of the United States currency.

title: Flippin Named to Head Sports at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 24 (AP)Royce Flippin Jr., former football and baseball star at Princeton University, was named today as athletic director at his alma mater.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LANCASTER, Pa., July 24 (AP)Gene Littler, who underwent cancer surgery April 5, scored a oneunderpar 69 today to win an invitation golf tournament at the Lancaster Country Club. It was the first time Littler had completed 18 holes of competitive golf since the operation. He sank birdies on the last two holes to beat Dave Eichelberger, who shot a 70.

title: City Moves to Improve Sewage Plants
description: The Cify Planning Commission voted at a speoial meeting yesterday, to seek an amendment to the 197273 capital Ibudget to provide $245.2million more in state and city funds to enlarge and improve six sewagetreatment plants. The announcement came only three days after the city, signed a $61million contract to upgrade and expand the Hunts Point treatment plant in the Bronx, and less than a week after the Federal Government sued the city, among others, for spilling sewage into New York harbor.

title: Business Briefs
description: A brief has been filed by a committee representing 21 apparel manufacturing associations in opposition to proposal by the Federal Trade Commission to eliminate the use of registration numbers under the Wool Products and Textile Fibers Labeling Acts.

title: TYPECAST, $8.40, WINS COAST RACE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI)Typecast established herself as one of racing's best mares today when she captured the 31st running of the $135,850 Sunset Handicap at Hollywood Park to become the first of her sex to win the race, the closingday feature here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The rather sad conclusion that may be drawn from John Seelye's touching account of a poodle's vigil over a collie dying on a highway (OpEd July 11) is that some dogs have a better developed sense of responsibility than people.

title: ELLSBERG DEFENSE TOLD OF WIRETAP
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24The trial judge in the Pentagon papers case surprised the defense today by disclosing in open court that the Government had conceded that it had overheard at least one defense lawyer or consultant by electronic eavesdropping.

title: Hanoi's Choice
description: What is probably the last round of the Paris peace talks prior to the American Presidential election now under way with the resumption of private meetings between Henry Kissinger and North Vietnamese Politburo member Le Duc Tho.

title: Results Top Hopes
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25 The success of the acquisitions of the bulk Of RCA Corporation's computer operations at the end of 1971 has thus far exceeded the expectations of the Sperry Rand Corporation, J. Paul Lyet, chairman and chief executive officer told about 200 stockholders here today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Republican liberals, seeking a way to make their voice heard at the national convention in Miami Beach next month, have seized on the issue of convention reform.

title: Hussein Visiting Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 25 (UPI)King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Teheran today to discuss Persian Gulf and ArabIsraeli problems with the Shah of Iran.

title: Former Banker in Jersey Is Sentenced to 10 Years
description: NEWARK, July 25 (AP)Douglas J. Schotte, who pleaded guilty to masterminding a multimilliondollar misapplication of funds from the nowdefunct Eatontown National Bank, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000.

title: A Bomb in Beirut Injures New Aide of Guerrilla Unit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25, (AP)A parcel exploded today in the Beirut office of a leftist newspaper, Al Hadar, seriously injuring the new spokesman for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the police said.

title: Market Place Japanese Bulls Are Stampeding
description: Scratch a stockbroker anywhere in the world and you'll most likely discover a bull. Tokyo brokers are no exception. The Japanese stock market has been at an alltime peak The DowJones average has been at about the 3,700 yen level up well over 30 per cent since the beginning of this year.

title: Soul Festival: A Cool Nikki Giovanni Reads Poetry
description: There was a poetry reading last night at Alice Tully Hall in the ongoing series, Soul at the Center, with the young popular black poet Nikki Giovanni as the focus of interest. But it would be a distortion to devote this notice to the niceties of the reading or even, in a way, to the substance of the individual poems.

title: Sports of The Times
description: With the single exception of Connie Mack, every man who ever owned a baseball team long enough to get dry behind the swivel chair has from time to time clutched his manager by the scruff of the neck and the blouse of the britches and, employing the clean andjerk technique, flung him into the street. Some do the deed in awkward, embarrassed desperation and some make a hobby, but none of the others ever had Phil K. Wrigley's flair. It is an inborn talent, not a matter of long practice, for although P.K.'s 39 years as proprietor of the Cubs make him the senior member of the lodge, there are owners who can go through two or even three managers in season, whereas Wrigley went five in a row without any manager at all. Since he took office in 1934 the Cubs have had only 9, 10 or 11 managers, depending on whether you count Charlie Grimm as one, two or three. (For years Pkil was addicted to alcohol'. After dozen years without a relapse, he appears to have kicked the habit, but authorities versed in these matters say there is no sure cure; if Whitey Lockman shouldn't work out as Leo Durocher's replacement, one phone call is all that would take).

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, July 25 (UPI)The stateowned British Steel Corporation today reported a loss of $112.5million after tax and closure charges in its last financial year and forecast higher steel prices and more plant closings.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Seen Doubling in 72
description: HAKONE, Japan, July 25A senior American trade official said today that the United States was headed for a trade deficit twice as large as the $2.1billion deficit registered last year.

title: 10 MILLION FREED FROM WAGE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Nixon Administration announced today that it was exempting 10 million more workers from Government wage controls.

title: Paine, Webber Merger With Shearson Dropped
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis and Shearson, Hammill & Co., the two big brokerage houses, announced yesterday that they had called off their proposed merger because of problems which would be extremely difficult to resolve.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: S.E.C. President Nixon accepted the resignation of James D. Needham as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Needham resigned to serve as the fulltime chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange. His replacement has not been named.

title: State Lawyer Suing Jersey Sports Unit Files an Incomplete Bill for $43,312
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25 The lawyer hired by the state to file a friendly suit testing the constitutionality of the New Jerse3'r Sports Authority has submitted a partial bill of $43,312 and is billing the state for $75 an hour for his continued services in an environmental impact hearing.

title: Youth Held for Selling Cocaine to Stones Fans
description: A 19yearold youth was arrested in Pennsylvania Station yesterday evening and accused of selling cocaine to people attending the Rolling Stones concert at Madison Square Garden, which is above the station.

title: WASHINGTON
description: In his fourhour speech to the central committee of Egypt's only political party, President Anwar elSadat said he had asked Moscow to reduce its military personnel in Cairo because of the Soviet Union's excessive caution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Whatever anyone else may think, from the point of view of the rider (almost never consulted these days) the proposed demolition of the final stretch of the Third Avenue El is sad news.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, July 25A British international player made a strong bid here today to become the firstnonAmerican to win the life master pair championship in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. Jonathan Cansino of London, who represented Britain in the World Team Olympiad in Miami Beach last month, joined with Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles in leading the field of 60 pairs into the final session.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Hip! Hip! Hooray! for Gen. W. C. Westmoreland's patriotic pitch for the U.S. Army and, by implication, Vietnamization and vicarious victory (A Soldier Looks Back, OpEd June 25). He bemoans the time when soldiering was a term implying that someone was slacking on the job. But now, because of the enduring truths and principles on which the militaryindustrial complex is based, the Army is doing its proper job of bloodletting.

title: U.S. Aide Hopeful on Asian Drug Curb
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The State Department's leading adviser on narcotics traffic said today that control of the opium exported from Burma through Thailand and from Afghanistan through Iran was off to hopeful start.

title: Staab of Mets Is Placed On 21 Day Disabled List
description: ATLANTA, July 25Rusty Staub was placed on the 21day disabled list today by the New York Mets.

title: A Tanaka News Conference: Free, Orderly
description: TOKYO, July 25  When Premier Kakuei Tanaka walked into the auditorium next door to his office for a news conference last week, he bent slightly into a formal bow to the assembled newsmen before taking his seat. The newsmen, however, remained seated and merely nodded to acknowledge his presence.

title: The Face of Venus
description: Beyond the moon, Earth's two closest neighbors are Mars and Venus. Mars is now relatively well known, since most of its surface was photographed by the latest Mariner vehicle sent into orbit late last year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 25 (UPI)Local 95 of the Newspaper Guild voted last night to ask the union's international executive board to rescind its endorsement of Senator George McGovern for President and to apologize publicly for entering partisan politics. A Local 95 resolution called for a national referendum on the question Shall the Newspaper Guild abide by its traditional policy of refusal to endorse any candidate for political office.

title: Most Power Back in City; Voltage Cut in Some Areas
description: Electricity was restored yesterday to most of the 500,000 people in areas blacked out Monday, but some Consolidated Edison customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan remained without power or with reduced power more than 32 hours after the failures first struck the city.

title: Studio Closing Stirs Controversy in Italy
description: ROMEDinocitta was meant as the permanent, stately home of HollywoodontheTiber, but now it's just a chunk of real estate half the size of Manhattan's Central Park, with a cluster of huge barnlike buildings that nobody seems to want at the asking price of $100million.

title: Advertising:
description: Although physicians have one of the highest incomes of any group, most advertising directed specifically at them is not after their money but their patients possissive.

title: Thomas School
description: If the Board of Education formally votes as it is expected to, New York will in a few years have students attending a Norman Thomas High School. One hopes that when they see that name carved over the doorway, they will not automatically assume that its owner was a member of the Establishment.
