Indeed, if the school lives up to its name, they will learn that this man who died so long agoin 1968believed in most of the things that youth believes in today: racial equality, social justice, economic democracy and world peace. He preached all of these for half a century, but he always rejected change by force. He worked within the system.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP)Jerry Quarry, saying his enthusiasm for boxing had wilted, announced today he was quitting the ring to pursue a career in public relations.

title: FAVORITES CASH IN AS BIG A LIGHTS UP
description: After a day of idleness caused by an electric power failure, thoroughbred racing returned to normal at Aqueduct yesterday. The weather continued to be sultry, but chalk players easily kept their cool as five fayorites raced home first.

title: News Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25A major test of the Government's authority over information and of the public's access to it will begin to unfold tomorrow when the Pentagon papers trial is scheduled to begin here.

title: HOUSE UNIT SCORES AMPHIBIOUS TRUCK
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) House investigators charged today that the Army was paying $15,400 for an amphibious truck, planned to cost $5,000, even though it had turned out to be a mechanical nightmare that often sank when it was supposed to float.

title: U. S Paris Team Charges Hanoi BuildUp
description: PARIS, July 25  The United States delegation to the Vietnam talks here issued a sharp statement today charging that there has been a significant buildup of North Vietnamese forces in the northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

title: U.S. LAND TRANSFER IS SPURRED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) President Nixon told members of the Federal Property Review Commission today to twist bureaucratic arms if necessary to convert more surplus Federal land into ecreational areas under his legacy of parks program.

title: Kennedy and Hanoi Letters Discuss P. o. W's
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has opened a discussion with the North Vietnamese Government over the question of American prisoners of war in Indochina.

title: Lee Anderson, Poet, Dead; Anthologist of Yale Series
description: YORK, Pa., July 25  Lee Anderson, poet and anthologist of the Yale Series of Recorded Poets, died today at his country home near here. He was 76 years old.

title: Blazers Offer Sanderson $2.6Million, 5Year Pact
description: BOSTON, July 25 (AP)Bob Woolf, a lawyer, confirmed tonight that the Philadelphia Blazers of the new World Hockey Association have offered a $2,625,000, fiveyear contract to Derek Sanderson, the Boston Bruins center.

title: TUPAMAROS KILL AN ARMY OFFICER
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 25 (Reuters)The Tupamaros, Uruguay's leftwing urban guerrillas, today machinegunned to death their highest ranking military victim. He was Artigas Alvarez, a 49yearold colonel who was chief of civilian defense.

title: Dean at Columbia Is Shot; Suspended Student Sought
description: Dean Henry S. Coleman of Columbia College was shot three times and seriously wounded yesterday afternoon, and police officials said they were seeking a suspended undergraduate for questioning.

title: Bay State Passed 816 Bills
description: BOSTON, July 25 (AP)There are 816 new acts on the Massachusetts statute books as a result of the work of the 1972 legislature, Secretary of State John F. X. Davoren said today.

title: Allstate Says 3 TV Networks Refused To Show Commercials Praising Airbag
description: WASHINGTON, July 25An insurance company executive told the Senate Commerce Committee today that his company had been refused by all three major television networks when it attempted to buy time for commercials praising the effectiveness of airbags as automobile safety devices.

title: Harlem Preacher Stresses Power of Money and Prayer
description: Close your eyes and see green, the minister exhorted. Money up to your armpits, a roomful of money and there you are, just tossing around in it like a swimming pool.

title: CONGRESS IS TOLD OF HIDDEN OWNERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  A Union City, N. 1, woman testified today that she had received unemployment payments during part of the time she was listed as owner of seven race horses valued at about $150,000.

title: After the Rain and Heat Wave, a Tide of Mosquitoes Is Whirring
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 25In the next three weeks, millions of mosquitoes more than double the normal amountwill be hatched in New Jersey's marshes and woodlands, sodden with pools of stagnant water after the spring's heavy rains.

title: EAGLETON TELLS OF SHOCK THERAPY ON TWO OCCASIONS
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 25Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, said here today that he was hospitalized three times between 1960 and 1966 for nervous exhaustion and fatigue and that he had undergone psychiatric treatment, including electric shock therapy, for depression on two of the three occasions.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS A RALLY FAILS
description: Stock prices struggled unsuccessfully yesterday on the American Stock Exchange to follow through on their sharp rise Monday. Enough selling entered to lower the index to 26.88, off 0.06.

title: Philharmonic Plays to 60,000 in Park
description: Ha! That's better than the Rolling Stones, said Pierre Boulez, music director of the New York Philharmonic, when he heard that the orchestra's concert in Central Park last night drew a crowd estimated by orchestra officials as between 60,000 and 70,000 persons.

title: Calls Were Made to Home of Nixon Election Aide From Phones of Man Held in Democratic BreakIn
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Diverse bits of new evidence, have emerged in connection with the breakin June 17 at the offices of the Democratic National Committee here.

title: S. E. C. PROPOSES RULES TO CONTROL NEWSTOCK SALES
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Extensive new regulations, aimed at preventing the development, in the future, of wildly gyrating hotissues markets in new stocks, were proposed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mayer 60, 63 Victor
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 25 (AP)Two metropolitan New York players were eliminated and another scored an easy victory in the third round of the Western junior tennis championships today.

title: Rivals at Reykjavik Still Using Surprise
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 25 The seventh game of the world chess championship, like the sixth, started with a surprise. The titleholder, Boris Spassky opened today with the king's pawn for the first time. In the sixth game, the challenger, Bobby Fischer, opened unexpectedly with a queen's pawn debut.

title: Treasury Bills Yields Mixed in Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: College Football Hall Abandons Rutgers for East Side
description: The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame has given up plans to construct its building on the campus of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N. J.

title: Washington's Evasion
description: In its response to Secretary General Waldheim's appeal not to bomb the dikes of North Vietnam, the United States Government has distorted and evaded the main issue.

title: Sudan and U.S. Resume Fall Ties After 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)The Sudan and the United States resumed diplomatic relations today after a fiveyear bieak, the State Department announced. Ambassadors will be exchanged soon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 3 editorial Total Control by U.F.T.? took the position that Mr. Shanker is playing a dangerous game if he intends to use the union's muscle as a means of usurping the legitimati powers of both the central and the local school authorities.

title: G.&W. Sees Gains
description: Sparked by the success of the film The Godfather, the leisuretime group of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., is expected to make a major contribution to corporate operating earnings in the fiscal year ending next week, according to Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman.

title: Marcos Bids Soldiers Hunt for Hoarded Rice
description: MANILA, July 25 (Reuters)  President, Ferdinand, E. Marcos ordeied troops today to search for hoarded rice in Luzon, the main island of the Philippines, where thousands of flood victims are threatened with starvation.

title: Two Doomed in the Ukraine In Nazi Massacre of Jews
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (Reuters) Two brothers have been sentenced to death and three other Ukrainians to 15year and 10year terms in labor camps for their roles in a Nazi massacre of 2,500 Jews in the wartime Ukraine, according to a copy of the local newspaper, Pravda Ukrainy, which reached here today.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The rate of real growth in the United States economy took a great leap upward in the second quarter. Measured at current prices, the total output of goods and services actually increased a bit less than in the first three months this year. But, due to a dramatic drop in the rate of inflation, real output, measured in dollars of constant purchasing power, shot up at an 8.9 per cent annual rate  the highest such rate of gain since 1965. The Nixon Administration, quite understandably, was jubilant about this news last Friday. However, considering the stubbornness with which the inflation problem has resisted all manner of economic medicines over the last five years or so, it is fair to ask some close questions about the longrun outlook for the rate of increase in prices.

title: DOCTORS WARNED ON GLOVE POWDER
description: The safety of the powder that surgeons use on their gloves when operating has been questioned by a leading medical journal.

title: McGraw Victor Aaron Hits Home Run
description: ATLANTA, July 25The largest baseball crowd in Atlanta's 125year history watched the National League defeat the American League, 4.3, in 10 innings tonight in the 43d AllStar Game.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)The nine owners of the Chicago Bulls voted unanimously today to sell the National Basketball Association club to a Chicago group including Arthur Wirtz, owner of the Chicago Stadium. The action apparently ended the offagain, onagain proposed sale the Bulls, although the N.B.A.'s board of governors must give official approval, expected Friday.

title: Joy Manufacturing Signs Pact With Soviet Agency
description: MOSCOW, July 25A key Soviet machinemanufacturing ministry, which was chastised only this morning in the press Ifor poor performance, later in the day signed an agreement with a United States company for technical data on better machines.

title: BORIS GAPONOV, 38, TRANSLATOR, DIES
description: TEL AVIV, July 25Boris Gaponov, who taught himself Hebrew in the Soviet Union and won Israel's most coveted literary award while still there, died today in a suburb of Tel Aviv. He was 38 years old.

title: SEEWAGEN BEATS CONNORS IN UPSET
description: CLEMMONS, N. C., July 25 (AP)  George (Butch) Seewagen, Jr., a late entry in the $25,000 Tanglewood tennis tournament, upset topseeded Jimmy Connors in the first round today, 63, 16, 64.

title: Patty Berg Billy Casper Are Inducted Into Golf Hall
description: PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP): Patty Berg, former women's National Amateur and National Open golf champion, was among four persons inducted into the American Golf Hall of Fame tonight.

title: Blackout Damage Stirs Claims Against Con Ed
description: Though a number of claims for losses on such perishables as ice cream and meat seem to be building up against Consolidated Edison because of power failures in Queens and Brooklyn, there was indication yesterday that few were likely to be paid without court suits.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's chief foreign policy adviser, will address two gatherings of prominent Wall Street financiers at the University Club in New York City tomorrow.

title: News Analysis
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 23Once again, Northern Ireland is plunged into terror. Secret talks and efforts to revive the ceasefire are overshadowed by the bombings, the sectarian murders, the killing of soldiers and the tactical decisions by the British Government to intensify action against the Irish Republican Army. Yet virtually all sides  Roman Catholics and Protestants, mod crates as well as militantshave drawn up plans in recent weeks for the future of the embattled six counties of Ulster.

title: MRS. JAMES B. SHEEAN
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., July 25 Mrs. Emily H. Sheean, the widow of James B. Sheean, vice president, general counsel and a director of the Chicago and North Western Railroad, now North Western Industries, died today in a nursing home. Her age was 88.

title: U. S. Starts Program to Locate Elderly People Eligible for Aid
description: Arthur S. Flemming, special consultant to President Nixon on problems of the aging, announced here yesterday that the Government would open a nationwide effort next month to locate elderly persons eligible for food stamps, surplus food and other Federal programs.

title: Insurance Man Cleared by Jury On Attempted Bribery Charge
description: After questioning Sgt. David Durk of the Police Department, a Queens grand jury yesterday threw out attempted bribery charges against an insurance man accused of offering a bribe to a close assistant of District Attorney Thomas Mackeli.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 25 (AP)  Topseeded Marita Redondo of National City, Calif., swept past Rayni Fox of North Miami Beach, Fla., 61, 6.0 today and gained the quarterfinals in the National girls 16andunder tennis championships.

title: PLATFORMS PUT UP AT RAIL FIRE SITE
description: The Penn Central railroad set up temporary platforms yesterday at the White Plains station to substitute for some months for the new highlevel platforms destroyed in a flash fire Monday afternoon.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Soybean prices dropped sharply in futures trading early yesterday and then staged a mild rally that helped regain much of the decline. The busy August delivery, for example, dropped as low as $3.43 a bushel and then closed at $3.47, compared with $3.49 on Monday.

title: Jagger Steams, and Stones Cook Along
description: The two shows by the Rolling Stones at Madison Square Garden yesterdayone in the afternoon, the other in the eveningprovided a startling, if perhaps predictable, contrast in musical substance and emotional content.

title: U.S. Defeats Russian Five In Soviet Tourney, 81.67
description: TRIBILISI, U.S.S.R., July 25 (AP)Scott English of TexasEl Paso scored 28 points to lead an American amateur basketball team to an 8167 victory over a Russian team today in an international tournament named for the first Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin.

title: NAVY YARD URGED FOR UTILITY PLANT
description: Two Brooklyn members of Ithe City Council proposed yesterday that the 23,000kilowatt power plant at the Brooklyn Navy Yard be reactivated.

title: Nixon Accord With Soviet Embitters NATO Officials
description: BRUSSELS, July 20Members of the North Atlantic Council, guiding body of the Atlantic alliance, are baffled and bitter at what they consider President Nixon's end run in signing a declaration of principles with the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev in Moscow last May.

title: Executive Changes
description: Richard J. Powers, 47 years old; chairman and chief executive officer of Indian Head, Inc., will assume the additional office of president Aug. 1. He succeeds Robert W. Lear, 55, who has resigned as president. Mr. Lear, who will continue as a director and as consultant to the company, has not disclosed his future plans. James M. Flack, 58, formerly senior vice president, has been elected vice chairman.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Governor Approves Plan for the Adirondacks
description: Governer Rockefeller yesterday approved a master plan to guide the management and recreational use of 2.27 million acres of stateowned land in Adirondack State Park.

title: HANRAHAN TRIAL GETS A SURPRISE
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI)In a surprise move today, prosecutors in the trial of Cook County State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan produced statements from four Black Panthers who said that they fired shots and handled weapons during the police raid in 1969.

title: Welfare Protest Brings Bill Of $12,000 at Hospital Here
description: A welfare recipient who said that her cityowned apartment was condemned and ratinfested refused to have Metropolitan Hospital release her newborn son for more than three months and accumulated a Medicaid bill of at least $12,000, is was disclosed yesterday.

title: DEATHS IN INDIA HALT FEEDING BY AGENCY
description: NEW DELHI. July 25The government of Kerala state hal ordered the suspension of a CARE food program covering two million children in 9,000 schools after reports that at least four children died and more than 250 became ill with food poisoning.

title: 3 LABOR FIGURES INDICTED BY U.S.
description: Three labor figuresone of whom is also the president of the San Francisco Fire Commissionwere charged here yesterday with ordering a strike against a national airfreight carrier here and elsewhere in the country to extort a lucrative fee as labor consultant for one of the defendants.

title: Harrelson Helped by Nicklaus
description: A few tips from Jack Nicklaus ave convinced Ken Harrelson, the American League's most valuable baseball player in 1968, that he will succeed in pro golf. Harrelson, who played in the recent proamateur invitation tourney at Columbus, Ohio, said, I've played several times with Jack. He told me I didn't have to hit everything; hard, that the ball will go just as far by swinging easy at it. Harrelson failed to survive the cut in the recent British Open by three strokes at 153. I have played much better the last two months. I'm learning to curb my temper. I'm not teeing it up and letting it fly any more. Since he turned pro, Harrelson's best finish was eighth in the $25,000 Dodge open in Denville, N. J., this year. Four years ago with the Boston Red Sox, Hatrelson had his best season a major leagueleading 109 runs batted in, 35 homers gnd the Most Valuable Plwer award. Last year Harrelson quit a $100,000ayear job with Cleveland for the uncertainties of pro golf. Despite winning only $5,000 in his new pursuit, Harrelson said, I've never been happier in my life. I don't miss base.

title: BURLINGTON NET ROSE IN QUARTER
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., the country's largest textile manufacturer, posted a thirdquarter gain of 18 per cent in earnings and 10 per cent in sales compared with the year before.

title: College AllStars Shore Up Defense for Cowboys
description: EVANSTON, Ill., July 25The college AllStars attempted to shore up their defense today after losing three of their best men, Walter Patulskl, Clarence Ellis and Herb Orvis, through injuries. The problem arose only three days in advance of their game here against the Super Bowl champions, the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 25 (AP)Jack Nicklaus was hospitalized today for treatment of an infected index finger on his right hand. Doctors at University Hospital said he would remain there for 48 to 72 hours. His condition was listed as good.

title: MEYER RABINOWITZ, RETIRED PHYSICIAN
description: Dr. Meyer A. Rabinowitz, a retired physician formerly associated with Greenpoint Hospital and the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn, died Monday night of heart failure at his home, 200 East 71st Street. He was 85 years old.

title: WARNERLAMBERT RAISES EARNINGS
description: The WarnerLambert Company had record results in the quarter and six months ended June 30, Stuart K. Hensley, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: DR. HAROLD A. LENTZ
description: CLIFTON, N. J., July 25Dr. Harold A. Lentz, a dental surgeon long associated with Passaic General Hospital and treasurer of the New Jersey State Dental Association, died yesterday in Middlesex County Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 278 Charles Street.

title: Head of Brookhaven Labs For Last 11 Years to Retire
description: Dr. Maurice Goldhaber director of Brookhaven National Laboratories for the last 11 years, has resigned, citing his desire to return to fulltime nuclear research.

title: Connecticut Loses an Island In Congressional Redistricting
description: HARTFORD, July 25After having its Congressional District lines at last redrawn and approved by a Federal Court, Connecticut has lost an island, it was learned yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Political associates and opponents of Senator Thomas F. Eagleton accepted without question today the Democratic VicePresidential nominee's explanation of a nervous disorder from which he suffered in the 1960's.

title: School Board Will Create Office of Safety Director
description: The Board of Education will create a new position of safety director for the city's public schools and appoint Eldridge Waith, a former commander of patrolmen in Harlem, to fill it.

title: Color Lures the Eye to Kelly's Paintings
description: BUFFALOEllsworth Kelly, who will be 50 next year, is one of the most accomplished, and at times one of me most baffling, abstract painters of his generation. He is also one of the most audacious.

title: Needham Resignation Accepted
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  The White House said today that President Nixon had accepted with regret the resignation of James J. Needham from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., July 25 (UPI)Following are excerpts from a statement today by Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, the Democratic Vice  Presidential nominee, and from questions and answers addressed to Mr. Eagleton and Senator George McGovern at a joint news conference.

title: DouglasHome to Visit China
description: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) Britain's Foreign Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, will visit Peking in late October and early November and hopes to meet Premier Chou Enlai, an authoritative British source said today. The exact dates of his visit have not been announced.

title: Bus Lane to Close 2 Days
description: Because of paving work at the crossover point two miles east of the QueensMidtown Tunnel, the exclusive bus lane on the Long Island Expressway will be closed for at least two days beginning today, the Traffic Department said yesterday.

title: ELLSBERG DEFENSE TO REQUEST DELAY
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25The judge in the Pentagon papers case denied today defense requests for a special hearing to determine if a lawyer or consultant for the defense had been overheard by an illegal Government eavesdropping device.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates displayed a mixed pattern yesterday as underwriters cleaned their shelves of some older merchandise, marketed a large amount of new bonds and set tentative terms for at least two additional offerings for sale today.

title: CHARGES UNPROVED, HOSPITALS UNIT SAYS
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that there was no documented proof of the charges by Coney Island Hospital officials that heart patients had died needlessly because the hospital could not hire additional nurses to staff a newly completed addition to a coronarycare unit.

title: LADY GUTHRIE
description: DUBLIN, July 25 (AP)Lady Guthrie, the widow of Sir Tyrone Guthrie, the director, author and producer, died today at Newbliss. County Monaghan. She was 67 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Electroshock therapy, though once used for a variety of psychiatric ailments, is used today mainly in the treatment of selected cases of depression, in which the success rate is considered good.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The North American Rockwell Corporation received $66.4million in military contracts, it was announced yesterday. The bulk of the funds, $63.7million, will be spent by the Air Force for Minuteman III missileguidance and controls systems.

title: Business Briefs
description: The SMC Investment Corporationa closedend investment company with assets of $213million and 75,000 stockholderssaid yesterday that it would submit to stockholders a plan to issue two classes of stock, common and preferred, to replace the present common.

title: Islands at Bay
description: Upstate New York officials were reported searching Cayuga, Lake recently for a runaway island, potpourri of logs, weeds and mud churned up by Tropical Storm Agnes which entangled to form a oneacre floating mass. They want to break it up before it becomes a menace to lakeside campsites. If they don't hurry up, some enterprising realtor may try to snare it and sell it.

title: Robert Hughes, Who Won Oscar For Robert Frost Feature, Dies
description: Robert Hughes, a documentary filmmaker who won an Academy Award and a television Emmy, died Monday in his apartment at 290 West End Avenue. He was 43 years old.

title: Revenues Also Decline
description: Net income of the United States Steel Corporation dropped sharply in the second quarter of 1972 from yearearlier levels, the company reported yesterday. Revenues for the quarter also were down.

title: Portugal's President, 77, Reelected to 7Year Term
description: LISBON, July 25Portugal's 77yearold President, Adm. Amdrico Thomaz, was elected today for a third sevenyear term, dashing hopes for prompt change.

title: Sheriff Frees Green Berets P.O.W.s
description: ALABASTER, Ala., July 25The Mayor of this little town and its chief of police were driving around one day last week tacking up posters for the Mayor's reelection campaign.

title: Weaver's Dictates Keep Two Stars in the Dark
description: ATLANTA, July 25  Earl Weaver, alienating people faster than a kibitzer at a, chess match, added two more enemies to his mushrooming collection tonight  Mickey, Lolich of Detroit and Bert Campaneris of, Oakland.

title: Cubs Warned to Produce As Durocher Is Replaced
description: ATLANTA, July 25In replacing cantankerous Leo Durocher with Whitey Lockman, rookie manager, the management of the Chicago Cubs has told the players to produce or else.

title: Maine Closes Clam Area Polluted by an Oil Spill
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 25 (UPI)Clam flats in parts of Casco Bay polluted by an oil spill last weekend have been closed effective today by state officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Where are the airconditioned buses? It is really a scandal and a disgrace. With a lot of noise and bragging the M.T.A. put a great number of those buses into circulation. Last year they really existed, but where are they now?

title: Saigon Reports Capturing Citadel and All of Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 26The South Vietnamese command said yesterday that its troops had recaptured the walled inner Citadel of Quangtri city and controlled the whole provincial capital, but this morning a command spokesman indicated that there was still resistance within the Citadel.

title: Fischer and Spassky Adjourn Tense Game
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 25The seventh game of the world chess championship, a tense, seesaw struggle between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, was adjourned tonight after 40 moves.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)The Justice Department today ended a suit against the Converse Rubber Corporation. The terms of the settlement require Converse Rubber to sell facilities capable of producing 7 million pairs canvas shoes annually.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE BACKS AMENDMENT SEEKING WAR'S END
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The House Foreign Affairs Committee, once an ardent backer of the Vietnam war, voted today for legislation that would order a termination of American involvement in the war, subject only to a limited ceasefire with North Vietnam and release of American prisoners.

title: NEWAUTO SALES OFF IN MIDJULY
description: DETROIT, July 25New car sales in the middle third of July totaled 274,272 units against 260,990 the year before. But there was one extra selling day in the July 1120 period this year, meaning the dealers delivered an average of 30,4751 Americantype cars per day, down 7 per cent from 32,364 deliveries a day a year ago.

title: Allende Announces Economic Plan That Couples Development With Austerity
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 25 (AP)President Salvador Allende Gossens has announced an economic plan that couples ambitious development with austerity aimed at pushing Chile faster along the road to socialism.

title: Bottle Deposit Law Fought
description: SALEM, Ore., July 25 (UPI)The bottle and can industry went to court yesterday in an effort to overturn a new Oregon law requiring refundable deposits on all beer and soft drink cans and bottles.

title: AMTRAK TO INCREASE CONNECTICUT STOPS
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., July 25 (AP)An Amtrak official has promised that Penn Central passenger trains will make more stops in Old Saybrook.

title: Britain Faces Paralysis in Labor Dispute
description: LONDON, July 25  Britain approached industrial paralysis tonight as more workers left their jobs and thousands threatened to follow in support of five imprisoned dock workers. But there was a glimmer of hope.

title: IF YOURE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR's
description: William Lawson's 86.6 Prool Blended Scotch Wthsktes. Imported by Palmer tb Lord, Ltd., Syosset, N.Y.Advt.

title: About Motor Sports
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 25  When is speed dangerous? Definitions have been debated since the beginning of motor racing, and they are still far from settled. An opinion widelybut not unanimously  accepted is that speed is dangerous when it is too fast for a given track200 miles an hour, for example, is said to be too fast for an old, slightly banked track like In dianapolis. Another popular opinion is that racing fans do not know the difference nor do they carebetween 150 and 175 M.P.H., that the important point is competition. What everyone does agree on, though, is that speed is expensive.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS AIDE OF MACKELL
description: Norman D. Archer, an assistant district attorney of Queens, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of accepting a bribe to quash a criminal case.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Disenfranchisement cuts both ways, as Senators McGovern and Eagleton are about to discover. A majority of those assembled at the convention at Miami Beach seem now only to have succeeded in disenfranchising their alleged disenfranchisers.

title: Fanny May Yield Increases To 7.629% at Latest Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Asociation said today it had issued $113milion in fourmonth commitments on Governmentbacked home mortgages at an average yield of 7.629 per cent at its latest auction against 7.626 per cent previously.

title: MISS FERRO LEADS BY STROKE WITH 75
description: DEAL, N.J., July 25Cindy Ferro of Forest Hills shot 38, 3775 to take a onestroke lead in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54hole strokeplay championship today at the Deal Golf and Country Club.

title: Assortment of Debuts Marks A Busy Day at Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater kept its devoted public busy all day Sunday with an assortment of debuts in both the afternoon and evening performances at the State Theater. These were not the kind of appearances that will go down in history books, but the sort of exposure that any dancerany company, for that matterneeds in order to grow and develop.

title: SENATE VOTES BILLS LINKED TO FLOODING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the White House today two separate bills triggered by recent flood disasters.

title: Mobil's Net Rises 4%
description: Earnings results of petroleum companies continued to show a mixed pattern. The Mobil Oil Company and Ashland Oil, Inc., realized higher secondquarter and halfyear profits, according to their semiannual reports yesterday. The Gulf Oil Corporation, the Sun Oil Company and the Cities Service Company were among the major companies that showed declines in yesterday's statements.

title: Newcombe Adyances
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25 (AP)Topseeded John Newcombe defeated a fellow Australian, Phil Dent, 63, 63, today, completing firstround play in a $50,000 tennis tournament for contract pros.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The report on the financial crisis in the Catholic schools in the Philadelphia area was given to President Nixon as a guideline for national policy on public aid to Catholic schools in the United States by Cardinal Krol and John T. Gurash, chairman of the study and selectee of the Cardinal.

title: British Troops and Guerrillas Fight Running Battle, in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 25 (AP)British troops fought a running gun battle against guerrillas in a Roman Catholic sector of Belfast today while seven funeral processions moved through other parts of Northern Ireland's capital, bearing victims of last week's bomb terror.

title: U.S. Agency to Tell Corvair Owners Of Special Problems in Early Cars
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that his agency would send letters to some 200,000 owners of 19601963 Chevrolet Corvairs advising them of special problems created by the car's handling characteristics.

title: Syphilis Victims in U.S. Study Went Untreated for 40 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 25For 40 years the United States Public Health Service has conducted a study in which human beings with syphilis, who were induced to serve as guinea pigs, have gone without medical treatment for the disease and a few have died of its late effects, even though an effective therapy, was eventually discovered.

title: JOHN DUBROW
description: John Dubrow, who operated a women's shoe store, The 57th Street Bootery, in Manhattan in the nineteenforties and fifties, died of a heart attack on Saturday in his home in Bucks County, Pa. In recent years he also had operated a shoe shop in Trenton. He was 69 years old.

title: MRS. IRENE DOBBS
description: DURHAM, N C., July 25 Mrs. Irene Thompson Dobbs, mother of the opera singer Mattitwilda Dobbs and grandmother of Atlanta's Vice Mayor, Maynard H. Jackson, died on Saturday at a rest home here. Mrs. Thompson, the widow of John Wesley Dobbs, Atlanta civic and fraternal leader, was 33 years old.

title: 4 MONISTS TWIST DIALS, PLAY MUSIC
description: That stock answer to the query What instrument do you play?I play the radiocame to mind watching Gershon Kingsley and his First Moog Quartet in action at the Central Park Man on Monday.

title: Con Edison Advances
description: Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., rose sharply during the first half of 1972, the utility disclosed yesterday.

title: Methadone Clinic Head Sentenced for Contempt
description: Dr. Robert G. Newman, director of the city's methadone, maintenance program, was held in contempt of court yesterday and sentenced to 30 days in rail for refusing to turn over medical records from a methadone clinic to the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Merger News
description: The Clorox Company annotinced yesterday that it had offered to acquire the Kiwi International Company, Ltd., the Australianbased distributor of shoe polish, household items and industrial products, for the equivalent of roughly $37  million in Clorox common shares. In Melbourne, Australia, the board of the Kiwi company, which last year had sales of $36million in 173 countries around the world, announced its support of the offer as in the best interests of Kiwi shareholders, employes and the company.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: OXFORD, Ohio, July 25 (UPI)United States Olympic archery team trials and the National Archery Association's national target tournament will be staged at Miami (Ohio) University the first two weeks in August.

title: RHAPSODY VICTOR IN SQUADRON RUN
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 25Dr. James N. Worcester's Rhapsody, a Culbertson and Cassian39 sloop that flies the burgee of the host club at Rye, N. Y., was the Division I winner on corrected time today on the first of five daily squadron runs of the American Yacht Club's 41st annual cruise.

title: Bow Bridge to Be Renovated
description: Bow Bridge, a historic iron structure spanning the Central Park Lake at about 73d Street, is to be renovated, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday. The restoration, he said, has been made possible by two equal grants totaling $260,000 from Mrs. Henry Moses and Mrs. Lila Wallace.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ATHENS, July 25  The Athens progovernment press attacked Senator George McGovern today for pledging to halt American aid to Greece if elected President.

title: LTV Unit Sees Loss
description: Wilson & Co., Inc., an LTV Corporation subsidiary, said yesterday that secondquarter and sixmonth results were not yet available but would be lower than in the same periods last year. Extraordinary losses of $2.65million in the second quarter would result in net losses in both periods, Wilson said.

title: An Archftect's 2Week Whirlwind of Decorating
description: For nine months, Robert and Sonya Lee Rhodes lived with the remnants of the previous tenants decor.

title: GIANTS DROP FIVE; BRACE FOR CHIEFS
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 25The New York Giants dropped five players from their squad today and settled upon an offensive lineup to use against the Kansas City Chiefs Saturday in their first exhibition game.

title: TEMPLE U. LIBRARY DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) A fivealarm fire ruined the Charles Klein Library of Temple University Law School today.

title: HISTORIC GETTYSBURG. PA. NOT AFFECTED BY FLOODING  VISITORS WELCOME (717) 3346274.Advt.
description: HISTORIC GETTYSBURG. PA. NOT AFFECTED BY FLOODING  VISITORS WELCOME (717) 3346274.Advt.

title: Vicar General for Archdiocese Named Auxiliary Bishop Here
description: Msgr. James P. Mahoney, a vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was named by Pope Paul VI yesterday as a new Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

title: Most of the convicts cannot or will not accept life as it is.
description: CHILLICOTHE, OhioThere's something mighty strange going on in the jails and prisons around the United States today. I should know. I have been in three prisons and numberless county jails over the last 25 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Republicans might not like this but Abraham Lincoln had advice foe the Democrats which exactly fits their present condition. On the occasion of the controversy between adherents of gradual and immediate emancipation he wrote on March 7, 1864:

title: DOW FALLS BY 0.91 AS TRADING SLIPS
description: Stock prices trended downward to form a consolidation pattern yesterday, following their sharp advance stretched over the two previous sessions.

title: YONKERS EVENT DRAWS FAST ONES
description: YONKERS, July 25With 14 3yearolds named to start, Friday night's Best of All Pace at Yonkers Raceway was split today into divisions of seven.

title: ALBERT W. HOWLAND
description: Albert W. Howland, retired president of Howland & Howland, publishers representatives, and a former resident of Douglaston, Queens, and Coronado, Calif., died Monday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: New York Woman Wins A Custody Fight in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 25 (UPI)The Israeli Supreme Court, in Jerusalem, today ordered a man divorced from a New York City woman to surrender two of their children to the former wife, ending her yearlong battle. He gave her the children shortly afterward.

title: Murtaugh Finds Stint by McGraw A Welcome Relief
description: ATLANTA, July 25For a moment before tonight's AllStar game, Tug McGraw'c biggest concern was whether he should thank Manager Danny Murtaugh for selecting him to the National League team.

title: Most of the convicts cannot or will not accept life as it is.
description: AN LOC, South Vietnam Dear Papa and Mama:

title: Advertising:
description: Domestic account losses are blamed by J. Walter Thompson for a poor secondquarter performance despite healthy international growth and good reports from subsidiaries.

title: 2 Deny Guilt in Conspiracy
description: SEATTLE, July 25 (UPI)Two men accused of conspiring to defraud a magazine editor by selling him for $30,000 a fake interview with D. B. Cooper, an airplane hijacker who parachuted to safety, have pleaded not guilty. William J. Lewis, 33 years old, and Donald S. Murphy, 49, both of Bremerton, Wash., will go on trial Nov. 27 for the alleged offense against Karl P. Fleming, a former contributing editor of Newsweek magazine.

title: Two Held in $5 Murder
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI)The police today arrested two South Side youths in the murder of Sandy Reed, a 73yearold ice cream vendor, who refused to hand over less than $5 he had accumulated in small change. The unidentified youths were both 15 years old. One was charged with murder and the other with armed robbery, the police said.

title: Notes on People
description: Doctors treating Lyndon B. Johnson, who was hospitalized Monday night in San Antonio, Tex., after suffering chest pains and nausea, said there is no evidence of a major severe heart attack.

title: WILLIAM M. LEARY
description: William M. Leary, who retired as assistant treasurer of Columbia University last November, died yesterday in Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, N. J. He was 66 years old and lived in Toms River, N. J.

title: Thais Report Drug Seizure
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25 (AP) Thai narcotic agents made early morning raids Sunday and yesterday in villages on the Burmese border and seized opium and heroin valued at more than $232million, officials said here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your recent churchstate editorial pragmatically accepts some form of aid to private education, but it ignores the case for human freedom in the distribution of the education tax dollar.

title: Lawyers for Colley Ask for New Trial, Saying Army Lied
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25Lawyers for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. accused the Army of fraud and demanded a new trial today on the ground of newly discovered evidence in the Mylai massacre case.

title: Critics of Bill to Limit Busing Prevent a Vote by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Legislation that would prohibit the use of any significant busing to integrate elementary schools ran into a temporary delay in the Hottse Education and Labor Committee today.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1941 a British Naval Intelligence officer named Ian Fleming recommended to Gem William (Wild Bill) Donovan that he recruit as American intelligence officers men of absolute discretion, sobriety, devotion to duty, languages, and wide experience. Donovan, a World War I hero and successful Wall Street lawyer, understood the fantasies of writers and Presidents, and in a memo to President Roosevelt promised an international secret service staffed by young officers who were calculatingly reckless, with disciplined daring and trained for aggressive action.

title: 9THRACE EXACTA CANCELED BY RAIN
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25The management at Monmouth Park canceled exacta wagering on the ninth race today after a sudden rainstorm made it necessary to shift the event from the grass course to the main track.

title: Business Briefs
description: ROME, July 25  A group of American investors, whose identity is still unknown, is negotiating to buy the Italian Lamborghini Automobile sports car maker, it was reported here today.

title: Hanoi Bombed at Night
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 25 (Agence FrancePresse)American planes bombed Hanoi during the night in their first night raid against the capital since United States bombings were resumed last April.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a secondary offering of 596,000 common shares.

title: Only One U.S. Unit Left In Vietnam Combat Role
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (UPI)Three thousand United States troops ended their combat roles today, leaving a single battalion as the last American ground combat unit in South Vietnam.

title: They're Trying Hard  Perhaps Too Hard
description: PARIS, July 25Andrd Courreges tried. The house of Chanel tried. Philippe Venet and the Lanvin people tried. The trouble is, they tried too hard. And so the second day of the fall couture showings here had everybody smiling grimly in the face of disaster.

title: Southern Railway Earnings Increase
description: The investment tax credit enacted by Congress last year was largely responsible for the Southern Railway Company's 28 per cent jump in secondtivarter earnings, the railroad reported yesterday.

title: Volpone Victor inGolf
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., July 25 (AP)Charlie Volpone, Massachusetts open champion, shot a par72 over the 7,0333kard, rainsoaked Portsmouth Country Club course today and won the New Hampshire open golf chainpionsthip. Volpone carded a,69 in the opening round yesterday for a twoday score of 141, one stroke better than Ross Coon.

title: Wounded Columbia Dean Called Likable by Students on Campus
description: Henry S. Coleman, the Columbia College dean who was shot and wounded yesterday in his campus office, is generally described by undergraduates as a likeable man.

title: Lance Reventlow, Barbara Hutton's Son, Killed
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 25 (UPI) Lance Reventlow, heir to the Woolworth fortune and son of Barbara Hutton, one of the world's richest women, was killed with three other persons yesterday in the crash of a small plane in the Colorado Rockies. He was 36 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The union representing 15,000 service employes who clean and dust offices in Manhattan opened a drive yesterday to protect these workers as they return to their homes late at night.

title: Try Prevention
description: The swarms of mosquitoes expected in the metropolitan area this summer will include the type that breed in temporary pools of water, such as in old tin cans, flower pots and the like. Accordingly Dr. Jerome Rosen, head entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History, recommends eliminating all little pools of water as the safest, most ideal way of controlling the insect around the house.

title: Stage: Speed Gets the Poppys Opens
description: The prospect of an antidrug musical may sound downright gruesome, especially with the fingerwagging aimed directly at young people. But the show called Speed Gets the Poppys that opened last night at the downtown Mercer  Brecht Theater was a pintsized charmer.

title: BOBBY UNSER WINS POCONO RACE POLE
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 25An impatient crowd of 16,000, booing, stomping feet and yelling Let them go, badgered race officials tonight into extending the first qualifying session for next Saturday's Schaefer 500.

title: Dance: Ukrainians Show Choreographic Vignettes
description: The Ukrainian Dance Company is one of the most engaging and endearing in the world. It has an immediacy of impact that is simply bewitching, and its simplicity of manner is matched only by the brilliance of its technique. Last night at the Metropolitan Opera House the company embarked on its third New York engagement, and once again enchanted its New York audience.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: RABAT, MoroccoUnusual interest abroad focuses on the American electoral campaign not merely because there is a striking difference between certain defense and diplomatic policies as enunciated by Mr. Nixon and Mr. McGovern but also because the recent Democratic convention was seen as dramatic manifestation of a problem concerning most contemporary nations, regardless of ideology. This is the famous generation gap.

title: MAX KIRSCHNER
description: Max Kirschner, a past president of the New York Retail Druggists Association and of the Jewish Pharmaceutical Society of America, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 399 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 (AP)With a full session remaining, the Keeneland summer thoroughbred yearling sale neared the $8.5million mark today and seemed assured of setting a world record for horse auctions. Keeneland sold $10.5million in horse flesh, a world mark, last year.

title: Belle Haven Takes Lead In L. I. Title Junior Sailing
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 25 The host Belle Haven Club crew, with Steve Hicks, the defending champion, as helmsman, held a 1point lead for the 49th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.

title: Prague Sentences 4 More for Political Leafleting
description: PRAGUE, July 25 (Reuters) Four persons found guilty of antiGovernment activity were sentenced here today. Their trial was the fourth involving political liberals in Prague's city courts within the last eight days.

title: Pickets Mar Housing Dedication Here
description: As pickets screamed from stoops of neighborhood tenements under the close scrutiny of the police, public officials and community leaders spoke for an hour under the broiling sun yesterday in praise of Cathedral Parkway Houses, which are to rise on 110th and 109th Streets between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.

title: Mormon Pageant In Upstate Town To Draw 100,000
description: PALMYRA, N.Y., July 25About 100,000 people will descend this week on this tiny picturesque town 25 miles southeast of Rochester to see the Hill Cumorah Pageant, which depicts the beginning of the Morman faith, the Church of the Latter Day Saints.

title: JOSEPH MILNER, 82, REALTOR, IS DEAD
description: Joseph Milner a real estate broker who figured in many large transactions in this city in the last halfcentury, died Tuesday evening in Kew Gardens (Queens) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 325 East 79th Street.

title: Finger Surgery Keeps Nicklaus Out of Golf
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 26Jack Nicklaus, who underwent surgery yesterday for an infected index finger on his right hand, is out of the national team golf championship.

title: FEMINISTS PLAN ANNUAL RALLIES
description: Feminists around the country are planning demonstrations for the week ending on Aug. 26, the 52d anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CALIFORNIACalled up Billy Parker, outfielder, and Dave Sells, righthanded pitcher, from Salt Lake City; sold Mel Queen, pitcher, to Salt Lake City and optioned Syd O'Brien, infielder, to Salt Lake City.

title: U.S. Sees Soviet Removing Most of Planes From Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  United States intelligence sources say there are strong indications that the Soviet Union is removing from Egypt most of its warplanes assigned with Soviet flying crews to the Egyptian air defenses.

title: 20 BOMBINGS MARK DEATH OF EVA PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 26 (AP)Guerrillas burned a country club and set off more than 20 time bombs today, on the 20th anniversary of the death of Mrs. Eva Duarte de Perlin. She was the wife of Maj. Gen. Juan D. Peron, deposed as President in 1955.

title: Hippies and Gerald L. K. Smith Make Ozark Resort Town a Model of Coexistence
description: EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark., July 24  On one page of Down Home, the town's new underground newspaper, an article announced the birth of a baby to a popular couple in the freak community. The headline, in letters an inch high, said, Welcome to the world, James Aaron Flatdogtales.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is with great regret that I must agree with the premise in your recent editorial that the proposed pumpedwater storage plant on Storm King Mountain is still a long way from realization. With all the efforts that have been made by the public utilities in the East, we have barely been able to keep our heads above water with regard to energy requirements.

title: Books of The Times
description: Anthologies are an agony to review. Coming to terms with a book by a single writer is difficult enough, but here, in Doors and Mirrors, I'm facing 44 of them, from 14 countries, and I feel that they are all shouting at me. Yet I think that this anthology, by Hortense Carpentier and Janet Brof is a good one, the best collection of SpanishAmerican writing I've read so far.

title: AMEX DOWN 0.05; OTC IS UP BY 0.16
description: Shares of the New Process Company fell 8 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The stock, the most actively traded issue of the day, closed at 21 after selling for most of the week below last Friday's close of 33.

title: A Goya Valued at $2Million Is Given to Metropolitan
description: The Metropolitan Museum, which already owns 10 undisputed Goya paintings, added another major work of the Spanish master to its collection this week. A fulllength portrait of a young boy, the canvas is valued at $2million to $3million by Jose LopezRey, one of the world's leading Goya experts. He believes the oil is one of the artist's masterpieces and one of his best portraits.

title: Japan Bars U.S. Bid
description: HAKONE, Japan, July 26 (AP)Japan rejected United States requests today to ease its import restrictions on American goods, particularly farm products, to help correct bilateral trade imbalance heavily in favor of Japan.

title: Merger News
description: Pepsico, Inc., and the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, 88.2 per cent owned by Pepsico, announced yesterday tender offers amounting to about $25million in connection with a previously announced proposal for Pepsico to acquire all outstanding equity securities of Wilson by January, 1973. Pepsico offers to buyl up to 500,000 Wilson common shares at $17.50 and any warrants to purchase Wilson common at $3.50. Wilson offers to purchase up to $15million principal amount of Wilson 6 per cent subordinated debentures due Oct. 15, 1988, at $920 per $1,000.

title: Caution on the Left
description: Not every longhaired troublemaker has returned to the system through George McGovern, the Presidential candidate with the Tim Leary smile. Though George has received the enthusiastic endorsements of such counterculture heavies as Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and Rolling Stone magazine, it is not because McGovern is a radical, but because Yippies Hoffman and Rubin have ceased being so and Rolling Stone never was.

title: Union Pacific Net and Sales Rise for Quarter and Half
description: The Union Pacific Corpora tion, a holding company operating five subsidiaries, reported yesterday increased revenues and earnings for the second quarter and half, with trans portation operations accounting for much of the gain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor'Isn't it about time we do what the Mexicans did decades ago  abolish the VicePresidency?

title: MRS. ABRAHAM SAFFIR
description: Mrs. Gertrude Sarni, widow of Abraham Saffir, lawyer and Brooklyn Republican leader, died last night at her home, 6345 Saunders Street in Rego Park, Queens. She was 76 years old.

title: Leisure Concepts Halted
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended overthecounter trading in securities of Leisure Concepts, Inc., of New York through Aug. 4 because of failure to receive adequate reports on the company's operations in the quarter ended June 30, when it had an indicated loss of at least $95,j000 and a working capital de1 ficit of $235,390,

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company said yesterday that it had received a $36million contract from the Baltimore Gas & Electric Company to build two power generating systems.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday Issued its latest report on changes in stockholdings by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange has not made such a list available this week.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Nothing better illustrates the change that is beginning to be felt in the traditionalist House of Representatives than the adoption of an endthewar amendment by the Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: Chinese Restaurants Flower Following Diplomatic Thaw
description: Where Mama Goldberg's kosher restaurant once served matzoh ball soup on Second Avenue, the Flower Drum Restaurant now serves NixonChou banquets at $10 a head.

title: Navy Expresses Deep Concern to Litton on Proposed Cost Rises and Delays in 30Ship, $2Billion Contract
description: The Navy has written to Litton Industries expressing significantly increased concern over the company's ability) to carry out its $1billion contract to build five LHA phibiousassault ships.

title: Did U.S. Player Miss a Triumph?
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 26 Did Bobby Fischer miss a victory in the continuation of his adjourned seventh game with Boris Spassky? This is the question heatedly discussed by the grandmasters and experts assembled here.

title: Bridge:
description: DENVER, July 26A New York pair became the first in the history of the game to win the life master pair championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League two straight years. Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J., last night repeated their 1971 victory in Chicago, and established a strong claim to be regarded as the world's best mixed partnership.

title: Kissinger Meets Here With 65 Businessmen
description: Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's chief foreign policy adviser, met with two separate groups of businessmen here yesterday for what was described by one participant as a general discussion of the Administration's attitudes on a broad range of subjects.

title: The Money Game
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Delegations of governors and mayors have trooped to Washington in recent days to have coffee with President Nixon, testify before the Senate Finance Committee, and lobby their Senators for passage of the revenuesharing bill. Already approved by the House in June and strongly backed by the Nixon Administration, this measure would provide $5.3 billion annually to the states, counties and cities.

title: Belle Haven Crew Takes L. I. Junior Sailing Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 The Belle Haven Club crew, captained by 17yearold Steve Hicks, won the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the second year in a row today. The 49th annual regatta, sailed in Lightning Class sloops, ended with three 5.5mile Olympiccourse races in 1Oto15knot northwest and westerly air off Belle Haven.

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA. July 26 (AP)The trustees of the financially troubled Penn Central Transportation Company announced formation today of a real estate reorganization board to manage its real estate empire until the giant railroad company was reorganized.

title: 7 FORD ENGINES PASS NEW EMISSION TESTS
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 26 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had met 4,000mile emissioncontrol test requirements for seven of 12 engine families for its 1973model cars. Thirtyfive vehicles have passed the tests.

title: Power Crisis Is Called Unforgivable by City Expert
description: The city's public utilities specialist, Dr. Charles Lawrence, castigated Consolidated Edison yesterday for its unforgivable performance during the heat wave.

title: Charles A. Lindbergh:
description: A supersonic transport is fast, but it is costly, noisy, a polluter, and its range is relatively short. After careful study and considerable development, the United States decided against constructing supersonic transports unless more satisfactory performances can be achieved.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: The World Hockey Association is extending its rivalry with the National League to international spheres. The new league has accepted a proposal by a Canadian television network to play six games against the world amateur champions, the Czechoslovak national team.

title: NASA CONTRACTS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The main multibilliondollar contract for development of the nation's space shuttle, a vehicle that will vault into space like a rocket but land like an airplane, was awarded yesterday to North American Rockwell.

title: SENATE REJECTS OIL IMPORT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Senate rejected today legislation that would have required much of the oil imported into the United States to be carried on tankers flying the American flag.

title: McManus Scores Upset
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., July 26 (UPI)The second major upset occurred at the $25,000 Tanglewood tennis tournament as Jaime Fillol of Chile, seeded second, was ousted by unseeded Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., 63, 36, 60, today.

title: A TREATY TO SAVE POLAR BEAR URGED
description: WASHINGTON. July 26 Government officials and conservationists called today for an international treaty to protect the polar bear.

title: Zalmen Zylbercweig, 77, Dies; Chronicler of the Yiddish Stage
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 Zalmen Zylbercweig, a historian of the Yiddish stage and editor and publisher of the multivolume Lexicon of the Yiddish Theater, in Yiddish, died yesterday. He was 77 years old and had lived in New York for many years before moving here.

title: Smoky Fire Disrupts Wall St. Trading
description: A smoky smelly fire in two Consolidated Edison transformer vaults in the Wall Street area early yesterday forced the closing of several buildings, and disrupted securities processing.

title: U. S. and Canada Resume Friendlier Talks on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Canada and the United States resumed trade talks today in a distinctly warmer atmosphere than when Washington broke off the dialogue in frustration in February.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Twice this year, on July 4 and July 5, the Massachusetts lake trout record was broken by anglers fishing Quabbin Reservoir.

title: DANIEL I. AUSTER
description: Daniel 1. Auster, a retired lawyer specializing in customs work, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home in the Croydon Hotel, 12 East 86th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: MORE TESTIMONY ON HIDDEN OWNERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) A former bank clerk told a House committee today that he agreed to have horses registered in his name after being wined and dined by a horse broker blacklisted by the racing establishment.

title: George Christian Will Work With Connally to Help Nixon
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 26George Christian, a White House press secretary under President Lyndon B. Johnson, said today that he would work with former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally to swing Democratic voters to President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Surely I can't be the only person who thinks it is farcical to talk about the war ending in Vietnam while we're dropping an increasing tonnage or bombs on an unhappy country we are systematically destroying along with its inhabitants. We are meant to be distracted from this unending horror by Mr. Nixon's praiseworthy peace efforts in Russia and China. These are calculated moves.

title: Peru Phone Company Seized
description: LIMA, Peru, July 26 (UPI)The military Government today assumed control of the National Telephone Company, owned by shareholders in Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg. A special decree yesterday authorized the transport ministry to expropriate 270,900 company shares worth $6million.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) The Communist party filed suit in Federal District Court today to get on the fall ballot in Pennsylvania. The decision to file the court action was announced earlier by Anthony Monteiro, the party's candidate, and Spenser Coxe, executive director of the city's American Civil Liberties Union chapter.

title: Brazil's Bishops Press for Common Man's Rights
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 26  Brazil's Roman Catholic Bishops in the last two months have begun to stake out a clear position as defenders of the little man and champions of human rights in a country where varying degrees of repression are the rule.

title: Miss Frindel Married To Mel David Morris
description: Miss Bonnie D. Frindel and Mel David Morris of London were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Samuel Frindel Jr. Rabbi Henry Glasser of Temple Ansche Chesed performed the ceremony.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS LIMIT ON SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, July 26President Nixon appealed to Congress today to protect the economic interest of all American citizens by enacting a $250billion spending ceiling, and threatened to veto any measure he deemed excessive.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOLS GET $375 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it had awarded $375million since the beginning of the year to schools that train doctors, dentists, nurses, veterinarians and other health professionals.

title: New York Plan for Jobs Held a Failure
description: The New York Plan, which was signed 19 months ago by Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay with promises to provide training for 800 blacks and Puerto Ricans in the construction industry, was condemned yesterday as a dismal failure.

title: E.E.C. Cancels Taxes
description: GENEVA, July 26The Common Market announced today that it would cancel most of series of special import taxes that the United States had complained were in violation of the European bloc's international trade commitments.

title: Schneck, No. 669 in Draft, Is Swinging a Weighty Bat for Languorous Mets
description: When the Mets began this season, they were depending on a $95,000 player to lead them to the pennant. Now, as they struggle to stay in the pennant race, they're relying on a player whom they once valued at $500.

title: Personal Finance: Car Flood Damage
description: If you know enough about an automobile to repair one, you may be able to get a very good buy in a used car right now.

title: Murder in Uganda
description: A commission of inquiry in Uganda, headed by British judge, has confirmed what had long been assumed: Two Americans investigating the report of a tribal massacre in the Ugandan Army were murdered by Ugandan troops July 9, 1971. Now it is up to General Idi Amin, Uganda's military ruler, to make good his pledge on appointing the commission that he would prosecute vigorously any officers implicated in the killings.

title: Jersey Standard Officer And Kaiser Chief Named
description: The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) elected a new president yesterday and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation named a new chief executive officer.

title: WIDE STRIKE PERIL EASED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, July 26Britain's industrial crisis eased today with the release of five dock workers whose imprisonment had led to widespead unofficial strikes by thousands of workers.

title: 49ers Beasley Is Disabled
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 26 (AP)The wide receiver, Terry Beasley, will be out of action two to four weeks as a result of fracturing the big toe on his right foot during San Francisco 49er drills.

title: Egypt Declines Comment
description: CAIRO, July 26  Egyptian officials today declined all comment on Premier Golda Meir's appeal to President Sadat.

title: The U.N. Assessment
description: The honor of the United States, solvency of the United Nations and prospects for international cooperation for peace will all be at issue when a Congressional conference committee meets soon to consider a State Department appropriations bill.

title: SUMMON FIRST IN YORKERS RACE
description: YONKERS, July 26 (UPI)Sonnetson, driven by Ken McNutt, captured the $6,000 New Haven Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: U.S. Terms Damage to Dikes Minor and Accidental
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Administration said today that any damage done to the North Vietnamese dike system by American bombing was accidental and had only the most incidental and minor im pact on the system.

title: AMERICO CASTRO, SPANISH WRITER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 26  Dr. Americo Castro, Ford Emeritus Professor of Spanish at Princeton University and one of the world's most distinguished Hispanists, died yesterday in Spain. He was 87 years old.

title: GAMBLING STUDY BEGINS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, July 26A series of hearings on proposed wider legalized gambling in New Jersey opened here today in the wake of the defeat last week of a state incometax bill proposed by Gov. William T. Cahill as part of a sweeping taxreform program.

title: Warning by Sadat
description: CAIRO, July 26 (Reuters)President Sadat warned today that a long struggle lay ahead in the conflict between Israel and Egypt and said Israel should know that nature and history were on the Arabs side.

title: Five Gunmen Wound Four In Brooklyn Bar Shooting
description: Four persons were shot and, wounded, at least one critically, when five armed men, invaded a Brooklyn bar early yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons is beginning to put into effect a tenyear plan for building more than sixty new correctional facilities that will cost taxpayers over $650 million at present estimates. This is wellintended, under President Nixon's mandate to make the Federal prison system a model, but such a construction program seems to many critics the wrong way to proceed.

title: PRICES SLIP A BIT IN STOCK TRADING
description: The stock market posted a slight decline yesterday for the second straight day. There was some weakness in glamour issues, steels, chemicals, airlines and oils.

title: Peking Paper Opens a Drive Against Turgid Prose
description: PEKING, July 26  Peking's official newspaper, the oracle of Chinese Communism for more than a quarter of a century, has opened a sudden campaign against the turgid prose that fills Chinese publications, including its own formerly unassailable pages.

title: Screen: Cryptic Manor
description: The night that Evelyn came out of the graveclimbing up from the crypt beneath the ruined chapel beyond the wild ravine in the farthest reaches of the manor parkLord Cumberland completely took leave of his senses. You see, she had been his wife, and possibly she had been unfaithful, and he blamed himself a little for her death. And what with the pressure of his guilt and her guilt, he was having no fun at all with his new wife, Gladysespecially after the ghost of Evelyn began appearing outside bedroom windows, or dressed as a maid dispensing warm milk from the kitchen.But it was Evelyn herself, red hair streaming above her hollow-eyed skull, who had Lord Cumberland thrashing in the mud that rain-drenched night, and who provided the title for Emilio P. Miraglia's new movie, "The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.It is a lovely title, in the sense that half a dozen people have asked me if somebody is joking, or if there really is a movie called "The Night Evelyn . . ." But I can think of other titles for this movie just as apt. For example: "The Night Aunt Agnes Was Fed to the Pet Foxes," or "The Night They Buried Alfred Alive." That last was nobody's fault actually; it's just that when it came time to shovel the dirt over him, the poisonous snake bite on his neck hadn't quite done Alfred in.I've told a bit; perhaps not enough. But certain movie stories, like certain lives, have a classic purity and simplicity that should not be disturbed. So I shall leave the plot of "Evelyn" undisturbed, scarcely pausing to mention the day that Cousin George falls into the sulphuric acid-filled swimming pooljust after Gladys kills the mysterious Susan, before herself succumbing to the strychnine in her bottle of champagne."The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave" is an Italian-made British horror movie, and despite the incredible English dubbing (Lord Cumberland seems to have inherited the voice of Ronald Colman) it is very much less British than Italian. The men might all have come from a convention of Milanese hair dressers, and the women, coiffed and disrobed to the limits of mid-1960's daring splendor, might have been their clientsor their assistants. When Lord Cumberland drives in the country, he passes rows of stately poplars. And his ancestral mansion, the splendid Cumberland Manor, looks as though it had been designed by Giulio Romano for some minor duke of Mantua.

title: Notes on People
description: So I go from diplomacy to politics, said Kenneth B. Keating at a luncheon in New Delhi marking his farewell as United States Ambassador to India.

title: Predatorsand Predators
description: A bill that might have gone far to take both the Federal Government and the states out of an unsavory business has been passed by the House of Representatives with amendments that all but undermine its originally good intent. The measure, which had the support of such conservationist Congressmen as Representatives Dingell of Michigan and Saylor of Pennsylvania, was supposed freeze into law President Nixon's excellent administrative order forbidding the use of poisonous chemicals on public lands for the purpose of controlling supposedly predatory animals.

title: Rockefeller to Nominate Nixon; Top Staff Aides to Assist Drive
description: President Nixon has asked Governor Rockefeller, once a political rival, to place his name in nomination at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach next month, Republican sources said last night.

title: Mc Graw Basks in Star Glow
description: ATLANTA, July 26 The ma ior leagues headed back to their pennant races today after an AllStar Game that produced another victory for the National League and new controversy for Earl Weaver.

title: Eagleton Hints He'll Quit Race if Polls Are Negative
description: HONOLULU, July 26Senator Thomas F. Eagleton indicated on his arrival here today that if public opinion polls over the next 10 days or two weeks showed a strongly unfavorable response to his disclosures of medical illness, he would withdraw from the ticket as the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, regardless of Senator George McGovern's encouragement of him in the last two days.

title: City Health Agency Charges 21 Places With Violating Code
description: The Health Department has made public the names of 21 more restaurants and food stores in which it has found serious violations of the City Health Code.

title: Recruiting Station Bombed
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 26 (UPI)A pipe bomb exploded in the dowtnown Army recruiting station today, blowing out the front door and windows and cause damake to the surrounding area. Detectives said the bomb went off at 5:10 A.M., and caused $4,000 in damage.

title: A 3Judge Panel Stays Ellsberg's Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 A special threejudge panel of Federal appellate judges, ineluding Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, met in a Pasadena hotel room this morning and stayed the beginning of the Pentagon papers trial until a wiretapping issue was resolved.

title: U.S. Bows in Volleyball
description: BUCHAREST, July 26 (AP)The United States men's volleyball team suffered a 30 setback today against a local club at Piatra Neamt. The scores were, 155, 154, 157.

title: Remember Henna? It's Back
description: The pinup girl of the nineteentwenties and thirties was redhaired. The screen idols women wanted to be like were (depending, of course, on the generation they belonged to) Clara Bow, Nancy Carroll and Ann Sheridan.

title: Personalities: Brundage Cautions Kenya
description: The Olympic ideals are becoming scarce, Avery Brundage said recently. His latest battle was staged yesterday when Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned Kenya to keep Government out of the selection process for that country's Olympic team. There has been a dispute between the Kenya National Sports Council (a Government organization) and the Kenya Olympics Association. If Brundage's committee finds that the council has interfered, the Kenya delegation may be forced to stay home. That would mean the absence of such goldmedal prospects as Kipchoge Keino (1,500 meters), Robert Ouko (800) and Naftali Temu (10,000). Keino and Temu are Olympic champions at their distances.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Demonstrating how a Bronx gasoline station at 175th Street and Jerome Avenue allegedly tampered with its pumps to deliver less gasoline than was being registered, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson announced yesterday that inspections of the city's 5,000 filling stations would be stepped up.

title: Gerulaitis Easy Victor
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 26 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis of New York, the fourthseeded player, gained the quarterfinals of the Western junior tennis championship today with a 60, 61 rout of Joe Edles of Long Beach, Calif. Brian Teacher of San Diego, John Holladay of La Jolla, Calif.; Freddie De Jesus of Puerto Rico; Billy Martin of Palos Verde, Calif., and Pat DuPre of Birmingham, Ala., also advanced.

title: Jets Hammond OneMan Depth Chart
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 26 If Gary Hammond could divide himself like an amoeba it wouldn't be long before he might make up an entire football teamcomplete with substitutes. Right now his name pops up in more places on the New York Jets depth chart than anybody else.

title: MISS FERRO SHARES JERSEY GOLF LEAD
description: DEAL, N. J., July 26Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks carded a 79 today for a tworound total of 155 and tied the firstround leader Cindy Ferro of Forest Hill, in the 39th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54hole strokeplay championship at the Hollywood Country Club.

title: Soviet Gives Activist a Light Sentence
description: MOSCOW, July 26  Gavriil I. Shapiro, the Jewish activist who has sought emigration to Israel and has evaded active duty as a reserve officer in the Soviet armed forces, was sentenced today to one year's correctional work without loss of freedom.

title: Building Inspector Is Dismissed for Taking a Bribe
description: A Buildings Department inspector was dismissed from his job yesterday after lie pleaded guilty to taking a $100 bribe. He was the eighth inspector to he cited for corruption in the last month.

title: Czechoslovakia Reports Sending Six in Moravia to Jail in 5th Subversion Trial
