description: TORONTO, July 27 (Canadi an Press)The Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., announced today it was beginning construction of a $3.87million sawmill in Kap uskasing.

title: Books of The Times
description: By a formula of his own devising, Sey mour Topping, assistant managing editor of this newspaper, has combined the per sonal and the historic in a narrative in which each quality enhances the other. His experiences in China and Southeast Asia explain, illustrate and sometimes dram atize the course of history. But they never

title: LEONE SEEKS RULE ON POWER LOSSES
description: Borough President Sebastian Leone of Brooklyn said yester day he would ask the Public Service Commission to deter mine if the Consolidated Edi son Company should reimburse businessmen for losses suffered through power outages in the last two weeks.

title: Providence Guild Neutral
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 27 (AP)The Providence News paper Guild voted today to de clare neutrality in all political matters and to dissociate it self from any organizational endorsements. The action fol lowed the recent endorsement of esnator George McGovern for President by the guild's International Executive Board.

title: Senator Pell's Mother Dies
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 27 Mrs. Matilda Bigelow Koehler, mother of Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, died today at her son's borne here. She was 77 years old and lived at 115 East 92d Street, New York.

title: Nixon Terms '72 Election Clearest Choice of Century
description: WASHINGTON, July 27President Nixon said today that the differences between him and the Democratic Presi dential nominee on fundamental questions of foreign and domestic policy were so wide that American voters would have the clearest choice in this century when they go to the polls in November.

title: Prof. Charles Wahl, 60, Taught French at Brooklyn
description: Dr. Charles Wahl, assistant professor of modern languages at Brooklyn College since 1959, died Wednesday in Brooklyn, where he lived. His age was 60.

title: Furloughs for 1,000 Planned by Pennsy
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) The Penn Central Transpor tation Company, estimating it sustained about $30million in damages and lost business dur ing the June flood, said today it was furloughing 1,000 employes in an emergency economy move.

title: ALLEN J.ELLENDER OF LOUISIANA DIES
description: Senator Allen J. Ellender oft Louisiana, chairman of the Ap propriations Committee and president pro tempore of the Senate, died last night of al heart attack at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 81 years old.

title: Just Who Does He Think He Is?
description: A T the outset of the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 someone suggested to Woodrow Wilson that he might find it useful to read a handbook, which had been written for the British delegation by C. K. Webster, about the Congress of Vienna and the international system it created. The President flatly refused to do so, with some derogatory remarks about balanceofpower politics and those who had practiced it.

title: Nevada Gambling Taxes Up
description: RENO, Nev., July 27 (UPI) Gambling taxes brought $54.9 million to the State of Nevada in the fiscal year just ended, an increase of 31.7 per cent over the previous year.

title: 100 Children Are Relocated
description: SALISBURY, July 27 (Reuters)  Rhodesian security forces have moved about 100 Tang wena children from their farm stead home to Umtali, about 130 miles from here near the Mozambique border, where they will be put into institutions.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ALGIERSIt is still too early to assess the importance of the with drawalat President Anwar elSadat's requestof the bulk of Moscow's enormous military mission in Egypt. Such is the view of Houari Boume diene, President of Algeria and one of the Arab world's most Important leaders.

title: TENNECO RESULTS AT RECORD LEVELS Burlington Northern, Eaton and Stauffer Also Gain
description: Tenneco, Inc., yesterday re ported an increase of 13 per cent in secondquarter earnings on a gain of 15 per cent in reve nues, bringing the halfyear re sults up 16 and 17 per cent, respectively, all setting rec ords.

title: STARK'S EXPULSION STAYED BY COURT
description: Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Ap peals issued a limited stay yes terday of a District Court de cision that would have permit ted the expulsion of Robert W. Stark Jr. Inc. from the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Guards Hit Berlin Apartment
description: BERLIN, July 27 (AP)East German border guards fired at a fleeing man today and some of their bullets struck a West Berlin apartment building. A police spokesman said no one was injured, apparently includ ing the man trying to flee, who was captured about 100 feet from West Berlin.

title: Voting for Peace
description: President Nixon's biting attack on critics of his Indo china policy at his news conference yesterday is not likely to stem the rising tide of antiwar sentiment that found expression in both houses of Congress this week.

title: Mets Top Pirates, 10
description: PITTSBURGH, Friday, July 28 The anemic Mets picked on the healthy Pirates for their most ferocious hitting explosion in six weeks and their lustiest run production In four weeks. But when they had finished playing six hours and one min ute of baseball early this morn ing, they had gained nothing.

title: Ballet a Base for Ukrainian Folk Troupe
description: The Ukrainian Dance Com pany currently at the Met ropolitan Opera House for a twoweek run, is one of the bestknown dance groups ex ported by the Soviet Union under the banner of a folk ensemble. Yet it is anything but an amateur ethnic dance company.

title: It's Fischer Again
description: Boris Spassky resigned yes terday in the eighth game of the world championship chess match in Reykjavik, Iceland. Bobby Fischer, the American challenger, now has 5 points to Spassky's 3, and needs only 7 more to take the title. Details on Page 32.

title: Soul Festival: A Curtain Call for Rhythm and Blues
description: It was state  of  the  art rhythm and blues night at the Soul at the Center concert in Alice Tully Hall last night. The groups ran the gamut from the goldenoldie sounds of the revived Moonglows to the newer rhythms of Bobby Knight and the Soul Society, New Birth and the Niteliters.

title: Austin Subdues Cramer
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., July 27 (UPI)Pat Cramer of South Africa, seeded No. 8, was de feated today by Jeff Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., in the $25,000 Tanglewood tennis tournament. Austin downed Cramer, 62, 64. Butch See wagen of Bayside, Queens downed Zan Guerry of Look out Mountain, Tenn., 76, 62.

title: DR. WILSON C. STARR, EYE SPECIALIST, 40
description: Dr. Wilson C. Starr, associate ophthalmologist at the Eye In stitute of ColumbiaPresbyteri an Medical Center and at St. Luke's, Hospital, died yesterday in Rome after suffering injuries in a fall. He was 40 years old and lived at 815 Fifth Avenue.

title: Shell Reports Gain
description: The oil industry continued to report mixed earnings re sults as the Shell Oil Company yesterday announced sharply higher profits and the Atlantic Richfield Company reported lower net income.

title: Washington Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Schoolyard Quintets to Play At Felt Forum Next Month
description: Schoolyard basketball, an art form developed in New York just as jazz was born in New Orleans, will move indoors to the highly pol ished inlaid floor of Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Architect Institute Backs Madison Ave. Mall Plan
description: The New York vhapter of the American Institute of Architects announced its support yester day of the Madison Avenue mall plan advanced by the Office of Midtown Planning and Development.

title: FIRE BASE YIELDED TO FM A 2D TIME
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 28  Fire Base Bas togne, an important strong point defending the southwest approach to Hue, has been abandoned to North Vietnamese forces in the face of intense Communist shelling and ground attacks, a Saigon spokesman reported yesterday.

title: Executive Changes
description: William J. Bailey, 57 years old, has been elected president of the Carrier Corporation, effec tive Nov. 1. Mr. Bailey, who has been executive vice president, succeeds Charles V. Fenn, who has de cided to retire ahead of his scheduled retirement date in Septemlier, 1973. Mr. Fenn wilt remain director.

title: SENATE ENDORSES RISE IN SPENDING FOR NUCLEAR SUB
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Senate endorsed today the Nixon Administration's pro posal to spend nearly $1billion to accelerate development of the Trident missilelaunching submarine.

title: Youthful Virtuosity
description: The quintet that Jimmy Heath has brought into Jazz City this week (the last week before the club, on Third Street at the Avenue of the Americas, reverts to being Folk City) is an exceptionally good balance of youthful virtuosity and pol ished experience.

title: A Frazzled Spassky Fizzles After 10 Moves
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 27 The eighth game of the world championship chess match ap pears to have been a disaster for Boris Spassky. To the dis may of onlookers, Spassky, after 10 moves of an English opening that gave him at least equality despite his playing black, seemed unable to main tain the high quality of his play.

title: Grumman Is Seeking $1Billion in Subcontracts in U.S. SpaceShuttle Program
description: The new president of the Grumman Aerospace Corpora tion, Joseph G. Gavin Jr., said yesterday that he hoped to ob tain $1billion worth of subcon tracts in the program to build a space shuttle.

title: DR. CHARLES C. LUND, DID STUDY OF BURNS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 28 (AP)Dr. Charles Carroll Lund. retired clinical professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School, died yesterday at his home. He was 77 years old.

title: Credibility Gap Seen
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 United States specialists on Chinese affairs and intelligence experts said today that they be lieved Peking had finally de cided to report Marshal Lin's death because of a growing credibility gap in other Com munist countries and the so called thirdworld nations.

title: Confirmation in Algiers
description: ALGIERS, July 28 (Reuters)  The Chinese Embassy here today officially confirmed that Mr. Lin died in a plane crash in Mongolia last Sept. 12 while fleeing to the Soviet Union after having tried to kill Chair man Mao.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday ap proved freightrate increases for the Middle West anti the southwestern motorfreight rate areas.

title: HOLIDAY MAGIC FACES TRIAL IN MINNESOTA
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) Holiday Magic, Inc., a Cali fornia cosmetics concern, and two Minnesota distributors have been bound over for trial next month on charges of vio lating a state law banning multilevel distributorships.

title: Tokyo Stocks at Record
description: TOKYO, July 28  Tokyo stock prices rose sharply to a record high today, exceeding 3,900 yen on the Tokyo Dow Jones adverage for the first time since the stock market was reopened in 1949.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagleton Asserts on Coast He Will Stay in the Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri said today that I will stay in the race as the Democratic nominee for Vice President. He made his remark before the Presidential nomi nee, Senator George McGov ern of South Dakota, implied tonight a shift from his po sition of allout support for the VicePresidential nominee.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: July 28, 1972 THE PRESIDENT

title: REV. GEORGE KOPFMAN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 The Very Rev. George Kopf man, subfriar of St. Louis Ber trand Roman Catholic Church, died of a heart attack today in Jewish Hospital. He was 45 years old.

title: Princess Chantal Married in France
description: PARIS, July 28Princess Chantal, a daughter of the Count of Paris, pretender to the French throne, was mar ried today to Baron Francois Xavier de Sambucy de Sorgue, of Provence, in civil and re ligious ceremonies at the town hall and the royal chapel of Dreux, 40 miles west of Paris.

title: Waldheim and Bush Meet After Criticism by Nixon
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28Relations between the United States and Secretary General Waldheim grew more strained today as Mr. Wald heim, responding to criticism by President Nixon, called in George Bush, the United States representative.

title: Another Channel
description: The Yea! and Nayl pieces on public television by Messrs. Cater and St. John add up to a nondebate. One protagonist focuses on one target, the other on another, neither on the real mark. Yea!Nay! The articles should have been serviced with ex planation rather than exclamation points. There is agreement (which I share) only on one point: that public television is in deep peril.

title: MISS POTTER GAINS U.S. OLYMPIC TEAM
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) Cindy Potter, 21 years old, of Dllas, was ahead from start to finish today as she led three qualifiers for the women's threemeter springboard event in the final trials for the United States Olympic diving team.

title: Commodities Broker Wins Judgment for Lost Seat
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)A Circuit Court has awarded $700,000 in damages to an in ternational commodities broker who lost his seat on the Chi cago Board of Trade in 1961 for allegedly failing to meet trading commitments.

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: Dynamics Corp to File Reorganization Petition
description: Andrew Lozyniak, president of the Dynamics Corporation of America, announced yesterday that the company would file petition Monday for reorganiza tion under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: AETNA LIFE PROFITS INCREASE SHARPLY
description: The two unrelated Aetnain surance companies reported widely divergent net earnings results yesterday, but operat ing earnings of both insurers showed strong gains.

title: RELATIVES BACK PHILLIPS'S ALIBI
description: The alibi for Patrolman Wil liam R. Phillips for the night that James Smith and Sharon Stango were murdered was supported here yesterday by two more of his relatives Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Mc Kee the uncle and aunt at whose home Mr. Phillips says he spent much of that night.

title: MURPHY APPOINTS TOPRANKING AIDE
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday appointed Assistant Chief Inspector Ar thur C. Grubert, an authority on organized crime, as chief of inspectional services in charge of the department's anticorrup tion, intelligence and efficiency units.

title: Senate Votes to Cat Off Funds for RainMaking
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (Reuters)The Senate voted today for an amendment cut ting off Defense Department funds for any use of rain making or creation of forest fires as a weapon of war.

title: Nastase, Tiriac in Semifinals
description: DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 28 (UPI)Ilie Nastase and Ion Tiriac of Rumania, Szabolcs Baranyi of Hungary and Juergen Fassbender of West Germany qualified today for the men's singles semifinals of the Rochus Club's international tournament.

title: WILSHIRE STUDIES JERSEY MERGER
description: Merger News

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Vernitron Corporation announced yesterday that reg istration statement for a sec ondary offering of a maximum of 1,379,181 common shares, originally filed Dec. 30, 1971, had been declared effective by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 6th Antiwar Veteran Freed
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 28 (AP)The last of six anti war veterans indicted on charges of conspiring to dis rupt the Republican National Convention with violence was freed today on $25,000 bond. Peter Mahoney, 25 years old, was released from the Leon County Jail after a representa tive of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War met the bond with funds he said came from private contributions.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CUSTER, S. D., July 28 Senator George McGovern rode in a parade here todaynot on a horse, despite his Western hat and suede jacket, but in a closed maroonandwhite Lin coln Continental.

title: SHELL OIL AND CHASE APPEAR TO FALL OUT
description: The Shell Oil Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank have apparently had a falling out.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: A joint venture of U. S. In dustries, Inc., and the Blake Construction Company received a $102.3million Army contract for a new hospital building at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center,

title: Continued RetailSales Strength Is Seen
description: Retail sales will benefit from improving consumer confi dence and do well in the rest of 1972 despite any changes in the consumersavings rate, a rominent investment banker specializing in the retailing in dustry predicted in an inter view this week.

title: Cowboys Triumph, 207, Over College AllStars
description: CHICAGO, July 28The Col lege AllStars at least scored on the Dallas Cowboys with an 80 yard drive in the final quarter. That was about the best thing one could say for the AllStar game here tonight, won easily by the National Football League's champions for the ninth straight year, before a crowd of 54,162 at Soldier Field. The final score was 207 for Dallas.

title: Ford Recalls Police Cars
description: DETROIT, July 28 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company an nounced today that it was re calling 3,025 police interceptor cars in the United States and 146 in Canada for replacement of the rear fuel tube and fuel hose leading from the gas tank to the engine because of a po tential for fire.

title: Mrs. Ellen Stevenson, ExWife Of Presidential Candidate, Dies
description: HAMMOND, Ind., July 28 (UP1)Mrs. Ellen Borden Ste venson, the former wife of the late Adlai E. Stevenson, Gov ernor of Illinois, Democratic candidate for President in 1952 and 1956 and representative at the United Nations, died to day of cancer at. St. Catherine's Hospital. She was 64 years old

title: WalkOat Wrong Call, Says Namath's Lawyer
description: Conceding that anything can happen in these types of negotiations, Joe Namath's lawyer denied yesterday that the quarterback planned to leave the Jets camp on Mon day unless he signed a con tract.

title: Dave Anderson Retooling, but Without All the Tools
description: Sports of The Times

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Carbide Price Rise
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion said yesterday that it would increase the price of general purpose injectionmolding and blowmolding grades of high density polyethylene by 1 kent a pound, to 13 cents a pound in railroad hoppercar quantities of 100,000 pounds or more, be ginning Sept. 1.

title: Tail Engine of Plane Falls Near Homes on the Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) The tail engine of a Conti bental Airlines DC10 that had just left Los Angeles fell off yesterday, dropping nearly a ton of smoking hot metal on Hollywood and Beverly Hills. No one was hit by the debris and the plane landed safely on its remaining two engines.

title: MESKILL WARNS MAYORS ON AID
description: HARTFORD, July 28 (UPI) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut warned municipal officials in the state today against hoping for further fi nancial aid because of the state's $30million budget sur plus.

title: Executive at C.B.S. News Moving to A.B.C. in Fall
description: Ernest Leiser, executive pro ducer of Columbia Broadcast ing System News, will become executive producer of the Amer ican Broadcasting Company's new weekly news program, The Reasoner Report, in October.

title: Elaine Bitel, Model, Is Bride Of Timothy Richard Murphy
description: Mrs. Norman F. Fishbein was matron of honor for her sister. Other attendants were Mrs. David E. Blessing, an other sister of the bride; Mrs. A. James Murphy, sisterin law of the bridegroom, and the Misses Donna McDermott and Susan Palacek. A. James Murphy was his brother's best man.

title: 13 Puppies Die in Plane
description: ST. LOUIS, July 28 (UPI) Thirteen dead puppies were discovered yesterday aboard a plane at Lambert Field. The dogs apparently suffocated in their cramped orange crate type boxes, Jim Dodson, super visor of the Humane Society of Missouri Shelter, said. The dogs were in a shipment bound from Beloit, Kan., to other cities.

title: Fund Passes $2,000 For Rochester Man Blinded in Gouging
description: ROCHESTER, July 28 (UPI) While the Rochester police continued their search for the robber who gouged out the eyes of two persons on July 9, a fund set up to aid one of the victims passed its original goal of $2,000.

title: 1972 Christmas Trees May Be Costlier
description: ALBANY, July 28  With 124 shopping days until Christmas, experts at the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets report that the Christmas tree industry is gradually be coming more sophisticated.

title: Paula E.Howe Wed To John Nordin 3d
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., July 28  Miss Paula Eleanor Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. C. Howe of Glen Cove, L. I., and Sanford, Fla., was married here this evening to John Edward Nor din 3d, son of Mr. Nordin Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Mrs. Nordin. The Rev. Dr. R. M. Minto, chaplain at Stan ford University, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Latta.

title: Western Union Tuning Out Singing Telegram
description: After 39 years of heralding birthdays, anniversaries, holi days, jobs, bon voyages and just about every other occa sion worthy and unworthy of lyrical note39 years after Lucille. Lipps started it all by singing Happy Birthday into the phone to Rudy Vallee Western Union's singing telegram is about to vanish from the American scene.

title: Text of Chinese Statement on Lin Piao
description: ALGIERS, July 28 (Reuters) Following, in translation from the Arabic, is the text of a statement issued by the Chinese Embassy here today in response to questions about the fate of former De fense Minister Lin Piao:

title: Slow Medicine
description: The United States ran a $590million trade deficit last month. That brought the excess of imports over exports during the first half of this year to $3.34 billion, or 60 per cent more than 1971's total trade deficit of $2.05 billion.

title: JAPAN CONCEDES LITTLE ON TRADE
description: HAKONE, Japan, July 28 A United States trade delega tion has failed so far to obtain from the Japanese Government any major concessions that would cut a projected $3.8bil lion American deficit in trade with Japan this year.

title: TWO TEAMS LEAD GOLF BY STROKE WITH 130 SCORES
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 28  All I was doing was praying for him, said Kermit Zarley after he and his partner Bryant (Babe) Hiskey finished with a 63 today and tied for the lead at 130 in the $200.000 national team championship. Sharing the topspot with them after 36 holes were Lanny Wadkins, the rookie, and Gibby Gilbert after a round of 64.

title: Suspect in Columbia Shooting Urged by Mother to Surrender
description: The mother of the suspended student being sought in the shooting of the Columbia Col lege dean of students, Henry S. Coleman, said yesterday that she feared for the youth's safety and joined the Congress of Racial Equality in urging him to surrender to the Har lembased group for his own safety.

title: Senate's New President Pro Tern
description: Man in the News

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: State U. Opens Study Of Why Dormitories Are Not Fully Used
description: ALBANY, July 28 (AP)The State University has initiated a study of why 5,000 vacancies exist in dormitories on the everexpanding university cam puses and what to do about the empty rooms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Peddler Crackdown Promised

title: ASHE BEATS ROCHE BEFORE RAIN HITS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe downed Tony Roche, 75, 62, in the only quarterfinal played before rain washed out the remaining matches today in the $50,000 First National Tennis Classic.

title: Personalities: Taylor Joins Nets
description: Although the Nets wanted to save the announcement for Lou Carnesecca's return from Spain, Brian Taylor admitted yesterday that he had signed with the New Yorker basket ball team for next season and will leave Princeton Univer sity. Taylor, sometimes known as the Black Bill Bradley, averaged 25 points a game last season for the Tigers. His reasons for quit ting: One, money. Two, the chance to play in New York. Three, New York did so well in the American Basketball Association playoffs last sea son. Carnesecca, the Nets' coachgeneral manager, had signed Taylor several weeks ago to a multiyear, nocut pact. When it comes to money, there was the possi bility there wouldn't be any next year, said Taylor.

title: PRINCIPAL IS UPHELD ON BAN OF OUTSIDER
description: A Queens Criminal Court judge yesterday upheld the right of a high school principal to eject a person he had cause to consider disruptive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Essex Jail Inmates, Assured by Cahill, End Work Protest
description: NORTH. CALDWELL, N. J., July 28 (AP)A work stoppage by prisoners at the Essex County Corrections Center here has ended after three and a half days.

title: Hotel Man Killed in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, July 29 (UPI)Gun men kidnapped and then shot to death a 51yearold hotel executive in Belfast yesterday, and others forced their way; into the home of a former, Cabinet minister in the North.; ern Ireland provincial govern ment, fired a shot at him, and, then set the house ablaze.

title: Mrs. Lyman Wins by Shot
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 28Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Plain field shot a 43, 4487 at the Essex County Country Club to day to win a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tourna ment by one stroke.

title: Sadat's Move: Bid for U.S. Pressure on Israel Is Seen
description: News Analysis

title: 22 U S. Editors to Visit China This Fall,
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Contacts between the United States and China are to be stepped up later this year with a visit to the mainland by 22 American newspaper editors and a tour of United States medical facilities by a group of Chinese physicians.

title: Congress in Chile Ousts a 2d Minister From Interior Post
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 28 (AP)For the second time in seven months, the Opposition dominated Congress has re moved President Salvador Al lende Gossens's Interior Min ister.

title: PARIS SAID TO SELL ARMS TO CARACAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) United States defense sources report that Venezuela has or dered $60million worth of arms from France in a deal described as the largest single Latin American purchase of ground weapons since World War II.

title: GASSALE TERMS SET BY MAGELLAN GROUP
description: The Magellan Petroleum Corporation has advised its stockholders that a group it heads plans to sell the Pacific Lighting Corporation of Cali fornia more than $1.3billion of Australian natural gas over 25 years. The original announce ment was made on June 29 but terms were not disclosed then. The group plans to export 500 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, subject to approval of the Australian Government and the California Public Utili ties Commission.

title: New Stock Issues Do Well as Group; BaskinRobbins Up
description: Public trading began in nine new issues on the overthe counter market in the week ended yesterday, and most of the stocks encountered a fairly good investor reception in quiet trading.

title: Gold Speculation Returns
description: PARIS, July 28While calm has returned to the currency markets since intervention by American authorities nine days ago to support the exchange rate of the dollar, the specula tive fever has returned in gold.

title: National Folk Fete Draws 300 Artists
description: VIENNA, Va., July 28  The National Folk Festival, which has been roaming around the country since its founding in 1934, is sinking its roots a little deeper in the Washington area this weekend.

title: On Ms. Night, the Bar Was Filled With Messrs
description: Oh, no, they said, it was not because Thursday hap pened to be a slow bar night. The real reason Sean and Peggy Doyle decided to do something special for women in their East Side barthey said  was because they thought it was time that women had their day.

title: DOUGLAS ENTERS ELLSBERG TRIAL
description: YAKIMA, Wash., July 28 Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court will decide over the weekend whether to delay the Pentagon papers trial until a wiretapping controversy is resolved.

title: Production of Cars Declined for Week And in Year to Date
description: DETROIT, July 28 (AP)  The United States auto industry built its five millionth car of the year Wednesday, the trade newspaper Automotive News reported today.

title: Count CoudenhoveKalergi Dies; Founded the PanEurope Union
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, July 28 (Reuters)Count Richard Cou denhoveItalergi, founder of the PanEuropean Union half a cen tury ago, died yesterday after a stroke. His age was 77.

title: HIAWATHA IS MADE INTO SMALL MUSICAL
description: Last year, Edwin Roberts, a composer, and Bill Tchakirides, a theater director, turned Lewis Carroll's The Hunting of the Snark into a musical theater piece of considerable charm for adults as well as the children for whom it was intended. The work had a number of success ful performances at the Whit ney Museum, where it was introduced.

title: AmericanWestern Air Merger Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Civil Aeronautics Board disap proved today, by a 41 vote, the proposed merger of Amer ican Airlines, Inc., and Western Air Lines, Inc. The merger was first negotiated in late 1970.

title: Panther Guilty of Murder
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28 (UPI) Elmer Pratt, 29yearold for mer Black Panther deputy min ister, was convicted of first degree murder today in the 1968 fatal shooting of a school teacher, Mrs. Caroline Olsen, 27, on a Santa Monica, Calif., ??nis court.

title: Soul Festival: Black Poets Want Change
description: Black critics have been saying that black poets will have to make their own forms, establish their own rhythms. As one writer put it, it is foolish to expect iambic pentameter in the work of a poet who moves to the rhythms of jazz or bebop.

title: Eight Missing as Schooner Sinks Near Newfoundland
description: ARNOLD's COVE, Nfld., July 28 (AP)  A 66foot wooden motor schooner with 15 per sons aboard caught fire and sank last night in Placentia Bay. Six persons were rescued and one body was recovered. Officials ordered a search for eight persons reported missing.

title: Halving Forest Hills
description: The mediator appointed by Mayor Lindsay to review the controversial Forest Hills housing project in Queens has submitted a report laying the foundation for reason able compromise. Mario M. Cuomo suggests that the project be retained in concept, but drastically scaled down in size.

title: PANEL ON REFORM APPROVED IN I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The International Monetary Fund announced today formal approval by its Board of Gov ernors  the world's finance ministers and central bank governors  of the new Com mittee of 20 to negotiate re form of the world monetary system and related issues.

title: Slayer of 2 Detectives Wins Rights Suit
description: A man convicted of killing two detectives was awarded a $7,500 judgment yesterday against a retired police official who was found to have violat ed his civil rights.

title: Yanks Down Red Sox, 31, After 65 Loss
description: A closely played double header between the Yankees and the Red Sox that took only 4 hours of playing time fin ished in a stalemate last night as New York salvaged the split with a 31 victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Saves 15 Cuban Refugees Fleeing in a Boat
description: MIAMI, July 28 (UPI)Two Cuban refugees now living in the United States have returned with 13 relatives and friends they smuggled out of Cuba in a leaky boat.

title: Chris Evert Spoils Mrs. Court's Return
description: CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) Chris Evert spoiled the tennis comeback of Mrs. Margaret Court today with a 63, 63 victory that gave the United States a 11 split with Australia in the first Bonne Belle series. In an earlier match, Evonne Goolagong of Australia defeated Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego, 64, 60. Miss Goolagong started shakily, but suddenly found her form at the end of the opening set, scoring on 16 of 18 points, 13 in a row.

title: India Ratifies Pakistan Pact
description: NEW DELHI, July 28Presi dent V. V. Giri today ratified the peace agreement between India and Pakistan. The agree ment, signed in Simla between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan on July 2, will take effect when the In dian instrument of ratification reaches Rawalpindi in two days. Pakistan has already ratified it.

title: DOW STOCK INDEX OFF 0.15 TO 926.70
description: Stock prices opened on a firm note and then eased in after noon trading yesterday, holding to the general pattern of the three previous sessions.

title: It is true that nothing is sacred? The Royal Canadian Mounted Policemen do not gallop, singing, through the pine forests, and hold Jeanette MacDonald in fond embrace? There is discord in the ranks, like unhappy cops everywhere? Oh, Mounties! Oh, Nelson Eddy!
description: TORONTOThe whole world knows the Mountie. He's courageous, fair and square, upright and morally sound as the Bank of Canada. His postcard image draws applicants to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police from among the cream of Canada's young men. And after a month or more of checking for health and honesty, loyalty and discipline, intelligence, knowledge and common sense, ambition, courage and maturity, the personnel officer sends the applicant, now a recruit, to training center and tells his mother and father as he told mine sixteen years ago: We take a boy and give you back man.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN DIEGO, July 28 (AP)The American Basketball Association today awarded a franchise to San Diego, in creasing its membership to ten teams. The franchise was awarded to Leonard A. Bloom, president of the United States Capital Corporation, a conglomerate dealing in real estate, finance, data processing and ice cream.

title: U.N. UNIT CONDEMNS RHODESIA TRADE TIE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 (AP)With the United States abstaining, the United Nations Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to condemn all acts violating its embargo against Rhodesia.

title: ROBERT H. SMITH
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 28 Robert H. Smith, president of the Standard Fruit and Steam ship Company, a major supplier of bananas, died today in a New Orleans hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Army Captain Dead in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Defense Department to day announced that Capt. John A. Spires of the Army, husband of Mrs. Kay A. Spires, of Bath, N. Y., has been killed in action in Vietnam. He previously was listed as missing.

title: SAIGON UNITS QUIT QUANGTRI CITADEL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam,Sat urday, July 29South Viet namese troops, after apparently suffering severe casualties, have pulled out of the inner wailed Citadel of the city of Quangtri on the northern front in the face of stubborn North Vietnamese resistance.

title: Bobby Unser, as Usual, Gains Pole for Schaefer 500 Today
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 28 Bobby Unser, the fastest driver on this year's Championship Trail of the United States Auto Club, is the favorite to win to morrow's Schaefer 500, which carries nearly half a million dollars in purses and awards.

title: Georgia Will Sue Pay Board To Force It to Act on Raise
description: ATLANTA, July 28 (AP)  Gov. Jimmy Carter said today that the state of Georgia would go into United States District Court to force the Federal Pay Board to act on raises granted to state troopers last winter.

title: Labor's Changed Political Role
description: News Analysis

title: U.S. ISSUES REPORT BRENT CHARGES ON DIKE BOMBINGS
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The Administration today re leased a Government intel ligence report finding that American bombing had dam aged North Vietnam's dike sys tem at 12 points. But the report concluded that the hits were unintentional, their impact was minor and no major dike has been breached.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: VALENCIA, Calif., July 28 (AP)Kathy Schmidt, years old, a Long Beach City College student, set an Amer ican record in the javelin throw today with a toss of 200 feet 6 inches.

title: CUBANS IN MIAMI PRESS FOR POWER
description: MIAMI, July 28  Cuban refugees, who account for one fourth of this area's 1.3mil lion population, are beginning to flex their political muscles.

title: British Ports Paralyzed As 41,000 Dockers Strike
description: LONDON, July 28 (UPI)  Britain's 41,000 longshoremen went on strike today, closing down the nation's seaports for the second time in two years. The government hinted that it might proclaim a state of emergency.

title: Suit Filed in Maino Oil Spill
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 28 (AP)A classaction suit seek ing reparations was filed in United States District Court to day against the Norwegian tanker that spilled more than 40,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil into Casco Bay. The suit was entered against the Tamano on behalf of residents of Long Is land, which is in Casco Bay.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton accepted an invitation today to appear Sunday on Face the Nation, the Columbia Broadcasting System's tele vision interview program.

title: Atlantic Airlines to Meet
description: GENEVA, July 28  Senior executives of the airlines flying the North Atlantic will meet Sept. 8 to seek agreement on a new oneyear package of fares to become effective April 1, 1973, the International Air Transport Association an nounced tonight.

title: Sales Advance 67.7%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation attained the high est earnings in the second quarter and first six months this year since comparable periods in 1969. The figures were also the second highest since the merger of Douglas Aircraft and McDonnell Air craft in April, 1967, according to the midyear report issued yesterday from St. Louis head quarters.

title: Death Rate Drops In Transportation But Total Is Higher
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Transportation accidents killed 58,452 persons last year 526 more than in 1970but the death rate declined for the sixth consecutive year, accord ing to a report by the Trans portation Department.

title: NADER CRITICIZES CONSUMER CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, has called upon Vir ginia H. Knauer to make a statement of conscience re garding her stand on the con sumer protection bill pending in the Senate by resigning as the President's adviser on con sumer affairs.

title: Antiques
description: The ivory revival in con temporary necklaces and bracelets evident at this week's jewelers' convention in New York should stimu late interest in antique examples.

title: Handicapped Elect
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 28 (AP)  Mrs. Marily Wods of Merrimack, N. H., has been elected president of the National Association of the Physically Handicapped. More than 130 persons attended the 14th annual convention here this week.

title: Roundup: Squeeze Lifts Perry to 17th Triumph
GRAINS, SOYBEANS DOMINATE TRADING
description: The grains and soybeans dominated commodity futures trading yesterday with some impressive gains.

title: Business Briefs
description: International Business Machines Corporation's new computer models haven't been officisly announced yet but they have already achieved great notriety. The Telex Corporation said it will go to court on Monday in Min neapolis to request a second temporary restraining order against the introduction of the new computers.

title: For Marine Trainees, Tougher Is Better
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C.The platoon of Marine recruits tramps down the street in the harsh sun. The recruits wear fatigue trousers, white Tshirts and helmet liners. Their faces rare wet with sweat and taut with concentration.

title: Silent Majority and Strike Out Triumph in Pacing Divisions
description: YONKERS, July 28Stanley Dancer had just completed a victorious 2:01 3/5 mile journey behind Silent Majority in the first division of the Best of All Pace at Yonkers Raceway to night. In a postrace telephone interview, Stan described the trip as so comfortable I could have driven the colt with two fingers. He, as was his sire [Henry T. Adios] is easy to handle.

title: The Thai Effort
description: WASHINGTONThe huge bulk of illicit opium production occurs in Burma, where output probably reaches 400 to 500 tons per year. The kingpin of the heroin traffic in Southeast Asia is Lo Hsing Han of Burma; whose con trol runs the gamut from poppy fields to heroin labs which he operates in Burma itself. Heroin refineries driven out of Laos and Thailand have come under Lo's control in Burma. We have discussed the urgent problem posed by. Lo's operation with the Burmese. But Lo operates within insurgentcon trolled territory and is beyond, control of the Government of Burma.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP)  For the first time since disclosing his history of treatment for nervous ex haustion and fatigue on Tues day, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton has faced pickets urging him to withdraw as the Democratic VicePresi dential nominee.

title: Gerulatis in Final
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 28 (UPI)Vitas Gerulatis of How ard Beach, Queens, and Patrick DePre of Birmingham, Ala., ad vanced to the final today of the Western open junior and boys' championships.

title: Charles Edwin Brundage Investment Counselor, 77
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 28 Charles Edwin Brundage, a partner in the firm of Brun dage, Story & Rose, New York investment counsel, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospi tal. He was 77 years old and lived at Mount Freedom Road, Dover.

title: Disappointment Voiced
description: George A. Warde, president of American Airlines, said the carrier was disappointed. . . but the decision has been made and the case is now closed.

title: LITTLE GIANTS SET FOR TOUCH CHIEFS
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 28 Amid the elaborate annual cere monials with which professional football honors its past, the New York Giants will launch their own modest aspirations for 1972 by playing Kansas City Chiefs in the Hall of Fame Game tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock. The game will be tele vised nationally by the Ameri can Broadcasting Company, Channel 7 in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNICOLOR SUED BY OUSTED OFFICER,
description: Harry Saltzman, who has been ousted as executive com mittee chairman of Technicolor, Inc, the colorfilm processor, has filed suit against company officers and a Swiss bank, Technicolor disclosed last night.

title: American Express to Mail Tender Offers for D.L.J.
description: The American Express Com pany and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., announced yes terday that American Express would commence its previously announced offer to acquire 25 per cent of D.L.J. through the mailing of tender offers today.

title: Third in Line
description: The elevation through seniority of Senator James O. Eastland, the ultraconservative Mississippi Democrat and state'srighter, to be president pro tempore of the Senate is another painful example of the irresponsible manner in which politicians of both parties designate potential successors to the Presidency.

title: BALLET ELABORATES ON CLASSICAL STEPS
description: The glacial pacing of William Dunas's dance The All the Same Faces Affair, which had its premiere Thursday evening at the American Theater Laboratory, would make slow motion camera footage appear indelicately hasty.

title: Pirates Set Back Mets and Seaver, 31
description: PITTSBURGH, July 28  This hasn't been a good month for the Mets and it hasn't been a good week for Tom Seaver.

title: Jersey Woman Sentenced In Slaying of County Judge
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 28 (AP)  Mrs. Naomi Stout was sentenced today to a 10to15 year jail term in connection with the slaying on Feb. 9 of Essex County Court Judge Roger Yancey.

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: The Anderson Charges
description: Columnist Jack Anderson has needlessly added con fusion and uncertainty to a situation that already had more than enough of both. By giving currency to a wholly undocumented story that Senator Thomas F. Eagleton had several times been arrested for drunken and reckless driving, Mr. Anderson inevitably stiffened the Senator's determination to pursue the Vice Presidency despite a medical history that almost certainly would have cost him the nomination had he disclosed it before his name was proposed to the Democratic convention.

title: SUMNER S. CLARK
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 28 Sumner S. Clark, retired Maine Central Railroad vice president and former chairman of the Portland City Council, died at a cottage at Old Orchard Beach today. He was 54 years old.

title: 2 Kidnappers Hunted in 6 Midwest States
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) A sixstate search was pressed today for two men who the Federal Bureau of In vestigation says abducted the wife of a Minneapolis million aire and left a ransom note de manding about $1million.

title: Three Sisters Die in Fire
description: GALENA, Kan., July 28 (UPI) Three girls died in their flam ing home today while their mother stood screaming in the front yard. The victims were identified as Sarah Merrell, 6 years old, and her sisters, Sharon 7, and Nancy 8.

title: S.E.C. Plans Proceeding To Seek Bar to Institutions
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Securities and Exchange Com mission served notice today that it would not abandon its attempt to keep institutional investors from becoming or re maining members of stock ex changes.

title: WOMAN IS ACCUSED IN A $4,000 SWINDLE
description: A woman was arrested out side the New York Hilton last night for allegedly trying to bilk a 55yearold victim of $4,000 in a confidence scheme, the police reported.

title: Pattison Subdues Parun
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., July 28 (UPI)Thirdseeded Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia, the highest seeded player re maining in the Tanglewood ten nis tournament, defeated Onny Parun of New Zealand, 75, 63, in the quarterfinals today.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE. By Yevgeny Zamyatin. Translated from the Russian and with an Introduction by Mirra Ginsburg. 204 pages. Viking. $6.95.

title: Jane Fonda, Here, Explains Plea to Pilots From Hanoi
description: Jane Fonda said yesterday that she appealed to American (pilots over the Hanoi radio to halt raids into North Vietnam and go home because she was so horrified by damage she said they caused.

title: Greeks Rekindle Flame For Long Olympic Trip
description: OLYMPIA, Greece, July 28 The Olympic flame, lighted by the rays of the sun in the ancient Greek sanctuary here, began today a 3,600 mile relay by torchbearers who will take it across eight European countries to the Games of the XX Olympiad in Munich, West Germany.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOSCOW, July 28 (AP)  The undefeated United States basketball team won its third game in the Yuri Gagarin international basketball tournament today, rally ing for an 8180 victory over Finland, the Soviet news agency, Tass, reported.

title: Pledge on Lira Reported
description: LUCCA, Italy, July 28  Premier Guilio Andreotti of Italy seems to have promised Presi dent Georges Pompidou of France that the lira will not be devalued before new high level monetary discussions to ward the end of this year.

title: HESBURGH ATTACKS BILL TO BAN BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, said today that antibusing legisla tion being considered by Con gress would inflict educational genocide on millions of school children from minority groups.

title: MOSCOW, July 28  The stuffy room in the Central
description: Chess Club of Moscow was slowly filling up for the regular analysis of the latest game in the match between Boris Spas sky of the Soviet Union, the world champion, and Bobby Fischer, the American chal lenger.

title: Text of Intelligence Report on Bombing of Dikes in North Vietnam Issued by State Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Following is the text of a re port distributed by the State Department today as a con sensus of the United States intelligence community on the issue of bombing of dikes in North Vietnam.

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: AMEX PRICES SUP IN QUIET TRADING
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange ended the Week on a downbeat, with the index at 26.74, off 0.02 for the day and 0.04 for the week.

title: Mrs. Dewey Is Married to Banker
description: The marriage of Mrs. Rowena B. Dewey of New Canaan, Conn., to Norborne Berkeley Jr. of New York, an executive vice president and director of the Chemical Bank and of its parent hold ing company, the Chemical New York Corporation, took place here yesterday after noon. The Rev. Darrell W. Udd performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Senate G.O.P. Seeks Way To Win Doves and Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Senate Republican leadership, with little encouragement from the White House, was trying today to work out a compro mise endthewar amendment that would satisfy some Senate doves and still be acceptable to the Administration.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LUDLOW, Mass., July 28 (AP)Dennis Cline, a 27 yearold research chemist from Geneva, Ill., won the 27th national field archery barebow championship today.

title: Two Lower Prime Rates
description: The First National City Bank and the Mellon National Bank & Trust Company, as expected, lowered their prime lending rates to 5 per cent from 5 per cent yesterday, effective for the week bginning Monday.

title: Executive Changes
description: A. C. Buehler Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Victor Comptometer Corporation, has been elected president. Mr. Buehler succeeds George W. May who resigned as president and a director. Mr. May joined Victor Comptometer as president in June, 1970. No reason was given for the resignation.

title: Nicklaus to Defend His P.G.A. Title; Must Limit Practice
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 Jack Nicklaus said today he was definitely planning on playing in the Professional Golf ers' Association championship that begins at the Oakland Hills Country Club, Birmingham, Mich., next Thursday.

title: TWO MEET MONDAY
description: CUSTER, S.D., July 28Sen ator George McGovern said here tonight that to a great extent it was now up to Sen ator Thomas F. Eagleton of Mis souri whether he remained as his Democratic running mate.

title: Notes on People
description: Thomas E. Dewey Jr., son of the late Republican Gov ernor and Presidential candi date, was appointed by Governor Rockefeller to the New York City Housing De velopment Corporation. The 39yearold Mr. Dewey, Manhattan lawyer, will re ceive $100 a day, with a maximum of $2,500 a year, for his work with the corpo ration, a state agency that helps finance limitedincome and nonprofit housing in the city.

title: Business Briefs
description: The helpwanted advertising index rose 3 points in June to a figure of 96 per cent of the 1967 base period, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The index last month was 13 points above the level of June 1971.

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, July 28 (AP)The United States Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson, has cut back on the travel and sightseeing proposed by his Soviet hosts in favor of additional negotiation on a United StatesSoviet trade agreement.

title: Action Interpreted
description: HONG KONG, July 28The Chinese announcement that Lin Piao died is believed here to in dicate that the present Peking leadership now feels the fac tional tensions that accompa nied the Lin incident have abated sufficiently to warrant publicizing the affair.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: YONKERS, July 28Albatross, suffering from an fection, will not race in next Friday's $50,000 Good Time, the oldest pacing event at Yonkers Raceway.

title: SMUGGLERS' FUNDS FROZEN BY SWISS
description: GENEVA, July 28  The Swiss Ministry of Justice dis closed today that it had frozen more than $500,000 hidden in secret Swiss bank accounts by international drug traffickers.

title: Inaction on Extortion Case Laid to a High Jersey Aide
description: A New Jersey legislator said yesterday that the information that led to the extortion indict ment of the state's Secretary of State last month had not been acted upon in the office of the state Attorney General for al most two years.

title: BAYREUTH FIGHTS FOR WAGNERIANA
description: BONN, July 28The sealed diaries of Richard Wagner's wife, Cosima, and other pack ages that may contain corre spondence between the com poser and his royal benefactor, King Ludwig of Bavaria, have become the center of a legal clash of almost Wagnerian pro portions.

title: Bridge: St. Louis Team Beats Roth' By 84 Points in the Spingold
description: DENVER, July 28The third round of the Spingold knockout team championship in the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League began here this af ternoon with one high ranked New York team on the side lines.

title: Things Look Brighter on 84th Street With New Sodium Lamps
description: They have changed the lights on 84th Street between Riverside Drive and West End Avenue, and the dif ference is like night and day.

title: Nixon Signs Bill to Let Youths Buy Crop Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)President Nixon signed legislation today permitting persons between the ages of 18 and 20 to buy Federal crop in surance. He told an audience of young farmers Your Govern ment has faith in young people: we believe you are a good risk.

title: Peking Aide Confirms That Lin Piao Tried to Kill Mao and Died in Crash
description: PEKING, July 28 (Reuters) China acknowledged today, for the first time, that Lin Piao, the former Defense Minister, had led a plot to overthrow and assassinate Mao Tsetung and was killed in a plane crash in Mongolia while fleeing the country.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressman
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 They don't like me right now, but I alternate on their list between No. 1 and No. 99, Senator Jacob K. Javits said this week in describing his current status with the White House and President Nixon's reelection campaign. Nonetheless, the liberal New York Republi can said he was preparing to campaign ac tively this fall for the Nixon ticket in New York State and elsewhere. So is his Conser vativeRepublican colleague, Senator James L. Buckley.

title: BURNS ADVANCES IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 28 George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills, recent winner of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship, became a threat to capture the 70th Metropolitan Golf Association amateur title today at the Deep dale Club.

title: Profits Set Record At General Motors
description: DETROIT, July 28The Gen eral Motors. Corporation dis closed today the largest three month profit ever reported by any American company. But General Motors still asserted that a price increase on cars and trucks was needed this fall.

title: Natural Death Closing
description: Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death, the Melvin Van Peebles play, will close at the Ambassador Theater after tomorrow's matinee. It will have played a total of 325 per formances.

title: Closed Door
description: Failure has marked the end of the road for another overtouted effort by construction labor and management in this city to prove that the walls excluding blacks and Puerto Ricans from skilled building jobs can be leveled without governmental compulsion.

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: State Regents Forbid Ties To Nonaccredited Schools
description: ALBANY, July 28 (UPI) The State Board of Regents to day adopted a regulation pro hibiting institutions in the state from affiliating with nonac credited institutions throughout the country that give higher education degrees.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardin, at Least, Said Something New
description: PARIS, July 28Even the French press, which tends to boost its own, is chiding the couture, ever so gently, for abandoning its traditional role as a laboratory of fash ion. The new ideas that have passed through the couture salons here could be in scribed on the head of a pin.

title: CITY DEFIES STATE BY CUTTING RENTS
description: City officials have defied state warnings that they were acting illegally by reducing the rents for tenants in more than 13,000 rentcontrolled apartments in buildings whose landlords were found in viola tion of the city's air pollution rules.

title: A.B.C. DROPS PLAN FOR CHESS FILMS
description: The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its camera crew from Iceland and giving up attempts to film the world championship chess match in Reykjavik.

title: U.S. COURT VOIDS CURB ON WELFARE
description: A portion of the yearold state law that has required nearly 20,000 employable wel fare recipients to report regu larly to State Employment Service offices to pick up their relief checks or accept work was invalidated yesterday by a threejudge Federal court in Buffalo.

title: ROSE LAROSE, 59, STRIPPER, IS DEAD
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 28 (UPI) Rose LaRose, the burlesque queen who was reported to have made $2,500 a week as stripper, died at her home here last night of cancer. She was 59 years old.

title: Art: Newark Show Is Tribute to Niles Spencer
description: When Catherine Brett Spen cer, widow of the American artist Niles Spencer, died last fall, She bequeathed to the Newark Museum what must be the largest and most com plete collection of Spencer paintings and drawings in existence.

title: Music: Strenuous Bach
description: Short of attempting to gulp down all 48 Preludes and Fugues at one sitting, there is nothing much more strenuous that a Bach key board performer might do than to play the Goldberg Variations in public. This stupendous Aria with 30 Variations demands such technical facility, musician ship, intellectual resources and sheer endurance that until a few years ago the single keyboard of the piano was considered an impossible me dium for fully realizing the score's potential.

title: Malik Cites Peace Proposal
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 (Reuters)  Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Adam Malik, said to day that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations meet ing in Manila July 1314 had worked out a proposal to end the fighting in Indochina and that it had been submitted to all sides involved in the war. He added that the proposal con tained a compromise that would be acceptable to all sides.

title: Camp Safety
description: Not all of the nearly eight million children who annu ally attend sumraer camps throughout the country can share in nostalgic memories; for some children and parents there is tragedy. More than seventy children died in camps last summer and still the public outcry has not been strong enough to induce Congress approve a bill establishing minimum Federal safety standards for camps.

title: Dance: Verona Revisited
description: There is, critically speak ing, an occasional very real pleasure in being wrong, especially of you were right in the first place. When first saw Antony Tudor's Romeo and Juliet in 1946, I very much admired the combination of Shakespear ean romance and Botticellian fancy, and indeed I've often suggested that the ballet, after a long lapse in the repertory, should be revived.

title: The National Pastime
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Teacher Is Arrested On Charge of Selling Heroin
description: A 25yearold Bronx element ary school teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that he sold small quantities of heroin to a police undercover agent.

title: Fire in Rockefeller Center Draws Crowd of Onlookers
description: A grease fire in a ventilation system at the British Empire Building at Rockefeler Center ast night sent smoke swirl ing around St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Hunt Pressed for Mafia Leader Who Vanished on Jail Furlough
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation is conducting a na tionwide search for Anthony L. DiLorenzo, a reputed Mafia leader who disappeared Wednesday while on an un escorted furlough from Federal prison to visit his dentist on Long Island.

title: New LeadPoison Test Devised Here
description: Two years of laboratory work by the chief chemist at Ford ham Hospital has resulted in the perfection of a new method for measuring lead poisoning in children, a major health hazard in slums.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. PLAN SCIENTIFIC MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) American and Soviet offi cials announced today that the first meeting of a joint com mission on scientific and tech nical cooperation, agreed to at the Moscow summit, would be held in Washington in late Oc tober.

title: Miss Deisler Bride Of Tirnothy J. Toole
description: RUMSON, N. J., July 28 Miss Marie Ann Deisler was married here this evening to Timothy John Toole. The Rev. William J. Carton performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: WaterChillers Prices Rise
description: Price increases ranging up to 5 per cent for products such as centrifugal water chillers, cen tral station air handling equip ment and packaged firetube and watertube boilers were an nounced yesterday by the Trane Company. The higher prices be come effective Aug. 1.

title: MRS. ISIDOR FELDMAN
description: Mrs. Ida Rabinowitz Feld man, the mother of Maurice M. Feldman, who retired last year as Commissioner of Water Re sources after 35 years in the city's service, died yesterday at Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens. She was 82 years old and lived at 209 Bay 29th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Merger Stay Refused
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia declined today to postpone the scheduled Aug. 1 merger of Delta Air Lines and Northeast Airlines.

title: Foot Woes Tied to Smoking
description: BOSTON, June 8 (AP)The hazards of smoking include possible foot trouble, says the past president of the American Podiatry Association, Dr. Ernest M. Weiner. He told the group's annual convention yesterday that cigarette smoking will ag gravate the problems of poor or borderline circulation.

title: Coating Cuts Reflections That Impede TV Viewing
description: Patents of the Week

title: CITY BALLET SETS A VISIT TO POLAND
description: The New York City Ballet will appear in Warsaw and one other Polish city following a tour Sept. 19 through Oct. 15 of the Soviet cities of Kiev, Leningrad, Tbilisi and Moscow under the United StatesSoviet cultural exchange agreement.

title: RATE RISE DENIED TO PACIFIC PHONE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Justice Byron R. White cleared the way today for a $150mil lion refund to customers of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: 1623 Shakespeare Stolen
description: MANCHESTER, England, July 28 (AP)A first folio printing of Shakespeare's works, worth about $24,700, has been stolen from Manchester University Li brary, officials said today. It was published in London in 1623seven years after Shakes peare's deathby Isaac Jaggard and E. Blount.

title: Shell Plans LowLead Gas
description: The Shell Oil Company said yesterday that it planned to in troduce a higher octane low lead gasoline to replace its low octane nonleaded product. The new gas will be priced between the company's regular and hightest products.

title: Delaware Regatta Tomorrow
description: CALLICOON, N. Y., July 28 The fifth annual Upper Dela ware Canoe Regatta will get under way Sunday morning with three eightmile races. These events will be followed by two 15mile tests and the featured 26mile race.

title: 8 Killed in Crash of Truck Carrying Vegetable Pickers
description: EUSTACE, Tex., July 28 (UPD) Eight persons were killed and seven others were injured to day in the collision of a car and pickup truck carrying 14 vegetable pickers home from work.

title: MRS. JOAN COLEMAN, LED PARENTS LEAGUE
description: Mrs. Joan Fraser Coleman, a former president of the Parents League of New York and a for mer trustee of Barnard College, died yesterday at St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L.I. She was 68 years old and lived at 139 East 66th Street and in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Catholic Seminary Worker Murdered in Dormitory
description: BOSTON, July 28, (UPI) For the second time in seven years, an employe of St. John's Seminary in Brighton has been found murdered on the grounds of the Roman Catholic school.

title: Psychiatrists Explain Medical Facts in Depression Controversy
description: Many thousands of Americans have suffered serious mental depression, and the vast ma jority of those treated with electroshock therapy have re covered quickly and fully, the American Psychiatric Associa tion said yesterday in a state ment.

title: DATA ON EAGLETON REPORTED LACKING
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A man who was the source of a charge yesterday that Senator Thomas F. Eagleton had been arrested in Missouri at least six times for traffic violations, in cluding reckless and drunken driving, said today that he had no documents to prove it.

title: Maket Place: S. E.C. Studies Prospectuses
description: What's in a prospectus?

title: SWIDLER DOUBTS POWER LIABILITY
description: The chairman of the Public Service Commission said here yesterday that he was very sympathetic to those who suffered losses through power outages in the last two weeks but doubted if he could do anything.

title: ELLENDER'S BODY WILL LIE IN STATE
description: BATON ROUGE, July 28  The body of Senator Allen J. Ellender will be flown to the state capitol here tomorrow to allow Louisianans to pay their last respects to the state's senior United States Senator.

title: Suit Filed to Void Jersey Zoning Laws
description: The zoning practices of al most all of New Jersey's 576 municipalities were challenged yesterday as unconstitutional and discriminatory against blacks, Puerto Ricans and others in the lowtomoderate income class.

title: Killings Go On in Burundi, U.N. Statement Suggests
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28The United Nations today broke weeks of official silence on conditions in the African country of Burundi with a statement calling the dimen sions of the human tragedy there staggering and strongly implying that killings were con tinuing.

title: PARIS AND LONDON BUY 9 CONCORDES
description: PARIS, July 28The French and British national airlines signed contracts for a total of nine Concorde supersonic trans ports in Paris and London to day.

title: Youngsters in a Racially Mixed Group Find Much in Common
description: The children, 8 and 9yearolds, were sitting in a circle. Three were black, one was Puerto Rican, four were white.

title: Kennedy Airport Guards Seize Man Carrying Gun
description: A man who identified himself as a Puerto Rican farmer was arrested at Kennedy Interna tional Airport yesterday as he was allegedl yabout to board a jetliner for San Juan with loaded 25caliber automatic.

title: Alcoholics Get a Second Chance
description: WATERBURY, Conn., July 28As Roger Rose toured the turnofthecentury red brick building that the Scovill Manufacturing Company still uses as its main center of brass production, the work ers stopped him to offer their loud congratulations.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PANAMA CITY, Panama, July 28 (AP)Rafael Herrera of Mexico will defend his world bantamweight boxing title for the first time tomorrow night in a scheduled 15round bout against Enrique Pinder of Panama.

title: DeJesus Overwhelms Wilburn, Nears Shot at Lightweight Title
description: Taking a giant step toward a shot at the lightweight cham pionship, Esteban DeJesus of Carolinas, Puerto Rico, scored a unanimous 10round decision over Chuck (Schoolboy) Wil burn before 3,500 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Model Planes Invade an Air Base
description: OLENVIEW, III., July 28 The Glenview Naval Air Sta tion, an ancient air base where three of the five run ways are closed and tall weeds bloom between the ce ment cracks, has become the nation's busiest airport. At least for this week.

title: WINE TALK
description: Moroccan wine is a rarity in this country, but may not be for much longer. Schenley Industries current ly is importing some 32,000 cases.

title: THE UKRAINE GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: MOSCOW, July 28  A for mer associate of Loonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Commun ist party chief, was named Pres ident of the Ukraine today in the latest shuffle of top po sitions in that key Soviet re public.

title: Broker Weds Miss Keliher
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 28  Miss Agathe M. Keliher and Henry E. Crouter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Crouter of Chestnut Hill, were married this afternoon at the home of the bride groom's parents by the Rev. Tom T. Edwards, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill.

title: MAY STARS, ANGELS DEFEAT RANGERS, 81
description: ANAHEIM, July 29Rudy May pitched a fourhitter and his batterymate, John Stephen son, drove in three runs as the California Angels completed a sweep of the Texas Rangers with an 81 triumph tonight.

title: In a Bronx Storefront Office, a Campaign Outpost for the I.R.A.
description: In a shabby storefront office In the Bronx, Gabriel Kennedy was raising money for the Irish Republican Army's cause. Collections have never been better, Mr. Kennedy said. People are waking up to what's happening in Northern Ireland today and not listening so much to British propaganda.

title: SCHERR IS VICTOR IN SOLING CONTEST
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 29 Robert E. Scherr sailed Aus lese to a 2minute43second Soling Class victory off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today in the season's 22d championship re gatta for Yacht Racing Associ ation fleets based east of Rye on Long Island Sound.

title: Law
description: I firmly believe that everyone should have equal rights to use what nature and God has put there, as serted Mrs. Evelyn Irons. It's time the barriers came down.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: DETROIT, July 29 (AP)The. Chev rolet Corvette, long the only American production car built with a fiberglass body, will switch to steel construction, probably in 1975, the trade paper Auto motive News reports in its July31 issue.

title: City's Planning Chief Questions Buck Rogers Urban Solutions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, said this week that urban leaders and the pub lic were growing impatient over what he described as aerospace technologists' unfulfilled prom ises of Buck Rogers solu tions to urban problems.

title: BRIDEGROOMTOBE SLAIN AFTER PARTY
description: A prospective bridegroom awaiting a ride home with six celebrators from his bachelor party at a Park Avenue res taurant was shot and killed on East 56th Street early yester day in what the police called a senseless altercation with a second group of men.

title: James Ferrer Is Fiance Of Jeanne Kerr Franklin
description: Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin of Locust Valley, L. I., and Mr. Franklin of Remsenburg, L. I., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Kerr Franklin, to James Christian Ferrer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer of New York and Southhampton, L.I.

title: YORKIE IS NAMED PROVIDENCE BEST
description: BARRINGTON, R.I., July 29  Ch. Gaytonglen Teddy of Mayfair, a Yorkshire terrier, scored an impressive bestin show triumph today at the 63d annual allbreed dog show and obedience trial of the Prov idence County Kennel Club. The show drew 1,027 dogs.

title: Mrs. Barbara Graves Jenks Married
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 29  Mrs. Barbara Graves Jenks of Barrington, R. I., widow of Alvin Cleveland Jenks, was married here this evening to Philip F. Miller of Palm Beach, Fla., a widower and retired investment coun selor. The Rev. Grant A. Mor rill performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: The great ripoff of Long Island's
description: Saltscented winds, gleaming sand fronting on cool green breakers and the rhythmic sibilance of the surfthat's the beach. Enjoy it while it lasts. Next year when you go, it may not be there.

title: Elizabeth Anne Postell Becomes Bride
description: In Christ United Methodist Church here yesterday after noon, Miss Elizabeth Anne Postell, daughter of Mrs. Robert Keedick of Westport, Conn., and the late John Cun ningham Postell Jr., was mar ried to John Edward Hicka, son of Mr. and Mrs. John An drew Hicka of Kew Gardens, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Teague.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Our motto, said Charles D. Peebler Jr., president of Bozell & Jacobs, is that you start losing an account the day you get it. That means you have to run full time and not take anything for granted.

title: Fund Drive Is Begun For Hamptons Hospital
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I.A $7million campaign to raise funds for a 222bed facility, the Hamptons Hos pital and Medical Center, Is under way. The hospital will be situated on a 45acre tract of land on Old Country Road.

title: Miss Douglas Has Nuptials
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., July 29Miss Katherine St. John Douglas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Woolman Doug las, was married here this afternoon to Allen Steele Torrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Lovell Torrey of Am herst, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Powers McLeod of Pensacola, Fla., a Methodist minister.

title: Welcome Extended To Errant In Nassau
description: ELMONT, L. I.Where can a youngster go when his family gives up on him, he finishes the maximum stay at a Children's Shelter and his probation officer is pre paring him for a possible stay in a residential institution? He can go to the home of Peppy Nunziatta and be welcome.

title: LESOTHO SEEKING BLACKS FROM U.S.
description: An African diplomat said last week that his nation wanted black American technicians to help replace British expatriate technicians who were being phased out.

title: West Berliners Now Dialing Directly to East Germany
description: BERLIN, July 29 (AP)West Berliners have began direct telephone dialing to 32 areas in East Germany for the first time since 1952.

title: Dance: In Connecticut
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 29For a quarter of a century the American Dance Festival presented by Con necticut College each summer has made a significant crea tive contribution to American dance. Literally dozens of important works have re ceived their world pre mieres here.

title: Shore Issue: GroupRentals
description: SPRING LAKEThey are as desirable as mosquitoes, as welcome as a rainy sum mer.

title: Carol Breitbart Fiance of Robert Furst
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, LI., July 29The engagement of Miss Carol Cecelia Breitbart, a junior at George Washing ton University, to Robert Paul Furst, a junior at Roger Williams College in Bristol, R.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Breit bart, parents of the brideto be. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Furst of Old Westbury.

title: 5 Bishops of Black Church Issue Nixon Endorsement
description: PHILADEPHIA, July 29 (AP) Five Bishops attending the national conference of the Afri can Methodist Episcopal Zion Church plan to support Presi dent Nixon for reelection in November.

title: Joan Hayden Muchmore to Marry
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., July 29  Mr. and Mrs. Henry George Muchmore have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Hayden Muchmore, to John Hendee Roach Jr., son of Mr. Roach of Fort Lauder dale, Fla., and the late Mrs. Roach. The wedding is planned for Sept. 23.

title: Drive Begun to Save DebrisLaden Pond
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.  Some 200 years ago, the area adjoining Camp's Pond was dotted with cattle. Nestled deep among tree covered hills that rise 250 feet above sealevel, this kettlehole lake  it was formed at the end of the Ice Agewas an ideal hiding place for livestock that the Colonials wanted to save from the occupying British troops.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The hierarchy of the deck is sometimes subject to demo cratic adjustment, both at the aristocratic and proletarian levels. On the diagramed deal played in a rubber bridge game at the Regency Whist Club in New York, a queen proved to be the equivalent of a king in the bidding, and an eight proved inferior to a seven in the play.

title: Sweet Smell of Profits
description: With these words, Guy E. Noyes, senior vice president and economist of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, be gan an analysis last week of the second half of the year and beyond. And undoubted ly, in making this bullish observation about current economic activity, booming corporate profits in the sec ond quarter and first six months of 1972 were not far from his mind.

title: Movies
description: RENO, Nevada

title: SHOP TALK
description: RED BANKThis borough stopped being a port town when commercial navigation on the Navesink River ended more than a generation ago, but it is still a river town at heart. Today it enjoys the reputation of being the river sports center of the East.

title: WALL STREET
description: Spotted at a quiet table at Patsy's Italian restaurant on West 56th Street the other evening were Vice President Agnew and Bernard J. Las ker, President Nixon's chief contact in Wall Street and a powerful Republican fund raiser.

title: Legal Defense Unit Is Established Here For Puerto Ricans
description: The creation of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Edu cation Fund to protect the legal rights of Puerto Ricans throughoutthe country was an nounced last week by leaders of the Puerto Rican community.

title: Virginia Folk Festival Stage Is a Cold Place for a Country Boy
description: VIENNA, Va., July 29The National Folk Festival at Wolf Trap Farm Park offers a basic contradiction, which made it self felt frequently yesterday, the second day of the threeday festival. The contradiction is that thousands of people are drawn to the festival's huge auditorium to hear performers who are at their best in inti mate, informal situations.

title: Brookhaven Chief Cites Lack of Aid
description: UPTON, L. I.In his 11 years as director of Brook haven National Laboratory, one of the country's most prestigious national research facilities, Dr. Maurice Gold haber has seen three eras of scientific research come and gopresputnik, sputnik and postsputnik.
