title: Miss Linda Elizabeth Sullivan Affianced to Stuart Grossman
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., July 29  Miss Linda Elizabeth Sullivan and Stuart Alan Grossman, medical students at the University of Roches ter, plan to be married here in December.

title: Astros Defeat Dodgers, 72
description: HOUSTON, July 29 (AP) Lee May drove in four runs, three with a home run, to lead the Houston Astros past the Los Angeles Dodgers, 72, to night.

title: Hiatt Traded to Angels
description: HOUSTON, July 29 (UPI) Jack Hiatt, a catcher, was sold today by the Houston Astros to the California Angels for an undisclosed amount of cash and a player to be named later. Hiatt, 30 years old, was hitting 200 in 10 games for the Astros.

title: To do good and cast a shadow
description: Harry McPherson was one of the best young men with Lyn don Johnson, humane, a liberal moderate, and intelligent  a Texas lawyer who reads liter ature and history for pleasure. His book therefore has a lot going for it, especially surprise. He worked loyally for Johnson for 13 years, assisting him in quelling the Senate Mends in the late fifties and writing his Vietnam speeches at the height of the war. His book therefore also has a lot going against it, especially, again, surprise. The author's skill is evident in his keeping the pleasure he gives offhand and catching the disap pointment he causes offguard.

title: London Turns To The Front Page
description: LONDON.

title: An Impressive Battery of Legal Talent Joins the Battle to Save Grand Central Terminal From Demolition
description: A group of lawyers in the city with impressive civic, po litical and judicial credentials have joined in the defense of Grand Central Terminal against the threat of desecration or demolition by the construc tion of a towering office build ing at its doorstep.

title: Rina Chagy Fiancee Of Mark A. Winick
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July 29Miss Rina Chagy, a law yer with the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Mark Alan Winick, a leasing officer of Citicorp Leasing, a subsidiary of the First Na tional City Corporation, plan to be married Aug. 27.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ALGIERS  Algerian President Houari Boumediene foresees in the 1980's a global energy crisis that will vastly enhance the importance of the Arab lands with their reservoirs of petroleum and natural gas. This fact in itself will help provide the answer to what kind of new international balance is developing and whether the superpowers are truly opening a new era of peace or simply preparing to redraw the map.

title: Barry Fulton Weds Martha Gerosa
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 29 In the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea here this morning Miss Martha Anne Gerosa, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred George Ge rosa of Harrison, was mar ried to Barry Freeman Ful ton, son of Mrs. Oliver Marcy of Franklin, N.H., and the late Col. Robert Freeman Fulton, U.S.A.F. The Rev. Donald R. Cutter performed the ceremony.

title: Moolah Extends Her Streak For Women's Pro Wrestling
description: Women made their second appearance in a professional wrestlnig exhibition here last night at Madison Square Gar den as Fabulous Moolah extend ed her winning streak (which began in 1956) by pinning Susan Gree after 5 minutes 44 seconds.

title: For the DroppinginforaDrink Season: A Guide to Offensive Action
description: The point of this whole operation is not simply to stint your guests on quality and quantityany fool can pre pour Moroccan red into Burgundy bot tles, or behave as if all knowledge of the existence of drink has been sudden ly excised from his brain at 10 P.M. but to stint them while seeming, at any rate to their wives, to have done them rather well. Note the limitation: your ideal objective is a quarrel on the way home between each husband and wife, he disparaging your hospitality, she saying you were very sweet and thoughtful and he is just a frustrated drunk. Points contributing to this end marked +.

title: Some OutofTown Social Events to Be Held in the Week Ahead
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries un less otherwise indicated:

title: Sarah E. Story Will Be Bride
description: MENDHAM, N.J., July 29 Mr. and Mrs. Julian W. Story have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Story, to William N. Benson, son of Mrs. John Tanger of Wayland, Mass., and the late William N. Benson.

title: WilkesBarre Dazed A Month After Flood
description: WILKESBARRE, July 29 The Wyoming Valley, engulfed by flood waters June 2324 when the pounding rains of Tropical Storm Agnes swelled the Susquehanna River to record heights, remains prostrate after the most disastrous flood in the nation's history.

title: Canton Hall of Fame Inducts Marchetti, Parker, Matson and Hunt
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 29 Three former football play ers of legendary skills and one curent clubowner of stillawesome effectiveness were inducted today into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Canoe Racers Vie Over Rapids Today On Delaware River
description: The fifth annual Upper Dela ware canoe regatta will get under way today at 9 A.M. with three eightmile races. These tests will be followed by two 15milers and the fea tured 26mile races. The finish ing line for all races is at Cal licoon, N. Y.

title: Joanne E. Gorman To Marry Aug. 26
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., July 29 Mrs. Daniel J. Gorman of Dunedin, formerly of Jack son Heights, Queens, New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joanne E. Gorman of Washington, to Richard D. Wickerham. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Wickerham of Schenectady, N. Y.

title: Miss Christine Lund Is Bride Of Bill Mauldin, the Cartoonist
description: WILMETTE, Ill., July 29 Miss Christine Lund and Bill Mauldin, the cartoonist and author, were married in the First Congregational Church here this morning. The Rev. Gordon Smith performed the ceremony.

title: From Must See to Must Miss
description: ACCORDING to research organiza tions, some people (quite a lot of people, in fact) seem to go to movies exclusively in the summer when the driveins are open, when the indoor theaters are airconditioned to a point only several degrees above freezing, when the children are out of school and at home, when they're away at camp, when television is one vast rerun, when all of the members of the family are on vacation and bored prac tically speechless with each other. The following is a mid  summer guide to (and away from) a number of the movies you're likely to encounter. Not included are several potentially impor tant films that haven't been reviewed as of this writing, particularly John Huston's Fat City, John Boorman's Deliverance and Woody Allen's Everything You Always Wanted to know About Sex ...

title: It's the Season Now For Country Fairs
description: TRENTON  As the har vesting season works its way toward the cranberry crop, New Jersey's growers and their friends will be celebrat ing the pleasures of rustic life from Wayne to Camden at 4H Fairs and such crowd pleasing attractions as the Flemington Fair and the New Jersey State Fair in Trenton.

title: Very sweet smells came from the grass and flowers and goodly trees
description: Thanks to television, we have re cently been privileged to witness the most disastrous flood in our history, involving the network of rivers that rampaged through Virginia, Pennsyl vania, New Jersey and New York among others, the Potomac, the James, the Susquehanna, the Alle gheny, the Monongahela, the Schuyl kill and the Genesee. In the early years of our nation, these rivers were major avenues of commerce and sources of power, as well as scenic panoramas for those who traveled on them. What they have become has been dramati cally brought home to the residents of Richmond, Harrisburg, WilkesBar re and Elmira, who even now are cleaning out the deadly detritus left by their receding waters. Those rivers are today an open system of sewers, turbid conveyors of the sludge that is one of the chief products manufac tured modern America.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Carter B. Horsley's article on holdouts [A Holdout Stands Pat on 42d Street, July 2] notes that the City Planning Commission sup ports legislation that would assure quicker assemblage of contiguous land parcels. The enactment of such a meas ure would unquestionably be a boon to the private de veloper.

title: Pirates Top Phillies, 32, on Sanguillen's Horner to Earn TwinBill Split
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (UPI)Manny Sanguillen horn ered and singled to drive in two runs tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3.2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and a split of a doubleheader. The Phils won the first game, 52.

title: Science
description: Flying 570 miles above the ground, a oneton package of cameras and elec tronic scanners is watching Earth looking for diseased forests 1,000 miles from any settlement, measuring the world's wheat crop, detecting the spread of water pollution over entire oceans and monitoring dozens of other phenomena on a scale never before possible.

title: The Eagleton Tragedy
description: The Eagleton Case dramatizes once more the need for a coherent policy of checking the medical records of men and women who are being considered for positions of great power. Senator Eagleton is not the cause but only the latest example and victim of a much more serious national problem.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: PITTSBURGH, July 29  The first four of 25 color dynamic trolley cars ap peared on Pittsburgh streets this week. One car was painted with orange rising suns on a field of yellow and purple.

title: New Aircraft Tactics Reducing Threat Of HeatSeeking Missiles in Vietnam
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 29  New tactics being employed by South Vietnamese and American aircraft have significantly reduced the threat from the enemy's small heat seeking missiles. which for a time curtailed air operations in some areas.

title: First There Was Milk And Honey (Fattening), Then...
description: JERUSALEMMinna Amsel, an Is raeli who was born in New York City, probably knows more people in Israel than anyone else. Not by face or by name, but by figure. She is the Jerusalem representative of Weight Watchers and runs an endless series of hortatory sessions in two lan guages: in Hebrew for local people and in English for visiting students and tour ists anxious not to interrupt Weight Watching just because they happen to be in a Holy Land and could wait for a miracle to happen.

title: Flame Stops at Athens
description: ATHENS, July 29 (AP)The Olympic flame carried by a Greek runner who will partici pate in the Olympic Games at Munich, West Germany, next month, arrived here tonight, its first major stop. The flame was lighted by the rays of the sun at ancient Olympia yesterday and carried here by relay run ners.

title: A Batchy, Sweaty, Funky Life
description: Sports of The Times

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH OVER BRAVES, 52
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants scored all five of their runs in the fourth inning tonight in a 52 victory over the Atlanta Braves, giving Frank Reberger his sec ond triumph of the season.

title: ENCYCLOPEDIA DUE ON' MEDICAL ETHICS
description: An encyclopedia of medical ethics, said to be the first of its kind, will be written at George town University by scientists and ethics specialists of Pro testant, Jewish, Roman Catholic and humanistic beliefs.

title: STRATEGY IN U.N. ON KOREA SHIFTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29North Korea's allies here are developing a new strategy in their campaign to get United States troops out of Korea and to end the United Nations presence there.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: We live in the age of Freud. Now we know that often our anxieties are name less dreads and that if we can just get them out of our unconscious minds and vis cera and lay them on the ta ble for explicit and conscious examination in the light of economic principle, then we may be able to exorcise our fears and dreads.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A nationwide series of interviews has indicated that despite the vote by the A.F.L.C.I.O. Execu tive Council to remain neutral, most of organized labor will offer its traditional support to the Democratic Presidential ticket.

title: Padres Top Reds In 17 Innings, 43
description: CINCINNATI, July 29Jerry Morales's runscoring single in the 17th inning scored Nate Colbert and gave the San Diego Padres a 43 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: Music
description: NEWARK  Jazzmobile, the mobile concert hall that has been traveling around the streets of New York ev ery summer since 1965, will come to New Jersey for the first time next week.

title: Music
description: MUSICIANS are apt to do odd things when they tangle with the outside world, but John Taverner, the great English composer of the ear ly 16th century, is surely the only one to have ended his life as a police informer. By early middle age Taverner had become master of chor isters at Wolsey's grand new Cardinal College in Oxford. But there he fell in with un derground Protestants and repented him very much that he had made songs to Popish ditties. When the Reformatio came, he sided against Rome, abandoned music and spent the rest of his days persecuting adher ents to the old faith. (Or so it was formerly supposed; re cent research tells a rather different story.)

title: DISPUTE IS SET OFF OVER DENVER WILL
description: DENVER, July 29The will of the late Helen G. Bonfils who was chairman of The Denver Post newspaper, has been contested in Denver County Probate Court by 11 distant cousins.

title: ARTISTS PRESSING PROTESTS ON RENT
description: In 1968, when remodeling work started for the Westbeth artists' housing community at 463 West Street on the Lower West Side, the project was hailed as the largest govern mentfinanced housing develop ment for lowincome and mod erateincome artists.

title: WALLACE ASSERTS HE'S OUT OF RACE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 29 Gov. George C. Wallace for mally ruled out today a third party race for the Presidency this year. He said his doctors had directed that I not involve myself in any extensive cam paign activity in the immedi ate future.

title: Wichard, Post Quarterback, And 3 Others Cut by Colts
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 29 (AP) The Baltimore Colts cut two quarterbacks and two other players today reducing their National Football League squad to 65.

title: The Need for Authority
description: WASHINGTON, July 29There is in America today a widespread crisis of confidence in the nation's institutions. It extends through political institutions such as the Presidency and Congress, bureaucracies like the police, and cul tural institutions such as colleges, churches and the family itself. No where is it more visible or more in tensely felt than in education since a nation's school system is both a mirror and a maker of a nation's values.

title: The town became something nobody could possibly foresee
description: Two books about old Connecticut towns have been recently published: Anthony Bailey's In the Village, about Stonington, and Donald S. Connery's One American Town, about Kent. Now Edwin Rosskam has written a book about Roosevelt, N. J., a relatively new town with a very different history.

title: Betty Hyatt Engaged
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., July 29Miss Betty Ann Hyatt and Patrick Breslin Kenny plan to be married Oct. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hyatt have announced the engage ment of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Kenny of Northbrook, Ill., and North Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Hyatt is a vice president of the CibaGeigy Corpora tion in Ardsley, the chemical company. Mr. Kenny's father is president of the Kenny Construction Company of Skokie, Ill.

title: Head of Auto Union Local Gets Nixon Campaign Post
description: PITTSBURGH, July 29 John McCarrell, president of the largest local of the United Automobile Workers in the Pittsburgh area, has been named vice chairman of Democrats for the Reelection of President Nixon.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELES  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton faced a news conference here last week and said: Quite frank ly, I did not think the experience have had in these instances [of de pression] was of that great moment. I now realize it is. I've read the head lines in the morning papers. . .

title: L.I. House Tour to Blend Old and New
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I, George Washington never slept there, but Mrs. A. Moore Montgomery's home in Water Mill, one of the five that will go on view Wednes day in the fifth annual House Tour sponsored by St. Ann's Episcopal Church, was built the same year in which America's first President was born.

title: Prague Trials Provoking Rising Criticism in France
description: PARIS, July 29The Prague trials in which the remnants of the liberal movement in Czechoslovakia are being con victed of subversion, are pro voking mounting criticism here.

title: English Defeat Aussies. To Retain The Ashes
description: LEEDS, England, July 29 (Reuters)England retained The Ashes today when Derek (Deadly) Underwood's bowling paved the way for a ninewicket victory over Aus tralia in the fourth cricket test. The victory, achieved inside three days, gave Eng land a 21 lead in the five match series, with one match drawn. So the English cannot lose.

title: The World
description: The Congo ... Nigeria ... Bangladeshthe list of emer ging nations racked by civil war and its attendant mis eries is a long one. Last week the focus swung on one of the latest names on the list.

title: News of Boating
description: The largest number of yachts to enter a race on the New York Yacht Club's an nual cruise has been 83, ac cording to William H. Foulk Jr., race chairman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: I find it pathetic that the writer is so parochial that he must report on Albuquerque with the condescendingly tolerant viewpoint of a National Geo graphic journalist interviewing the Masai. On my next trip to the West I must procure a native guide, prefer ably one who speaks English, from the Governor  General of Santa Fe. I am eager to observe these curious peo ple who remain ignorant of the basic metaphysical truth that distances are short, who frequent The Last Chance Saloon of a Saturday night and who seldom venture more than 10 or 15 miles from their simple wooded huts. As an effete Eastern snob, Mr. Ge wertz's prose offends my sensibilities, and as a native Southwesterner, I'm right annoyed.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sunday July 30  Unending rains that have inun dated five provinces on Luzon caused landslides yesterday in the mountain city of Baguio, burying homes and their oc cupants.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter Reuther
description: An attractive biography of the United Automobile Work ers leader. Begun by the late Lorena Hickok, it has been completed in an unidentified way by Jean Gould. Miss Gould's mark is on the book, however, and she seems to have done considerable re search. Although she writes ob jectively, not ignoring Reuth er's faults (among them an en larged ego), the book does not really penetrate Reuther's character, but is mainly a de scription of his career and the battles he fought for his many and firmly held ideals.

title: New 'Novel
description: How do you get attached to people? asks David, a with drawn 19yearold, who has picked up (or been picked up by) the novel's heroine, a preg nant, 250pound runaway ma tron named Margaret Adams. And that indeed is the question Miss Rossner explores in a sunburst of human relation ships. The pseudomaternal at tachment that links Margaret and David, when they finally come to roost in a Vermont commune. The ambivalent fa therdaughter thing that Mar garet has for DeWitt, the com passionate impostor who is the commune's guru and who de livers her skillfully of twins. The attachment Margaret has to her nutty husband Roger, a sometime creator of intestinal collages and bad scenes, and to her father, a benighted Bos ton traffic cop. And the ties that bind the dozen or so fugitives who make up DeWitt's extended family.

title: SOME BUG KILLERS CITED AS HAZARDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Consumers Union warned to day against using bugkilling shelf papers and vaporizing strips.

title: Jackson Hits 2 Homers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 29 (UPI)Reggie Jackson hit a pair of solo homers and Joe Rudi hit a threerun shot to lift Jim Hunter and the Oakland A's to a 72 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Limits to Growth, a product of an M.I.T. team led by Denis Mead ows, and subtitled A Report for the Club of Rome's Project on the Predicament of Mankind, is an at tempt to explore the complex of troubles affecting men of all nations thatin the authors' viewthreaten the survival of our species.

title: Poet as his own victim
description: Negative capability, as the romantic poet John Keats defines it, is the writer's special gift of remain ing in doubts and uncertainties, of sympathizing with many points of view, and not trying to assert him self by irritable reaching after fact and reason. The strength of Jon Anderson's Death & Friends is the obverse of that negative virtue. Anderson's verse is peculiarly irrit able without ceasing to be empathic and imaginative. It displays a speed of phrasing and positivity of observa tion that strike back at experience by heightening it. Though the poet seeks a measure of distance or the aesthetics of painsomething to allow him real maturing, a Keatsian luxury of selfdevelopmenthe finds only further experience. He writes on, therefore, in a kind of bitter ecstasy, making his stupor his sub ject. His head nods as he walks, affirmative machine.

title: Quisling The Career and Political Ideas of Vidkun Quisling 18871945. By Paul M. Hayes. 368 pp. Indiana University. $12.95.
description: Despite giving his name to the language as a synonym for traitor and despite giving his country to the Nazis in 1940, Vidkun Quisling remains a mi nor historical curiosity. Why he conspired with the Germans to set himself up as puppetFh rer in occupied Norway has remained something of a mys tery. One consequence of the mystery has been a spate, in Norway, of books seeking to defend Quisling's actions. The key to the man, now writes Mr. Hayes, a fellow at Oxford, was his ideas, a vague collec tion of fascist opinions. Frus trated in his desire to interest his countrymen in them, he ac cepted Nazi help. This is a sensible attempt to understand the man in terms of his intel lectual bias rather than through some quirk of personality. It is quite convincing.

title: Disabled Children Taught to Adjust
description: WILLISTON PARK, L. I.  A waystation for the handicapped pupil who is nearly ready to move from a segregated special educa tional program to a normal school life has been estab lished here by the Nassau County Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

title: Undercutting SALT
description: The sky appears to be the limit in the efforts of Defense Secretary Laird to ease the apprehensions of President Nixon's conservative supporters over the stra tegic arms limitation (SALT) agreements with Moscow. After successfully pressuring Congress to approve the first installment of a $25billion program of new strategic weapons, thus reviving the arms race in fields not limited by the SALT I pacts, Mr. Laird is now undercut ting a vital American proposal for the second round of the SALT talksthe proposal to ban landmobile ICBM's.

title: The Guest Word
description: The following essay is from Roland Barthes's Mythologies, just published by Hill & Wang, which is reviewed on Page 5 of this issue. Though it was writ ten nearly 20 years ago, we feel its re flections on literature and women are still apt. It's worth noting that Barthes was well aware of the acerbic tone of his short essays: the times, he wrote, may well make sarcasm the condition of truth. We offer Novels and Children in ad miration of Barthes and as a complement to Joan Didion's superb essay on the wo men's liberation movement, which ap pears on Page 1.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONAn idea has begun to be talked about here, within the Nixon Ad ministration as well as among some sophisticated members of Congress of both parties, that might help to clarify significantly the debate about tax reform.

title: WARY LEATHERBEE, EDITOR AT LIFE, 61
description: Mrs. Mary Lee Logan Leath erbee, a senior editor of Life magazine, drowned Friday when she and three others tipped over in a canoe as it passed through rapids in Campbell River, British Colum Lia. She was 61 years old and resided at 870 Fifth Avenue.

title: Music
description: APSEN and Central City both are Colorado mountain towns with interesting summer music festivals. But beyond those bare details, not many similarities can be cited. To go from one to the other it is necessary to go over the Continental Divide, which seems rather symbolic in that the two festivals are widely separated in their philos ophies and goals. In a way, Aspen and Central City stand for opposing forces that cur rently play tugofwar with American society. Visiting the two festivals in quick suc cession is like peering into the microcosm enclosed in a drop of waterthough, of course, immensely more di verting musically. (All the paramecia and amoebae that one has known personally have been tone deaf.)

title: Sadat Launches a 2d Ship
description: CAIRO, July 29 (AP)Presi dent Anwar elSadat returned to the shipyard in Alexandria today and launched his second ship in three days. The Middle East News Agency described the vessel as the first Egyp tianbuilt warship equipped with the most modern naval fighting instruments but gave no further details. On Thurs day, Mr. Sadat launched the 14,000ton merchant ship Suez.

title: News of the Camera World
description: A WORKSHOP in creative photography will be conducted by Ansel Adams from Sept. 30 to Oct. 8 in Yosemite National Park in California. The work shop will include instruction in both advanced and basic techniques, in the zone sys tem of exposure control that was originated by Adams, in taking photographs by na tural light, and in mountain and environmental photog raphy. There will be daily field trips in and around the park, combined with lectures, seminars and conferences, and the staff of instructors will include Paul Caponigro, Marie Cosindas, Wynn Bullock, Morley Baer and Ted Organ. Tuition for the workshop will be $200, and those interested should write to: Best's Studio, Inc., Box 455, Yosemite Na tional Park, Cal. 95389

title: The Revenue Dilemma
description: For nearly a decade, state and local governments have been caught in a threesided financial squeeze. There has been an upsurge in the demand for public services for everything from higher education to daycare centers, from narcoticstreatment programs to Medicaid.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK THEATER STAGES REVIVAL
description: It is an impressive, vivid and often gripping program that the National Black Theater is presenting at its twoflightup premises at 9 East 125th Street. The work itself, labeled A Re vival: Change! Love Together! Organizel, and the very set ting comprise a microcosm of lowerdepths, Harlem squalor and community hope, projected in the show's second half, by a contrasting gospel rally of song and testimony. And the gospel is black fulfillment, unity and diligence that would purge the community of evil and outside exploitation.

title: Chess Epidemic Spreads to State
description: TEANECKThough Reyk javik, Iceland, the site of the current world championship chess match, is thousands of miles away, chess fever has definitely spread to New Jersey.

title: AROUND THE
description: Damp, humid weather is an inviting climate for mildew, especially on lilac and phlox. It appears as a white mold on foliage. Control with Benlate and repeat every two weeks. . . White flies are busy this year and difficult to control; use mala thion at 10day intervals or try frequent swishing with the hose.... It is late to pinch back 'mums for bushy abundant flowering; do so if you must this week only.

title: Two Gain in Tennis
description: DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 29 (UPI)Juergen Fass bander of West Germany and Ilie Nastase of Rumania ad vanced to the men's singles fi nal today at the Duesseldorf Rochus Club's international tennis tournament.

title: The World
description: It was last September, and the an nual preparations for the grandiose parade and fireworks display that mark the Oct. 1 anniversary of Com munist rule in China were proceeding apace.

title: Home Improvement
description: SOME people always buy cheap paint brushes and rollers because they pre fer to throw them away after every job, instead of cleaning them out each time they are used. The trouble with this system is that low quality, bargain priced tools make it almost impos sible to get a smooth, uni form finish that one can be proud of.

title: Full House the W.H. A.'s Goal As It Deals for Drawing Cards
description: After his league stole yet another player the other day, a World Hockey Asso ciation official was asked what the W.H.A. was going to do about a development league.

title: Allende's Future: A Hostile Congress Is Only One Obstacle
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 President Salvador Allende Gos sens has fulfilled a major part of his socialist program in less than two years in office, but he faces an uncertain political future.

title: Books: Countless Court Treasures
description: THE FIRESIDE BOOK OF TENNIS. Edited by Allison Dan zig and Peter Schwed. 1,043 pp. Simon and Schuster. $14.95.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stamps
description: DESIGN errors on stamps do occur. This lightning struck twice in Mexico in 1969 from designs by Artura Brisha. There was a stamp honoring Father Junipero Serra, the Franciscan mis sionary who began the de velopment of the Spanish missions that led to coloniza tion of California. The por trait on the stamp was of Father Francisco Palou, a co worker, whose portrait ap peared alongside Father Ser ra's in a painting by Mariano Guerrero, which hangs in the Museum of History in Cha pultepec Park, Mexico City.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The article on Albuquerque was the equivalent of someone coming to New York City for an overnight stay, talking to nobody, seeing only the Times Square area, and going home to write a com prehensive essay on New York and its people. The writer didn't mention a single worthwhile aspect of Albuquer que itself. It has one of the finest winter sports areas in the country; one of the world's largest tram systems; the Old Town area, which is a restoration of the city from the Spanish era; fine homes, which indeed have trees, grass and gardens; the Indian pueblos only a few miles away, and other points of interest too numerous to relate here. Mr. Gewertz is like many in this area who have preconceived ideas about every place else and, by God, nobody is going to change them.

title: Miss Martha Jane Wentworth to Wed
description: NEW VERNON, N.J., July 29Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henry Wentworth of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Jane Went worth, to Milan Daniel Baker Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ba ker of Culver, Ind. The wed ding is planned for Sept. 2 in Charlotte, N.C.

title: SCRAM, SCAD, ULMS and other aspects of the $585.9billion defense budget
description: Melvin Laird, who says he will retire as Secretary of Defense at the end of this year, is attempting to leave an historic legacy for his successors: an $85.9billion defense budget, the largest in peace time history. And inasmuch as President Nixon has declared an end to the cold war both East and West, this one will be the foundation upon which all future postcoldwar budgets raise their shining minarets.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, July 29 (Reuters)  A vast re lief operation headed by an American pilot to aid mil lions of people facing starva tion in Bangladesh has run into difficulties because num bers of burlap bags used in air drops have burst.

title: Financing Canada's Energy
description: TORONTO  With the opening last month of the $1billion Churchill Falls hy droelectric plant in Labra dor, Canada completed the first of the many projects she is planning to help meet the energy needs of both her self and the United States in the nineteenseventies.

title: U.S. ACCUSES 13 IN HOUSING FRAUD
description: CHICAGO, July 29  Four Federal Housing Administration employes, two real estate men and seven builders have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of bribery and fraud. Others are expected to be indicted.

title: Art
description: THERE is a new book out called Henry Moore: Unpublished Drawings (Abrams, $15) that took me by sur prise by giving a feeling of personal contact with an art ist through reproductions of his work. The book consists of an introduction by David Mitchinson (only 7 pages) and 212 plates, selected from a much larger number of pages in a series of notebooks kept by the sculptor from 1921 to 1970. The drawings, are left to speak for them selves, which they do fluent ly. Never intended for pub lication, they make up a kind of informal autobiography of Henry Moore's creative life. Going through the book is like talking to him about his work. Or better. I once in terviewed Mr. Moore and didn't get half as far.

title: Science
description: To the parent birds all the eggs in the nest look alike. So do the chicks, when they hatch. Their begging cries for food sound the same. Yet there is an interloper in the familya chick that will grow up to be a radically different bird.

title: Modernity Coming to Mali Cliff Dwellers
description: SANGHA, MaliSome of the cliff dwellers north of here have never seen a white man and have no contact with the mod ern life of the outside world.

title: Alan Ruben Is Named U.S. Olympic Fencing Captain
description: Alan M. Ruben, president of the Amateur Fencers League of America for the last four years, has been named the captain of the United States Olympic fenc ing team.

title: Recordings
description: WITH the 1972 Rolling Stones tour fading into history, virtu ally everyone who attended the highlypubli cized concerts will be left with his or her special mem ories. Spectacular as the Stones were (and there can be little doubt that their per formances were prime ex amples of the dictum that all music tends toward theater), my most vivid musical mem ories are of the chargedup playing and singing of the blind soul singer/musician Stevie Wonder and his crisp little band, Wonderlove.

title: the traveler's world
description: STOCKHOLMThe last time I was in this pleasant capital was in August, 1967, just before Sweden made its big move from driving and walking on the left side of the road to driving and walking on the right. Joining moat of the world on the right side of the road was a convulsive oper ation, achieved by an act of Parliament that rejected previous negative plebis cites and required changes of habits drilled into the consciousness and sub consciousness of people (and animals, as well) from the day they left their cradles.

title: Movies
description: I'M tired of going to movies and seeing women get raped. It makes me so damned angry. And what also makes me angry is the way critics can go blithely along passing cinematic judgments on films while ignoring all sorts of ques tions raised by their content. Alfred Hitchcock's latest film, Frenzy, is a per fect example. Here is Vincent Canby in The Times: Strangulation, rapes, close shaves, pursuits, the arrest of an innocent, amusing character bitsnone of these things is especially meaningful except in Hitchcock, for whom method is meaning, and whose perfection of method involves an evident passion.

title: Andrew Rudnick Plans to Marry Christie Ramsey
description: RUMSON, N. J., July 29 Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Ram sey have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Christie Carnegie Ram sey, to Andrew John Rudnick. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Newton Rudnick of New York.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Women's ?? ?? ing, brassieres are selling very well, and even girdle sales are staging a modest. comeback.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Monmouth County horse show, a fixture on the New Jersey shore for 77 years, has been canceled be cause there is no place to stage it.

title: Photography
description: PART TWO in the Con tinuing Saga of Jack Hunt and His Amaz ing Photographic Eggs! (In the first installment of our drama, Jack Hunt was discovered last spring by this reporter at the Nei krug Galleries, fresh from California with a line of curious photomedia objects: eggs  chicken, duck and ostrich  with photographs upon them, created by unique and secret processes which Hunt was not at liberty to divulge. Hardened and sensi tized by ingenious patent pending techniques, these eggswhich can be tossed 15 feet onto a rug without breakingbore a variety of images upon their surfaces, most of which were Western landscapes. Questions per taining to exhibiting these objects and distributing them in large numbers were be ing discussed. (While the is sue of the gimmickiness, or lack of it, inherent in these artifacts did arise, it was never resolved, primarily be cause the tempting distrac tion to bounce just one more on the rug kept offering it self.)

title: Travel Notes: Ghosts and Gurus
description: HAVE you ever seen a ghost? Ever stayed in a haunted castle? Practiced Yoga? Attended a seance? Or met a guru? If not, you may get a chance, for with interest in the occult skyrocketing, a whole passel of tours has become available to acquaint the openminded traveler with the other world beyond.

title: Back on the Track
description: After a good deal of fumbling, the Democrats now seem ready to face up to the unpleasant necessities forced upon them by the belated disclosure that Senator Eagleton, their VicePresidential nominee, was three times hospitalized for nervous exhaustion and depres sion. Senator McGovern has left little doubt that he would welcome his running mate's withdrawal from the ticket and, painful though such action must be to a man with so many attractive qualities and such eagerness for higher office, it is hard to believe that Mr. Eagleton will not proffer his resignation when the two meet tomorrow.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  It was long after midnight, a nearly full moon gleamed on a tumble of waves and tide rips southeast of Chappaquid dick, and to the northwest the land lay low and black.

title: DISPUTE IS SET OFF OVER DENVER WILL
description: DENVER, July 29The will of the late Helen G. Bonfils, who was chairman of The Denver Post newspaper, has been contested in Denver County Probate Court by 11 distant cousins.

title: CHIEFS TOP GIANTS AT CANTON, 2317
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 29 Instead of being embarrassed, as some feared, by the Kansas City Chiefs, the New York Giants did well enough today in a 2317 defeat to give their more optimistic followers some thing to hang on to.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, July 29 (AP) Mayor Henry Maier, a Demo crat whose wife recently an nounced she was voting for President Nixon in November, says he'll support his party's ticket. The Mayor said yester day be was supporting Senator George McGovern although he was not satisfied that the Sen ator chemically relates to the conditions of the cities.

title: Cynthia A. Boll Bride in Jersey
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., July 29 Miss Cynthia Anne Boll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Eugene Boll of Glen Rock and Hortonville, N. Y., was married here this morn ing to Robert Douglas Rhodes of Waldwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Andrew Rhodes of Franklin Lakes.

title: Two Unions Based Here Support Bid by McGovern
description: Two unions based in New York City with a total mem bership of 460,000 have en dorsed the Democratic Presi dential candidacy of Senator George McGovern and his run ning mate, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton.

title: Women, the convention and brown paper bags
description: It is absolutely crucial that no one go for hot dogs or anything else during the voting tonight, or the Senator could lose the nomination. You must look and listen carefully for our instructions on the floor. You know we're not exactly a fascist organization, but it is imperative that you follow our orders implicitly.

title: Sale of Cigarettes, Put at 547.2 Billion In 1971, Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) Americans purchased 547.2 billion cigarettes in 1971, record.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S MUSIC L.I. May Get Downbeat Of Nashville
description: HOLBROOK, L.I.  John Keller has a vision of Long Island as a center of country and western music  in ef fect a northern Nashville. For the last three years, Mr. Keller, who grew up with horses on his father's potato farm in Hicksville, has been slowly building what he hopes will be the foundation for such a movement.

title: A House on Sutton Place Transferred to U.N. Chief
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 (AP)Secretary Gen eral Waldheim of the United Nations got a new home yes terdaya town house on Man hattan's fashionable Sutton Place.

title: Games
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland It is the classic confrontation between the good guy and the bad guy. On the one hand is Boris Spassky, chess champion of the world, and on the other his Ameri can challenger, Bobby Fischer. Spassky is cultured, literate, witty, handsome, wellmannered. Fischer is petulant, secretive, inconsiderate, ungracious. And he is simply ruining Spassky. At week's end the score stood 5 to 3 in his favor. Fischer needs 7 more points to win the title. Spassky needs 9 to retain it.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDemocratic Vice Presidential nominee Thomas F. Eagle ton had two fundamental goals: to give the public some exposure to Tom Who? from Missouri ... and to help unite the party behind his Presi dential running mate, George Mc Govern.

title: Cathy L. Prettyman Fiancee of Lawyer
description: MILFORD, Del., July 29 Mr. and Mrs. John A. Pretty man have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Cathy Lynn Prettyman, to Roy E. Kinsey Jr., who is a member of the White House staff in the office of John W. Dean 3d, counsel to the President.

title: Diane Langsam Fiancee
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 29 Miss Diane Paula Langsam, a senior at the Uni versity of Pennsylvania School of Allied Medical Pro fessions, plans to be married next month to Steven Alan Bernstein, a cum laude grad uate of Penn and son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bernstein of Woodbury, L. I.

title: ELECTIONS BOARD SET FOR CHANGES New Head Seeks Automatic Registration for All
description: The new president of the Board of Elections hopes to move New York toward some form of automatic or universal registration under which all residents would be eligible to vote unless they took some af firmative action to unregister themselves.

title: R. D. Becker Marries Lucy Ann Goldberg
description: Miss Lucy Ann Goldberg and Robert David Becker were married last evening by Rabbi Harry Halpern at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: Chiles Urges OilGas Ban In Ocala National Forest
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reu ters)Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, has urged the interior department to ban the exploration of oil and gas in Florida's Ocala National Forest and maintain it as haven for nature lovers and endangered animal species.

title: Urban Guerrillas Studied in West
description: The United States Army and armies in Western Europe and Latin America are devoting more and more time and ef fort to the operational tech niques of urban guerrilla war fare.

title: 4 Stand and Watch Girl Caught in Ride On School Grounds
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 27 (UPI)  A school principal, a doctor, policeman and firemen could only stand and watch for 70 minutes yesterday while a 5yearold girl cried in agony with her finger caught in a playground ride.

title: FAKE BIG MAC ANGUS TO BE AUCTIONED OFF
description: DENVER, July 29  Big Mac, a fake black Angus steer that fooled the judges of Den ver's 1972 National Western Stock Show, was declared a stray animal this week and or dered auctioned off.

title: The Nation
description: At the end of a long, government gray hall on the seventh floor of building near the Capitol in Washing ton is a large, windowless room where billions of dollars were up for grabs last week.

title: McGovern's Peace Views Called Positive by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, July 29In its first public evaluation of Senator George McGovern's program to end the Vietnam war, North Vietnam has said that his position contains po sitive elements which would lead to a correct, peaceful set tlement of the Vietnam prob lem.

title: New York
description: The heat is off New York this week end but it's on Consolidated Edison in a big way. The utility faces city and state investigations, law suits and a mountain of public ill will.

title: The Nation
description: It was a scientific experiment. For 30 years Fedetal health officers al lowed 400 poor black men known to have syphilis to go untreated despite the discovery that penicillin could cure their devastating disease.

title: MOHAWK EDUCATOR CALLS TEXTS BIASED
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 29 American Indian youngsters are still victims of misrepre sentation in history books and of cultural ignorance, the chair man of the third annual confer ence of New York State Iro quois Indians said here today.

title: Schroder Back in Bonn
description: BONN, July 29 (AP)West Germany's former Foreign Minister, Dr. Gerhard Schroder, returned today from the first visit to China by a prominent Bonn official and said that the trip had convinced him that BonnPeking relations could be intensified and strength ened. He is chairman of the lower house's Foreign Policy Committee.

title: In the Beginning There Was Aleph and Beth...
description: Many people travel each year to Portugal, the Netherlands or Greece, but how many stop to learn Portuguese. Dutch or Greek before they go? A surprising number of people who go to Israel, however, first take lessons in Hebrew. For such travelers, courses in Hebrew are offered in schools, colleges, synagogues and ulpanim, or Hebrew schools, throughout America.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to Each OtherBehind Bars
description: GEORGE COHEN is a black man. He is short and lithe in build, gracious in manner, and proud when he needs to be: Up to a year ago he was a substitute teacher in the Newark, N. J., school system.

title: How McGovern will win
description: Man an' boy I've seen the Dimmycratic party hangin' to th' ropes a score iv times. I've seen dead an' burrid an' th' Ray publicans kindly buildin' a monymint f'r it. . . . I've gone to sleep nights wonderin' where I'd throw away me vote afther this an' whin I woke up there was that crazyheaded, ol' loon iv a party with its hair sthreamin' in its eyes, an' an axe in its hand, chasin' Raypublicans into th' tall grass. 'Tis niver so good as whin 'tis broke.

title: 3 Men Drop Body at Hospital In Early Morning and Flee
description: The body of a 23year old man, apparently stabbed to death at a rock concert in Queens, was delivered early yesterday morning to Jamaica Hospital by three men who fled before they could be ques tioned, the police said.

title: John Lowe to Wed Muriel M. Costigan
description: Arthur J. Costigan of West Brighton, S.I., has announced the engagement of his daugh ter, Miss Muriel M. Costigan, to John A. Lowe, of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Lowe of Clifton and Spring Lake, N.J. The wed ding is planned for December.

title: ROCK NOMINATED BY PEOPLE'S PARTY
description: ST. LOUIS, July 29The Peo ple's party, a shifting coalition of radical groups around the country, officially chose Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatri cian and antiwar activist, as its Presidential candidate today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: Maybe it takes a Midwesterner trans planted to New York for many years to appreciate both East and West. I feel sorry for this boy who went West and saw nothing but imitation New York tawdriness and who gave only a slight nod in recognition of the grandeur of the Rockies. In the desert he saw none of the wonderful variety of what grows and lives there. He didn't see the astonishingly delicate flowers that spring up out of the gypsum sands of White Sands Monument in New Mexico. He didn't come down the Coronado Trail (U.S. 666) from Springerville, Ariz., with one spectacular view after another as you wind down to the desert floor carpeted with yellow, pink and white flowers. He didn't visit Monument Valley, stay at Goulding's Trading Post, ride among the Navajo around the valley and see the dawn bring those wonderful monuments, created by wind and weather, to life.

title: The dress is back
description: No more bits and pieces

title: Shorter Reviews
description: This is the inspirational, true story of Harold Krents, whose life Butterflies Are Free was based on. Thanks to un derstanding parents who en couraged a fierce independence in the blind boy, Krents learned to deal with the world by him self. There were lonely periods in his childhood and adoles cence, but he managed to par ticipate in an amazing number of boy's activities. Krents was graduated from Harvard Law School, passed the New York Bar examination and took a wife. There are sentimental as pects to this story, but it is Krents himself who tells it, and one doesn't begrudge him a word. in the blind boy, Krents learned to deal with the world by him self. There were lonely periods in his childhood and adoles cence, but he managed to par ticipate in an amazing number of boy's activities. Krents was graduated from Harvard Law School, passed the New York Bar examination and took a wife. There are sentimental as pects to this story, but it is Krents himself who tells it, and one doesn't begrudge him a word.

title: Spassky Refuses a Bid For a New Chessboard
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 29 (UPI)Boris Spassky, the world chess champion, re fused today to change chess boards to please Bobby Fischer and the judge of the match refused to apologize to the American challenger for allowing television cam eras to film one of the games.

title: The Bargain Basement at J.F.K.
description: THE terminal is often Jammed with groups milling around trying to find their leaders, and there are people sprawled on the floor after waiting hours, maybe days, for their flights to materialize. It's a place where horror stories abound: stranded groups, bumped passengers, missed flightsand a missed flight often means kissing your cashonthebarrelhead, paidinadvance fare geed by. Patience and a sense of humor are priorities and, somehow, the harried, frustrated wouldbe travelers retain their cool. But then they don't fit the usual airportcrowd mold; they are generally a younger, more informally dressed bunch. There are no starched dresses and white shoes, but plenty of blue Jeans and long hair. Even the older passengers look hip, and their luggage, like everyone else's, is battered.

title: Miss Robin Ann Chadwick Is Wed
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., July 29In the Union Church of Pocantico Hills this after noon, Miss Robin Ann Chad wick, a pianist, was married to Michael Barnett Duram, who attends Principia College in Elsah, Ill. The Rev. Mar shall Smith performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Bongson, Home of 40,000, a Wasteland of Rubble and Craters
description: BONGSON, South Vietnam, July 26The shops and houses are broken shells Many walls and roofs are missing. Living rooms are heaped with charred furni ture, twisted metal and shards of glass.

title: The LeftHanded Bellwether
description: Sports of The Times

title: Park Names New Chairman Of His South Korea Party
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 29 President Park Chung Hee has appointed former Premier Chung II Kwon as acting chair man of the governing Demo cratic Republican party. Mr. Park is the party's leader.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: If, in her search for cutesy criticisms of the model rooms at 60 East End Avenue [To morrow Meets Today and Yesterday on East End Ave., July 16] Linda Charlton had actually looked, asked some one or put her eyeglasses on she would scarcely have been able to avoid the realization that this was hardly a fitting subject for a really withit review.

title: Teacher Weds Mrs. Susan Dexter
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 29Mrs. Susan O'Rourke Dexter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. O'Rourke Jr. of New Canaan, was married here this afternoon to Porter Dean Caesar 2d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Caesar 2d, also of New Canaan.

title: The World
description: TOKYO  A century ago, Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli set Brit ain on an imaginative, diplomatic course to play off the German, Rus sian, and AustroHungarian Empires against one another. Today, Premier Kakuei Tanaka appears to have launched Japan on a similar independ ent diplomatic venture by maneuv ering among the United States, the Soviet Union and China.

title: NORTHPORT RIDER WINS YOUTH TITLE
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 29Carol Potter, a 19yearold blonde from Northport, L. I., who thinks there is nothing in the equine world like a quarter horse, won the allaround youth championship today at the Orange County horse show.

title: Home Improvement
description: TO solve the problem of neatly storing long elec tric extension cords, yet keeping them instantly available when all or part of the cord is needed, a port able reel is now available that will hold up to 100 feet of threewire cord (No. 16 in round or No. 14 in flat). Made of welded steel with a heavy zinc plating that makes it rustproof enough for out door, as well as indoor, use, the reel comes with its own stand and carrying handle. The reel itself measures 9 inches in diameter and is 5 inches wide. Cleats at the side secure the end of the cord when not in use. Reelit, $5.95. (Central Specialties Co. 6030 Northwest Highway, Chicago, III.

title: APARTMENT FIRES PLAGUING DENVER
description: DENVER, July 29Two more apartment complexes being built in the Denver area have burned, continuing a pattern of more than 30 fires in the area that have caused more than $6 million in damages in the last four years.

title: The World;Canada: An Opening, To the South
description: Last February, Canada and the Unit ed States broke off trade talks that had been going on unsuccessfully for some months. Mutual recriminations abounded. Canadian diplomats and politicians left no doubt of their irritation over remarks made by then Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally.

title: The World
description: BELFASTFollowing Bloody Fri day,  a British Defense Ministry spokesman said last week, the Sec retary of State for Northern Ireland [William Whitelaw] said nobody could be in any doubt that very res oulte and determined antion must be taken against those responsible.

title: LYNN TAKES SAIL; 78 FAIL TO FINISH
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 29 Only eight Etchells22 Class sloops in a fleet of 86 in nine classes finished today in the season's 23d Yacht Racing As sociation championship regatta conducted on Long Island Sound by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

title: Study of New Documents Holds Up Hanrahan Trial
description: CHICAGO, July 29The trial of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County state's attorney, and of 13 other persons charged with conspiring to obstruct justice as a result of a police raid on the Black Panthers has been re cessed following the disclosure of longsecret documents.

title: Television
description: ASKED to list the most pressing problems currently confronting commercial television, a key net work executive began with the broad category of consumerism. That category was headed by the subject of counteradvertising  specialinterest commercials taking issue with standard corporate commercials. And then, a close second, came the highly sensi tive subject of children's programing.

title: Jo Attia Is Mourned in Paris; Last of OldStyle Gangsters
description: PARIS, July 29Jo Attia, last of the oldstyle gangsters of the French underworld, was buried quietly here this week after a ceremony at the little RightBank church of St. John the Baptist. Among those attending were both gangsters and policemen. He had friends in both camps.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Starting this fall, the College Boards, the Law Boards and other nationally standardized tests will be joined by the Mechanics Boards a series of examinations designed to certify qualified automobile mechanics.

title: Television
description: ONE morning recently, as I was leaning over the bathroom sink trying to jolt the sleep out of me with handfuls of cold water, a voice piped up from about the level of my thigh.

title: MADRID TIGHTENS REIN ON STUDENTS
description: MADRID, July 29The Gov ernment imposed rigid discipli nary controls over Madrid's two universities today in an effort to curb student and faculty unrest.

title: BLACK PAY LAGS IN SOUTH AFRICA Survey Shows Many Earn Only $14 a Week
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 29Many black workers in South Africa's white industries are being paid less than $14 a week, well below the poverty line, a new survey shows, despite and increase of 10 per cent in blacks' wages in the last year.

title: Mysore, an Indian State, Is Renamed as Karnataka
description: NEW DELHI, July 29 (AP) The name of the southcentral Indian state of Mysore has been changd to Karnataka, after the language spoken there.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Government last week seemed to be at war with itselt over just how effective President Nixon's war on narcotics has been.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The antiwar up surge in Congress came as something of a jolt for the Administration. Presi dent Nixon had seemed for so long to have the Vietnam issue so well un der control. Then, suddenly last week, he was under doublebarreled political attack. The message to him from Capi tol Hill was: Get us out of the war or we'll do it for you.

title: WALL STREET
description: Abraham H. Treff, a 19 yearold college student from Philadelphia, captured world wide attention seven months ago by opening accounts at six wellknown brokerage firms and buying more than $200,000 in stock without ever putting up a penny in cash.

title: White Sox Win, 42, in 9th
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) Ed Spiezio singled with two Spiezio singled with two outs in the ninth inning today to score Carlos May from third base with the winning run and a 43 decision for the Chicago White Sox over the Kansas City Royals, their 26th onerun victory this season.

title: Stamps
description: THE man history forgot, John Hanson, will get some postal recognition on September 1 when a 6cent blue postal card will be released in Baltimore that bears his portrait, his name and the word Patriot. Haz arding a guess, most every one reading this is going to ask: John who?. John Han son is who, a man who might have claimed for him self, and which some have claimed for him, that he was actually the first President of the United States.

title: Recordings
description: THE year 1636 saw a transfer of power within the Holy Ro man Empire: the ail ing Ferdinand II gave way to Ferdinand III, causing some confusion in at least one ar tistic quarter, for Claudio Monteverdi, the maestro di cappella of St. Mark's in Ven ice, had planned to dedicate his eighth book of madrigals to the old emperor. But the great composer, ever capable of absorbing the quick changing requirements of his royal world, let this develop ment inspire him to invent rapturous celebrations of Ferdinand III's immortal glory and include them in the collection before they published in 1638.

title: Carol J. Hehre, Walter Slocum Plan Marriage
description: EASTVILLE, Mass., July 29 Dr. Frederick W. Hehre, an associate professor of anes thesiology at Yale University, and Mrs. Hehre of North Haven, Conn., and Eastville, Martha's Vineyard, have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Jean Helve, to Lieut. Walter Scott Slocum, U.S.N.

title: Rumania:
description: BUCHARESTThe 2,200 delegates to the Rumanian Communist party conference held in Bucharest earlier this month were back in the provinces last week spreading the word: The country's 197175 fiveyear plan was in good shape, but there'd be some changes made. It was this second part of the party's message to the people that seemed the more important one. What had happened, in the view of independent observers was that Pres ident Nicolae Ceausescu's dream of an industrially advanced and politically independent Rumania had gone a little sour.

title: Where Are Our Nuclear Weapons?
description: WASHINGTONNo aspect of na tional defense is so heavily veiled in secrecy as the deployment by this Gov ernment of nuclear weapons in foreign countries. Most people, including pow erful members of Congress, not only take this secrecy for granted, but con sider it justified.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A SURGE OF BUYING on Friday pushed gold prices to new highs. In London gold hit a record $68 an ounce. In Zurich the price rose to $67.15 and in Paris $68.57. A halt in Soviet sales was cited for the rise.

title: The World
description: Quangtri was the only South Vietnamese provincial capital to fall to the North Vietnamese in the offensive they launched March 30. Its fall was a major propaganda victory for the Communists. When the Saigon forces be gan a counteroffensive a few weeks ago, recapture of Quangtri was a key objective.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: GENEVA, July 29  Senior executives of the airlines flying the North Atlantic will meet Sept. 8 to seek agreement on a new oneyear package of fares to become effective April 1, 1973, the International Air Transport Association an nounced tonight.

title: Laura Wishnick to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 29  Miss Laura Wishnick and Staven Michael Arnold plan to be married on Aug. 20. Mr. and Mrs. John H. Wishnick have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Arnold of Golden Isle, Fla.

title: GrandmasterSpectator Adds Color to World Title Match
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 29 There are about 90 chess grandmasters in the world, and 10 or so of them are in Ice land watching the Spassky Fischer confrontation in the world championship match. Of those 10, the most colorful, the most uninhibited, the most amusing and the shrewdest is the Polishborn Miguel Najdorf of Argentina.

title: Kidnapped Woman Found Unharmed
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 29 (UPI)  A 49yearold woman kid napped from her suburban es tate by two men on Thursday was found unharmed today after her husband paid a $1 million ransom.

title: New &Novel
description: Sloth and Heathen Folly takes one full turn in the wheel of destiny of an uneasy, over populated East Asian country. Gamalia is a shaky republic that has been conducting a lowlevel civil war with various insurgent factions out in the boondocks. Mr. Robinson's pes simistic narrative tells how en lightened diplomacy almost helps to clear the monsoon filled air.

title: Crime Still Seen as Peril In City Garment District
description: It was a fine summer's day, and the two garment district executives were care fully decked out for their noonday stroll along Eighth Avenue.

title: Escape from her husband's towering shadow
description: As one can sense from the title, Joseph P. Lash could not conceivably have written a volume comparable to his tour de force, Eleanor and Franklin. There is, there had to be, an anticlimactic quality to Eleanor: The Years Alone. Gone is the contra puntal tension between those two sin gular human beings; that strangely disembodied yet vital symbiosis has vanished. However, the story of Mrs. Roosevelt's solitary journeywhich was to last another 17 yearshas great inherent interest, and Lash has chronicled it in moving terms. This sequel could easily have become an annotated social calendar, but Lash has used it as a vehicle for exploring a number of fascinating aspects of American politics in the postWorld.

title: Jacklin Out of P.G.A. Field
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 29 (UPI)Tony Jacklin of Eng land has withdrawn from the Professional Golfers' Associa tion championship, which will begin on Thursday at Oakland Hills Country Club. A P.G.A. spokesman said today that Jacklin notified tournament of ficials of his decision in a tele gram, but gave no reason for withdrawing.

title: An Actress Tells Her Beauty Secrets, Or.. Never Let a Whale Bite Your Leg Off
description: THERE are certain differences between me and Mark Twain. Besides the obvious one of gender, and him being a river boat pilot. His cynicism what I refer to. I hate to take advice from some people, he said, when I see how bad they need it.

title: Ickx Takes Pole Position, Averaging 119.5 M.P.H.
description: NUERBURGRING, West Ger many, July 29The most fa mous German Ring since the Nibelungen's Trinket inspired Wagner stretches for 14.1 miles in all directions through the Eifel Mountainsa fearful combination of uphills and downhills, hairpins and bumps that has resulted in several automobile racers going to their personal Valhalla.

title: The World
description: President Anwar elSadat's bombshell of two weeks ago his expulsion of Russian forces from Egyptis still reverberating in the Middle East. But the focus of the reaction seemed to shift last week from Cairo to Jeru salem.

title: The Nation
description: It took nearly a decade to put Ralph Ginzburg in prisonand eight months to get him out. The publisher was originally convicted in 1963under an 1872 Federal antipornography statute of sending obscene material through the mails in connection with his maga zine, Eros. After a series of appeals over the years, the Supreme Court, 5 to 4, upheld Ginzburg's conviction, creating at the time the pandering doctrinethat is, that he could be pros ecuted not because of the content of the magazine but because its advertis ing pandered obscene material. No one before or since Ginzburg has been con

title: Coins
description: MORE than 500 guests, including Govern ment officials and prominent numisma tists, attended the recent dedication of the new Exhi bits Hall of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Republicans are getting ready to hold their convention and I am getting ready to go on vacation, so as a parting shot here is the inside dope on the awards program Clark MacGregor is planning, which he hopes will give the big show at Miami Beach some suspense and pizzazz. Re member, you read it here first and last.

title: Miss Melville's Victory Helps Australia Take 31 Tennis Lead
description: CLEVELAND, July 29Aus tralia's top women tennis play ers scored victories today and took a 31 lead over the United States into the Bonne Bell Cup finalwhich will feature a re match between Chris Evert and Evonne Goolagong tomorrow.

title: 57 Suspects Held In Ulster Drive
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 29  One hundred and thirty three persons were ar rested in a weeklong search by security forces for suspected Irish Republican Army terror ists and 57 are still in custody, the Royal Ulster Constabulary announced today.

title: To Dan Gable, Wrestlers Are the Craziest People
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 29 Sweat oozed down Dan Ga ble's forearms as he pulled a 10 of spades from the deck.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md, July 29 (AP)President Nixon spent much of today working and relaxing at Camp David, his mountaintop retreat in western Maryland. He scheduled some of his time for social activities with his wife and the Nixons' close friends, Mr. and Mrs. Roger Johnson, who were along for the weekend.

title: Blind in Connecticut Get Trail for Bird Watching
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 30 Blind men and women went bird watching here this week on a novel woodland trail de signed specifically for the sight less.

title: POLICE EMPLOYE FIGHTS DISCHARGE
description: NEW HAVEN, July 29  A hearing convened by the New Haven Board of Police Com missioners to investigate a shoplifting charge filed against a public information officer for the police came to an abrupt and uproarious conclusion last week when the defense lawyer charged that his client faced a kangaroo court.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: An intelligence pro looks at his fellow pros. General Strong has served in a variety of posts; he was wartime Chief of Intelligence under Eisenhow er's Supreme Command and DirectorGeneral of Intelligence at the Ministry of Defence, so he knows his spies. He dis cusses such figures as Lieuten ant  Colonel Hentsch, Ger many's chief intelligence offi cer in World War I; Gen. John Chateris, Douglas Haig's chief who was sacked; Colonel Gauche of the French Deuxime Bureau, who watched the Ger man buildup between the wars; Allen Dulles and John A. Mc Cone of the C.I.A. Strong down grades the importance of spies; most useful intelligence infor mation, he maintains, comes from the collation and evalua tion of large masses of data from mainly public sources. He defends the function of in telligence in national planning and refuses to impute evil mo tives to governments that use intelligence service.

title: Shipbuilder on Long Island Has Concrete Plan
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I. Already a hero in this town, David Kent has not even completed building his 127 foot, twomasted brigantine, a vessel made of steel rods and cement, much less put her into the water, sailed off and fulfilled the dream of a lifetime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The World
description: LONDONLast Sunday, about 100 pickets lounged in the sunshine out side London's Pentonville prison. They seemed goodnatured, quenched their thirst at the Balmoral Castle pub, talked of their anger but didn't show it. Inside the jail were five dockers, held for illegal picketing and wrapped in a mantle of tradeunion martyrdom.

title: Freed Mental Patients Found Needing Services
description: In New York State, as else where, the number of people in ??ental institutions has drama tically declined in recent years.

title: EVANS, MISS ASHTON TAKE KAYAK TITLES
description: BLOOMINGTON, Md., July 29 (AP)Eric Evans and Caro line Ashton won national kayak solo championships to day and moved closer toward clinching berths on the United States Olympic whitewater team.

title: One of the Flying Wallendas Dies in Fall From Pole
description: WHEELING, W. Va., July 29 (AP)Richard Guzman, a mem ber of the famed Flying Wal lendas high wire troupe, died early today after a fall last night before an opening night circus crowd here.

title: Lisa Hills, Briarcliff, Alumna Bride of Thomas McChesney
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, July 29Miss Elizabeth Crawford Hills, who is known as Lisa, was married here this evening to Thomas Bal mer McChesney. The Rev. F. Washington Jarvis performed the ceremony in the Fair mount Presbyterian Church.

title: Maureen Downey Is Bride in Suburbs
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 29Miss Maureen Elizabeth Downey was mar ried here this morning to Robert John McLaughlin at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Sylvester Taggert performed the cere mony, assisted by Msgrs. Hugo A. Doyle and Charlton Burns.

title: August
description: This strange year of weather extremes brings us to August, traditional season of ripening toward the maturity of autumn, toward total harvest. And, as always, toward both blessing and bane. The natural harvest, particularly in the woodlands and brushy margins, will be much larger than normal. But the farmers, particularly here in the Northeast, have been disastrously shortchanged, with hay crops lost completely and corn crops cut in half by the record rains and their aftermath.

title: Executioner Choice Today In Delaware du Pont Stake
description: STANTON, Del., July 29An attractive field of stakes stars will battle it out tomorrow in the sixth running of the $50, 000added William Du Pont Jr. handicap at Delaware Park.

title: Worst is the willingness of the press to be had
description: When Spiro Agnew is no longer a household word, he may yet be re membered for his attack on the press. That attack opened national debate on a subject previously the exclusive domain of a small cogno scenti. It was about time that some one demanded that the press reflect a broader spectrum of national opin ion and it was salutary to recognize openly that news is what pub lishers, editors, and reporters say it is, not some omnipresent truth wait ing to be divined. But Agnew had things all backward. The problem was and is not an effete conspiracy by the Eastern Establishment. As Ben H. Bagdikian, the media critic and an assistant managing editor of The Washington Post makes abun dantly clear, the newspapers of this country are overwhelmingly Repub lican and conservative. They usually operate without real competition. They most often simply accept the official administration version of events. And they are generally less interested in service than in profits.

title: Patrolman Shot in Ankle With Own Gun in Scuffle
description: A Transit Authority patrol man was shot in the left ankle and had his revolver stolen from him yesterday while try ing to arrest a young purse snatcher, the police reported.

title: Joan Laycock, John M. Wolfle Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Miss Joan Elizabeth Laycock, assistant to the director of the National Council of Crime and Delinquency, here, and John Morrill Wolfle, divi sional manager of Cleaves Food Service in Silver Spring, Md., were married today in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral. The Rev. Dr. Jack McClendon of the New York Avenue Pres byterian Church performed the ceremony.

title: Movies
description: THERE'S more to Dis ney than Disneyland and Disney World. There are still Disney movies, and the latest one just happens to be the most expensive one in the entire history of the company founded by the late Walt Disney. It's called Island at the Top of the World, and it will cost in the neighbor hood of $8million, which is a pretty fancy neighborhood.

title: American Motors Rolling Again
description: DETROITAt the Ameri can Motors Corporation's headquarters on Plymouth Road in Detroit they have blasted away the old motto that was carved above the entry. It read: I've thought of a better way.

title: Leonard Wins 500 on Recount
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 29  Joe Leonard won the Schaefer 500 today with finish clouded by the kind of confusion that endears the United States Auto Club to racing fans.

title: An ExLawyer Defends Role in Investment Scheme
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 29Don Lowers swirled a vodka and grape juice in his right hand, staring at it while he groped for an explanation for his $11 million bankrupt investment scheme.

title: Making space
description: A dramatic sweep of space seems to be what the daring souls who re model city brownstones want. And they are discovering architects inven tive enough to find the space (or the illusion of it) even in New York City's notoriously narrow Victorian build ings. This brownstone on the fringes of Chelsea is a scant 13 feet wide and is set on a 15  foot  wide lot. Every inch had to count, explains architect Ming Wang who achieved a feeling of openness without killing any floor space. Ming Wang's secret was her use of plaster rather than expensive carpentry and wood detailing. She encased the existing staircase in elegant plaster curves, retaining the wooden hand rail since it would be very costly to have a new one made today. The most dramatic element of the house is the large circular conversation pit. The owners, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Wales, wanted a family room but were re luctant to forgo the luxury of the doubleheight room. Wang's solution gives both plus spatial drama.

title: Meri Leeds Engaged To Thomas F. Pollak
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 29 Miss Men Ellen Leeds, a junior at Cornell University, and Thomas Frederick Pollak, a Cornell senior, plan to be married next May.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Triumph Over Indians, 43, on Home Run by Robinson in 11th Inning
description: BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP) Brooks Robinson slammed his fifth home run of the season with two out in the 11th in ning today, lifting the Balti more Oriles to a 43 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Local Field Days
description: SEVERAL field days are scheduled to give home gardeners practical an swers to yard problems. On Saturday, a Lawn and Garden Field Day will be held at the Kitchawan Field Sta tion, Ossining, N. Y. Coop erating will be staff members of the Brooklyn Botanic Gar den and the Westchester County Agricultural Exten sion Service. From 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. lecturedemonstra tions will be given on lawn care and weed identification as welt as vegetable garden ing. A free soil testing tent will be set up and a question and answer booth. The field station is on Route 134, two miles east of the Taconic State Parkway, seven piles northeast of Ossining.

title: Overcoming the thereness of things
description: Roland Barthes is one of the very few literary critics in any language of whom it can be said that he has never written a bad or uninteresting page. He has produced twelve books (and these two excellent translations now give him a total of five avail able in English) and well over a hun dred articles, and though I can't claim to have read everything he has written, I have eagerly read much of his work. He is now almost 57, and almost no one will dispute his place now as the major figure in criticism in France, having for a time been the center of a fairly loud literary quar rel between the Old and the New Critics.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Women's Movement
description: To make an omelette you need not only those broken eggs but someone oppressed to break them: every revolutionist is presumed to under stand that, and also every woman, which either does or does not make 51 per cent of the population of the United States a potentially revolu tionary class. The creation of this revolutionary class was from the vir tual beginning the idea of the women's movement, and the ten dency for popular discussion of the movement still to center around day care centers is yet another instance of that studied resistance to the pos sibility of political ideas which char acterizes national life.

title: MISS PENELOPE RENZ
description: Miss Penelope Ann Renz, daughter of Walter A. Renz, president of the American Rail way Car Institute, and Mrs. Renz, died yesterday of a train tumor at her home, 136 East 64th Street. She was 23 years old.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Arlene Merne Is Bride
description: Miss Arlene Susan Merne was married here yesterday morning to Gerald C. Smal done. The Rev. Thomas P.
