McNich ol as performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Angels in Brooklyn. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. William F. Merne of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Smaldone of Valley Stream, L. I.

title: Joe Frazier Travels a Lifetime and a Century to Cover 19 Miles
description: BEAUFORT COUNTY, S. C. Enslaved blacks once worked the Brewton Plantation: field hands and house servants in the whites' genteel, deceptive nomenclature of that day, field niggers and house nig gers in the blacks' bitter, accurate mem ory of this clay. Brewton, set in the flat, spongy Carolina lowland, goes back 240 years to a royal grant from King George II to Miles Brewton in 1732. History clings to Brewton like the Span ish moss on the huge oak trees that line the driveway: one of the early owners, Charles Pinckney, was a signer of the Constitution, and if George Washington did not actually sleep under Brewton's hospitable roof, he did pay a Presidential visit in 1791. During the Civil War, Gen eral Sherman's troops put Brewton to the torch as they swept from Savannah to Charleston. The owners rebuilt the main house on the original site after the war.

title: The Homecoming Singer By Jay Wright. New York: Corinth Books. 95 pp. $3.
description: Most first books of poems are scatterings, a necessary shedding of skin. Not Jay Wright's. The Home coming Singer, in its gifted, delib erate way, tells not simply the story of what worlds a young man casts aside, but how those worlds provide the secret strength to begin again. It is a tense and memorable collec tion.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Primary Loser Sues to Run for Mayor
description: NEWARK  A loser in the June 6 primary election has asked the United States Dis trict Court here to enable him to run in the general election despite his defeat.

title: Sky's the Limit on L. I.
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I. It's 10:20 on, Saturday night on Teaneck Drive, a quiet residential street that runs east and west for a few blocks here. A few lights are still on in the Wellkept houses that line the street, and an occasional automobile passes through.

description: DENVER, July 29A galaxy of New York bridge stars clashed here today in two Spin gold knockout team matches at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

Eberle, President Nix on's special representative for trade negotiations, said at a news conference today.

title: Nalees Man Takes Atlantic City Handicap By a Neck and Returns $22.20
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 Nalees Man won the $57,550 Atlantic City Handicap by a neck today at Monmouth Park, taking the victory from six ri vals who went under the wire within a length and threequar ters of him.

title: MISS SALTZBERG, 80, TAUGHT AT MONROE
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 29 Geraldine (Jerry) Saltzberg, who retired in 1952 as chair man of the English department of James Monroe High School, the Bronx, and then carved out a new career here as a music critic and commentator, died Tuesday. She was 80 years old.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Olympic Fencing Site Is Damaged by Fire
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 29 (AP)  The Olympic torch for the Summer Games here was ignited yesterday. Today another Olympic flame burned, damaging the site of the Olympic fencing matches.

title: Some PlayfulAnd PicaresqueAdventures With Klee
description: 0F the modern masters, Paul Klee is one of the most difficult to categorize. Early in his career, he was a member of the German Expression ist group, the Blaue Reiter, yet his work, with its sense of order and efficiency, seems far removed from the untidy emotionalism of his Expressionist colleagues. That he was influenced by Cubist pictorial practices is undeniableyet there, too, his habit of using narrative and anecdotal devices in his paintings makes him some what alien to the Cubist tra dition. For 10 years, begin ning in 1921, he was a teach er at the Bauhausthat hot bed of modern design theory with its high ambitions for placing the fine arts at the service of a design revolu tionbut Klee's art remained rooted in the older, fineart conventions of easel painting.

title: TWO LEAD AT 146 IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (UPI) Jan Ferraris, a slender brunette from San Francisco, battled rain and a soggy golf course to day in carding a oneoverpar 74 that put her in a tie with Gail Denenberg of Monroe, N. Y., for the lead in the Lady Pepsi open. After 36 holes the coleaders had 146 totals.

title: Orchids Flowering In Tropics of L. I.
description: Like the Dutch who claim the tulip as their special flower, hundreds of Long Islanders claim the orchid as theirs. Mere mention of it to them elicits fervid descrip tions of windowsill boxes and of glvenhouses in the backyard where the prized orchids are carefully nur tured every day.

title: New York
description: Anthony J. DiLorenzo went to the dentist last Wednesday; what Federal authorities would like to know now is where he went afterwards. DiLorenzo, a longtime, mobster who was once considered the heir apparent to theleadership of the Mafia family of Vito Genovese, was most recently at the Federal House of Detention in New York, serving a 10year sentence for transporting stolen securities and fac ing trial on two other Federal indict ments. He'd been having trouble with his teeth, and two weeks ago Warden Louis L. Gengler gave him permission to visit his dentist on Long Island without guards; there was nothing un usual in this since it is common prac tice in the Federal prison system to let convicts with good records take short leaves unescorted.

title: WALL STREET
description: When Robert W. Haack formally steps down as presi dent of the Big Board to morrow, Wall Street will still have a Haack around.

description: DENVER, July 29A galaxy of New York bridge stars clashed here today in two Spin gold knockout team matches at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Clark Arrives in Hanoi During Air Raid Alerts
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 29 (Agence France Presse)  Ramsey Clark, for mer United States Attorney General, arrived here today from Moscow on a twoweek visit as guest of the North Vietnamese Government.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Naturally, the relation of the black man to society has also come under the province of the mystery novel. Nearly al ways, these books are written by white authors, and nearly always they leave one a little dissatisfied. No matter how skillful a white author may be, he still is viewing the world through a conditioning appara tus that has little in common with black life. Thus, he leans over backward to be fair. In the process, he can become pretty damn condescending.

title: Miss Australia Named As 1972 Miss Universe
description: DORADO, P. R., July 29 (UPI)  Miss Australia, 20 yearold Kerry Wells of Perth, was named Miss Universe of 1972 tonight in the finals of the pageant at this Puerto Rican beach re sort. It was the first time in the 21year history of the beauty pageant that an Au stralian girl won the title.

title: The town became something nobody could possibly foresee
description: How is Roosevelt, New Jersey doing in Roosevelt, N.J.?

description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: ...And a New Start
description: Jackie Robinson, the man who cracked the black bar rier in bigleague baseball and a leader in the drive for recognition of minorities in business, has now set up a biracial construction com pany that should widen the participation of minority businessmen in inner city and suburban building.wealthy, with a record of more than $800million in construction behind them.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to see a total eclipse of the sun, you will have to station your self on the right day along a path thousands of miles long but only 100 miles wide. Total eclipses occur once every year or two, but most of them are over water or unpopulated areas. New York, which last witnessed a total eclipse in 1925 (totality was visi ble only for those north of 80th Street) will have to wait until April 8, 2024.

title: John E. Countryman Dies: Retired Del Monte Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (UPI)John E. Countryman, re tired chairman of the board of Del Monte Corporation, died last night at the age of 69.

title: Growing Rights Cases Overload State Agency
description: NEWARKJust as demands for equal rights and a new attack on discrimination in housing have sharply increased the work load of the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, its budget was frozen and staff shriven by austerity in Trenton.

title: On to a Million at 18, With No Strings
description: In the days when British youths with an eye toward instant fame and fortune could either grab a guitar or kick a straight pass, Trevor Francis picked the latter, Now he is as popular as George Best and he's on his way to his first million.

title: Turnpike Plans Refuge For Wildlife in Meadow
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The New Jersey Turnpike Au thority  frequently accused of building superhighways that disregard the surround ing environmentplans to set aside 85 acres or marshland in the Hackensack Meadow lands for perpetual preserva tion as a marshwildlife sanc tuary.

title: Gynecologic Services In Nassau Expanded
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The Nas sau County Health Depart ment has expanded its serv ices for women. Two centers, in plainview and Hempstead, are now offering Pap tests and breast examinations, am,:ng other gynecologic services.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market ended the week thoroughly mixed but all of the leading averages showed slight gains as trading continued at a relatively moderate rate.

title: AMTRAK TO INSTALL COMPUTER SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Amtrak has announced that a nationwide computerized service will begin operations next summer in the Northeast and will be completely func tioning by 1975.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: I work only for the pleas ure to create something. This is my philosophy. I like the people and I like the com panies.

title: ExPhotographer of Young Is Focusing on New Career
description: SYOSSET, L.I.Constance Bannister, the photographer whose provocatively cap tioned children's pictures en joyed great success in the 1950's, is at work at her home here, searching for new areas to which to direct her creative talents.

title: PAROLE BOARD PLANS REGIONAL UNIT SETUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Maurice H. Sigler, the new chairman of the United States Board of Parole, said Tuesday that the eightmember panel was preparing a pilot project to create regional parole boards with full authority to act on parole requests from Federal prisoners.

title: Come One, Come All to Saratoga!
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 29 Herewith your Spa correspondent's annual report on Saratoga, respectfully submitted:

title: U.S. TEENAGERS TRAIL RUSSIANS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 29 (AP)The Soviet Union's teenage track and field ath letes, scoring unexpected points in the high hurdles and pole vault, swept into a 6254 lead over the United States halfway through the first dual meet be tween the countries' juniors.

title: Western Junior Tennis Captured by Gerulaitis
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 29 (UPI)  Vitas Gerulaitis of New York won the West ern, junior tennis title today by beating Patrick DuPre, of Birmingham, Ala., 6.3, 63, 61.

title: Brazil Plans Trading Companies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Bra zil's economic planners are preparing a bold move aimed at making the country one of the world's industrial forces in a relatively short period.

title: Crangle Questions Poll to Elect National Delegates
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the State Joseph F. Crangle, the State Democratic Chairman, is ques tioning the validity of a poll being taken of the party's state delegation to the national con vention to elect four members to the Democratic National Committee.

title: LAKELAND TERRIER WINS SHOW HONORS
description: DALEYVILLE, Pa., July 29 Honors in the 43d Lackawanna Kennel Club show today were taken by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell's Lakeland terrier, Ch. Special Edition.

title: Miss Northrop Plans Nuptials
description: PROCTOR, Vt., July 29 Mr. and Mrs. John H. North rop have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Rachel Ann North rop, to Christopher Scott Keyser. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Ray Keyser Jr. of Proctor and Chelsea.

title: Miss Bakke Affianced
description: MANKATO, Minn., July 29 Mr. and Mrs. Einar Carl Bakke have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Kathleen Ann Bakke, to Graham Rathman Fonda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Cadwallader Fonda Jr. of Nantucket, Mass., for merly of Stamford, Conn., and South Salem, N. Y. The future bridegroom is proprie tor of The Pantry Shelf, a gourmet food and cookware shop in Nantucket

title: Ouster Fails to End School Speech Issue
description: TRENTON  Teacher and schooladministrator groups have taken sides for the next round in the case of a teach ers association president dis missed for having criticized her superintendent of schools.

title: Dr. Anna M. Lankester Bride On Coast of Bruce C. Webster
description: TIBURON, Calif., July 29 Dr. Anna M. Lankester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willem G. F. Lankester of New York and Candlewood Isle, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Bruce C. Webster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Webster of North Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Bergen Presses Mosquito War
description: PARAMUSNow that the area has undergone repeated and heavy spring and sum mer rains that are a boon to mosquitoes, the Bergen Coun ty Mosquito Extermination Commission has launched massive attack on this year's increased airborne menace.

title: Bronx Woman, 23, Is Slain As She Is Hit in Cross Fire
description: A 23yearold Bronx woman was fatally shot yesterday af ternoon when she stepped out of her apartment building, at 1997 Davidson Avenue in the High Bridge section, into a hail of gunfire.

title: Berthe Hanover Betrothed to John Ford
description: Miss Berthe Diana Han over, a candidate for a doc torate in political science at the New School for Social Research, plans to be mar ried Aug. 19 at the Waldorf Astoria to John Gilmore Ford, founder of the interior design firm of John Ford As sociates.

title: B. P. Coffin Jr. Weds Arlene Lechtanski
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29 Miss Arlene Rose Lechtan ski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jerome Lechtanski, was married here today to Bruce Pitkin Coffin Jr., son of Mrs. A. A. Butler of Montreal and Mr. Coffin of Cincinnati. Msgr. Hugh J. Murphy performed the cere mony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: About Motor Sports
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 29 Whenever a United States Auto Club hot shot like A.J. Foyt invades the south to run in a stockcar race sanc tioned by the National As sociation for Stock Car Auto Racing, he drives a car pre pared by a NASCAR crew. The reason is eminently soundNASCAR cars are better. Tomorrow's Penn sylvania 500 here at Pocono Inter national Raceway is something of a turnaround. This is a stockcar race sanc tioned by USAC in which a few visiting celebrities from NASCAR will compete, not ably Richard Petty, Tiny Lund and David Marcus. But there is one significant dif ference  they will drive NASCAR machinery.

title: Helen Traubel Dies; Wagnerian Soprano
description: Helen Traubel, the famed Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, died of a heart attack Friday night in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 69 years old.

title: Judith King Is Married to Teacher
description: GREENVILLE, Del., July 29Miss Judith Marie King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. King of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married here this afternoon to Charles Theodore Axarlis, son of Mrs. S. Theodore Axarlis of Leb anon, Pa., and the late Mr. Axarlis. The Rev. Stamatios Ganiaris performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church. He was as sisted by the Rev. George Gregory and the Rev. C. Dale David Doren.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Prefontaine Is Heading For Last LapMunich
description: Atter an eightmile morn ing workout in Maine and sixmile jog the same after noon around St. John's Uni versity in Hillcrest, Queens, Steve Prefontaine left for Europe bubbling with confi dence and eager for the chal lenge of the Olympics.

title: Music
description: ANYONE who feels that 19thcentury music needs a rest in the concert hall should look kindly on the 12day festival, The New and the Old, that will open the second season of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washing ton. The day it begins, Aug. 30, there will be two charac teristic programs, one by the American Brass Quintet of works by the 15thcentury Josquin des Prez, the 18th century Bach and composers in between, the other by the National Symphony Orchestra of works by Copland, Pen derecki, HaubenstockRainati, Ligeti and Zimmermann, all of this century.

title: Manila's Olympic Funds Going to Flood Relief
description: MANILA, July 29 (AP) The Philippines has virtually canceled the participation of its basketball team at the Munich Olympics to devote the funds, $93,350, to flood relief in Luzon.

title: New Battle in Philippines
description: MANILA, July 29 (UPI) Armed Christians and Moslems fought for 90 minutes in southern Philippine tow today, and when the fighting was over, five persons were dead and five others wounded, the Phil ippine press agency said.

title: M'GOVERN DEFERS EARED MOVE PENDING PARLEY
description: RAPID CITY. S.D., July 29 Senator George McGovern said today that there may not be any change in the Democratic ticket after he and his running mate, Senator Thomas F. Eagle ton, meet early next week.

title: Queens Is Basking in a Housing Boom
description: The massive Rochdale Vil lage project of 5,860 units, big as it was, still accounted for fewer than half of the new dwellings erected during a construction boom in Queens Community Planning District 12 during the nine teensixties.

title: TENSIONS ABATING ON BERLIN CAMPUS
description: BERLIN, July 29The wave of student unrest that has trou bled the West since the late ninetcensixties has left Ber lin's Free University In dis array, polarized and near pa ralysis.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Child to the Effrons
description: YONKERS, July 29  A daughter was born on July 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Barry J. Effron in the St. John's Riv erside Hospital here. Mrs. Effron is the former Tova Altman. Her husband is a systems analyst with the Martin Marietta Corporation. The child has been named Leslie Ann.

title: YONKERS FEATURE TO C.B.'S JIMMY
description: YONKERS, July 29  The mile feature tonight at Yon kers Raceway was won by C. B.'s Jimmy ($25.85) in 2:03 2/5, but the victor of the trot had toa share honors with 67year old Jimmy Jordan.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWhile the country focused last week on the agonies of the Democrats, Richard Nixon was sitting exactly where one might have expected to find himin the catbird seatextracting political profit from the powers of his office, the machinery of his organization and the difficulties or his opponents. Seldom have the advantages of incumbency been so richly and concisely displayed.

title: Public Gets a Rare Peek at Fine Art Lent to Show by Prominent Jerseyans
description: TRENTON  The homes and offices of some of New Jersey's mostprominent citi zens contain a large quantity of exceptionally fine art, and now the general public is getting a rare chance to see some of it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: World Health Organization Sees a Decline in Cholera
description: GENEVA, July 29Cholora, after reaching an 18year peak in 1971 with a total of 171,329 cases, appears to be on the wane this year. The World Health Organization said yes terday.

title: For Republican Women, It's Their Turn to Shine
description: Now come the Republicans. Theirs will be a very social National Conven tion with parties galore. At the same time, their best estimate is a possible 32 per cent women delegates compared with the Democrats' 40 per cent. Mrs. Anne Armstrong, the National Commit tee's cochairman, sees that as a signifi cant advance.

title: Newcombe Eliminates Riessen by 75, 62 in Tennis at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 29 (UPI)Topseeded John New combe romped in the quarter finals today, but secondseeded Nikki Pilic and the defending champion, Tom Okker, lost in the $50,000 First National ten nis tournament.

title: Packer Excels at Quarterback As Jets Top L.I. Chiefs, 293
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 29 While it may have been just the first scrimmage of the sea son for the New York Jets with an opponent other than themselves, it was quite a bit more for the Long Island Chiefs today.

title: Syphilis Program Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The National Medical Asso ciation, an organization of black doctors, said Friday that it had begun an investigation into a 40yearold Government syphilis experiment involving 600 Alabama black men. Public Health Service officials say that 400 of the men had the disease and never received treatment.

title: Ancient Roman Harbor Is Discovered in Italy
description: ROME, July 29  Prof. Frank E. Brown of the Ameri can Academy in Rome has announced the discovery of an ancient Roman harbor whose structure shows evi dence of a highly advanced engineering technique.

title: CloseQuarter Fight Rages Near Citadel at Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 30South Viet namese marines fought bunker to bunker yesterday in an advance toward Quangtri's Citadel.

title: The Nation
description: Depression. It is one of the most common, most insidious of all hu man illsand like so many forms of mental illness, one of the least under stood. Last week Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, for his own special reasons, indicated that he would seek to edu cate the public about depression. Political considerations aside, the need for such instruction is widely recog nized in the medical fraternity.

title: Penn Ridge to Stress Variety In Its Record Entry Saturday
description: News of Dogs

title: Key Witness in Calley Case Seized on Perjury Charge
description: TULSA, Okla., July 29 (AP) Charles Dean Gruver, the key missing witness in efforts to win a new courtmartial for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., was arrested by the Tulsa police today on a warrant charging him with perjury.

title: J. B. Weller Weds Janine M. Southon
description: DEERFIELD, Ill., July 29 Miss Janine Marie Southon, national public relations di rector with Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes in New York, was married here this evening to Jonathan Bruce Weller, an associate of Eastdil Realty, an affiliate of Eastman Dillon Union Securi ties & Co., Inc., in New York.

title: EDWIN R. BERGER
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 29Edwin R. Berger, a former president of the Master Sur gical Instrument Company of New York, died today at his home, 385 Ocean Boulevard. He was 71 years old.

title: Television
description: THERE we were, crawling through the parched Sands of Apathy in the gray land of Rerun, nothing ahead but less and less of less and less, when up popped an oasis called David Steinberg. My parents ac cept me for exactly what I am, said the oasis by way of introduction, a punishment from God. Refreshing.

title: Young Classic Tickets Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets for the Grambling Morgan football game, to be held in Yankee Stadium Sept. 9 will go on sale tomorrow.

title: More of Brooklyn's Poor Participating in Community Programs
description: A growing number of poor people in Brooklyn are taking an aotive part in community action programs, as indicated by their record turnout last week to elect 241 neighbors to the boards of nine antipoverty corporations.

title: Unusual Weather May Prove To Be Asset
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.For sun worshipers, swimmers, scratchers and sneezers, the summer of '72 may go down as a very bad year, indeed. But for shoppers, hunters and birdwatchers, this year's soggy spring and muggy summer may well be remem bered as something akin to paradise.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Gets $4.9Million to Fight Crime

title: Hoover Center to Stress Domestic Problems, Too
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 29 (9P)In a major change in em phasis, Stanford University's Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace will begin devoting the same amount of attention to domestic problems as it does to international af fairs.

title: Miss Hazeltine Is Wed
description: CHATHAM, N. J., July 29 Miss Beverly Ann Hazel tine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Hazel tine of Tequesta, Fla., for merly of Chatham, was mar ried here this morning to David Gardner Bellamy of Tucson, Ariz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gard ner Bellamy of St. Davids, Pa. The Rev. Clarence La crone performed the cere mony in the Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Education
description: Crime and violence have been growing in New York City's public schools; the number of reported in cidents reached 580 last year as compared with 333 in 1970, accord ing to Board of Education figures. And Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, who believes that the figures ac tually are much higher, has made safety a major issue in contract talks.

title: Giant Rookie Defends Well for AllStars
description: CHICAGO, July 29It was John Mendenhall, a 23yearold rookie from Grambling College who knocked Roger Staubach, the Dallas Cowboys' quarter back, out of the College All Star game last night. Menden hall reported to his pro team, the New York Giants, at Can ton, Ohio, today and, inasmuch as no Giant has done anything especially offensive to the Dal las Cowboys in several years, this may be a good omen.

title: R.D. Schmidt Marries Miss Joan Pinkerton
description: The marriage of Miss Joan Margaret Pinkerton to Rob ert Denny Schmidt took place here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The Rev. Hugh McCandless performed the ceremony.

title: George F. Berlinger
description: City Council leaders set up yesterday a showdown confron tation between the state and city chiefs who have been war ring, mostly at long distance, over the extent of ineligibility in the $1.3billion annual pay ments to city relief recipients.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Burns Defeats Sacks, 15 and 14, in 36Hole Metropolitan Amateur Semifinal
description: MANHASSET, LI., July 29 George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills swept into the 36hole final of the 70th Metropolitan Golf Association amateur cham pionship today and became the favorite following a 15and14 victory in the semifinals over Dr. Jerry Sacks of Metropolis.

title: Don't Call Me Triumphs
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 29 (AP)Don't Call Me won the feature race at Finger Lakes race track today by half a length over Deltas Gem. Jockey Bobby McKeever gave the win ner a steady ride and covered the 11/16mile distance in 1:47 2/5. Don't Call Me paid $7.20 to win.

title: New E Novel
description: Cat Dancing is the name of a Shoshone Indian girl, and the man who loved her is her hus bandstrong, silent Jay Gro bart, a quondam trooper out of Fort Laramie, circa 1880. Gro bart's wife is long murdered as this superWestern opens, but her memory supplies the in centive for a great train rob bery, plus an even greater chase across the dusty Wy oming tundra.

title: Mine Disaster Inquiry Set
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) Congressional panel will conduct an onsite investigation nekt week of the Sunshine sil ver mine disaster that killed 91 persons in May. Members of a subcommittee will leave tomor row for Kellogg, Idaho, Repre sentative Dominick V. Daniels. Democrat of New Jersey, said yesterday. He is chairman of the subcommittee.

title: Stephen Geller Fiance Of Miss Anne Fishkin
description: The engagement of Miss Anne Fishkin to Stephen M. Geller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Geller of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Fishkin, also of Brooklyn.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS travel?? cheques at no service charge. Call (212) 3584400 Flushing National BankAdvt.

title: Cows Give Way to Homes
description: MENDHAM  Ronald de Jong feels that it is a good deal more satisfyingand profitableto be tending a herd of dairy cows on a rent ed piece of rolling meadow here than wielding an acety lene torch in his native Netherlands.

title: Delegates in 3 States Say Eagleton Should Quit Race
description: A survey of Democratic Na tional Convention delegates in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed yesterday that the delegates favored the withdrawal of Senator Thomas F. Eagleton from the Demo cratic national ticket by a 21 margin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. LEILA GIBBON
description: Mrs. Leila Fleischmann Fiery Gibbon, daughter of the late racehorse owner, Charles R. Fleischmann, died Friday in the Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived here.

title: Msgr. Christopher G. Kane, 48; Catholic Charities Official, Dies
description: Msgr. Christopher G. Kane, codirector of the department of health and hospitals of New York Catholic Charities since 1967, died Thursday in Miseri cordia Hospital after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

title: ROBERT E. ALCOCK
description: Robert E. Alcock, an execu tive of the J. Walter Thompson Company, the international ad vertising agency, died of a heart attack Friday in the com pany's offices at 420 Lexington Avenue. He was 46 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Proven Tune Wins by Two As Choice at Rockingham
description: SALEM, N. H., July 29 (AP) Proven Tune waltzed to twolength victory in the $16, 025 Rockette Stakes at Rock ingham Park before a crowd of 16,307 today.

title: Chamber Orchestra Joined by 3 Soloists In Mozart and Bach
description: A new conductor, a veteran pianist and sister violinists at the outset of their careers ap peared with the New York Chamber Orchestra at Philhar monic Hall on Friday night in Mostly Mozart Festival concert.

title: MAYS GETS 3 HITS
description: The Mets retreated to New York under fire last night and opened a nineday home stand by dropping a 63 decision to the Montreal Expos for their third loss in a row.

title: College Gets a Taste of Scandinavia
description: While other Queens College students were taking copious lecture notes this past spring, members of Carol Korzeniow sky's Scandinavian studies course were toiling over thick slices of black bread, herring and caviar. But the lesson was geared as much to the intellect as to the pal ate, for such openface sand wiches are an inherent part of Scandinavian tradition.

title: REFORM IS ADVISED IN COURT HANDLING OF CRIMINAL CASES
description: A task force of leading management specialists. study ing the mounting backlog of felony cases in the State Su preme Court. has asked the two Appellate Divisions in the city to consider unified city wide supervision by a single administrative judge of all courts handling criminal cases.

title: Wedding Is Set By Joan Potter
description: Mrs. M. Wedekind Potter of Port Washington, L. I., and John T. Potter of Locust Val ley and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Joan L. Potter, to Frederick W. Arnold 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold 3d of Can ton, Mass., and Little Comp ton, R. I.

title: Age Is Creeping Up on Hall, 21
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., July 29  After 14 years of competitive swim ming, Gary Hall appears ready to make a golden splash in the Olympic Games.

title: HOSPITAL MOVED EAGLETON DATA
description: ST. LOUIS, July 29Barnes Hospital officials said here to day that Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's medical charts had been moved from the record room on the main floor to an undisclosed place at about the time of the Senator's nomina tion as the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 29Margaret Haugen is a clerk in a paint store, the mother of six grown children, and a registered Democrat who voted for Senator Hu bert H. Humphrey in the California primary last month. But she is not sure whom she will support for President in November.

title: Straight
description: With closet doors popping open all over the place, fewer homosexuals feel the need to change; but change is what William Aaron (under a pen name) advises. Aaron had been a homosexual for 20 years, since age 12; he is now married, with children. In a wellwritten book he presents his homosexual past straight forwardly. An interest in re ligion and a vestigial desire for girlsone girl especiallypro vided the seeds for conversion. This is hardly selfhelp litera ture, and Mr. Aaron is no saint, it's just that he didn't like what his life was becoming as a homosexual (at one point he lists the mortality rate among his homosexual friends, and it is chilling). He does not deny homosexual love but finds him self happier now that he has made a successful heterosexual life. Homosexuality is not in evitable is the message.

title: Out of the sea and into the stew
description: In seacoast towns around the world, good cooks make use of the local catch in delectable fish soups and stews. There is California's cioppino, the bouillabaisse and bourride of France and, of course, the chowders of New England. With the addition of a crusty bread and a glass (or two) of winea Meursault, perhaps, or a Pinot Chardonnaythey are hearty enough to serve as a main course. The New England fish stew given here has Italian accentstoma toes, oregano and basil; the Oregon shrimp chowder is creamy smooth with an unexpected cheese flavor.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubs Down Cards
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) Randy Hundley's fourth homer and sacrifice flies by Billy Wil liams and Ron Santo accounted for the Chicago Cubs runs in a 32 verdict over the St. Louis Cardinals today. The Cards also scored on a fly, by Joe Torre. Hundley's homer in the seventh was the deciding run.

title: South African Press Is Pondering What To Call Nonwhites
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 29 (Reuters)  The South African press is in a state of confusion over what to call the majority of the population that is not white.

title: Biblical Scholar in Israel Denies That Fragment of Scroll Is From the Gospel
description: JERUSALEM, July 29  A leading Biblical scholar has sharply disputed a colleague's claim to have discovered a sec tion of the Gospel of St. Mark among the miscellaneous frag ments of the Dead Sea scrolls.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: OVER the course of the next few weeks, inevi tably, there will be considerable rhetoric and written appraisals of the Nixon Administration's New Economic Program at its first anniversary on Aug. 15and the commentary is likely to be quite disparate.

title: How to Control Diploma Mills' Has Become a National Problem
description: The problem of controlling the booming diplomamill in dustry, according to one man concerned with it is akin to nailing a custard pie to the wall  there's nothing that really works at the moment.

title: Growth of Community Mental Health Is Reducing the Number of Patients in Hospitals
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 29More than 260,000 people live in and around this Pacific Coast city, 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles. And as in every other city and town in the United States, about one of every 10 suffers at one time or another from schizophrenia, deep depression, acute anxiety, alcoholism or some other form of mental illness.
