description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Tax Center Awaits First Returns
description: HOLTSVILLE, L. I.  It will not be any less pain ful, but at least it will be closer.

title: Beef Cut on Colombia Menu
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 29 (Reuters)Beef is being taken off the menus of Colombian restaurants and hotels for two days a week starting next month as part of a drive to in crease exports.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONMore than 10 mil lion workers were exempted from the wageprice controls program last week, bringing the total in this group to 32.5 million56 per cent of the nonfarm, nongovernment labor force. One question: With more than half of the labor force exempt, can the antiinflation program succeed?

title: Music
description: You and Cecilia and Beatrice, I try to believe did not happen. But that would be denying your very existence, and the meaning you had for me and other friends, your close relationship to your family, and the great hopes that you, Goeran, had given to the world of opera.

title: Running on the Sands of Time
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, (AP)It is on the beach. Seven young men in track shorts sprint past some startled Somali fishermen. Mal Whitfield's preOlympic regional African athletics' training camp is under way.

title: BRITISH DOCK STRIKE HALTS 70% OF TRADE
description: LONDON, July 29 (AP)The national dock strike in Britain idled more than 600 ships by today and halted about 70 per cent of the nation's importex port traffic.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Brewers Rout Tigers, 83
description: MILWAUKEE, July 29 (AP) A threerun homer by John Briggs and tworun homers by Joe Lahoud and Dave May led the Milwaukee Brewers to an 8.3 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

title: Jersey Legalizes the Common Scold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., July 29 Common neighborhood gossips can talk more and worry less in New Jersey. It is no longer a crime not to get along with your neighbors.

title: A. B.C. Seeks Key to Radioactive Leak
description: There is evidence that a phe nomenon that led to the release of radioactive material into the cooling water of a Rochester nuclear plant may be affecting other atomic power plants.

title: Gardens
description: IRISES have been ad mired by man since those faroff days when the goddess Iris traveled up and down the Grecian rain bows, and Egyptian Pharaohs collected exotic Persian spe cies for their palace gardens. (Carvings on ancient temples, and paintings on excavated palace walls tell us so.)

title: World News Briefs
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 29 Two Colombian airliners on domestic flights collided in flight over an isolated area in the Las Palomas Mountains to day and all 38 persons on board were killed, Avianca Airlines reported.

title: Art
description: DISCUSSING the relation of Kan dinsky's early abstract painting to occult thought, and specifically to theosophy, last week, I suggest ed that the artist found in the literature of spiritualism something more than a few useful hints for the fabrication of a pic torial style. What he found, indeed, was what the Germans call a Weltan schauung, a comprehensive view of ex istence. The terms of this Weltan schauung were such that they tempted Kandinsky to consider (albeit briefly) the possibility of abandoning painting altogether. Since, according to theoso phical doctrine, the material universe was heading toward an imminent dis solution, the painter began to wonder, as Sixten Ringbom observes in The Sounding Cosmos, whether art could not even dispense with its material.

title: Bridal Planned By Tully Lyons
description: PINE PLAINS, N. Y., July 29  Mrs. Philip Anthony Lyons has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Tully Lyons, to Thomas Weston Fels. He is the son of Mrs. Donald K. Price of Cambridge, Mass., and the late William Carl Fels.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Let There Be Darkness, Please
description: What group of 800 American intellectuals would miss both the Dem ocratic National Conven tion and the opening of the World Chess Cham pionship to make a round trip to a nonedescript point 900 miles out in the cold North Atlantic?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY GRAFT STUDY BALKED BY UNION
description: The Allied Building Inspec tors Union has advised its mem bers to refuse to cooperate if the city's Department of In vestigation asks them to help gather evidence on corruption among their fellow inspectors.

title: A JOB DRIVE IS SET BY JESSE JACKSON
description: CHICAGO, July 29The Rev. Jesse Jackson told the first convention of his new organ ization, People United to Save Humanity, that the group, known as PUSH, would take the offensive and confront major corporations on their re sponsibilities to blacks.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: New York (Madison Square Gar den)Esteban DeJesus, 140 pounds, Carolinas, Puerto Rico, outpointed Chuck (Schoolboy) Wilburn, 140, Cleveland, 10 rounds; Dario Hidal go, 149 Miami, outpointed Dan ny McAloon, 150, New York, 10; Hector Matta, 144, Santurce, Puerto Rico, and Chu Chu Malave, 134, New York, drew, 10.

title: Soviet Tells of Temperature Of 870 Degrees on Venus
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI)  Soviet scientific instruments parachuted onto Venus a week ago encountered surface tem peratures of 870 degrees Fahr enheit and atmospheric pressure 93 times that on earth, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Industrial production has been rising since last Au gust. Plant and equipment expenditures by manufac turers have accountedand continue to account for a large share of this output.

title: American Y.C. Cruise Ends
description: MARION, Mass., July 29 Dr. James N. Worcester's Rhap sody, a Culbertson and Cassian 39foot sloop launched only this spring, and Frederic B. Comlossy's Crackerjack, a Tartan30, were trophy winners today as the 41st American Yacht Club cruise ended with a 17mile race in Buzzards Bay.

title: SCOTT IS INJURED IN CYCLE MISHAP
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 29 The suburban quiet was shat tered tonight as Roosevelt Raceway, amid a cloud of dust, staged its second Yamaha Gold Cup motorcycle races.

title: Rich to Help Poor Pay for Schools
description: TRENTON  Despite the defeat of Governor Cahill's tax  reform program, New Jersey's affluent suburbs still face the prospect of provid ing up to $100million to support school districts in poor urban and rural areas starting Jan 1.

title: Ellen C. Mayer To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Durgin of New York and Quogue, L. I., have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Durgin's daughter, Miss Ellen Cecile Mayer, to Har old James Diamond of River dale, the Bronx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Diamond of New York and Sandisfield, Mass.

title: Census Finds Incomes High Among Morris County Families
description: In Morris County, fastest growing of the eight metro politan New Jersey counties close to New York City, 40, per cent of the families had incomes exceeding $15,000 in 1970.

title: LETTERS
description: It's fun, to see how stu dents of the Statistical Ab stract of the United States fall into three categories: Group A is able to prove that Senator George McGovern's economics are wrong; Group B can prove that he is tight, and Group C can satisfy themselves that nobody knows yet.

title: New England History Set
description: BOSTON, July 29 (AP)A bibliography of New England history will be compiled by the Committee of a New England Bibliography, Inc., headed by John B. Armstrong, associate professor of history at Boston University. The National En dowment of the Humanities an nounced Monday that it had awarded the committee $57,790 to help fund the project.

title: Red Square At Noon By Natalia Gorbanevskaya. 288 pp. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.95.
description: The author is a young Soviet poet who, with seven compan ions, demonstrated in Red Square against the Soviet in vasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. The peaceful trouble makers were set upon by KGB agents, roughed up and ar rested. Five of them were tried and sentenced to prison; the author and another demonstra tor were incarcerated in one of the policerun mental institu tions that are becoming dump ingbins for dissenters in Rus sia. (She was freed in February of this year.) She has no illu sions that her act was revolu tionary, but she says: One must begin by postulating that truth is needed for its own sake and for no other reason; that human dignity will not permit one to condone evil, even if one cannot avert it. No argument here.

title: Peanuts, Popcorn and $1 Movies, Too
description: A diller, a dollar, a 10 o'clock double feature at the movies? Easy.

title: LINCOLN, 21, GAINS U.S. DIVING BERTH
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) Craig Lincoln, 21 years old, a silver medalist in the Pan American Games, succeeded today in his first bid for a birth onthe United States Olym pic swimming team.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Caution, Un dulating Sidewalks [July 16] attempts to show similarities between the efforts of a de sign group called Site and the project by Ms. Pamela Waters at 747 Third Avenue, New York. As Ms. Waters' clients, we may not be unbi ased, but we clearly see dif ferences.

title: P. W. Oldershaw, Lawyer, Fiance Of Miss Hawley
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 29  Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hawley of Fairfield and Land grove, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Hawley, to Peter Wakelin Oldershaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Oldershaw of Holyoke, Mass., and Bidde ford Pool, Me.

title: A Few Kind Words for Paris Couture As Quite Unexciting Showings End
description: PARIS, July 29  There were more laughs in the couture showings here than there were in Rome, but that doesn't prove anything. There were more grim moments, too.

title: A Black Business Failure...
description: When you walk through Boise, Idaho, you see about as many blacks as you see whites when you walk through Harlem. The worlds are far apart, and perhaps there's no way to get from one to the other.

title: The Caretaker at the Rock
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass.Almost every day for the last 15 years, Harold Gessner has taken a ladder from atop a state public works truck and slid it over the sturdy old walls of an enclosure that prominently dis plays a sign: Erected by the Colonial Dames of America to commemorate the three hundredth anniversary of the land ing of the Pilgrims. He lowers the ladder all the way down into the well that contains Plymouth Rock and goes to work.

title: LARGE AUTO CONVOY OF WAR FOES IS SET
description: MILWAUKEE, July 29Plans for a nationwide automobile convoy to take demonstrators to the Republican National Con vention in Miami Beach next month have been announced by the national steering com mittee of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

title: Law Held Violated in Fatal Mine Fire
description: PURSGLOVE, W. Va., July 29 The director of the West Vir ginia Department of Mines told a group of miners today that a state law definitely was vio lated at the Consolidation Coal Company's Blacksville No. 1 mine where nine men died in a fire one week ago.

title: DOUGLAS DELAYS ElLSBERG TRIAL; U.S. SETS APPEAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29The legal struggle over Government wiretapping in the Pentagon papers case embroiled the Su preme Court today, as Justice William O. Douglas stayed the opening of the trial, and the Justice Department announced it would ask the full Supreme Court to countermand his order.

title: SAMUEL CERONE
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 29 (AP)  Councilman Samuel Cerone died early today after falling down a flight of stairs at his home. He was 61 years old.

title: South Korea Hangs 2 More After Conviction as Spies
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 29Two South Koreans who had been sentenced to death for spying for North Korea were hanged yesterday at Su daemoon Prison here, it was announced today.

title: SUSAN'S GIRL WINS COTILLION STAKES
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29  Fred W. Hooper's Susan's Girl ran off and hit in the stretch run to capture the $59,950 Cotillion Handicap at Liberty Bell by 4 lengths over Mrs. Henry D. Paxson's Groton Miss.

title: Victory by Kekich Puts Team Over 500 Mark
description: The Red Sox continued to be treated at Yankee Stadium yes terday as if they were trem bling trespassers.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md, July 29 (AP)President Nixon spent much of today working and relaxing at Camp David, his mountaintop retreat in western Maryland. He scheduled some of his time for social activities with his wife and the Nixons close friends, Mr. and Mrs. Roger Johnson, who were along for the weekend.

title: Education
description: When Juan Ortiz began bringing his homework back from the second grade in Brooklyn, this mother no ticed that he had changed the spell ing of his first name on his papers.

title: Eagleton Says McGovern Remains Firm in Support
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 29Senator Thomas F. Eagleton came home tonight claiming new encouragement from his running mate, Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, to stay on the Dem ocratic ticket as the Vice Presidential nominee. When he telephoned Mr. McGovern from San Francisco this morn ing, Mr. Eagleton either ig nored or defied the South Dakotan's implications to newsmen last night that Mr. Eagleton might want to step aside because of public reac tion to his history of emo tional problems in the nine teensixties.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Dr. Parrish tells about his year in a behindthelines Viet nam hospitalthe stream of mangled men, the triage where the quick are separated from the dead and dying, beers at the officers' club, leave in Bangkok for five days of ob livion in drink and sex. The doctor wonders why he is there, worries about getting killed, mourns a lost patient, when there is time, counts the days of his twelvemonth stint. This is no M*A*S*H or 365 Days but it is an honest ac count of what an ordinary, good man saw, thought and felt.

title: An Obituary On Old Pete Makes Past Live Again
description: Point Lookout's Piccolo Pete made the pages of the local newspapers a couple of weeks ago. Too bad he had to die to do it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The source of a charge that the Democratic Vice  Presidential candidate, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, had been arrested several times on charges that included drunken and reckless driving identified himself tonight as William True Davis, a former United States Treasury official and diplomat who is now a bank president here.

title: Miss Maiorca Fiancee Of Edward Driscoll 3d
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29Miss Lydia Ann Maiorca and Edward F. Driscoll 3d, son of Mrs. Driscoll of Hav ertown, Pa., and the late Mr. Driscoll Jr., will be married in September.

title: The Nation
description: The confusions that so often attend effortspublic and privateto de ceive were on display, last week, in two developments involving that most elaborate of deceptionsthe wiretap.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Camp Is Low Hurdle for Blind
description: ROCKAWAY  A sum mer camp here in Morris County for blind children from throughout New Jersey is a place where they can learn to have fun despite their handicaps.

title: Scott in Ttitle Final
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 25 (UPI)Topseeded Gene Scott beat thirdseeded King Van Nostrand, 63, 62, today, to win the final of the men's over35 national clay court ten nis championship.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: HONG KONG, July 29 The cheapest metropolitan ferry ride in the worldless than 2 centswill have some competition next week when commuters in this British crown colony will be able for the first time to drive across the harbor dividing the cities of Victoria and Kowloon.

title: Javits Foresees a Test Of Attitudes of Public
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that the Presidential election might develop in part into a test of public attitudes toward mental illness if Senator Thomas F. Eagleton remains on the Democratic ticket.

title: An Evening That Made Montauk Seem Like A Swinging Resort
description: MONTAUK, L. I.Normal ly, this sedate resort and fishing community on the tip of Long Island would not be singled out for its swing ing social scene. The Hamp tons, it isn't.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN.
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Nearly half the $4.2million currently ayailable to labor unions for campaign contribu tions is controlled by union leaders friendly to Senator George McGovern, a study of the political treasuries of labor and other specialinterest groups has disclosed.

title: Thousands Are Evacuated As Waters Rise in Luzon
description: MANILA, Monday, July 31 Mass evacuation of thousands of people living near dams, rivers and lakes began yester day under the control of the National Disaster Coordinating Council as squalls brought more water to floodstricken Luzon Island, it was reported today.

title: Unitarians See U.S. Harassment on Gravel Papers
description: BOSTON, July 30The head quarters of the Unitarian Uni versalist Association, a tranquil brick mansion on Beacon Street overlooking the Boston Com mon, shows no outward signs of fear or paranoia. Among the staff there is some banter about the telephone being bugged and a suggestion that the F.B.I. may have planted listening de vices behind the portraits of early Unitarian leaders, but no one talks in whispers.

title: Man Held as Sniper Upstate
description: LIMA, N. Y., July 30 (AP) Livingston County sheriff's dep uties arrested a 25yearold man for allegedly sniping at an automobile passing through this western New York com munity early today, wounding a woman passenger. Deputies said Donald Schweizer of Lima was charged with firstdegree assault in the incident. They accused him of pulling his car off the road and firing a single rifle shot at another car carry ing four persons. Suzanne Niel sen, 22, a Geneseo State Col lege student from the Buffalo suburb of Holland, was wound ed in the back. No motive was offered.

title: Humane Groups Closely Watch Annual Wild Pony Roundup, Swim and Auction at Chincoteague Island, Va.
description: CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 30Humane Society officials, who had threatened to use their powers of arrest unless organizers of the popular Chincoteague wild pony round up and auction took immediate steps to improve the animals' care, took no action last week as more than 50 of the wild colts went to the auction block.

title: JAN FERRARIS WINS BY SHOT IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, July 30 (UPI) Jan Ferraris, a slender bru nette from San Francisco, won the Lady Pepsi open by one stroke today although she was 2 over par in the final round.

title: 8 KILLED IN GEORGIA IN CARTRUCK CRASH
description: MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga. (AP) Eight persons were killed tonight in a headon collision between a truck and a car that carried seven men on Georgia Route 22 near this central Georgia city.

title: G.M. Unit Is Back in HeavyDuty Haulers
description: CLEVELAND, July 30The General Motors Corporation is back in the heavyduty equip ment market, which it was forced to leave under terms of an antitrust consent decree four years ago.

title: MRS. ABE STERN
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., July 30 Mrs. Anne Stern, widow of Abe Stern, organizer of the Ramapo Police Department and one time president of the New York Police Chiefs Association died yesterday at the Ramapo Manor Nursing Home. She was 76 years old.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STANTON, Del., July 30Executioner carried the top weight of 122 pounds and the role of an 11to10 favorite to victory today in Delaware Park's $56,450 William du Pont Jr. handicap before a crowd of 14,945.

title: 400 Race Canoes in the Delaware for Charity
description: CALLICOON, N. Y., July 30 In a sight that would bring joy to a liniment salesman, some 400 canoeists crossed the finish line here today in a daylong series of races.

title: DEFENSE HOPEFUL ON ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30De fense lawyers said today that the Supreme Court would con firm their contention that the Pentagon papers case is indeed a political prosecution if it convenes a special session to consider overturning Justice William O. Douglas's stay of the trial.

title: DR. CHANNING SWAN
description: BLUE HILL, Me., July 30 Dr. Channing Stearns Swan, a retired urologist, died today at the Blue Hill Hospital after brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived here and in Weston, Mass.

title: Ruskin Assails Inspectors' Union on Its Refusal to Back Inquiry
description: Robert K. Ruskin, Commis sioner of Investigation, yester day strongly attacked the Allied Building Inspectors Union's an nounced refusal to cooperate with the city's investigation into corruption in the construc tion industry.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: VERNON, N. Y., July 30 (UPI)Super Bowl, who won the $46,015 Gold Cup last night at Vernon Downs, became one of the leading contenders for the Hambletonian on Aug. 30. Stanley Dancer guided Super Bowl to successive heat victories over the threequartermile track. In the first heat, trotted in 2:01, Super Bowl beat La Salle Han over by two lengths. In the second heat, Super Bowl trav eled the mile in 1:58 35, a track record for 3yearold trotters.

title: Released Woman Recalls Fears When Abductors Left Her Alone
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 (AP) Virginia Piper, home safe after being kidnapped for $1million ransom, said today she had feared for her life only after her abductors abandoned her in the darkness of the northern Minnesota wilderness.

title: Vandalism by Teenagers Plagues Merchants in City
description: Around the Plymouth Rock Provision Company's ham can nery in the Bronx, young boys mostly 12 and 13 years old warm the way gamins have done since the farms in the neighborhood became just a memory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Communism: 125 Years Later
description: BELGRADE  Communist ideas did not spring forth from the working class. Doctrinaires and political move ments put them there instead. Marx and Lenin were aware of the difference between Communist theory and the workingclass movement. The advan tage of Marx and Lenin over other theoreticians and Communist leaders is that for them the revolution and the new society provide the link between their scientific views and the work ing class, that is, the labor movement.

title: Mostly Mozart Drawing a New Breed of Longhairs
description: At 8:06 P.M. Saturday, three teenage girls bounded up the escalator of Philhar monic Hall emitting squeals of dismay as they saw the doors to the hall being closed by the ushers. Their tickets were for the second terrace two more flights upso they settled on a bench near the veranda to hear the opening number piped in over the loudspeakers.

title: Miss Goolagong Is Beaten But Aussies Take Series
description: CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) Chris Evert avenged her Wim bledon loss with a 63, 46, 60 victory over an erratic and careless Evonne Goolagong to day but the 17yearold Florid ian failed to prevent an Au stralian triumph in the first Bonne Belle tennis competition.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire Pool Rate Cut Is Ordered

title: SCOTT TURNER DIES; LED MINES BUREAU
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 Scott Turner, who served as director of the United States Bureau of Mines from 1926 to 1934, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He would have been 92 years old tomorrow and lived at 44 Patterson Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Close Companion of Mao Implicated in Lin's Plot
description: PEKING, July 30 (Agence FrancePresse) Pota the former personal secretary of Chairman Mao Tsetung and former head of the Cultural Revolution Directing Group, was implicated with the late Piao in a plot to seize pow er from Chairman Mao, accord ing to information from ranking Chinese officials here man Mao and said he was killed in a plane crash in Mon golia while fleeing the country last September.

title: Caribou Deaths Near Army Base Puzzle Alaskans
description: FAIRBANKS. Alaska. July 30  Biologists of the Alaska Fish and Game Department here are puzzled by the death of 53 caribou found clustered in a valley about four miles south of Fort Greely, the former site of a chemical, biological, and radiological laboratory and test center of the United States, Army.

title: Whose Beach?
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has handed down a ruling that has a certain logic and justice in it and yet seems on balance to be neither completely logical nor altogether just. The decision, which is certain to affect seaside communities throughout the state, struck down an ordinance of the borough of AvonbytheSea impos ing on nonresidents of that community higher fees than on residents for use of the municipal beach.

title: Workers Learn Varied Jobs in Sweden's Auto Plants
description: STOCKHOLM  A young Swedishspeaking Finnish girl selects a wrench from the bench by her side. She turns to the automobile en gine on a stand nearby and tightens a nut. There, she says, that should do it.

title: Investment Adviser Takes Cautious View of Market
description: James W. Harpel, 34, is a general partner of Century Capital Associates, a private investment adviser that man ages institutional, foundation and hedgefund accounts. His firm is geared basically to man aging institutional moneythe sector that dominates present day markets. As far as the individual investor is con cerned, Mr. Harpel says, suc cess often consists of finding one or two outstanding smaller growth companies and holding them. Harvardeducated Mr. Harpel outlined his thoughts on the stock market and the economy last week in an inter view with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Por tions of their conversation fol low.

title: 13 Flying to Scatter Ashes Die in Crash Over Pacific
description: SAN DIEGO, July 30 (Reu ters)Two light planes collided over La Jolla today killing two brothels and the pilot they had hired to help them scatter their grandfather's ashes at sea.

title: LIBYAN TO CONFER WITH SADAT TODAY
description: CAIRO, July 30  President Anwar elSadat will fly to Libya tomorrow to face yet another crisis  the request of Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Lib yan leader, for an Immediate merger of their two countries.

title: M'CLUSKEY VICTOR IN STOCK CAR RACE
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 30 Roger McCluskey, leading all but 50 miles of the way, easily won the Pennsylvania 500 stockcar race today with a 10 mile margin over the runnerup, Butch Hartman.

title: U.S. CrimeInsurance Rate Cut 50% for Home and Business
description: The Federal Government has cut by 50 per cent the pre mium rates for its crime insur ance for businesses and homes and has added Tennessee to the number of states where the coverage is available.

title: Man Found Shot to Death
description: A 24yearold Manhattan man was found dead yesterday in the rear yard of a housing project at 1350 Fifth Avenue, near 112th Street. He was shot once in the head, the police said. The victim was identified as Willey James of 2 West 111th Street.

title: Legislators' Raise Opposed
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) A proposed pay raise for state legislator is not too popular among the readers of The Phila delphia Evening Bulletin. A poll being conducted by the paper showed 14,604 readers opposing the raise and only 14 favoring it, a smaller num ber than Philadelphia sends to the legislature.

title: WOMEN'S SONGS DEFIES TRADITION
description: VIENNA, Va., July 30Tra dition, which is at the root of most of the songs performed at the National Folk Festival, was briefly shunted aside yesterday during the festival's third day at Wolf Trap Farm Park to al low the voices of women's lib eration to be heard. The occa sion was an afternoor, workshop billed simply as Women's Songs but the women who sang the songs, who ranged in age from youthful Holly Tannen to grandmotherly Almeda Rid dle, were united in their point of view.

title: Guyana Fire Kills 7 Children
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July 30 (Reuters)Seven children, from 10 months to 9 years old, were burned to death in a fire that swept through a tenement building in Georgetown today. An 81yearold greatgrand father or the children and four other children were rescued.

title: City Youth Aide Seized in Car For Using a Forged License
description: Ted Gross, the city Commis sioner of Youth Services, was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of a forged driver's license after being stopped early in the morning in a routine check for stolen cars.

title: SPASSKY'S ILLNESS POSTPONES CHESS
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 30 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, saying he had a cold, today requested and received a postponement of the scheduled ninth game in his 24game world championship chess match against Bobby Fischer of the United States.

title: Sitka Suffers Slight Damage From Quake in Alaska Gulf
description: SITKA, Alaska, July 30 (UN) A strong earthquake in the Gulf of Alaska sent shock waves south to Seattle today and caused a brief evacuation of about 6,000 residents from their homes in Sitka in a tidal wave alert.

title: Postel Sets Up a Center For Citizens Complaints
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel said yesterday he had set up a Center for Public Responsibility to receive and investigate complaints about municipal government operations.

title: MAN SHOT, ANOTHER STABBED IN FIGHT
description: One man was shot and an other stabbed just before mid night last night during an al tercation outside the Tam bourine Bar at 350 East 81st Street, the police said,

title: Mrs. Leonard M. Sperry; Founded Center in Rome
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30Mrs. Rose Adler Sperry, the widow of Leonard M. Sperry, an in dustrialist and civic leader in Los Angeles and Chicago, died today at her home here. She was 68 years old.

title: ArafatSadat Talks Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 (UPI)  The Palestine News Agency, a press agency op erated by Palestinian revolu tionaries, said today that the guerrilla leader Yasir Arafat and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt conferred yesterday.

title: WORKER BENEFITS HELD INADEQUATE IN NATIONAL STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The National Commission on State Workmen's Compensa tion Laws reported to Presi dent Nixon and Congress to day that workmen's compen sation programs were inade quate and inequitable. It called for massive reforms guaranteed by the Federal Gov ernment.

title: $2 Bet Pays $25,776.90
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, July 30 (AP)A track record payoff of $25,776.90 for a $2 ticket was recorded last night at the Wind sor Raceway in the quadactor event, in which the bettor picks the first four finishers in order. Only one ticket was sold on the 8451 combination and two buyers split the pot.

title: The McGovern Image
description: News Analysis

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Burns Downs Courville For Area Title, 4 and 3
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 30 George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills captured the 70th Metro politan Golf Association ama teur championship at the Deep dale Club today.

title: Ickx's Ferrari Wins German Race
description: NUERBURGRING, West Ger many, July 30  Jacky Ickx lost an exhaust pipe off his Ferrari but the way things were going at the Nuerubrgring today, this was hardly enough to stop the Belgian from scor ing a recordbreaking victory by 47.7 seconds In the German Grand Prix.

title: PAUL COHEN
description: Paul Cohen, a New York real estate broker and investor, died Thursday in Montefiore Hospital of complications fol lowing surgery. He was 84 years old and lived at 1815 Monroe Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Excerpts From Television Interview With Senator Eagleton by Three Newsmen
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of a tele vision interview with the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, yesterday on the program Face the Nation broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System, as re corded by The New York Times. The interviewers were Jack Anderson, the syndi cated columnist, and George Herman and Barry Seraf in of C.B.S.

title: Gen. Edward McGrew Jr., Led State Building Unit, 69
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 30 Maj. Gen. Edward J. McGrew Jr., U.S.A., retired, who was chairman of the New York State Building Commission from 1949 to 1953, when he was named head of the New York City Housing Authority's De partment of Design, died last night in the Fort Bragg Hospi tal. He was 69 years old.

title: G.O.P.Say Convention Shift Led to $1.8Million Saving
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 30 (UPI) The Republican party saved $1.8million by moving its na tional convention to Miami Beach from San Diego, the con vention coordinator, Robert F. Knowles, says.

title: Pop Dominates the Scene At Soul at Center Fete
description: Slick, glossy pop music dom inated most of Saturday eve ning's Soul at the Center program. Performing at Alice Tully Hall were Eddie Palmieri & Harlem River Drive and the songwriting/performing duo of Valerie Simpson and Nick Ashford.

title: Owner Finds $2 a Rat Too Much for His Boa
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., July 30 The price of rats is so high in this plush northern Michigan summer and winter resort that Jack Whaley, 22 years old, of State College, Pa., feels forced to sell his pet boa constrictor.

title: Sizable Declines Found Taking Tax Returns Into Consideration
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Government has revised down ward significantly the official figure for corporate profits in the first quarter of this year as well as for the year 1971.

title: 15 ROCK FANS HELD IN CONCERT FRACAS
description: LANCASTER, Pa., July 30 (AP)Two policemen were hit by rocks and 15 persons were arrested today in a disturbance at a rock concert here, the po lice said.

title: 103D SPA MEETING WILL START TODAY
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 30 (AP)Saratoga's 103d meeting opens tomorrow and Riva Ridge, Numbered Ac count, Key To The Mint and Executioner are among the bigname horses scheduled to race during the 24day meet, which ends Aug. 26.

title: ASHE ELIMINATES NEWCOMBE, 64, 64
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. July 30 (AP)  Arthur Ashe defeated top  seeded John Newcombe, 64, 64, and Mark Cox downed Cliff Drysdale, 75, 60 today to advance to the final of the $50,000 First National tennis tourney.

title: Man in Wheelchair Held In a Fatal Stabbing Here
description: A 44yearold man was stabbed to death last night by a man in a wheelchair on a visit to a friend's apartment in Har lem, the police reported. The unidentified suspect in the kill ing was being questioned about the circumstances of the slaying but had not been charged early today.

title: Carey Winfrey Weds Mrs. Phillips
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 30Mrs. Laurie Platt Phil lips, picture editor of the Newsweek Book Division, was married here today to Carey Wells Winfrey, who produces Behind the Lines, a weekly review of the press, for Channel 13/WNET in New York.

title: Eddie Carrel, 500Pound Giant At Ringling Circus, Dies at 36
description: Eddie Carmel, a onetime cir cus giant who weighed 500 pounds and was 9 feet tall, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 36 years old and lived with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Carmel, at 10022 Elgar Place, the Bronx.

title: LEUCI REPORTED TO ADMIT CRIMES
description: Robert L. Leuci, the key un dercover agent in an 18month Federal investigation of corrup tion in the criminal justice sys tem here, was said by Life magazine yesterday to have ad mitted committing crimes dur ing his seven years as a police narcotics detective.

title: Apollo 14 Crew Carried Medals Coined by a Private Mint on Trip
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Apollo 14 astronauts, with out the knowledge of the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Administration, carried 200 sil ver medals coined by a private mint on their moon flight in January, 1971.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CRANS SUR SIERRA, Switzerland, July 30 (UPI)  Graham Marsh of Australia held off the charge of Britain's Tony Jacklin today and won the Swiss open golf tourna ment by one stroke. Marsh, the winner here in 1970, shot a oneunderpar 70 for a 72hole total of 270.

title: Coast Bus Strike Averted
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30 (UPI) A threatened bus strike that could have affected almost half a million passengers in the Los Angeles metropolitan area was postponed today after the union received word that a new con tract proposal was forthcoming. Some 2,700 drivers in the United Transportation Union had threatened to stage the area's second fleetwide bus strike in five months. The strike had been scheduled for mid night.

title: Chief of Soviet Navy Says Fleets Can Reach Any Foe
description: MOSCOW, July 30 (AP)The commander of the Soviet Un ion's Navy said today that his fleets, led by a growing number of nuclear submarines, could de tect and destroy an enemy ves sel anywhere in the world.

title: School Violence Study Unit Cites Shortage of Lawyers
description: The chairman of a City Coun cil Committee investigating vio lence in schools asserted yester day that Family Court judges were dismissing charges against an average of three suspects week because the Board of Edu cation had only one lawyer to represent teachers and students who said they were victimized.

title: Tanaka Moves Quickly on China
description: News Analysis

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., Queens County Democratic leader, de clared yesterday that he would not vote for the Democratic Presidential ticket if Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, who re ceived treatment for mental depression, remained the Vice Presidential nominee.

title: Nixon Works at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., July 30 (AP)President Nixon spent a rainy. Sunday at his Camp David mountaintop retreat working and conferring for sev eral hours with his top domes tic adviser, John Ehrliclunan. He returned to the White House tonight.

title: Meyerhans Captures Prize In Predicted Log Contest
description: FAIR HAVEN, N. J., July 30 Bob Meyerhans of the Shrewsbury River Yacht Club, in his Golden Eagle, won the club's 22d annual predicted log contest yesterday.

title: Concerns Rolling Back Rises to Be Exempt on Margin Limits
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Price Commission plans to ex empt from profitmargin re strictions companies that agree to roll back any price increase since last year's freeze and re fund the difference to custo mers.

title: The Real War Issue
description: President Nixon's return last week to the tired theme that his war critics are naive dupes of Hanoi indicates a desire to pose campaign debate over the nation's de fense posture in terms as irrelevant and unilluminating as were the arguments over the missile gap and the future of Quemoy and Matsu in earlier election dialogues.

title: Soviet Tops U.S. Juniors
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 30 (AP)  Tom Woods, Oregon State University's National Col legiate Athletic Association high jump champion, leaped 7 feet, 2 inches last night, but the Soviet Union's young distance stars scored a 124108 victory over the United States in a two day junior track and field meet.

title: Afghans Hang 2 for Killings
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 30 (AP)Two men convicted of the murders of four French tourists were hanged today in Kandahar, 250 miles west of here. A spokesman for the at torney general's office said they had beheaded four Frenchmen in Kandahar on May 5 after having served them dinner and a pipe of hashish.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Senator George McGovern and Senator Thomas F. Eagle ton have for the last few days been like the tips of two icebergs bobbing up and down, back and torth, in the troubled waters buffeting the Democratic national ticket.

title: Alex's Shrew Takes Series
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 30Chris Alex's Shrew from the Huntington, L. I., Bay fleet today won the Green Star Class regatta on Nyack Bay. Alex, who won yesterday's only race, finished second in both of today:s starts, for five points. Billy. Burtis of the Sea Cliff, L. I., fleet was second.

title: Traubel, Great Soprano
description: An Appraisal

title: Mujib Has Appendectomy
description: LONDON, July 30 (UPI) Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, was in satisfactory condition today after the removal of his appendix and of a gallstone, doctors said. Sheik Mujib en tered the London Clinic Friday. There was no indication how long he would remain hos pitalized.

title: EAGLETON IS FIRM DESPITE PRESSURE BY 2 PARTY CHIEFS
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Senator George McGovern in tensified the pressure today on Senator Thomas F. Eagleton to withdraw as his VicePresiden tial running mate, but Mr. Eagleton refused to yield.

title: U.S. Five Bows in Soviet
description: TBILISI, Soviet Union, July 30 (Reuters)  Czechoslovakia beat the. United States, 7865, to finish second behind the So viet Union in an international basketball tournament for the Yuri Gagarin prize today. Geor gia beat Finland, 9076.

title: Hanoi Claims U.S. Plane
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  One American plane was shot down and one pilot was taken prisoner during a raid on Hanoi today it was announced over the city's airraid warning loud speaker system.

title: U.S. Loses Polo Final
description: MIDHURST, England, July 30 (AP)The English polo team, Oaklands, scored a 76 victory over Ambersham, a team of Americans, in the final of the Holden White Cup at Cowdray Park today. Lester Armour of Chicago, with four goals, led the losers.

title: Harps and Wings, Canton Style
description: Sports of The Times

title: Pacific Quadrilateral
description: The future peace and stability of East Asia depend essentially on an accommodation among the four major powers whose interests intersect in the Western Pacific: Japan, China, the Soviet Union and the United States. Nothing would be more disastrous than an attempt by Japan to play off the other three against each other or Japanese suspicion that the others are trying to make a deal at the expense of Japan, as occurred after Pres ident Nixon's surprise announcement of secret negotia tions with Peking.

title: Personal Finance
description: Some significant class ac tion suits are moving through the courts that question whether interest should be charged by lenders on the basis of a 360day yeara practice banks have long fol lowedor the more exact 365day calendar year basis.

title: Cash in Capital Raid Traced to Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, July 30The money found in the possession of five suspects in last month's breakin at the offices of the Democratic National Committee in Washington has been traced to four bank drafts totaling $89,000 issued here in the name of a prominent Mexican lawyer.

title: EDWIN T. WARREN
description: WESTPORT, Conn. July 30 Edwin Taylor Warren, former president of the United States division of the Tata Iron and Steel Company, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport. He was 78 years old and lived at 33 Sturges Common.

title: N.A.S.D. RULES DUE ON MUTUAL FUNDS
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, prodded by the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed new regulations yesterday designed to prohibit reciprocal brokerage transactions by mutual funds.

title: 4 Killed as Private Plane Crashes in Utah City Park
description: OGDEN, Utah, July 30 (AP) A private, twinengine plane orashed and burned in an Ogden park tonight, killing all four persons on board and narrowly missing nearby homes. Flaming debris was strewn over the area and part of an engine came to rest in a driveway 16 feet short of a house.

title: Welf are Rolls a Record, but Rise Slows
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  The nation's welfare rolls topped 15 million persons in March, a record, but the rate of increase has slowed to only a third that of the last two years.

title: China Strives to Integrate Her Minorities
description: PEKING, July 30China is a monolith, a country inhabited by hundreds of millions of people of common racial de scent, with a common written language, a common culture, and a common definition of the national identity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: London: FilmBuffs' Nightly Queue
description: Arts Abroad

title: A Park Police Force Urged
description: City Council Theodore Silver man said yesterday he would introduce legislation at the next City Council meeting calling for the establishment of a City Parks Department police force. Dismayed by the stabbing death of a 23yearold Brooklyn man at a concert in Forest Park, Queens, Saturday night, the Brooklyn Democrat said it was the city's duty to protect the public from the drug deal ers, drunkards and sex deviates in the parks.

title: Australia Mine Blast Kills 3
description: BRISBANE, Australia, July 30 (AP)Methane gas exploded in a coal mine near here today, setting off flames and further, blasts that killed at least three men and left a dozen missing and feared dead, authorities re ported, Three miners were hos pitalized.

title: Opera Italian Style Thrives in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 30  On Wednesday evening, more than 3,000 operagoers, per haps half of them from across the Hudson, will file into a cavernous hall, a former Ma sonic mosque, in the heart of this city's central ghetto to hearas they do several times each yearopera, Eu ropean style.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, July 30 (AP)Paul Nihill, a 32yearold London bank clerk, set a world record for the 20kilometer walk today with a time of 1 hour 24 minutes 50 seconds. His performance lowered the mark set earlier this year by East Germany's Hans Ryman and Peter Frinkel, by 29.4 seconds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WINDFALL TO HELP CITY'S HOSPITALS
description: A fiscal windfall derived from increased productivity will en able the 19 municipal hospitals to end their attrition policy shortly and hire much needed nurses, therapists, aides, clerks and other personnel to replace those who have left the system, top hospital officials said yes terday.

title: DeCavalcante Praised As a Nurse in Prison
description: NEWARK, July 30 (AP) Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, reputed organizedcrime fig ure in New Jersey, has be come a highly rated nurse in the Federal prison system.

title: MRS. JULIAN BACH, 59, AIDED BELLEVUE UNIT
description: Mrs. Halle Schlesinger Cowen Bach, chairman of the social service committee and a mem ber of the executive committee of the Bellevue Hospital Auxil iary, died yesterday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived at 241 East 48th Street.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Sends a FastRising Woman Politician to Take Charge in Orissa, India's Problem State
description: BHUBANESWAR, IndiaMrs. Nadinl Satpathy, the youngest Chief Minister of an Indian state and only the second woman to hold this powerful political office, is tackling the numerous challenges of Orissa, India's problem state, with the verve and zest of the school girl firebrand that she once was.

title: Four Die in Yugoslav Storm
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 (UPI)Four Yugoslav moun tain climbers were killed and five persons injured by lightning during a thunderstorm yester day on Triglav Mountain in northwestern Yugoslavia, the Belgrade radio said today.

title: Dallas Is Setting For the Nuptials Of Nancy Naber
description: DALLAS, July 30Miss Nancy Naber, daughter of Mrs. Manson Harris and the late Eugene Joseph Naber, was married here last night to Victor Gustav Bloede 4th. The bridegroom is the son of victor G. Bloede, board chairman of Benton & Bowles, Inc., the New York advertis ing agency, and Mrs. Bloede of Plandome, L. I., and New York.

title: Hewitt Singles Victor
description: CLEMMONS, N. C., July 30 (AP)Bob Hewitt of South Africa won the rain  delayed Tanglewood tennis singles title today, defeating Andrew Patti son of Rhodesia, 36, 63, 61.

title: West Side Highway Faces Closing, City Aide Asserts
description: Parts of the West Side High way in the vicinity of 14th Street are now so badly in need of emergency repairs that they may have to be shut clown within the next three or four months, City Transportation Administrator Constantine Sida monEristoff said yesterday.

title: Drop in Europeans Found In City as Latins Increase
description: New Yorkers of European birth or parentage declined in number precipitously in the nineteensixties, while those of foreign descent from the Carib bean and South America more than doubled.

title: Chess Craze an Ancient Malady Among the Chinese
description: PEKING  Walk through the streets of a Chinese city on a summer's evening, and you will come across dozens of groups of men, youths and small boys huddling together in the dim pools of light cast onto the pavement by the street lamps.

title: Beef Barbecue for 15,000
description: ESPANOLA, N.M., July 30 The barbecue pit was 35 feet long and a ton and half of beef had been cook ing in it beneath a blazing fire for 24 hours.

title: ERITH H. REED
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., July 30Erith H. Reed, assistant controller of the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company from 1964 until his retirement in 1967, died at his home here Monday. He was 65 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: ADDICTS ARE TOLD TO TAKE THERAPY OR LOSE WELFARE
description: A new program for immedi ate removal from the city's welfare rolls of all addicts who discontinue therapy in an ap proved drugtreatment pro gram was announced yesterday by the city's Human Resources Administrator, Jule N. Sugar man.

title: A.P. and China Agency Agree on a News Link
description: PEKING, July 30 (AP)An agreement was reached today on the exchange of news and photos between the Asso ciated Press and Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

title: Sally Hill Bride Of Gary Towlen
description: BRIGHTWATERS, Li., July 30 The marriage of Miss Sally Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel C. Hill of Roseburg, Ore., to Gary Tow len, a concert pianist, took place here this afternoon. Judge Alexander W. Kramer of the District Court of Suf folk County performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Bert Horwitz. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Towlen of Blue Point and Sun City, Ariz.

title: British Leaders Press For Dock Settlement
description: A crucial managementlabor meeting tomorrow, and an other between the parties and the Government on Tuesday, will attempt to work out a formula on lob security and severance pay to end Britain's dock strike. Longshoremen will vote on the plan Thursday.

title: U.S. Pilots Down 2 MIG's In Raid on Hanoi Rail Line
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, July 31 (AP)United States planes have shot down two MIG21 interceptors northeast of Hanoi, American pilots re ported yesterday.

title: Miss Pierrel Bride of Psychiatrist
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30The Manning Chapel at Brown University was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Rosemary Pierre!, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gren Oren Pierrel of Providence, to Dr. Louis Vin cent Sorrentino. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Sor rentino of Barrington.

title: MARY LEATHERBEE, EDITOR AT LIFE, 61
description: Mrs. Mary Lee Logan Leath erbee, a senior editor of Life magazine, drowned Friday when she and three others tipped over in a canoe as it passed through rapids in Campbell River, British Colum bia. She was 61 years old and resided at 870 Fifth Avenue.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 (AP)Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge will run in the $100,000 Monmouth, an invita tion handicap, on Saturday at Monmouth Park. His trainer, Lucien Laurin, confirmed today that Riva Ridge would start in the 1mile race for 3yearolds.

title: A BLACK LEADER ASSAILS CONGRESS
description: ST. LOUIS, July 30  Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, in remarks prepared for, the league's 63d annual convention here today, was sharply critical of the Nixon Administration and Congress over such issues as busing, welfare reform and housing.

title: Advertising:
description: This year, for the first time since 1966, The New Yorker has been publishing issues with more pages of advertis ing than comparable issues in the previous year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 30In their moments of personal polit ical crisis, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton and thenSenator Rich ard M. Nixon went on national television to defend themselves against being dropped as Vice Presidential candidates.

title: NOVELLA NELSON ON SOUL PROGRAM
description: Soul at the Center's Sun day night program at Phil harmonic Hall finally drew the kind of audience this fine series deserves. No doubt the pro gramthe singers Novella Nel son and Donny Hathaway and the soul group Labellehad something to do with the fact that a large and enthusiastic houseful of listeners turned out for the show.

title: Conservatives Give 100% Rating to 10 Legislators
description: Ten state legislators  all with Conservative and Repub lican party backingwere given a 100 per cent rating by the New York State Conservative party, which gave the 1972 Legislature as a whole a rating of 78 per cent.

title: Colon Tops Pentathlon Field, Taking 4 of 5 Track Events
description: Tony Colon of New York won four of five events yester day to win a running pentathlon at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx conducted by the Road Runners Club of New York.

title: BLACKS MAY WIN MORE AUTONOMY
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 30The Government is prepared to consider conces sions to the people of Soweto, the black African township satellite of Johannesburg, that could give the people more powers of selfadministration.

title: STRATEGISTS FACE TREASURY OFFER
description: Credit Markets

title: Judyt Landstein Wed to James Mandel
description: Miss Judyt Landstein and James Mandel were married last night at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Landstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi Leon Fink performed the ceremony.

title: Webster Content With Loss ... Considering
description: All in all, the Giants were content with the way things went in Saturday's 2317 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs, played in the shadow of pro football's Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio.

title: ARTHUR DELSON
description: Arthur Karl Delson, a part ner in Edwards & Hanly, stock brokers, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 37 years old and lived at 241 Central Park West.

title: U.S. DIVERS PICKED FOR MUNICH GAMES
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) Mike Finneran compiled what was described as the only per fect powerdive score in major meet history in the platform event today as the United States Olympic diving trials ended.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Build on Parkland Upsets Tudor City
description: A group of residents of Tu dor City, angered by the own er's plans to build a new resi dential building on private park land in the area, has urged the City Planning Commission to set up a new zoning category that would forbid any construc tion on the site.

title: A Brief for the Pipeline
description: No greater challenge to the Ameri can process of democratic government will cafront us in the coming few years than finding a sane and sensible way of reconciling the often conflict ing requirements of adequate energy supplies and of environmental protec tion. The human and social costs of failing to find a wise balance between them are truly awesomeperhaps irreversible damage to the global en vironment on the one hand, and the interruption of human and social prog ress in the United States and to degree throughout the world on the other.

title: Cubs Replace Pizarro
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (AP)The Chicago Cubs announced yester day they had placed Juan zarro, lefthanded pitcher, on the 21day disabled list and re called Bill North, outfielder, from Wichita of the American Association.

title: Prague Views Trials as Last Step in Crushing Dissent
description: PRAGUE, July 30The cur rent trials of prominent sup porters of Alexander Dubcek, the former Communist leader, are intended by his successors to close a bitter chapter in Czechoslovak history.

title: Building Contracts Up to Peak $8.5Billion
description: The high level of residential building has pushed the total value of construction contracts to a record figure of $8,477, 640,000 in June, the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw Hill Information Systems Company reported over the weekend.

title: City to Test New Material To Foil Graffiti Artists
description: The city has a new plan to confound graffiti artistscoat ing public buildings with a spe cial spray or painton surface that is easily wiped clean.

title: ZarleyHiskey Win Team Golf on 262
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 30Ker mit Zarley and Bryant (Babe) Hiskey of Houston, who had never finished better than in a tie for 30th place, succeeded Arnold Palmer and Jack Nick laus today as the national team golf champions.

title: Trying to Untie Britain's TieUp Maurice Victor Macmillan
description: Man in the News

title: Shirley Caesar Teaches Gospel In a Running Sermon of Songs
description: The evangelist Shirley Caesar belted gospel hymns and danced in the frontrow aisle of Alice. Tully Hall yesterday in an exuberant service that marked the midway point of Soul at the Center, the two week black arts festival at Lincoln Center for the Perform ing Arts.

title: Cooper Takes Dutch Tennis
description: HILVERSUM, the Nether lands, July 30 (AP)  John Cooper of Australia won the singles title today in the Dutch international tennis champion ships, beating Hans Kary of Austria, 61, 36, 1210, 36, 62, in a threehour match.

title: Senator Critical of F.T.C. Drive For Judging Advertising Claims
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Senator Frank E. Moss said today that the Federal Trade Commission had revealed widespread and flagrant ab sence of adequate documenta tion for many claims by ad vertisers.

title: Dissident Mineworkers Campaigning With New' Strength and Confidence
description: SHENANDOAH, Pa., July 30  Shuck, a 66yearold retired miner, waited on a hill top corner to shake hands with Arnold Miller, a candidate for president of the, United Mine Workers of America.

title: U.N. WILL SPONSOR MARKETING CLINIC
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30A marketing clinic the first of its kindwill be held this fall to provide prac tical guidance to the underde veloped countries in how to tailor their products to con sumer tastes around the world.

title: Immunology: Doctors Use It in Fight Against Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, July 30In mice and guinea pigs, scientists have been able to make cancers diminish or even fade away by deliberately manipulating the animals' own natural immuno logic defenses.

title: But June Shows Lag in the Sales Index
description: The machine tool industry both new and used segments had strong firsthalf volume and may be headed for record highs for the full year, accord ing to figures released over the weekend.

title: Hot Summer
description: This is another of those deceptive occasions when, on the surface of things, a return to the past may seem like progress or sorts.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, July 30 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Rumania, a finalist at Wimbledon this year, won the singles title today at the Duesseldorf Rochus Club's tennis tournament. Nastase beat West Germany's Juergen Fassbender, 60, 62, 6.3, and earned $5,000. Fassbender received $3,000.

title: FreezeDrying Planned To Save Damaged Books
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) The 180,000 books damaged by tire and water at Temple University's Charles Klein Law Library will be freezedried like cof fee in an attempt to save them, according to the school librarian, Edward C. Sur rency.

title: Roundup: Killebrew Near 2 Sluggers
description: Harmon Killebrew of the Minnesota Twins should soon become the second leading homerun hitter in American League history. The muscular first baseman yesterday wal loped the 533d homer of his career (his 18th this season) to give the Twins a 10 tri umph over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Soviet Is Pressing the Blending of Its 100 Nationalities
description: MOSCOW, July 30After 50 years of trying to knit its more than 100 ethnic groups into a single society, the Soviet Union appears to have made great gains in the educational and cultural development of its nationalities. But it remains well short of the ultimate goal of total harmony.

title: The Screen: James Dickey's Deliverance Arrives
description: James Dickey, who won the 1965 National Book Award for poetry and pub lished his first novel, Deliv erance, in 1970, has been described as a poet con cerned primarily with the di rect impact of experience.

title: The Sudanese Defection
description: Although President Sadat of Egypt continues to casti gate the United States despite his dramatic loosening of ties with the Soviet Union, his efforts to forge a united Arab front against Washington suffered a further set back last week. The Sudan's decision to restore diplomatic ties with this country marked the second defection in a monthYemen was the firstfrom the ranks of Arab states that broke relations with the United States during the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Enough Rabbits
description: When President Nixon flew to Peking and Moscow there was euphoric elation by some writers and there were dire predictions by others. This was particularly true regarding the Peking trip. How do the trips look in retro spect?

title: Personalities: A New Champion
description: Amid controversy over tactics and the referee, the new world bantamweight boxing champion, Enrique Pinder, left yesterday from Panama City to visit the shrine of his patron saint, Martin de Porres, in Lima, Peru. Pinder dethroned Rafael Herrera of Mexico with a 15round decision Saturday night in Panama City. Pinder, a former jockey, admitted that I escaped dan ger, moving away and grab bing at the Mexican. That angered Herrera's manager, Jesus (Chuco) Cuate, who said, A fight is won by punching and not by running around the ring and embrac ing the champion. Cuate also accused the referee, Waldemar Schmidt, a Puerto Rican, of favoritism. Said Schmidt: Only a prejudiced and desperate mind can rea son that way.

title: Unfreezing Low Wages
description: The Government's effort to halt the inflationary spiral will undoubltedly be complicated by the decision to push the lowwage exemption so high that well over half the country's workers are now outside the control program.

title: Isaac, Piloting a Dodge, Is Victor at 70.208 M.P.H.
description: HICKORY, N. C., July 30 (UPI)Bobby Isaac raced to the front at the start and held the lead for all but 12 laps to day to win the Buddy Shuman Memorial NASCAR Grand Na tional East stock car race.

title: Navy Blue Angel Injured
description: KINSTON, N. C., July 30 (AP) The flight commander of the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team escaped serious in jury today by ejecting from his fighter plane as it was landing, moments before it skidded down a runway and struck a pickup truck. The pilot, Lieut. Comdr. Donald Bently, 32 years old, of Seattle, was thrown about 100 feet into the air and his parachute was fully open when he came down on the runway. He was treated for scraped knees and a broken toe.

title: Cooking With American Products to Achieve a French Taste
description: Two Parisian restaura teurs, Michel Oliver and Main Senderens, flew home yesterday, ready to trans late a dream into reality.

title: J.W.T. Picks Overseas Director
description: Don Johnston has been named an executive vice president of J. Walter Thomp son and put in charge of its international operation 34 offices with billings of $355million. He replaces Tom Sutton who had the job for seven years and who at his own request has been named chief executive officer of JWTJapan.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: ENDGAMES, Attacks & Openings of Masters. Perramon Chess Books. Any BooksellerAdvt.

title: Four Guerrillas Are Killed During Iranian Police Raid
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 (AP)  Four leftist guerrillas were killed and one was in jured in shooting during a po lice raid on a house in down. town Teheran yesterday, the Iranian police reported today.

title: CITIBANK TO ACQUIRE UPSTATE INSTITUTION
description: The First National City Cor poration announced agreement to acquire the $16.4million Central Valley National Bank, Central Valley, N. Y. yesterday. The acquisition is part of a series of such deals by First National City and other large New York City bankholding companies to acquire small bank outside the metropolitan area in preparation for state wide branch banking in 1976.

title: Eagleton Replacement Being Considered
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Anticipating a new search for a VicePresidential nominee. Senator George McGovern's staff members said today that they were consideringanum ber of urbanbased Roman Catholic politicians as possible replacements for Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Mis souri. The name of Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic Na tional Chairman until two weeks ago, ranked high on virtually every list.

title: Steel Industry Is Bullish; Orders and Scrap Prices Up
description: PITTSBURGH, July 30Steel producers were looking at some bullish numbers last week.

title: Average Hospital Care Cost Rose to $92 a Day in 1971
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) The cost of caring for a hospi tal patient for one day aver aged $92.31 in 1971, an in crease of 13.9 per cent, the American Hospital Association reported today. The 1970 aver age was $81.01, an increase of 15.7 per cent over the previous year.

title: Scott Wins 35andOver Title
description: MANHASSET, L.I., July 30  Topseeded Gene Scott of New York defeated Dr. Richard Ras kind of New York, 63, 61, to day to win the men's 35year andover national clay court tennis championship at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: Books of The Times
description: I've culled these sentences at random from The Taxi, by Violette Leduc. It is a classically contemporary novel, depicting, through the kind of dialogue quoted above, the lovemaking, in a taxi, of a 16yearold French boy and his sister, 14. They are not making love impetuously or spontaneously, seized by an irresistible impulse: They've planned this for several months.

title: WILLIAM WEIDBERG
description: William Weidberg, a member of the New York law firm of Lesser & Weidberg, died Satur day at his home, 1041 East Fifth Street, Brooklyn. He was 66 years old.

title: Stage:Of Mice and Men
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 All good plays age well, but some good plays age unex pectedly well. These are often just plays that at their time of writing seemed the most contemporary and, therefore, the most evanes cent. In these particular in stances the passing of time takes the emphasis off their immediacy and permits their more lasting values to be seen more clearly.

title: Ryun Sheds a Problem As He Wins 3:52.8 Mile
description: TORONTO, July 30 (AP) The opposition didn't concern me. When you're concentrating all you're worrying about is running to the best of your ability, said Jim Ryun after he ran a sparkling 3:52.8 mile in the Metro Toronto Police games last night.

title: 10,000 at Newark Parade
description: NEWARK, July 30 (AP) More than 10,000 spectators and a reviewing stand of vote seekers watched the bands and floats of the 10th annual Puer to Rican Day Parade today. The queen of the parade was Evelyn Martinez of Paterson, this year's Miss Puerto Rico of New Jersey.

title: Richard B. Felder Weds Miss Slater
description: Miss Deborah Slater and Richard Bruce Felder were married at noon yesterday in the St. RegisSheraton. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: HOME LOAN BOARD DISCLOSES OPTION
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed over the week end that it had invited appli cations from mutual, that is, depositorowned, savings and loan associations to convert to statechartered capital stock associations.

title: SCOTT PEELS G.O.P. CAN CONTROL SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott said today that Republican chances of taking control of the Senate have been hurt by the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s de cision to stay neutral in the Presidential election and con centrate on electing Democrats to Congress.

title: Yankees Lose, 50, and Drop to 500 Again
description: BALTIMORE, July 30It took a little more than 24 hours and a short trip here for the Yan kees to become a 500 bail club again.

title: Bridge: Three Teams Gain Big Leads In Spingold QuarterFinals
description: DENVER, July 30  Three bridge teams piled up big leads tonight in the quarter finals of the Spingold knock out team championship in the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Agee Homers as Mess Defeat Expos, 31
description: The good news is that Tom mie Agee started a game for the first time in three weeks and hit a home run for the first time in two months. The bad news is that Jim Fregosi re placed him on sick call with a strained right knee.
